And with 9% ABV it does the same for you as the 6 pk of the 60 min IPA which offers 6% ABV. Bottom line: if you appreciate IPAs and their complexities, you absolutely will not go wrong with this beer.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2014 Bottle. Pours a deep amber with a good finger of off white head. Aroma is full on hops! Strong, dry, piney hops and a good bit of malt. Lasting bitterness and a good amount of alcohol.. Wonderful beer, but not excatly my favorite hop profile.
user_location: Menasha Red Light District, Wisconsin, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 26, 2016 Poured from tap into 10oz flute. Pleasant and mild aroma consisting mostly of hops and grass (maybe more floral than grassy) but I could pick up whiffs of citrus (orange mostly), and mild butter/caramel. It pours sparkling golden-orange with nice finger-width, slightly off-white, head consisting of evenly sized small bubbles. This pour had the benefit of a glass which must?ve had etching on the bottom - there was a constant stream of carbonation feeding the head, giving it a presence throughout the drink (New Holland High Gravity flute), and leaving a nice lacing around the glass by the end. Even in a plastic glass, the head retention is generous, creamy, and fluffy and has a lot of sheet lace. The taste is a balanced medium high, citrus bittersweet. It?s a nice, medium body, a bit sticky with a mild hop flavor lingering. The constant head gives it the benefit of being creamy and frothy throughout, but it doesn?t feel fizzy at all. Its a medium body, a bit sticky, thats creamy and thick but also smooth with flavors of bread toast, biscuit, and caramel with some citrus. There?s a reason Dogfish Head gets so much credit for their beers, and this is a shining example of how to make and Imperial IPA without over-doing any aspect of it.
Rating based on notes from some time ago... Bottle. Golden amber pour. Malty with lighter hops than expected on the nose. Malty flavour, boozy, with a hint of bourbon and sweet caramel. Fabulous IPA.

From the archives: Second best from the beers that I managed to try when I was in US *(North Coast Old Rasputin Russian Imperial Stout being nr1). I needed to take a chair, and get a proper glass once I opened the bottle. Malty, hoppy and bitter to the max; yet enjoyable and refreshing. One bottle is absolutely enough for the evening. Superb brew.

Amber beer with a three finger high head that leaves a lot of lacing on the glass. 
Nose: Tropical fruit, mango, pineapple, pine, citrus and grapefruit. 
Taste: Sweet taste of orange, pineapple and malt. Full body and light carb. Great!

Poured to new Belgium globe. 
Bottled 11/2010. Also drinking a 11/2009 just to compare.

A: gloden amber ale. No head development. Decent foam production of bubbles on surface which hug the edge. Decent spotty lacing

S: piney hops, caramel malt. Spicy. Some citrus. Nice

T: bitter with good balance of malt. Hops shine well in this. Great balance. 

M: medium body with moderate carb. Leaves mouth both dry and slick. Nice. 

D: could drinkt this all night without issue.

Serving type: bottle

02-21-2011

Heavy floral and hoppy aroma slightly bready. Bright golden appearance. Medium bodied palate, creamy for an IPA, light carbonation. Great bitterness, leaves the palate dry. Fades into a nutty, toasty, bread aftertaste. Long finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

On draft. Hadn?t had one of these in a long while. Seemed surprisingly one-note: Sweet citrus, high register alcohol, sweet caramel malts... and not much more. Reminds me of a circa 2006 DIPA before brewers figured out how to add some nuance?

On tap @ Birreria, NY. Clear amber color with 1 finger thick creamy off-white head, nice lacing and sparkling appearance. Aroma of pine and citrus hops, caramel malt and dried fruits. Tastes of sweet bready and caramel malt accompanied by subtle alcohol warmth, while quickly overpowered by long and heavy bitterness. Full body, thick texture and fizzy carbonation in palate. Forgive me, my rating is biased as appearance is worth of 4, aroma of 9, but my first soooooo desired visit of Birreria temporarily ruined my taste buds :)

Insanely balanced imperial ipa. Poured from bottle a smooth copper color with a thin lasting white head. Nose of citrus and pine. Not overly dry mouth feel balanced well with biscuity malts. Tasted of grapefruit, raisins, and grass.
Orange-gold pour with decent white head and good lacing. Huge hoppy aroma - citrus, pine, toffee, slightly boozy. Taste is grapefruit, pine needles, caramel, a little alcohol warmth. Fantastic

Bottle pour into crystal goblet. Amazballs! Best beer to touch my taste buds! The score is too low, this reapply is some goodness. From the lace it leaves on the sides of the glass to The creaminess I feel on my cheeks. 100% all the way for sure!

On tap at Dan's. The pour is a dark orangey gold. With a nice filmy head and a bit of good lace. The aroma is very hoppy with great citrusy grapefruit notes and a bit of earthiness to it. The flavor is very much the same. The grapefruit and piney tastes dominate a good solid hoppiness. The mouth feel is good, and it lingers just a perfect amount before fading away to nothing. Solid.

Growler @ home. Pours orange with a white head. Aroma is citrus, pine, hoppy, earthy. Flavor is dank, earthy, pine, citrus, grapefruit. Pretty nice.

A product of the American idea that theres nothing like too much of a good thing, this beer is a failure on most counts. The bitterness is so overpowering that you might as well be eating hop salad. The aroma is reduced to nil, the palate is astringent to a level you feel might kill your tastebuds and the carbonation is so off-balance it gives the beer a sorry look. To blast all this away it is brewed to an overpowering 9% strength. A typical beer for the braggard brewer; and as if this wasnt enough, Dogfish went on to brew an even worse 120 Minute, and will undoubtedly soon be producing 360, 720, and 1440 minute varieties. Still, I like the Dogfish label artwork.
Very good a little bitter but love the taste has very high quality in alcohol percentage

You can taste the malts. Slightly sweet. One if the most balanced IIPAs I?ve had. Very smooth beer. Could drink way to many any of these. Pretty light but very flavorful. Waited a long time to try this beer. Not disappointed. - UPDATE: I finally finished my 4 pack.  With every bottle I drank, the less I liked it.  Not sure why.  The bottle on date was late October of 2013, so it shouldnt have been getting old yet.  I would say Ive had many many IIPAs that were better than this.  Would now probably not buy again.
UPDATED: MAY 3, 2014 Great copper-orange color. Light head when poured. Inviting hippy, bitter aroma. Love the citrus finish on the aroma. Great bitterness without being too much. Great choice!!

One of the best beers out there, second to the DFH 120 minute IPA. Does not taste like your chewing hops.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 19, 2014 This is a rerate. Fresh bottle brought from the states to ozland. Salted caramel and peanut aroma. Sweet maltyl taste, big on spice hops. Decent pour, fine texture head. Rose gold colour. A little sweet for me but a very different IPA.

Aroma: sweet, rich hops, hints of citrus. Appearance: hazy amber, white head. Taste: quite sweet. Palate: malts again, alcohol noticeable. Overall: a bomb - love it. Pint at Gordon Ramsey Pub&Grill, Las Vegas.

Pours off white head. Massive aroma of hops. Tastes rather sweet, with a good hit of hops and the malt backbone showing through, a bit of alcohol creeping in. Real smooth mouthfeel, and a lasting malt flavour.

Visuellement très claire. Belle mousse qui colle. Au nez, des notes de malt et de noix. En bouche on sent que du houblon a bel et bien été choisi comme ingrédient important, mais on est loin dune hop bomb! En fait, cest une bière plutôt vraiment très, très bien balancée. Elle séloigne dune IPA fruitée et raffraichissante mais vise plutôt un style qui se veut à la fois très riche mais aussi très équilibré. 

En fait, à laveugle, je ne suis même pas certain que jaurais détecté que cette bière se voulait une IPA! Par contre, jaurais définitivement détecté que cest une bonne bière... Une excellente bière.

Ar: Moss and orange - a bit of peach.
Ap: Clear orange-amber - medium-small off-white head with moderate-low retention - leaves a ring of fine foam bubbles, some film.
T: Big tangy orange citrus flavor, juicy tangerine - medium sweetness - some herbal accents, with high bitterness - finish is lemon and orange, with a clean lingering bitterness.
P: Medium body with high carbonation - finish is dry.
O: Nice 2XIPA - the aroma is very subdued, but the flavor is robust, with a clean bitterness and smooth alcohol.

Pours a slightly hazed amber/light copper color with good thick head. Aroma is slight roasted caramel malts and some citrucy Sweet pine hop notes and a underlining chocolate note. Some lingering hop resin Noticable great malt backbone. Slight mango fruit note. Medium mouth feel. Very good! Earlier Rating: 8/31/2012 Total Score: 4.2Sunburst gold color, floral Carmel malty hoppy aroma. Very smooth medium to heavy body. Floral citrucy Hoppy butterscotch sweet malt flavor. On the sweet side. Very smooth palate! Slight Alcohol taste. Very good beer!

A: Dark amber with a head of about 2 inches and a nice thin lace. 

A: Flowery with a subtle pine and citrus. The scent is really inviting.

T: A rich blend of pine, citrus (grapefruit), and bread with a hint of something sweet at the end. 

M: Very full and silky followed by a nice crisp bite at the end. Feels like a good scotch and leaves you wanting more.

The is a solid beer by all standards. The hops really come through but are not overpowering, and this lacks the strong bitterness that turns some away from "hoppy" beers. It has really complex flavors and aroma, and the high ABV is not apparent in the taste, which makes this a great beer for sipping. I like serving in lightly chilled bottle,and drink slowly to really enjoy its depth.
Deep red, gold colour. Full, rich pour with good head. Attractive malty nose. Citrus, strong tastes. Slightly astringent alcohol tones but a beer that is refreshingly assertive on the palette.
Very flowery and bitter aroma. Tastes of very different hops. Spicy but round and flowery.
Orange amber coloured brew. Decent head. Complex brew, grassy and citrussy. Some grass, sweet and sour fruits. Nice moderated and soft bitterness.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2014 Deep reddish gold color. Aroma: hop leaves, raisins,lemon & some yeast. The malty sweetness coats the mouth, very nice balance with the hoppy finish. Light carbonation. This is a tremendous beer.
Bärnstensfärgad med mellanstort vit skum som fastnar på glaset! Massor med humle i doft och smak! Bra kolsyrad fast lite mycket alkohol i smaken! Dracks i New York!

Bottle into a ale glass. Pour is a amber gold with a thick head. Aroma is straight sweet spring bitter grass. Taste is heavy malt and sweet hop. Finish is a wash of tastes and feels. This is a great ipa, one of the best.

Pours an orange copper with a finger of off white head. Aromas of grapefruit hop bitterness. Alcohol also present on the nose. Citrus hop flavors up front with alcohol lingering slightly. Finishes nicely balanced with malt notes. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

If you love hops, this beer has you covered. Nice copper color with a thick tan head.
 It is a bit boozy for a daily drinker.. It is a good way to start a great night of drinking high quality beers

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle @ døe meeting. Clear amber, small white head that quickly disappear, some lacing. Aroma, malty, hoppy, sweet, piney, grapefruit, honey fruity. Taste, malty, hoppy bitter, piney, citrus, sweet, honey. Slightly oily mouth feel. Bitter aftertaste.

"Not at all what I thought it was. Too malty. No citrus aftertaste, just the lingering of malt. Probably wont buy it again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone"

This sums it up perfectly. The only highly regarded IPA/IIPA I completely disagree with.

Not at all what I thought it was. Too malty. No citrus aftertaste, just the lingering of malt. Probably won't buy it again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A: not the hop bomb smell I was expecting. It is as though there is something stopping the aroma from escaping. The smell is there but it is faint. A: this baby is gorgeous. Very clean and clear pour with a great long lasting head that leaves lacing a stripper would be jealous of. T: wow. Nice balanced taste between sweet and malt. Tastes of honey and grapefruit and alcohol. Extremely smooth. P: sticky mouthfeel with a great bitter finish. O: this is one of the best tasting beers I have had. The only knock on it is the weak aroma but its a MUST try.

Unlike most things like claim to be the best of something, this beer actually lives up to the hype

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Really good beer, just the right amount of bitterness and maltiness. Could smell orange.
(bottle 20/11-2013) Low beige head, clear orange color, very smooth hoppy taste, good balance between bitterness and sweetness, hoppy aroma, soft co2, full body, hop candy. Bottled 06/19/13.
Smooth great taste. No funky after taste. One of my top 2 favorite beers. Off tap nothing better.

Great east coast DIPA, poured from a bottle into a Dogfish IPA glass. Poured amber with a reddish hint. Smell floral, hoppy and a hint of honey. Taste was slightly sweet, hoppy, great balance. Love this beer and keep a few around all the time.

Incredibly smooth and easy drinking for a 9% IIPA. The alcohol is quite strong in the aroma but less so in the tasting. Theres strong aromas of pine and peach, while in the mouth that peach and honey malt combines with really prominent but subtle hops. My only criticism is that its a little sweeter than Id ideally like, but this is a beautiful beer.

Not as good as I remember. Very sweet. Sticky mouthfeel. Nice hop flavor, little bit of pine and citrus. Not very bitter finish. Malt is there and appreciate the balance for a dipa, but doesnt do a whole lot for me.
UPDATED: FEB 14, 2014 Caramel color, not much head, aroma of citrus, warm bread and dried fruit. Taste of cereal, dried apricots, with a slightly bitter palate of citrus zest
UPDATED: DEC 7, 2013 First time with this beer. Was very good. Nutty flavor. This was part of a sample that I tried.

Wow wow wow. I love this beer. From the first time having it to it now being old hat, this is a great beer. I love that brews like this, unique and bold, are making it to mainstream markets. If you dont like this beer there is something wrong with YOU. It IS that good.

Bottled on 2013-06-19. Clear orange with a medium sized creamy off white head. Good lace and retention. Sweet tropical fruits - persimmon like, light citrus, pine, bread, caramel, spicy hops, residual sugar. Taste is medium sweet with some bitterness to balance it, but pretty mild for the style. Medium/full body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Hardly any bitterness in the finish, very mellow and soft, no alcohol showing. Really nice.

Bottle pour, clear copper, not a very significant head. Smells botanical, obviously lots of hops but not overtly citrus or pine like other imperial IPAs. Taste definitely has sweet fruits alongside the strong bitters. Can pick out the barley as well, smooths out the hops nicely. Quality IPA, not what I was expecting, Id probably say its better.

Bottle: Light amber with a hint of red or copper. Clear and good light white head. Very lifted. Clean. No piney resin. Malt dominates. Caramel, cream, touch of brown spice and then the underlying hops with fruit and just a touch of floral or spice. Off dry dim sweet. Not sour but certainly bitter. Its certainly balance. Creamy palate. Very rich,dense and long. Massive hop driven fruit flavors. 
Guess this is a classic East Coast DIPA. Very different from the California DIPAs. This is a great and I find it more approachable than West Coast IPA.
Pours clear amber with small off-white head. Clear aroma of hops and malt, with touches of grain. Sweetish, malty grainy and hoppy flavour. Malty aftertaste. A nice DIPA, although rather rough.

355 ml bottle @ home. Color is bronze with a 2 finger off white head. Aroma is sweet with honey, orange and pine. Taste is really smooth with orangepeel, honey and some spruce. The abv is well hidden. Nice one!
Thank you bernard. Solid DIPA. Beautiful look and amazing aroma. Flavours are big and balanced. A real joy to drink and a must for DIPA lovers.

I was disappointed in this beer. Aroma was lacking, appearance was cloudy with visible particles floating in the beer. I thought it was cloying, and unbalanced. I expected a more hop forward beer, but the hops take a back seat to the malt sweetness. Taste was accurate to the commercial description, "brandied fruitcake, raisiney, citrusy", with some tropical fruit also. Alcohol presence was subdued which was nice, despite it being 9% Alc. by Vol., overall I thought this beer was overly sweet.

Bottle. Dark yellow with a small yellow-white head. Aroma is mild with grapefruit and pine. 

Taste has wood, some malt with a light piny grainy body. Very smooth mouthfeel with the alcohol very well hidden. Pleasant bitter aftertaste. Really good for casual consumption.

A: Golden Straw/Mild Amber Hue, Passes Most Light, White Head, Great Lacing

S: Floral, Sweet Bread, Mild Resin

T: Sweet Bread, Floral, Mild Resin, Mild Crackers

M: Great Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet, Mildly Drying

Overall, the maltiness is a little sweet and the hops kind of get buried in the background but overall good.

Nice and hoppy (obviously). With the high ABV its not a sessionable type of beer (for me anyway), but this is a great go-to. Very well balanced with the citrus, hops and malt. Clean finish on the palate.

Sample from bottle @sbwf13 (finally got to try this one). Copper color with white head. Aroma with lots of hops; grass, pine, citrus, earth and fruits. Also some caramel and alcohol. Taste is similar, massive hop notes with earth, pine, resin, herbs, pepper, flowers with added caramel and alcohol.

FROM NOTES: July 1, 12
From a 12 ounce bottle into a DFH glass. 

A: Holy hops, Batman! The strong hop nose dominates, but there is some definite malty sweetness apparent. I almost smell some honey, but I could be imagining it..... 
A: Pours a semi-hazy deep golden brown color with a one finger head that retains and laces very well. Tons of carbonation constantly drifting up the glass.
T: Complex and interesting in a fantastic beer way! While dominant, the hop profile doesnt overpower like most Double IPAs, perhaps due to the malty sweetness that follows the initial hop bitterness. A faint alcohol burn precedes the hoppy, bitter finish. 
P: Sticky and chewy, maybe even oily. The taste camps on the palate establishing all of the flavor. While this is thicker than most, the hop profile demands that it be, lest it be unbalanced. 
O: While I am not a hop psycho, the overall flavor of this beer is excellent. I am not impressed with a DIPA that over-loads the hops without balance, and this beer offers that balance that should go with such a large DIPA hop profile. If ever there was a DIPA that you could drink a few of, THIS IS IT!
Gentle, but also aggressive in its hoppiness and flavor profile. Poured well, with a mild but distinct aroma. Lots of citrus and malt, and definitely a great imperial I.P.A.

Bottle @ Taco Mac cumming. Pours a clear amber with a thick frothy white head. Tons of sticky lacing. Aroma of sweet malts, citrus and floral hops, and pine hops. Taste just like it smells, caramel malts, citrus, pine,and a bit of roastiness. Smooth creamy texture. Very enjoyable!
Surprising. Made me interested in IPAs again. Floral aroma with no overpowering bitterness. Probably balanced with dark or caramel malts. Beautiful!

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2014 I have had this beer a number of times before and have always loved it. Pours medium amber color with an off-white head. Some lacing. Citrus aroma. Taste is hoppy, though balanced with a big malty sweetness. On re-rating, I note that it has characteristics like a barleywine - there is a huge maltiness here. Definitely one of my favorites.

Safer territory vs some of the other hyper agressive beers in this style category. Which I think makes this better representation on the imperial ipa style. Not all hops but jacked up malt presence as we. Top of class to my taste

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a a light brown with a Nice rich hoppy smoky aroma. Mild citrus with a rich nutty flavor. Unique IPA

Not your usual IPA. Dark amber color. Very smooth with a more malt taste then hop taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Generally not a huge fan of IPAs, but this one made me reconsider my position on them, serving as a gateway to trying even more of them in the future (as well as consuming more of this particular brew).

I had previously tried the 60-minute IPA from Dogfish Head and it didnt really convince me as a thing Id love to drink, as I felt the hops were kind of overwhelming (though if you love hops that drink is probably great for you). However, I quite enjoyed the 90-minute IPA as I felt it much better balanced the hops by also mixing in a lot of barley, and it ended up one of the first IPAs to truly wow me and turn me from a skeptic of that style into a believer.

So, if youre like me and are generally not too into IPAs, definitely give this one a try to see if it can convince you otherwise. Excellent price for the taste too!

UPDATED: APR 23, 2014 Bottle: Dense, hazy, golden-yellow & copper with a nice white head that lasts as a thin film and leaves great lacing behind. Aroma is full of hops, hop oils, flowers, pines, roots, citrus, grapefruit, tangerines, earth, mild alcohol, & a bit of toasted malt sweetness. Taste contains plenty more pines, pine needles, herbs, light white pepper, florals, earthy esters, grapefruit peels, orange zest, and a pronounced finish of sweet malt. Great hop flavor & aroma profile, but I just wish for a little let malt sweetness (it can wear on you quite quickly). Thick mouth feel & body. A good DIPA, but one that I often find is a little too sweet for me to call "great". I prefer 60 minute for its drinkability & dryness.
Hands down one of my favorite IPAs... Extra smooth, not hoppy. Dont think itll last 90 Minutes. Enjoy

The 90 Minute pours a mostly clear sunset orange with an off-white head that lasts and leaves nice lacing. The aroma is citrus with raisin. The flavor is a nice balance of citrus and raisin. Overall this brew is delicious.
Excellent hop aroma and taste. Goes down smooth and nice balance. One of the most enjoyable beers readily available.

Bottle.Copper colour with medium head.Aroma of barley malt and fruitcake,hint of rye and hops,feels Warming and well balanced with oily texture and sweet malty and fruity taste,long and well balanced finish.

Bottle from Voldby. Hazy orange with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and moderate hoppy - grapefruit. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish with warming alcohol. 191013

(355 cl bottle from Kihoskh; Bottled on June 19th 2013 15:22) I realise this one is probably way past its prime but short of jet set IP trades this is the most common age of American beer in Copenhagen and having heard so much positive about this beer and its family members I decided to sideline my usual preference for freshness in hop-forward beers. This one pours a clear amber with creamy, white head. Good retention and lace. Aroma is fruity sodapop hops with a slight hint of caramel malt. Oily texture, medium carbonation, full body and a dry, astringent and warming finish. Flavour is complex and balanced with initial impressions of citrus fruit followed by malty sweetness and hop notes and some final alcohol and bitterness.

Awesome beer. I never go wrong with this choice. Expensive 4 pack, but great for a relaxing night

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

355 ml. bottle poured in to a snifter. Clear, deep orange colour with a dense, off-white head. Fruity aroma with citrus, resin and floral hops, caramel and chocolate malts. The aromas linger long after the bottle is empty. Taste is sweet. Full body with creamy, bordering thicker texture. Carbonation is almost flat, the beer could easily use a little bit more "soft" carbonation. Long lasting dry and bitter finish with lots of floral and citrus hops, backed by a hearty amount of malts. Excellent DIPA, well balanced and lots of hops aromas.

Poured from 12 fl oz bottle. Clear light copper brown with off-white head. Caramel malty, sweet aroma with mild resiny hops and mild heavy bread. Sweet malt flavour with very balanced hops to fill it out. Slightly oily texture.
Incredible taste of Imperial IPA. This beer turns upside down all you knew about IPA before. Extreme hoppy flavor. Strong bitter aftertaste.

Bottle from Mitsuyas Liqour @ Asagaya, Tokyo. Pours nice brown with a small keeping head. Aroma is full, malty, cheesecake. Taste is very balanced, hops are not at your face but combine well with the sweeter maltiness and fruitiness of the drink. Aftertaste is pleasant, some dry bitterness remains for long after everything else is gone. Great beer, living up to its reputation!
A nice hoppy double IPA. Very sticky and fruity. Would definitely drink again.
Again one of my top 10s. You cant go wrong with a Dogfish IPA. Great beer for summer and BBQ or just alone in a frosty mug.

Awesome beer. Delicious from start to finish. Sam is a genius. Awesome beer. Delicious from start to finish. Sam is a genius. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught @ The Ginger Man, NYC. Pours clear amber with small off-white head. Clear aroma of hops and malt, with touches of grain. Sweetish, malty grainy and hoppy flavour. Malty aftertaste. A nice DIPA, although rather rough.

Bottle. Finally!!!! Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. not as powerfull as hoped but nice citrus/mango notes. Heavy bitter wonderfull balanced flavor. Long great finish. Creamy palate. Wonderfull beer.
Bottle pour a few months back. Dogfish knows IPAs and this one might be my fav of theirs. The mellow malt taste with the high hop taste makes this a delight to drink.
2/20/2010. From bottle. Dark amber color with a white head. Malty aromas with hops, citrus, resins, caramel and flowers. Very well made and one of the best DIPAs out there.

Bottle, 355 ml. Hazy golden, snall off white head. Toffee, karamel, bread, spicy herbal hops. Abricots, orange zest. Sweet and bitter. Lovely balance. Quite some body, but alcohol well hidden. More Zen than extreme, more prog than punk. Most of all: Eclectic. Personal. Good.
Not my favorite but very drinkable, more bitterness than tropical fruit from the hops. Very well balanced.

Pours caramel but you can smell the hops as soon as bottle opened. Strong malty flavour with a caramel taste. Not for faint-hearted. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Brown gold with a white head. Nose is dominated by caramel malt. Taste is strong caramel malt, balanced very well with pine hop. Nice.

Pours a mildly hazy orange-golden color with a two-finger beige head. A good balance of creamy malt and hop on the nose in spite of its aggressive hoppiness. Full body and lubricating with some hop heat and carbonation sting. Feels pleasant. Flavors of table sugar, grassy, citrusy hops, and faint alcohol.
Flaska från Kihoskh, Köpenhamn. Söt doft. Även smaken är söt, men man hittar också citrus, karamell och grape. Fyllig med en tilltagande beska. En riktigt god, välbalanserad DIPA!

Bottled. Pale copper in color with a tannish head. Light fruity, quite the sweet aroma, some marzipan, feels a bit boozy even at times. Flavor is also a bit sweetish boozy with some grassy bitterness lying underneath. Unfortunately it feels a bit boozy for the moment and this is making it quite hard to drink. Gets a bit better towards the finnish though.

355ml bottle as a gift brought home from Virginia:
Strong pine hop aroma with some oily bits & lots of bitterness. Some floral notes, caramel and sweet malts with citrus too. Almost no alcohol is noticeable.

Bright amber with a 2cm, foamy head that holds great and leaves some good lacing on the glass.

Bitter pine hops, grapefruit, citrus with sweet malts & caramel. Alcohol is well hidden and beer is a bitter one but not overpowering.

Bitter and smooth with a medium to full body, great balance & alcohol is well hidden. Carbonation is perfect with a good citrus tang. Excellent stuff.

An outstanding beer from start to finish. It looked & smelled great but tasted pretty much perfect with a great mix of sweet caramel malts and bitter hops with the usual citrus and grapefruit flavours coming through as well. The only negative about this beer is that it isnt available in the UK and Ill have to wait far too long before I get to try it again.

Bottle. Cooper with a white head. Aroma is pungent hops and caramel malt. Taste adds a chocolaty malt note up front and lots of tropical fruit in the finish. Full smooth mouthfeel. Haven't had this in years and I'm pleasantly surprised by this.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2013 Bottle from acland cellars. Another lifeless grey market dogfish beer. Will try again when in USA later this year. Will re rate then. 

Re rate, tap at pub 1842, MGM grand Las Vegas. Poured a light orange with a small thick white head. Nice head retention. Nose is upfront bread malts. Loads of floral grassy hops and almost herbal flavours creep in. Great balance. Taste is again a nice balance of the grassy hops - not getting much fruit...more of a dry pine/floral bitterness. Touch of sweetness from the strong bread malt presence rounds it out nicely. Booze is felt fuck me. Much better fresh here in the USA!!!
Bottle. Malt and pine aroma. Pines, dried fruit, malt, hop flavor. Medium body and medium carbonation. Pretty smooth. Very solid beer. Could use more citrus.

Bottle from Total Wine Summerlin, Las Vegas. Clear deep golden pour, thin white head. Aroma is full of heavy hops, resin, pine, but also balanced by a load of heavy malts with some biscuits and caramel. Flavor is bitter citrus fruits, caramel and spicy with a slightly boozy finish. Expected more, but its definitely a good beer.

12oz bottle. Deep amber. Pine and deep dark fruit on the nose, thick sweet caramel, touch of citric grapefruity zing too. Taste gives plenty of pine and caramel, red fruits, pithy grapefruit, more sweet caramel. Decent pine bitterness. Sweetish finish - caramel and sweet red fruit takes over. Not how I like my DIPAs, but it's a tasty American strong ale.
Decent IPA, a good standard. This was a hoppy IPA with a fair amount of bitterness, but not so much as to overpower the flavor. It definitely wasnt my favorite, but overall a good solid brew.
One of my top 10 all time favorite beers! Big taste, big alcohol content! Highly recommended for IPA fans, or those wanting to experience an awesome IPA!!! Cheers ;)

One of my favorite IPAs that is even relatively easy to find at most craft beer and whole foods. The complex nature of many different tones make it an enjoyable IPA. While Im still waiting to find the 120 min IPA this one sets the standard from Dogfish head.

Bottle, 1 week old. Clear amber pour, white head and irregular lacing. Aroma: herbal, medicinal, resiny, oniony, dank, almost cheesy. Hints of underlying sweetness behind that pungent wall of (not entirely pleasant) hop aroma. Does not bode well for the next stage .... Taste: loads of sweet, caramel and brown sugar, which carries the bitter embodiment of the aroma on its back. Palate: slick, nearly syrupy texture, full body, average carbonation. Overall: for such a highly-rated, established classic, I'm surprised by how much I dislike this. Hope the alcohol catches up with me fast enough that I can get past this taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(bottle) pours a murky golden-amber colour with a frothy white head. aroma of heavy resin, banana, caramelized apples, white chocolate and light herbal hops. flavour is mostly the same, though quite earthy and grainy, with a hint of apricots and a light meatiness in the medium-bitter finish. heavy-bodied with average carbonation.

*12 oz. Bottle* Look: Golden amber body, small white head. Smell: Herbal, earthy, dense floral, vanilla sweetness. Taste: Candied oranges, marmalade, hints of cedar, floral, mild citric rind, doughy sweetness, alcohol, semi-dry bitter finish. Feel: Medium smooth body, active carbonation. Overall: One of the sweetest DIPAs Ive had. It is like a dessert IPA. Not a bad thing, I just need a sweet tooth to be able to enjoy all the qualities it offers. This brew is worthy.Earlier Rating: 9/15/2013 Total Score: 3.7*12 oz. Bottle* Look: Golden amber body, small white head. Smell: Herbal, earthy, dense floral, vanilla sweetness. Taste: Candied oranges, marmalade, hints of cedar, floral, mild citric rind, doughy sweetness, alcohol, semi-dry bitter finish. Feel: Medium smooth body, active carbonation. Overall: One of the sweetest DIPAs Ive had. It is like a dessert IPA. Not a bad thing, I just need a sweet tooth to be able to enjoy all the qualities it offers. This brew is worthy.

Belle bière couleur de miel, limpide et couverte dun large col bien dense laissant au verre une épaisse dentelle. Des arômes de caramel brûlé et dagrumes. Elle est très amère avec un peu de sucre. Elle est très effervescente, de texture crémeuse et se termine sur de longs arômes et une amertume tranchante.
Rather grassy and sweet aroma. The taste is fruity, hints of sweetness, thick malt body and a bitterness which appears after a while.

Du möts av en ganska diskret doft som växer om du låter den stå några minuter. Smaken är bred med fina nyanser, beskan låter vänta på sig ett tag. När den kommer är den mycket balanserad. En mycket bra imperial!!

Åhh vilka fina mjuka dofter. Oerhört krämig i smaken. Där finns allt Inget sticker ut. För att ge ölen topp betyg hade behövts nånting extra., Men detta troligen den krämigaste mest balanserade Dipa jag någonsin druckit.

Holy god is this beer good. I dont see the raisiny fruit cake flavor people speak of. Amazing hop tones. Good balance of malt. Beautiful color. Smell to die for. Probably top 5 in my favorite beer list.

Ambrée. Beau collet. Nez: caramel. Fleur. Sureau. Fruité. Fruit confit. Ananas. Alcool. Pomme. Bouche: bonne amertume persistante très bien équilibré avec le côté malté. Fruit confit. Bien houblonné. Caramel. Assez sèche pour le pourcentage. Fruit exotique. Mangue. Résineuse (conifère). Pêche. Tarte au sucre sans être sucré. Absolument sublime.

Floral citrusy hop aroma. Heavy malt smell as well. Taste is quite malty. Malt dominates the hop I would say. Would like a bit more hop for the malt level. Doesn't taste as strong as it is. Overall I think it is a bit too malty and sweet. I prefer the 60 minute to the 90. 90 is thicker on the palate with similar flavors. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a burnt orange color with creamy white head. Hop, citrus and caramel aroma. Grapefruit, orange, hop and caramel flavors with a thick malt backbone. Medium full body and a lingering malty grapefruit finish. Very good.

I found the malt too overpowering. I am not a fan of fruit cakes and this tastes very much like a raisiny fruit cake.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The culmination of 2 years trying to get this beer, first sip has blown me away! Extremely hard to get outside of the US, I was lucky to have this bottle picked up for my by a friend at the Great British Beer Festival 2013 in London. Light ruby red body, thin yellowed head, aroma kicks off with healthy wet hops leading onto faint raisin aroma and alchohol notes, very sweet raisin and fruity cake taste, not too dissimilar from turkish delight alongside a very complex layered taste, sweet and syrupy in texture and flavour. This beer surprised me, I expected it to be much more hop focused, but it actually felt a lot more like a Belgian fruitbeer along the lines of Rochefort instead of that American double IPA I was expecting, however it is simply an amazing beer, playing a fusion between fruit beer and IPA. For quite a while now I have been dying to get one of their beers, after this first bottle I have to say Dogfish Head has lived up to their clearly well earned reputation! I cant wait to get a hold of some more!

Aroma: fruity, sweet, mellow, banana, tropical, floral.
Appearance: honey color, small foamy head, clear, no cloudiness.
Taste: bitter up-front, then fruity and floral, light malty finish. Heavy, thick taste. Tons of flavor
Palate: from start to finish, its a winner for me.
Overall: I love this beer.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2013 A subtle nose of raisins, and sugar.  Pours a translucent mahogany with a off-white ring and no lacing. The taste malt forward - not what I expected from a "90 minute" IPA. Toasted malts, hints of caramel, raisins, fruit sweetness, and very little bitterness. A nice bready/grainy/slightly sweet aftertaste. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Overall, this was a vey pleasant surprise! Would drink again.

Appearance- Pours amber with a crisp white two finger head.
Aroma- Piney tangerine and light toasted malt.
Taste- Big malt backbone under citrus peel pine and bitter hops.
Palate- Medium bodied with medium carbonation
Overall- Real stand up IPA. Interesting malt presence.
Excellent IPA. Amber beer with a white head. Medium hoppy aroma and a light hoppy, lightly sweet flavor. Delicious.

Pours a slightly hazy golden, orange with a nice slab o head. Aromas of caramel, malt, raisin, and citrussy hoppage. Medium body with a nice balance of honey/caramel sweetness to bitterness. Some raisin, pine and citrus come through with a long finish of sweet caramel and bitter pine needles.
 Well brewed, alcohol is warming as apposed to hot and offensive. Solid brew!

Source : Richard Grocery
Appearance : Light amber with a medium lasting white head.
Aroma : Strong hop and citrus.
Taste : Rich hop, citrus and grain.
Palate : Medium body and medium carbonation.
Overall : Very complex, fun to drink sip after sip.

Taste is a malty bitter with an aftertaste to match. Alcohol is slightly noticeable. Medium body with a low-medium carbonation. Syrupy with slight bubbles in the mouth. Was more malty than I expected. Not bad but not what I was expecting. Perhaps the bottle was a touch off. Will review again.
Great brew. Perfect combination of sweety and bitter. Beautiful looking beer from bottle and even better when on tap. One of my favorites

This is a very big, bold beer with substantial flavor. The appearance is golden amber with persistent head. The bitterness of this DIPA is punctuated by the strong alcohol content. The texture is thick and full bodied. This is not a beer to take lightly.

Bottle at MGM Grand. 
Malty and hoppy. Pines and fruity. Medium body and medium carbonation. Quite sticky.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2014 12oz bottle. Pours a transparent golden orange with a two finger, frothy, off-white head with nice lacing. Aroma is slightly fruity with hints of pine, resin, tropical fruits, caramel, and bread. Aroma really opens up when the beer warms up a bit.Taste is a malty bitter with an aftertaste to match. Pine and resin with a bit of citrus, and caramel/bread. Alcohol is slightly noticeable. Medium body with a low-medium carbonation. Slightly syrupy with slight bubbles in the mouth. Was more malty than I expected. Not bad but not what I was expecting.

On tap nice color medium head but overall appearance nothing special. Taste another story..... very good hop and malt flavors smooth from start to finish. Very drinkable actually too much so. My mistake not to check the alcohol rating until several pints later.
Have had in a bottle and on tap in Ann Arbor. Holy cow. This is nectar. Nice body. Superb hop balance. All around great for a huge ipa. Very nice.

Aroma of raisins, straw, flowers, and wet leather. Complex! Slightly metallic taste (definitely feel it on the tip of my tongue), with multiple, multiple levels of flavoring (my palate is too wussy to be able to pick them apart). A wonderfully complex beer. Not my best beer of all time, but definitely in the top ten!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

4-pack of 12 oz bottles for 8 bucks. Pours a clear golden amber with a creamy head. Looks really nice. Smells piney, slightly fruity with some malts and caramel in there as well. Really unique aroma for an IPA. Taste is malty, some chocolate. The bitterness comes in afterwards but honestly I dont notice it much. For a beer that is 9% and 90 IBU, it is dangerously easy to drink. Texture is thicker and oilier than most IPAs which I like. Average carbonation. Overall it is way different from their 60 minute IPA. This is one of the best IPAs and stands out because of its unique aroma and taste.

Bottle. Pours clear copper with a frothy off-white head. Aroma is grass, spruce, grapefruit, citrus, earthy and floral. Taste is medium sweet and very bitter. Oily texture, full bodied and average carbonation. Deep intense flavour which should be savoured. Very good.

4/23/13. Last of my 6 IPA's. bought at CBO. Drank while watching Hell's Kitchen. Lil fruity. Strong alcohol content. Need to get a 120 next

This beer said all it was going to be on the website. No flaws, just a little sticky sweet for me--I was hoping for less sweetness and more hop depth
UPDATED: FEB 28, 2014 On tap at DFH Fairfax VA. Coppery with buff head that leaves nice lacing. Pineapple and resin up front with leathery bitterness in the finish. Outstanding!

My first Dogfish beer. 4 months old, cold bottle. Amber with minimal head. Body is medium with high carbonation. Smells of toffee, Centennial hops (it doesnt say which are used, but Id guess Centennial from the smell). Taste - more toffee, light fruits, some raisin, chocolate and resin. Crisp finish. Alcohol not noticeable. Hmm, was expecting a lot more. Im sure its more impressive when its fresh, but the bottle in front of me is pretty average.

I love the fact that you cant really taste the alcohol. Usually big beers have that certain burn from the alcohol, but you wont find that here in this 90 minute IPA. I was able to pick out the raisin notes as well as the citrusy flavor.
The rich smooth taste of chocolate and roasted nuts and hint of coffee mask the bitterness of the hops. The first time I had it, I realized this is what I was looking for in an IPA. Savor ever sip.
Big hoppy taste. Lots of malt. Nice balance. Spicy cinnomon notes. Nice mouthfeel.

Bottle. Clear honey color with a creamy head and nice lacing. Aroma is honey and wildflowers with hints of grain. Flavor matches the aroma and is very well balanced. Smooth finish. A stellar Imperial IPA.

Bourbon brown-gold and clear with a light token head. Smells delish. Rye alcohol pine raisin. Taste is righteously hopped with flavors of pine, lemon and mild grapefruit citrus, raisin and plum. Some maltiness as well. Finishes with some alcohol and balanced bitterness that lingers. Lightly carbonated. Heavily enjoyed.

Bottle from 16 Tons Taphouse, Eugene. Pours a medium amber, decent amount of off-white head. Aroma surprisingly sweet, caramel, crisp pine. Body medium/slipper/thicky, finish malty sweet, very little lingering bitterness, some resinous notes. Very different from the west coast IIPAs that I am used to, hard to believe this is even 90 IBUs.

Very malt forward. Sweet nose. Choclately taste. Sweet melon nose. Slight tropical fruit.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass. Aromas of caramel, butterscotch, vanilla, and bourbon barrel. Pours a reddish-orange color with a frothy white head. Big flavors with an alcohol punch, fruity esters, cooked bread and enough hop to balance it out. Its very viscous, almost liqueur-ish. Overall, this is a very good beer, but it seems a bit misidentified as an Imperial IPA.

Bottle at work courtesy of Greg. Havent had one of these in ages. Pours a cleanish orange with and fluffy, beige-orange head that quickly diminishes to a thin cover and nice seafoam lace. Nose of booze, raisin, citrus, nail polish remover, sugar. Medium body, medium bitterness for a DIPA, slightly boozy but does not taste 9%. This used to be my go to beer. Had I rated this 5 years ago it would be a mid to low 4 rating Im sure.

Bottle from 28-Jul-2013 I got from Wegmans. Pours clear burnt oraaange to light brown with nice head that lingers. nose smells fresh with mild piney and biscuity notes. first sip is similar with a spicy hoppiness. finish is clean doughy and mild citrus.

Pour is amber, with a small white head.. 
Aroma is of weeds, grass, and quite some malty notes as well.. This is slightly perfumed, but it doesnt ruin it. 
The taste is slightly (slightly slightly) sweet upfront, with a heavy dose of bitterness towards and through the end.. Medium bodied, with a sparkling/slightly fizzy carb..

Good stuff here. Surprised at the malty/caramel flavor-almost could be mistaken as a barleywine style instead of IPA. Still-plenty of hops and raisin, chocolate and coffee flavors (to name a few!) mingling to make this an outstanding beer.

The color is amber, clear, and the head retention is two-fingered and stays in the room awhile. The hop aroma, for a hopped up treatment, is surprisingly not necessarily forward on the nose. The mouthfeel is expansive, creamy, with the taste of a malt monster: caramel and toffee. The bittering hops make an appearance on the finish. At 9% ABV, the deft balance hides the high alcohol. Only an A+++ brewery could pull off balance like this on a high alcohol recipe. Homebrewer alert: dont try this at home!

This is my favorite IPA. Immediate hoppy taste but not overwhelming. Long aftertaste but mild.

Pours light amber with a full, long lasting head, slowly diminishing leaving lovely lacing. Aromas of pine, citrus, grapefruit, flowers, some resinous odors. Taste is toffee, raisiney malt flavors blending smoothly into sharp spicy flavors and a citrus tang. Mouth feel is medium bodied with nicely moderated carbonation. overall a very good ale.
One of my favorites. perfect look and taste. An imperial ipa that I could drink all day.

One of my favorites for a long time, just getting around to reviewing it. Danky and pineyhoppiness is present just as expected, but not at the top of the range like something from Stone. The great thing about this beer is really the other things going on. The malts have this nutty taste that I only notice in this beer. The booziness is in line with any other DIPA at this ABV.

My favorite IPA by far. Light amber hue with big frothy head. Honeyed apricots come to mind when I first taste this brew. Its not as good this year as in the past, but still the best IPA readily available to me.

Bottle at the foxhole. Aroma is citrus resin and heavy caramel malt with thick hop scent. Taste is one of a kind thick caramelized sugars, a toasted backbone, fresh hops lending a grapefruit-like bitterness. Not style typical. Very delicious and well crafted. Nicely balanced

Pours golden and smooth, with a piney and faint citrus aroma. Definitely big in the ABV department, but one would never know without looking at the label before finishing the last drop. A well balanced flavor and palate, combined a mild, but complex bitter finish, makes this one of the true kings of Imperial/Double IPAs. This is the beer I use to try to broaden the palate of friends who are leery of, or even downright opposed to IPAs. Virtually all of them are easily persuaded to come back to it in the future.
Pours amber with massive head, aroma is sweet pine, taste is similar with a lingering bitter finish.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2013 12oz bottle into Belgian chalice. Pours a golden amber with sparse head. Floral and citrus scents. Smooth and very pleasant on the palate, with similar flavours to the nose. ABV is well hidden. Came pretty close to living up to the hype.

Definitely one of the better IPAs out there today. Great aroma and flavor; But what really stands out about this Imperial is the palate. Its persistent, but not in the way a heavy stout is. The citrus and floral hops would be to thank for that. Great beer. few like it.

I can see why this is rated so high. Beautifully smooth and drinkable, with a nice palatable pucker of astringent hops. Pours dark gold/light amber with sticky white head. Piney aroma and taste, nice thick mouthfeel. IPA isnt one of my favorite styles, but this one could win me over.

Pours a deep gold color with just a hint of amber. Small creamy head. Smells a little flowery. Weird taste for a DIPA. Not bad.

Bottle courtesy of my Californian brother-in-law. Cheers Tommy! Pours a clear amber with small white head that lasts well. Aromas are resin, red grapes, Christmas cake. UPDATED: APR 20, 2014 Great complex aroma of hops. Color was amber red with a medium head on it. Great beer.

Lett fruktig lukt med preg av malt, humle, tørka frukt, våte blad, gras, jord. Fruktig smak med preg av malt, humle, tørka frukt, karamell, gras, våte blad, sitrus. God bitterhet som set litt. God.

Big beer sweet malt very high alcohol beer. Aroma is nice piney floral hefty . Not very hoppy. This beer is great as it warms and opens up. Highly recommended. You better like strong alcohol in your beet for this one. Still its a wonderful beer.

A great beer all around. Fabulous hoppy, resinous, somewhat grassy profile with a very nice malty backbone, enough malt to stand its ground. Very drinkable. An instant favourite. Hides the big 9.0% ABV very well.

Dark copper pour with a white head. Floral aromas with citrus and pine notes. Big malt presence as well. Flavor is big floral/citrus hop with lots of malty goodness to back it up. A really well balanced double IPA. This beer really lives up to all the hype that surrounds it. Great brew!

Copper colored pour. Brilliant. Foamy white head. Little bit of lacing. Big citrus nose, a little piney. Some hints of caramel. Taste is a nice malty back with some soft citrus notes. One of my favorite IPAs, but not the best...yes, it has the hoppiness and a bit of malt flavor, but there is just something lacking to the body. It is perhaps a bit too bitter/alcoholic-tasting for me? Again- not bad at all, but not my favorite either.
Rich amber color, creamy, persistent head. Low carbonation and slightly syrupy feel. Tamed hoppy flavors, not as sharp as the 60.

This is what I use as a measuring stick for IPAs. The copper coloring, with the off white lingering head. It smells of a proper IPA. Hop bitterness, but with a nice malt sweetness in the background. The stickiness on the tongue afterwards is the only drawback. Does have an alcohol feeling too...but that does not bother me.
Delicious. Better than the 60 min variety and stands up well to spicier foods. As an imperial IPA it doesnt have the freshness that the 60 does.

This is a big beer thats hard to ignore. Even a place with a good selction it would take something really amazing to get me to choose that over this perfect brew. Ive had the 120 min and this still trumps. Its a staple in my eyes.

The americans are the masters of imperial ipas and this is another example of that. Would love to try their 120minute ipa but is impossible to get in new zealand.

Probably the best beer Ive ever had. Great in the most, smooth on the palate, and finished wonderful. Love this beer!

Pours a light amber. Has a sweet, fruity smeel with some hints of hops. A sweet fruity and raisin flavor, with a light hint of hops.

Bottles from Coppers, Rehills, Newcastle. An orange beer with an unusually sweet floral flavour, orange marmalade, tropical fruits and a smooth, fruity finish. Very easy drinking and therefore a dangerous beer!
Bottle. Medium amber clear color. Nice initial hop aroma. Noticeably hoppy on palate. Nice malt/hop balance but not best aftertaste. Aftertaste gets old.

I have now had this beer twice, one bottle I picked up online and one was from Craft Beer Base in Osaka. It occasionally shows up in Japan, I just wish some of Dogfish Heads other beers would also make a showing... anyways onto the beer. This beer pours your classic amber IPA color, it has a fantastic fruity floral citrus hop aroma that is quite complex. The beer is superbly balanced with a sweet caramel base being overlain with tropical fruit notes and a bitter pine hop finish.  I am not a big fan of ultra-bitter beers but the 90 minute IPA (and Stones 16 Anniversary IPA) show that ultra-hoppy doesnt have to mean super bitter. Very nice.

Hazy, deep amber with a short, yellowish head.
Aroma is malt, sweet sugary fruit.
Taste is tingly sweet with a growing, orange-peel bitter.....
Rich, a little spicy...
Superb.

Appearance:
Polished orange and copper under a pithy head that lasts as a nice layer with scattered bubbles on top. A small collar slightly crawls up the sides of my glass. Swirls with more bubbles and head.

Nose:
Peaches, apricots, mandarin oranges, mango, star fruit  all boozed, spiced, and caramelized. Green leaf aloe in the back. Caramelized melba and toast, just the crusts please. Spiciness in the middle with ginger, cumin, and curry. Fruit skins on the outside, juicy flesh on the inside.

Palate:
Bitterness of orange, peach, and star fruit skins in the back. More star fruit along with aloe in the middle  fresh and tropical. Greenness in the back and underneath  tropical fruit skins. Lips are sticky with pine sap, caramelized apples, honey, and hop resins. Love the juicy middle ripe with boozed mandarin oranges and mango. Candied ginger along the edges. Slight settling of warmth in my chest.

Final Thoughts:
Amazingly drinkable and complex all at the same time. Because the 90 Minute Imperial IPA from Dogfish Head is so readily accessible, it is easy to forget how damn good this beer really is. Of course I prefer mine on draft, but Ill take it either way. Delicious and an excellent standard bearer for the Imperial IPA category.

(An original written work by Beer Ambassador, LLC. Plagiarism is not tolerated.)

One of the benchmarks for imperial IPAs. Nice mix of hop aromas: floral and piney. Color is an amber/copper mix with a mild head. Higher than average weight as I imagine the grain bill is high but it doesnt make the beer feel too heavy. Good carbonation. The beauty of this is its balance. The malts add a certain sweetness that mixes well with the overabundance of hops, which are definitely there. The alcohol is also well hidden but remains a key component. Superb.

Bottle found in NYC. Clear deep golden colour, looks nice. Have to say not quite what I expected. Superbly well balanced IPA - yes there is a lot of hops, bitter, citrus/pine, long finish. But this isnt just another stupid hop beast, the malt stands up and makes the beer very drinkable. Very good.

Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA has a medium, off-white head, an unclear, brilliant, amber-orange appearance, with thin, white lacing, and an enormous amount of bubbles all about. The aroma is very juicy up front (think of mango), with an underlying toasted barley malt note. Taste is of sweet, juicy hops, hop oil, some bitterness, and toasted barley malt. Mouthfeel is medium and a bit oily, and Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA finishes semi-dry, sweet, mildly alcohilic, and surprisingly easy drinking. Overall, this beer was not as bitter, rich, extreme, and hoppy as the hype led me to believe. That aside, I still think it is a wonderful beer to be able to sample. Overall, I rate this as outstanding.

Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA has a medium, off-white head, an unclear, brilliant, amber-orange appearance, with thin, white lacing, and an enormous amount of bubbles all about. The aroma is very juicy up front (think of mango), with an underlying toasted barley malt note. Taste is of sweet, juicy hops, hop oil, some bitterness, and toasted barley malt. Mouthfeel is medium and a bit oily, and Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA finishes semi-dry, sweet, mildly alcohilic, and surprisingly easy drinking. Overall, this beer was not as bitter, rich, extreme, and hoppy as the hype led me to believe. That aside, I still think it is a wonderful beer to be able to sample. Overall, I rate this as outstanding. RJT

12 oz. bottle into a snifter. I just really started to drink DIPAs on a regular basis over the last year and finally had to rate this one. Very aromatic grapefruit, pine and caramel. Aroma is a little sweet with strong hop but packs a punch with aftertaste. Beautiful looking. Creamy white head, amber body, and chocolaty and kinda earthy taste. Little unexpected bitter. Still a great beer.

Bottle.  Pours a clear amber with a very nice head that persists.  Very nice aroma - leads with hop notes, then gives rise to dark fruits, malts, and alcohol. Dark walnut in color.  Nice, lightly tan head.  Aroma of spicy noble hops and caramel.  Flavor is very malty and toffee with a slightly spicy and bitter compliments.  Body is heavy to medium and oh so lovely.

Is this the most legendary craft beer?  Very complex hop/malt combination.  It starts with the expected orange, grapefruit, and pine flavors but then has a lemon/pepper twist on the finish.  I dont get it very often because there are so many other good options for the price point, but im never dissapointed after drinking it.  I think part of its mythic status is that for many people (myself included) this is there first really good beer after the intial craft gateways like fat tire, snpa, and sam adams.

Not completely sure why this rates 100 and why people swear by it as they do. Not saying it is not a good beer,  but certainly would not make my list of top 5 or perhaps 10 for that matter in the imperial ipa book. Enjoyable.. Yes... 100 and a 100 on style NO...in my opinion. does not really fit my description ofa a dipa.

Awesome beer. Lots of strong flavours that overshadow the bitterness and trick you in to thinking youre not drinking a strong beer.  I would like this more bitter to balance the sweet raisin/fruit body. its a thick beer that I thoroughly enjoyed drinking. a bit quickly to be honest.  Top stuff.

Cuivrée et limpide, une mousse typique qui perdure en dessinant une dentelle décousue. Odeur modérée dagrumes et de conifères et aussi omniprésents....Goût assez intense de houblon avec une texture résineuse qui sapparente à des saveurs de gomme de pin. Pretty much perfect. Its an absolutely gorgeous malty IPA that is just bursting with rich, earthy flavour. The balance of malt, hops, wood and yeast works so well. Just enough bitterness on the back of the tongue, and a truly fantastic nutty feeling that you cant quite place but comes back stronger with each sip. The aroma is malt with just a little caffeine on the surface. The pour is dark and golden. I love this beer.

Aroma is very sweet with plums, alcoholic Xmas cake and over ripe stone fruit of some kind. Taste is same with a bitterness swamped by the sweetness. Finish is increasingly sweet, sticky with rough alcohol. This is not a great beer, but it is a bit better than average. Its like its trying to be too much, it s a bit too big for its boots and should be shaved down to a more spritely 5%

A great beer, but over the years I think that it has been surpassed by other imperial IPAs. It does have a "great malt backbone" as they say - maybe even too great, because it doesnt really taste like an IPA. I would almost call this an American strong ale in the style of Stones double bastard ale. And some of the flavors, like figs and raisins, are reminiscent of a barleywine or a quad. Its hoppy, but the hops are balanced, and almost overpowered, by the malty flavors. Regardless, its a classic and a great brew.

12oz bottle be it ever so humble. Pours a slightly hazy rich amber with a healthy lasting foamy head. Aroma is a full spectrum of caramel, pepper with well-balanced fruity overtones. Revisit, finally rating...golden pour, lingering head with nice lacing. Aroma is malt and carmel with a little hop presence but seems more barley wine than DIPA. Still nice. 33cl bottle. Golden/brown with medium, white head. Nose : tart, nuts, dairy cream, toffee, ginger bread, citrus, banana ... it goes and goes. Sip : thick body with oily texture. 0,33 bottle from friend. Got it fresh. Medium white tan head. Nose of rich hoppy grass, nice maltyness, citrus but hops is still not too heavy. Taste is also rich on hops but still not dominant, nice touch from the maltyness. A lovely Imp IPA.

Bottle pours golden amber with a medium tan head. Hoppy, citrusy aroma. Taste is smokey with a smooth hop finish. Smooth take on a double IPA.

Appearance: Pours with a ridiculous head that just doesnt go away. The color is orange, and theres maybe a little tad of haziness. Surprisingly little lacing for the amount of head. 

Smell: Oh mama... so subtle, but so nice. Its a really nice hop smell. Honestly, I dont think the beer tastes much like it smells, but that really doesnt even matter with this one.

Taste/feel: Has to be the most interesting IPA Ive had up to this point. Its certainly loaded with hops, but it also has -- as the bottle puts it -- a ridiculous amount of barley. I absolutely love it. Its hop heavy up front and in the smell, but the malts come through on the finish. I love it. Theres also a bit of warmth as well, making this a perfect Autumn beer. The feel of this one bothers me a tad, though. The whole beer itself is legendary, but I almost feel this beer to be a bit too syrupy to have more than one in a sitting. Regardless of all of that, 90 Minute IPA is an absolute must try. It may be $3 a bottle, but trust me -- there is a reason.
Pours a golden amber colour with a thick head. At 9%, be careful, it could knock you down. But at least, youll go down drinking great beer. Because this is a very good IPA. One of the best for sure.

Bottled on February 20, 2013.
Appearance: The body is crystal clear with a slightly dark amber hue. The light tan head is tall and dense with a bready texture. The head has great retention, slowly settling into a thick and frothy coating.
Aroma: The aroma is a bit restrained but comes off as bready and earthy with a touch of citrus.
Taste: The flavor is strong varying from bready to moderately hoppy. Flavors of bread, raisins, earthy bitterness, and citrus come to mind.
Palate: Full bodied with soft carbonation.
Overall: This is not the kind of double IPA I like, this actually drinks more like a barleywine. I would like to see how this handles with a few months on it actually. Fresh this is solid, but I prefer others.

Pours a coppery amber with a slight white head and fair lacing.  The malt character completely neutralizes the hops, with caramel being the dominant aroma with just a hint of floral.  Very smooth and drinkable, just dont reach for this if youre in the mood for a hoppy IPA.

One hell of an imperial IPA. Great savory taste, has an extreme hop profile that would satisfy any hop fanatic. Raisins, stone fruit, lemons on the nose. Tastes exquisite, like a dry spring filled with bitter wildflowers. Yeah, I just said that. Drink this now.

Golden amber pour, white thick head.  Malty body rounded with citrus flavor, mild bitterness sets in at the finish. Malts hang around for awhile. This is a very very smooth well rounded Imperial IPA, its hard to believe its 9%. The only thing that could be better is the strength of the aroma, but that is in no way shape or form a deterrent from drinking this again.

Wonderful imperial ipa. Notes of citrus and floural on the nose. Amber orange with a lingering finger length head. Lures of hops but balanced with make. Very full and well balanced beer. Some bitterness, but mild at the end.

A - Pours an amber copper with a 1 finger white head that dissipates quickly. Little to no lacing.

S - Nice caramel malt with some floral pine and alcohol coming through. It kind of reminds me of Hobby Lobby.

T - Sweet buttery caramel malt with a slight fruity character. The hops are assertive and have a kind of a candy bittering. Oily pine and citrus comes through to even out the heavy malt.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation.

This is the 4th time Ive had this beer and the malt always surprises me. I always thought from looking at reviews that this would be all hop and little malt. This beer is quite balance with the malt presence almost having a slight edge over the hops presence. Although this time the beer seemed to be significantly less hoppy that the previous three. The first 2 ties the lacing was incredible. The last 2 werent that great. The bottle says 8/20/10 so it makes it less less than 2 months old. I dont know. Seems a little different every time.

Pours a semi hazy, golden color with a thick head. Leaves a decent amount of lacing. Aromas of roast and caramel come in strong, with a nice citrus bite. Taste is also very citrusy with a smooth mix of roasted malt . Not nearly as bitter as I was expecting for an imperial IPA. Overall, a well balanced flavor. Im still hunting for 120 minute, but the 90 minute makes a great substitute.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2013 Had this again & had to re rate, this was better than I remember.  Amber pour with thick head & full of grapefruit aromas & taste.  Perfect level of bitterness and a well hidden abv.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2014 Bottle. Clear golden orange with a  frothy, off-white head lasts and laces. Aromas of caramel, pine, some earthy notes and light citrus. Flavor is caramel, pine, grapefruit and light orange. Medium bodied, smooth with some warmth on the end.

12oz bottle.  Still one of the finest, however the competition is getting stronger and aggressive.  Great lacing on my glass.  Well balanced aromas and tastes of fruits, grass, pine and citrus.  Smooth mix, slightly sweet, but still a good combination of malts and hop bitterness.  Clean finish.
There?s a great aroma of hops, but the flavour is somewhat underwhelming.  Could do with a bit more kick. (On closer inspection, its possible that I was served the wrong beer.)

12 oz bottle.  Pours golden-amber and pretty clear with a nice white head that leaves spectacular lacing.  Aroma is mostly hops, spruce and fresh herbs with soft fruitiness and soft sweet malt.  Juicy hop flavor, fresh and smooth with a nice malt balance and great feel.

12 oz bottle pours rich amber. Slightly cooler than room temperature. Foamy, slightly frothy, off white head with lacing thats lasts all the way down. Slightly floral hop aroma backed by malt sweetness and a slight alcohol tone. Flavor initially hoppy and bitter followed quickly with a very strong malt backbone. My personal opinion is that the maltiness is slightly overpowering for this highly hopped ale. Mouthfeel is thick, full bodied, and captivates my pallet. Have another? 23 more bottles to go...

Bottled. Light amber, clear beer has lacy thinnish head. Hoppy and malty nose: wine gums, floral notes, watermelon, strawberry, some citrus. Caramel-topped maltiness with some biscuity toastedness. Intensly malty and thick, still not too sweeet. Light dryfruit notes. Strong but really round bitterness. Amazingly smooth palate, full body. Delicious DIPA.

About a finger of head on a cloudy, medium straw colored body.
The aroma is a wonderful mixture of apricot, lemon and orange.
Well, the taste certainly passes the 90 minutes of hop boil and healthy dose of malt, which balances nicely. Big and bold, though the bitterness seems to be deadened a little bit. Finishes with a mild sweet note.
The texture is crisp with a thickness to it. Moderate carbonation.

Pours a slightly hazy golden amber with a frothy off white head that leaves a ring of lacing with every sip. Aroma of tropical fruits, citrus, pine, floral notes & a little bit of grass. Taste is a smooth malty sweetness up front with pine, citrus, fruity notes, toast and then transitions in a nice hop bitterness and a very smooth booze taste(almost unnoticeable). Overall this is a very smooth and easy drinking double ipa, if it wasnt for the slight sweetness Id think it was a really smooth ipa.

Pours a nice clear golden amber colour with a fantastic white head with big lacing all up the glass. Aroma is tropical fruits, citrus, floral notes and malty sweetness. Flavour is complex malty sweetness, toast, caramel, toffee, pine, and tropical fruits. Med-High bitterness. Everything about this beer is complex and blends together so well, though overall seems a bit more mellow than i expected.
Grassy hop scent. Taste is bitter with a nice underlying sweetness and a bit of a sour aftertaste. Will review more in depth some other time.

Very smooth IPA. Amber color. Citrus aroma. Not harsh. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A great beer, I would say one of the best IPAs out there for sure. Love this beer!! Great appearance, aroma and taste. Doesnt get much better than this one.

The middle brother of the series. Pours a enticing amber and the aroma is an amazing combo of malty backbone and hoppy bitterness. the taste doesnt disappoint and has hints of alcohol to accompany the imperial title of this beer. Overall one of my favorite dogfish heads.

12 oz bottle, consumed during a respite from crib training. Joyousness.

A: Copper penny color. Aggressive pour yields fluffy foam that falls into itself quite quickly. Lasts on the rim. 

N: Very sweet. A cornucopia of pineapple and mango as well as biscuits and honey. Floral components. Lots of toffee, and theres a heavy barley that shows up - like a mass produced lager. (Ironically.)

T: Sweet bitterness. More pineapple, mango, and toffee. Lots of vine, but not much earth. The pine is more of the nut than the cone. Biting crystalized sugars. Everything is intertwined but no one component stands out. 

M: Somewhat light for the style. Alcohol is well hidden. 

O: I have fond memories of this beer because its the one that got me into IPAs. That said, its the bridge between the former light lager types and the heavier styles, for which it might be unfairly maligned, but to a mature palate, it starts to lack when compared with the menagerie of options out there. Its a stalwart and good in a pinch, though.

Citrus, bread, and pine in the aroma.  Flavor starts fruity and slightly sweet, with pine hop bitterness and drying alcohol in the finish.  Definitely a great beer with a great balance between a solid base beer with a really nice hop punch, but I have to say I was a tiny bit disappointed.  Its really good, but Ive had better IPAs.
Bottle home. Pours a deep amber; minimal head. Aroma is piney.  Taste is bitter then dark fruit.  Finish is clean, dry.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2014 1/30/13 - 1.11.13 bottle.  Pour into tulip.  Good old 90 minute.  The first double ipa i had after being introduced to ipas at peoria beer fest back in 09.  Really blew me away back then.  But ive had a lot of different beers since.  Pours a amber copper with minimal head.  Aromas of bitter hops, grapefriut citrius, biscuit malt,  and bread yeast.  Taste is rather sweet for an ipa.  Decent amount of hops in there.  Medium body.  Fairly smooth.  Pretty good stuff.  There are better ones out there but this set the tone for a lot of them.  Easy to find and pretty good value for a solid double ipa.


11/6/14
7/2 bottle. Floral. Old hops. Kinda sweet. Maybe there was a time when this was better than the others, but now its below mid pack at best.  Id give this about a 3.2, but Ill keep the older rating as its a fresher bottle.
With Jon. From a bottle. Smooth and sweet but full bodied from the hops. Delicious fruity taste and smell.

Bottle poured into tulip. Lovely opaque copper color with an orange tint. Moderate off-white head which dissipates fairly quickly with some lacing. Aroma is all citrus, floral, and pine, exactly what Id expect from a hoppy beer. Taste is the same. Lots and lots of hops, but excellent balance. Overall, an wonderful beer which I will be enjoying again.
bottle.  Another great beer from Dogfish Head.  Tasted it in 2011 and 2012.
I drank this beer last night with a good friend he had it for 2 years until last  night.  Very nice beer i will drink this beer again.

Bottle 12 Oz. Poured a Nice Amber clear color with a thick white head. Aroma of hops and citrus notes, honestly it is quite awesome. sweet but very well balanced with the bitterness of the hops. I actually think it just became one of my favorite beers.
Like the bitterness but a bit to much malt for me and it is also a little boozy. Would have liked to get more flavor from the hops.
I love the aroma of this beer. Just love it. Its a step above its 60 min counterpart. If you like hops and like beer, you will love this. I recommend starting with the 60 though.

4 pack of bottles. Very little foam. First taste is boozy and malty. Very sweet. Hops come through in the finish.

A very malty ipa that is also very bitter.  Not a fan if the dogfish brands and this does not make my top list. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours honey copper color with a small white head with nice lacing. Aroma of biscuit and light citrus hops. Medium body with resin and pine hop bitterness nicely balanced with a malt backbone. One of my favorite Imperial IPAs.

Fruity, hoppy and round smell. Dark golden with nice white head. This one might have matured for to long sp im missing some bitterness, but very round in flavour. More like an imperial PA, than an IPA. Nice mouthfeel, quite thick to me an IPA. Overall a very good beer!

Nice golden color. Tasted fresh in the US. Some resemblence with its little brother the 60 Minute IPA - but more of everything. A nice hoppy aroma with a solid malt back bone to back it up. Some phenolics from the alcohol or yeast. A nice hoppy finish. A real treat!

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2015 5/22/15. Pours a beautiful clear, copper with two fingers of white head that stayed around for a while, and left good lacing.  Aroma had a subtle hop presence with some sweet malt.  Taste was balanced with a bit of candied citrus and mild pine along with a malt backbone.  Finished semi dry with not much bitterness.  Medium body and carbonation.  Well put together put I prefer the west coast style. 

1/13/13 Clear honey colored with decent head and lacing.  Aroma of peaches and grass.  Hop taste that borders on astringent but doesnt get there.  Not near as bitter as expected but alcohol is apparent but not bothersome.  They balance each other out.  Finishes dry with moderate carbonation and mouthfeel.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2015 Bottle poured into stein glass. Pours a hazy amber with some straw color near the bottom. Thin pencil collar. Soapy lacing leaves sparse threads down the glass. Aroma is straw, earth, hints of citrus and pine, hops, and Marcos butt. Tastes is malt heavy with a long, consistent hops bitterness that does not bite as hard as expected. Honey and citrus influences are present as this fades to a bitter aftertaste that sits on the back of the tongue. This Imperial IPA is delicious and easily one of my favorites, with a well hidden ABV that sneaks up. This not recommended for beer newbies or the faint of palate, but is a fantastic beer for fans of the variety.

Aromatic with a fruity head but not overwhelmingly piney or citrusy like so many IPAs. Full bodied with a surprise hint of caramel. Finish with a hint of raspberry and blueberry. Delicious :)

Pours a honey copper color with very little to no white head.  Smell is grassy with some peaches and light citrus.  Taste is grassy hops with not a lot of bitter and some citrus.  A little astringant with a slight soapiness. Mouthfeel is dry.  Good for an IPA.  Would drink again.

Bottle pour from a trade in the forums.  Not like the IPAs Im used to, but I can appreciate the goodness here.

I had a few of these a couple of months back and didnt really dig it, but this time round the brew was a whole lot fresher - booyah! Surprisingly no big fruity aroma coming off the beer (marks down definitely), but the taste was exquisite for a hophead. Perfectly balanced (not too sweet, not too resiny). A great summer beer.

Aroma crackers, caramel, light toast, raisin and light citrus.  Taste is Raisins, and medium to high sweetness and light to moderate bittering.  Its pretty good and a trend starting beer but it falls short of the new versions of the style

Jan 9, 2013. 12oz bottle pours clear deep apricot colour with a 1 inch white head. Once carbon settles the head is a nice cap that leaves blotchy lacing right down to finish. Aroma is malt driven and initially more sweet and biscuity than hoppy. There is a trace of citrus and hops but not nearly what i expected. This beer is all about balance.  The initial malty biscuit caramel is made richer by the citrus hops which both seem to cut each other and leave a perfectly balanced not too sweet or bitter mouthfeel in aftertaste. Maybe too perfectly balanced as the lingering flavours do cut each other short. Alcohol is hidden well and makes for an easy drinking strong brew.

Not nearly as hoppy as other Imperials, but extremely good... Very malty and sweet... The only thing lacking is the aroma.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2013 Great beer. Slightly sweet, some malt and hoppy finish. 9% alcohol is well hidden...until you finish your 2nd! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

caramel, malty, resin, plenty of body, hints of prunes or figs. overall an excellent imperial ipa, but you dont need me to tell you that. Weve all had it a million times and its just a damn fine ipa with a lack of booziness you can get with high gravity ales.

My favorite IPA as of 2013. Amber pour with a lttle more re than brown. White head with better than average lacing. Aroma is citrus leaning toward malty lemon. The taste....Wow. Sip it for for a little citrus sweet and bitter with a mild bite on the tip of the tongue which spreads back and out. Burble it like a wine amd the bitters explode. The only reason this is not a 5 is because of a very slight astringent/bitter finish. This is as cl ose to perfect as I have had.

Finish taste is very pleasant. Very nice aroma to go with it. Perfect for advancing your hop recognition in higher IPA's. I believe this is a must before trying the 120IPA. Lovely color as well. Will be purchasing in the near future.
