Tasted from a bottle. Pours a beautiful amber color with a hearty hop aroma. Strong hop flavor that tasted a bit creamy. Layers of flavor with a bold finish. I highly recommend this beer.

Pours evenly out of the bottle. The malt aroma strongly introduces itself and is a harbinger of good things to come. It has a definite IPA taste but with a strong malt presence. A heavier drinking IPA. Believe what you have heard about this one, definitely a top choice!

One of my favorite IPAs without a shadow of a doubt. The smell is quite pleasant without being too citrusy. Though, the ABV is quite high you dont get the alcohol taste. Very smooth. With an aftertaste that doesnt leave you reaching for some chips. And for being an Imperial IPA it has minimal piney notes. Solid "A"

I enjoy having this beer around, lots of flavor but it doesnt linger too long and I dont find it overpowering.

I pick it up any time that I can make it to Texas since its not sold in Louisiana.
Aroma:  honey, peach, slight citrus, slight caramel.  Appearance:  honey with off-white head.  Taste:  roasty, bitter peachy hop flavors, citrus notes.  Palate:  smooth and quite balanced.

roma is malt driven and initially biscuity. There is some candied grapefruit rind and black pepper. Darker amber with gold edges. White head becomes a ring leaving splashy lacing. Bt his beer has great blance, the malt has a presence in the taste, really makes the word imperial seem justified. The hops slide into the taste profile riding a wave of malt. Bouncy citrus hops round out the initial malty biscuit caramel. This behemoth is insanely drinkable
Hoppy, alot of flavor, nice lacing on glass. Nice amber color. Will definetly try again

From notes: Poured hazy orange-amber with moderate bubbling and a 3-finger bone-colored head.  Deep piney hops aroma with a touch of citrus and a slight nutty note in the background.  Full-bodied with a bit of thickness to it, and an oily finish that turns dry.  Resiny, piney hops flavor with a touch of grapefruit peel beneath.  Theres a light caramel note in the finish that gives way to citrus peel.  Excellent.
Just the right amount of hopiness,  perfectly balanced. Wonderful finish,  slightly dry and floral. This is one awesome beer.

Pours a darker golden amber than the 60 min. Smells similar to the 60 but the pineapple/citrus is more apparent. Tasted  side by side with the 60. Wow a great beer  nice hops, big,  complex, but the abv does not show. Excellent! A must for hop heads.

Bottle. Golden, hazy, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate to full, malty and caramel sweetish aroma, tropical fruitiness and grapefruit hoppyness. Body is medium to full, malty and caramel sweetish flavor, grapefruit hoppyness. Finish is average, malty and sweetish, caramel and grapefruit hoppyness, light alcohol. Caramel sweetish DIPA - too sweet for me. Dont believe the hype.

Enjoyed this delicous IPA with my Family and a bowl of Chili at dinner the day after Christmas. It had a great flavor and very satisfying after taste. Like everyone else has said, this is the best IPA I have ever tried, and I dont like IPAs all that much.

Quite hoppy (90 IBU), not overpoweringly so, but well complemented by a generous amount of malts and plenty of raisin aroma and ripe fruit sweetness, some floral and spice notes as well. A small head, more of a lace, which yet lingers throughout the drink.

pours cloudy bronze with off-white head.  aroma is mostly sweet candied fruits; some citrus hops too, but less than i was expecting.  taste is candied orange and citrus hops, with a strong caramel malt backbone. the finish is superbly balanced (like the rest of the flavor profile), with honey sweetness meeting floral hop bitterness.

Smells bitter, malty and like dried fruits.  Taste is just like it smells with a malty fruit sweet with just enough bitter to balance.  I prefer more citrus hoppiness in my IPAs but this one is so balanced I can overlook the extra malt and sweetness.  Like usual with Dogfish Head not near my favorite beer in its style but so unique I enjoy it enough to keep coming back.

Pours a pretty translucent orange gold with a small white head and a bit of clingy lace.  Caramelly aroma with a bit of hop, but less than I expected.  Maybe I have it too cold.  Quaffs boozy yet balanced, not syrupy sweet or overbearingly hoppy, somehow.  Big, smooth, and flavorful.  Goes to your head.

Pours a hazy semi clear, reddish gold in color with one finger white head that leaves lace and bubbles. Aromas of resin, grapefruit and fresh cut wood. Surprisingly balanced, malt sweetness, fruity citrus flavors. Raisin. Alcohol notes, winey; Hops show through more in the aftertaste. Great body, well carbonated. Well crafted flavorful brew for sure. Very enjoyable.
Wow..Hoppy but balanced. Smells intensely Hoppy.nice pour,goody head, solid lacing. Effing Delicious.

Honey colored very little head. A sweet fruit scent mixed in with the grassy pine, peaches. Light sweet taste with a bitter that washes away quickly. Pretty good overall, but not as complex as I would expect from the smell. Would like more of the fruitiness to come through, but definitely a good beer. For people that aren't huge fans of IPA. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Khourys; pours clear amber, sweet honey aroma, resinous mouth feel, perfect hop and malt balance, not a in your face hop caramel monster but a more subdued quaffable easy drinking DIPA.
Has all the desired qualities.  More sweet than bitter.  Complex, full flavored. This is the standard from which other beers are judged.
As always, a fantastic IPA from DFH.  Great aroma, the mouthfeel is perfect, and that hop flavor is amazing.  Delicious.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2013 12oz bottle. Instant citrus sweet/bitter lime aroma on pour. Rich head and persistent lace. Explosive taste of oranges and lemons but with an intense malty barley balancing act going on. Quite a tasty IPA with focus on taste and not on the IBU - which was a nice surprise. Compared to the 60 minute brew, this one is WAY better.

Dogfish Head nailed it. The color,  aroma and mouth feal are perfect. The sweet noise along with the velvet mouth feel make for one exception al brew. Dogfish Head knocked it out of the park with thia one.
Good beer but would prefer a bigger hop bite.  Good taste. But boozy when warmed up. Thanks

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2013 Poured in a duvel tulip glass from a 12 oz bottle. Appearance was a dark golden/amber. Crystal clear with a pure white finger head dissipating quickly. Aroma was sweet up front with biscuit, orange and lemon, maltiness followed by some mild earthiness.  Taste was smooth with sweet fruit followed by what an IPA should....hops. Mouthfeel was medium with smooth carbonation.  A solid sipping double IPA.  Drink this as fresh as you can and you will be a happy hop head!
On tap at Bruery Provisions, poured into a snifter.  Yellowish orange color with fluffy white head.  Nose and taste and nicely balanced citrus and hops.  Really good.

Bottle from Earl. Thanks! Pours clear golden to orange with lovely thick lasting head. Aroma is hops, citrus fruits, hint of some wooden tones. Flavor is hops, then some more hops, chillies, citrus fruits. Bitter, but not excessively like some other imp. IPAs. Long bitter hops aftertaste, that is surprisingly not dry. Excellent stuff.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2013 12 oz bottle served in a snifter.  Pours a hazy, dark orange-amber with a small, fragile head.  Very fruity (citrus) aroma and flavor, but with the orange in the nose giving way to a load of grapefruit in the mouth. Hoppy, especially in the finish and aftertaste. High ABV is partially hidden.
Bottle-> snifter.  Orange amber wi fluffy white head.  Aroma is hops and citrus.  Tastes of hops, conifer, malt.  Great balance, every aspect is pleasant.

12 oz. bottle to snifter @ Union Woodshop. Really nice balanced aroma, bready malts + citrusy hops. I dont know if my sniffer is stuffed or what but Im not getting a crazy bouquet on this one, will have to revisit with pleasure. Color is a wonderful golden orange borderlining on amber or perhaps its a light amber borderlining on orange. Small white-ish head with average lacing. Taste is a dance of citrus fruits and some fruity esters, never cloying of course. Much like Sierra Nevada pale ale became my go to beer when I first got in the game, 90 Minute is my go to year round DIPA, always solid + readily available. Maybe its the story of the old electric football game shaking hop pellets down into the boil for an hour and a half, but I just love this damn beer and always will. Mouth feel is medium with just the right amount of carbonation, sometimes I can taste mandarins! Finish is quite pleasant & unique, grassy and almost lemon verbena-ey. What else can I say, we all know this is just a solid ass double ipa, Ill stop rambling. Anyone wanna ride bikes? How about those tigers...
Floral, mild citrus aroma. Clear copper color.Medium bodied, bitterness not overpowering. Tropical fruit, resin and malt. Mild carbonation. Sweet but not cloying. Slightly viscous. Great IIPA.
Appearance is a clear amber. Aroma is a pine hop. Taste is bitter with earthy hops, but not overpowering. Overall a really nicely balanced variety.

Fluffy white head and golden amber color. Has a very citrusy and floral scent with the caramel malt making an appearance. The taste is just about perfectly balanced. A nice strong malt presence gives way to an abundance of resiny hoppy goodness. One of the absolute best examples of the style.

Appearance has a light amber color supporting a steady fluffy head leaving nice lace.  Aroma of sweet malt, citrus and a little piney.  Taste has that nice sweet grapefruit flavor thats rich malty backbone, but nicely balanced with the amount of  hops they throw in.  Mouthfeel is medium with good carbonation.  A very nice Imperial with more complexity than most.

Its not bad!  There is a good bit of booze on the palette but the hop aroma and flavor is not as big as I would hope.  Not lacking in any real way, I just feel like I expect better from Dogfish.  Maybe they should spend more time perfecting and less time being strange, though I do appreciate their efforts.  There is also like a roasty or cocoa flavor?...maybe the line was unclean.

Bottle. Poured a deep amber color with a nice one finger off-white head. Excellent lacing. Bright citrus notes in the aroma. Perfect balance between the malt and hops - phenomenal. Great bitterness on the finish.

A clear orange-tan, one finger head and great lacing. Nice looking brew.

Smells of strong grapefruit and intense hoppy goodness. Some pine accents as well. A little floral in the background.

Tastes really nice. Hops and grapefruit dominate, pine and light fruits combine with a solid malt background to complete this tasty DIPA.

A very rich feeling brew, nicely carbonated to just the right amount. Smooth, almost too smooth for the ABV, the alcohol is very well concealed. Bitterness lingers along with some grapefruit.

Overall quite delicious and certainly something you should try.
Very intense fruity hop aroma. Flavour has rounded malts and a complex hop with plenty of fruitiness. Its thick, syrupy and quite warming.

Bottled sample from public house Las Vegas. This is a big beer with lots of punch. Do not drive after a few of these.

A nice strong, dark beer and excellent for 9% abv. It went well with a good cigar.

Aroma is malt driven and initially biscuity. There is some candied grapefruit rind and black pepper. Darker amber with gold edges. White head becomes a ring leaving splashy lacing. Bt his beer has great blance, the malt has a presence in the taste, really makes the word imperial seem justified. The hops slide into the taste profile riding a wave of malt.  Bouncy citrus hops round out the initial malty biscuit caramel. This behemoth is insanely drinkable.

Pours Golden brown. Aroma of citrus and apples. Very well balanced for a DIPA with a great malt backbone. Hard to top Dogfish Head

A damn sight closer to the 60 than the 120, but still tasty.  The color is amber/yellow, the head is nominal, but theres a decent amount of lacing.  Floral hops and citrus in the aroma. Very aromatic, with notes of grass/ hay.

Pours a golden orange amber. Great hoppy IPA aroma and great taste. Tastes a little bit alcoholic but overall a great IPA. Had 4 pack from holmes

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2012 Outstanding DIPA. I look forward to making this part of my regular roation. 90 IBU but incredibly well balanced with great malty and citrus flavors to compliment the insane amount of hops.
Citrus, floral aroma.  Medium amber color that is cloudy.  Citrus flavor upfront with a nice big hoppy finish.  A big beer but not too overpowering.  Very good beer.

Draft at the Yard House at Costa Mesa, last day og our motorhome tour - pours orangy yellow with a thin head. Aroma of sweet peach and some pineaopple. Taste is sooooo mellow: sweet and bitter at the same time and just in a perfect balance This is TOP IPA! Easily to be put next to Heady Topper & Pliny (if not even better than the latter one). Waauw
Dark orange amber pour with large white head. Strong aromas of hops. A lot more drinkable than expected for such a strong alcohol content.

Malt, with sharp bitterness on back of tongue. Viscous mouthfeel. Not propostourously hopped on the nose, mostly just bitterness. Good ale.

Taste is sweeter than expected. Intense hints of honey... full-bodied, smooth, and creamy on the oalate. Subtle hops flavor, very complex. Certainly not the best IPA Ive ever had, but its very good.

Unfortunately this didnt live up to my expectations.  A fine beer for sure but not "perhaps the best IPA in America" for me.  Great aroma, color and pour.  Too dry for me which kind of muted whatever complexity and boldness of flavor there might be.  Tasted a bit of what I imagine wet ashes would taste like.  Due to the great ratings this beer usually gets, Ill surely try again as I respect the brewery and the rating system here.  Perhaps my taste buds are off tonight.

Easily one of the best IPA aromas Ive ever encountered - has the citrus of Bells Two-Hearted, but with a great malt backbone as well.  Also hints of pine, floral notes, and perhaps a bit of candi sugar.  All of this without being overpowering.  I sniffed this beer for several minutes before finally sipping it!  Head is absolutely fantastic, and the bubbles of lacing are everywhere consistently.  So far, living up to the hype - now, will the taste?  Full-bodied, sweet, creamy, smooth, hops coming in at the finish.  Full-flavored, and yet so SMOOTH!  Sweet malts and hops last full well after each sip.  Very close with Ruination, but I think I have to give this the edge overall - its a clear victor in aroma, and it compares equally, or almost equally, well in all the other facets.  Geez, I wish this was available at my local - had to special order this, and I just have four bottles!  Must!  Savor!

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2013 Bottle bought at de bierkoning. Pours a honeycolored liquid with a medium offwhite head that lasts forever and leaves alot of lacing when it finally disappears. Alot of citrus and hops in the nose. Insanely thick and rich mouthfeel. Sweet honeylike taste. Alot less extreme than I expected, hopwise. But definately enjoyable, will buy again!

Colour of honey with a good pale head that leaves a slight lacing. Aroma is citrus, tropical fruit, pineapple, honey. Slick and slightly  sticky mouthfeel, very well balanced on the palate, sweet with a balanced citrus bitterness that slowly swirls around the palate - long finish with several layers of hop character but never overwhelming. Taste is orange marmalade, pomelo, honey, papaya. Im normally not a fan of IPAs but this was awesome.

Pours a apricot color with a white head. The nose is caramel, malt, floral apricot and orange skin.  The pallet is very balanced. In the middle there is an astringent orange peel, rose petals, Brussels sprouts and finishes with a subtle bitterness that lingers but not over the top... As you drink more the bitterness does build though.

Pours a semi-clear light amber/copper with a 1 inch head that lingers for a little bit before fading away to a nice lacing. Aroma is complex citrusy hops. Taste is very much the same, although hop bitterness does not dominate this beer as much as with others. Has a nice lingering aftertaste that lets you savor this beer over a very long period of time. Overall, this is certainly better than the 60 minute IPA and has a nice boost to the ABV, but I do not personally think that it is worth the significant increase in cost.
12 ounce bottle for my birthday, floral aroma and flavor, nice bitterness and punch.
Wonderful dark carmel aroma with droplets of fruit, flower, and herbs.  Complex aroma continues to the very end of this bold and refreshing IPA.
This has to be the best ipa Ive tried so far. To describe this ipa is impossible. It is the most pleasant experience could possibly have in your mouth.

12 oz bottle. Pours a clear copper/orange with light persistent head and lots of carbonation. Aromas of malt, light citrus, and bread dough. Similar flavors with additional honey and pine notes. Lingering bitter finish. Good classic IPA.

Clear light copper pour with a nice clean-looking white head.  I am hit with lively aromas of pine and apricots, white grape, raw dough, citrus and a little spicy sweetness. What a flavour!  Woody, creamy caramel and toffee, toast crust, bright hop bitterness.  The fine balance between bright and rich flavours is the great achievement of this brew says I.  Finish is long with a boozy, bready ending.  Not hard to see why this beer is famous.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I saw the blurb and I thought "Mere puffery sprinkled liberally with bollocks." and then I sampled:
Appears amber with a marshmallowy creamy white head that left good lace. I certainly did not expect the cake-like aromas that I got when I stuck my (sizeable) nose over the glass and snorted. Like sniffy sherry cask finished whisky along with mandarin, tangelo, cut spruce logs and green cones. Some fresh alcohols, but the predominance is toward glace citrus peel and all sorts of lovely rich dessert. The flavour was another leap altogether. Creamy oranges and green grasses matched with persistent sherbet carbonation and a silky body. It is unctuous and viscous and gives a good whack of bitterness. The finish is enduring and brings out fruit salad laced liberally with golden rum, lychee and creamy orange.
I loved everything about this beer except the emptiness of the bottle. Do I agree with the labelling? Not entirely as I think the Sauvignon Blanc comparison is off (I live near Marlborough and Sav is too light, too fresh). More like Viognier with its tropical fruit and nectarine, which is also present in the finish.
Just a remarkable, remarkable beer.

This definitely is one of the best IPAs Ive had.  The mouth-feel kind of reminds me of Centennial IPA from Founders in that its slightly oily.  While I tend to prefer the mouth-feel similar to the 60 minute and Stones IPA when Im drinking this style of beer.  That aside, I cant think of anything else that remotely turns me off.  The first thing that struck me: malt and hops are so well balanced.  Citrus notes from the hops give way to raisins and a bit of caramel from the malt and then finishing with a clean, bitter hop flavor that doesnt linger too much.  This is phenomenal.  The flavors are so well rounded with just enough of that lingering hoppy bitterness to not be cloying.  This coming from a person who is really picky about his IPAs.
A fine fine IPA, not to hoppy and Im someone who hates the bitter hoppiness.  Go easy, at 9% theyll have  you feeling a bit cloudy in no time!

Bottle, 355ml - Clear golden beer with a large head. Aroma is fruity with notes of lychee, mango, passion fruit and toast. Flavor is fruity with notes of grass, passion fruit, citrus and some minty notes. Overall a fantastic beer, slightly dusty perhaps but truly great.

Like its big brother but not so over the top. To me an easier drinking Imperial IPA then most. The ABV on this will get you. Pours rich copper in color with wonderful citrus floral. Great sweet malt balances this out.

Ezer köszönet Aramando 629 a lehetőségért!
 Régen vadásztam már rá, de most végre sikerült találkoznunk, amihez a  Grabanc papája volt a kerítő. Igen zavaros, sötétebb sárga színe van, vékony krémes habbal, ami nálam jó jelnek számít. Illata igen citrusos, gyümölcsös. Íze - ahogy általában a dupla ipáknak - igen édeskés és tele van trópusi gyümölcsökkel, malátás, ami lassan átkúszik borókás és gyantás keserűségbe. Utóíze pedig férfiasan kesernyés, citrusos és száraz. Remek!

Grapefruit aroma. Pours light honey gold with a bright white head. Caramel sweet hint with dried fruit overtones.  Strong grapefruit hops which lingers on the finish. Another Dogfish Head IPA that this guy who doesnt like IPAs likes.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2012 Pours brownish red, clear, with creamy head. Smells of alcohol and citrus. Flavor is sweet with serious alcohol warmth. Nice and bitter on the tongue. Good dipa from Dogfish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I love it. Im not great at describing beer in general but its delicious and enjoyable

Smells citrusy with a little bit of bread scent.  Looks like a medium orange, a little hazy, tiny bubbles throughout, with a nice frothy offwhite head.  Has a medium sweetness with a heavy bitterness, with the bitter coming through more strongly on the aftertaste.  medium body, slick feel, lively carbonation on the tongue,  long bitter finish.

Dont get me wrong.  This is an outstanding IIPA.  Its got all the elements you need for it to be a beautiful brew.  The only qualm I have is that the aroma doesnt come through as much as the taste does for me.  Its sweet and has some citrus notes, but it doesnt have the same impact on my nose that something like Hopslam or Hop Stoopid did.  Its a pretty dark clear color with some frothy white head to start which dissipates and leaves some moderate lacing.  Its oily and medium bodied.  Flavors of citrus and some mango as well as apricot.  There is some lingering alcohol on the tongue, but not too bad.  I havent tried the 60 yet, and will do so next.

Pours a transparent brown-orange, frothy white head, minimal visible carbonation. Aroma: Very subtle. Vanilla, raisins, lemon, nuts. Palate: Medium bodied, slightly oily, a bit watery, slightly dry finish. Very pleasant. Taste: Slightly sweet, fades quickly to quite bitter, and then back to sweet for the finish. Probably the most well balanced IPA Ive ever had.

Poured from 12oz. bottle into my Founders snifter.

A: Pours a deep amber color with a creamsicle head with great retention. Slowly leaving revealing a nice lace. Very carbonated on sight.

S: Sweet citrus hops, light fruit. Malted barely throughout the middle and sweet little miniature kick of a tight booze all the way in the back, but you have to dig for it.

T: Bitter hops with a sour citrus through out. Strong barley in the middle with the slightest burn on the back end.

M: Light to medium body. Prickly mouth feel with a carbonation that can be a little overpowering at the beginning, but tones down rather nicely.

O: Very nice DIPA and the taste doesnt fall very far off from the smell. I enjoyed it very much.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-17-2011
Bottle. Malts- caramel and some sweetness, green hops tones. Bitterness assertive.. Pines. Quite light, easily drunk.-- bb/h
Bottle to snifter.  Looks good; amber with white head.  Smells and tastes of floral hops and sweet malt with an average mouthfeel.  Nice.

Bottle @SBWF12.  Poured deep golden with a white head. Very piney, fruity, slightly sweetish aroma. Caramel, pine, tropical fruitiness in the flavor. Smooth, very easy to drink. Biting, bitter citrusy finish.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2014 Draft: beautiful amber with a cream colored head.  Aromas are dark fruits and citrus.  Flavor is like a nice sweet bread, studded with fruit and drizzled with a bitter citrus sauce.  Delicious and so well balanced. Awesome.

355ml bottle, New Zealand. Deep orange gold pour with a creamy, frothy lasting head. Body is slightly sparkling with a little chill haze. It looks delicious. Aroma is light hops, hint of perfume, big spruce/pine, a little light breadiness, a hint of caramel, then lovely fruits - pineapple, vanilla, melon, strawberry. Taste is sweet with some fruitcake character up front with a very long, quite bitter and malty fruit finish. Surprisingly light body and smooth, quite dry mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Superbly balanced and ridiculously drinkable.
Bottle into glass. Nice clear dark amber. Quite a bit of carbonation. Crisp with a lot of undertones to the flavor. Very full of flavor. Finishes clean with almost no aftertaste. Amazing beer.
One finger head, off white, mostly diminishing, light amber orange color, Carmel hop flavor.  I like this beer.

Draft offering..good constant to pair with a burger for a one and done..wouldnt buy this in bulk because it just is too sweet and missing little sumpin sumpin to make this extraordinary..after having some world class doubles lately this just comes up short IMHO..is very nice at the brewpub thru the Randall, kicks it up a notch...

This is one of my absolute favorite beers of all time!  Id have to say I even love it more than my original favorite the sixty minute.  It is strong, yet retains a very unique balance of flavors within.  I just wish they would sell it in more than four packs here in Pennsylvania.

Since Ive never tasted the Plinys (bucket list), this is far and beyond the best IPA Ive ever had, (double triple, whatever).  Intense flavor overpower the hoppiness that can sometimes ruin IPAs, and it goes down incredibly smooth, it almost feels like it leaves a lace on your throat.  Simply amazing.
draft. pours clear orange with large white head. lots of citrus and malt in the aroma. taste is fruity and bitter lots of sugary hops too sweet of an ipa for me
For being commonly available in my area, its hard to beat the taste and punch of the 90 minute.

From bottle. Pours a deep amber Orange colour with a thin yet persistent head. Inviting aroma of fresh hops, grass, oranges. Well balanced flavor. Initial malts are south and bready leading to a tight hop flavor that belies the imperial nature of this brew. This beer lives up to its reputation and imo is worthy of it not for being groundbreaking or an eye opener but is a superb example of an iipa.

Soo darned sticky! this borders on non IPA-ness for me. I know its a DIPA but the hops are relatively subdued and the malts are at more present. Aroma is pine, spruce, juniper, light citrus. pours yellow. taste is sticky dank sweet malts. Palate is clingy. not going out of my way for this again.

bottle in Milwaukee.  One of the greatest beers ive ever had.  sweet and strong.  bitter and friendly.  warming.  wonderful aroma.  it is a travesty that Minnesota does not get dogfish head beer.  id buy this twice a week.

355ml bottle, bottled 07/06/12. Pours a slightly hazy deep amber color with a small eggshell white head. Aroma is sweet malt, biscuit, slight honey, pine resin, a litte ripe tropical fruit and caramel. Beautiful balance. Taste pretty much follows the nose with a slight grapefruit bite. Medium carbonation, smooth. Nice.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2012 Hazy Dark Amber with a strong haze. Has a strong aroma of chocolate, caramel, malts, and mild citrus hops. Flavor is solid citrus hops, sweet caramel, toffee, chocolate and malts. Body is thicker and slighty chewy, but since it has little carbonation, its very creamy and smooth. Its very tasty and easy-to-drink Imperial IPA and definitely worth drinking
My current favorite beer. Less citrusy than their west coast counterparts. Fantastically balanced dipa.

Pours a very nice clear amber orange with a finger of off white head and nice lacing. Aroma is pine, orange, pineapple, apricot, lemon, and a slight breadiness. Flavor is a complex mix of tropical fruit, grapefruit, caramel, toffee, apricot, and oranges. Medium mouthfeel with moderate alcohol burn, finishes somewhat dry, but a bit sweet as well. Fantastic beer.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2013 perfect golden amber color, good carbonation.  nice smell of hops.  Strong flavor sits on top/back of tongue with a long finish.  Have to be in the mood for a strong, hoppy beer.  sweet.  much better on tap than in a bottle.
Golden amber.  Strong malt aroma pairs with the citrusy hops.  Detected a lotnof alcohol smell also.  This kept me from rating it any higher.  Nice viscocity.  Very drinkable and smooth.

Smooth and tasty best describes this IPA.  Extremely fragrant and balanced very well it goes down just a little to easy when your trying ton savour every sip.  I think the method that goes behind making all dogfish brews adds to the overall experience as well which makes this beer so interesting.
UPDATED: APR 3, 2016 On tap at Cigar bar Ft Myers. Really big beer. I like how its big on malts and not just a hop bomb. Filling and slightly boozy. Sipper that satisfies.

Aroma of hops and caramel, hoppy-caramel... Yum! Appearance: Looks a lot like a good grade maple syrup but with a thin white head. Taste-wise  it is a bit harsh and cloying but still quite drinkable and even enjoyable at times, you just need to remember that an IIPA can be balanced toward malt. Flavors were not defined as well as the 60 minute and Im still partial to this one. DFH does good beer but this one is just a bit too heavy.
Little to no aroma inherent after pour into glass, darker amber color, slightly boozy but that is to be expected given 9% ABV, wasnt as crisp as Id like in an IPA, potentially due to bottle
This is as close to perfect as there is. This is the one that hooked me into the world of double ipas. The caramel malt middle is so money. The balance is impeccable. Liquid sex

Pours a hazy orange color with a one finger slightly of white fluffy head. Good head retention. Aroma is very hoppy, pine, grapefruit, sweet maltiness, no alcohol at all present in aroma. Taste is very nice! Piny hops with a nice malt background, sweet malts, definately some grapeforward notes in this one. I get grass in the taste aswell. All in all a very nice DIPA from DFH!

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2012 Deep amber, no head; hops and alcohol on the nose; plenty of hops, citrus, orange marmalade flavour with a malty backbone; lots of taste and balance; slightly sweet; hoppy finish; impressive.
Great beer, solid aroma at first. Alcohol content does not overwhelm, hard to believe its 9%

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2014 One of my favorite IIPAs, right up there with Abrasive. Had my fill this summer when in Delaware. Great hoppy flavor with a nice malt to it that is less sweet than the 60-minute and less harsh than the 120. Well balanced and delicious.

Rerate: this isnt very good compared to other ipas I have had that I consider excellent.  Too malty!

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2016 "Strong Beer" or Imperial IPA 9%abv. A: Tall, persistent tan head, medium density foam, persistent. Old gold, refulgent, shiny, limpid, light color.
Full body and high flavor concentration, high heat with high (but well woven) alcohol reminds one of barley wine or spirits, lingering flavor. Despite high hops, balance is only moderately bitter due to the "ridiculous" amount of malt, crosp acidity. 
Hoppy, malty, molasses-malt taste and aftertaste, grapefruit, sweet-sour like apricots. A favorite. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured out of a bottle
Light amber in color with large off white head
Malty sweetness and alcohol nose
Great lacing
Sweet taste balanced with hops
Full mouthfeel

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Again!!! I haven't rated this beer before? Fffffffuuuuuuu. 

Just a fuckin great IIPA. Drink it.


Draught at rattle n hum. Clear, pure amber colour with a dense, white cap. Solid lacing. Aroma is nutty/woody, caramel, with a subdued pine fragrance. Alright, not subdued. The aroma is like the pine sap shit that gets stuck on your fingers when you're a kid "exploring in the trees", and this annoying crap is on you so as a kid you need to smell the annoyance, cuz that's what will explain what it is all over your body now. But add to that, your fingers had the sugar from a lollipop dripped all over because you were a veracious fiend of candy consumption, where you slobbered all over the fuggin place. So. Your fingers are coated in the previous lollipop candy stickiness, followed by pine sap adventure. Then an old geezer didn't like your frolicking, so they spritzed you with a bottle of homemade citrus rind extract. What a shitty old fucker! But you never knew tgat later in life, you'd get to use that discipline to your advantage. So, that in mind as a kid, smell your fingers. That's this beer.

The taste is good.... LOL 

Better than good. Highly malty, piney. Just a fuckin great beer. Period. Drink it.
From a bottle. Rich golden hue. Fine head. Toffee and caramel nose. Hops nicely balanced with malt backbone. A real treat.
Great beer hops are nice and smooth, had on tap in San Francisco. Pours clear and has a fruity/citrus aroma.

12 oz bottle poured into a tulip. Seriously, I cant believe Ive never reviewed this one before.

A: Pours a tawny copper color with low clarity. The head not only has a nice texture and offwhite color, but it retains itself in nice fashion, settling down to less than a finger tall. Nice splotches of lacing are left on the glass.

S: Malty. Lots of caramel and toffee notes, with hints of darker fruits, spices, mint, and piny evergreen. It could almost pass for a barleywine at times.

T: Whats malty on the nose...is malty on the tongue. The hop profile only exists to lightly augment the malts, rather than rely on the malt to provide just enough balance beneath crushing waves of grapefruit and pine. Caramel, toffee, and even some milk chocolate provide the initial flavors, before giving way to a faint herbal, dark fruit, and pineapple finish. Gets a little boozy as it warms up.

Looking back on it, I never should have had Burton Baton before getting a chance to (finally) try this. Im finding myself missing some its complexities and drier tannic finish - if not its higher price tag - compared to this ($50 says that this beer was used in the making of Burton Baton), and just isnt that impressive in comparison. On its own merits, however, its still quite good.

M: Really thick and rich, to the point wheres its almost too heavy for the flavors being presented. It presents itself as a sipper rather than a steady drinker, basically, but cutting down the heft could go a long way to increasing its drinkability. Still, I love how creamy it feels on the palate.

O: Pretty enjoyable, all told. This is the DIPA Id use to wean hop haters onto the general style, but personally I want a little more pizzazz. It also doesnt seem to suffer from age like other IPAs do, and its available pretty much everywhere in my area. Recommended, but not my favorite DIPA by any stretch.

There is nothing bad to say about this beer. Consistently excellent, with a balance difficult to find in IIPAs.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Very similar to Dogfish 60 minute IPA, but much heavier, with 9% ABV.  Frankly, this beer slowed me down.  Very tasty, but I had to slow my usual drinking cadence down to small sips at time.  This is definitely a sipping beer, whereas the DF 60 minute is a drinking beer.
Read with caution:  I do not like IPAs.  This is just another IPA that I didnt like.  Better than the Devil Dancer triple IPA, but still too hoppy for me.

I can't complain.. This beer is delicious and complex, with a great texture. Though I am unsure why it is called an Imperial IPA, as I get more sweet malt character, then dry hop character... Rich, toasty, malted bread notes and caramel, first hit the nose, with undertones of deep orange citrus. On the palate, the rich malt character continues, with a concentrated mix of sweet orange, caramel and mild, toasty character. A lingering finish of orange and caramel sticks in your mouth for minutes. This is not your classic "West Coast" style IPA.. Not that that is bad.. This is actually easier to drink then many of the over hopped versions, even though the palate is thicker and richer, and more full bodied then some IPA's... yet it's not at all sticky like some IPA's. This beer manages to be concentrated, without the heavy feeling of being concentrated.. Smooth, smooth, smooth..

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...
Pours a hazy amber with a 2 finger head that quickly disapates. Nose is bready and a little funky. Taste isnt that hoppy for a DIPA and has a huge malt backbone.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2014 Amber pour. Cream colored medium head. Complex hop aromas. Great full bodied consistency. Complex aroma carries over to a more complex flavor of hops and malts in perfect balance. One of the best beers on earth. ---Rated via iPhone

The best IPA I have had so far. IPA is my favorite style of beer. This has one of the most unique tastes to a beer I have had. And at 9% alc. you wouldn't even know it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Only dogfish beer I have tried, Definitely the best IPA I have had, a bit strong but very well balanced.  Give a great buzz also
Stockholm Beer & Whisky Festival 2011. Clear golden beer with a offwhite head. Hoppy and brown sugar aroma. Hoppy, malty and citrus flavour.
The perfect one of the minute series for Dogfish head. Coming out of a tap made this beer even better than the bottle. The perfect balance of strength and flavor comes when drinking this beer.

Pours amber with a thick white head. Aroma is full of citrusy hops. The taste is smooth at 9%. Its citrusy upfront with a malty finish. The hops are present but not overwhelming & it leaves just a hint of its potency at the finish. A very good IPA!

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2012 Bouteille 12 oz. achetéé au IGA de Potsdam, NY. 9%. Couleur ambrée dorée,claire comme leau de source, mousse blanche. Arôme de grains, herbes, un peu de caramel, houblon. En bouche, douce et mielleuse. Notes de malt, pain, houblon, fruits jaunes. Finale un peu amère, maltée. Excellente...une grande bière.
From bottle to tulip. My favourite IPA so far! NIce apperance, great taste with lots of hops! No alcohol taste at 9%!
Hazy orange colour and off-white head. Fruity and hoppy aroma and flavour. Very good, but I marginally prefer their 60-minute.
Pours a copper color. Smell is very hoppy.. Taste is hops, some malts and citrus, alcohol becoming more pronounced as it warms. Overall a decent beer.
This is a good IPA, but I am not as crazy about it as everyone else. While definately hopped, I think it needs a little balance from malts to help with its complexity.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2014 Fruity nose.  Poured from bottle into a pilsner glass at Barclay Prime, Philadelphia, Pa.  Impressive persistant carbonation.   Strong beer but with a light feel.  Great start to a great meal.

Bottle (12 oz). Clear orange with a small creamy white head and some lacing. Aroma of malt, hops, citrus and pine. Flavor is moderate sweet and hoppy with malt, citrus, pine, pepper and herbal notes. Creamy mouthfeel but its drying the palate. Refreshing and well balanced. Very good malty DIPA.
Pours an orange amber colour with slight head.  Aroma has some pine hops and strong alcohol.  Taste is very strong bitter with some citrus notes.  Very intense.

pours a deep orange with a foamy white head. lots of malt followed by some nice earthy and citrusy aromas all deliver in full force in a deep and complex flavour ranging from heavy caramel and toffe to stone fruit and citrus all rounded out with a lovely warmth from the high abv. definitely not dissapointed.

The aroma is malty sweet with some mild pine and alcohol scent. The appearance is a orange with little carbonation almost flat and full looking white head that does not last . Leaves little lacing. 9% alcohol and it is very easy to drink very clean citrus heavy malt leaves the mouth with a little sweetness. Awesome beer.
Nice silky smooth hop aroma. Nice smooth flavour. Bit of an alcohol burn to it.

I smell the malt for sure smells very malty sweet and very full body. I can smell a hint of hops. The color is a hazy copper color bout right for an ipa right?   Very full body seems to expand on your tounge. Has a malty flavor and the hops comes in strong but not over powering. A good flavor a decent imperial brew.

A-- Poured an orange carmel color with a light brown head. Moderate carbonation, with a big 2 finger head that took a while to dissipate. Left some nice sticky and fairly thick lacing on the glass. Looks in very good shape!

S-- Big carmel malt smell to start that let way to pine and grapefruit. The more it opened up the more the grapefruit took over and the malt took a back seat. 

T-- Pretty big malt blast to start, then came the hops. It is as if the hops are waiting to be unleashed. Very much there but they sit in the background until the right time. More of a lemon taste with touches of grapefruit.

M-- Now the hops...Big citrus and pine feel to it. Have a sort of menthol feel when after I swallow and then breathe in. Very coating and thick in my mouth. Get a good amount of sweetness to this that was not in the taste.

D-- Very drinkable.Plain and simple. Well hidden ABV and just tasty. 2 would be just right for this. Still one of the best US beers that every so often shows up in Australia and makes me want to move back.

Bottle at Great British Beer Festival. Clear dark gold pour with a thinnish white head. Nose is tropical fruits - mango, pineapple, grapefruit. In the mouth and those fruits all meld together with some generous warm malts, incredibly smooth. Bitter hop explosion almost comes out of those nose. You can feel the dry hopping in this classy IPA.

Big head and a decent amount of lace. Clear golden amber in color. Smell is citrusy with an overlay of orange and light pine. Taste is well balanced with a healthy malt core. quickly followed by an powerful wave of hops. Caramel sweetness and hunks of lightly toasted barley bread. A spread of butter. Finish is smooth and dry with a oily hops lingering . Feel is somewhat thick and chewy with a velvety smooth carbonation.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2012 Plenty of caramel taste followed by chocolate, herbs, and vanilla. This is one of the hoppiest beers Ive ever tasted. Except the hop taste in this beer is clean, refreshing, and uplifting. Sooo many hops! I payed $12 for 4 bottles, and each beer was easily worth the price. Amazing beer created by an amazing company.
Very smooth for a high abv brew.  I have been looking forward to trying this one for months.  Not dissapointed at all.
This is one of my favorite IPAs. Dogfish Head knows how to brew a damn good IPA. I still have yet to try the 120 minute but coming from a hop head this beer is damn good

12 ounce bottle.  I like the 60 minute from Dogfish, so its no surprise I like the 90 minute too.  Its one of the first beers Ive liked with a pine taste as the main attraction.  Usually the pine tastes more like Lysol than fresh hops.  Here, they pull off the hops presence really well.  This is a good example of an imperial IPA that doesnt taste like grapefruit juice.  The only thing that drags it down is the lack of any aroma.

Pours a golden with a full and frothy white head.  Aroma consists of grapefruit, orange, pineapple, and raisin.  Its actually a bit tame.  Leaves a floral impression here.  Moving to the taste, the floral impressions disappear and is instead more fruity, most notably orange and pineapple.  Alcohol tasting undertones let you know how potent this really is.  Medium bodied.  Not as hoppy as most IPAs, and lacks that bitter hoppy kick.  Not bad at all, but I expected more.

Hazy copper to orange. Hops and malt balance nicely earthy citrus peel combine with malts but are each distinguishable.  Superb 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 12oz.
Pours golden/brown with high creamy ligth beige head. Aroma is of malt, citrus, tropical fruits.Taste is of malt, citrus, tropical fruits, alcohol. Overall: Good body. High bitterness, but not too grapefruit-like. A very good, seriously malty, Imperial IPA.
Mmm, very tasty stuff. Great, balanced hops, on the heavy end, but not too boozy. Complex and delicious.

Bottle. This pours a clear orange colour with a beautiful, big white head on top. Aroma has tropical fruits, anice, a small piney background a sweet malty overall smell to it. Awesome. Mouthfeel is a bit sticky and juicy, making you want to drink it fast. Flavour has a lot of juicy hop presences and a lot of tropical fruits. Abricots, peaches and apples are all present in the flavour. This is incredibly easy to drink, despite being 9%. Defintely worth my money (it was expensive). Minor setback btw, I could not find a date on the label or bottle.

Bottle. Deep earthy and citrus hop, some minor fumes, thick malt, and a little bit of fish. Clear pretty orange-gold, 2-cm head, and a creamy head with fat bubbles. Sweet fruitness: peach and mango. Mid palate is thick and sweet. Final is very well balanced. Bitter aftertaste goes on quite some time. Medium-heavy body. Approaches barley wine in sweetness. A whole lot packed into this brew.

Sight: Brandy snifter; dark copper color, modest head, crystal clear. 

Aroma: Not excessively hoppy, but floral, citrus and toasted malt notes present. 

Feel: Somewhat silky, not oily, low astringent; enough cleansing for the next bite of food. 

Taste: Maple, chocolate with some vanilla notes, middle, nice malt to hop balance.  Citrusy, orange note finish. 

Overall, I am a big fan of this Imperial IPA since I first had it 2 yr. ago. It is a perfect 'last one (or 2)' of the night. Can't really session it, I believe it is meant to be something special, and it is. A sipper to be enjoyed and savored with your better half during a Blu-ray viewing of your favorite flick, or whatever relaxes you. If you have it available in your region, get a 4 pack, if not, find a relative or friend who lives where it is sold and have them get some to you





Taste: Toasted malt,

I can find nothing wrong with this beer. It's a well-balanced, citrusy and, if had in the bottle, malty IPA. Having had it both on tap and in the bottle, I must say I prefer it in the bottle as it conditions the beer and brings out the malts. On tap the malts are minimal and grapefruit is the dominant flavor.

36cl, American brew, thx to Secret Santa!, complex bitter brew, bitter/malty and slightly spicy/sweet, balanced, clear, good head, good brew, yet expensive

It poured  a clear copper color with an off-white head. The aroma was of pine, grapefruit, some herbs and caramel. The taste was moderately bitter sweet, clean and crisp with a strong hop presence, citrus and pine. A very good DIPA.

12 oz bottle poured into a wine glass. Mouth watering aroma of pine, hops, and citrus. Beautiful orange color with a small beige head. Very complex taste of raisins, oranges, honey, berries, and tasty hops! Smooth palate that hides most of the alcohol taste. Probably my favorite of all beers at this point in my beer journey. Delicious!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
355ml bottle. Pours golden with a white head. Hoppy, malty aroma with apricots and some pine. Very fruity and malty flavour. Sweetish finish.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 6/25/2012.  Pours fairly crystal clear golden orange color with a nice 2 finger dense cream colored head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Some nice foamy lacing clings to the glass.  Aromas of grapefruit, orange rind, herbal, floral, pine, caramel, biscuit, mango, peach, toast, and earthiness.  Very nice and well balanced aromas with good strength and complexity.  Taste of big grapefruit, orange zest, pine, herbal, floral, caramel, toast, biscuit, peach, mango, and earthy spiciness.  Good amount of smooth and spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of citrus, caramel, biscuit, toast, nuttiness, pine, peach, mango, and light herbal spiciness on the finish for a good bit.  Fantastic balance of pronounced caramel and toasty malt sweetness, with smoothly bitter hop flavors; very good flavor complexity and balance as well.  Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a pretty creamy, slick, and lightly sticky mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a highly excellent DIPA.  The English two row adds a nice unique dimension to the flavor profile; and it has a very smooth balance of hoppiness with the malt profile.  Highly enjoyable, and I am glad I was able to get this really fresh for this re-review after not having had this one for a couple years.

I will always be able to recognize dogfish head beer...alcohol first, hops next then beer. I love it. Precursor to the 120. A great beer. Muscular IPA with just under a 120. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sweet, crisp, slightly grassy nose, hints of hay and bread. Strong malty base to the aroma. Thin head dissipated immediately. Opaque amber in colour, fairly low carbonation. Deep bitter taste, with a slightly syrupy sweet edge. Long bitter finish.

Overall a very solid IPA, but the aroma didnt grab me like some other double IPAs/imperial IPAs Ive had recently.

12oz bottle poured into a Karmaliet tulip glass. Pours a clear amber color with a slight dissipating head with a bit of lacing. Aroma and taste are mostly sweet malt. Ive had this before but I dont remember it being this sweet. I was expecting a bit more hops based on the 60 minute. No alcohol burn. Smooth beer. Very tasty

Pours a clear golden color.  Aroma is a little pine, sweet malt, and alcohol.  The aroma is definitely not this beers strong point which is fine with me since taste is of the utmost importance.  Having said that, the taste is excellent and for some reason this one is extra tasty today (I have had many of these in the past).  I am going back and forth between this and a Sierra Nevada Torpedo and the one difference I really notice is the malt presence in the 90 minute.  My taste buds are somewhat hindered at the moment from other beers but this seems to have a very nice balance between hops and malt.  I really enjoy hops but the malt seems to be keeping the extreme bitterness under control in a thoroughly enjoyable way.  The body is medium and the finish is much less bitter than one would expect from a beer of this style.  I have a few of these left, and will revise this review if I think it is inaccurate, but as of right now this is one good beer.

12oz into snifter
A Amber, very little head
S Malty and a bit floral, not the nose I was looking for
T Malty sweet, a bit floral, a bit almost maple syrup like, not much in the way of hops.
M Undercarbed, thick
O This bottle is almost 4 months old, need to try a fresh one.

Serving type: bottle
This is the beer that began my love of IPAs! Its extreme hoppiness is well balanced with the malts in my opinion. My only regret is that I cannot find it where I currently live.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2012 An awesome malty aroma, strong bready and caramel flavors.  Maybe the bottle has to be young, but there is little hop aroma present in this beer, maybe a slight floral hop aroma.  Per the Imperial IPA style, this is a very enjoyable and drinkable beer, not as harsh and overpowering as some IIPA?s.
UPDATED: APR 3, 2013 This is the smoothest of the DIPAs. The continual hopping really does blend the bittering and flavoring hops perfectly. Well balanced against a flavorful malt backbone.
