UPDATED: MAR 9, 2012 A gorgeous brew. Crystal clear bronze in color with a thin off-white head. Slight citrus aroma. Tastes slightly fruity.  Very smooth on the palate.

Aroma: Dried fruit bread, Mild spice notes

Appearance: Deep orange foamy pale white head 

Taste: Like fruit cake only it taste good, it is rich bright and floral not at all biter quite sweet

Palate: Easy to drink, thick with moderate carbonation


Overall: fantastic

The aroma is full of citrus hops with some resin and floral notes as well.  The beer also presents a slightly bready smell. The cor is golden to amber with a nice white head and continously streaming bubbles.  The taste really pops. At first hread notes meet citrus hops and are followed by a resin pine taste and finishes with floral ambiance.  The palate is medium to full with nice carbonation. Overall a great beer.  Perfect with creamy brie and the sweet herbal notes of tomato dill soup.

Bottle ordered from beersofeurope. I would categories it somewhere between an IPA and a DIPA. It has the body and the hopburst of an DIPA and the freshness, almost juice citric character of an IPA. Whatever! A great beer anyway. Lots of juicy grape, pine and bitterness matched by body of caramell, raisin and fruitcake that never feels to sweet. Fantastic.

Pours a clear orangy tan with a medium (but fading) white head.  Aromas of caramel, candy sugar and ripe tropical fruit (especially pineapple).   A strong malt sweetness hits first with a follow through of the pineapple and caramel along with raisins, cotton candy and a light vanilla flavor.   Cutting through that sweetness is a nice piney bitterness that keeps things from getting too cloying.  Theres even a slight mustiness in the background thats really interesting.  As it warms, the hops come through as an underlying vegetal flavor.  Leaves with a perfect mix of sweet and bitter.  A great beer from a great brewery.

On tap.  A nice golden color with a white head.  It has an aroma of hops with a lot of caramel and malt.  It has a malty sweet taste with plenty of strong hop citrus and bitterness with a nice, round aftertaste.  A great, rich IPA.
Smoothest IPA I have ever had. Not overly bitter, beautiful honey gold color, no head, strong aroma of Hops. An old favorite.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of pine hops, citrus, & some fruit; Flavor of sweet malt, caramel, rich pine hops, and citrus (notably orange & some grapefruit); Finish is bitter with some alcohol; Nicely balanced; Similar to a barley-wine; Overall, excellent DIPA.
Bottle. Pours amber with a thin offwhite head. Smelly of hops, some sliught citrus notes. Tastes remarkably light for 9%.  Hoppy but not as bitter as id expect. Solid.

Decisamente las cervezas de Dogfish me estan enamorando,quiero probarlas todas,las primeras dos me han impresionado,la stout de 18 grados me encanto y me tome ahora la 90 minute ipa y me quede doblemente encantado,una cerveza fantastica,un olor a malta y un mix de frutas incluidos citricos te da un deseo de degustarla rapido ,su cuerpo suave pero redondo esconde bien el alto grado de alchool envolviendo el paladar con aromas a malta,lupulo, fruta y un toque de citricos. Muy recomendada esta en el listado de  mis mejores cervezas
user_location: SANTIAGO DE LOS CABALLEROS, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

text:
Stuck with a bit of an oldie 10/24/08.

Pours a nice copper color with a big white head. The hops are much more subdued from when I drank this fresh with alot more carmel malt showing through. Mouthfeel is thic and almost creamy with little hops across the palate. Light citrus and as I drink it the hops are showing up more in the finish.

This beer like many other DIPAs needs to be fresh and I know my review would be better if it were. Overall as always a solid beer.

Pours clear amber with half finger head and good retention.  Aroma is rich candy caramel, toffee, raisin, resin, pine.  Taste is candy sweet pine, toffee, caramel, some grapefruit on the finish but incredibly well balanced throughout.  Body is medium-heavy, below average carbonation, thick oily juicy mouthfeel, long bitter resinous finish, warms the throat.  Overall, when Dogfish Head sticks to brewing "normal" beers, they hit it out of the park every time and this is perhaps the best example in their fleet.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2013 Pours a hazy orange with an off white head and aroma of grapefruit, pine, and hops. The taste is sweet and of hoppy bittnerness with pine, grapefruit, and citrus that come through very nice to make a flavorful, smooth, and drinkable imperial IPA. Great DIPA

Wow ! Nice hoppy floral aroma, the appearance is a beautiful orange with a small golden vanilla head. Heavy bitter wonderful taste once it hits your palate, however not astringent in the least. Finish follows through rather nicely, a great IPA ! Well balanced, another winner from the brewmasters at Dogfish !
Drank this from a bottle.  I like the balance of flavors and especially like the bitter hoppiness.  Have to take it easy on this one.

Every time I drink this beer, the alcohol kick always sneaks up on me.  The first time I drank it, that really got me into trouble.  Needless to say, this is a very solid beer that I would never say no to.  This imperial IPA shows off a deep caramel color with a fragrant, thick head that gets slightly rocky as it recedes.  In the glass, it has excellent lacing and amazing head retention.  In the nose, you can really smell the residual sugars, malt and an ample, fruity hop kick that has a solid grapefruity twang to it.  There are also notes of pine, passionfruit and pineapple.  There are some other pungent fruity flavors lurking under the nose as well.  On the palate, the beer is thick, creamy and fruity-sweet with a slight alcohol present and more grapefruity hops with citrus zest and melon.  There is an underlying candied sugar quality to it, almost like a musky cotton candy.  Either way, its delicious.   The sweetness doesnt get cloying, but it can make your lips a little sticky.  This beer finishes with more malty fruit and some bitter sweetness.  When you put the glass down, the lacing still remains as a testament to this giant.  Excellent and semi-sessionable.

Aroma- floral hops, big spices, spicy herbal notes, sweet malts, wood
Appearance- sunburnt orange, nice 1.5 finger creamy white head, superb lacing
Taste- dual initial taste of sweet malts and big floral hops, definitely east coast, spicy kick in the middle, end with lingering hops and a certain smoothness
Palate- medium-bodied, near perfect mouthfeel for a DIPA
Overall- Top 3 session beer IMO.  I try to have a 4-pack on hand at all times.  My first experience from DFH was perhaps my favorite.  All that I really want and need in an Imperial IPA.

355ml bottle. Smell is strong hops in the usual pine/spruce/grapefruit sort of way. Aroma is big and bold, but not aggressive. It doesnt attack so much as envelop. Poured orange/amber, somewhere between filtered and cloudy. Hazy, maybe. Decent foamy white head that leaves lots of lacing. Taste is hop bomb, grapefruit and pine sap. It is bitter, but not offensively so. Not a trailing wheels IPA, but a hop head should find it more pleasant than challenge. A little sweetness, like pink grapefruit. Body is thick, but not too think, texture is a little soapy. Dry finish.
Overall: Not sure if this is the best IPA in America, but it is definitely a contender. It is a nice drinking beer.

meh. bottle is about 5 months old, mostly malty. not unpleasent all that much, but has faded hops and a good bit of that 9% shows up feeling quite hot. decent stuff, best very fresh. a classic, but definitely not all that in the end. i think its about time to tweak this recipe and update it a bit.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours deep golden with orange/amber hue and small off-white head.  Small amount of lacing, medium body, sticky texture, and grapefruit aroma.  Taste is light grapefruit and heavy resinous pine.  Too much pine for me and expected more.

355ml bottle poured a golden-orangeish color with small white head and some spotted lacing.  Aroma is lightly toasted malts and hops.  Taste is a toasted malty sweetness and big hop bitterness.  Medium body and moderate carbonation.  Another fine beer which I really enjoyed, but once again I think it is a little overrated on this site.

Dark Amber beer with heavy floral scent, maybe cotton candy with alcohol. Dont get the brandy fruitcake flavor advertised, but this beer is sweet and bitter from start to finish and beyond. Put a few away and you will sleep with the fishes as they say.

Bottle. A fantastic Imperial India Pale Ale. Wonderfull balance with sweet malts at the start taken over by a great hop flavor to the end. Closes with a long lasting bitterness and a touch of alcohol burn.

33cl bottle. Amber orange colour with small to no head. Sweet malty aroma with notes of alcohol and caramel. Some fruity and hoppy notes as well. Flavour is also sweet but more bitterness than the aroma. Alcohol is more prominant as well. Caramel, toffee, malts and some hops. Long lingering aftertaste.

A deep golden brew with lovely bubbly. Pleasant aroma. Flavor is extremely well balanced. Good sweetness but plenty of hoppy bite also. Grapefruit and piney notes. Very filling. 294 calories never tasted so good! Lingering bittersweet finish.

Slighly hazy light amber with a off-white to light yellow head. Very rich in both nose and mouth. A lot of pine and citric fruits from the hops and rich sweet body from the malts. Ends with a nice long bitterness. Altogether very nice balanced.

This is a nice middle of the road I.P.A..  By middle of the road, I mean it is well balanced.  The hops got a little stronger as I got further into the beer, but if hops is what you are after, this brew is first rate

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2012 rerated on april 6th 2012 - 12oz bottle pours clear light caramel with plenty of creamy white head.  Nose is spruce and citrus.  Flavor adds caramel, alcohol, forest fruit and grapefruit.  Taste is dominated by the bitterness, but there is some sweetness to it.  dry finish.  hardly better than I remember it, but I will rate it higher now that better appreciate 2XIPAs.  

Draft in a Trappist glass - pours clear golden with with white head and provides lacing. Nose is citrus hops and ether.  Aroma is more hops(pine or spruce). Sweet for such a hoppy flavor, but does end on a noticeable bitter note.  Dry finish and medium to full body. Does not live up to the hype. 7/4/7/3/12: 3.4
UPDATED: DEC 9, 2012 Not bad. Perhaps too piney for my liking - Could taste the alcohol. A sipper for sure but I dont think Id buy it regularly. Too strong for my taste.
Yet another great IPA by dogfish head, goes down smooth and has a big malt flavor to balance the extreme hopping

Aroma is nice somewhat mild and soft with fruit notes like cantalope /tangerine sweet citrus candy and maybe yeast esters faintly picking up english malt and as it warms spice/herbal seems to show up.Very clear copper reddish orange glow and very clear,creamy lasting head with some lacing.Hop taste is big and about the same as the aroma description with a bit of alcohol and yeast.The bitterness in this is really pleasant alot differnet than most ipas as how it bitters.A good front of the mouth numbing.The carmel taste in this is real nice its fairly sweet but creamy and tastey with the hops and balanced  with a soft  mellow  herbal easy bittering
En botella.Color anaranjado con buena corona y buenos encajes.Aromas a resina y alcohol.En boca es contundente con buen lupulado .El alcohol se nota demasiado.Interesante.

I was expecting a lot from that one. Bright orange with light head. Aroma is honey, toasted cereals, onions and floral. Taste is soapy, light citrus and a hint of alcohol. Thick body. A special one but not my thing. Disapointed.

Flaska på Stockholm beerfestival 2011.
Mycket fruktig doft, ännu mer frukt i smaken. Mycket appelsin och grape. Lång trevlig eftersmak. Mycket god

Unique IPA.  I dont think Ive ever had an IPA that starts out sweet and finishes bitter and at first I wasnt impressed.  I mean who buys an IPA for a malty/amber lager like characteristics?  But after a few sips the hoppy notes shine through.  Easy drinking, just be careful because if you finish the four pack the 9% will keep you from accomplishing much...

Phenomenal... Pours clear amber color with a great head that lasts just long enough to get a couple sips to experience it. Great hop, pine bread aroma. Palate is clean & hoppy with a nice citrus bitter. Yes please, Ill have another...

Ported from BA.

Appearance: 
Light-amber or copper colored. Fairly clear. When first poured not much of a head, but about 10-15 seconds after pouring it rose up to about 1/2" and then quickly settled back down.

Smell:
Hops, hops and more hops! And grapefruit. Smells a tad more sweet than your average IPA. A definite amarillo/simcoe combination. Looking it up, it also contains warrior hops, which dont come through in the aroma quite as clearly as the others.

Taste:
Very sweet while your lips are still on the glass, followed by a buildup of bitterness. Thats where the warrior hops went. A bit like a sour grapefruit, though meant in a complementary way. As the bitterness resides the high alcohol content becomes apparent. While not overwhelming, it definitely tells you that youre not drinking a regular pale ale.

Mouthfeel:
Reasonably smooth, somewhat creamy. The carbonation tickles the tongue a bit, and if it were flatter the creaminess would really come through. The feeling sticks in your mouth for a bit, which is nice because it lets you enjoy this 9% beer a bit more slowly, but still taste and feel it.

Drinkability:
Everything but the ABV and the price makes it very drinkable. If youre a hophead you could probably drink several, but the ABV will limit you if you have to drive home, and the price per 4 pack will limit you if youre on a budget.

Pours a clear orange white a white head that laces slightly. Nice hop profile, not an amazing IIPA but it easy enough to find and very drinkable. Definatly worth grabing if you see it and are in the mood for and IIPA/IPA
Sampled at SB & WF 2011. Golden with a small white head. Smells very hoppy. Tastes sweet hoppy, abit dry with a similar finish.

Better when freshest, the Hop aroma really comes out, and thats what Iam rating, a bottle about 3 weeks old
appeaence nice amber color, head is thick and stays around
taste Strong but not overpowering Hop Flora taste, not bitter at all
smell very Flora which extends itself in the tasting
overall a nice mellow IPA, I would like alittle more Hop bitterness, but never the less a Awesome beer.
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: UPDATED: AUG 11, 2012 Sample @ SBWF on September 29. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Smell is dominated by fresh hops, citrus and some caramel notes. Taste is complex with lots going on. Its quite sweet and malty with fresh grass and some lemon zest. Aftertaste is quite bitter and very nice.

Belle couleur orange brulée, totalement translucide. Au nez le malt crystal, un peu dastringence et dalcool. Au goût on retrouve le raisin en avant, au milieu des fruits plus foncé comme une Quad. La finale est assez sucré avec un kick pamplemousse. Très facile à boire.
Bottle - nice foamy head, medium amber color, outstanding strong hops aroma and flavor, with a decent malth backbone - Excellent beer!
Possibly my favorite. Extremely smooth on the front end. Basically invites you to drink it up. Finishes nice and bitter. Fantastic lacing.

12 oz into pint from carmel mtn bevmo.  Threw in freezer for 35 mins.  Smells of citrus, pine.  Looks amber, red, clear.  Tastes of a strong mixture of bitterness and pretty rough medium bodied darkish pale.  Some thick ale yeas but good.  Overall 9 of 10.

Bottle. Pours orange with nice white head. Smells maltier than hoppy. Same on the taste. A blind test would not have prompted me to call this an IIPA. Its marginally bitter and the flavour is more derived from the Malt than the hops. Good gear.
Bottle. Pours golden with nearly no head. Lots of caramel malt aroma, slight fruity background. Taste is the same. Well balanced and smooth, not overly bitter. Very nice
Beautiful IPA. Hoppy, but not overpowering. Cant really pick up on the raisins that the description provides. Smooth on the palate and still refreshing.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2012 This is an excellent IPA, one of the best Ive had.  Very smooth (belying its alcohol content), rich and fruity.  It is hoppy, of course, but not at the expense of a delicious maltiness.  And it is much sweeter than many other IPAs.  Almost a barleywine, it will sneak up on you.  The only downside to me is that it has too much alcohol (9%), which makes it almost impossible to enjoy more than one bottle without getting tipsy.

As good a beer as Ive ever had. Like other Dogfish head beers my only wish is it had more aroma, but so good. The balance is amazing for a beer this big. Sweet aftertaste is balanced by the incredible hop bite. Far too easy to drink for a 9% beer. Love the toffee and carmel notes in the end.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2016 Great orange--copper color, small head. Nicely balanced hoppy aroma whit caramel notes. The taste is citrusy hops, sweetness with hints of pine with a powerful hop and alcohol finish. The alcohol becomes more pronounced as the beer warms, but it never becomes overpowering or distracting, it rather accentuates the bitterness nicely.

Whammo Blammo thats one hoppy brew! Who let the hops out? Who? Who? Who? Who? Who?!! Hoppy is as hoppy does! One of the most hoppy brews I have tried thus far and the first of the Minute brews from Dogfish Head for me. Nothing overbearing but full of hops from start to finish and loads in between! But given that, its a darned good brew! Theres just enough sweet malts in the background to tame this brew into something I can definitely learn to appreciate!
12oz bottle pours copper/ amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of musky caramel, citrus, and pine. Taste has lots of pine, with citrus and caramel, very strong and heavy. Nice, well rounded.

Ive had a lot of beers in my life, and when I tell you I cant find a better beer for the price, I honestly mean it. This beer is 99.9% without fault and will leave you wanting more. Incredibly smooth, terrific aroma, outstanding color and wonderful hoppiness that exudes from it.

poured from 12 oz. I have been drinking cascade hop IPAs for the past few months and bam along comes this tasty treat. poured an orange haze and cloudy. traditional hoppy aroma and scent of slight pine and leafy. taste is sweet with right kick of hop, and flavors of earthy/leafy flavors. overall very nice
Great beer.  I have been drink good beer now since I was 18 and this is one of the 3 best beers I have tasted!

Outstanding, quite possibly the best IPA I have ever tasted.  Extremely concentrated hop flavors that are robust, yet in complete balance.  A touch of sweetness from the alcohol which is kept in check by fresh, bitter citrussy hops.  

Tasted out of a shaker glass.

Bottle quite graciously given to me by an associate at work. Pours a light copper colour with a fantastic white head. Lacing left behind here and there. Aroma is sweet and hoppy. Taste is bitter but not as much as I was expecting, tastes citrus but nothing in particular I can nail down. Solid.

I dont like IPAs and wasnt expecting to like this one at all.  I was wrong.  This is a very special beer and, like most Dogfish Head offerings, very interesting and unusual.

Id put this on my top 20 list for sure and recommend it whether youre a fan of the style or not.  Its unlike any IPA youll try.

It has a distinct ethyl acetate flavor on the finish but its not displeasing.  Im not sure if thats an intentional note or not but it worked pretty well as far as Im concerned.
Very nice beer.  Starts with a nice sweet roasted nut flavor and ends with some orangey bitter hops.  Very easy on the palate.  Great beer.

I got a four pack of these at small hippie grocery store, so glad i did. This IPA has become one of my favorite beers. It pours a dark golden red color with just the right amount of head. Great smell, caramel hops which is exactly what a good IPA should smell like. The flavor is very complex, again caramel, hops, some malt and assorted fruits and a little maple. The 90 minute is very sweet and easy on the palate while delivering a high abv with just the right amount of carbonation. A truly excellent beer.

12 oz. bottle. Pours dark copper with a large off-white head. Courtesy of Carlson, drunk from a mason jar. The aroma is pine and resin, with creamy, nutty notes. The flavor is very bitter, with a surprisingly well balanced malt profile. The palate is heavy, sticky, and astringent. Overall, this is an amazingly well balanced and flavorful beer.

Pours a deep amber with thin white head.  Nose is flat with elements of citrus hop and graham cracker.  Thick and vibrant mouthfeel with initial sweep of almond and hazel nut moving to a biting coppery and resinous hop explosion which is surprisingly mellow and balanced with a deep toast biscuit.  Nice.
Great IIPA, nice strong hops, can at times feel a bit too raisiny or fruity but thats rare. Overall Id highly recommend this brew. Just take it slow because they can creep up on you fast
Barley on the nose with a really sweet smell.  Amber color in the glass.  Super sweet upfront with a nice clean bitterness at the end.  This stuff is awesome.  Really well done DIPA.

Wow, this is sweet, but its very balanced with the hops. Its like you get a sweetness like from a fruitcake and then the hops just cuts it and balance out the whole thing and doesnt linger for long. Since this is a bottle from May, i dont expect to be as the original. But aroma is peach, pineapple, grapefruit and caramel. Taste is mostly fruitcake, pine, peach, apricot, pineapple. Mouthfeel is great, it leaves me hanging and wanting to come for more, big body. Great beer overall, Ill re-rate this if I find a newer bottle.
Although this is an excellent malt in my opinion, and I enjoy drinking it. I would not call it an exreme IPA.

bottle; clear amber to orange with small whit head; aroma-very sweet, caramel, roasty, raisins and citrus, orange-strong hops; taste-very sweet, medium bitterness and carbonation, strong alcohol. Fantastic beer, complex aroma. Hard to beat
On draft.  A Golden orangish color with a nice head.  A great hop aroma and taste. Clean, refreshing and strong.  A nice example of the style.
Head disappeared almost immediately-pours a nice amber color. Well balanced flavor as well as good density and abv. Overall a great IPA. Definitely something to look for.
Whenever this superb IPA is available at my local pub, its my first choice, every time!

Refreshing hoppiness, crisp, caramel overtones, pleasant alcoholic finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a dark amber with lots of foam head. Aroma is moderately strong pine hops. Lots of sweet malts in the flavor mix. Really balances the agressive hops out to a fully rounded beer. Finishes sticky on the tongue and lingers in the mouth.

I really like the light brown color with an inviting haze. Lots of citrusy hops in the nose. Starts off with a lot of sweet caramel followed by a big hop punch. The hops are there, dont worry about that, but they arent blowing out everything else like I expected.

This is my kind of IPA. Huge hop notes, big bitter finish, but its got some malt to go along with it. Its not like youre drinking hop juice. The 9% ABV warms on the way down, but doesnt have much presence other than that.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2012 Completely different from the 60 minute. Reminds me a bit of 12 vs 18 year aged whiskys and how they differ in character. This one, just like a whisky thats been aged longer, is much rounder, more balanced. Pours amber with fairly big tan head. Aroma is sweet, caramel and vanilla, with a hoppy backdrop but more citrus and orange than bitter grapefruit. Taste is also sweet up front before the hops kick in. You can definitely tell the alcohol is there, but more from the swetness than from direct taste. Body is very rich and creamy with low, subtle carbonation. A very good beer, even though I do prefer my IPAs more bitter and fresh.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2014 Definitely one of the all time greats you have to try, a bit pricy, but the abv makes up for it, dark and complex, yet hoppy and fruity, bitter as well, for the big beers, one of the best you can get.
This Imperial IPA is so good I dont care what it looks like, but it is pretty. Super hoppy but no harsh bitterness. Smooth finish. Will make Sam Adams BL taste like water after you had one of these.

Bottle.  Nice malty aroma with mild citrus.  The taste is full of hop flavor without the lingering bitterness that plagues a lot of IPAs.  The aftertaste is mild malt with whiskey overtones.  Not the best Imperial IPA Ive had but right up there.

Rusty brown pour with about a one finger light brown head. Sweet aroma ripe with caramel malts, and some toffee and biscuit notes. Citrus and pine hops are also very evident. Taste is definitely on the sweet side, thanks to the high alcohol content which really isnt noticeable. A lot of caramel/toffee flavors, backed up by a big hop presence. Finishes bitter, but not uncomfortably so. A completely different beast than the 60 Minute, but still surprisingly drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2011 Powerful beer that develops a big head and smells of green hops (grapefruit) and huge additions of malts (cake, caramel, dried fruits). The taste is very much what the aroma suggests, and the body is full. The malt sweetness is every bit as powerful as the hop bitterness. I wouldnt have known this was above 7% abv. Nice.
Poured a big golden/amber with some lacing. Great balance of sweet malts, some hoppy bitterness and spice notes. Well made yumminess.
My favorite IPA. Probably the biggest head Ive seen. Much lacing in the glass. Bitterness followed by a some sweetness and a fruity taste. Always a have a few on hand.
There is all kinds of stuff going on in this beer, an excellent IPA, one of the best I have had.  Nice aroma, tastes of fruit.

12 oz. bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a crystal clear, amber-orange color with a thin, foamy off-white head that dissipates quickly to a thin layer and lasts throughout. Nice lacing. Aroma is a light citrus hop with a hefty malt backbone. Dark fruits. Slight alcohol. Flavor is actually quite sweet with caramel malt balanced nicely by a substantial citrus hop bitterness. Finish is moderately dry and grassy with a faint oak character, and slightly warming.  Medium to full bodied. Really great Imperial IPA.

pours amber golden with a fine whitish head.  Aroma of clean gentle citrus hops, with a nice, mild soap undertone. Taste starts a mature sweet - definitely getting a brandy or bourbon character.  Fresh dates, caramel too.  Medium body with a really nice oily mouthfeel.  Bitter finish, but not overwhelming, and dry.  Real balanced beer, this one.
Bottle, shared. Originally rated on 28.5.2010. Great, well balanced IIPA. Loads of fruity notes, malts and hops.

Bottle.  Burnt Orange pour with a white head.  Fruity hop aromas.  Great body with bitter fruity hop flavors and a bold caramel malt backbone.  Well done.  Even though this 9%, for me its a session beer:)

It pours a clean golden/amber color with a frothy yet small head, then again I made a pretty safe pour so I might get a little more lacing with a more aggressive pour. The aroma is of citrus and floral hops with a little bit of caramel malts and some dark fruits. In terms of taste all I have to say is wow, its much sweeter than I was expecting the citrus and floral hops are perfectly balanced with the caramel malt and dark sticky fruits little sign of alcohol except for the warmth. The palate is sticky and medium to almost full bodied yet its smooth and refreshing.
A perfectly balanced IPA with medium bitterness, smooth body and a very good ending. Aromas of raisins and citrus. On eof the best imperial IPAs around.

Pours an amber colour with a frothy head which leaves nice lacing. Aroma is sweet dark fruit, malt and some caramel. The taste is also sweet dark fruits, some spices with quite a lot of barley all leading into quite a strong dry bitter finish. Really lovely IPA.

Clear amber with off white head.  Piney hop aroma. Good hop flavor in the beginning, a little alcohol in the middle, with some sweet malt at the end.  A little malty for what I look for in an IPA, but a decent IPA none the less.

12oz bottle. Clear amber color, thin light-tan head. Some ropey lacing. The creamy malt aroma actually strikes me before the hops do - unusual for an IIPA, and I like it. A little warm throughout the middle, but it works very well. I wasnt too impressed with 60 minute, but 90 minute lived up to the hype.

I immediately smell the hops when I pour it. Mostly pine (it almost smells like the woods, whic is great for a country boy trapped in a city boys body like myself) and some grass and citrus too. Tastes just like it smells. Absolutely delicious, the best way I can describe the taste of this beer is that it tastes like the woods of upstate New York smell. One of my favorites.

Pours a hazy copper with white head a tons of lacing.  Aromas of grass, citrus, and an earthiness to it.  Taste is sweet, light bitterness on the front end with a smoothness throughout.  Some bite on the back end but a nice dry finish.  Overall, this is a very good IPA, but I am partial to the lighter more citrusy one.

Draught @ Iron Monkey, Jersey City, NJ
Pours cloudy orange with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, citrus and grape. Body is medium sweet and light to medium bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

You can never go wrong with 90 minute. This brewery always does some exciting brews that I have no problem paying the money for. This 90 minute has a really hoppy flavor to it. Not a taste for the weak but a great beer for someone who loves some hops. I think the aroma is outstanding. Kind of wish they sold it more in a 6 pack instead of a 4 but then again, I would like to be rich and Im not. 
Cheers!

Bottled on 02/11/11 pours golden yellow with a off white 1" thick head. Smells of grapefruit, pine, mango, caramel and touch of honey. Taste of huge amounts of malt, pine, grapefruit some sweetness like honey. This has interesting taste and mouthfeel it starts out almost pungent and thick with the hop character then fades to a mild  sweetness then it finishes long and bitter. Very tasty!
So, Ive been drinking this from a bottle for years (sacrilege?) and I never realized how light in color it poured. Mmmm... smooth going down.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2014 Full-on rerate. Welcome back to Indiana, DFH. Pours a clear blush color with about a finger-width of off-white head that sticks around and leaves some intricate, soapy lace. Nose involves herbal and resiny hops, stone fruit, and floral notes. Fairly sweet and fairly bitter, not too intense either way, pretty well balanced. Medium bodied, oily, pretty actively carbed, bright, with a lengthy herbal bitter finish. This is a well-made, drinkable, nuanced, tasty brew. It seems somewhat restrained to me, but that just goes to show what a few years of drinking crazy beers will do to a person.

Pours a hazy orange color with a large off-white head. Aroma of caramel,dark fruit, and some light citrus hops. Flavor is a lot of citrus and grapefruit hops, brown sugar, and quite a bit of caramel malts that balance the hops nicely.  There is bitterness throughout the drink & the alcohol is well hidden.

This is where I want my double IPAs to live. A golden yellow beer that is caramelized in color with a dense off-white head that stick to the glass. Aroma is sticky with malts, citrus, hay, pine, sweet apples, honeycomb and some floral hints. The flavor is sublime and silky with wide malts blended perfectly with a complex array of hops that linger through grapefruit, sugar cane, pine needles, jasmine, orange zest and tropical fruit. Wicked.

By far the most aromatic and smoothest IPA I can think of.  Well rounded flavors of citrus, malt, and exquisite hops.  Poured less syrupy than I had expected from an Imperial IPA.  Well defined long lasting head.  Served well chilled.

Bottled on 1/12/11. Drank 7/2/11. Yes, a little late. 

Nose: Caramel and honey covered tropical fruit salad with mild citrus zest. 

Palate: Much the same as nose. Nice bitter tang on finish. 

Mouth feel: Even though far from super fresh, can feel the [resinous] hop oils cover the surface of my entire mouth. 

Overall: Definitely more malty than hop forward.

Like a West Coast-style barley wine LIGHT.

2 bottles, from glass.  Im usually not a visual guy.  I dont care what the beer looks like, usually.  This beer is an exception.  It is amazingly clear and a beautiful color.  Bready aroma and a well balanced taste that allows bitter recepticles all over the tongue to be activated.

bottled may 15, 11. awesome piney hop and malt aroma. clear amber pour with a little head. the heavy caramel malts overpower the hops. i prefer IPAs that he hops overpower the malts, but nonetheless this was still a very good beer.

Hopfiger Geruch, leicht nach Kaffee. Der Hopfenantrunk ist dementsprechend recht malzig und karamellig, zudem alkohlisch. Die leichte Kaffeenote ist schmeckbar, röstig. Karamellig bleibend, vollmundig, die Hopfiegkeit gerät teilweise in den Hintergrund. Sehr würzig-malzig werdend, cremig, hefig frisch, aromatisch. Sehr gut! 	 
Test vom 13.8.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 9,13,12,13,12,13 - 12,40

Pours amber with a lot of head that lasts a while, but not forever. Very clear with moderate cabonation. At first this smelled of pizza dough but now I am convinced that is smells like an ocean breeze. In any case my mortal tongue is probably not capable of distinguishing all the flavor in this beer. It has so much flavor in fact you would not guess its over 9% ABV. Very nice, complex flavor with a good bitter finish that leaves your mouth saying "mmm" and not "blehhhh". If I were Spock I would say, "fascinating".

Bottle at home.  Aroma:  floral with a hint of citrus.  Appearance:  deep golden brown, slightly redish tint, white head.  Taste:  citrus, lightly sweet, very bitter at the swallow.  Palate:  medium body, long-dry-bitter finish, soft carbonation.  Overall:  a great example of the style, Im not a huge fan of extremely bitter and this is bordering on too much, but is enjoyable.

Picked this up in a 4-pack from a local liquor store.  Was much smoother than anything I was expecting.  Had an orange/copperish color and was not extremely hoppy, Is an awesome 9% too! Highly suggest this especially if you like the 60 Minute IPA

330 ml bottle at Sorbon. Almost clear, amber body with small-medium off-white head. Hoppy aroma with notes of pine, grapefruit and some caramelly malt. A bit sour. Dry taste with light sweetness and medium to high bitterness and maybe a little tart. VERY well balanced and wonderfully tasting. Medium bodied with nice carbonation. Overall: Nice, but not outstanding, aroma and excellent taste. Very good DIPA, one of the best.

12 oz bottle. Pours golden with a small white head. It has a grassy, floral , citrus and spruce aroma. This beer has incredible amounts of hop complexity without the overpowering bitterness I expected. Its so complex that its hard to pick out the individual flavors making up this beer. The alcohol taste is masked almost completely by the hop flavors. Id have to say I taste every flavor that I associate with hops is in this beer. Im really enjoying this one despite having a hard time describing it.

pours amber with a small off white head that dont last too long. aroma is of malts and citrus hops, a bit of grass also. taste is quite sweet, with caramel hints then bitter orange peel comes through and it finishes with just a slight alcohol heat, i like the squall DIPA a bit more but this is also great.
Aroma is wood, hops, some malts, pine, orange. Taste not as bitter as expected; some malts, alot of hop notes such as pine, grass, and citrys,
12 oz bottle pours a dark amber color with a nice white head.  Aromas of citrus, grass, with a nice malt backbone.  Full bodied with a bitter finish, a great DIPA

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours orange/amber with small white head. Aroma of dark fruits, syrup, citrus fruit, caramel, some floral. Flavour of caramel and syrup to start, quite thick and luxurious, then a real nice, citrusy, bitter hop finish which refreshes each mouthful, and keeps you interested. Beautifully complex.

Bottle.  Pours a bright amber with a smallish white head.  Aroma is big:  lots of citrus, pineapple, and piney hops with underlying notes of caramel and honey.  Flavor is more balanced:  lots of resinous hops and sweet caramel.  Palate is thick but not as oily as Id expect from a beer this hoppy.  A very good DIPA.

Enjoyable! Slightly hoppy aroma.   The flavor is complex and balanced. Little more on the acidic side. Well balanced, good carbonation.  The flavor of hops and bitterness in the beginning and middle, than a nice hit of alcohol at the finish, which doesnt linger.  I would not guess it is a 9% beer .   But, it will hit you.

This brew has a great first impression and doesnt get overly bitter in the finish. Does have something in the after taste I don;t love, but overall this is a sneaky brew because you could drink a lot without noticing!
This is about as good an IPA as it gets.  I go between this and Sculpin from Ballast Point.  If youre a hop head like me, you will be sure to enjoy the DH 90.
Bottle shared with friends.  Not very bitter for an ipa, seems to have mote malt.  Good flavors though

33cl bottle shared with friends.  1 year old from my beer cellar.
Nowhere near as bitter as a fresh 90 minute.  Still a little bitter. Very nice

Looks good, pouring a bright, translucent amber with a modest white head that leaves plenty of lace.  But the smell of 90 is its greatest feature, a huge, amazing wall of grapefruit rind and skunky weed, one that near-staggers your olfactory sense.  The taste carries over this citric, herbal hop madness, yet with a startling amount of malt sweetness to balance out the brew.   This honey-like center adds a good bit of heft to 90-Minute, making the bitter, warm fade much closer to liquor than it should be.  Still, the nose alone is worth the price of admission.  (5/15/09)

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2012 Bottle.  Pours a medium golden orang with slightly off white head. The aroma was very balanced for a IIPA.  Along with the citrus aroma, I caught the malts and a little toffee. The taste was evenly balanced between sweet sugary malts and citrus hops.  Really sweeter than I would normally dig, but this works perfectly.  Very nice DIPA and quite possibly deserves a better ranking.  Pretty solid that I can get this at Kroger.
enjoyed on draft at the yard house at colorado mills i have had it before but this one was the best i have had. not as malty as it has been very well balanced

Bottle poured into a snifter. Coloring is bronze, with a thick fluffy head and thick lacing. Scents of fresh hops, citrus and cinnamon make this beer all the more appealing. Flavors are of hops, citrus and cinnamon are enclosed around sweetness of honey, and man is this good! The warmth of alcohol, as well as the spicy flavor, provides an overall robust flavor and an elegant distinctive finish. WOW.

Pours a bright hazy amber with a thick fluffy head. Tons of lacing.  Aroma is strong citrus hops, tropical fruit, and sweet malts. Pineapple stands out.  The taste is amazing and very well balanced with citrus and piney hops, sweet malts, and some booze.  Medium/full bodied, slightly oily and creamy mouthfeel. Definitely one of my favorite beers.

cloudy glowing copper colored beer with a creamy white head that laces well and appropriate carbonation for this style.

Smells of rich fruity malts, citrusy hops, alcohol, and grain. This smells potent.

Taste is a very well blended balance of citrusy and earthy hops much better than most American IPAs. Most American IPAs will have dish soap citrusy taste but this eliminates that. After the hop blast a delicious fruited bread taste and grains. It finishes out with a hoppy citrus blast in the back booyah!

Mouthfeel is hop assertive, astringent, and drying.

From the bottle.  The aroma is definitely not what I normally think of in an Imperial IPA.  More malty with some coffee wafts here and there.  The beer pours a very dark color and one might not again discern it as a DIPA. The taste lets you know it is a DIPA but not that super hoppy bomb that dominates the category.  Its got some pine but mostly the malts come into play and go very nice with the hoppiness and bitterness of the beer.  The palate lends itself very well to a thick mouth full that I very much enjoy in this beer.  Overall it isnt necessarily the first beer I would order if I had the choice of a DIPA but it is one of my go to beers in ANY style.  A well balanced and great brew.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Pours a slightly hazy amber with a slight white head that leaves a tremendous amount of lacing on the glass. Big citrus hop aromas, with floral and pine notes. Sweet hoppy taste, with caramel  and raisin notes. Has a great malt structure to balance out the the loads of hops. Surprisingly smooth for the style. A classic brew.
Not the usual overwhelming citrus-ness of a DIPA. More malty and full bodied, definitely a fine beer to be paired with a fine meal.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2013 medium body, thin feel, lively, bitter, orange, clear, 
I usually hate IPAs but this beer is delicious.

Bottle, straight up. Intense aroma with hops and malt. Flavor was similar but with a high amount of bitterness, probably the most bitter that Ive had. Fruity and malty as well. I had higher hopes for this one but because of the reputation but I think there are actually better double IPAs out there.

This beer pours clear with about 1/4in of head.  color is orange.  The nose is subdued but the hops are there.  Taste is well balanced.  Its a sweet beer with a strong malt backbone and the perfect amount of hoppiness to balance it.  Excellent IPA and Im totally bummed that I cant get it in Indiana any more.
great citrusy hop aroma and taste with a strong malt backbone to support it. A staple IPA, one of my favorites.

Right up my street. Bottle thanks to mesandsim. Epic tasting at theirs. Appearance is golden, slightly hazy, nice white head. Beuatiful aroma, citrus and hops, rubber like a gimps mask might smell like (a clean one) but in a good way. Flavour more of the same with the malts coming through just a touch. Alcohol is noticeable. A nice long dry finish.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2012 EDIT April 2012:

This is a ridiculously good beer, but Im not finding the love I first had for it. Some initial citrus hop, and then lots of apricot/peach and some more sweet malty tons. I do love the balance, just not enough to call it my favourite beer in the world.

Bottled on 3/3/2011 so this ones about 6 weeks old.  Pours clear amber with an average beige head.  Thins quickly but doesnt go away.  Good lacing.  Aroma of pine, grapefruit, caramel, something earthy.  A little alcohol sharpness.  Tastes similar but sweeter.  Nice bitter finish with a touch of alcohol warmth.  Very good, balanced beer.

An exquisite balance of malts and hops create this top shelf classic which I cannot purchase in MN....and soon-to-be unavailable in WI I now hear! Earthy sensations abound as the hops welcome you to the rest of the beverage, which pours practically purple into my pint glass. The malts and sweetness are a perfect compliment to the hops, and I sensed a tiny hint of raisins and licorice hiding somewhere beneath. A true American treasure.
sampled from a shot glass, sweet aroma, inviting appearance, feels great on the palette, one of the best IPA flavors

12 oz. bottle into a shaker glass. Big floral hop nose with some dried fruit and orange. Starts off with a big hit of complex bitter hops, with grapefruit and pine flavors dominating. The finish opens up with a lot of sweet caramel malt flavors, and it is very much in balance. The finish seems to last forever and goes back and forth between sweet and bitter. A little bit of warm, almost hot, alcohol keeps this under a "4" for me. I think I like the 60 minute a little bit more.

Very little head, but beautiful lacing. Served cold, cold youre gonna get what tastes like  a beautifully hoppy double IPA, but warm it up a couple degrees and that malt backbone becomes prominent and creates the most perfectly balanced beer I have had to date. Serve with something spicy when cold, cold; serve with chocolate once warmed up for dessert.

Although the appearance is nothing special, it only gets better from there.  Has a heavy hoppy, floral aroma but the taste deceivingly doesnt pack that overly hoppy taste.  Although high in alcohol, very very smooth.  Clean on the palate and has an interesting sweet finish.  Im a big fan of IPAs in general, and this IPA has to be towards the top for me.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2011 21 March 2011, bottle. Light amber, faint haze, occasional bubbles. nice nose, sweeter than anything. not much aroma hops. alcohol and raisins. full body and slightly fizzy. very rich. lots of alcohol. very well balanced! hops arent huge but are the finishing flavour. middle taste is raisin and alcohol. lovely!

Draft. Pours amber/dark gold with a boring biege head. Aroma is great, getting lots of citrus, raisins, rich caramel malts, pine. Flavor is equally good, very sweet with a nice hop bite in the finish. Rich and very oily on the palate. Alcohol is not noticeable. Im usually pretty skeptical of DFH but this was great. That being said, get it on draft, the bottles are usually less impressive.

Bottle from Breeze Thru. Pours a rich orange with no head, nice lacing.  Aroma is caramel, pine, fresh fruit.  Taste is pine, overripe fruit, caramel.  Very syrupy.  Finishes dry and somewhat thick. Alcohol present, but not strongly so. A slight taste of that Delaware water in most Dogfish stuff is a bit off-putting.

Draft sample from the Burger Bar at Mandalay Bay in Las Vegas. Dark gold in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of navel orange, herbs, grainy pale malts and light caramel. Theres more of an orange-ping grapefruit mix of citrus elements in the flavour profile, and the graininess of the malts remains. Black pepper and cut grass notes show up on the back end, along with some smooth but on overly sweet caramel. Lighter bodied than expected. It seems to lack a bit of pop overall.

Really nice. Easy going and good to sip on. The malt background carries the hop pill very well.  Overall I like this alot, I am into the hop overload mostly but its nice to see how much development went into an IPA to get this nice result
Hoppy, smooth, easy to drink.  Like a Racer 5 or other comparable Hoppy Beer.  60 Minute is a little bit more subtle (obviously) and more relaxed.  This is a sipper for sure.

Pours dark but translucent amber with a finger wide bubbly eggshell head. Appearance is very carbonated and lively. Aroma is extremely hoppy with notes of grass, citrus, pine, flowers, and a touch of sweetness. Flavor is sweet and hoppy - brown sugar, orange, pine needles, and warming alcohol. Medium bodied and quite bitter at first but ends in a sweet finish.

Golden amber in appearance and a bit hazy. Pistachio, honey, malt and grapes on the nose. Big pistachio, honey, malt & sultanas again. Rich palate, creamy structure and quite refreshing on the end. To serve slightly chilled next time. Fairly balanced, I think.
Probably one of the best Imperial/ Double IPAs  period. I will continue to drink it for the rest of my life, but nothing beats a Dreadnaught.
Had it on bottles. Very well balanced! Long hoppy aftertaste bur nice complimatet by the sweetness of alcohol and malt. Little tast of vanilla.

This brew had the best texture i have ever encountered in a beer, though it was on a hand pump, it was creamy, gently fizzy, and filled my mouth up. The scent was very floral with a citrus hint. The taste was actually a little too sweet for me, and i felt it needed a little more wet hops. my pint had excellent head and lacing. I will never forget the mouth-feel of this brew, very nice.

A - Pours a clear amber-orange color with lively carbonation visible and a finger of foamy white head. Head fades fairly quickly to a ring around the glass with some lacing.

S - Aroma is full of citrus and floral hops. There is also a nice balance of sweet malt and a bit of bread also in the nose. Just a touch of booze evident.

T - Starts off with some nice building bitterness and some sweet malt and a touch of citrus. Really nice and balanced from the start. Through the middle the hops really jump out, but there is still that sweetness from the malt and citrus flavor. The finish has even more hop flavor with some nice bitterness that really lingers along for a while. There is just a hint of booze at the end.

M - Medium bodied with a slightly above moderate amount of carbonation. Feels really lively on the tongue and super smooth and crisp overall. The finish is nice and dry and leaves a bit of a syrupy feeling in the mouth.

D - Very drinkable, even at 9.00% abv. The flavors are very excellently balanced from start to end with a nice hop profile while still having the right malt presence. Very balanced mouthfeel and taste.

growler from whole foods... this, my friend, is one that I have been waiting on rating for just the right moment. I was disappointed by the 60 minute and felt it was overrated so this 90 minute would be held to a high degree.. immeediately the golden copper color shimmers against the glass.. smells of hop crusted, citrus infused flowery notes that delicately billow above the brim.. The initial hit to he palate is a complex array of slow roasted bitterness immediately followed subtle hints of chocolate and touches of molassas with a passionate kiss of malts on the aftertaste. It is so much more appealin than the 60 minute and incredibly smooth throughout the entire drink..  I was a fool to wait this long to try a bit of heaven but I am so excited I am no longer blinded by the light!!

Nice dark amber color, complex floral smell with a definitive hop smell with a tinge of alcohol. Taste is pure heaven... so much going on... flowers, grass, alcohol, caramel. Seems like it will have a bitter finish, but leaves almost no trace... just a subtle hint of hops and a warming sensation. No aftertaste which for me makes it dangerously drinkable. Key word is balance... so much going on, but none of the elements override the others. 
Draft and bottle in snifter.
Pours clear golden with a huge white head. Strong hop aroma. Flavor is very balanced. Not so bitter not so sweet. Very nice beer.

Bottle @ Hotelroom, Denver. Pours dark golden with a 1 nicecreamy white head, lots of small bubbles . Aroma of caramel, malt citruss, orangepeel, pine. Taste is sweet caramel at first, cituss, grapefriut, grapefruit, alcohol. Medium body, soft carbonation, lasting bitter finish. Very nice IIPA, but abit to sweet to be really great for me.120311
Poured a nice amber color, had a strong hop smell. Had a rather nice taste with a bitter after taste.

Clear Amber pour with big creamy eggshell head. Lots of head retention and lot of lacing.  Nose is dark fruits, caramel malts and buried piney hops. Medium bodied full of velvety textures and a lot of  fruity complexity. Semisweet throughout.

The problem here (and it still deserves a high rating) is that it is more about the malts than the hops. The hops come off as oily and are so masked by everything else that its hard to find them.

(null)
Malt: caramel, toast, molasses
Hops: orange, citrus
Other: alcohol
Color: golden, amber
Liquid: clear
Head: frothy
Initial: medium bitterness, heavy sweetness
Finish: medium bitterness, medium sweetness
Finish Duration: average
Body: medium, full
Texture: creamy, thick
Carbonation: average
Finish: alcoholic, bitter

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2011 Draft vs bottle ratings below.  I averaged the 2 for overall.

6/21/11 (8/4/8/4/16 = 4) Bottle.  Pours more of a rusty copper with a small tan (almost brown) head and lots of visible carbonation.  Im not getting the bubble gum aroma I apparently experienced below; citrus is still there with some apricot, caramel.  Definitely very sweet; this isnt a hop explosion but there is a good balance with the malt.  Doesnt hide the 9% incredibly well.  Sticky/chewy; finishes slightly bitter.

3/4/11 (10/3/9/5/17 = 4.4) Tap @ Urge.  Pours a dark copper with good lacing.  Aroma of bubble gum and citrus hops.  A very malty drink, and not nearly as hoppy as I expected.  Smooth mouthfeel with just the perfect touch of bitterness at the end.  Quite good.
Golden-red color. Smells of bitter fruit. Taste at first is very fruity, then hops, bitter, and flavorful aftertaste. Interesting. I would drink it again.
Smells like banana nut bread. An amber that is a bit cloudy. Oh so sweet, medium sour and smooth. Extra creamy to the point of sticky. Clean finish.

12oz bottle that has been in my fridge for awhile now. amber color pour and an off white head that lasted for awhile nice oily lacing around the glass. the aroma of floral hops is the main stay and it is quite a remarkable beer. taste is a malty hop mix which blends very well together. one of the better and smoother ipas i have had..are there better sure but i like this one.

Pours amber with a minimal white head.  The nose is actually really nice: sweet and extremely floral.  The flavor is somewhat malty and fairly sweet, but not so much that it turns me off.  This very much strikes me as a classic East Coast IIPA with a good dose of hops that is well-balanced by a noticeable malt backbone.  Im a West Coast IIPA guy, but this is a really nice change of pace from time to time, and, I think the best beer Ive ever had from Dogfish Head.

Bottle- Pours a clear burnt-orange color with a decent head and good lacing that lasts quite a while. Has an unexpected mild aroma of pine and fresh grain with a trace of citrus poking through. Taste is a unique mixture of pine, citrus, fresh grain with a touch of sweetness. Has a good bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body, very smooth and very well balanced. The 9% ABV is well hidden. Good drinker. Excellent beer, even though this style is not my favorite.

2/28/2011. FIgured this would be an appropriate beer to give my new snifter glasses a spin in.

Pours a copper orange, little head.  Aroma is of hop, some citrus and a lot of the English malt.  Taste of mild hop and raisin up front, then the huge malt knocks out the finish.  Overall, a pretty impressive DIPA.

Just one of the best beers ever to hit  your lips. 90min blows me away every time i get to enjoy one.  fresh from the tap is my favorite way to drink in at first the aroma hits you and you already know that your in for a treat.  then at first sip the perfect combination of malt and hops is the first thing present followed with a wonderful after taste

Pours a golden honey color with a small white head.The aroma is of floral and citrus hops.The flavor is of syurp and bitter hops with an alcohol tone to it.Gose down smooth with a bitter syrup aftertaste.Overall a very good brew from deaware.

Amber orange color with a white head. Strong sprucy/piney nose very pleasant.     As it warms up the cereal malt start to be more apparent.   This is very well balanced, not over powered by hops.  Good mouth feel, sticky.  The 9% alcohol I feel is detectable but not overpowering.  A mild lasting bitterness almost of grapefruit rind.  Mild sweet of caramel malts.  Really enjoyed this.

330ml bottle at home. Pours a slightly hazy amber, perfectly formed white head that stays around for a long time. Big American hoppy aroma, with a slight hint of peach/lemon and some slight breadiness. Initial taste is big and malty, almost like fruitcake, before a hoppy bitterness thats unmistakeably there, but more subtle than you would think. 9.0% ABV certainly warms you up. A really great, rich beer, although I personally slightly prefer the lighter 60 minute version.

A - dark gold, orange. Nice creamy and firm head.
S - hops and hops and hops with some lemon tones
T - breathtaking taste of hops. In the middle of if you can feel both sweet and hoppy taste, unbelievable. Alcohol is enormously perfectly hidden in the body of the beer.
M - medium to full body with medium carbonation
D - incredibly drinkable and so much dangerous with respect to high ABV

This is one of the best IPA style beers I have ever had. Absolutely awesome.
Very clean nose, hoppy, piney, the body isnt as smooth as I would have hoped, alcohol not well integrated, otherwise great IPA
Perfect balance of hops and malt, bitter and sweet. The alcohol lacing at the end is great. One of the best beers you can hope to have.

Fresh and fruity aroma. Has some citrus and a nice metallic touch as well in the taste. Aftertaste is more aciduous than bitter, but the bitterness still remains in the back of the mouth. The alcohol level is completely hidden by the other flavours

I like this beer a lot but prefer the 60 minute over this. Dark red/Amber color with a hint of grapefruit aroma. Taste good with hints of grapefruit and some caramel. Very bitter though and i prefer the 60 minute over this...Also prefer the Heavy Seas Loose Cannon IPA over this as well. Still a very good beer though.

very sweet piney and malt notes with some sweet peach and mango like smells as well, probably one of the mosr delicious smelling beers Ive ever had, mahogany appearance first taste is a sweet roasty maltiness, then a sweet resiny hop taste and finishes bitter

Aroma: Lots of citrus and floral hops.
Appearance: Clear gold with a thick white head.
Taste: Medium sweetness, light bitterness and a very light saltiness at the back of the tongue.
Palate: Light-medium body, soft carbonation, slick texture with a long finish and slightly odd aftertaste. 
Overall: This is a very solid beer with a lot to praise. Not mind blowingly outstanding as some would insist, but certainly something that Id stock in my fridge and pair with meals.

Absolutely delicious! Has a sweet smell, almost like perfume, and a very balanced taste. Great hop flavor is matched with sweet malt. Beautiful amber color and nice feeling in your mouth. This is a phenomenal beer that is made with care and a must drink for any beer enthusiast.
The 90 minute poured amber with a bright white head from the tap.  Citrus and sugar notes mingle together.  The hops give this beer a very balanced taste and keep the alcohol flavor in check.

12 oz 1 yr old bottle. Pours a light copper/amber, 1/2 inch of head, fades quickly to light lacing. aroma is floral, hoppy, with some malts and citrus. lightly fizzy and soft mouthfeel, medium body.bitterness increases slowly, but balanced, continues long after you swallow, a rich hoppy and bitter but sweet aftertaste. Easy to drink, incredibly tasty, and much better then the 60 minute.

Chef Pauls, bottle, Marci and Dad. Light copper, no head. Dried fruit
aroma, sweet. Flavor is sweet, thick, syrup. More dried fruit- apricot
and orange. Surprising balance with the hops, not overwhelming but
nicely paired with the malt. I swear I even got a hint of chocolate or
cocoa powder with this.  Nice beer

Pours a hazy golden amber with  a small offwhite head.  Nice lacing. Smells strong of hops, some alcohol, grapefruit, spruce and cereal. medium body, some syrup in mouthfeel, nicely carbonated. Opens with a sweet citrus/grapefruit taste, that moves on to some malts and a nice hoppy finish.  Not too bitter, but nicely hopped.  Excellent IPA.

Bottled 4-3-09

This is my first DIPA so Im reviewing this more as a master of other styles.

I pour it into my tulip glass it pours a nice rich copper/amber/red. Decent head retention in my Duvel glass as it recedes after a few minutes leaving very nice lacing. 

Smells hoppy im not smelling really any malts just some grapefruit and piney notes.

Taste is fantastic, and suprisingly theres malt here. That was the big shocker here for me being my first DIPA. Not a huge blast but enough. But up front you get that hop madness, with some pine and citrus notes. Finishes with a good malt flavor thats a bit syrupy.

To me this beer has exceptional mouthfeel and is much more drinkable then anticipated.

Overall this was a solid, solid beer, 120 is next up for me it appears.

Found this in my notes, somehow I missed it 
Appearance: Clear golden with a nice white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Apricot, fruits and citrus 
Taste: Fruity, caramel malts and grapefruit  
Nice IPA, easy to drink.
Bottle @ home. Pours amber with some head. Lots of hop flavor, pine, resin, light citrus. The malt base tastes of caramel, toffee and dark sugars. A great IIPA all over.
nice and hoppy. a little light on citrus, which I like, and a few more sweet, caramel tones. but over all really great beer and nice to pair with food.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2011 Pours a light copper with a small, dense white head. Big hop aroma as expected but balanced out very well by caramel/toffee malts. Taste is of citrus, pine, hop resin, caramel, sweet malts. Balances surprisingly well. Get a rather large dose of blood orange throughout the nose and taste. Great IPA

Bottle. Deep caramel colour with a thin head. Lovely warm aroma, hoppy caramel, a little like Christmas. Flavour is hop with a medium bitterness. Finish is dry and leaves a long dry chocolate and bitter palate

I was pleasantly surprised by this brew that is for sure. I expected a harsh overly hoppy and bitter experience. Brewed with hops for 90 minutes and dry hopped? What I did not understand was the hop and malt choices that blend to a well balanced easy drinking IPA with no harsh bitter. Surprised indeed. 

Pours clear copper with a two finger white head that fades a little after a few minutes. Citrusy aroma with a light smell of raisen? The hops are well played, but the malts really shine in my opinion. The earthy citrusy tastes are balanced with a slight sweet toffee flavor. a light toasty taste to the toffee. Texture was full with a lively carbonation. Very very enjoyable.

Bottle. Finger of white head that reduces to a bubbly cap on a clearer copper orange.  Citrusy hops in the aroma with some sweetness, and pretty balanced.  Balance continues to the flavor with some pine, citrus, heavier caramel and a sweeter finish with some bitterness.  Medium to thicker body with softer carbonation.  Pretty good, but definitely East Coast.

12 oz bottle.  Pours an amber gold, with a fair amount of saffron/white head, which dissipates moderately quickly but with a lot of lacing on the glass.  Nose is predominantly hoppy - a nicely balanced note between pine and floral with a hint of citrus, and a little bit of toasted bread in the background.  Taste is also well balanced - saying a lot for how much bitterness is here - you get a big malt note of caramel and toast first as a grapefruit and moderatly bitter note builds in and lasts through a moderately bitter, slightly spicy finish with just a little hint of alcohol warming as the glass warms.  Excellent.

Appearance: Pours copper, with a strong orange hue. Dense moderate white head with light orange tint, great head retention, nice lacing. Hazy, as to be expected from strongly hopped brew.
Smell: Not too fragrant, I have expected more. Piney, resiny, citrusy hops. Orange peel, peach, passionfruit. Some caramel notes.
Taste: Hops galore. Big, but sweet,soft and rounded hop character, piney, grassy, resiny. Fruity (orange, passionfruit, peach). Sticky sweet maltiness / caramel / nutty notes.
Mouthfeel: mouthcoating hops balanced by sticky sweetness, thick body, light lingering bitterness and alcohol warmth in aftertaste.
Highlights: Very pleasant, rounded but massive hop character, can be too much for unprepared drinker. Orange (peel) In color aroma and taste.

Felt like I got punched by the hops.  Really have to be in the mood for an IPA.  Interesting beer- felt like I got somthing different with each sip.   Good beer to savour.  Seemed overly carbonated and had almost no head- will blame the bar for that one, not the beer.

Dude.  Its 90 Min IPA.  This is the yardstick for a good Imperial IPA.  Perfect balance of hoppy bitterness, a little brown sugary sweetness, and a tart bit of grapefruit.  This is one of the worlds great beers.
Bottle.  Pours gold with a thin white head.  Aroma is citrus and slight caramel.  Flavor is mild grapefruit and caramel.  9% ABV is very well hidden.  Smooth and delicious.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2012 12oz bottle poured into a tulip.  I cannot believe I have never rated this beer...it is one of my favorites.  Aroma is of alcohol and grapefruit...drink it warm, as it aroma really develops about 50 degrees.  The appearance is a beautiful dark yellowish red with a white head that leaves great lacing.  The taste is super rich and hoppy, but also the maltiness comes through to balance very nicely.  Palate is full bodied with medium carbonation and a long finish where the malts really come through.  Overall, this is one of the best IPAs out there...double actually.....yum
its an imperial IPA, which isnt my fav style. but not bad...........................

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2011 Bottle. Clear dark gold pour with an off-white head leaving moderate lace. Resinous nose, medium-heavy body with resinous hops, figs, honey, cheese, and moderate carbonation. Citrus, bitter finish. Great in the bottle, its notably better on tap, travels well. When fresh, DFH90 is neck and neck with the best IIPAs such as those from Three Floyds, Green Flash and Russian River.

Enjoyed on tap. This    beer poured a golden amber with a moderate head. The head quickly disappeared leaving little lacing. My first impression was that this would be similar to a handful of aggressively hopped  California brews. Aromas of grapefruit peels pine resins and roasted malts. Tastes of citrus fruits and fresh hops. Strong malt backbone to round off the hop bitterness. Finishes slightly  bitter and sweet.

Huge beer. Pours a nice amber color with a moderate head. Has a hoppy aroma with some roasted fruits. The beer has a thickness to it that doesnt show in the pour but definitely comes through in the taste. Big hops with a good finish.
Absolute best IPA I have ever tasted, lots of bitterness, with hint of grapefruit, and all kinds of good flavors!! And the finish that stays around....

Its angry.  Highly bitter, beautiful golden color with a moderate head.  This is what I would judge all IPAs against (maybe the 60).  Its hard to find thanks to that show on Discovery which irritates me because this is the IPA I want whenever Im eating something spicy.  I wish it were thicker on the palate so the bitterness and general hoppiness would stick around a little longer, but other than that, I cant find anything wrong with it.

Part of a 60, 90, 120 tasting.  Appearance:  close to the 60 minute, but a little warmer brown, with some orangey highlights and a smaller head; very little lace.  Aroma:  orange rind, caramel, floral hops, and a lot of malt; kind of a potpourri feel.  Taste:  blast of citrus and floral hops, with a solid burnt wood/malty backbone, with some sweet caramel underneath.  Finish:  ngering, bitter and chalky dry, with flavors of tangy floral hops and dry dark brown bread lingering.  Notes:  Definitely more rich than the 60 minute version, but not too much more bitter.  Hops are more on the floral side, and the malt is more pronounced as well.  Medium-bodied  The 120 minute is going to kill me.
Pours a nice amber color. Nice pungent aroma. I was expecting a stronger hoppy taste but it was a but thin and didnt linger very long.
UPDATED: DEC 18, 2011 Just an incredible, legendary beer.  Massive hop aroma and flavor, tons of malt backbone.  Chewy with a finish that hangs around in the best of ways.  A benchmark of the style.
A very, very, very nice IPA. I get a lot of grapefruit citrus in this beer. On top of the hoppiness, I also do get some dark fruits in the sweetness that adds a nice complexity to this beer.

Crisp appearance upon pour, looks like apple juice with a solid white head on top that retained pretty well. Aroma is a bit weak, crisp hops and a little floral stuff going on, but isnt pungent. Taste is much better, with refreshing bitterness from the hops to go with an awesome raisin/alcohol sweetness. Malt is present in spades - its always there in the background the whole time, bringing the whole package together. Feel on palate is decent, a very free feeling beer. Drinkability is very high, you could take big swigs of this without any ill-effects (other than the 9%).

Pours a hazy amber with a small off-white head.  Aroma is grapefruit, citrus, piney, and there is a malt presence as well.  Flavor is sweet, with caramel coming through, as well as pine, and citrus notes.  Finish is a very soft bitter, despite the IBU.  Overall, VERY well balanced, and one of my new favorites!

I do not understand all the rave reviews. DFH 90 min is a quaffable beer for its high alcohol content, but I always find myself asking, "where are the hops." My girlfriend said, "thats not an IPA" when she tasted it. The beer borders on being a "malt bomb" and is just really not hoppy enough to be called an IPA. It is, however, a fine beer. The malt backbone is more than a backbone, it is really where the soul of this beer lies, and that maltiness is pleasant and delicious. I suppose if someone doesnt care for hops, they would fine DFH 90 min to be superior to a "true" American IPA of similar size, but I still think, "where are the hops?"

Bottle from the Cracked Kettle, cons 2011-01-14 Göteborg
My first one from Denver :-)  !!! bottled 12/17/09???
AR: great aroma, roasted malt, pines, pineapple, some fruit sweetness - like pruns. And there is some alcoholic notes comming though when pouring it.
AP: appel cider honey colored body, 3 cm thick steady organic cream beige head
F: syrup thick beverage, great and long bitterness, likweise is the fruit flavors (pruns/apricot) starting strong and lingering with the bitterness for a long time, warm feeling, some roasted tones mixed with some caramel, great stuff!

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2011 bottle.  Pours clear orange with frothy yellow tinged head.  Aroma of orange citrus, buttered biscuit, fruitcake, surprisingly malty aroma for a double IPA.  Smooth and balanced for DIPA, with abv well hidden.  Creamy, and slightly chewy mouth.  Lots of citrus notes with buttery warm biscuit malt notes, kind of cakey.  Lingering bitter finish.  Pretty good DIPA, and one of the first ones I ever tried.  Years later, it is still good, but in comparison to others not as outstanding; still, it is a great beer.

Copper with rich, creamy, white head.  Laces well.

Aroma is Hops!  Citrus with pine and slight pineapple and grass.  Malt comes behind.  

Hops hit big on the first sip.  Citrus and pine dominate.  As I drink, the bitterness is offset some by malt sweetness--buttery and sweet.  Light toast.  Even some toffee.  Definitely has a strong and bitter hop bite.  Slightly creamy/syrupy but still crisp.

The high abv is well-hidden.  It drinks light and refreshing but the heaviness catches up by the end of the beer.  

Excellent beer.

Another I have been waiting to try, It did not dissapoint. The aroma was complex, it seemed to go in several directions but the taste was what I expected. It was an explosion of hoppiness that quickly balances out and makes you want more. It is another super brew from dogfish Head.
Smells like a citrus forrest! Has a creamy head with a golden amber color. Taste very hopped and piney. Very smooth.
Bottle Amber pour with small head. Very hoppy aroma and flavor. Great flavor that starts hoppy and transforms to a malty flavor with a malty aftertaste. Alcohol is well hidden. Great balance.
Unbelievable.  An absolute knockout.  One imperfect score (Overall 19/20) only to give the gang something to strive for.  The hops, the malt, its got it all.
I do not think I am ready for the world of hoppy beers.  This reminded me of chewing on a pine tree.  Too bitter.  I ike the rich thick dark beers please!

12 oz bottle @ Beer Temple. Orange colored, hazy. White head. Aromas of sweet malts and sweet fruit with some hops in the background. Fairly sweet flavor with some fruit and roast. Medium bodied. Finishes somewhat bitter. You can detect the hops in the aroma, but they are overpowered by malty and alcoholic sweetness. Its not bad, but Id expected a bit more.

I thought it was real bitter the first sip, then it was smooth as could be after that.  Drove into Wisconsin for this beer after watching Beer Masters on TV.  Worth the drive as ill be making the 20 minute drive anytime.

This is by far one of my favorite IPAs. Dogfish Head is an amazing brewery. Im not a big fan of the 60 minute IPA. Their Double IPA Burton Baton is pretty good too. If you like the 90 minute give the Burton Baton a taste.

Wow. This is what a well-balanced, super-hopped IPA should taste like. The punch of the hops are there, but theres an incredible balance that doesnt leave that mouth-puckering aftertaste that plagues other hop-heavy brews.

Appearance- Dark red/Amber with a white head

Aroma- Grapefruit

Taste- Grapefruit bitterness followed by a tasty caramel sweetness in the finish.

Mouth-feel- Medium bodied

Drink-ability- The bitterness might get to be a bit much after a while but since it is on the front of the flavor profile and followed by a very pleasant sweetness it is quite drinkable.
I had this beer at Bentlees in Parsippany. This is a very boring looking beer, but it has great hoppyness.

Poured into a Chimay goblet. Appearance: pours orange-ish, golden with a small off white head that settles quickly into a nice film and ring that leaves spotted lacing on the glass. Aroma: although not as intense as many IPAs, citrus, resin, and some herbal hop dominate the nose with some fruity alcohol esters and some malt sweetness in the background. Taste: the most well-balanced IPA I think I have ever had. A solid citrus and resin hop palate with plenty of malt sweetness that is not at all like caramel to support it. Alcohol esters exist in the flavor but are complimentary and pleasant. Overall: this beer is a knockout. Its an easy drinking, super flavorful, hoppy, well-balanced IPA that packs a punch at 9%. A 4 pack will go down a little too easy and have you feeling real nice. This is in my top 10 if not top 5 for sure.

Tap in a snifter.  Possibly a little too cold as it improved as it warmed and there was more space in the bottle.  Deep gold color, clear, light white head.  Pleasant aroma but not as strong as many IPAs... surprisingly mild hoppy.   Very clean finish with a good overall taste.  Alcohol doesnt carry through too much... not warming.
Strong citrus aroma, orange pour with a thin cream head.  Flavor of hops and light malts.

Amber with little cream head.  Flavor/Aroma are delightful.  Some citrus, but not the overwhelming grapefruit I get from some american IPAs.  A Solid caramel sweetness balances the delightful hop bitterness and flavor.  Hopping schedule is balances both flavor and bitterness, maybe a bit on the bitterness side of things.  Awesome, good mouthfeel and carbonation.

Poured into a pint glass.  Deep orange color with copper hues.  Fairly thick off white head that lingers.  Aroma is basically 100% floral hoppiness with maybe a hint of wood.  Smooth start with a semi-sweet flavor and a slightly drier finish.  Floral hoppy flavor is most prevalent.  Surprisingly smooth and drinkable considering the ABV and hoppiness,  IPAs generally arent my favorite style, but this one is extremely good.

Copper to dark honey color - very clear. Thin wispy head.  Slightly grassy or earthy straw smell -- maybe some pine too. Some sweet fruit smell -- like melon -- is nice. Upfront hop bitterness. Noticeable alcohol. Less sweetness in the malt than I expected. Bitter dry finish.

Im slowly becoming addicted to this. Living in SD I feel guilty drinking an east coast IPA with some of the best IPAs in my backyard but this is an A+. Perfect Balance, pours with a little head and has an amber glow that makes me smile.

Pours with a beautiful clear red/orange/amber colour with small beige head leving pretty lacing. Aroma is sweet caramel, malty, bready, piny, citric and hoppy. Sweet alcoholic and malty mouthfeel. Hoppy, piny, alcohol, dark fruity, very velvety sweet and bready flavor. Palate feels notes of acetone, alcohol and hops. Finishes with a excellently velvety lean, still intense longlived tart bite.
Hard to find a better IPA. The upfront sweetness is balanced extremely well by the kick of bitterness at the end. One of my favorite Dogfish products

Swirl this around in your glass and you will be hit in the face with a fruity hop farm of smells. It gets backed up by a sweet smell as well. The taste has that really forward citrus hop flavor with some of that fruity sweet malt/yeast flavors. It finishes with a herbal almost piney bitter hop taste you should get from an Imperial IPA. The blend is fantastic and you really couldnt ask for much more in a beer. It has a bold to medium body as it should for 9 percent alcohol. Which by the way is extremely well masked by the bitter and fruity hop flavors. It may not be as bitter as some other Imperial IPAs (even though its pretty bitter) it incorporates that hop flavor the most... just as how Dogfish claims... so it isnt your typical IPA. You shouldnt be let down this unless you get it not so fresh which will bring down the hop bitterness. So get this fresh!

Clear brown pour with a nice sized head that doesnt stick around very long, but leaves some nice lacing. Smell is not as hoppy as I would expect, citrus tones with a light hint of malts. Tastes of a distinct hoppiness, but a nice malt backbone.  Expected dry finish is not overwhelming. Light with a bit of a tinge of carbonation.  Smooth drink. For an IIPA, this is extremely drinkable. The hops really dont overpower you.

This one was easy to rate for me.Lots of citrus, gobs of hops, but still has the malt to compete with it.  I could not ask for a better IPA. This is the benchmark for an IPA to me. I have not tried the 120 yet. Once I do, it may become the new benchmark.

355mL bottle.  Pours hazy gold with a medium off-white head that slowly settles to a ring and leaves a decent amount of lacing.  Clean hoppy aroma of citrus, tropical fruit and berries with a little malt backing it up.  The flavours quite sweet and malty, with a strong fortified wine/blackberry character, and a little bitterness and citrusy hop flavour.  Medium-full bodied, average carbonation, very smooth with a lingering bittersweet finish.
