Color is dark orange with a white head. Smell is mainly of citrus with some other fruit notes. The flavor is mainly of fruits up front with a lot of hops following it. One of the better IPAs Ive had in my day, though it is very sharp with the hop bite.

This is real elegant and refined beer. Dark orange with a medum to small head. Aroma of citrus, spice, pine and sweet malt. Rounded complex flavour, grapefruit, spice, caramel, very fruity, surpisingly sweet. Nice full body.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2012 Bottle. Amber with a foamy off-white head leaving lacing. Aroma: tropical fruit juice, pineapple, toffee. Taste: pineapple, tropical fruits, toffee, malt, lemons and some pepper. Well balanced bitterness with grapefruit in the finish. Medium-bodied with medium carbonation. Awesome!

355ml bottle in a tasting between Dogfish Head and Stone IPAs. Rusted orange pour with eggshell head that leaves a good solid lace. Big resinous, piny hops on the nose with a solid backbone of caramel and cereal grain. Sweet entry with noticeable alcohol, resiny hops and caramel with a long bitter finish.

Aroma reveals sweet malt overtones with floral hop accents.  12oz. bottle poured into a sampling glass.  Pours a golden amber color with a creamy off-white head.  Taste is a blend of sweet malt and dry crisp floral hops which ends with a subtle aftertaste of malt.  Overall a perfectly balanced blend of malt and hop.  This is a great beer.

Tasted on 12/17/10 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Whole Foods Chandler, bottled on 11/18/10E.  Pours very light amber with a thick white head that quickly recedes to a nice lace collar.  The nose is a good mixture of tropical fruit and very "green" hops with a solid caramel malt backbone.  The flavor is features the green hops and tropical fruits up front with the malt coming through nicely and then bitterness taking over.  The body is medium with an average amount of carbonation and a long green hops finish.

Appearance: Orange brown. Some off-white head.
Aroma: Hops and fruit. Flowers. Citrus.
Taste: Lots of hops, but also enough fruit and malt. Oily. Bit of alcohol.
Info: 355ml bottle, 21/11-2010
Tap. An easy option for a good IPA when the beer menu isnt so great. Orange copper color, hefty 90 IBUs produces a somewhat sharp hop bite. Well balanced IPA.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2013 Great beer. Pours an orange-yellow; pretty cloudy in there. Head is thin and white. Aroma is grapefruit, bitter hoppiness. Taste is sweet and bitter, grapefruit and some pineapple. Palate is clean. Full and tasty beer.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy light reddish amber with a thin but lasting white head (slight greenish tinge).  Spicy aroma, some citrus, definitely hoppy.  Taste of hops - citrus, pine, some earthiness, a bit of malt sweetness, like caramel, Warming mouthfeel.  Finishes with a citrus warming bitterness but not too bitter, and some grassiness.  One of the finest examples of an imperial IPA.
12 oz bottle. Golden amber color. Aroma is citrus, raisins, caramel and floral. Taste is sweet malts with tart citrus and bitter hops that leads to a dry finish.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2011 This has a very fruity aroma, It has a dark amber color.Average carbonation. Im not sure if it adds up to the hype of this beer. It does taste good but almost too nice for a beer.  I saw Dogfish hyped on "Beer Wars" documentary so I felt obligatory to try this. 

Update: I can not drink this. Way too hoppy. Bought a 4-pack and 3 were drain pours. High rating doesnt mean itll taste good. Too sour,too bitter, too fruity.

This is a good beer.  On pouring, the head was nice but it went away rather quickly but managed to lace nicely.  Color was a nice deep gold.  On the nose, wow, it was pine, earth, and citrus hops over a nice malt, caramel backbone.  The beer was medium full bodied and very smooth.  Bitter in the finsh.  On the tongue, Im gettinging what my nose smelled.  Pine, citrus, and earthy hops over a nice caramel malt backbone.  Well balanced but with plenty of bitter.  Ive not had one of these in well over a year, until today.  The next taste will not wait that long.  Well done.

Notes from Tuesday, August 31 2010
12 oz. bottle from Woodmans Madison

Ar: A bit of caramel, grapefruit zest, a bit of black pepper-like spice.
Ap: Pours a light copper with a light orange streak when held to the light.  3/4" head sticks around for a while, but doesnt leave much lace.
T: Citrus, a bit of pine, with a nice caramel-malt sweetness.  Very complex finish.  Medium alcohol burn, brandy-like complexity.
P: Very nice.  Chewy body distributes the flavors nicely.  Just enough carbonation to wake up the palate.

O: As advertised, excellent IIPA.
Delicious IPA. In my opinion, as the beer warmed up in the glass, it became significantly more flavorful.

drank in comparisson to the 60 minute IPA and Squall 90 minute IPA and Stone Ruination and Stone IPA. darker in colour than the 60 minute brew but alot of the same tones. overall a more expressive brew.  big hops and again some cereal notes but I love the malted notes in there. extremely balanced on the nose and palate. wow big! boozy, hoppy and malted notes. it floats on the edge of having a bit too much tertiary boozy notes but not really, really really good stuff.

12oz bottle pours a nice golden beer with a slight white head. Aroma is a little strong with strong notes of grapefruit and citrus and some yeast. Great floavor right from the start. The hops is very well balanced with sugars and fruit that is very pleasing. IPAs are not my faviort beer but this one is very pleasing, a must try for anyone.

Excellent IPA for 9.0% and not as bitter as one would think for 90 IBUs. Good head and carbonation that last throughout with a sweet banana aroma. Its a dark copper color with an almost creamy texture. Little expensive at a price of $12.95 a 4-pack (12 oz) at Safeway-Jantzen Beach Portland, OR. If held in the mouth, the alcohol content will start to seep through. Overall, a very good and well balanced IPA.


banana, copper, medium bitterness, light sweetness, full body, bitter, lively, creamy, medium body.

The highly rated 90-Minute Imperial IPA delivered what was it promised as being a very rich and high quality beer.  Like all beers it is all in the eye of the beholder with their individual tastes.  Myself personally, I am not the biggest fan of IPAs, but Dogfish Head still produced a very nice high quality beer.  I would have to say like all Dogfish Head beers that the aroma was fantastic.  A characteristic that really starts off the party and is often overlooked.  It had a very nice heavy dry hop aroma and a white mostly lasting head.  The beer had a beautiful cloudy appearance to it and surprised me with an initial sweet flavor in the beginning.  The middle yielded a fruity touch with the common bitter finish with IPAs that was quite delightful.  A full body on the palate with a soft carbonated oily texture with a long lasting bitter finishes.  I am always impressed with what Dogfish Head produces, and love their TV show on Discovery.  Whatever it is that they come up with next, I will be theyre waiting in line.
Perfect IIPA. The nose isnt misleading in the taste. Nice punch of hops and alcohol

I should write something pithy and self righteous but the bottom line is this  is a great hoppy beer.  A bit overwhelming at first sip for an undeveloped pallet.  It mellows after a couple sips and you can enjoy its complexity.  This rating is based on a draught.  From the bottle not nearly as good but there is no way I can go to Enos and not have one.  Awesome!

Poured into a sniffer. Nice head copped color body. This is what a double IPA shoud taste like. Bitterness with a pleasant aftertaste. Alcohol is not overly present but it definitely is there. Probably the best/most balanced of the 60, 90 and 120. G-d bless Sam and his vibrating football game which gave him the inspiration for the 90 minute...look  it up.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2012 A: Darkened copper color, nearing a more bronze-ish hue. Plenty of lacing as it goes down and a good head to start.

S: Plenty of hops in this one, but the malt comes in strong with sweetness and fruit.

T: Sweet malt has definite presence to balance out the excessive amount of hops. The standard for an East Coast DIPA.

M: Big and creamy. Very nice.

D: For this style, this is definitely quite drinkable. Very nice beer all around.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-24-2009
Golden color. Very light head. Smooth finish First time trying it and loved all the flavors that it offered.
Poured beautifully. Nice big head. Heaps of hops on the nose. dried fruit, sweet and citrus. Flavour was much the same with a bit of grunt from the 9%. Creamy in the mouth. Just great!
Same bottle as pictured. Pours small head that retains. Not as much pine as expected. Enjoyed more than 60 min.
Typical aroma of an IPA but not a normal taste. usually you get a pine like flavour this one has a flavour similar to a coffee flavour. I do like this one alot
one of my favorites. great bitter taste with a slight sweet finish. the hop quality is outstanding, subtle notes of citris and raisin. very drinkable year around.

Draft at the Euston Tap. Pours clear, shiney gold with a modest, tight, white head. Good and hoppy nose with pine and light fruits, along with tons of malt. Very sweet flavor with notes of caramel and honey, and plenty of bitterness, but not at all abrasive. Medium to full in body with average carbonation and a fairly resinous mouthfeel. Lightly warming on the finish with tons of sweetness, malty caramel and sugar, and plenty of lingering bitterness. Just great and super drinkable. Worth the reputation.
Orange and floral aroma with an oily, alcoholic taste. Both are quite strong. There is a creamy, smooth after taste.

Ahhh 90 min.  From a 12oz into a snifter.  Pours a nice pinkish red with an inch or so of head.  Mild lacing.  Aroma of flowers, alcohol and sugar.  Palate is smooth with a perfect amount of carbonation to give it some body.  Taste is very floral with some warmth.  Good hop and alcohol kick, but not at all bitter.  Its just a solid IPA and the gold standard upon which all others are judged.  It doesnt floor me, but impresses me every time I have it.
This is the perfect beer! God himself couldnt balance a better IPA. This beer is what made me a fan of IPAs.
12oz bottle.  Not a big IPA drinker.  Could only handle about half.  Great beer, but too hoppy for my taste.
Slight head, foam sticks to the sides.  Nice color with some bubbles.  Good taste and slight bite.  Overall good beer.
Great IPA. Its got the bite but also the deeper comlexity of flavor more common to stouts etc..

My first review, beer newbie here.

Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA. (India Pale Ale) I had it in 12oz bottle, poured into a pint glass. Pours a orange-bronze color. Thin, 1-finger head. As soon as I opened the bottle, I immediately smelled the hop aroma; Pine-like. Taste starts off with a subtle sweetness and finished with a big, bitter, hop bite. Like the smell, I also taste citrus and pine notes. Mostly the latter. A little alcohol taste in there too. (9% ABV, stronger than your average beer.) Slight creaminess but not too thick. Crisp. Very Drinkable. Overall, this is a great beer. I enjoyed it. This my first in this style, Imperial IPA which is known for a its bitter hop taste, that Ive had and thought the hop bite was refreshing.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 Smooth, light brown beer with small bubbles; no real head. Aroma not as rich or strong as expected. Earth, sugar cane, cheese, leaves. Tasty textures in here, with a nice bitterness and well balanced sweetness. Not too complex but a smooth IPA with great aftertaste. (On my FL trip.) (Rating re-indexed)

90 minute gave a very clear copper pour with bronze-gold and orange hues, and made a faint off-white head with a little orange tint, there is a stream of effervescent bubbles in the center of the glass and the bubble stream is persistent, I found no sediment in the bottle, 

this beer has aromas of piney, grassy, resin and citrus hops, toasted malt, some malt sweetness, light orange and lemon fruit, touch of caramel, 

there are flavors of toasted malt, and lots of hops, citrus, some light fruit, 
the malt flavor and sweetness trail a bit after the finish but it ends sort of dry, there is a touch of alcohol dryness on the tongue, 

the mouth feel is thick with a touch of alcohol warmth on the palate, 

a nice IPA2.

It pours a deep golden color with a nice small white head that lingers. It has small amounts of lacing. The is a vast amount of carbonation but it is very tiny bubbles.

On the nose I get some pine notes and a little malt and some floral notes

The hops steals the show when it comes to the flavor. There is some malt there and pine. It has a decently high above so the alcohol taste comes through as well. The hops are very in your face but not overpowering at the same time. The malts actually do a pretty good job of standing up to all the different hops in this.

It finishes well obviously bitter with a little citrus in there. Not much of a session beer. Well due to the 9% abv. But  a must for any Dogfish head fan. Just a little too much on the hops for me.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2010 Pours a lovely golden amber brown with a pale head that has orange colored notes. Smells floral and of raisins and other fruits and also smells of alcohol. Starts off tasting sweet but quickly moves to a crisp bitterness due to the added hops. Medium bodied with a smooth, creamy texture and not very intense carbonation. Has a bitter finish that lasts smooth.

12 ounce bottle consumed within 2 months of bottling.  Pours a nice caramel color with brilliant clarity and a medium white head.  Aromas of dates, raisins, with strong grassy and floral notes.  Taste starts out sweet, with hints of raisins, dates, and caramel backbone is decently balanced with the grassy and floral bitter finish.  Finish also has an almost bourbon like alcohol bite to it.  Medium bodied and carbonated.  Overall, decently balanced yet I have to say Im disappointed.  For all the hype Dogfish Head and the 90 Minute IPA gets, I can think of many more enjoyable double IPAs.

I had this beer a while back and from what I can remember I enjoyed it.  Ive had this at the pub/brewery so it was fresh.

Nothing special about it is popping into my head at the moment.

Bottle poured into tulip glass. amber orange with a creamy white head that dissipated to leave lots of lacing. Aroma of pine and citrus, with some floral hints. Taste is all hops, hoppy crispness, hoppy sting. Also some sweetness. This is great Double IPA. Very refreshing

Very classic and typical DIPA.  Thick and fully flavoured with big sweet malts and syrupy full throttle hops. To my palate got progressively lighter through the palate and extremely quaffable for a 9% beer. The sweet citrus and light brandy notes are very attractive.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 Bottle @ Old Chicago Fort Collins. Clear, burnt orange appearance with a white head. Toasty toffee malty, brown sugar, piney, earthy hoppy aroma. Toasty, dark caramel, toffee, dark cracker malty, piney, earthy, a touch citrus hoppy flavor.

Aroma is pine and citrus. Poured in a snifter, creates a nice creamy head with good lacing. Decent amount of bitterness, heavy sweetness from the malt. Caramel and a little bit of pine citrus in the finish.

A great beer. This is the the one that turned me onto IPAs in the first place -- and still one of the best IPAs Ive ever had. This has a dark, golden appearance and a rich hoppy taste that has a smooth bite to it. You wont notice that 9 percent ABV until you try standing up.

12 oz. Pours a nice amber, thin white head with good retention, thin small bubble lacing. Strong hop aroma, slight malt sweetness. Hop dominance, but very smooth, not too bitter flavor followed by a hint of alcohol and malt. Very smooth slick texture, medium body, medium-low carbonation.

Time to step things up a notch and try out the Dogfish Head 90 minute IPA.  Ive been holding onto this one for a couple of weeks but I figured Id better drink it before it loses the majority of its hop characteristics.  Pours kind of a tangelo orange brown, with very little head.  Granted, Im using a snifter for this one so I wasnt really looking for a big ass head.  I might use a tumbler if I come across one of these again.  Nose is an incredible detonation of hop aroma.  Floral and citrus hops are there and theres this raisin sent underneath, almost like what youd get out of a dark Belgian strong ale.  Kind of surprising, actually.  My first impressions while taking my sample is dang, this beer is smooth.  Its very full, almost thick, with a slight alcohol burn in the finish.  Its more well rounded and less sharp than the 60 minute IPA, especially in the finish.  Theres hops here, to be sure, and well catalog those in a moment, but I think its important to note I actually think this may be less bitter than the 60 minute IPA.  Either that, or the assload of malt thats in this lends a huge sweetness that helps you push through the bitterness.  I mentioned the Belgian Strong earlier when talking aroma, and that comparison is valid when talking about the mouthfeel.  Its thick, bordering on syrupy.  Huge sticky lacing just coats the glass.  Raisins are there in the taste too.  Its extremely malt centric, with a roasted caramel syrup note that really sticks out for me.  The hops are most certainly there in this one, with pine and orange rind coming out the more that you drink it.  Theyre not as pronounced as I would like.  Not sure if thats what the brewer intended, or because this one sat on the shelf for a while before I picked it up.  Regardless, this is one phenomenal beer.  As I said Im not completely sold on it being a double IPA, but its very good nonetheless.

Phenomenal beer. Aroma is sweet crisp citrus hops. Beautiful head and golden body. First taste is huge on the hops. Hops and more hops. Pine and citrus nuances. I love the hops. Huge alcohol hit as well.

Clear med red-amber with 1/2" off white head. Not a lot of Smell getting lite barley malts with some citrus sweetness..not getting a lot of aroma of hops here? Taste brings a good balance of the malts, hops, citrus sweetness, mild alcohol..a nice balance.  lite to medium body, malts mildly cream feel, nice carbonation zing and decent alcohol warmth. Overall a fairly strong brew with nice hop and barley malt sweetness. All tied together well. 9% abv shows up but fits in the mix nicely!
Bottle: Pours a clear amber with a foamy off-white head. Aroma of citrus hops and malt. Primary flavor of caramel malt with some citrus hop finish. Was expecting more hop flavor.  Well hidden alcohol

330ml bottle.  Pours amber with a tight head.  Aroma is resin hops, pineapple, grapefruit and other tropical fruits.  Piney hops on the start, but balanced nicely with the malt.  Lasting grapefruit bitterness on the finish.

[330ml bottle, Beers of Europe, Kings Lynn] Been wanting to try this for a long time, given its reputation. Pours a hazy caramel colour with a menacing hue  the aroma is astonishing, massive hops, warming alcohol tingles the nose. The mouthfeel is also very warming, which disproves my theory about dark spicy beers working best in the chillier months. You need to chew your way through it, but its absolutely worth it. At the beginning it wont affect your tastebuds the way a 9% beer should  later on though, they surrender and it really drinks to its par, coupled with a fantastic rising bitterness on the aftertaste. Simply one of the greatest beers in the world [20112009]
This is delicious. Very robust and hoppy.  Some great citrus notes as well. I would recommend this to anyone who loves IPAs

Citrusy, very hoppy, and backed with plenty of malts. Dogfish Head 90 minute is a very palatable double IPA that hides 9% very well. Finishes with a crisp hoppy bite. Very nice beer for most all occasions, but best consumed with food :)

Almost (perhaps it is) amber, not much head.  Plenty of pine hops aroma, but you can tell theres some malt going on in there too - almost a caramel aroma.  Taste is plenty of bitterness and pine hops flavor, but well balanced with malt.  A touch too much sweetness.  This and Stones IPA make for an interesting comparison.

Yellow amber color.  Bready aroma, sweet malt, faint citrus hops.  Full mouthfeel, caramel, citrus, nuts and toffee.  The hops didnt come through nearly as much as I remember it, might be an old btl.  Finishes sweet with only a slight bit of bitterness.

A very light floral hop aroma. Pale amber in color, clear and slightly sparkling. Minimal white fast depleting head. A perfect medium body and not overpowering hop flavor. Not at all what I expected from an Imperial IPA. Creamy, long aftertaste.  Overall a fantastic beer and another great IPA from Dogfish Head.

DEEEElicious!  So much flavor in this, and I dont know hat it is but wow what a good flavor.  Is there a beer label between an IPA and a double IPA?  That is where this should be, and it is a perfect balance.
Faint amber color leaving thin lace. Nose of lemongrass, spruce, roasted nuts and mango. Taste of raisin, dark chocolate, caramel, and apricot. Bitter finish.

1/10/2010 - 355ml bottle @ Klaas place Thanks to Nate for the bottle! 
Pours a clear orange to amber coloured beer. Practically no head. Aroma has spices, pepper, cloves, some sweet malts. Taste has sweet malts, spices and a little hop bitter. Aftertaste has fruity hops, passion fruits and pineapple. Maybe because weve been drinking/building up to this one, but it doesnt taste as bitter as I expected. Very nice complexity in it though.

A- Poured into Snifter. Nice Golden Auburn, Orangery colour. Clear as well. Nice foamy head that lingered fairly long.

S- Super hoppy. Wonderful smell the hops are very floral and heavy. Also picking up lots of fruity smells. Apricot seems to be present, along with what seems like berries (strawberries, raspberries)

T- Very Sweet. the hops are wonderful, far better than the 60 min. The fruity flavour comes out with the hops and blends with them very nicely. There is also a hint of some citrus flavours. The beer has a very smooth mouth feel as well and sits in the mouth nice and somewhat creamy texture. There is very little bitterness to be had as well in the after taste, also an improvement over the 60 min.

D- Definitely one of the best ipas out there. Hops and fruitiness and balanced very well to make for a beer that is very enjoyable to drink.
Although pricey,this IPA is the standard by which all the other IPAs are measured.In my opinion DFH 90 min. is the best IPA in America.

Bought a 4 pack.

A: Clear Red color with a moderate head and lace. The brew was highly carbonated and alive.

S: Sweat floral bouquet of spices, grass, and hops.

T: Sweet raison malt base with a punch of aroma and bitter hops. Very fresh grass undertone. 

M: Chewy and highly carbonated. 

D: For an imperial IPA, this was very smooth and drinkable. The packaging says this has been voted the #1 IPA, but I have a couple other IPAs I would rank above this one. I do, however, recommend this beer highly to IPA lovers.

A: snifter. pours a nice, deep amber/copper color, with some burnt sienna hues. big off-white head with outstanding head retention and gorgeous lacing.

S: Huge simcoe hop aroma with big citrus hop notes. Nice sweet malts really bring out the hops. Some light caramel hints.

T: I remember this being way hoppier before. This is so well-balanced. Wonderful citrus hops, mostly or all Simcoe, matched perfectly with the sweet malts. such a solid flavor. I pull some oak characteristics as well.

M: nice and thick. perfect carbonation. thick malt flavors make my mouth really happy right now.

D: obviously a great beer, and if you havent had it, either you are 21 or have been hiding under a rock for a while. Beautiful.
Clearly really special brew...deep complex flavor that is intense and has a wonderfully clean aroma

355 ml bottle. Rated @ 28.5.2010.
Pours a clear amber colour with a small frothy white head. Sweet on the nose with raisins, caramel malts and citrus. Flavour of strong hops, caramel malts, raisins, caramel and dark chocolate. Full bodied with a warming bitter finish. Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2014 Poured beautiful copper color.   Lingering head.   Strong hop and malt Aroma.  A ton of taste from start to finish.  I cant stop drinking these.  A masterpiece, and an alltime favorite.

Probably my favorite offering from Dogfish, nice floral citrus aroma. Pours golden amber with nice frothy head, sticky lacing. Hops are immediately exploding in my mouth and the booze is almost masked by the intense flavor making this a dangerously easy to drink brew.
One of the best IPAs Ive ever tasted. Good hoppy flavor, but doesnt detract from the beers natural deliciousness.

"Imperial IPAs are probably my favorite specific style of brew, and I would not call myself a hop head by any stretch, but very much liked this beer. The first one of the four pack seemed to have too much hops for my tastes, but the other three where quite good. Not much else I could add to the reviews, but it was very good.
Wow, 90 IPA is well balanced.  This is one of the few beers Ive had that has clocked in at 9% that tastes pleasant.
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2011 grass and citrus aroma, dark orange pour with light tan head, thick, sticky palate, very nice taste with a smooth, long finish

Copper, thin bubbly white head. Nose is hops with a warm malt backnote. Some citrus, along with the hop piney dustiness. Slight almost dustiness in the nose. Mouth is massively hoppy, dry, some sweetness, citrus notes on the swallow. Sweet coating mouthfeel, with some bitterness cutting through. Almost weird sweetness (because you dont expect it), with a lasting alcohol warmth. Fantastic beer.

Pours a burnt orangey copper with a nice white creamy head. Aroma of floral citrusy hops, sweet spices. Taste is floral citrusy hops with some sweet malt. Palate is full body, good carbonation, and  nice smooth mouth feel. Finish is bitter floral citrus hops, but not overpowering, balanced by some sweet caramel maltiness. Overall a very nicely balanced, complex, drinkable and flavorfull brew.

12 oz bottle. Pours an orangey copper with a little fluffy white head. Nose was at first an explosion of hops, but I let it warm a bit and the malts really come through with notes of dried fruit. Full, smooth body that finishes somewhat crisp. For as hoppy as this is, it has an amazing balance of sticky malts on the finish. The taste and the finish are complex and I wish I could do it justice- bitter hops that give way to rich, sweet malts. What a lovely beer- Im looking forward to the next time I can spoil myself with a four-pack of this. Two thumbs up.

Le liquide est orangé.  Présence dune petite tête mousseuse qui laisse derrière elle quelques traces visibles sur le verre.  Au nez, les houblons laissent échapper déminents parfums remplis dagrumes et de résine.  En arrière-plan, les grains maltés qui émergent sont doux, façon très «sucre dorge».  Présence délicate de lalcool.  Au goût, les houblons sont gros et huileux, enrobés dun intéressant sucré de malt, avec un côté très amérisant de pamplemousse et de parfum doranges.  Bonnes touches résineuses qui se manifestent avec vigueur et complexité.  En bouche, le liquide a une belle rondeur avec son effervescence juste à point et sa texture veloutée.  La finale est explosive et persistante avec une amertume qui se dévoile avec intensité.  Présence en arrière-goût dune belle chaleur dalcool.  En résumé, peut définitivement créer une dépendance. (Thumbs in the air for Benjamin)

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 Clear orange-amber with a substantial, billowy off-white head. Aroma of caramel, citrus, sweet ripe fruits and flowers. Taste is very well balanced; big and malty with a solid hop bitterness. Medium-full bodied with smooth carbonation.

Pours orange with nice pale head and good lacing. More citrus-y than I expected. The hops are there, but not as pronounced as in most American style DIPAs. I think I may actually prefer the 60 minute.

12oz. bottle. Belle couleur cuivrée avec un filet de mousse blanche. au nez la bière développe des arômes de caramel, très fruité,  beaucoup de houblon. En bouche la bière est soyeuse, un peu herbeuse, doucereuse, avec un peu de sucre résiduel et beaucoup de houblon. Lalcool ne se fait pas trop sentir. Très bonne bière, moderne comme style. (merci SK)

Appearance is an orange color with a nice white head that turns into a thin lacing as it works its way down the glass. Aroma is very heavily laden with citrus-y hops. Taste is much more than I expected in that it has a blast of hops up front that taste very much like grapefruit, then a more mellow hop flavor like that in an American Pale Ale, and then the finish is slightly yeasty with another kick of a more floral hop. This is a magnificent beer that I would definitely like to have again soon.
A little better than the 60 minute, but still not a big fan of this popular IPA.

Just a deadly beer... strong beer with hops not too overpowering.  Cant really drink more than 2 of these, but that goes the same for any 9-10% beer.  Grab a 4 pack and have yourself a weekend.  Cheers
Poured a golden brown with heads that quickly faded. The initial aroma contained hops, banana and a subtle mix of other fruits. It was not as bitter as I thought, but still strong.

This is the closest thing to a perfect IPA I have ever tasted. I REALLY wish they would distribute their fine, fine ales in Kansas. I get really sick of having to take a trunkload back from Colorado/Tennessee whenever we roadtrip. I love this beer!!!  60 minute, not enough. 120 over the top. 90 is perfection.

Poured from 12 oz bottle while doing laundry on an early September night, also after a long and boring day at jury duty.  Ive had the 60 minute IPA before, which is great, along with the 120 minute IPA, which is destructive.  This one flows more on the 60 minute side as its not 20% ABV and I can drink it without excessive slurring by the end of the bottle.  Aroma is a fantastic balance of citrus hops and woodsy/roasted malt.  Appearance is a very clear amber with a thin head.  Taste is relatively thick for an IIPA, has a touch of that "enamel stripping" from the hop oil that Sam describes in his book, definitely a very hoppy beer.  Im a fan.

Poured from a 12-ounce bottle into a "thieved" tulip glass.  Notes of candy, apricots, citrus and malt.  Strong alcohol and grapefruit profile. Im a little drunk right now, but Im thinking this is a little too much for me.  Dont get me wrong, I enjoy tough beers.  But, the alcohol / hop / malt dynamic is too over-the-top for me.  Having said that, I think this is "spot on" for a DIPA and Im sure you hop heads dig this. Cheers.
Perfect beer for a relaxing evening. Toasty sweet malt character is prevelant on the tongue and less in the aroma. Hop aroma is citrus hops!

Bottle: Pours a cloudy golden, with a modest white head. This brew smells like the 60 minute. Maltiness dominates here , once again, like the 60 minute. You sense the caramel malt over all else - coupled with piney and floral hops. A hint of citrus, a hint of breadiness. And once again, this heavy malted (double) ipa feel from dogfish doesnt work for me. Just a personal preference , but I prefer the dreadnaught flavor type, nothing against the brew.

A strong, powerful IPA that suffers from being a bit sweet and a bit too powerful.

Nothing wrong at all with this brew - Id have it again, but the strength of it overwhelmed all else.

One of the best IPAs around. This and Flying Dogs Double Dog Double Pale Ale are tops in this style. This is one of my staple beers. The aroma is heavenly hoppy, the taste is smooth carmely hoppy, and the aftertaste is just supreme.

12 oz bottle Pours to a deep cloudy orange color with a light white head. Aroma is heavy hop with light citrus notes. Taste is medium to high bitter and light sweet. Palate is medium body with a slick texture. mildly lively and finishes with a nice bitter end. Overall a fantastic beer. Dogfish Head knows their business and this beer is top notch.

4 pack from the local liquor store, Chicago, IL.  I heard a lot about this before i actually tried it, and everything lived up to the hype.  Great D-IPA.  Taste is pine, caramel, with a slight citrus.  Easy to drink.  Easy to sip.  Easy to relax.

Copper color.  PIney floral hops in aroma with some caramel.  Full body.  Complex flavors with bitter hops but a lot of maltiness and almost a litte sweet.  Wouldnt drink more than 1 or 2 at a time.  If anything less bitter than the 60 min.  One of the best I think but not what to have if looking for extreme bitterness.

Poured with an amber color and a quick to disappear tan head. Pine, citrus, caramel, apple in the aroma. Hops are not overpowering, but very much present. Medium dense body with high carbonation. Well balanced all around, cant complaint. Good one.

The beer that got me into the "I must try every IPA on the planet" phase. 

 The taste, the smell, the alcohol... Ill always love this beer.

12 oz bottle into snifter. The first aroma I smell is mold (ugh!), and I take my nose away for a bit. Sticking my nose into the glass again, Im relieved to say that the moldy smell is gone. Whats left is some caramel malt, pepper, citrus. Pours a hazy orange with a medium dissipating head that leaves some spidery lace and a blanket of foam. Starts out malty sweet, turns bitter for a second, then goes back to sweet, then finishes with an alternating sweet/bitter taste. Very different for a DIPA, or any other beer Ive ever had for that matter. Very tasty. Medium to high carbonation with an oily mouthfeel and a long finish. Very good.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2010 Pours a light orange with a moderate head. It has a fresh grapefruit aroma. The taste is of very dry malt with lots of hops. The alcohol was a bit too noticeable, but it was okay. It wasnt the worst beer Ive had, but I cant see myself buying it anytime too soon. It just seemed a little unbalanced and sloppy.

One of the best double IPAs in my opinion, because it doesnt get too heavy.  I find a lot of double IPAs can get a heavy body, and why?  

Huge wonderful hop nose with a lot of citrus to it.  The body then has the hops, but its not overpowering, and those citrus, grass, floral flavors continue in to a full (but not heavy!) body and a clean finish.

Highly recommended.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2011 Beautiful color on this one. Dont get much on the aroma except a kind of fruity sweetness with grapefruit. For being 90 IBUs, this is suprisingly on the sweet side. It starts out with a pleasant light sweetness in the mouth, but it leave a slightly bitter hop taste on the end of the palate.  The dominant taste, and aroma, here is grapefruit. Surprisingly drinkable, with the alcohol somewhat well hidden, it sneaks up on you though (comes out more as it warms). Palate (and taste somewhat) is easily destroyed by having food while drinking this; dont start eating after starting this beer.
Darn near perfect.  Wonderful hoppy aroma, nice head that lasts as long as you have beer in the glass, beautiful golden color and a hop bite that seems just right for an Imperial IPA.

Finally rated this. I have no idea what took so long. Pours a clear amber with nice white head. Nose is very floral with lots of hops and citrus. Taste is citrus, bushel of hops, dark malts and almost a bourbon taste in background.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2014 Pours a deep hazy amber with off-white head.  Aroma is amazing - layered hops that start piney then go to grapefruit then give a brief floral kiss at the end of the inhalation.  Also a bit of candied-fruit in there somewhere.  Clean bitterness that sits right above a well-positioned caramel malty backbone.  Deep fruits.  Bitterness hangs on and reminds you what youre missing when the glass is empty.  Well-carbonated with flavors that bounce off the palate.  A masterpiece!  Re-rate: fresh bottle.  Way more English-like than I remember.  English-like citrus bitterness with deep toasted malt.  Herbal and citrus hops.  Not altogether impressive.  Reality rate -1.0
Bottle) I was expecting something better based on the ratings. Dogfish owns the IPA style, but I have actually had better Imperial IPAs.  Good, but could have been better.

Bout time I rate this.  Bottle, poured into a glass outside of the Falcons game last night.  Good looking pour, clear, copper, nice looking thick head.  Aroma was a good mix of malty sweetness, citrusy hops and a bit of earthiness.  Big hops flavors throughout, oily mouthfeel, finished with a decent bitterness.  Lively carbonation.  A great example of a big American IPA.

Light orange pour, with a foamy head that lasts. Intense aroma with some floral notes. Taste is floral hops, citrus hops, spruce hops, some subtle malt tones.Enough malt and barley flavor to keep it balanced. Nearly perfect!
Très bonne IPA, brassé au Delaware, belle mousse, bien gazeuse, goût de raisin. Pack de 4 bouteilles.
very good thick texture with a full head.  notes of alcohol and hopps. very hoppy

Bottle.

A - Copper/light amber color with a large foamy and fluffy white head. Good retention with a decent layer of lace that sticks behind.

S - Good amount of different hoppy aromas come out with citrus/orange aroma, tropical fruit (mango, some pineapple, grapefruit, and others). Some floral and pine also present. Good backbone of caramel and other sweet malt aroma.

T - Similar to the nose. A lot of the hop flavors are sweeter fruit flavors along with touches of floral and pine flavors. Along with the sweeter caramel malt, this is a bit of a sweeter IPA. Not a lot of caramel flavor, but some, and definitely a malt presence in this one. There is a nice spiced and bitterness underneath this and some more earthy flavors as well.

M - Fuller side of medium body with a good amount of carbonation. Pretty smooth.

D - Pretty easy to drink with lots of fruity hop flavors. Definitely has a sweeter side, but there is enough bitterness and other flavors that it isnt cloying. Alcohol is pretty well hidden.

Notes: Overall this is a pretty good beer. Lots of fruity hop flavors and it comes off a little on the sweet side for the style, but it isnt cloying. Nice, easy to drink beer that is a good quality and easy to find beer.
citrus, herbs. Great aroma, appearance, and taste. Golden brown color. Very tasty beer.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2010 Slightly see-through orange pour, with a medium foamy head that lasts through most of the drink.  Smells sweet yet fruity--Im getting orange rind, citrus hops, and sugar.  In all, it kinda smells like an orange Sour Patch Kids medly.  Taste is intense yet reserved.  Ive never had a IIPA this smooth and malty.  Taste hits with heavy citrus hops and floral hops, with an aggressive caramel/toffee malt.  Long fruitish aftertaste that keeps a little of the taste in your mouth until your next sip.  Only letdown was the texture, which was slightly oily and slick.  Magic in a glass.  Potentially one of the best IIPAs ever, and a fair argument for best common beer on market.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2013 Clear light brown pour with a thin white head with good lacing. Aroma is moderate malty and hoppy, citrus notes with alcohol presence. Flavor is moderate sweet with malt, very "soft" and bitterness with a great balance, only slightly oily. Finishes soft and light lingering bitterness.

On tap at White Horse, London SW6. Colour; orange, decent carbonation with foamy hay-cloured head. Nose; aggressive hops, citrus, fresh pine. Taste; citrus hops, floral, dried fruits, tangy, wood, more hops . Brilliant long bitter finish. Very, very enjoyable, its a bit like getting punched in the face by a big bag of hops.

Nicely done. The pour immediately lets you in on some of the texture tones. It pours thick like 10W-40. The head is very creamy and slow with tight lacing and the color is a deep amber. Smoother than the 60 minute with a harsher bite and the after taste is long lasting. The bitters open up flavors in your mouth that are untouchable by other beers of this caliber. It comes in a four pack and is meant for four people. This is a great beer.
Pours a clear orange copper color.  Fresh floral pine aroma.  Intense piney hops upfront that mellows as you work your way through the brew turning into a great beer.  Overall, one word... delicious.

12 Oz. Pours a clear golden amber with big white head that leaves heavy lacing and the perfect amount of persistent carbonation.  Aroma is very hoppy, a grapefruit, resinous, and citrusy type of hoppy but I also a slight not of raisins.  Taste is spot on, most DIPAs are over the top hops but this one is incredibly well balanced.  Very strong bitterness with a very strong sweetness followed by darker malt tones.  Finish is a sharp spicy bitterness followed by a long much milder sweetness.  Full bodied and slightly sticky and oily, carbonation is medium strong for a beer of this caliber.

12oz bottled July 26, 2010.  Very fresh.  Pours clear amber with a two finger off white head that leaves a bit of lacing.  Aroma is very nice and features juicy citrus, orange, grapefruit, pineapple, as well as floral and grassy hops.  There is also a fair bit of sweet caramel and fruity malts.  Flavor heavy duty citrus and resinous hops, golden raisins, and some serious sweet caramel malt for a DIPA, moderate bitterness that is held back by the big malt presence.  Noticeable alcohol.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy, gets sticky, low to medium carbonation.  Its been a long time since Ive had this, always enjoyed it in the past and it is indeed a very good DIPA.  Glad to revisit.
Pours a clear amber color with a white head that diminishes quickly, has aroma that is full of hops, citrus and delicious malt, taste is balanced with hops and malt, a very nice imperial!

Aroma: nothing standout, but youll notice that Im not very good at discerning aromas and, therefore, not very good at rating aroma either, you can smell the hops, which is all that Id want in an Imperial IPA; Appearance: beautiful, clear, tan with full, white head when poured, the color is perfectly representative of the amount of malt that is mixed in with the hops, good carbonation that is slow to dissipate; Taste: Id have to say that Ive had Imperial IPAs that are more flavorful, but I dont think I can say that Ive had one thats more balanced between the "maltish" and the "hoppish" aspects of the brew, tremendously easy to drink and very addictive, one that you could "savour" several of in a row, citrusy, grapefruit aspects to the hops more than pine or cedar, excellent; Palate: again, like I said, very addictive, youre left wanting to drink more, actually writing this review is making me want to go to the cooler and grab another; Overall: Ive had more unique and standout IPAs but perhaps not one as balanced, its the paragon of blending the flavors that hops and malt bring to the table, one does not overpower the other, highly recommended

Ive had 90 minute several times, but Im always amazed at how I enjoy this beer out of the bottle more than from a tap.  From a tap the beer is like a meal in itself.  Luckily, the amount of malt to hops is well balanced and Im not overcome by the IBUs.  The alcohol hits hard with this beer and drinking this will take some time if you plan to enjoy anything else in the evening.

My favorite from DFH. Medium amber with a red tint. Lots of hops and citrus...smells refreshing. Hint with hops right off the bat but calms down afterwards with a very refreshing finish. A great double that I drink often...a must-have for IPA fans and a great beer from DFH.
citrus, vanilla, raisin, amber, clear, minimal head, medium bitterness, medium body, average carbonation, bitter,

Amber/copper clear pour white head thick lacing..... citrusy hop aroma and some bready malt ... taste of citrusy hops way maltier than the 60 minute lots of malts in this one with some hints of raisin/dark fruits... a bitter malty finish .... not a bad brew a bit overrated compared to some other dbl ipas but a solid one

(2009) Not as hoppy as many hopheads would like from a IIPA, but still pretty decent. There is a very present malt characteristic upfront with a backing of floral hops. As someone who was introduced to hops through Stones characteristic pine flavor this is an interesting change of pace.

Bottle. Poured a clear deep amber with a near white head that dissipated slowly to the edges and laced nicely. Aroma was full of citrus notes with backing grains with hints of dark fruits and raisins. Flavor began with strong citrus notes that mellowed to sweet syrupy grains, dark fruits and raisin.

The summit of IPAs...doesnt get much better than this.  I love this beer, it is probably the best American Double IPA, period.  Stone puts out a good one too, but this one takes my trophy.  The aroma is of hops and caramel sweetness with the right amount of alcohol hinted as well.  The appearance is a deep golden amber with a two finger off white head.  The taste is the best there is...it attacks your taste buds with malty goodness and then assaults your tongue with just the right amount of hops.  The mouthfeel is just right, not too thin and not too thick.  Overall, an amazing beer.  4.3

This smells amazing: sweet, floral citrus aromatic smell, some malts, god this smells good. Not much of a head, but I didnt pour it; otherwise, its amber, clear and lovely. Taste is lovely: nice balance of caramel hops and bitterness at the end - but not overwhelming.

A tall white head tops this deep amber ale and when this diminishes it leaves a layer of tight lacing.  A perfectly rounded aroma of pine, malt, lemon grass, grapefruit and mango rises to the nose.  Its a mellow scent, certainly not as zesty as some single hopped IPAs but just as certainly its more complex.  There are notes of raisins and marmalade, maybe just a little brandy.  In the mouth its thick and oily with rich, heavy hops.  The continual addition process really does round the flavour.  It goes from fresh passion fruit to woody straw in a second; but then the tastes develop backwards and forwards between sips.  Finish is bitter and sweet.  Its so easy to grow a bit bored with this, due to the wide regard and easy availability, but every time I actually have one Im reminded of just how good it really is.  Surely something of a modern classic.

Pours a wonderful amber color and a nice head to boot.  Im not a fan of the hoppier the better and this beer is wonderful.  All that wonderfull barley and  roasted malt slide right into the hops and it finishes slightly bitter.
Pours an amber color with decent head. Smells like hops, malt, and more. Goes down smooth no real bite at all. I love it

12oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours deep amber with a thick off-white head.  Aroma of some light malts, a little alcohol, but mainly citrusy/floral hops.  Flavor of very sweet caramel with a bitter hops finish.  Very nice texture.  A great beer.

Quite possibly the perfect IPA, it was simply fantastic.  Great mild citrus and lightly floral hops on the nose with a hint of the caramel malt.  A nice full malt body that definitely holds its own with the ton of hops in there.  I loved it and am having a hard time not drinking the 2 left in my fridge.  So sad I cant get it in little rock.

355 ml bottle. Banff, AB, Canada.
Clear deep golden colour with small white head.
Delicious fruity fresh bitter hoppy aroma with vanilla, pine, caramel and fresh fruits. Pine, grapefruit and strong quite harsh bitter hops in flavour. Strong but still very drinkable. Well hopped but not overdosed. Great!

I wish it was cheaper. The kind of beer I would choose almost everytime if it was available for less. I love the taste and the palate of this beer. It has such an excellent bitterness and a full body. Not a big fan of the aroma but its not terrible.
I like the 60 Minute IPA much better... This one is ok but is a little bit too hoppy for me... Great aroma though!

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2010 Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Cigar City snifter. Bottled on 09/07/10 printed on bottle.

Appearance: Pours a clear copper color with orange highlights and a 1 finger pure white frothy head. Looks exactly like what I want from an Imperial IPA.

Smell: Pine and grapefruit hops are dominant with a nice sweet floral and citrus background.

Taste: Hops are very bold but not overwhelming. Nice mix of citrus, malt and spices. The flavor is much sweeter than I remembered. It is bitter, but not overly so. Aftertaste is bittersweet and light. Excellent flavor overall.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a decent amount of carbonation. Very smooth.

Drinkability: Very high drinkability. Because it is so well masked, the ABV could sneak up on you pretty quickly.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. Ive heard many people say they prefer the 60 Minute IPA to this one, but Im not in that camp. Both are great beers but this is near the head of the class. I would highly recommend this one.

Coppery orange in color with an off-white head. Hoppy as can be, but still balanced. Dried fruit, hops, underlying maltiness, hints of citrus and earthiness. Quite good, and something I would never hesitate to drink when available.

Bottle. Pours a orangy copper. Aroma of pine, with notes of malt. Tastes of loads of hops but is balance by a strong malt profile with just a hint of alcohol lingering on the tongue. My favorite IPA and probably beer out there.

Bottle. Bottled on 6/18/10. Poured a gold orange clear color with a 1 finger head of tiny bubbles. Fairly strong piney aroma with some citrus characteristics, but mostly the pine. The frist sip is a barage of bitterness with a nice balance of sweet malts. Finishes crisply with a lingering bitterness. Not too bitter in that is really kills your pallet but for sure more probably more bitter than most people would like. Actually prefer this one over the 60 minute version. Medium mouthfeel.

Light amber coloured beer with limited carbonation and a small off-white head. Sweet herby hinted (almonds?) aroma. Full spicy palate with light bitter hints. Finish is bitter hopy, moving to a bitter herby an light dry sweet bitter ending. Very nice hoppy and bitter hinted beer.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2010 Tap @ Flying Saucer (SA), Swifts Hibernian and others. Cloudy orange pour with a brief, off-white head that leaves a heavy lace. Extremely well balanced and full-bodied. Hops are complex when fresh, less so when older. At its best, citrus and pine abounds with subtle floral and fruit undertones. Hops become more resinous and dominant near the finish. Malt is smooth, with singed caramel and a strong alcohol flavor is evident. Heavy body, but still smooth and almost creamy at the start. A classic Dogfish Head case of the whole is (even) greater than the sum of the parts. Pairs well with bland and spicy foods.

Bottle @ Beertemple. Almost clear brown, orange glow, small quickly dissipating head. Aroma is sweaty blue cheese hops, some fruit. Flavour is a very full yet subtle hop bitterness with blue cheese, malt and spices.
Very nice balance. Long lingering subtle bitterness. A bit on the sweet side after a while but thats probably what makes it so drinkable. Nice one.

Pours a light amber.  Aroma of delicious floral hops and citrus.  Taste is more hops, but a very nice balance of floral, citrus and the right amount of bitterness.  Palate is superbly smooth for the amount of hops.  A great IPA.

Cant believe I have never rated this beer, especially considering it was my favorite beer for years... Sweet citrusy hops aroma... Golden orange in color... Sweet malty aroma with piney and citrusy bitterness throughout... Not overwhelmingly aromatic or bitter on the finish, but definitely one of the best east coast ipas out there.. Supremely good
UPDATED: OCT 12, 2010 Orangy golden with lots of white lacing. Caramel malt aroma. Malty upfront followed by a little hop bitterness. Not bad, nice drink.
A big beer with a big head. Has many citrus notes that compliment the extreme hops. While not a fan of strong hops flavor, its a stand-up beer worth trying.

Have had great bottles and lesser ones (Im in NZ and freshness of imported beers can be a problem). I generally find this beer exceedingly crisp for a 9% beer with notes of grass, caramel and lemon and limes... very sexy

Smells of clean slightly citrus hops well balanced with a caramel like malt flavor. Golden in color with a perfectly frothy head. The bitterness seems mild for an imperial ipa due to the amount of malt flavor balancing it out. It sits quite thick on the tongue with a back of the mouth bitterness and goes down with a bit of an alcoholic burn. An excelent beer rising above the rest and as always, off-centered from Dogfish Head.

Wow, Beer. This beer is so good it transcends description but I will try. Lots of thick maltiness right from the beginning, which I love. Good bitter but balanced with floral essence perfectly. Great Brew!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Reviewed from notes (2007).

a: deep orange body with a healthy creamy head

s: a nice balance of hops.. citrus and pine lead the way... the malt comes through

t: much like the taste the presence of pine and citrus is bold, yet reserved enough to leave room for caramel and sweet malts before giving way to a sizeable piney aftertaste

m: pleasantly smooth for such a full bodied beer

o: its a good thing this beer is rather accessible in my area.. its a solid offering

While Dogfish Head claims that their 90 minute iPA is balanced, I beg to differ. To me, it tastes like the malt and the hops are battling one another for the spotlight rather than working together for the good of the beer. Each mouthful involves a massive infusion of citrusy hops followed quickly by a thick, cloying sweetness. Rather than the crisp mouthfeel of most IPAs, this one has an oily, slippery character to it. After drinking a few of these, I find each one more distasteful than the last. The robust flavors just dont work well together. Compared to Dogfish Heads excellent 60 minute IPA, which I absolutely love, their 90 minute variant is practically drainworthy.

A deep copper like color pours from the bottle with hints of orange mix throughout the glass. The aroma is very big and robust. The tast starts with a piney almost citrus like rollercoaster and settles with a creamy ending. One of Dogfish Heads best beers!

Initially I was enjoying this beer - the aroma was pleasant and the relatively strong hoppy bitterness helped to mellow the sweetness.  As the glass progressed, however, the alcohol content of this beer overpowered the aftertaste and it lost its depth.  Ultimately, I was left to "enjoy" a rubbing alcohol flavor at the end of each sip.  Not good.
My current favorite.  I read a lot about it and decided to give it a try, glad I did.   Definitely a beer to sip and enjoy.

Pours a clear copper amber like buckwheat honey, medium sized eggshell white head that leaves some good lacing. Complex aroma of sweet caramel malts and brown sugar with floral hops. Some pine in there. A hint of peach or apricot. Taste is similar to the aroma. Sweet malts cut with piney, floral hops. Lots of flavor here, but balanced flavor. Finish is resinous bitterness that lingers. The mouthfeel on this one is really enjoyable, slightly creamy with just enough carbonation. This beer to me kind of has barleywine qualities. If i was going to age a IIPA it would be this one.
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 A friend or mine who loves this stuff was very kind and traded me a bottle of the 90 min so I could try it. Im glad he did.  Very tasty and complex. Serving: Bottle

The aroma is sweet and malty, just like in the flavor as well.  The aroma has citrus notes as well. The flavor has a winey, malty sweetness ending smoothly on the palate. The appeareance is clear, golden amber with a small white head on top.

[355ml bottle from Beers of Europe] Pours a so-clear-it-looks-artificial copper with a moderate off-white head.  Slight fizz which gets a bit annoying as you drink it.  Big pine aroma, but not quite as pronounced as youd expect, or as tempting as on similar beers.  On tasting its very sweet - candy sugar or bubblegum comethrough at first, then a lot of malt, loads of caramel, and some more pine skulking along behind.  A bit minty too.  A dirty, pithy bitterness lurks behind, but its not enough to balance the sweetness.  The mouthfeel is syrupy; too much so by the end.  A disappointing and rather unbablanced beer - not sure what all the fuss is about.

Draft from Fatheads on 7/1/10

Update on the taste and aroma, the rest is pretty accurate.  Rating on those from recent tasting and went up from previous bottle rating.

S-The nose is bready with caramel malts up front.  Peach and citrus are present behind, huge balance and interesting aroma.

T-taste follows the nose, huge malt presence, lots of toasted bread and some caramel, good hop backing, notes of peach and citrus, hints of herbal marijuanna and grapefruit, light lingering bitterness.

Overall-love the balance now, very pleasant and still has a great hop presence but a beautiful malt balance make this a great bear to enjoy and I can actually keep drinking it unlike many of my favorite hop bombs that make me suffer towards the end of a growler.

***************************

A-very clear golden amber color, pure white head that is thick and creamy. Solid retention on the head leaving a nice lacing on the glass

S-the nose is faint, light grapefruit notes stand out with hints of pale malts and touches of biscuit.

T-the taste is more like a decent pale ale. Pale malts are quite present, grapefruit, peach and a touch of citrus compliment, notes of bready malt towards the back and just a touch of bitterness

M-medium body and extremely smooth. Great texture with just enough carbonation to give it a great feel throughout. Its actually quite creamy and inviting

D-solid brew, not as hoppy as i remember it; but still quite nice. a little honey maybe? great feel, nice texture, some balance.

original review from march of 2010.

Pours a medium pinkish-brown, with a little bit of head that lingers.  Aroma - what aroma!  Bright, vibrant, exotic, citrusy hops.  The flavour just erupts as soon as it touches your tongue with lemon/lime/herbs supported by a rich sweet maltiness, almost a honey flavour.  Moves towards a soothing, perfectly and potently alcoholic sweetness before a long, lingering bitter finish.  Ill still be tasting this one tomorrow!  Wonderful progression of flavours and aromas as you sip.  This is a very, very well done beer.

Aroma:  Wonderfully hoppy, with citrus and (honey?) underneath.  Frothy head, good retention and lacing.  Clear amber, quite pretty.  Flavor:  Huge hops up front with a solid caramel foundation to match it.  Very well-balanced, just like it says on the bottle.  Body is medium- heavy.  Soft, slippery mouthfeel.  Moderate carbonation / alcohol burn in the finish.  Very enjoyable.

Deep hoppy aroma, dark golden appearance. Starts with a great hoppy taste, ends with a sweet floral taste. Fairly thin texture is not particularly exciting for the palate but does not detract from the delight of drinking this beer. Overall a GREAT ipa. More bitter than the 60 minute but ends with the same sweet finish.

Poured from bottle. What an amazing color this beer is; it almost glows, like polished amber or brass, and has a Platonic ideal for a head. The nose is spruce with floral overtones. Its intensely bitter and hoppy, but backed up with a roasted malt that keeps it balanced. There is a faint honeyed and oily overtone to it. Mouthfeel is unctuous. Amazing.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Sour grassy malt aroma, cloudy medium brown colour with subtle orange tinge. Very strong sweet malt flavour. Much too strong for me but it isnt a bad beer . My taste is obviously different from most people on this site.

Bottle bought at the BSF bar, GBBF 09, cellared for almost a year and opened to the match Argentina vs Mexico from Soccer City on TV. Frothy, near-white head with good retention and fine lacing on the glass. Clear, amber-copper in body colour. Aromatic hoppy to the nose on the backbone of sweet malts. Solid hoppy flavour with grapefruit, apricot and caramel malt. Rounded and long-lived finish of spicy bitterness. Near full bodied (Tromsø, 27.06.2010).

Pours golden-amber color with a slight haze and nice head that gathers around the edges with large bubbles and clings to the glass. Pine, herbal hop aroma, oily with a some fruity esters and touch of pineapple. Smooth on the tongue, round in body, leaving a pleasing finish with some alcohol warmth. The taste is juicy with soft hops from start to finish, a nice malt backbone, with a subtle alcoholic finish. A really well-balanced and pleasing DIPA. One of my favorites.
gracias geek.  dulce y hoppy, que barbara. cualquier cosa arriba de la 60 minute es demasiado duilce.

Bottle. Copper-gold and slightly hazy. Small head. Little lace. Mild carbonation. Aroma of strong malt and hops. Malt is sweet and thick like honey. Very strong malt flavour. Well hopped, it is bitter and resinous. The 9% alcohol is well hidden. Also, the extreme malt levels hide the 90 IBUs more than expected. A hop bomb that doesnt taste like one.

Its an Imperial IPA so its going to be BIG, but I was still unprepared, we just dont get a lot of beers like this here in Oz. Pours a lovely copper, clear (poured it carefully as it is bottle conditioned). Firm carbonation results in a long lasting persistent head. Aromas are all those big American citrus hops, smells fantastic. The pallet has plenty of up front malt which is then flattened by a huge rush of hops, not that its unbalanced, just that I get both malt and hops in big doses at different times; odd. The high alcohol adds an acrid bite to the finish that gets you ready for another sip. Its a great beer, well made and really tasty but I couldnt drink to many. I can only imagine that this thing must be a monster from the tap.
pours a deep copper. VERY hoppy beer which i was happy about (hoppy happy?) flavours of orange, spice and grass
Copper pour from bottle.  Rye and fruit abound in the nose and taste.  Slick mouthfeel.  Alcohol is well hidden by notes of raisin and yeast, yet very present.  Excellent and unique IPA.
UPDATED: JUN 28, 2010 Had on draught at the Dogfish in Rehoboth.  Citrusy, pleasant taste.  Very smooth at 9% and not overly hoppy.  Highly recommended.  Best beer Ive ever had from the tap.
Light brown with a nice head with staying power. Smells a bit smoky. Pretty smooth flavor. Very smoky aftertaste, but very smooth.

12 oz bottle from warehouse wine. Had a sweet, hoppy, pleasant citrius smell. Pours a nice burnt orange with a thick full light tan head. Has a nice bitter, pretty hoppy but focused taste. citrius and orange taste throughout. Palate was its best asset. Warms the mouth with its full body. excellent feeling. A very good Double IPA from dogfish head.

Huge white head; tawny gold in the glass.  I think the single 12 oz bottle I purchased was too old or not stored properly.  The hops smell was significantly degraded as compared to my recollection of this beer on tap.  Sweet, predominately malt character with some mild hops in the mix.  Enjoyable but I know Ive had it far better.

(on tap at Yardhouse).  Copper color with off-white head.  Aroma is citrusy.  Very sweet with lots of bitterness, but its perfectly balancedl  Medium bodied with dry hop finish.  Almost spicy/peppery.  One ofthe best DIPA around!!  This is a beer that should always be in a beer snobs fridge.
Love this beer but the 120 is better. Expensive but worth it every now and again.
A wonderful IPA that has a high alcohol content that melds nicely with the barley and hops flavors. Not absurdly hoppy, but delicious.

This could possibly be the nicest beer Ive tasted. Nice colour with a creamy white head.Full bodied.  Very hoppy and fruity with caramel and vanilla notes. Nice, bitter lasting finish that had a strong kick. Dying for another bottle of this fine, fine beer.

12 oz. Pours wonderfully bright orange with a trailing white head all the way down. Aroma is strongly hops, grassy, and nicely earthy. Awesome flavor. Hoppy, but not exactly bitter, and impressively sweet and balanced for this style (right up there with Hopslam). Finishes sweet and tangy. Wonderful.

12 oz bottle.  Pours amber in colour, with smallish white head.  Lots of lcaing.  Aroma is primarily sweet.  Taste is a big sweet malt, with big hop finish.  Hints of brandy for sure.  Very nicely balanced, for such a big beer - big malt, big hop!
Burnt gold colour, persistane beige head. Sweet musky  malt & hops in aroma. High sweet malt character with some roasted grain present. drying hop finish. Smoooooth & yummy IPA.

Pours a dark amber with minimal head.  The aroma is dank with lots of noble hops and sour malt.  Flavor is thick and sweet, but well balanced with bitterness.  I list the malt quality first, because I believe it predominates to some degree.  The alcohol is well hidden.   Overall, this feels more like something other than an IPA, though it may just be made so well that it doesnt fit the usual profile.

Always on tap at Boulders on Broadway, this is my go to beer. I cant get over how sweet, and alcoholic this beer is. at 9% it has to be one of the sweetest IPAs I have ever had. I think the balance on the beer gets better the warmer it gets and unlike a lot of IPAs, this one doesnt get worse if it warms up a little bit. Dogfish Head instantly hooked me with this beer.  I am happy it did.

Pours clear gold with decent white head. nose is nice citrus, piney, spicy hops with some sweetness. Taste is strong grassy hops with good balancing fruity malt sweetness with lingering green/grassy taste and a hint of plastic. Nice, but not as well balanced as the 60 minute IPA.

Pours ruby amber with strong slightly tan head.  Magnificent nose full of citrus and herbal hop notes with a prominent sweet malt backbone.  Massive explosion of citrussy hops and sweet malt balance oneanother perfectly.  9% alcohol is nearly undetectable.  A true gem of the craft beer world.  Impeccable.

Pours an amber orange with a white head.  Nose full of hops, honey, caramel, and oak.  Palate is a creamy mix of carmel malts, big hops, and woody herbs.  Not much combination but the mouthfeel is gorgeous.  Delicious!

Pours light amber-orange with almost no head. Nose is very sweet for an IPA and is primarily a fruitiness with only a modest level of hops. This pattern continues in the flavor: if this beer is really 90 IBUs, Im the Queen of Scotland. There is a very sweet, red apple tasting malt and very subdued hoppiness for an IPA, with most of the bitterness in the finish. Even then its not much, relatively speaking. Its a good beer but its very not bitter for such a well regarded IPA.
spectacular, strong, good flavor, obtainable and not terribly expensive (~$10/4 pack)

Dark golden orange body with short head. Lovely aroma, piney notes then malty sweetness. Taste reflects the aroma, bitterness stands out but very welcome, well balanced and almost chewy and thick but feel like I could easily drink plenty of these.

Had this one on tap at the Flying Saucer in Addison. 

The beer pours a cloudy orange color with a white head. The aroma is orange with a nice malt backbone. The flavor is caramel malt with citrus hops. The beer has some nice sweetness from the malt but it is balanced nicely with the bitterness from the hops. A very balanced Double IPA. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Dogfish head 90 Minute IIPA pours a clear, rich, burnt sienna with a lacey, off-white foam.  The aroma consists of caramel, pine, resin, floral notes, slight citrus, raisins, and black licorice.  The taste is a medium sweetness, light sourness, and heavy hoppy bitterness.  The palate is medium bodied with a sticky texture,  average carbonation, and a long finish.  Overall, Dogfish Head 90 Minute IIPA is a deliciously complex and well balanced ale.

Pours relatively clear for such a well hopped bear. I prefer the haziness of other IIPAs. Noise is nice but maybe my bottle isnt the freshest. Hops hit you first and then theres just a ton of malt sweetness that washes it away. Love the malt backbone this beer has. Very drinkable at 9% ABV - they hide the alcohol exceptionally well.
Bottle. Hazy amber with off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit and lots of hops.

Bottle. 2700+ people have rated this beer..and you know why? Because its a damn good beer. Finally good to try on of the best for the style. Got via trade. As dogfish head hasnt made it to missouri yet..damn shame. Amazing beer. Poured a very dark amber color with a smaller white head. Aroma was spruce, pine, and grass. Actually a pretty balanced dipa. Still amazing flavor. Maybe Im over rating it because I cant get it here in missouri on a regular basis but it would be my everyday beer if I could get it. Ive had 4 dogfishes now and ever one above par. And 2700+ people will tell you the same story.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2010 I bought this one in search of a great IPA experience, and it didnt disappoint. Beautiful color, white, fluffy head. The aroma was an experience unto itself. The initial taste was almost overwhelmingly malty, the initial aftertaste strongly alcoholic. Took about half a bottle to balance out, but then total awesomeness. Quite strong, too.

12 ounce bottle from 3 Sons. Pours copper-orange with a pillowy light tan head that becomes rocky and thin but sustained. Immediate resinous hop aroma followed by apricot and orange with deeper caramel malt. Medium-thick in the mouth and sweet on the tongue. Hop flavor only apparent as resin, with toasty cereal malt really dominating. Clean bitter finish is unfortunately not enough to clear the mouth of the malty sweetness. A little more hop flavor and aroma would really help to balance this out. There is also significant alcohol burn in the throat. A good beer, no doubt, but almost like a strong Belgian ale instead of an American DIPA.

Okay, I may be alone in this. But, Im not a huge fan of the 90min. There are better imperial IPAs out there. I love the brewery, but this one is a little more alcohol-y to me. Its not as smooth as the 60. The aroma is good. Its malty. But, has a thick maltiness. I had one and switched to something else. Again, I know I may be alone in this, but just my rating.
Pours a clear bourbon color. Aroma of caramel, dried fruit and grass. Flavor is caramel, vanilla, and grass with a spicy nutmeg finish. Quite good!
great beer that packs a sneaky punch. anything that is this smooth and has an abv of 9% is definitely worth every penny.  i highly recommend a 4-pack of this to end a perfect evening.

Ive had this bad boy many times before, but got to have one right next to their 120 at my bachelor party last weekend.  DFH 90 minute has always been one of my favorite DIPAs, and I had high hopes for the 120.  The 90 is so perfectly balanced, so much character and flavor, the hops and malts playing off each other.  Unfortunately, the 120 minute is just far too unbalanced.  So sweet it becomes almost like a nectar or syrup.  Still, an amazing experience... but a bit of a let down after my years of enjoying their 90.
4-pack for $11 is totally do-able for the amount of stuff going on with this beer.  The alcohol is definitely present but it doesnt spoil the hops and the malts in the beer.  Pretty saweeeet.
Pours cloudy orange with one finger orange head. Smells of orange, malty nuts. Taste is sweet; caramel, nutty, bready, with a good amount of spice and hops. Bitter with a medium dry finish.

Pours with a very, very light syrup like consistency. Color is Golden and clear with a bit of orange color. Aroma is fruity with citrus and lots of malt. Taste is sweet with plenty of hop bitterness to balance things out. Somewhat of a lingering bitterness. Excellent brew!

Bottle, 355ml. Pours a clear orange colour with a small, fluffy white head. Aroma is of course extra floral, very intense and promising. Taste is complex and heavy, apart from the hoppiness, theres also lots of citrus and some nice dry fruit character.  Has not only an extra bitter finish, but also a strong alcohol touch. Perfectly balanced, never letting all the hoppiness overwhelm the beer. Excellent.

Clear, slightly dark amber color with tall white head and nice lacing. Aroma is very hoppy, but very malty as well.  Complex flavors of floral hop bitter, traces of citrus, nice carmel malt sweetness in the finish. Strong alcohol noticeable but not overpowering. Quite balanced and drinkable for such an extremely hoppy beer.

Fresh aromatic, fruity aroma.  Very clear with strong hop taste from start to finish.  Smoth and think on the tongue.  This beer feels heavy (in a good way) when drunk.  I thought this beer was comparable to Stones IPA but a little thicker on the tongue and more enjoyable for it.

bottle. Poured hazy orange with a large chunky yellowish head. The aroma is pungent floral hops. Full bitter mouthfeel . Flavour is a mix overwhelming herbal hoppiness and caramel malt. The finish is sticky with a lingering bitterness. This beer definetly reflects the traditional IPA style but the alcohol is rather undetectable.

Served from tap into standard pint.  Poured a nice copper color with minimal white head formation.  Lacing was evident but minimal throughout.  The aroma was overpowered by hops.  The flavors seemed to change throughout each sip.  You would get a really bitter bite from the hops upfront, upon swallowing you would get a nice malty finish, that was followed by a hoppy aftertaste.  Overall, this brew has a very nice flavor that is light on the palate with low carbonation.  I love how the flavors of each sip changed to keep you on  your toes while drinking it.  However, it was not as hoppy as I would have expected, but still good nonetheless.

Nice big hoppy caramel malty aroma. Dark copper hue. Big malty hop taste. Very well balance of caramel malts and hops. One the easiest drinking imperial/double IPAS out there. Alcohol is well hidden however it creeps on you. Excellent strong session brew.

Looks absolutely stunning! Deep amber body, with a slight cloudiness to it. A rich creamy beige head. Great head retention and impressive lacing.

The smell is extremely intense, but it is quite a challenge to tell whether there is more maltiness or hoppiness in it. I also got some tropical fruit notes, like mango and papaya. The list of aromatic notes includes, but is not limited to: caramel, bread, toffee, oranges, grapefruit, pine needles, even chocolate!

The taste: Hops, more hops, then malts, and more malts! Packs a very good hop punch, with equal amounts of resinous pine and citrusy grapefruit, with some bitterness. The malts bring a very nice sweet breadiness to the finish, which is definitely more on the malty side. Not much bitterness lingers on. Very flavourful and balanced.

Medium-to-full body to it. Smooth, but slightly sticky and syrup-like.The alcohol is well-masked, but you will probably feel it. After a while, it gets a bit more difficult to swallow.

Enjoy this one in moderation, as it gets tricky with the well-masked 9% abv.

All in all, now I can totally see why this beer is so acclaimed. Great job, Sam Calagione and his team!
Wow....DogFish head knows how to make some beer, my friends. Excellent mixture of piny/floral hops balanced with some nice sweet malt.....excessively drinkable and enjoyable.

On tap at British Beer company in Hyannis. Deep mahagony with a white head clinging to the glass. Underbrush and forrest floor with chocolate and an indescribable scent of "spring" in the background. Full chewy mouthfeel. Dried, dark fruit and prune. Not many hops left on this. Great malt backbone. Finishes with raisin.

A reddish orange (like strawberry blonde) color poured into a tulip shaped glass. Thick and highly carbonated. Clear, but opaque. Beautiful white head. 

The aroma. Oh the aroma. Just a big fat burst of hops. A slightly sweet smell is the perfect balance. Its just teasing me. As it warms up, the hops move to the background and the malt takes over. 

The first cold sip is filled with a sweet, hoppy goodness. And a surprisingly strong malt backing. The distinct elements swirl together to create a rich beer that is loaded with flavor. Each sip is sweet, bitter and malty all at the same time. I wonder how long they added hops for. 

The feel is a bit fizzy, but does not detract. Still very easy to drink, and smooth considering the higher carbonation. As it warms up and the carbonation goes down, it becomes a creamy, cozy beer. 

This beer is very strong. It is delicious, but two or three a month is probably all I could handle.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2013 Pours golden with a nice white head and solid lacing.  Aroma of peach, apricot, ginger, bitter citrus and some sugar.  full bodied and dry.  Taste is complex blend of grapefruit, yeast, herbs, and alcohol.  finishes long and bitter sweet.  Hop character beautifully balanced.  Really not the hop-bomb people try to peg it as.  I love this beer!
caramel, coffee, vanilla, golden, amber, red, sparkling, frothy, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, average carbonation, astringent,
One of the best standard IPAs out and my "go to".  Solid hop aroma and full taste that you expect from DFH.  For someone who appreciates an IPA but is not looking for something overly intense.

12 oz bottle, poured into a pint glass.  Nice gold/amber color with about an inch of head.  Smelled citrusy and sharp, not sure how else to describe it.  Taste is also citrusy, bitter, with a spicy aftertaste.  A very good beer.

On tap in a pint glass at the flying saucer in San Antonio.

A medium copper with a thin white head.  Decent lacing all the way down.  I actually cant smell much, mostly caramel malt.  The taste is surprisingly balanced.  Raisin, citrus and caramel.  Has a bite to it, but the sweet malty finish balances it out significantly.  Very good, but maybe not quite as great as heralded.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2010 Poured clear copper with a small off-white head. Aroma: grapefruit, citrus, mild pine & grass, hops, sweet malts. Taste was the same as the aroma but clean, crisp and bitter. Nice body & depth. Overall a great DIPA... I wish I had bought more bottles now.

A deep orange pour with white head.  The aroma is a wonderful mixture of citrusy hops, raisin, caramel, and some vanilla.  The taste is full and sweet with a finish that slowly grows to a mild bitterness with alcohol warmth.

330ml bottle. Honey amber colour with a tidy even dirty white head. Bursting with hop aromas that jump from the glass and attack you, deliciously aromatic with a strong flavour that, like the aroma, is bursting with hops. Sits wonderfully in the mouth, what a great beer. Everything I have read about this beer is true and it has been worth the wait to be able to buy it here in Australia.
