12 oz botte. Pours a suprising lighter golden with ample foamy off-white head. Hop aroma, while not overpowering, is immediately evident. Big mouthy feel, citrusy hoppy taste, although the sweet malt does not get lost. A beautifully bold beer, one of my favorite IPAs.

Bottle. Flowery hop, Battenburg cake, notes of chocolate maltiness. Lots of grapefruity citrus hop, and some spiciness. Also alcohol and caramel on the nose. Clear copper/amber with a thin off-white head. Sparkling. Medium bitterness and some sweetness. Was expecting a lot more bitterness to be honest, but was less so that BrewDogs Punk IPA. Lively carbonation. Hugely overrated, so I ended up a little disappointed, but at least its a challenging beer.

Poured into a tulip glass. This bottle has a bottled on date of 1/19/10. Been a while since I had this one so I thought it was high time to give it another go. Great amber color, head formation and retention. Bright, fresh hops on the nose rounded by an underlying malty sweetness. The hops might not be as fresh as you would like but a few months hasnt hurt this beer too much. It has a supple texture without being overly malty like some high ABV imperials can err towards. The hops are at the fore throughout. Start to finish the malt stays in the background, allowing the hops to be prominently displayed without being overpowering. This might not pack the IBUs but its well-rounded character makes it very drinkable. I wish they would put this in a bomber.

Bottle. Hazy copper with persisting white head. Aromas of grass, caramel, pine and citrus. Flavors of caramel, candi sugar, grapefruit, pine and dark fruit. Some alcohol toward the end. Medium-full body with foamy mouthfeel and active, low-moderate carbonation. Not as hoppy or as tasty as I remembered it.

Perhaps the most delicious beer I have ever had. I will not exam the aroma, palate, etc. But it is a pleasure to enjoy this beer. Ive tried many an IPA, including Stones Stone Ruination IPA. But this one is my favorite.

Leafy, earthy, full of hops and tufts of hay. This beer hits you like a kick from the hind-leg of a racing horse. Plump with bitterness and roaring spiciness, this IPA has so much bite it needs a muzzle and a handler to stop it from shining its canine teeth. Great for relaxing, feeling existential, or nursing near a white hot fire. One of the more gruff, curt brews around. Hail Dogfish.

Bottle pours orange-amber with a decent sized off-white head and tiny amount of lacing.  Aroma shows raisin, peach, orange, caramel, honey, and light pine.  Flavor shows primarily the same.  I honestly have to say, even though this is a good beer, it is highly overrated (in my opinion) and I would much rather drink their Burton Baton.  Overall body is moderately sweet and finishes moderately bitter with a slight amount of warming alc.
Bottle. Golden and  very clear. Small head and a creamy hoppiness.Gentle bitter finnish but not as hoppy as I had expected. Sill pretty awesome though.

90 Minute was once the benchmark for Double IPAs among my beer-drinking friends.  Pliny the Elder has, for me, redefined this variety.  90 Minute is high on hops and malt.  It is 90 Minutes malt balance that reduces its appeal as DIPA.  90 minutes malt balance is cloying, almost syrupy sweet  -- it lacks the citrus/grapefruit tartness of the best hop DIPAs.  For this reason, 90 Minute is not very drinkable -- a far cry  from the two Plinys. Other, far well less known DIPAs, such as Squatters Hop Rising outshine this overrated beer.  Not to mention the Russian River Plinys and Alesmith DIPAs.  Long live the king, the king is dead.   Its time for Dogfish Head to revisit this variety.
Wonderful flavour.  Possibly a little high on the malt flavour, but the hops definitely come through.  The alcohol content doesnt overpower.

Poured into stemless wineglass. Amber in color with light head. Slightly cloudy.  Bready aroma with WAY less aromatic hops than I expected. Tastes and looks more like a hoppy, complex amber ale or american strong ale with some dark fruit notes and perfect amount of hop bitterness. Slightly sticky mouthfeel. Very good beer.

pine, citrus aroma.
Orange amber, hazy, white head.
Bitter sweet; medium, grapefruit.
Medium bodied, lively, delicious.
Overall an amazing beer.

Bottle: Poured a hazy copper color with a off white head. The aroma is hops. The taste is a mix of nice malt with that grit and spike of hops. A delightful beer and I enjoyed it better then the 120 minute.
One of my favorite beers.  Notes of grapefruit and other citrus.  A total winner.
Small off white head. Hops are prevalent in aroma. Slightly bitter finish. Woody delicious taste that masks alcohol well

12 oz. bottle into a Duvel tulip.
Beautiful, dark, cloudy, amber color.  Large head which quickly disappears.  Lacing is wonderful and lasting.  Good carbonation.
Nose is as balanced as the taste.  Malts are there and so are the hops.  Sweet, citrus.  Mouthfeel is medium.  
Taste is complex - citrus (lemon, grapefruit) with strong malt backbone. Some alcohol warming but subtle. Balance is the word that typifies this beer - malt and hops, sweet and bitter, etc. A good Double IPA for people to try who arent looking for extremely bitter which is so common in this style.
By the number of reviews, EVERYONE knows this beer.  Its no wonder - great beer, reasonably priced and widely distributed.  I like the 60, the 90 not at all, and yep, this is the perfect compromise.  If you are one of the few who has not had this, you need to.
Perfect balance of maltiness to match the hop character as well as the alcohol content! Outstanding!

Excellent IPA.  Pours an amber color with a decent head, had it on draft at the Rose Alley Ale House.  Strong malt tones, with somefruitcake and raisin aromas.  Very smooth IPA that is not as hoppy as expected, but very flavorful.  Quickly became one of my favorite IPAs.

Dear fricking jeebus. This is the perfect form of an IPA, the standard by which all should be measured. Absolutely gorgeous flowery aroma, lovely mouth-feel and a hoppiness that guides you by hand and when alls said and done, kisses you goodnight. Mind-blowing.
UPDATED: FEB 26, 2015 By the smell of it, youd think this beer would be tougher, but the taste is actually kind of wimpy. This dogfish is all bark, and a little nip.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2010 Bottle. Pours a deep golden amber with an inch think cream coloured head. Some lacing. Aromas were quite sweet with plenty of malt, rich dark fruits and some alcohol. Definately getting that brandied fruitcake. Some citrus hops are also there but certainly not the huge hop aromas I was expecting. Flavours are very sweet up front with some hop boitterness on the finish. Once again not as bitter as expected though. Lots of resiny hops in the after taste which hang around for a while. Mouthfeel is quite creamy and sticky.

Ive had this a few times and it seems to get sweeter to me. I get he hop citrus bitterness but more and more I get  malt and sweetness. A hall of fame of fame classic big IPA and one of DFHs signature beers. I can definitely taste some dried apricot in here too. Definitely can relate to the comparison the brewer makes to sauvignon.

A- Beautiful transparent bronze body with no head at first. As the pour settles a beautiful white head emerges and sticks with it the whole way down.

S- not what I was expecting at first. Smells sweet and malty (not extremely hoppy in the nose).

T- very complex. I have to keep tasting it to see what is in it. Very interesting. Sweet and fruity malt up front with maybe some carmel flavoring. The hops kick in but they are not extreme. They are deeper and lay in the back of the palate..

P- high carbonation and a medium weight body. Goes down suprisingly easy.

O- This is a great DIPA and one of my favorite offerings from DFH. Its sweeter than I expected but Im not complaining.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-24-2007 21:51:50

From a pint glass - Amber in color with a half inch off-white head that lasts awhile. Some peach and hop scents come through, but massive nectarine dominates here. This full, nicely carbonated IIPA delivers a thick, heavy, creamy mouthfeel.  As strong as the hops are, and as dry as the finish is, DH managed to balance them out with the fulfilled promise of big nectarine flavor.

Draught served in Goblet at the burger bar in Mandalay Place (between the luxor and mandalay bay casinos). What an experience.. Smallish head just covering the top surface area. Rasin-like aromas are present along with the sweet malt and some citrrus hoppiness. Mouthfeel is medium-thick with sweet malts dominating. The 90IBUs were balanced well in my opinion. Carbonation was low-medium and the finish was a touch alcoholic, but nonetheless pleasant. Am looking forward to having this one again tomorrow!
By far the best IPA ive ever had.  Very strong floral/citrus aroma adds to the pleasure of a strong hoppy finish.  To me, this is the perfect beer.

In a bottle from Lees Discount Liquor in Las Vegas. I now love this beer and see why people and "beer snobs" alike love this beer. This is what an IPA should be IMO. Dark fruit and citrus are in the taste with a huge hop flavor on the palate. Once you sip this you instantly know youre drinking a huge quality beer and the alcohol level doesnt ruin the taste. Great beer!
Beautiful deep amber with thick tan head.  Floral aroma. Very bitter taste.  Couldnt finish it.

Amber with a soft golden halo color under a nice eggshell head.

Aroma is raisiny, with notes of ripe, cloying fruit and a slight crisp citrus edge.

Palate is well balanced, hops do not overpower the tongue with the usual burn. Nice level of carbonation. The body is pleasant and comfortable.

Tastes of  currants and other dryish fruits, with a soft grapefruity hop taste and a nice long balanced finish. Not nearly as hop-crazy as I expected, which I am just fine with. Just beautifully balanced.

Overall a top notch Imperial IPA that is flawlessly balanced and smooth as silk on the palate. Highly drinkable, if only a 4 pack wasnt quite so expensive it would be a go to beer for sure. Wonderful example of the best traits of the style!

Bottle. Been wanting to try this for some time, and what can I say that hasnt been said by many others? It is very good, and its definitely classical in terns of style (as opposed to some DIPAs currently being brewed). Rich, sweet nose with lots of resiny, citrusy hops as well as honey and caramel malt sweetness. Flavour is just about the same with some spicy hints in the background. Thick, sticky mouthfeel with fairly low carbonation and a long bittersweet finish. An excellent brew overall, but there are a couple of other brewers I can think of that do this just as well.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2010 Bottle. Amber, coating beige head. Smells of poached quinces and other autumnal fruits as well as bass register pine and citrus. And brandy. Quite restrained nose. Real sweetness in the heavy and complex dark sugar malts followed by strong and persistent but not egregious bitterness. Quite syrupy and not unlike a fortified wine finished with bitter herbs. Balanced but tiring - Id be happy to share a small bottle of this amongst three. [3.6] Colder this time (10C) and its less tiring to drink and rather less fortified wine-like. But the flavours are very compressed and the overall effect is a dull roar. The notion that an IPA might not travel still seems like a joke to me, but maybe some sparkle has been lost on the journey.

12 ounce bottle from South Bay Drugs ($3.99).  Pours an orange-amber with one finger of white foam.  There are floaties in there which I assume are hop remnants.  Aroma is more muted than I might have expected but consists mainly of hops (peach, orange, grass).  Flavor of course is full of hops (more peach, grass, apricot, spicy) and has an impressive balancing malt component.  The finish is not very bitter and trends toward sweet.  Also contains a certain amount of booze.  Generally well balanced and good but not quite up to the level of some of the better California DIPAs.  (2694, 262)

(I believe this was my second review; score is from a more recent tasting) This beer is sublime. It was one of the first beers that I discovered through the internet and one of the best beers I tried in the first few months of drinking good beer. Dogfish Head is a masterful brewery and I dearly wish that they would distribute more styles out to California. This beer pours a beautiful amber with a fine sticky head. It smells just exquisite. Its sweet and oily with hops. The hops are citric but smoother than most hop bills on a DIPA. Theres also better balancing malt than some competitors. The beer is honey sweet and floral with bittersweet finish that hits the spot. The feel is like a gentle surf breaking on your tongue. Its just fantastic beer. I cant wait to one day get my hands on a bottle of the 120 minute version.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2011 One of my very favorites. Really, though, whats the point in rating this? If youve found this site, you  probably know all about 90 minute already. If not, well, shame on you. Go get some today! I drank (several) 12 oz bottle(s) poured into a DFH chalice.

Draught. Clear copper with some white head. Beautiful, complex, balanced aroma - floral hops with sweet notes and fruitiness. Full bodied with light carbonation. Mouthfeel is almost coating and oily in a very pleasant way. Beautiful flavour - complex and so well balanced. Sweet and fruity start (fruits are raisins and something tangier I couldnt put a name to) transitions nicely to a long and pleasant finish with decent but balanced bitterness. Overall, a very impressive beer.
Copper color in the glass.  Aroma of floral/fruity hops with a toasty malt character as well.  Flavors on the palate show nice depth with a strong malt presence alongside the robust hop notes.
A citrusy aroma that is a tad sweet, but also smells a little like carpet. Golden appearance. Flavor is bittersweet with a slight hoppiness. Very yummy...you should try it. :)

Bottle from Corks, Bristol. Clear amber in colour with a slick of off-white head and slight carbonation. Sweet, peach and apricot fruit aroma with citrus and pine hops and creamy caramel. Flavour of sweet malts, orange marmalade. Lots more pine and citrus hops, leading to a dry finish with accompanying warming alcohol. Excellent.

355ml Bottle via trade with Lithy. Clear copper amber colour, frothy off white head. Aroma of sweet toasted malts, caramel, spicy and grassy hops, alcohol, light roasted note. Flavour is sweet, sugary, malty, grass and pine, caramel, alcohol, strong lingering hoppy and alcohol bitter finish. Medium to fullbodied, syrupy mouthfeel. A bit too sweet imo. Thanks Justin!

Bottle.Pours an amber dull color with a white head that coats the edge of the glass.Nose is a  resiny/bready aroma with a bit of citrus.Taste is full mouthfeel with thick hops and malt with a nice finish.A bit too thick and unbalanced to be considered with the best but a nice IPA/Double IPA for quaffing...

On tap at the Saucer in San Antonio.  Pours a dark amber body, topped by a very sticky ivory head that left tons of lacing.  Aroma of pine, citrus (orange), light toffee sweetness.  Flavor is malty, medium toffee/caramel sweetness,  Piney bitter and some alcohol.  Medium mouthfeel with active carbonation.  Medium pine/resin bitter finish.  Very balanced all in all.

Technically a Double IPA, but no doubt one of the best IPAs around. Fruity hops are prominent, but surprisingly well balanced with malts as well. Excellent beer choice of a slightly higher price range!

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 Great freaking beer. Not as amazing in my opinion as some other IPA^2, but damn good nonetheless. Excellent malt presence both on tap and in a bottle. Theres an wonderful creamy sweetness that really balances well the hops. Speaking of hops, thats where Im kind of disappointed in this beer. Its not that they get it wrong, but was hoping for some more piney, resinous, stick to your palate hops. Oh well, thats a stupid criticism anyways. This beer is damn good.
Excellent nose of bubblegum and citrus.  Pours medium copper.  Flavour is fresh, fruity, bitter and citric with some banana, some cloves, and some pleasing alcohol.  A great IPA.

Bouteille 12oz, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur ambrée-orange et claire. Nez de houblon citrique (pamplemousse), moyennement résineux et à la fois légèrement floral et aux notes herbeuses, malté de caramel sucré aux notes de toffee et fruité (agrumes, notes dabricots et de raisins) avec des notes dalcool doux. Ronde-moyenne en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture à la fois moyennement crémeuse et légèrement huileuse. Goût fruité (agrumes sucrées et pamplemousse, faibles notes de raisins et dabricots, faibles traces de dates) avec un goût assez amer de houbon citrique (pamplemousse) et légèrement floral (qui dure toute la gorgée) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté dun mélange de caramel sucré et de caramel toffee léger puis une finale où ressort une amertume légèrement herbeuse de houblon (feuilles de thé et herbes fraîches) ainsi quune légère chaleur dalcool. Post-goût long un peu sec, amer de houblon citrique, moyennement herbeux et aux notes florales avec un léger goût dalcool et de fruits (zest dagrumes).

Dark amber in colour with a big white head. Huge floral hop aroma. A little sweeter than the 60 minute IPA, but still heaps of hops. Big hop flavour with soft hop bitter aftertaste. In NZwould be choice bro!!!!
Quite possibly one of the near-perfect DIPAs around.  Loaded with hoppy goodness, but not unbalanced.  You could very easily get into trouble with the 9% ABV, though, since it is so very drinkable.

12-oz bottle. Big aroma with citrus and candied dates. A beautiful medium clear amber color with a pillowy white head that completely fails to smother the wonderful aroma. The taste is perfect for an ipa. Balanced sweet malts with pronounced American hops. The texture of the beer is medium-heavy with enough substance to encourage meditation. Great finish with no unpleasant side notes. Ridiculously drinkable. A real pleasure.

Bottle from jprime (BA). Nice copper pour with thin white head. Aroma is mainly cookie dough, lots of peppery hop some nuts and toffee too. Taste is relatively sweet, brandy like with a bitter hoppy backdrop. Very palatable beer, carbonation just managing to break through all that syrupy sweetness.
Very good beer.  Nice hoppy aroma.  Balanced.  Nice flavor.  Its not worth 12 bucks for a 4 pack though.

I did not care for IPAs before trying this wondrous elixir at the recommendation of a friend. I have since become a fan of the style, but have yet to find one better than the Dogfish 90. A close second is the Dogfish 60! The 90 minute offerring from Dogfish Head is very floral but expertly balanced. No single taste seems overpowering to me. It is very flavorful without bowling you over. Whether you like the India Pale Ale style or not, I urge you to give this excellent example a day in court.

12-oz bottle Specs, Houston, TX - Aroma: malty, raisiny, orange; Appearance: clear, reddish-orange color, white head, some laces; Flavor: sweet, salty, malty, raisin, orange, bitter; Mouthfeel: medium bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation; Overall: nice fruity and malty backbone to citrus hops.  However, not overly bitter or hoppy, probably to the age of the bottle.

this is great stuff..perfectly balanced..easy to drink,citrus grapefruity quality,color of a summer sunset,nice head,lacing hoppy and citrus aroma,perfect mouthfeel and palate,delicious my favorite summer beer even at 9%

Very good IPA. Tastes alot like the 60 Min. But slightly more bitter to me. Which is always welcome. Aroma was citrusy. Appearance was that of most IPAs, perfect. Taste was basically perfect. Well balanced and smooth. Palate is comfortable and casual. Over all an exellent IPA.

Excellent beer that does not drink like a 9%.  Pours amber with a nice white head.  Aroma is very fruity and floral, hops come through nicely.  Taste is bittersweet with a crisp finish.  Very drinkable.
Very nice beer, IMHO. Bright hops, crisp flavor. Lip smacker. I know that doesnt tell you much, but if youve had IPAs and you like them youll definitely enjoy this one.

Very nice citrusy hop aroma.   Pours a nice caramlel color with a good head.  For being an Imperial the alcohol is masked very well with a complex malt taste.  Hints of darker malts pull this beer together incredibly to offset the hop flavor.

Totally tropical to the nose with huge passionfruit and guava aromas abounding.  They continue on the tongue with rich caramel and toffee maltiness. In the mouth it is soft and pleasant with a hint of alcoholic burn in the throat. There is a dryness to it but it is well combated by the sticky sweetness of the malts. Bloody lovely.
Not a whole lot to say about this one except its fantastic. Great aroma of hops all the way through. Really nice flavor. just one of my favorites plain and simple.

I want to like this one, but the taste which is a slight bitter fruit one, is not a flavor I am fond of. On tap at the Yard House. A rich, dark yellow/brown color. Sweet aromas permeate from it, nice thick head on the glass lasting throughout.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2015 Tap - Beavertown Brewery - 19th September 2015. Thanks to Logan for importing this. 

Loads of good hop bite. Floral notes. Spruce. Forest dew aroma. Lots of good light citrus notes. Great drinkability. Super soft malts. 90 IBU punches your mouth but not too intense so you dont lose the flavour. A nice balance.

What can you add to whats already been said about this beer? Among the top 5 beers Ive ever had. Very good balance between bitter hops and sweet malt. Actually a bit sweeter and maltier than I expected but great nonetheless.

Esquire Magazine calls our 90 Minute I.I.PA., "perhaps the best I.P.A. in America." Hahahaha! I dont think so. Maybe the best IIPA in the east coast but this brew does not hold a candle to anything in the west! A bit to malty of an IPA if you ask me not enough hops, not well balanced. Vastly overrated IMHO.

The standard when it comes to American IPAS.  Spicy, hoppy and crisp with strong floral notes.  The flavors come in waves and last for the entire mouthful.  I absolutely despise most IPAs, but the 90 minute is a unique beer that can be enjoyed by any and all beer drinkers.
On Tap at Bridge View Tavern, Tarrytown, NY. Deep Golden pour with a nice creamy head. Bold smooth hoppy mouth with some vinella notes. Fresh clean pallet that you will love.
Great balance of malt and hops. One of my favorites and definitely a beer I could drink daily. One of the best IPAs out there!

Poured light amber, with half-finger, long-lasting head. Aroma is piney hops and a little bit of bread. Flavor is complex and balanced.  I taste a little bit of pineapple and grapefruit rind in there, perfectly balanced by the malt. Well done.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass (didnt see the snifter recommendation until it was too late).  Pours a deep, cherry amber, almost molasses-like.  Smells sweet, Im picking up caramel, malt and a bit of alcohol.  Initial palate hit is a Mike Tyson right hook to the teeth, with the strength of that 90 IBU behind it.  Aftertaste is a bitter, tangy malt....what are you Dogfish Head 90 minute?  Seems like the stronger, older brother of Karl Strauss Tower 10, only this IPA isnt wishy washy...it blazes its own trail.  The sophistication of this brew is apparent, yet its not my style when it comes to IPAs.  I respect its bitterness, yet Im not a syrupy, malty, caramely kinda guy.  I crack open an IPA looking for hops, florals, citrus, pine and more hops.  Dogfish Head 90 minute is like The Three Tenors...I can respect their talent, and maybe for a moment or two be entertained by them...but ultimately, I wind up flipping the station over to Zeppelin.

Pours a light amber with a decent white head that laces the glass.  Has a pleasant aroma with hints of citrus.  Goes down with a smooth malty taste since it isnt overly carbonated  and finishes off with a nice bitterness due to the hops.

Bottle from VBS.  Nose is toned down citrus hops, with a syrupy sweetness.  Pours cloudy orange with a creamy off-white head.  Lots of hops, but focuses more on the spicier characteristics of the ingredient.  Some mild sweetness and smooth finish.  Not too terribly bitter.  Im of fan of bitterness in my imperials, but this beer is an interesting twist, and they did it right.

bottle from a box sent to me by bhensonb.  thought i would try my senses out with this one since i felt i was getting over my sickness a little.  poured a nice gold with an excellent white head that laces the glass.  aroma was like a candi sugar type malt, butterscotch toffee type thing going on.  flavor was lots of malt and some signs of hops.  body was medium-heavy with low carbonation.  pretty good stuff that i should try again.

A: I gave this one a vigorous pour into my Moonlight pint glass. The result is a dark caramel color with two fingers of a fluffy white head and some nice carbonation.

S: The smell is much more of a mix of hops and citrus than our West Coast IPAs. A nice balance of citrus and pine hops along with a sweet, caramel malt backbone.

T: The hop flavor is mostly bitter grapefruit. There is also a very strong malt component that has a very roasted, yet sweet flavor. The finish is a bit of pine and some more grapefruit.

M: This is actually quite full bodied, but thats not too surprising for a double IPA. The tiny carbonation bubbles help to keep things from getting too heavy.

D: For a 9% beer, this is surprisingly lacking in the booziness department (and a welcome change from certain other DFH beers). That said, I still find it hard to stray from our West Coast IPAs which are just so much more hop-centric.
Has a rich amber color with a thin layer of foam.  The aroma is immediately hoppy with a light maltiness.  The flavor is maltier than you would expect.

Purchased at Winslows Tavern, Greenville, NC

"Features a single, constant 90-minute hop addition."

Very heavy alcohol taste.
this is what an IPA/DIPA should taste like; sweet, bitter, piny, floral, its all here

This is really an outstanding beer. Pours a light orange color with a thin head. Citrus and grapefruit on the nose. Palate is thick and fullbodied. Initial light, pleasant carbonation followed by bitterness and then sweet at the end. Long but crisp finish.

bottle, dark-golden with medium head. this is nice!. aroma; caramel, chocolate, coffee, dough, vanilla. taste lightly bitter, light sweetness, full body, creamy, lively, long finish. overall id say this is one of the better american beers ive had so far!

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2010 Beautiful mahogany colour, with a small off-white head, quite clear. The aroma was full of hops but the malts were also quite present, very nice on the nose. The taste is fairly bitter especially towards the finish, the maltiness was also a more present as well. On the palate this is fairly thick and the carbonation was quite smooth. Overall a great I.P.A., definitely a must try.

12oz bottle, has the citrus/peach flavor of a good pale ale and then the bitterness of the hops kicks in...in an absolutely massive way, never before has the hops stayed on so long after the sip as with this beer, this is definitely a sipper

12 oz bottle scored for 8$ a four-pack. Ive had this before but never reviewed. The color is dark orange-brown with a white head. The taste is slightly resinous but really balanced very nicely with the malts. The aftertaste is definitely "hot" as you can "feel the burn". A very good DIPA and even better through the randall.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-12-2007 21:40:54
perfect. dont read about it, drink it. see for yourself. i would, however, like to try one of these on draught, poured through randall the enamel animal. you hear me, craft ale house?

light copper color. Decent head, thin lacing. slightly cloudy. Aromas- Warm and fruity, copper, malt, hops, caramel, chocolate, alcohol, Flavors-Hops, caramel, Sweetly bitter?,pine, and alcohol. Slight pine aftertaste, Over all thin, light carbonation. Warming long bitter aftertaste.

Bottle.  Nice hoppy aroma with a solid background malt.  May not have been 100% fresh as the malt had kind of started taking this one over.  The hops were still present though with notes of citrus and bubblegum.  Thick mouth with a touch of stickiness.  Good.
Pours light amber in color.  Has a decent head along with really nice lacing.  A slight citrus note with a perfect amount of bitterness.

Dark orange-amber body with almost no head.  Strong floral aroma with a resiny character.  Flavors are mostly hop oriented with some grass and sticky citrus.  Mouth feel is thick almost syrupy feeling as a result of the complex bombardment of flavors.  Finishes out with a nice bitter hop character.  Definitely a great beer.

Pours dark amber with a lasting creamy head.
Aroma is a huge mix of hops and malt, with loads of resin, caramel, nutty, bready and toasty malt. I dont think this is all that fresh... But I love malty IPAs anyway.
Flavour profile is huge! Caramel and toasty malt are definately at the forefront, with hop resin and grapefruit also present in large amounts. Clean alcohol makes an appearance, followed by a strong bitterness that doesnt quite manage to balance the malt.
Very smooth carbonation, with quite a rich body. Perhaps too rich.
 Apart from the sweet malt overpowering everything else, this was pretty tasty. Old bottle perhaps.
not as hoppy but more malty than the average Ipa.  Smell is great.  Good color with a foamy head. Very heavy mouth feel.  A great beer but not the average IPA

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2010 Poured from 12 oz. bottle to snifter. Aroma is floral with hints of honey and hops. Appearance is ruby red orange with thin white head and nice lacing. Taste is great, notes of flowers honey and grapefruit. palate has slick oily which comes off rich. I love it deffinitly one of my top five DIPAs.
UPDATED: APR 21, 2010 A good solid IPA that is well hopped.  A lot of citris and fig flavors.  Deep blonde color with medium carbonation.

Corked BOMBER at beer tasting. Who says you cant cellar an IPA?? This bottle was at least 5 years old and considering I had never seen it in a bomber sized bottle before, I was quite delighted. Thick flat pour, no head. Super sweet aroma with a bit of balsamic vinegar? I was pleasantly surprised by the flavor...it was not as sweet as the nose and not overpowering. Obviously any sign of hops are long gone but this experiment went quite nicely.
Beautiful appearance.  Nice tan head.  Very fruity, tastes of raisins and alcohol.

On tap at Old Bag of Nails (Tremont). Pours a nice orange color with a persistent off-white head that laces nicely. Big aroma from the hops; pine, citrus, resin, and floral. The taste has a strong fruity bitterness from the hops that is ameliorated by the caramelly malts. Full bodied, clean palate with a dry, slightly bitter grapefruit finish. Good stuff.
it bites! citrus smell fruity taste with some hint of grass. a big IPA. Very Drinkable. Definetly hits your mouth. Great color as well. another quality dogfish product

Bottle.  Orange color with a short living head.  Citrus, spice, grape, caramel on the nose.  Nice balance of bitterness and sweetness. A very complex and impressive finish.  Not overpowering but a very balanced and complex beer.
UPDATED: JAN 18, 2010 Very sweet, malty up front but long, bitter, hoppy finish. Raisiny and a little cloying but balanced with great hop character.

Bottle.  A clear pale copper color pour with a rocky offwhite head , long lasting leaving plenty of lacing behind. Aroma is quite piny with some nice citrusy notes mixed in with it , lightly sweet , a touch earthy. Flavor is ever so malty up front , nice and toasty and then fades to a nice hop profile of resin and citrus and spicy hops , nice level of bitterness , dry finish , full body with out being too sweet or sticky , crisp clean mouthfeel with a dry hoppy finish , very drinkable and one damm fine glass of beer .

Pours a nice orange color with a thin white head. Aromas of pine, carmel, and citrus overwhelm your nose. Taste is fruity, mainly citrus, but you also get a grassy flavor as well. This was a very drinkable beer, and his a nice kick to it. Great brew...hats off to Dogfish Head for one hell of a brew!

Bottle. Good amber colour with a healthy off-white head. The aroma is really fruity that is slightly citrusy. There is a hint of bitterness but also a hint of sweetness at the same time. The taste has a strong fruity bitterness that is followed by a slight berry sweetness and finishes off nicely with a bittneress not as strong as the initial one.

This beer is a copper color that has floral scent with a slight alcohol undertone. Its flavor isnt what I was looking for and I bit over-hyped in my opinion... But none the less it is a good brew with sweet floral notes. Its a bit lacking in complexity and is much sweeter than I would expect. Overall it is better than the average beer but maybe not one Ill be searching for.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2010 Dogfish Head Brewing Company--90 Minute IPA--2002 25.6 oz. Bottle.  9.00% ABV--90 IBUs.  (4.75 / 5.0)  IPA--Imperial--Corked & Bottle Conditioned.  Clear thin bright amber golden color.  No head.  Rich earthy floral hop front.  Smooth sweet crystal malt body.  Earthy rich hop spice end.  Balanced rich hoppy brew.  Earthy.  Sampled 10/20/2002.

Dogfish Head Brewing Company--90 Minute IPA--2003 12 oz. Bottle.  9.00% ABV--90+IBUs.  (4.75 / 5.0)  IPA--Imperial.  Thick pour.  Mild lacy head.  Clear rich bright light amber color.  Sweet flowery hop aroma.  Sweet thick rich aromatic smooth caramel tangy citrus body.  Balanced rich mildly hot citrus hop spice end.  Sampled 9/15/2003.

Dogfish Head Brewing Company--Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA	2005-10--12  oz. Bottle.  9.00% ABV--90 IBUs.  (4.75 / 5.0)   IPA--Imperial	Mild lace head.  Clear thick golden color.  Rich floral hop front.  Smooth creamy rich balanced sweet caramel hop infused mild grapefruit chewy body.  Tangy balanced rich hop spice mild citrus Hot tongue end.  Sampled 6/8/2005.
Comprata ad amsterdam nel beershop cracked kettle.... sikuramente una delle migliori IPA ke abbia mai bevuto!!!!!!!

Pours orange with red tint and a thin head. Very hoppy smell with malt undertones. First taste is all hop and bitterness. As you drink your palat begins to notice more spices as the complexity of the beer comes through. I bwould recommend this beer to some one who wants to know what an ipa should taste like

Bottle. Pours dark amber with a laced white head. Big aroma of pine, caramel, fruit and a little boozy. The flavour I found to be a letdown with the alcohol quite evident in taste. A mate mentioned that it was quite medicinal and Id concur. Theres more of that boozy character right through to the finish. Would like to try again sometime as maybe the bottle wasnt up to par.
Having now tried the 60, 90 and 120 minute IPAs from dogfish head, I can safely say that this is my favorite. Big hop smell and big hop taste. To me a much better overall beer than the other two.

Pours medium orange with a smallish creamy white head. Light lacing on the glass that seems to hang around. Aroma of Raisins, hops some alcohol. Slight woody aroma with a citrusy tang. Aroma gets stronger as the beer warms. Slightly crisp mouthfeel from the bubbles. Taste of hops, honey, alcohol, dried fruits and rosemary. Some citrus flavors as the beer warms. Very well balanced with nothing too overpowering. Yummy. I would drink several of these or add them to the regular rotation if it werent so expensive

While, going from the 120min. to this is a  big difference, they are still both to sweet for my liking. The 120min. I can only drink about 3-4 oz. before Im so overwhelmed I no longer enjoy it. I can make it through this, but would not want a second. Will give the 60min. a shot with higher expectations, not my favorite IIPA.

pours amber with a medium off white head. what i really liked about this beer is the big hop flavour backed up by a considerable amount of malt. You get some nice citrus and pine flavours with lots of caramel and toast in the background. Very nice on the palate leaving not much of an aftertaste. A great beer.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2013 This is a revision of my rating from 2009-12-26. 12 oz. bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in a tulip. Pours clear copper-amber with a small off white head. The head slowly fades to a thin cover and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has huge citrus and pine, along with caramel and bread, flowers and a touch of perfume. The flavour is very well balanced between complex caramel malts and big, floral, perfumey, citrus hops. It is fairly acidic. The finish is long, peppery and bitter resiny hops. On the palate, it is medium in body with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is easily one of the best double IPAs out there. Definitely one to keep on hand. 2011-05-19

Addendum: Randallized at Dogfish Head Brewing & Eats. Basically a sweeter, subtler version of 90, with a nice Cascade nose and citric, slightly piney flavour. It feels a bit more spicy as well. 2012-06-08
whoa! dogfish head = bang! this was a big beer that certainly didnt disapoint.... huge on flavour that reminded you with every sip that it was a serious beer! fantastic flavours and hop cahracter.

Tasty and delicious! Pours a gorgeous coppery-orange with an ample white head. Hops come out clearly in this, but the malt is what makes this a great beer. Id love to pair this with some food - Im particularly thinking roasted meat with cheddar or blue cheese... Alcohol is well hidden and could really sneak up on you.

(drought at Eli Cannons in Middletown CT, also 6 packs, 9%)

solid backbone of crml-malts with tons of hops dancin all over their face.
hops are thick and oily but not quite overwhelming.

too IPAish for me the first time i had it, too much oily hop flavor or something like that. but now i love it, and its one of the only beers that i enjoy drinking out of the bottle because it changes the flavor in a way i dont mind or maybe even like.

12 oz bottle. The balance of this beer has always really stood out to me. It really is perfect in that aspect. As far as the aroma goes, it really is more mild than you would expect from a hop bomb. Non-hop notes on the aroma include a light oaky bourbon, nutty caramel, apple pie, and other mild fruits. Also some earth, mixed citrus, and light resin on the hop side of things. Lighter white head on the pour, minor lacing and retention, medium opacity, and dark orange in color. Again, balance is fantastic in the taste, and a nice feel as well with a light crisp bite throughout. A lot of mild wood and fruits here, apples and apricots, along with some earthy pine, bitter citrus, minor bourbon, and mixed grain cereal. The finish is very evened out for dipa. Everything here works very well together. This is a very nice beer overall.
First IPA I really enjoyed.  Enjoyed the hopped pine flavor that did not finish as bitter as most.  Slightly sweet, but par for the style.  First choice among IPAs.
UPDATED: DEC 9, 2010 (bottle) amber colour with small white head; aroma of citrus, bit of longan; more malty flavour than other IPAs I tried; totally hidden alcohol,excellent

Amber with white film. Citrus, resin, white wine and gooseberry.
Taste is moderately sweet and bitter. Finishes bitter. Medium bodied. Soft Syrupy mouth feel.
(Bottle, courtesy of tarjei 12.12.2009)

One of my favorite, go to DIPAs, that I have enjoyed many times, but just recently found that I failed to review. So, I bellied up to the bar at The House Pub in St. Charles, IL., and ordered a 12oz. bottle. Poured to a large snifter, the color was a deep, orangy amber with a white, bubbly foam head, and spots and ribbons of clingy lacing. The aroma was an intense combination of fruit sweetness and bright, sharp citrus. The flavor followed these with a potent hop bitterness that was balanced nicely by rich malt sweetness, and warming alcohol. As solid as they come, and now its finally recorded.
Dark copper colour. Amazing balancing act between the malty bakground and the intense hoppy eruption. Great beer, best IPA in the states....maybe?

Interesting mix of very sweet and very bitter.  Im not a hophead, but can surely appreciate a well hopped beer.  However, the balance of sweet and bitter here, while impressive, is a bit lost on me.  Sweet caramel malts up front with celery and grapefruit hops coming right behind.  The palate is creamy and a bit metallic.  The finish is long and bitter.  Glad I tried it, and I certainly appreciate the artistry,  but it wont be on my top 10 list.
The smell is a nice hop aroma and looks quite beautiful sitting in a glass with its white head. Taste is incredibly hoppy with a slightly bitter finish. Excellent IPA

Pale golden color, clear, generous head. 

Nose is somewhat soapy-like with a citrusy clean component. 

Palate has an odd sweetness that is quite prominent and then followed by a dryish hop finish. Very atypical to me, as far as my DIPA experiences have been. 

Scary how drinkable this ale is.

holy fuck.  why was i walking past this one at the nova?  this is one tasty beverage.  pours reddish brown with a junior high, prom queen-wannabe head.  taste is sweet with an , kinda like shooting for alpha king status.  a malty typical IPA flavor and one of the best.  give me more, more, more.  the alpha king reference may have been a little influenced by a bunch of brews, the latest being ALPHA KING.  thank you, sucker.

A: This baby pours a nice copper brown color. There head builds quickly only to die just as suddenly. Lots of tiny bubbles rise to the top and brings the head back with a simple swirl. Nice thick lacing left behind.

S: Bold aromas. There is a huge hoppy aroma with tons of Florida grapefruit. There is a wonderful sweetness to balance out the insane amount of hops.

T: This is where this baby shines. This is one of the best DIPAs out there. Tons of citrus blast your tongue putting your senses into overload. Just enough malt is used to mute the hops a bit so that they dont totally trash your taste buds. Hoppy, sweet, and wonderful. The crown gem in the DFH crown.

M: Medium to full bodied with nice carbonation. This one really clings adding to full enjoyment.
Aroma of molasses and raisins and some fruitcake.  Taste is very heavy on on the raisins, molasses, brown sugar.  Thick but goes down smooth with alcohol warming in the aftertaste.  Excellent.
outstanding imperial ipa. grapefruit! lovely, warming alcoholic finish and perfect amount of sweetness in the flavor.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2010 I agree that it deserves top honors among the DIPAs.  This beer has great flavor, great balance, great body, texture, aroma, everything.  For me this brew is old faithful.  Its widely available in the northeast and I am always in the mood for it.  There are other top DIPAs that are arguably better.  The Plinys, Ports DIPAs, the Maharaja, Unearthy, all excellent.  This DIPA runs right up there with those heavyweigths.  Try one on tap at the Rehoboth Brewpub on a summer day and youll be in love. 

June 25, 2010 - 90 Minute on Randall at the Brewpub.  Excellent.  Feels a bit more malty.  The bitters are a bit smoother.  More piny taste.  Loved it.

June 26, 2010 - Unfiltered version on tap at the RHB Brewpub.  It was explained that this was essentially a screw up that had to be sold to somebody.  Some was given to the staff free and the rest sold at the Brewpub.  Tasted amazing.  Really that same as 90 Minute standard.  Just a bit creamier and perhaps chewier.  But not a big difference.  90 Minute on tap is just awesome.

Bottle served in a tulip. Silky honey orange in color. Half head, half liquid. The way an IPA should be. Flavors are rich caramel, raisin, orange, and pineapple. Thick, creamy mouthfeel and mild carbonation on a soft delivery. This is followed by a waft of sweet malt, then a slightly bitter finish. Great balance between the malts and hops.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2010 12oz. bottle.  Amber in colour.  Minimal head that quickly disappeared.  Smells a bit like hoppy Drambuie.  Caramel, and citrus hops.  Full bodied.  Again, Ill stick with the Drambuie comparison with beautiful citrus (grapefruit) hops.  Bitter finish.  A favourite.  In my top 10 for sure.

Didnt like this beer that much.  It was drinkable but the sweetness reminded me of the Ska Decadent IPA.  Too sweet.  Nice bitterness from the hops in the flavor and aftertaste but the sweetness ruined this beer for me.
Overall one of the best IPA ive ever had, Big flavor, Big hops, very complex you cant ask for more when wanting an IPA. Great brewery as well!!

12 oz bottle at 2.75$ @ Winooski. Pours clear amber with a medium head. Nose is hoppy. Very fruity, piny and a bit floral. Some alcohol and spices also. Nice complexity on the nose. Taste is quite bitter but with some mellow fruits at the same time. Finish is very bitter and fruity. Alcohol is quite present but goes well with the bitterness. A bit sweet but quite crisp and dry overall. I am a big fan of the 60 minute IPA but this is much better. A bit less drinkable but much more complex and rich.

Poured with a nice but non-lasting 2 finger head.  Aroma of sweet hops and a matching taste.  Very sweet citrus notes.  I say citrus, but it actually tastes like theres a lemon/orange peel in the beer.  Nice taste, bittersweet palate.  Overall, ive had better IIPAs, but this isnt bad

(draught at Holy Grail Pub) pours clear orange with nice lasting creamy head. Nose of fruits, sweet bread, and citrus hops with light pine aroma too. Taste is alcohol, white pepper, fruity bread, and syrupy caramel malts. Finishes thick, creamy and syrupy. A nice dipa but not top tier for me.

Slight scent of saramel ... dark  mahogany appearance with a great, foamy head ... the carbonation was slight and the beer tasted a little syrups on the tongue, smooth finish w/ a nice, bitter bite ... I love the steadiness of the flavors.  Its sweet and barely hoppy but drops hints of caramel and dark chocolate.

12 oz bottle, pours a cola-like brown color with noticeable head. Lacing is prominent on sides of glass but retreats quickly. Aroma is fresh and floral, some roastiness. Taste is bitter but complemented with some toastiness and a little citrus. Some maltiness noted. Palate is very full; you can feel the carbonation. Really nice beer, very satisfying.

Goes down incredibly smoothly for an imperial IPA. Has great depth in flavor, beginning with a hoppy assault on the taste buds and finishing with sweet citrus undertones. One of the fullest flavored and most complex beers Ive ever had.

This is the beer that changed my life as a beer drinker, was a canoe beer drinker before.  This beer made me see the errors of my ways. If there is a perfect beer this is it. The perfect balance of malts without being overly sweet and the perfect hop bitterness without puckering your backside.  Had on draught and bottle in fact if i were cut i think i would bleed 90 minute IIPA. Cant get enough

Pours rich amber with volumious head.  Moderate lacing.  Nose is citrus with a hint of pear and apricot.  Hops are monstrous pine and resin, but as it warms to proper temp malt backbone really plays a solid balance.  Excellent crisp mouth feel with nice finish.  All in all a nice ipa from an even nicer brewer.

Excellent beer!  Just wish it was more easily accessible in Canada.  aroma is full of floral hops and taste combines a good amount of bittering hops with some more subtle flavors of nuts and even some fruit.  Smooth on the palate.

Bottle. Even though I am a malt lover, its beers like these that make me really appreciate the hoppy side of things. The flowery, fruity flavor and aroma seems to actually stimulate more then taste and smell. This beer is highly recommended and will drink again.
UPDATED: JUL 13, 2010 (glass) frothy and malty taste, nice lacing.  Has raisney citrusy and almost choclatey taste.  Syrupy mouthfeel, but it is still carbonated.  Great beer from a great company.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2010 If poured right, Ive discovered this sweet treasure forms a mountainously frothy white head.  Light carbonation in a glowing orange brew.  Thick, frothy lacing.  Aroma of cool, sweet and spicy hops with a grape/raisin touch.  Flavor more of the same, but very easy to drink for a double IPA.  You cant even tell its 90 IBUs, really.  Id guess less.  Delectably sweet flavor of raisin and fruit lingers on the tip of the tongue.  Warm on the back of the tongue, very well-rounded.  Hoppy but not in your face with hops and sweet but not grossly over-sweet.  This is a treat for the tongue.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2012 4th May 2008. Very hoppy beer but well balanced by lot of malt. As undertone of fruitiness adds complexity. Smooth and silky. Finishes bitter, slightly fruity and dry. Original rating 3.8. 20th March 2012Bottle in hotel before Norway trip. Clear gold beer, tidy white head. Smooth softish palate with mild fine carbonation. Nice hops. Floral start before deep rich citrus kicks in but somehow its still light and so drinkable. Some hop bitterness comes through but its balanced by the lovely malty sweetness. Finishes semi dry with some minerals. Immensely drinkable IIPA. Lovely.

Im not a hop-head - A lot of IPAs Ive had in the past just gave me that bitter beer face and tasted like a field of weeds.

Holy crap, this stuff is good.  Despite the high level of hops presence, its totally balanced by the malty finish.  Gorgeous copper color, nice bone head gives way to thick lacing, aroma has that citrusy-grassy quality of many IPAs, but its the flavor - delicate and bold, hoppy, malty, just plain good.

Definitely an instant favorite.  Wow.
Pours a copper color with a thin tan head. Aromas of sweet citrus; flavor is the same. Very good, but just a little too sweet for my taste.

35cl [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ mondial de la Biere.
Nice full complex intense aromas. Citrusy. Orange. Nice full body, fruity, fresh and dry. Long and lasting full bitter taste.
Golden in color, nice white foam. You can taste the that its the main-selling beer.

Perfect. Honey Orange sweet (but not too sweet) grapefruit, some dark fruit and pineapple, very well hidden alcohol. There may be no better delivery method for the deliciousness of hops than this beer.

Orange copper body with tanned head. Aroma is excellent. Full of citric notes and sweetness of malty bread. Flavour has lots of fruity hoppiness with grapfruit, some pineapple and piny notes. Yet the malty body is so perfectly balanced. I must say I have never drinked a better IPA.
This is another hoppy beer that is nice on the palate.  Hoppy but balanced.  Enjoyable to drink.

Bottle at Union Jacks poured into a tulip glass produced and beautiful amber body with light tan head.  Tastes of citrus fruits and fair amount of hops that was well balanced.  I enjoyed this ale very much.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2009 Bottle. Brilliant dusky orange under a massive blossom of foam worthy of the Tripel Karmeliet tulip;festoons of lace like cosmic dust clouds. Thats a 5. Unanticipated caramel sweetness on the nose like Brewdog Punk IPA; cinder toffee, digestive biscuits, batter and liquorice as much as Mango Jammy Dodgers (imagine) and juicy satsuma on the edge of moulding. Smells like tangerine cheesecake left in the sun. Spruce, almond, bags of booze as the head subsides. Hops big but tropical and ester-like, with more than a suggestion of pineapple. Fat but supple; hop intensity accelerated to the point it goes backwards and begins to imitate the mellow estery glow of a big Belgian Tripel. Warm but not fierce, alcohol spike cushioned luxuriously in malt, tangerine, walnut, satsumas on buttered toast, soapy biscuit..The brilliance of this beer is that it smacks you in the face with hops and you hardly notice.
Pours an apple juice color.  Aroma of mild fruityness with a slight musty smell.  Taste of a very distinct hops with a certain bite to the aftertaste.  An enjoyable IPA.
12 oz bottle, university market, 2.79. As a hop head, it needs more hops. But it is still very tasty lots of malts, sweet, real light bitter.

This beer is simply amazing. Nose is hoppy with a blend of sweet malts and almost citrusy. Pours a deep amber with a small amount of lacing. Taste is wonderful, big on malts, this balances the hoppy flavor you normally get from an IPA with 90 IBUs. No bitterness on the end from the hops. Low on carbonation, this is pretty easy to swallow. I could drink one every night. Thanks for another wonderful beer DFH.
Not much aroma off this.  Color is a muddy brown.  Not much hop taste at all.  Pretty malty actually.  OK as a brown ale but not a west coast IPA.

bottle: pint glass: So this is the famed 90 huh? Pours a deep amber, leaving 1 finger of slightly off white head.  Nose is the sweaty hoppy I expected, with lots of floral and fruits, citrus.  The initial taste is bitter hops, rush of carbonation... as it moves through the mouth and warms the young fruits and citrus come out... also a surprising high malt level giving this beer a great balance.  The finish is bitter but not too dry, and there is a nice warming feel from the esters.

Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Clear amber-orange with nice retained (but small) head and lacing.

Smells somewhat like the 60 Minute, but the citrus is more prominent and the toasted malts less so. Also, a slight alcohol smell, especially as it warms.

Fairly sweet and fruity, with a very citrusy hop taste. Overall, it has a strong malt and hop taste without the hop bitterness. The 60 Minute is actually more bitter than this, and that is not a very bitter IPA either. Slight taste of alcohol. I was surprised by how malty and sweet this beer is, without much bitterness (despite the supposed 90 IBUs). Basically, this is a different DIPA, but I really like it.

Very, very smooth. Low carbonation and medium body.

Besides for a slight alcohol taste, this is ridiculously easy to drink - dangerously so.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2013 Wow!  Yes!  Umm....BAM!  One of the best beers I have had the pleasure of drinking in a long time.  Not as bitter as I would though for an IPA, but who cares?  Just simply beautiful.  I paid about $10.99 / 4 and would do it again.  Re-rated 6.24.11 - who would of thought that after multiple re-tries over a year and a half that I would actually downgrade one of my former favorites.  I still enjoy the 90 minute, but now it taste a little cloying and syrupy to me.  Interesting how taste change.  re-rated again!2.11.13  This thing just doesnt wow me anymore.  Of course it is better than average, but it is feels very one-dimensional in an ever-increasing multi-dimensional IPA world!  That just sounded like total b.s., but it does encapsulation how I feel about this beverage after many years of sampling.  Taste change and so should your ratings!  So here is to re-rating!!!

Deep dark amber orange with nice head that fazes quickly but leaves good lacing. Aroma of hops, hops and malt. Taste is of hops but balanced out with nice big malt backbone. Not as hoppy for the style or as I expected, but delicious nonetheless. The hops are definetley there but are balanced by great maltiness. A great ale.

Delightful!  Nice amber color with a creamy head that lasts -- lacing throughout.  A wonderful creamy texture; something that I do not experience much in a IIPA, or any IPA -- interesting.  It seems that I have a dilemma . . . Dog fish vs. my favorite IIPA: The Pliney Elder.  I shall, as of now, say I favor the Dog Fish.

Im not going to re-word every single review on here.

Amazingly well-balanced IIPA.  In fact, this is probably one-half of the golden standard for IIPA.  I know that it wont be everyones favorite, but this is one of those beers that HAS to be on the drank-list to be able to say that you are a true beer-nerd.

My girlfriend even likes this one...and she is a "not too hoppy" beer lover.

This is a sexy beer.  

Can beer make you sexy?

Why...yes.  Yes it can.
One of my favorite beers! Was pleasantly surprised by the sweet, hoppy finish.

A light amber coloure beer with a small white head and no carbonation. A hoppy aroma. Full palate. Finish is sweet hoppy bitter. This my personal topper I have drunk at the Mondial in Strasbourg. Just a fantastic beer.

Pours a hazy orange-amber with a small ivory head. Aroma is of citrusy hops and sweet chocolatey malts. Flavor is quite sweet with heavy flower nectar and powdered chocolate toward the end. The hops are pretty mild. Medium viscosity, bitter finish. Overall, very good.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2009 12 oz. bottle- Wow, I was blown away by this, I  started my night by drinking a six pack of slow elk, then drank a Kona pipeline porter, then a Great Divide Chocolate oak aged imperial stout. After those great porters and stouts, I was in the mood for something hoppy, so I grabbed what I assumed was the hoppiest beer in my beer fridge, a 90 minute IPA, and it delivered. The ample amount of hops are well balanced with a nice sweetness to it. The best of the Imperial IPA bunch- so far.

Growler from Village Beer Merchant.  Pours a light amber color with a small off-white head.  Aroma is of delcious fruity hops, alcohol, and sweet biscuity malt.  Tastes sweet with lots of pine/spicy/citrus/apricot hop flavors. Finishes with spicy hop bitterness and alcohol burn.  Yum!!! Always a good brew, but seems lighter and the hops seem less bitter than a few years ago.
my go to iipa.  such hoppy goodness that makes my mouth water every time.  a hop heads dream come true. A+ dogfish head.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours amber with streaks of gold.  A grassy nose meets with a very well balanced beer in the flavor.  Lots of malts as well as hops prevent a huge bitterness (not necessarily a compliment) despite the IBUs.  Still, very tasty and refreshing.  Hints of liquor, just a tad syrupy.  Very smooth.  Gets you drunk before you realize what happened.

Bottle @Mondiale de le biere in Strsbourg
Ottimo Aspetto oro aranciato e buona persistenza della schiuma, Non è molto intensa al naso ma il luppolo si eprime in maniera molto fine. Al palato risulta  molto frutta e sbilanciata verso note di malto, molto morbida e poco amara Studiata per essere molto gradevole e beverina.Molto persistente e molto armonica...
Gorgeous golden color with pillowy white head. Wonderful balance; massive hop bite transitioning to a nice malt finish and a citrusy aftertaste.
Bottle 33. Impressive hops flavour, close to citrus. Malt is quite missing. Intresting beer but to hoppy for me.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2011 12 oz. bottle, pours an attractive amber into chalice. Beautifully balanced aroma of intense hops, balanced by caramel malts and a potent grapefruit scent. Flavour is complex- high hops, but the bitterness is masked by everything else going on- grapefruit flavours are prominent as well as a considerable sweetness. Simply one of the best IPAs there is.

400th rating. 33cl bottle. Clear, bubbly amber with a fine, mostly dissipating white head and a scattered oily lacing. Grapefruit, mango and orange peel aromas with floral and honey notes. A big hit of demerara sugar sweetness followed by rhubarb and honey. Grapefruit, lemon sherbet and spicey hops balance with a grassy, piney finish leaving a floral, grassy and toasty aftertaste. Medium carbonation, crisp, lasting and balance mouthfeel with a touch of alcohol in the throat. So, so drinkable. Bottled on 05/06/09.

This ipa is gold in colour with a nice bright white head. To the nose there are scents of hopps, grass, juniper and more hopps. First taste is smooth and creamy with lots of hopp flavour but no over the top as I was expecting. Flavours of orange and lemon citrus and raisens make this a nicely flavoured ale. Finish is lemony with the hopp bitterness being just right.

Bottled, 111009.
Orange with white head. Aroma of orange, malt and spices. Flavor is malt, fruit and hop bitterness. Well balanced.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2011 bottled 6/16/2011.  Fruity malty nose with hops. pours darker shade of clearamber like a torpedo, head is average. flavor is malty like a barleywine, brown sugar, thick, fruity, pretty sweet overall.  hops in the background and finish.  chewy mouthfeel is fun.   a very big and bold beer but blind i would have called it a barleywine, and that just kind of bugs me.  we dont need every double IPA to taste like the next, but this one blurring the line too much if you ask me.  the lack of strong bitterness bugged me also.  alc content seemed really boozy and pronounced, again, like a barleywine.  too malty for my preference in IIPAs and also very expensive, douglas.  loses points for those two things but it is a very well executed beer (with an identity crisis).  most IIPAs are hop bombs, this one is a malt bomb!

I like this. The hops and malt balance works, very well blended. Not as bright on the hops as others but makes up with some brown sugars which gives a very good feel on the tongue. Lacing is nice on the glass. Good stuff.

Bottle.  Dark Brown Pour.  Very Malty.  High ABV, doesnt really drink like an IPA.  Very Smooth.  Hint of citrus, nice clean finish.
B+

Aroma is citrus and caramel. Lots of malt sweetness come through. I like this beer, but it feels more like an American strong or even American brown than an IPA to me. I guess Im partial to west coast stuff.

Esquire Magazine calls our 90 Minute I.I.PA., "perhaps the best I.P.A. in America." An Imperial I.P.A. brewed to be savored from a snifter. A big beer with a great malt backbone that stands up to the extreme hopping rate. This beer is an excellent candidate for use with Randall The Enamel Animal!

Bottle at Oliver Twist in April 09.

Dark brown color with a small head.

Citrus, caramel, some chocolate, sugar and slightly burnt.

Initially I thought the taste reminded a bit of a stout, a little coffee and chocolate. Thereafter became more fruity taste with a pleasant bitter. Medium-heavy body, very good!
I love the 90 Minute from Dogfish Head. This beer is so good!  Floral and hoppy with the perfect amount of hops. Just wish it was sold in 12 oz.

This stuff is just plain good. The softest icing sugar taste combine with luscious and tangy hops to form an awesome pairing. The bond of these two just crash the mouth with wave after wave of depth. Just when you think its all done, an amazing toasted roast comes through on the finish and leaves you wanting more. Smart, sexy and masterly crafted. One of the best I have ever tasted.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 @ a tasting, thanks kerenmk, pours honey orange with a small head, aroma of marmalade, tangerine and malt sweetness, flavor is dry and sweet, with grapefruit and malt, pretty sticky, medium bodied, not fresh 7/3/6/3/12[3.1]

From bottle, cognac color with a small to medium head, aroma of mandarine, vanilla, mint and lavender, flavor of mandarine, grand marnier, clove and bitter finish, body is medium to full. Nice beer 7/4/7/4/15[3.7]

Bottle.Sure ,a nice IPA ,but also kind of a let down as I expected so much.Aroma of grains and piny hops.Nice bitterness and malt profile,sure lots of hops but not outstanding.I might not have gotten the freshest bottle living in the outskirts of Europe ,hopefully I will get the chance to sample this brew again.Still ,nice beer.
a great dipa from one of the best stateside brewers.  lots of malt in this one (which is not a bad thing in a DIPA) and caramel/molasses notes.

An amazing IPA.  Not as much hops as I expected.  Very smooth and balance for an IPA.  Dark caramel mixed with dark fruits, what could be better.  Grapefruit with some pine bitterness mixed in with sweetness.

This is an outstanding, double IPA with a rich, well-rounded character similar to a hoppy, lighter barleywine

Its amber with a large pale tan head that  shrinks slowly to a lasting foamy top.  It leaves a little weak lace.

The aroma is rich with caramelised fruit, bread crust, raisin, hints of grapefruit, orange, hay, dry leaves, and candy.

The taste is interesting, with firm sweetness, bitterness, and spiceiness, all coordinated and balanced nicely.  It tastes of dry bread crust and prunes with hints of grapefruit, leaves, caramel, candied fruit, spicey raisins, candy, alcoholic spice and warmth. The sweetness is thick at first but this soon is joined by rich hop character and tingly bitterness on the sides of the tounge. Rich and engaging,  its well-integrated and very drinkable.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2009 Great shit.  I guess these guys invented the style in the mid 90s and what a  seminar on Hop Bombs in a bottle.  Very soothing .,Im gettiing a head spin.  Nice grassy ,chewy hoppiness ..pretty waxy and inprinting on my gumbs .  Syrupy/Malt caramel .  Alcoholic grapefruit everywhere.  I  alwayz knew this would rule.  Cant  wait to sink some 120 minute.

Pours a nice clear ruby red. Aroma is strong and strangely musty, very musty actually, with some soily notes along with a bit of citrus. The head pours nicey but sadly dissipates quickly. Huge taste and very full bodied. This is a serious beer, strong taste with earthy notes in the end. Not for the faint of heart, very bitter, very fulfilling. Im still waiting for an IIPA to please me as much as Weyerbachers amazingly wonderful Simcoe Unfiltered Double.

Bottle.  I was excited for this one.  It poured a nice golden color with a milky white, frothy head that stayed for awhile before dissipating.  Very nice lacing.  Aroma of hops and malts, and the taste was a wonderful blend of the two, with a bit of caramel and a brief hop attack to end it all.  Aftertaste is sweet.  Medium bodied.  Since finally taking an interest in how my beer tastes, IPA is easily my favorite, and this one does not disappoint.

Pours amber golden with a thin white head. 
Nice hoppy aroma, grapefruit with a bit of pepper and the sweet caramel malt background. Classic American aroma. 
A nice balance between malt and hop flavours here. A very sweet caramel dominates the hops for the first few sips, but the bitterness builds and takes it on nicely. A very prominent citric hop character, which dances over the back of the tongue and lingers for quite a while.
A very drinkable and strong flavoured beer, very nice.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2010 Bottle. 12 oz. Pours transluscent orange-copper with a thick, frothy off-white head. Aroma of grapes, barley, scotch, figs, vanilla, dry hops, and traces of vanilla. Full bodied with a great sticky mouthfeel and an outrageously warm, smooth finish, Hands down one of the best IPAs I have ever tasted. Highly recommended. Though, be wary the alcohol is remarkably well hidden!

let me first say im not an IPA person. its not my style. however, for an IPA its very good. flavor is heavily grapefruit oriented, and hey even i like eat a grapefruit from time to time. i can see why this is so popular, byt not really my thing all the same. but very good for what it is.

12oz bottle.Pours a dark amber red colour. Not a bad beer, I noticed a slight alc.% burn in the after taste though. Only thing knocking it from a higher rating for me. Maybe im just not ready for it yet, but solid over all.

My only real complaint of this is that it smells a little sweet when its first opened.  It does however dissipate in time, and not alot of time either, happily.  This is one hoppy beer! And damn tasty too.

It poured a hazy dark golden liquid with a small foam with big bubbles. It had a strong smell of caramell, hops, citrus and grape. It had a very round and smooth mouthfeel. Lots of hops, high bitterness and some citrus, caramell and grape. Very nice!

Bottle that I picked up from Bellingers, Jet Garage, Grove Nr Wantage, Oxon, consumed 19-09-09   Pours amber with a slight chill haze and a white head sits atop. There is a fresh hoppy aroma with a touch of honey but I somehow feel that the aroma has been blunted a tad by the chilling of this beer. Tasty hoppy beer with wonderful bittersweet balance. The bitterness is really quite lovely. Ive had this on a number of occasions before but have never got around to rating it until now, a classy beer  A7 A4 F8 P4 Ov17  4.0
Poured golden with a little bit of a head, awesome aroma full of hops, didnt taste much alcohol little citrusy, one of my favorites.

bottle - (asheft) amber orange beer with a thin white head. Aroma is full with citrusy hops. Flavou has malty sweetness well balanced with a nice hops bitterness. Mouthfeel like oil. Alcohol is detectable.

Pours dark copper, lots of carbonation and very little head, just some off white froth.  Aroma is strong hops and alcohol that I can get from half way accross the room, also some citrus fruit and sweetness.  Taste is initially sweet, cakey and fruity, cherries and almonds, some citrus, and then a pleasant - but quite mild - bitter citrus finish.  The bitterness becomes more prominant and malty as it warms up.  Nice background malt and honey sweetness throughout.  Enjoyable viscous texture.  Lovely.

14-SEP-2009 @Ølbaren.
Have been looking for this for some time after having had the 60 and 120 min.
And surprise, not a lot on the nose.  Very shy, some orange but overall way to subdued. Where is the bitterness? This is an IIPA, right?
Like wine is it just a matter of balance? If so I can aggree with the hype.
Orange with low head. Beautifull colour.
Citrus nose, lacks some in complexity. Very nice bitteness, but far from what I expect in an IIPA.
Very sweet with loads of dried fruit.
Wonderfull balance, wonderfull creaminess and mouthfeel.
Nothing extreme about this one, and maybe that is the greatness? Oh, and where is the alcohol? Maybe I had to many (strong) beers tonight to rate it properly? Will have to rebuy some time.
I dont really know what to think of it? Very fine beer, could drink tons of it.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2010 I need to try this again.  Had it a long time ago and hated it.  Needs another try.  0.7, later a 1.5

EDIT:  After several years and about 4 or 5 different tries, I finally came to terms with this beer.  Aroma is sweet, brown sugar, caramel, hops, and fruit.  Taste is bitter citrus, caramel, and pine.
A malt forward beer.   Toasted malts with a good balance of hops.  Different than most IPAs in a good way.  Not too harsh.

Pours a clear orange, some white foam. Aroma is very much hops, with some nice spices on top. Some malt comes through on the taste, nice and complex, some fruity and sugary flavors to balance the major hops.  This is possibly the best IPA Ive ever had.

Bottle, Rehills, Newcastle. Wow! Read a lot about this beer and was looking forward to trying it - I was not disappointed. Not the hop overload I was expecting, rather a mellow, beautifully smooth complex beer. Flavours of caramel, treacle, lemon sherbert and brown sugar. Fine pale russet colour, lovely warming sensation as it goes down. Im not a hophead, but this is amazing.

One of my favorites that Ive been meaning to review. Beautiful, dark, golden appearance, with a thin, white head. Aroma is pure hops. The first sip is always something of a system shock. Its strong... but not. They do a good job of balancing it with barley. The mouthfeel is IPA, but the aftertaste is barley wine. Just a fantastic beer.

Bold, flavorful, strong IPA!  Deep golden color.  Aroma is floral and citrusy almost tickles your nose. Bold hoppy malted flavorwith fruity alcohol finish. Reminded me slightly of Pannetone (Italian holiday raisin bread/cake).  Big beer.  one of my favorites to date.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2009 Color: Gold with orange tint

Aroma: Caramel, moderate earthy and vegetal notes, rich, concentrated fruity malt

Flavor: Caramel and dried fruit dominates at first and is followed by savoury/earthy roast grain and dried date/fig carries through on the finish. 

Comment: 2008 purchase; aged one year. Very smooth mouth feel, Moderately sweet but not cloying. Understated bittering supports the malt from start to finish. The flavor also evolves, creating a complex drink. A favorite and one of the best beers Ive had this summer.


2008 tasting of a 90 minute purchased in 2007.
Aroma:  resin, spice, ripe orange, burnt coffee, rich malt
Flavor: Rich malt, fruity, creamy sweetness with coffee notes
Long 40sec+ finish--sweet malt caramel, some butterscotch spice

Comment:  Emphasis is on sweetness over bitterness; Very smooth, beautifully integrated, complex.  Could be a 4.6+.
Great, but Id rather have a Stone Ruination IPA if I want something big and bold.  The two have a similar flavor and I look at the 90min as a "lesser than" Stones Ruination.

I have been putting off rating this one for a while.  I needed many, many tastings of this one to properly form an opinion.  It seems the more I drink of them, the better impression I get.

This beer is a flat out East Coast DIPA.  Heavier on the malts than the hops, this is a classic example of how an east coast DIPA differs from say a Ruination or a Hopslam. 

This is a Big beer.  Great floral character in the nose, it is a slight let down when it gets in your mouth.  The malt seems to dominate, which is a good thing if you are a fan of the East coast style.  Good lacing, great drinkability, etc.  Great beer.  Not as hoppy as I would have imagined, but great nonetheless.  A 4 pack will get you bombed for $10.

Bottle.  Pours a reddish copper color with a small white head.  Looks a touch viscous.  Big malty aroma, roasted malts, caramel, raisins, and hops.  More of the same in the flavor; tons of roasted malts, cocoa, caramel, sweet sugar cane/brown sugar, and hops.  Very well-balanced beer, neither too sweet nor too bitter from the hopping.  Thick and rich mouthfeel.  Im really enjoying this one; how come I havent had this before?

Bottle (in NZ). Got the big beautiful US hop aroma - full of fruit and pine. The palate is a lot creamier and sweeter than expected, with chocolate touces to the malt - but where are those hops? OK, there they are! As I swallow it hops bit strongly, increasing the sweetness while also drying my mouth out with orange and pine flavours. Probably not as good as some other US IIPA ive tasted lately - but they are setting a high standard.

Aroma is actually sort of light. Lemon and pepper. The flavour has so much more going on. Lots of sweetness. Lots of bitterness. Iced tea, barbecue sauce, grapes. Reminiscent of fine wine. Medium to heavy body, finishes dry.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a clear gold color, a light yellow copper held to the light with a slight white head with nice lacing.

The smell is of hops, sweet hops with some piney flavor.

The taste is subtle hops, not slamming into the taste buds but gently letting your mouth and tongue get used to the hoppyness. Again there is a hint of pine and some grains feel as well.

The mouth feel is the best I have had in an Imperial IPA. Just the right balance lets this beer let you enjoy this beer without biting to hard back. Not heavy on the pallet and is nice and smooth. Some the thickest lacing I have seem on an IPA, Nice!
This has to be one of the best beers I have ever experienced.  Smooth and crisp.  The taste is superb!

the color is that of a white zinfandel wine and the head was a bubbly white head that faded rather quickly.  the aroma is on par with a super flavor coming in behind it.  it is not overpowering and a new beer drinker could probally enjoy this one. bubbles rise continuing in a glass.  the abv is perfect for this style of beer.  good brew for this style and would almost agree as being one of the greatest ipas but we all know there is one better, but i really enjoyed this one.  good job dogfish!

Appearance - pours a nice translucent gold with a thick head that disappears quickly. Lacing is there, and heavy. 

Smell - not as hop infested as I had expected, maybe not even as much as its little brother, the 60 minute. Citrus, sweet smell.

Taste/Mouthfeel - not nearly as scary as I had feared. Quite tasty actually with the hops of course up front. Mouthfeel is medium bodied.

This hides its relatively high alcohol content pretty well so I recommend you be careful here.
chocolate and roasted malt nose, clear dark orange in appearance. Bit too chocolatey for me but it hangs around the palate for a good long time and warms as it goes down.
Flavorful mix of hops and malt, excellent nose and a beautiful outer shell. 90 minute a local rider.

beautiful golden amber somewhat hazy colour that belies its potency.......aroma is somewhat subdued but there are hints of hops and large volumes of malt.......overall a nicely balanced brew......the brewmasters have done a wonderful job of creating a very creamy mouthfeel with a sweet, nutty, and malty finish.......actually had this while eating fritos ( odd but it works!)

One of my favorite beers out there.  A strong ipa with a pleasant floral aroma with hints of some kind of wood.  The taste begins balaced with the same wood/smokey taste and finishes with strong hops and alcohol.  There is no substitute!

ambrata buona schiuma piuttosto persitente note decisamente luppolate intense quasi astringente poi si trova anche malto in buona quantita perche nonostante la luppolatura riesce quasi ad essere bilanciata
UPDATED: OCT 4, 2009 Golden brown in color with a quickly dissipating head.  Prominent citrus hops aroma with a hint of malt.  Thick, malty mouthfeel with a subtle but very good fruity hop flavor.

Poured into a tulip glass.  Nice amber color with one finger off white head that disipated quickly.  Left no lacing on the glass.  Aroma has a nice sweet malt and hop aroma...gives the impression of the balance which is to come in the flavor as well.  Taste is very well balanced...plenty of hops, but brought into line by the substantial malt presence.  Much different from a west coast style ipa...kind of reminds me of a barley wine with the richness of flavors including some dark fruit along side the more common hops flavors like grapefruit and citrus.  A very complex beer.  Very tasty...worth all the praise.

I had this beer to celebrate the first Vikings preseason game and was not dissapointed.  Pours a copper color with an off-white head.  Rich hoppy aroma.  The taste is complex but is so malty and hoppy it almosts makes you cringe.  Nice grassy finish.  This beer is top shelf!

Poured from the bottle into a pint glass.  Pour produced a dark amber body (with a slight haze) topped by a small head of off-white foam.  Fragrant nose of hops, citrus, and floral notes.
