Crisp carbonation with a slight sweetness at the beginning, ending on a bitter note.  The hops lays on your tongue for a while, and is nicely balanced out by the malts, which, as mentioned before in other reviews, is stronger than other IIPAs.  I do recommend puring this in a snifter or any other glass that can capture the aroma, as there is quite a profile to sample here.

I think I like this a little better than the 60 minute IPA.  The hops are stronger but the general flavor seems a little bit more interesting.  Overall, I think the flavors seem unbalanced or unblended.  As in, the malts, hops and fruity overtone flavors seemed immediately separate on my tongue. For that reason, it doesnt get a higher rating.

However, I was served this beer very poorly... with a glass at all! (so I resorted to a plastic cup) and at too cold a temperature. 

I would like to try this again done the right way in the future. Maybe the flavors will be better.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2009 Tasted 15/08/2009. Well worth the mad props. HUGE in all respects while still maintaining integrity and respect for the palate with a fine balancing malt character.  Probably too malty for what Id consider and IPA, with a little toasty melanoidin character lurking in there, but a fine fine beer that Id love to try fresh.  IPAs (and IIPAs especially) can be be all aroma show and not enough palate dough... this is not one of those imposters.  Food pairing: the best, big, fresh and delicious burger you can wrap your mouth around.  Vegetarian is even better but Id lower myself to some meat.

How this stands up depends almost entirely on the serving temp. When served warmed up properly, the smell is a blossom of hops, peach, apricot, bubblegum. The taste is complex and unique ~ butterscotch, rum, sugar, hops, more peaches, ghee. The hop balance is pretty strong yet this is quite drinkable. However, this particular IPA has a very "locked in" sort of taste compared to other IPAs that I like that tend to have a more open, loose, and free kind of taste. I find this kind of flavour profile to be a bit of a trademark with every single DFH brew that I have ever had. Its a bit hard for me to explain...I do like this beer, but I find it to be a hugely unrepresentative of the traditional IPA style. That is waht DFH does best though, right? So...cheers to this amazing and singular example of an interesting beer done...right? Sure...just be sure to warm it up.

The aroma has molasses, grapefruit and resin.  It has a good, off-white head that disappeared quickly. It was clearer than I expected and makes me wish they had left it unfiltered.  The flavor was full, acetic, and just delicious.  I feel a little bad not absolutely loving this, but I love Dogfish head for existing and making this beer.
12 oz bottle. Copper color, nice white head. Huge amount of malts and hops, but in a good balance. Pine and citrus notes. A really great beer.

Bottled on 6/18/09. I guess I am still to green to get the love for this beer. Maybe I need to try again with dinner instead of a stand alone. It was tasty indeed and complex etc just not at all what i expected .

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2010 New Rating: Holy CRAP! Now I get it. From the way it looks in the glass (crystal clear amber, with a pillowy beige head), to the perfumey and heady oranges and fruitcake aroma, to the luscious, deeply complex flavours of wood, brandy, oranges, and madeira... this is everything I want in a beer and nothing I dont. So glad I gave it another crack.

Old rating: Theres so much complexity to this beer, but alas, its lack of freshness is showing. I am rating it as it stands (and I dont think 3.6 is bad given age and distance travelled) but its become overwhelmingly malty - tasting of maltesers - and needs a re-rate when I taste it fresh. Recorded for reminder purposes only! :)

I have enjoyed this beer numerous times both in the bottle and on tap.  I find that each time I drink this beer i discover a new flavor to latch onto also this is dependent on what im eating.  But the maltiness is perfect with a good sweetness in the hops and great texture and color.  Just a perfect offering from my favorite beer company

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2012 Pour a copper color with a nice lingering white head.  aroma is of pine, grapefruit, and some a good amout of carmel.  flavor is similar with alot of pine, grapefruit hops, but also has some nice carmel malt falvor.  also has a spicyness to it that pliney the elder lacks.  mouthfeel is very thick and rich and the alchool is well hidden.  the larger amounts of malt in this compared to other DIPAs really makes this a wonderful beer.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2010 Has a lovely copper pour with a nice amount of head.  Fresh pine aroma,with some caramel.  Sweeter than a lot of imperial IPAs Ive had.  The bitter hops arent as strong as Id expect from the style either, and the sweetness really clings.  Its a bit too cloying on the finish for my taste and is the only thing that brings this beer down for me.  Still, a solid and interesting beer.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2010 I have had this beer many times and it is definitely one of my favorite DIPAs.  Citrusy and malty sweet, the balance becomes more bitter (and therefore better balanced) as it warms and you drink. Outstanding!
Best IPA that Ive had so far.  Typical piney and grapefuitty aroma.  Hides the 9% very well.

On Tap at Shallos. Pours slight cloudy dark copper with appealing foamy head. Lots of fresh citrus hops on the nose with a good malt character as well. Taste is rich hop greatness! The malt balance really makes this one special. A tiny amount of caramel and something like marshmallow comes through making this a truly unique tasting double. Its no mistake that this is the highest rated of the DFH minute family.

The bottle looks great, the beer in the glass also. Starts quite hoppy and strong, also intense spicy notes, caramel, some fruit. Modest alcoholic. Well balanced finish, goes down warming still with nice hoppy notes. A great beer! Big thanks to Cletus (jjpm74) for the bottle!

Pours hazy copper with a nice white head, smells of thick hops of grapefruit and citrus with more emphasis on pine.  Tastes very hoppy with a floral/piney emphasis, and finishes extremely nice and bitter.  Very thick mouthfeel. Overall a very good DIPA!
Nothing to say about a master piece. Raisins on the nose with rich amber color. Hoppy and drinkable as hell. Could not put it down.

12fl oz bottle poured into a semi-clear plastic cup (Im still at the hotel).  Amber with a ton of creamy white head.  Aroma is raisins and some other fruit, slight alcohol.  Flavor is raisin, alcohol, strong hops bitterness.  The flavor sort of sneaks up on you and grabs you and doesnt want to let go.  Finish is bitter and long and leaves you with some warming alcohol.  This is an intense beer.  This is my first American IPA.  I didnt care for any of the British examples Ive had.  I think I prefer the American hops.  This brew really grabs you by the balls.  More than just a beverage, it is an experience to be had.  Good stuff.

Pours golden, white head. Aroma is light hoppy, but it is masked with some "wet dog".... Very strange. Flavour is hoppy, flower and some cirtus. Also some sweet caramel and honey. This is not what I have expected from this beer. I must taste it again.
Pours a deep amber. Smells like pine sap and malt. For 9% it hides it pretty well. Potent but smooth. Fruity notes but I cant place them.  Great IPA!!!

Best beer Ive ever tasted. Lots-o-hops, great white head, fruit flavors abound, and a kick like a mule. You feel the buzz after just one bottle.  THe best part is the finish, which is bitter and lasts forever.....
amber pour with a large white head...tons of hop flavor without being overwhelming like the 120
Ruby colored brew. Intense hoppy aroma. Hoppy, rich, full flavor. Fruity, very well balanced IPA. Very nice.
love it - nice and strong - very hoppy - not as incredibly strong as the 120 minute ipa, but carries a bit more intensity than the easily drinkable (daily drinker) 60 minute ipa.

Drank four out of bottle during poker game, i think one more may have hindered my play.  Great mouthfeel and finish, coats your entire palate, plenty of apricot and molasses flavors.  Pretty much loved everything about this beer.
Bottle. Amber with off white head. Hoppy citrusy aroma sweet peaches. Taste sweet malt peaches and a lot of hops citrus grapefruit herbs and more hops. Long bitter finish

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a pint glass. 

Appearance: On top there is a very good tall just off white colored head. It is very thick and creamy, long lasting and makes cool rings of lace on the glass after each sip. The body has a slight hazy appearance and a golden amber color.

Smell: The aroma is full of sweet malt and pine resin and citrus hops.

Taste/Mouth Feel: The flavor hits you with a full bodied punch of piney, resiny and citrus hops balanced by thick sweet malt and sweet warming brandy like alcohol. It finishes with more herbal and piney bitterness. The palate has a smooth mellow carbonation with a smooth slick almost sticky texture.

Notes: Im not a big hop head but this is a hop bomb that I can get into. It is big, bold and very tasty.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2010 On draught at Rattle N Hum (NYC): By far one of the most memorable beers Ive tasted.  Notes of apicots, peaches, cranberry, maple syrup, and raisins... So delicious!  Its one bountiful fruit basket in a pint. Ill come back to this one again and again. For sure. #070 on 15072009, DG.

I dont normally like a hoppy beer, but wanted to give this one a shot.  Im pretty impressed.  Although the hoppiness is a little too much for me, as i normally prefer a more malty, yeasty type of beer.  This one has a good mouthfeel and a very strong finish.  Hop hop hoppy hop.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: Dogfish 90 is an exceptionally well-balanced brew. The flavor is hoppy, but just right for anyone who enjoys a good IPA. The ABV is high, but there is no alcohol bite like many others in this class. The flavor is long-lasting and does not loose its great body as it sits while you sip. It has a very nice head for this style -- and the head lasts. Do yourself a favor and drink this from a glass. This is a special beer.

This beer followed Urthel Samaranathanantnatnantntn at the Freakin Frog in Vegas and it certainly lived up to the expectation without considering how my wallet just got raped.
Poured out a clear amber brew with a great light tan that was quite thick and left average lacing. The aroma is insane! One of the best Ive ever smelt. Beautifully floral with peaches, apricot nectar, more fruits that I didnt have time to identify, weak pine, raisins maybe, thick malts. The taste was incredible form first sip - the wonderful aroma just set that up. Intense hops of grapefruit, orange, lemon, sweet bready malts, soft caramel, tastes like flowers smell, weak molasses. Its all just put together so nicely. Every sip I told my wife that this is one of the best tasting beers Id ever had in my life. Smooth on the mouth with good, soft carbonation, deceiving bitterness that was no where near as taste bud crippling as I figured it would be. The shit part of this is that I had to attempt to review it and drink it in under 5 minutes. But still, what a five minutes that was.

wow! Pours a copper-gold with off white head laces nicely. Aromas of sweet malt, dark fruits some caramelly molasses, citrus hop - orange, and noticeable alcohol. Creamy-medium body malts upfront and then bite into the hops (citrus, pine) which tingles the top of your mouth while your tongue takes in the sugary malt, dark fruit molasses. "Brandied fruitcake" is pretty dead on - 294 calories of deliciousness! Sweet raisin contrasts the piney bitterness and alcohol to round off the finish(last a good while). You have to expect a 9ABV to be sweet...all around just fantastic!
I didnt care for this. Its hopped over and over and over. It just tasted like I was chewing on a hop cone as using it like snuff and drinking the juice.
did not really live up to the hype, maybe a bad batch but i really didnt like this one too much. Dogfish Head is sort of hit or miss for me, i guess this was a miss.

Original review date 10/30/2008...12-oz into Cab glass. I havent had this for a few years, so lets see if I can trust my palate memory...

Crystal-clear copper color with sparse carbonation. Head is thin and dissipates quickly, leaving yeasty bubbles.

Extra-grassy and earthy hops, but there is that DFH tell that I remember profusely...quite a bit of earth. Theres actually a little cowpie stench in there, too. Copious amber/caramel malt.

Even thought theres clamminess and the cowpie stench shows up in the back of the palate, there is a nice malty taste to this with slightly alcoholic sweetness. Still...that extra-earthy tone detracts from this quite a bit and grassys up the hop bitterness a great deal. Good, but not as impressive as one would expect.

Palate feel is OK once the earth is traversed. Its mostly amber maltiness, with some austere grassy hops and maybe some pinyness. Still, that signature DFH earthy aftertaste will bite down on it hard.

Now I remember why I havent picked this one up recently. Decently-crafted but maybe its the water that provides that ultra-earthiness. Not for me.

Bottle from nearby liquor store.  Very balanced, very tasty, this is a big time beer. 
Kind of like a rich and fulfilling entree or dessert, the calorie intake says it all. Great taste, though not the kind of beer you would pound playing beach volleyball.  I will specifically hunt this out when beer shopping.

Drank from a bottle into a chalice.  

This beer pours a amber almost orange, with a nice white head that pops up, stays a while not forever.  Nice lacing for an IPA.

It smells very hoppy with a hint of citrus.

This taste is hoppy with a fruit, with a lite of bitterness at the end.  This is a very good beer.

Pour: Amber/copper, fairly large head.  Aroma:  Balance of citrus hops, caramel and syrup sweetness, bready malt.  Flavor: Suprisingly balanced for an imperial IPA, hops provide mostly bitterness and aftertaste, some citrus.  Sweet malts, almost tastes like a dessert, with a good beery bitterness behind it.  Finish is hoppy, bitter.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2009 From Full Throttle Bottles in Seattle, WA.  Starting with an inviting colour of clear, rich copper - almost orange it was, underneath a frothy white two-fingered head.  An appealing aroma of hop and malt blend pleased the nose, and shit howdy, did this ever taste good!  Nice bite from the hops followed with a slightly sweet finish from the malt.  Why cant all, or at least most beers taste as good as this?  Now to kick myself for only buying one.

Bottle, poured into a snifter. This beer really sparked my interest in craft beer. To this day it remains one of my all time favorites. Pours a beautiful amber color, darker than most DIPAs. Leaves some lacing on the glass. All the big citrusy notes you would expect from a beer that is this hopped up but the hops are balanced by a great malt undertone and a smooth creamy mouthfeel. Not nearly as brisk as most others in this style. Very drinkable considering the IBUs and the ABV. Absolutely fantastic. Anyone who calls themselves a beer lover must try this beer. It turned me on to IPAs. Go out and buy it now. Seriously, stop reading my review and go get in your car.

Two sips in, and this is infinitely better than the 60 Minute IPA.  Dogfish, you have redeemed yourself!

Pours a hazy amber with a bit less than a finger of off-white head.  Smells sweetly of vanilla cake, toffee, and banana - almost like a hefe.  Taste is not bitter, considering the 90 IBUs.  Malt dominates the palate and the citrusy hops barely break through.  

If I were an Imperial IPA purist, I would say that this beer was too smooth for the style, but instead, Ill say its a great beer!

Fully hazy orange-amber, under thick yellow-creamy head. Sweet & hoppy, cakey malts, waffles syrup, bit of banana ester. Sweet, slightly roasted, syrupy malts, ananas & banana esters, under the all-American-muscle C-hops. Bit of lytchee/rosewater. Very thick MF, syrupy, slick, but ending very balanced, all flavours converging. Nice twist - as this sample was apparently not the usual 90minutes. The original brought me probably to C-hops forever...  Big thanks to CK!

Poured amber. Nose is HOPS! Pine and citrus melded with a sweet caramel nose. Flavor is a little off balanced bitter citrus and pine hops, some sugar, and toasted grains. Very nice IIPA that hides most of the booze.

On tap. 
Pours dark amber with a white head good lacing. Light caramel and honey on the nose. Herbal hop and a sweet malt. A great ipa.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2009 12 ounce bottle.  Pours amber with a slightly fluffy head.  I see this as pretty much the standard as far as IPAs go- sweet with caramel and fruit, perfect amount of bitterness from the hops, and easy to find.  Sometimes I feel like a hoppier IPA, but this one is good for any time.  Light aftertaste.  Perfectly balanced, and so easy to drink for an imperial IPA.

Pours clear copper with a two finger size off-white head.  Good retention and sticks to the glass as it recedes.  A mix of coffee and floral bitterness with caramel malty sweetness on the nose.  Interesting flavor that starts off almost like an imperial stout with coffee maltiness, followed by the hops and finishing with mild alcohol sweetness.  Smooth medium body with moderate carbonation.  I prefer a longer lasting bitterness in my IIPAs, this one kinda drops off in the middle.  Good beer, however.

One of the better 2x IPAs (technically imperial) out there.  Dont listen to anyone who says this beer has little or no head and tastes like alcohol-  the flavors in this beer are abundant- and it pours nicely if you know how to pour an imperial style beer-  Probably my favorite DFH "production" beer-
Pours a dark orange with no head. Aroma is piney hops, citrus & alcohol. Taste is strong of alcohol, hops, & bitter finish. Taste is dominated by alcohol with a little grass.

bottle 09
Poured a golden copper color with alot of carbonation. Smells sweet with plenty of hops. taste really good, get the sweetness up front and then the hops finish it off. Overall a great beer for anyone who appreciates hops.

12 oz bottle.  A different imperail IPA.  Poured a nice opaque orange/copper color with a fluffy head.   Nose is nicely floral, but mild.  I like the nose of the Pliny the Elder so much better.  Initial taste was surprisingly sweet and floral for an IPA.  No brutalness, like offered by many.  Finished nice and long with a thick, but not heavy maltiness and hoppiness balance.  I think this one will be a favorite for some time.

i am probably one of the few beer drinkers that does not like this beer. i LOVE IPAS and too me this does not reflect a great IPA, the malts are too dominant and the hops are too soft. i love Imperial (double) IPAS as well and expect a fair amount of malts and alcohol but this one is too one sided, i love DOGFISH HEAD but i can not stand this one.

Im not a huge IPA fan, but this one is my hands-down favorite of the IPAs.  Pours a golden-orange-copper color with a great head and nice lacing.  Hoppy aroma with hints of coffee and caramel.  Mouth taste is initially sweet with a bitter, hoppy finish.  Clean finish with little aftertaste.

bottle, pours deep gold/copper with a medium fluffy white head.  Strong hop aroma, some grapefruit and cascade noticable.  Sweet malty body, some carmel notes and a wallop of hop bitterness in the finish.  Ends dry with a citrus rind bitterness in the back of the mouth.  Solid.

Bottle, about 1 year old. 
Orange/copper color with a low, fine head. Spicy, piney hops, big malt (chocolate and caramel) background in the aroma. Very fruity, from lemons to cherries to raisins. Flavor includes a bit of smoke, wood, chocolate, alcohol heat, and something vinous. Very complex, with a very bitter finish. Great, though the hop aroma is way down compared to a fresh one.  This one should be consumed right away for sure!

Im not normally an IPA drinker but this is one I could actually enjoy a bit.  Its normally the overwhelming hop bitterness that turns me off, but this IPA had all of the wonderful hop and citrus flavors without knocking me over from the bitterness. Not bad.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2011 THIS IS ONE OF MY FAVORITE BEERS ,ITS CLOUDY GOLDEN IN COLOR WITH LITTLE HEAD, SMELLS OF DELICIOUS GRAPEFRUIT AND HOPS, TASTES OF PERFECT SWEET BITTERNESS , INCREDIBLY ENJOYABLE AT 9% ALC CONTENT IT GOES DOWN AMAZINGLY SMOOTH . IF THIS CAME IN 99 CENT 22 OZ BOTTLES THE WORLD WOULD BE HOOKED! AND DRUNK!!

Gorgeous orangey-brown color, small lacy head.  Deep, sweet malt aroma is cut by mild yet distinct hop aroma.  Flavor is similar; strong malt flavors - sweet and caramel, but with a distinctive flavor of coffee and brandy - with good hop bitterness and very complex character. Finish of raspberries. Excellent.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2009 Bottle 355ml from crackedkettle.com. Celebrating my 1000th rating. A flawless, deeply pleasant Imperial IPA. All the great components of the style showing up in both nose and taste; both having also interesting hints of quinces and coffee (the latter being unusual for the style)  but really integrating well. Strong bitterness. Incredibly enjoyable. Quite a lot of coffee showing up in the finish. Wonderful!

Bottle. This poured a nice copper color with golden yellow hues. Very, very thin white head (could have been my pour), with light lace. The aroma is beautiful. Strong notes of caramel, nuts, sweet malt and fruit. The taste is about the same but a great hop bitterness is present. The mouthfeel is a bit resiny with good body, a little chewy. Very nice finish, the hop bitterness follows through to the end and all the way down. There is slight alcohol character in the finish, that lets you know it is a 9%er. Overall a great Imperial IPA, that orders to be drank again and again.

Was never a big fan of the IPAs as many of them load up on the hops which just overpowers everything else.  This beer however has managed to maintain a really nice balance of hops and malts that just taste great.  The bitterness is not overwhelming and the finish is very clean.

"The word yummy gets tossed around a lot these days, and I truly have no clue where Im going with this statement except to say this beer is yummy. Burnt orange, clear body with a thick off white floating on to. Impressive lacing and retention for a beer of 9%. Awesome hopy aroma, sweet candy peaches, tons of citrus, leathery malts. Flavour is also awesome nice and malty, leather, toasted wood, and the hops are insane giving a almost un rivaled bitterness. Not a single trace of alcohol making this relatively easy to drink, the carbonation gives the mouth feel a very nice spice. So much sweet peach flavour, pine, citrus, this has it all. The intense bitterness lingers for a long time in the back of your throat. I could drink these all day if I wasnt afraid of ending up in a alcohol induced coma that is."

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2010 Bottle from Bottleworks.  Great grapefruit hops aroma.  Pours a clear orange with light white head.  Tastes very sweet with citrus and honey, with only slight bitterness.  A bit syrupy, but a clean finish.

(NOTE: I have had this on tap out on a randall at the DFH brewpub and this WAS one of the best IIPAs had, so bottles dont do it justice. Well, that plus the randall is amazing!)

Finally tried one of these in bottle a few weeks ago.  Probably the first Imperial I can remember, and it was a great one.  Maybe a little strong, but i can see why the ratings are so high.  Will try again for sure.

Bottle. Poured with an average-sized, white head and a clear body, with nice lacing. Nice, golden-copper color. The aroma hits you like a ton of bricks - light malt and yeast, heavy hops, and quite heavy on the alcohol... but in a good way. Light melon aroma as well. Great on the palate: medium body, average carbonation, with a bitter finish. As for the flavor, this beer is more alive than most Ive tried. Lightly sweet, quite bitter, but not at all overpowering, and while you can taste the alcohol, you wouldnt necessarily guess that its a 9% ABV. Theres so much going on in this beer its hard to put it in words. Ive never been a huge IPA fan but this was quite the experience.
citrus and floral aromas, beautiful orange/amber color, fantastic flavor with a great combo of american style IPA with european undertones.  wonderful.

Great beer, that I drink quite often. Pours dark amber, with about a finger width head. Very hoppy, with decent malty flavor. Better served warm, or enjoyed over a long period of time, as it warms it gets better.

Bottle. Initial aroma was hoppy raspberrys.
Interesting and complex for an IPA. Pour was amber and head was a bit weak. At first taste it seemed a little boozy but was followed by another shortly thereafter. a little on the sweet side but drinkable for sure.

Bottle bought about a year ago.
Pours hazy amber. 
Hopps, butter and malty aroma.
Tastes malty with candy hops, there are hardly any citrus hops left.

I think it is a great quality mark for an IIPA that it still is a interesting even when the fresh hops are gone.
Pours amber with a nice thin head.  Citrus notes and a very smooth mouth feel.  Taste of grapefruit and evergreen. Very balanced considering the alcohol level.  Very drinkable.
Not my personal favorite. Taste is very blunt and stays in your mouth even after. Bitter yet sweet. Too sweet for me. Kind of a chocolaty taste.
Freshy hoppy aroma, amber hue in the glass, tastes just like it smells... delicious!

Bottle. Pours a clear golden-amber with a large off-white head. Aroma of pine, citrus, and sweet fruit...pineapple?  Flavor ia very rich. Nice  and citrusy; with a great sweet backside that really evens out the flavor. Great IIPA!  Definitely my favorite east coast hoppy ale.

Hands down the best IPA Ive ever had. Until I try the 120 minute IPA aged for like 2 or 3 years (which Im in the process of doing right now) this one is King. Has an awesome aroma and an incredible drinkable flavor. Highly recommend.

Bottle. One year old bottle. Still very good. Not many IPA:s can say that. The large ammount of barley and malts makes this beer into a round hoppy barley wine after a year in the cellar. Will try this one fresh soon.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2009 Almost an entire bottle at Montreal Mondial de la biere.  Impressive deliciously knocking beer, hop in many dimensions of the taste, caramelised-malt sweetness.  Hop-head world-wide wonder, second best DIPA I had.  I could drink only that beer and forget all the others!  And to say I had a (really) bad opinion about that boring Delaware State before knowing this brewer.  But theres no way Im going back there; export those beers!
UPDATED: JUL 1, 2009 Bottle. Great beer, IPA that pairs well with anything and is delicious for this high of an abv.

Bottle. A nice dark coppery red and a thin white head. Aroma is rich with resin, dark honey and plum. Rich caramel malty flavor is overlaid by citrusy, piney hops and finishes into a pleasant piney bitterness. Smooth and finely carbonated. Really more like a barleywine than an IIPA, given the high ABV, but its exquisitely balanced and packed to the brim with wonderful flavor. Its a classic for a reason.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden with a thick, fluffy off-white head. Nice lacing. Strong, sweet and spicy hop aroma with malt. As it warms, it becomes more heavy on the sweet malts; cloying. Flavour is malts with a candy-like sweetness. Hops roaming around somewhere in the background, but not very outspoken. Has some similarities with a Belgian strong ale; a blend of alcohol, brandy and plums. But the sweet malts reminds me more of a overly sweet brown ale. Finish is grassy, and quite sweet and malty. Cloying. Develops some liquorice notes as it warms. Faint spicy notes lingering. Not very bitter; a medium bitterness lingering. Soft palate. Interesting, but too cloying for the style and could do with more hops. 03-06-09.

Pours a surprisngly clear rich copper color, with a thick, pillowy white head, with OK lacing, but nothing special. Aroma is all N American hops, with the classic grapefruitiness of Cascade, add to that pine resin, spruce boughs, crystal malt, and fresh cedar. Palate starts surprisngly sweet, then ends up quite sour in the finish, which is a sensation I thoroughly enjoy. Pine, grapefruit, malt, lemon, apples, with surprisingly restrained hops, although you get all of the character. No booziness or alcohol, very, very well done. My favorite example of my favorite style.

Pours a beautiful copper orange color with a thick creamy white head.  Beautiful aroma of pine, flowers and tropical fruits.  Flavor is surprisingly sweet up front, with citrus and honey notes.  But plenty of grassy, pine and grapefruit hops grab your tongue and dont let you forget this is a big IPA. Mouthfeel is medium and very smooth, but just slightly sticky.  Even at 9% ABV, the alcohol is almost unnoticeable.

Even if you took away much of the hops, this could stand alone as a good beer.  Add the big hops, and its a great one.

On draft at Sugar Maple.  Pours amber-orange with bright white, two-finger head that fades to a film.  Aroma of pineapple, pine, some floral notes.  I could sit and smell this for quite some time.  Flavor is sweet and stick upfront and very resinous.  There is a small amount of citrus and also a little malt in the background.  Finishes fairly dry with a considerable dose of hop bitterness and alcoholic.  More alcoholic tasting than I remember, but still one of the best overall DIPAs around.

Cant believe I havent rated this yet, so here goes.  Pours a nice amber orange with thick white head.  Very pleasant citrus hop aroma, pine, grass, and a decent balance of malts.  Flavor is not what I was expecting, but in a good way.  A lot of DIPAs have a similar flavor, this one does not.  This is a readily available (for me), very solid DIPA that is a change from the norm.  Awesome job DFH.
On Cask... golden amber color, great citrus and hop aroma... I have had it in a bottle and on tap but on Cask was the best by far... very smooth hop flavor well balanced with citrus and sweets...
On tap. Golden to amber in color with.  Great aroma of citrusy hops and some malts. Very crisp . Pleasant hops flavored well balanced by sweetness of malt. Complex, well balanced, perfect beer.
UPDATED: JUN 8, 2009 12 oz bottle.  Very hoppy and very complex; lots of sweet caramel and raisin and almost wine-like flavors coming through.  My first good beer and still a top-line choice.
Poured amber from the bottle with a small head. Strong hoppy aroma. Sweet citrus taste, with moderate, but not extreme, bitterness.

12 oz bottle served in a clear pint glass.  I am not an IPA fan, but this was an excellent beer. The nose is hops and citrus.  The taste was similar, but the hops were toned down a bit from the 60 minute IPA to make this beer pretty enjoyable.

Good head and carbonation in a clear copper coloured IPA.Aroma citrus and dark fruits like prune plum,alcohol note of cognac liccorice malty nose strong.Flavour caramel maltiness citric bitter raisin plum brandy taste or cognac,the 9% alcohol is perfect strong tastes yet a lovely mellow IPA.Sweetness on the palat good finish alround good flavour stays with you.

This is one of my go to beers.  When I go to the local beer and wine store to find a satisfying brew and I see this glorious four pack illuminated in front of me I know all is well. 
 
It is a hop explosion but it has a lot more going on, the after taste is a tad sweet; it is a good counter taste for the bitterness from the hops.

It is a solid beer at a decent price point and the fact that it comes in a four pack is good news for craft brew junkies who are breaking the bank exploring what is out there.
Cant add much that hasnt been said.  Amazing hop experience in a bottle!  Would benefit from just a slight bit more malt and perhaps some spicyness.  Phenomenal anyway!
The best imperial ipa ever. This beer should be in the hall of fame...thanks Sam for blessing us with this 12 0unce wonder...
A nearly perfect IPA. It smelt incredible, and the flavor was almost just as good. Maybe a little too bitter? Thats about all I can find to say thats bad about it.

I remember tying this and not liking it, I remember it being overly bitter, with a strange flavor.  Tasting it this time, on tap, it was great.  Deceivingly light and clear light copper/amber with a thin cream-colored head and nice lacing.  Nice aroma of floral hops, lightly herbal, hint of sweetness.  Fairly thick, slightly creamy mouthfeel, mild carbonation.  Quick bitter citrus bite on the front of the tongue.  Quickly followed by a strong floral hop taste, with a little citrus, a hint of caramal and bready sweetness.  Very very hoppy, just bitter enough to wake up the tongue, but the hop flavor easily overpowers the bitterness.  Hoppy, resiny, lasting finish.

Pours a clear golden amber with a small head that quickly fades to some lacing.  Pleasant grapefruity and lightly resinous aroma with some maltiness.  Moderate carbonation.  Flavor: a burst of tartness is quickly followed by grapefruit with an underlying malty sweetness and notes of dark fruit.  This leads into a long finish of citrus peel and bitter herbal notes.  Rich but crisp, complex and layered but well-integrated, this is an exquisitely balanced beer and probably my favorite IPA to date.

Creamy expansive caramel-raisiny goodness. Superficially like a richer DFH 60, Brandy-like tones of powerful fruit, aroma and taste buzzing with hops. I pour a DFH-60 as a reference, the 60 is a bit of a mess (I think the shipment got light struck, it has a petrol/match-head flavor problem) Oh well.. this 90 has an almost vanilla-cake quality in there... describe hops as citric. After-aroma of barley. Alcohol not too present in nose but very warming Bottle from Premier.

13 bucks for a 4pack!!!! SO WHAT, this my friends is arguably hands down the best (readily available in most areas) IPA in America! this IPA is simply PACKED with hops and really opens up the nasal path quick! this one hits you hard and tastes extreme hops and leaves you wanting more and searching for a better IPA in america! is there one???
A very nice color and pour.  The head is short lasting but the taste is what makes this IPA.  Excellent overall.  Expensive, but worth it.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2010 pours amber with a head that fades quickly.  smells hoppy and citrusy. tastes is huge hop start and a slight malt finish.  re rated and i didnt really like it as much as the first time.  i actually rated it last in a blind taste test with several other IPAs

Burnt amber clear pour from a bottle. Balanced malt and floral hoppy aroma. Small off white head low carbonation and good lacing. Full on the palate with citrus & floral taste. Long balanced finish. Great!

Bottle. Half inch of white foamy head atop a hazy amber body. Aroma is sweet caramel, grapefruit, crisp citrus, slightly vanilla, and fruity sweet alcoholic finish. Flavor was sweet caramel, tauntingly chocolate, slightly toffee, and slightly bitter coffee, wonderfully fresh grapefruit and pine acidity. I found this to actually not be that bitter since the malt was so strongly counterbalanced. All the same wonderful beer.

This is quite a tasty beverage.  It poured a medium orange amber color with a light caramel head.  There wasnt really too much of a distinct aroma to me, more of a general IPA smell, pretty hoppy - not the citrus that I am accustomed to however.  It has a great mouthfeel, almost what I would equate to drinking a glass of milk.  It tasted quite good, but with no outstanding flavors.  Overall a pretty good beer.

Sample @ Bock&Rock.Aroma was all hops.Copper color with a good white head.Very bitter flavor dominated by the hops the citrus flavor does come through nicely though with the slightest sweet hints.Good beer,very good.
This is by far my favorite IPA. Nice flowery hops in the nose. Nice copper color. Woodsey character: this would be great sitting by a campfire.

Pours deep amber with a thick white head. Aroma is dominated by cascade.  The flavour is very full and bold. Very hoppy and very bitter. This is a great IPA. It is soo well balanced you would never guess that it was 9%. It has a smooth creamy mouth feel a real pleasure to drink.

12 oz. Malty barley, floral hoppy nose. Orange colored with abrupt off-white/tan head dying into a foam ring. Mid-heavy sweet, medium bitter. Medium body, thin feel, light carbonation. Initially sweet into med-long finish. Strong maltiness, hint of honey. Prominent but not overpowering hop taste balanced well by sweet malt. Better than the average Imperial IPA.
Bold and malty with almost too much hop. Nice nose and flavor. The only down fall to it is that it is a pallet killer. Reserve this one for the end of the session.

Appearance: Pours an amber gold. Lets about 60% light through. A picture perfect fluffy offwhite head sits atop.

Aroma:  Hop notes including fragrances of lemon, orange, pineapple, earth, grass, and pine. Sugary malts are also in the nose as well.

Taste:  Starts off with a sweet and bitter, piney mouthful. Then I get a layer of bitter hopping and sticky sweetness. I also found a very small touch of dry buiscuty malts as well after a closer examination.

Mouthfeel: Sticky, thick, and creamy.

Overall:  A fantastic Double IPA with awesome aroma, and a flavor that is very unique to the style. I think I could pick out 90 Minute easily in a blind taste test.
Bière aux arômes et saveurs de bois et légèerement de prunes. On retrouve également des notes de malt et de houblon bien balancés et tout ça avec une bonne dose dalcool.

12 oz bottle purchased at Total Wine and more, Jacksonville, Fl.
 Pours golden with a medium white head.
  Very nice hoppy aroma.  Great hop flavor with a bit of malt flavor to balance it.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 A-pours a deep golden copper with a nice inch plus frothy head..plenty of lacing once the head settles.

S-pine hops, grapefruit,resin citrus..

T-what a great taste on this one, bitter pine hops, caramel malt backround..

O-no complaints with Dogfishs ipa dipas are on the money..wish I had another one..
(bottle). Pours a copper color. Medium off white head. Hoppy citrus aroma. Strong hop and alcohol taste. Medium body. Smooth finish. Moderate carbonation.

12oz bottle. Pours translucent dark ruby orange with a medium off-white head. Aroma of sweet malts and fresh hops. A strong citrus and pine hop presence on the tongue is balanced by sweet caramel malt and dark fruits. Maybe a tad too sweet. Medium-bodied and smooth with a pleasantly dry, bitter finish. Dangerously drinkable for the style. Fantastic.

First beer from dogfish head. dam dog this fish got some head yallz. Smells really great i was expecting more hops from this. Not that it wasnt good but a lot of malt covers the hops im used to from a dipa. Still very smooth and good definite good stuff

The hop aroma infiltrates your nostrils and temps you to taste it, though I say temps b/c its not TOO strong smelling. Equal parts deep dark red and golden yellow hues, it looks almost sexy. The taste is loaded with hops and malt, but maybe too much malt, as it covers up the hops too much, although I personally think a slightly different hops usage would be preferable. The palate is quite strong, but drops off sharply to compensate for the crazy bang in the mouth. But I think its too much and then too little, there could be a better balance still. A great slow IPA, my #2.

Was lucky enough to snag a 4 pk of the extremely limited quantity available in Alberta. Pours a coppery orange with a big white head that retains well and laces to the glass well. Aroma is initially extremely hoppy, tonnes of pine and citrus on the noes. Then as it warms some sweet malt comes through. Really cool pine, resin, melon, honey, caramel nose. Sweet malt dominates the palate... weird, not what I expected. Biscuit, honey, dandelion, resin, bitter chocolate, melon, pine, raisin on the palate. Nice mouth feel. Honestly, this wasnt what I was expecting. Its drinkable, but I was expecting more hops. Flavor was nice, good complexity, but I wanted more out of this beer.

Bottle.  Poured a clear, orange-yellow color with a small white head and some lacing.  The aroma has a very hoppy aroma with citrus and floral scents.  The beer had a medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, and a bitter finish.  The flavor was a very hoppy blend of citrus (grapefruit) and floral.  Overall this was a really hoppy beer and I liked it.  This is a great beer to drink for the flavor of it.

Bottle - Dark honey color.  Medium sized white head.  Ok lacing.  Very nice woodsy aroma.  Hoppy, but not as much as I would have expected.  Sweet, a little too much alcohol flavor.  Good mouthfeel.  Overall a little dissappointed.  Keep hearing how great this beer is, but come on, the Best IPA in America.  Lets be real.  I thought the hoppiness was covered up by the sweet fruit flavor.  Both Bells Hopslam and Stone Ruination are much hoppier Imperial IPAs.
Too sweet, too malty, and not enough bitter hops to balance it out. It drinks well, has a nice mouthfeel with a well crafted medium body, and pleasant aroma of dark fruits and hops.
Citrus and malt aroma, hoppy! Deelish imperial IPA, good balance between strong malt and hops flavors. Pours a nice golden/orange.

12oz bottle poured into a snifter, an orangey amber color with a small off white head. Aroma is of dried fruit (apricot) with a lot of malt sweetness and a tiny amount of citrusy hops. The flavor is not as sweet as the nose would make one think, a little alcohol peaks through and then florally hop. This is not the style of IIPA that I enjoy, the flavor is too caramel and dried fruit, the malt is not balanced by the hops enough. I see what Dogfish Head was attempting to do though and I think they did it well, just not my cup of tea.

Pours deep golden yellow with a generous, lovely head. Nose is all floral hops, hints of grapefruit and other sweeter fruits. Flavor is well-balanced for something this hoppy, less bitter than others in the style. Big hop flavor balanced against the malts and fruits to make it an enjoyable IPA, at least for someone like me who is not a huge fan of the style. Lingering bitterness on the finish has roasted coffee notes--or maybe thats just me.

Pours a clear orangey/gold color  with off white head. Aroma of hops obviously, but caramel malt and slight citrus really makes it enjoyable.  Caramel malts and spice up front makes way to the hop explosion in the finish.  Very sticky, but Im really digging this one. Another winner from Dogfish Head.

On tap at Papago.  Pours a shiny amber color with a trim off-white head.  Smells of pine, caramel, and grapefruit.  Tastes of each with an added helping of salt - particularly at the back of the palate.  Malty for its apearance.  Dense and balanced.  A fine DIPA.

12 fl oz brown bottle. Orange/deep gold colour. Large white head, sticky lace. Strong west coast grapefruit resiny hop scent, light alcohol. Flavour is floral and citrusy - notes of orange and grapefruit, honeyish  sweetness. Finishes with a nice grapefruity/leafy hop dose that lingers, also some sharp alcohol. Medium body, carbonation is mild. Maltier than I was expecting, very drinkable.

smells floral and hoppy, poured it and i knew what i was in for. tastes like raisins, is complex but not what i was looking for, just not enough hops to balance out the rotten raisin flavor. i could see how people would be crazy for this, its just way too sweet and needs more hops not balanced at all, ata least for me. it seems to be more of a barleywine and at that is a very good ale, but when i get a double ipa i am looking for hops and this ale just gives me raisins and booze. if this was a barleywine i would give it a higher mark. it is very complex which ill give folks credit for but is just a barleywine.
Great beer! Good balance of hops and malt, Notes of citrus are my favorite of any DIPA.

Hazy amber with a fast disappearing white head. Strong hoppy aroma, grassy and fruity, boozy, caramel. Full bodied, sweet but quite hard to swallow. More balanced than other hop bombs has a nice not that bitter end.

Bottle. Hazy caramel appearance, pours a  thin head that disappears quickly. A great balance between bitter hops and sweet malts that are almost too sweet. A must drink for any IPA/Double IPA lover. For casual beer drinking, i like the 60 minute better, but if your looking to concentrate 
on your brew, clearly the better of the two. overall-A+

Bottle. Amber colored with a small lively off white head. Aromas of hops, orange, pineapple, sugared grapefruit, flowers, grain and caramel. Flavour of vanilla, caramel, alcohol, corn flakes, sweet malts, honey, orange and parmesan cheese. Lovely complex interpretation of this style.

Bottle. Hazy orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma: Mostly sweet and malty actually, notes of tosted bread, spicy hops, caramel, toffee, rosted sesam seeds. Taste: Also very malty, but with a bitter finish. Notes of spicy hops, citrus, caramel, roasted sesam seeds, nuts, alcohol. A bit too sticky and alcoholic for my liking. Full bodied. Very malt dominated for a Double IPA. Maybe this bottle was a bit old?

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2009 Re-Rate... Bottle from Bevmo.. Bottled on 4/03/09...Pours copper with fluffy white head..  Sweet malt with a slight hop nose...Very malty with some slight citrus and raisins notes..Way to easy to drink @ 9%.

12oz bottle. It has been a week of some very BIG IIPAs. This one is certainly great but very different than many in its style. Pours a dark brown/reddish. As complex a nose as Ive ever experienced in this style. Candied fruit, big malt and piney hop combo. Long and slightly sweet, rich flavor that lingers pleasantly. Very good.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Dark-red copper pour with tiny white head. Aroma is predominantly sweet, candy, pineapple, piney hops, bready malt. Full mouthfeel with tastes of pine, raisins, caramel, bready malt and various spices. Very oily palate, a bit of warming alcohol. Malty and sweet - where is that hops? Is my bottle too old perhaps?

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2009 Pint, approximately 40deg.
Excellent overall.  Honey like sweetness followed by citrus overtones, malt, and then the classic IIPA bitterness.

If it was cheaper it would be my house beer.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine (bottled January 26, 2009).  Pours orange; hard to distinguish in appearance from an IPA.  Thin white head on top.  Floral hop aroma with a malty sweetness.  Piney hop flavor with a well balanced caramel malt sweetness.  Excellent balance of hop bitterness and stickiness in the mouthfeel.  Alcohol is not noticable at all.  Certainly one of the best DIPAs out there.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2009 Bought at a local store in a bottle.  The hops are great, malty as well. I didnt like at first, but as it sat and warmed up I couldnt put it down.  Mixed emotion, I will have to rerate when I try more IPAs

One of the best IIPAs on the market, for sure. I tried one out of a Randall recently at the brewpub in Rehoboth. Attempted several times to switch beers, but kept coming back. The stuff is like crack (I assume). If I could choose my own death, it would be by drowning in a vat of DFH 90-Minute.

I never get tired of my experience with Dogfish Head 90 Minute!  
The aroma of hops leaps up your nose and says "Drink me!"  
Its a beautiful amber IPA with a wonderful hopped malty, carmely, raisiny, taste!  It reminds me a little of a good single malt scotch Aberlour.
This beer looks and tastes the best in a snifter.  It looks beautiful on the sides of the glass.
Considering that this beer is 9% alcohol, I am also pleased to say there isnt a medicine after taste.
Recently I had it on tap and can say it maintained its quality and had even a better head!
Whats not to like about this beer?  Great hop aromas and flavors.  Nice malt balance.  Best of all its year round.

Bottle. An amber coloured pour with a light head. Hoppy aroma backed up with plenty of malt. Hint of caramel and some fruit, sweet too. Had this beer many times Stateside. This really is my kind of beer, bloody superb!

For a person who has never tried an imperial/double ipa...  common sense would suggest that 90 min would be hoppier than the 60 min... this is definitely not the case!!! the 90 min is malty.  I had this beer after 3 other traditional ipas during an ipa sampling with my brother in-law.  If you want hopps this is not the beer for you.  However, it is a very good malty beer that warms you up.  a definite must try on a cold winter day.
Everyone else has already said what needs to be said about this near perfect beer.  I cracked one open to welcome the first great day of Spring in Dayton, OH.  What a wonderful world :-)

12 oz   Had this many times living in fl. 4 packs and on tap at mellow mushroom. Pours dark amber with medium head. aroma is full of floral and citrus hops. this is a full bodied work of art.  suprising finishes with perfect mix of sweet malt and bitterness. I think it lives up to its hype. runs a close race with pliny the elder  east vs west.......

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a medium amber color with 1-finger off-white head that lingers for a bit and masks the aroma initially.  Good lacing on the glass.  Aroma is fruity hops, a bit of citrus fruit similar to a witbier, perhaps raisins, very faint hint of pine.  Mouthfeel is very thick like a stout, a bit creamy.  Flavor begins with fruity hops, smoke, pine, caramel malted barley.  Trails off with building bitterness of hops, alcohol, pine, and a faint hint of citrus hops.  Definitely a complex shifting of flavors in the aftertaste.  My new favorite IPA!

Based on the hype, I was actually a little disappointed here. The apperance in particular is top notch and the aroma is also superb. Has a very nice chewy mouthfeel. Its the taste that lets me down a little bit. I think perhaps a different combo of hops might have served better here. I prefer the Weyenbacher Double Simcoe to this really. But I wont complain, just probably wont seek it out again for the price.
This is simply one of the best beers in the world.  Citrus and grassy hops are the stars.  Extremely well balanced and totally sexy.  A must try.

Just finished the 35,5cl Bottle. Pours a nice amber with small head. Hoppy nose with citric fruits and grass.Flavor balances well the sweet malts and bitter hops. Lasting aftertaste and nice bitter finish.

Honestly... I continue to think.. year in and year out that this is one of the best beers I have ever tasted... I even limit myself to getting a pint only now and then... so that I dont get used to it... Whenever I am at the British Beer Company in Pembroke... I always ask for one (most of the time they have it)...  Great Beer... great everything about it... The Prefect Imperial IPA!

3yr old, thanks to Holdenn.  Hazy orange with medium white head.  Slight sherry oxidation and caramel.  Vegetable, caramel flavor, slight hops, alc, oxidation.  Medium body, light carbonation.  Oxidized, meh. Love this beer fresh, actually kind of surprised Ive never rated it before.  Will have to get a bottle soon.

12 oz. bottle.  I have had this many times over the years and just realized that I had not entered a rating.  Pours clear amber in color with a medium sized creamy off white head.  The aroma has a nice dose of hops (citrus, grapefruit, tropical fruit) and sweet malts.  The flavor is more malt forward than many DIPAs, but does have a hop presence.  The sweet malts are up front with grapefruit and citrus hops leading the way to a nice bitterness in the finish.  Medium/full bodied.

Orange amber in color with a small off white head. It has a surprisingly sweet aroma of orange, pineapple, and alcohol. Sweet flavor as well with candied fruit, brown sugar, and then the bitter hops in the finish. A little over the top for me, but still a unique Double IPA.

On tap at Coopers IPA Fest.  Pours clear amber with a nice lingering off-white head.  Funky, earthy hop aroma with a hint of alcohol.  Surprisingly stouty flavor profile- lots of roasty malts complement the earthy pine hops nicely.  Mouthfeel is chewy with a roasty pine hop finish.

12oz bottle. Aroma of Grapenuts cereal, caramel and just a faint hint of floral/citrus hops. It really has a smell of doing a mash, like popping off the lid of your mash tun after about an hour of mashing. Orange/amber with a small off white head and a tiny bit of lacing. Very nice sweet flavor cut with a bitterness that just lingers in the background. Slightly thick with average carbonation and a bitter finish. I homebrew and this beer really tastes like a cross between a finished beer and a sweet fresh wort. I really have never tasted any beer or IPA like it. Unique and delicious, try it as soon as you can.

this beer introduced me to imperials and how great they are.. pours a nice yellowish color.. aroma pinapple, grapefruit... taste is out of this world for being a big beer is is so smooth a love this beer
Caramelly sweet hoppy nose,  sweet taste and a hoppy finnish. A bit too sweet for me and the bitterness is not too refreshing. I prefer the 60 min ipa by a long shot.
Smooth hop flavor sets this one apart from the usual intense bitterness of imperial ipas. (im looking at you ruination) Strong like an imperial should be and does just about everything right.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy light orange with a small, white head.  Nice hop aromas abound.  Mostly orange, but there is some boozy fruit from the malt as well.  Medium-low carbonation with a rich, full bodied mouthfeel.  Citrus and boozy fruit on the palate.  Surprisingly sweet but it does balance out the hops.  The malt is very sweet with hints of almost a cross between honey and a simple syrup.  As the beer warms, the alcohol does begin to creep out a bit.  The finish is long with a lasting bitterness.  One is probably enough for an evening.  Overall a very good IIPA.

pours a great copper/pink with thin white head that disappears fast. aroma is floral and hoppy with a sweetness coming through. drinks almost gritty from the hops. nice malt notes come through with a little alcohol burn on the finish. great beer

i found it far too sweet but it did have a unique taste. ill have to come back to this one some time and try it again. id love to sample it at the brewery in rehoboth. however, as it stands, i like the 60 minute much better.

Pours from a bottle provided to me at a family function. I have a cousin with good taste.  The pour is copper with a decent head.  The aroma is hoppy and sweet.  The taste is about the same.  It was more like a strong ale with hops.  Smooth and mild.  I am not an IPA fan but this is one I could drink often.

[Bottle, 2 months old at time of consumption] Pours clear amber with a medium-small off-white head that dies quickly. Aroma is nice and big with citrusy hops and a decent amount of caramel malt--a little sweeter than I usually like my IIPAs, but still very nice. The taste is initially sweet, the hops and malt combine to form an almost nutty taste that I often find in barley wines. A little alcohol becomes detectable as it warms, as do some notes of lime. There is certainly a good deal of hop influence, but it is not as bitter as I had expected, with the malt taking center stage much of the time. Despite this, it actually does work for it, and is enjoyable. Pretty good mouthfeel, quite smooth, and has a long, dry finish. Not the kind of IIPA that I am usually crazy about, with the malt so forward, but it turned out pretty well despite that. A very solid, albeit not spectacular beer.

My gateway beer, and one time my favorite beer ever.  A wonderful intro to the world of big beers, but one that eventually doesnt hold up to the best.  Unfortunately this beer can be very temperamental, with a SEVERE drop off after 3-6 months.  Too much malt for my tastes, and that DFH graininess that can be hit or miss.

On draft it tends to be much better (probably because it is much fresher)

I brought this bottle to DuffmanSW beer tasting event with mspindler, hophead22, and NickTheEdler. Bronze orange color with no head. Floral notes. Very balanced for an imperial IPA. Dogfish head living up to their reputation.
UPDATED: AUG 20, 2013 big citrus flowery aroma.  but too much sugary syrup sweetness.   sticky.   okay.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2010 Pours a mostly clear copper with a small, frothy white head that leaves super thick lacing. The aroma is big on grapefruit and pineapple, with citrus, woodiness, and floral hops. Sort of an Amarillo aroma, with a lot of citrus behind it. The flavor is very well balanced. A very sweet start, with a light but rich maltiness that fades into more and more citrus, with a slightly warm bitter finish. Full bodied with light but lively carbonation. Well done.

Appearance: Pours an impressive clear medium burnt orange color with a diminutive tan-colored head.  Right off the bat I can tell you there is not as much head as I normally like to see on an Imperial IPA.  Even a forceful swirl of the glass brings minimal head to the surface. There is, however, a nice bit of lacing which at least proves theres something good going on in this bottle. 

Smell:  When I hear people say that Imperial IPAs smell like cat urine I typically scowl in skepticism.  However, I really do get that aroma in the Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA; and I mean that in the best way possible.  Along with this strong presence of pungent hops and powerful malt comes a touch of orange caramel, and oddly enough, even a faint smell of espresso beans. 

Taste:  This definitely tastes like an Imperial IPA, yet it has a heaviness that you dont normally find in its class.  Even as I taste it Im reminded of the same bitterness one might expect from the mouth feel of an espresso.  And while I do only get a faint taste of coffee, there is clearly enough hops to keep it firmly planted in IPA territory. 

Mouthfeel: There is a good amount of bitterness here.  Although, I would hope that an Imperial IPA would have a touch more luster than this seems to have.  The bitterness and flavor profile that is left behind is quite pleasurable, though.

Overall: Not as impressed as Id hoped, but Id definitely drink a shit ton of these again.  The hoppy bitterness is really pleasing and the flavor it leaves behind is quite enjoyable.  At 9% ABV, I think this is a good session beer if enjoyed 12 ounces at a time.
12 oz. bottle, light orange-red color.  An intense experience with a long finish transforming from pine to citrus.
UPDATED: NOV 7, 2009 Pours a golden amber with lasting white head. A beautifully balance of malt and big hops Big hops upfront, but finish is smooth. Has a hoppy, citrusy nose.  Great beer!
One of the best IPAs Ive experienced.  A long finish that rests on the back of your palate.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2009 Bottle 12 oz. Solid copper golden pour. Not the biggest lover of hoppy IPAs, but this beer wasnt too bad. Not as bitter as some, and fairly balanced. Bigger fan of the 60 minute, but this was still somewhat enjoyable.
Poured amber with white head. Aroma of pine and citrus. Great hop bitterness that finishes a little dry. Good stuff.

Bottle; not what I was expecting; dark clear copper pour; foamy head; typical aroma; EFG 1; lots of carbonation; nice malt flavor with a slight bitter hop taste; as it warms the alcoholic aroma and flavor really kicks in. (#58)

12 0z bottle bottle 1/23/09 ( I think)

smell of caramel, hazelnut, citrus, and a little chocolate.

head was small and dissapeared quickly.

i found this to be overly malty.  not much alcohol taste, for the percentage of alcohol... to be honest i dont find it that hoppy.  It seems to drink much like a rogue hazlenut nectar, but not quite as smooth

294 calories? good lord.. glad i dont care about that stuff...

overall a great great beer.  dogfish does some amazing and different things.

Pure amber with a thick off-white head. Aroma is floral/citrus hops with a side of hops. Yet another IPA that renews my faith in this style. Hop profile is huge but is backed up well by the malt flavor. Alcohol taste is evident and not masked as well as I would have thought. I think Stones IPA is better mainly because of its drinkability.

12 oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours a glowing dark orange color.  Little head.  Faint lacing.  Aromas are subtle.  A bit over-carbonated, but extremely well balanced flavor with a smooth malt finish.  Very nice beer.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 BOTTLE: clear copper pour, aroma of pine hops and fruit. Taste is raisin, citrus, hop, and a nice malt backing. I like the 60 minute better, but this is good.

Re-rated: this rocks.

12oz bottle at Gallos.  Copper/amber pour with a medium off-white head.  Bitter citrus hop aroma with a bready malt balance.  Citrusy hop aroma up front, followed by malty sweetness and the bitterness returns for the finish.  Good stuff.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2009 Location: I wanted to update this rating, so I picked up a 12 oz bottle from Gillys, and Im rating updating on 7/24/09


Aroma: Really nice grapefruit and pine aroma, light caramel malt in there too

Appearance: Clear amber looking color, about 1 inch of off-white head, nice lacing

Flavor: Somehow this has a nice balance, while still having a huge hoppiness to it.  Tastes as good as I had remembered.

Palate: Great mouthfeel, medium to full body, long lasting palate

Overall Impression: 
These guys know how to make an IPA, and this one is great.  One of the better IPAs out there.  This is one tasty beer, and Im glad Im updating it, but not changing the rating, because its really quite good.

Bottle. Pours a deep orange-brown with moderate tan head, leaving a pleasant lace. I recall this bottle seeming over-carbonated when it was cold, but this sensation vanished after about ten minutes of idling. Whatever . . . this stuff is awesome. Sweet malts, raisins, and citrus upon entering the palate, with its piny hop notes shining through down the throat. A bit more substantial of a mouthfeel than some IPAs, because of the remarkable balance. This beer is incredible; its definitely the best IPA Ive ever had.
Poured from 12-oz bottle. Looks great - clean copper pour with very thin head.  Taste has a bit too much raisin or fruitiness for my liking, though the hoppiness is definitely right there.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2009 Testing including Ruination, Double Simcoe, and DF 90min. Poured from 12oz bottle. Nice copper, orange color w/ light tan head.  The Aroma is of Hops, Citrus, Dried Fruit and Pine and oddly enough a light black coffee smell... Taste is very nice bitter, floral, bready, pine hops, and sweet malts. It has a nice long finish that is sweet, bitter, refreshing and very satisfying. Out of the 3, this is has my 2nd place vote. It was just a little to sweet.

Enjoyed via both draft and 12oz bottle.  Pours light copper.  Aroma is of citrusy American hops (Cascade/Centennial?).  Flavor is thoroughly hop-centric, as one would imagine.  However, a dry finish and some background malt sweetness make this extremely drinkable.  Overall, one of the best, if not the best, imperial IPAs brewed on the east coast of the U.S.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2011 Ok, so Ive finally made the choice to revisit this beer and I am very glad I did.  Im keeping my old rate just so I can see how much my opinion of this beer has changed.  The aroma was nice and full of sweet citrus fruits like mangoes, grapefruits, and oranges.  A bit piney at times, but mostly fruity with some nice bitter hops in there as well.  The flavor was much improved with it being mostly dominated by sweet mangoes and tangerines.  Simply divine!  The finish was long and heavy, bitter and dry, yet complex and very enjoyable.  My palate has really changed over the years and I now really enjoy this one.

I know Im supposed to love this beer, its a god of IPAs.  However, I dont, and I enjoy IPAs.  The aroma had faint floral notes, but nothing impressive.  The flavor seemed to be pointlessly bitter.  There is very little hop character to this beer, other than just being bitter.  Its not that I dont like IPAs, I do.  But this beer seemed to lack depth in its supposed hop glorification.  I will revisit this beer down the road and do a rerate, but at this point, their 60 minute is much better.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2009 (Original Rating) The strongest IPA Ive ever had. Incredibly strong.  In all fairness, I have decided to try this beer again as I originally tried it VERY early on in my beer education.  I mightve had a bad bottle, and since this beer is so well received, I will re-rate it.  But for the time being, I have to stick to my original rating, flawed as it might be.
RERATE: Upon 2nd tasting years later, I found this to be a very excellent beer. Still quite hoppy, but complimented well by sweet flavors and a tasty finish. What a difference time makes.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2009 Pours clear golden amber with a one inch off-white head that lingers for a long time. Strong citrus aroma with pine and mostly orange-pineapple. Pineapple taste as well is dominant with floral notes. Smooth and surprisingly not too bitter except for the finish. Has some roast characters in the finish as well that help balance the hop.

12oz bottle. Pours a see-through, burnt orange body with a small, fizzy, off-white head that dissipates quickly and remains delicately laced. Aroma is pretty straightforward, but plentiful. Lots of woody bitter hops and a plethora of caramel. The caramel malts have a "cooked" character to them in that they arent burnt, but it seems like they are on the verge of toasted. Sweet, sugary boozy backing as well. Flavor is initially a big, biscuit malt quickly infused with an almost harsh bitter citrus. Lots of that "cooked" caramel again and even a bit of licorice flavoring. Finishes very woody and dry with a touch of sugary booze warmth. Palate is medium to full and somewhat harsh, although very well balanced. Overall, a really nice DIPA with a great balance of flavors. I think a 4 is rightly deserved.
A bottle tasted at Pikkulintu. Hoppy flowery nose. Pale golden yellow slightly coppery colour. Pale head. Slightly sweet soft taste. Tasty crispy hoppiness. Lacey forming head.

Pours a deep honey amber with a 1/2 finger soapy white head. Decent lacing. Smells of strong floral hops and sweet malt. Dry hopping is pretty obvious here.
Flavor is hops up front (duh) with a pleasant malty sweetness. This is more balanced than I had expected. Medium mouthfeel that coats the tongue and finishes sweet with a teeny bitter kick. The high abv% is expertly hidden here. This would be the perfect accompaniment for a nice bloody steak. Awesome.

This beer was surprisingly sweet. It reminded me very much of Dogfishs Raison Detre. When I tried it beer for the first time I found myself savoring it so much that it went from ice cold out of the liquor store cooler to room temperature in my hand. Where that can be a killer with some beers this one took on a whole new interesting flavor, resembling the drinking of a really nice liquor neat. If one does not normally like the intense bitterness that IPAs offer, this is definitely worth a try. Not your common IPA by any means, but definitely now one of my favorites.

2006 Bottle - Pours a vibrant orange with a medium, lasting off-white head...aroma is big ass bourbon and candy malt, rich pit fruit...flavour is similar but the hops have disappeared over time, replaces with a sweet, dried fruit pungency...I love this beer fresh, its a rich hop/malt bomb...but with almost 3 years in the bottle, it has evolved into something more resembling a cloying American Strong...delicious...
Again I have to say I am not an IPA fan.  That being said 90 min has good fruit forward flavor with aromas of malted hops.  A little orange or lemon on the finish.

Fantastic beer. Pours a bold, dark golden yellow with a light cream head. Dry, citrusy aroma. Taste is slightly bitter, dry, with strong citrus accents, especially grapefruits and Meyer lemons. Finish is powerful but clean. As double IPAs go, Dogfish Head 90 Minute is near the top. Although I personally prefer Stoudts double IPA, 90 Minute is an excellent double.
An amazing brew, and my personal favorite. I only drink this with a good meal, typically a nice steak or burger. An excellent citrus flavor and smooth finish.

Medium amber with a small white head that fizzes out rather quickly.  Excellent hop aroma with a reduced malty taste thanks to the dry hopping. Nice balance with a lingering alcohol finish.  An excellent IPA that ranks near the top.

"perhaps the best I.P.A. in America." I agree. Despite it being the only one Ive tried. Excellent beer I would love to have again when I return to the States because unfortunately though, beer selection in Canada is atrocious.
This was good, one of the better imp IPAs Ive tried. Massive citrus on the nose, which follows thru to the taste blended with nice maltyness.

Bottle:  Dark amber color, medium head.  Nice hoppy, citrus smell.  Taste is sweet with a bitter bite, and then a nice alcohol burn that washes the bitterness away.  Big flavor, nice bite, smooth ending... GREAT IPA!

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a deep amber, big cloudy white head.  Aroma is fruity, citrus, hoppy, hints of the sweetness to come.  Taste is subtle sweet malts and fruity notes, but it is big on the hops.  Somewhat syrupy palate, thick, elixir. Great impy IPA

Bottle. Pours a deep amber with a fluffy head that disappears too quickly. Aroma of malts and heavy citrus like raisins, dates, figs etc. Very tasty malt flavor that almost overpowers the hops. I got the hops on the back side after the sweet malts had disappeared. This is another outstanding brew from Dogfish.
Found some old notes. (6/30/07). Pours a deep golden amber with a diapering white head. Strong pine aromas from the hops. Follows to the taste with a nice malt balance. Long dry bitter finish.
Bottle. Orange colour with a big tan head. Aroma: Floral hoppy, citrus.  Flavor:  sweet grapefruit , hoppy taste. Medium to full body and a sweet grape, hoppy finish. Great!!!

(35.5cl bottle) Hazy, orange-amber colour with a medium-sized, slightly tanned foamy head Very aromatic piney and subtle fruity (sultanas) hoppy nose with a present and slightly toasted malty blend and licorice spice. Bitter flavour with a rounded malty sweetness, full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel. Robust malty base with notes of licorice and a touch of caramel, accompanied by delicate fruity flavours of raisins, citrus and pineapples. The aromatic hop character is always present in an elegant way. Medium-dry, bitter-sweet lingering hoppy finish with delicate but warming alcoholic notes. Superb (15.II.09).
This is a staple of mine.  An imperial that has a light amber but is very bold and intensely flavorful.  The aroma is almost sweet and the taste has depth with citrus and raisins.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2009 12oz bottle at RFD.   Bright amber with a creamy head.   The aroma definitely lets you know its DFH--there is something about the hops, maybe the result of the continuous hopping, that is quite similar to the 60min, with a grapefruit and melon fruity quality.   They are also more floral and piney here though, which I like more.   There is also a good bread crust and caramel balance.   The flavor comes as expected after the aroma with a good balance of fruity melon and citrus, floral and piney hops and bready caramel maltiness.   Malty, yes, but with a big bitterness in the finish to balance.   Not a kick of pure hops, but for what theyre going for this is quite nice.
Draught at Toronado SD.   Thought it would be fun to compare this with the local IPAs that I has been having this weekend.  Very sweet, syrupy, and malty in comparison.   Didnt seem this sweet out of the bottle before, but I really was not digging this on tap nearly as much.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2014 Rerate again.  1st beer.  Had been sitting several months.  Overall to 19 taste to 10

Rerated again.  Once top 5 beer, my palate has expanded.  This can never go lower than 4.5 simple because its the start to better things.  Dont like IPA?  try this.

Rerated 13  aroma is a bit malty  After having the southern tier double ipa, i have to drop this .2 points on aroma and .1 on taste..still great.

09 RatingThis is the best IPA I have ever had.  Very robust.  So many flavors, you detect the raisons, dates and other dark flavored senses.  I would highly recomend.  On draft one of the best beers you will ever have.  Light on the hops.  Just enought to add a tang.  Smooth and enjoyable!

Nice hoppy aroma, with some wheatiness and earthy tones, maybe even a touch of grapefruit. Amber appearance with carbonated head that was mostly a memory by the time I sat down for sushi. I definitely tasted the brandy, surrounded by some orange, sour apples and other bitter fruit flavors. Palate leaves a sting, nearly a sizzle. I love that the aftertaste of this beer leaves the bitter behind, very pleasant. A great beer in a style I once thought I despised.

On tap - many locations, but very nice at the Squirrel Hill Cafe (Squirrel Cage). I must agree with Equire mag.- perhaps the best IPA in America. Excellent hops, aroma, color and finish. Really nothing bad to say about it, except perhaps that after 6-8, Ive got a little package on!

Served on tap at my colleges pub, this is a go-to on a Thursday night.  For an IPA fan, it really doesnt get much better than this.  Citrusy, hop-filled, and goes down smooth leaving a delightful aftertaste.  One of the best.
Tap at Mellow Mushroom.   This is easily one of my faves because its so easy to find. Great sweet citrusy hops with great mouthfeel.  Very evergreen smell and taste.  Awesome.

On tap. This is probably the best of the "double" style IPAs I have tasted. It is worth seeking out a location that has it on tap. In my case I found it on tap at my local British Beer Company restaurant. Have also tasted from bottle and would score that option slightly lower yet still very, very good.

12 oz. bottle.

Pours amber in color with a good amount of white head.  Aroma is very strong of citrus and hops.  Taste of lemon, pine hops, and malt.  Medium bodied, very complex.  Very good IPA.

A- Rich, caramel golden hue, thin layer of white head that dissipates, minimal lacing
S- Pine and citrus hops, grass and floral tones, bread malts, alcohol, somewhat subdued for this style
T- Initial taste is unsurprisingly pine and floral hops, pale bread malts enter soon after, finishes oily and very bitter, a truly delicious beer
M- Medium/full-bodied, oily and chewy texture, moderate carbonation
D- Balanced and complex profile, the alcohol is well-masked, this is my favorite non-West coast DIPA and I can drink this all night long

Bottle.  Pours amber with a nice white head, long lasting lacing.  Aroma is hops, pine, and citrus.  Flavor is hops, pine, lemon, malt, and simple syrup.  Medium mouthfeel, just right on the carbonation.  Top notch.
Bottle. Poured a medium amber orange color with a small tan head. Hoppy aroma with a hint of wood. Has a sweet hoppy taste with a pine bite. Finishes bittersweet. An excellent IPA.

Medium amber with a bubbly tan head and medium lacing.  Excellent aroma of coffee and caramel malt, pine hops, and hints of alcohol.  Taste of pine hops balanced with sweet malt and a medium bite to the finish.  A nice, complex and balanced IPA.  Wish the alcohol content wasnt so high but this is a great beer overall.
Nice hoppy aroma. Pours a nice amber hue with a white head. Nice balance of flavor with malts, hops, and alcohol. Nice lingering aftertaste. Beer leaves a nice lace on the glass.

Pours a deep amber orange, with good sized white head.  Great piney hoppy aroma without being too strong.  The flavors are citrus with of course the hoppy pine notes, balanced by some nice sweet malt flavors.  Great bitter to sweet finish, lasting on a nice balanced note.  Very smooth and easily drinkable for a 9% ABV.

Picked this up at Wine and Wares in Jacksonville NC.  Poured an orange/amber color with a 1 finger head.  Floral scents in the nose.  Medium body.  Zesty carbonation.  Taste is some up front bitterness from the hops, citrus notes, a touch piney, with a bready/cake-like sweet 
malt to smooth things out.  Hops stay prominent, with a bitter/sweet finish that leans slightly more to the bitter, but remains pleasant.  Also a bit of warming in the finish, which is the only time I noticed the 9% ABV.

0.35 l bottle at Konttori, Tampere. Amber color. Sweetish aroma with perfumed piney and lemony hops. Bittersweet flavor with toffeish maltiness lemony, grapefruity and piney hops.  This bottle had probaply lost some of its freshness.
Amber color with a nice head.  Smell is intense and hoppy but not too much.  Taste is smooth, crisp, and highly hopped but goes down easy.

Pours a clear deep-orange with a hint of red. Head is off white to tan. Aroma is strong hops, floral. The taste is amazing, just the right amount of bitterness from hops but the nicest thing is the very strong malty presence. It has a very heavy sweetness to it that nicely compliments the hops. Very full bodied, with a sticky-creamy palate. Very strong and warming, but wonderfully balanced.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2010 Pours a golden brown color with medium head.  Great piney aroma, even more so than the 60 Minute.  Citrusy, piney, fresh-tasting East coast hops balanced by sweet malt.  Medium-full bodied with a really smooth palate.  Extremely drinkable given the alcohol content and bitterness.  EDIT 1/2010: This beer is still good, but just doesnt come close to some of the great west coast IPAs/IIPAs like Pliny, Sculpin, and AleSmith summer YuleSmith.  The hops just arent really there with the same force.  Has a nice woody/earthy character, but is a little more malt-forward than Id like for this style.  Still good though for sure.

12 oz bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Amber color, low off-white head. Hoppy aroma with some alcohol. Full, bitter flavor with plenty of piny hops and a syrupy caramel malt finish. Medium-full body, medium carbonation. Worth tasting, if not my personal favorite.

A strong finishing beer.  I drank this after a day of nachos and lighter sweeter beers.  I am no hop head.  This beer will seduce anyones taste buds with its massive flavor. You cant chug this beer.  If you want something to get you ready to stumble out of the bar and leave a good taste in your mouth on the ride home then buy this beer.  Got it at Highlands Grill, if you live in GA any where north of ATL then get here.  Its the best.

This is a fantasic beer  - hoppy but not overly dry or bitter.  Color is great and it taste even better.  Bitterness is nively balanced with malt so it is easy to drink - too easy?.  Be careful with this one,.,

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Appearance:  Crystal-clear medium reddish copper; questionable off-white head stand
