Aroma:  Seemingly a beautiful marriage of malt and hops; chocolate mocha with toast from malt; subtle citrus hops

Flavor:  Probably the best part of this beer; complex; good hop presence, but is matched pound for pound with malt; bitterness surfaces on finish just like it should in a medium-dry finish

(tasted & rated three times)
recent tastings have revealed that an argument can be made that the malt backbone is too strong and too sweet for an imperial ipa

Served in a 12 oz bottle, 9% ABV

Aroma:  
Earthy aroma, clean sensation with mild fruitiness

Appearance: 
Deep copper color, some haze, off white head, with medium lacing and mild carbonation 

Flavor:  
Complex hop profile, well balanced between the hoppiness and malt back bone, low fruitiness

Mouth feel: 
Crisp feel on the tongue, medium-full body, medium dry finish, mile residual mouth feel (body) in the after taste

Overall Impression:  Classic balance between the high hoppiness and malt back bone.  It is a very drinkable a beer and a joy to drink.

Pours a nice golden pinkish color with a rapidly dissipating head.  Strong floral, hoppy accented aroma.  Not too strong.

Rich hoppy flavor with just the right amount of maltiness.  Pleasant Imperial.  Lingering hops.  Deliciously bitter without being too stout.  An amazingly high quality IPA.  Recommended

Coppery colored with little yellow head. Rich bitterly hopped aroma with toffee, peaches and mildly alcoholic tone. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is soft with caramelly hops, toffee and mild flowers, still mild disappointment. Aftertaste is soapy with hops too.

one of my favorite beers from one of my favorite breweries.  sweet tone, nice alcohol content, piney citrusy hops, wonderful aftertaste, and not too heavy ya cant have another.   is that simcoe im tasting?  mmmmmm. i heart DFH.  best version i ever had was at the old blind tiger alehouse in nyc about 5 years ago that was on tap, and before it exited the tap it ran through a batch of fresh hops, essentially dry hopping it one last time, seconds before it hits the glass. i think someone at DFH invented it... not sure if they still use it at their brewery???

I love the stylistic bottle, at 12 ounces, in a four pack, for $9.00 in Florida.  At 9% ABV this Imperial IPA hides it well with the hops and malt.  It has a light brown look in a snifter, and has a finely bubbled head.  After  the pour I took a sniff, which was heavily malted with sweetness, and had a tad bit of hop aroma.  The alcohol was very well hidden.  The mouth-feel is slightly viscous, and has just the right amount of carbonation.  The alcohol warms your innards, and the flavor of the alcohol dissipates quickly.  The beer comes off on the tongue sweetly, and progresses into a spicy hop.  It is all finished with a nice grassy bit of sweetness.  Very awesome beer.

(12 oz blt)  Pours a rich, hazy amber; minimal off-white head which quickly disappears.  Aroma is toffee/caramel and candied pineapple.  Robust malty sweetness w/ citrus peel tang.  Aftertaste is fruity sweet (dried apricots?).  Tastes like hopped wort.  Not a BAD beer, but IPA is a misnomer.  The aroma and flavor do not meet my expectations of an IPA, but I will pretend its something else and enjoy it.

(Bottle at Pikkulintu, Helsinki, on 2009-01-20) Deep amber. Clear. Small white quickly disappearing head. Strong hoppy aroma with some toffee notes. Very strong bodied and oily palate, warmth from alcohol, somewhat dry and contains little carbonation. Malts, sweetness, lots of hops, bitterness, toffee and hint of fruitiness in taste. Malty and bitter aftertaste. Quite balanced beer.

Draft @ Capones Dec 08:  Poured an amber orange color with not much head.  The aroma was pine, citrus, and flowers.  The flavor was hops, flowers, oranges, and pine.  Overall, this beer fresh and smooth.  An excellent IPA.
UPDATED: APR 12, 2009 12oz bottle.  Pours an off-white head with an amber body.  Smells of pine and apricots.  Juicy like a peach with a nice bitterness.

A: A clear orange amber with off white head. Tiny little bubbles.

S: No lack of aroma. Pungeant sweet smelling hops with orange blossom and malt.

T: It keeps getting better. Beautiful balance of sweet and bitter. Citrusy hops, malt and apricots come to mind.

MF: Light syrupy feel with light carbonation.

D: I just love the balance of this beer. The flavor coats your mouth and fades off perfectly. Because of the sweetness (and alchohol content). I couldnt drink more than one a night but what a treat.

Pours a golden amber into my La Fin du Monde glass with a thin white head, intense lacing, and a mild, but constant stream of bubbles... Good Glass... Aroma is not nearly as pungent as you would expect, with up front sweet maltiness characterized by a bit of toffee and dark fruits along with a nice nose of citrus hops... Taste is mildly alcoholy, with a creaminess that is unmistakably east coast imperial ipa maltiness... The earthy hops are interesting but dont do as much as the big citrusy hops usually do to balance the malts... There is a certain complexity here that is not always prevalent in IIPAs, each sip is a bit different... Notes of toffee, chocolate, fruits, pine, and citrus...Medium to Full bodied with a less lingering finish than expected...

12 oz bottle

Poured a slightly cloudy burnt orange with a moderately thick, but firm, off-white head.  Nose contained a lot of malty/molasses tones for an imperial IPA, but the citrusy/earthy hops still dominated.  The taste was similar, and slightly sweet.  The hops were very well balanced, so that they could shine without scorching your palate.  At first I thought it tasted very similar to brandy.  Nice, thick mouthfeel with lingering flavors.  Overall, one of the finest beers in existence.

This is a bomber, with amazing floral, resiny and sweet.  The aromatics are perfumlike in their pungence, with pine and citrus assulting the nose.  The flavor begins malty-sweet, slight caramel and toast, then switches to lemon, orange, pine and earth.  The impression is very mouthfilling (at 9%), sweet but not cloying, resiny, and very bitter through the finish.

Excellent beer.  Although this beer has a very high alcohol content, they did not give up taste to achieve that goal.  The hops are strong, but in a good way.  This beer has jumped to the top of my list of ipas overnight.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2009 A really great beer. Amber pour with a white head. Strong aroma of hops and an equally strong flavor of hops. The hop flavor really comes through and the bitterness is well balanced with a little raisin sweetness

Poured out a golden amber and very translucent. Head was white with a hint of tan and very strong. The head was also very long lasting with good lacing on the glass.

The nose is complex and simply amazing. Hops dominate but are not overpowering. Citrus notes shine through and make the mouth water.

Taste is pretty damned close to perfect. Hoppy through and through but not to the point of burning out your palate. Plenty of complexity to be had and an almost sweet finish that leaves you wanting more. 

Highly recommended as probably one of my favorite beers.

Ive had this a bunch of differnt places, but This was fianlly rated from a 4 pack of bottles I got as a gift.  Solid copper color with a nice white head, strong hoppy aroma with some malt presence. the flavor is wonderfully hoppy but balence with eough carmely malts to make it smooth as candy while being refreshingly bitter. Im really happy to see this getting regular distrabution on the west coast now.

On tap and in bottles, I get this one quite frequently.  It helps not being that far from Milton.  By far, this is the best IPA Ive ever tasted!  Its continually hopped for 90 minutes, which is apparent in the hoppy bite, but it also is very well balanced and smooth.  Pour it into a glass and enjoy!

Dark amber body under an off white head with nice lacing. Smell suggests a good deal  of caramelized malts, candy sweetness, raisin. Wow. Beautiful balance of sweet malts and bitter hops, a touch of stout style charcoal at the end with bitter chocolate. Wow this is good. Palate is soft and medium. Thanks to TimE for a great reccomendation.

On tap at City Beverage in Durham NC this beer came over as a solid golden color with a nice white head.  The aroma is pine, grapefruit and caramel.  Taste is perfect - citrus, nice malt background with a prominent hoppy flavor and subtle alcohol with makes this Imperial IPA extremely drinkable.  A great, great IPA.

A really great beer.  Amber pour with a white head.  Strong aroma of hops and an equally strong flavor of hops.  The hop flavor really comes through and the bitterness is well balanced.  Extremely drinkable.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 My Lord, what a beautiful beer. You must drink from a glass, its a glorious mixture of amber and red. Aside from that, a molestation of flavor, tingles, and jingles. Quite a party in your mouth. Hops galore, it taste like some type of gem. But, its a strong flavor, I would not have more than one per night, and I would have rated it higher if I was a hop-head

one of the most lovely colors ive ever witnessed. starts ultra light, almost lager like and evolves during the pour, as more and more is exposed to light. becomes copper, nearly ruby and eventually tarnished orange. nose is immediately of wonderful malt, crunchy toffee wafer. little of the expected floral hops are present in aroma.  flavor is so soft and smooth, coating mouthfeel, taste is lightly of nearly roast coffee, almost wood. willamette hops really come across in a wonderful way that no one else is doing in their IIPAs. this is one of a kind, and amazingly drinkable.

Poured from bottle an orange-blonde with medium sized ecru head.  Aroma bursts with a floral citrusy hoppiness but not over-powering like some IPAs.  The flavor checks in with nice floral lemony-orange hops, caramel, a touch of malt sweetness and some sweet bread.  Palate is surprisingly smooth with just enough sweetness to bitter and a nice malty mouthfeel that makes one believe this couldn’t possibly be that high in ABV.  Wow,  a truely great beer.

Since I believe that this is simply the best IPA in existence, I give it a perfect rating. So hoppy I want to chew every sip. Caramel flavors with a perfectly bitter oak after-taste; exceptionally smooth. Bronze color with a perfectly carbonated head of sand-coated foam. Perfect beach-taste for a beer born in a little Delaware beach town. A little stronger than the Dogfish Head 60 min. IPA, and just a little better. Their 120 min. is ridiculously good, but too strong to enjoy and remember.

Beer for the Imperial Court of the Krimson King! Poured with and nice head and clear pale amber color. Good lace. Aroma is hoppy and malty; not too fruity. Earthy. Flavor is outta this world tasty. GFD! Lots of clean, chewy, earthy, zesty, robust HOPS mofo! And the malt to make it all work. Excellent body. Carbonation is spot on. Finish is satisfying and in spite of the power, enticing enough to want another. My god, this is beer!
bottle.caramel, chocolate, citrus, white foam, amber, cloudy, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, full body, lively, long finish, excellent brew - one of my favorites.
12oz bottle. Medium amber, off white head. Smooth malt flavor with a nice hops bite. Excellent balance.

On tap at the Cock and Bull (formerly Glendale Pub)

It’s a lightly hazy orange amber and the way the bartender poured it gave it about 3mm of off white.

The aroma is of sweet malts and loads of bitter citrusy hops, smells like it’s a sibling of the 120 minute with a similar but lighter mead-like quality.

The flavor is sweet up front, followed by citrusy, grassy, bitter hops and a bit of alcohol.

This is wonderfully thick and creamy, mouth coating, and warming.

Overall this is a great IPA that I will continue to drink.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2009 My favorite IPA. incredible aroma of apricots, citrus and grains.  sweet maltyness upfront.  a slow inhale through the nose as the brew flows across the tongue will showcase the perfection between the aroma and flavor.  Big full fruit and hay/grass  flavors. flawless balance.  Shear perfection. Pairs really well with Stones RIS.

12 ounce bottle.  Pour was a very clear apricot color, and light on carbonation.  Aroma was nice, very sweet with tones of citrus.  Flavor was very bitter with hops, but not overpowering.  Went down almost too easy, orange and grapefruit lingered with a warming alcohol aftertaste.  Solid, drinkable imperial IPA.

Nice deep copper color with lasting white head.  Lacing is amazing and resinous.  Great aroma of spicy hops and sweet malt.  Piny and grassy notes of the hops.  Flavor is  malty sweet and resinous hop.  Definitely pick up some candied fruit and nice sweet balance.  Really balances well together.  Smooth but chewy mouth feel.  Excellent beer.

Deguster au Mondial de la Biere. Intense. Tres houblonner, tres savoureuse.

Tasted at the Mondial de la biere. Intense. Very hoppy, very good.

Bottle.  One of my favorite beers, but I saved drinking one for a review until my 90th review.  The 120 minute gets to be rating 120.  Pours a clear golden amber with a very large cream colored head which slowly deflates leaving a little bit of lacing on the sides of the glass.  Clean pine aromas with a hint of lightly sweet citrus greet the nose.  Mouthfeel is velvety smooth and quite thick, enveloping the tongue.  A bit of sweet, subtly raisin like malt leads into a very slowly developing gentle grapefruit bitterness.   The 9% abv here is astonishing since I cant detect a hint of it, it is that well hidden.

12oz bottle, case from the head brewer.  As if the 90 minute was not good enough.  this made it ten times better.  The extra hops come through everywhere.  They really come out in the nose.  The added bitterness in the flavor helps balance things out even more.  The real 90 minute.Earlier Rating: 12/17/2008 Total Score: 3.712oz bottle and tap. Clear copper in color with a two finger fluffy head that recedes with nice lacing.  Muted hop aroma with notes fruit. Some sweetness and a bit of grain are also there.  Smooth and malty up front. The hops show up in the middle with a hint of orange zest. There is a decent bitter bite to the finish. Very well balanced throughout!
Clear orange with medium white head.  Aroma of flowers and banana.  Big hops of course, but also some tones of citrus.  Very dry finish.  Good one.
Orange amber, smooth, creamy, mallty, hoppy, caramel, piney, little citrus, dry finish.

On tap at the Dogfish Head pub in Falls Church, Virginia. A truly exceptional IPA. Just when I thought I understood what an IIPA was all about - Titan. This just blew me away. Great balance - the threat of phenol a la single malt scotch, which remains just that, strength and bitterness in perfect harmony. They also serve a black-and-tan with this and Chicory Stout, which is superb. Pity we cannot rate blends on this site.
UPDATED: FEB 3, 2009 Bottle. Powerfull tons of hops. Nice orange color with a small white head. One of the best imperial ipa. More of that please.

Sampled at the Great Decatur Beer Tasting Festival in Georgia on 10/18/08. Golden in color. Pine hop aroma. Taste was nice balance between pine hops, grapefruit and malt. I am not a hophead, but this one was good.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2009 12 oz. bottle. Pours a pleasantly tannish thick head with good duration and very nice lacing over a clear coppery body....nose is mild floral hops, with minimal pine and resin....tastes initially of malts then lingering grapefruit type bitterness....mouth feel is quite good with that indefinable chewniess of great brews....balance is superb. This is east coast hopping in that they are rather quiet. 12/04/2008

Bottle courtesy of MP via NYC. Thanks bud  This was the best of MPs US selecta. Good lookin amber colour with a niiiice white head. Lovely sticky piney hop aroma.  Big hoppy flavour with pineapple raisin and citrus notes. Great balance and poise. Superb fragrant dry bitter finish.
Top effort. Want more.
Orange color.  Typical imperial IPA taste except I noted a hint of banana.  A very good imperial IPA, but not the best.

Bottle, consumed about a month after bottling. Aroma of bready, almost doughy malt, and an odd concoction of hops, floral, perfumy, grassy, maybe some woodsy spiciness in there. Flavor gets rather unpleasant with the odd, semi-spicy, semi-floral hops not meshing well at all with the intensely bready malt. Just didn’t agree with me, though I know I’m in the minority.

12 oz. bottle. Tons of floral hop notes in the aroma. Nearly no head, just a ring of white bubbles around the perimeter of the glass. Appearance is clear with a lovely dark orange color. Long finish with a strong bitterness of grapefruit. Excellent IPA.

Bottle. Golden with white head. Fruitish hop aroma with some cabbage, apricot and resin. Very oily, almost like syrup. Bitter but also very sweet flavour. A bit to oily and sweet, but still very good.

Bottle. Golden amber with thick, foamy white head. Aroma of hops, lime, peach, banana. Luscious creamy body fills the mouth, gathers response from all over the tongue. Hops well balanced with malt for a full woodsy flavor. Plenty of alcohol. Bitterness does linger. I’ve been drinking a case of this so as far as I’m concerned I’m living large.

Bout 12 oz, 7.8 Degrée C.
V: Orange-rouge avec teinte de brun, clairé, mousse présente et collante.
Nez: Houblon frais, florale, légé malt, note de café et de coriandre.
Corps: Très rond, très long en bouche.
Goût: Malté, assex Houblonnée, plante verte, fruité légé citron et note de café/chocolat. Super belle équilibre, houblon moins présent qu’on aurait pensé, mais bonne bière de dégustation qui coule super bien.

Pours a cloudy dark orange color with a thin head.  A nice mix of fruit and hops.  Really a great IIPA

12 oz. bottle
UPDATED: DEC 1, 2008 Starts off sweet, with the hops bringing up the rear with attitude.  Well balanced nonetheless.  Worthy of its hype, and a huge success for a great brewery.
This is the real deal.  I have had this on tap and in bottle, and both are superb.  This is what an IPA is all about, hoppy, great aroma, good head.  Pour this into your favorite goblet and enjoy it.

Pours the color of burnished cooper with an intesely delicious smell. In fact intensity is a good term to describe this beer; intense hop and malt flavor, intense crispyness, intense alcohol finish that leaves almost a sugary feeling going down. I would give it a higher rating but for the fact that everything’s explicit and ’in your face.’ In other words it lacks sublety like many American beers.
bottled, pours clear bubbly tan/light brown with white head, 100% aroma of floral hops, full mouth of raisins and alcohol, very light hop, sweet palate

Bottle.  Pours a clear dark orange with a thick, off-white head.  Aroma of bitter garlicy and grassy hops and toasted malt.  Flavor is quite toasty with some grassy icky bitter hops.  Apparently this used to be good in the past when they bottle conditioned it, but its not a very good IIPA right now...so why do people rate this so high???  There are SO SO SO many better IIPAs out there!!!
A great solid IIPA just piped by the ruination. Pours witha bubbly head. Strong floral hops on the nose and a good alcoholic finish. Can’t say anything bad about it
12oz. Hard to say more than the epitome of an ipa. Aggressive hops but lots of sweet malt to balance. Sticky but not syrup. Not extreme, not perfect, but everything you could want.

Assaggiata al Salone del Gusto allo stand USA, è unIPA di spessore notevole con uno splendido aroma di luppolo e unaggressività nellamaro che può uccidere. Non riesce tuttavia a mascherare il tenore alcolico, che dà un po fastidio e scombina le carte in tavola.

bottle, bought at ølbutikken, cph. denmark.
ar:hoppy, fruity, raisins.
nice amber, small light brown head.
flavor is sweet and hoppy, slightly fruity, aftertaste is very very good, You need to drink a good deal of the bottle before all impressions settle. also watch out for temp. A very good ipa, but not more than somewhere in the best 10 i’ve had. i’d like a more solid mouthfeel, a less barleywineish aroma, a stronger aroma, and better looks.

Extremely rich beer.  Pours an amber/copper color with a very thick fluffy head that sticks aroiund a while.  Smells like a hops bomb.  I’m totally fine with that.  Surprisingly sweet taste that balances well with the hops and the bitterness the hops bring.  Slight nutty and earthy taste goes almost undetected because of the abundance of hops.  An exceptional find.

Wow... I love this beer. It’s best to remind yourself that it’s still a high ABV brew... but it sure doesn’t taste like it. Would love to be able to drink more of these in a session! Taste is full, although the aroma is not a strong as maybe you’d want. I am always amazed at how this has almost no negative aftertaste... just a sort of sweet/hoppy leave behind. In any case... this is one of my top ten beers and I just love having one after work... when I can afford to keep it in the fridge :-) If you can get it... TRY IT!

12oz bottle, a bit old though, as this is my go to beer, i’ve probably had this beer 40 times, the quality control has been called into issue, the only thing im noticing is the hops are not particularly bright here... still tasty and bitter, but not in your face sunshine citrus.... Still easy to drink and delightful, wish i knew how old this was.

Definitely my favorite beer.  For tasting, poured from bottle into Sniffer.  Pours a healthy amber color with a small white head.  Smells of honey and hops.  Tastes of barley malt and ... Hops hops hops!!!  My personal beer of choice.  On top at Timothy’s in Newark as well.  Great beer!

Delicious IPA. Head and color something darker than pale. Strong barley-malt flavor with hints of toffee and a hoppy finish. The most surprising thing about this beer is the heaviness of the lace. Great value.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2011 I feel sorry for the prior reviewer, I live about 6 hours north of SF and never have any trouble finding this delightful brew. Maybe hes not looking in the right places...  I recently introduced a beer neophyte friend to this beer and he immediately fell in love as well, a testament to how surprisingly easy drinking it is for a 9% brew. Heavily hopped and tasty as all hell.

Excellent, smooth Double IPA.  Just enough complexity to satisfy extreme hopheads, with enough simplicity to serve to newbies.  

I only wish this particular beer was available more often.  We were lucky to get this one on the West Coast for a short window of time.
Very virbrant IPA.  Nose of fruits, grassy hops.  Flavors of sweet malts with lots of citrus, some apple.  Good DIPA
Absolutely great beer. Good alcohol and and it is not as thick or heavy as one may expect. Dont hesitate.
Absolutely great beer. Good alcohol and and it is not as thick or heavy as one may expect. Don’t hesitate.

Bottle at EBF. Copper, small white head. Sweet honeyish aroma, passion fruity hops.  Sweet toffee malty flavor, flowery hops. Slightly over sweet. Smooth low carbonation. Simple but enjoyable DIPA, not that extreme. I’d sure like to try this at home.

12 Oz. bottle.  Nutty hoppy aroma.  Not floral, bitter, almost a coffee aroma.  Quarter inch head, and that was a vigorous pour.  Dense little head dissapated quickly.  Light lace left.  Boom!  Big round flavor.  Fat.  Definitely more flavor than the nose let on.  Damn this at 10 bucks a 4 pack.  Big flavor, with lots going on.  Not sharp and dry like some, but not super fruity either.  Flavor is light in the front, and thick sweet in the back of the mouth.  Definite mouth movement.  Not the beer to drink if you want to pound down a couple of brewskies, as this thing kinda’ commands you to pay attention to it.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2011 The fist IPA I ever liked. The aroma is largely of hops with a nice malty sweetness in the background, plenty of floral & fruity notes in the nose. The beer looks gorgeous in a glass, it is a very deep copper color with a big fat fluffy head that sticks around till the end and sits at the bottom of the glass leaving plenty of lace along the way. The flavor is amazingly well balanced and huge; the first tasting notes are absolutely that of very spicy hops, but there is a sweetness in the malt that calls to mind a barley wine. Notes of apple, raisin, and lemon are also present. This is also remarkably easy to drink and always a pleasure.

A nice hoppy beer.  We scored it low in the aroma dept. but wish we would have tried it in a snifter.  Full and oily with a crisp hop finish and a pang of alcohol at the end along with some orange and roasted malt.  Overall a nice Imperial IPA!

Pours dark amber, off-white head.
Aroma is fruity, malty, floral hops, and grapefruit.
Taste is hoppy, floral piney hops, sweet with caramel malts.
A better version of the 60 minute IPA. 
Who thought the East coast couldn’t make great IPA’s.

Pours dark amber with a 3 finger light tan head that lasts a long time and leaves lots of lacing. 

Aroma is lots of citrus and pine hops with candied fruits, rum,  caramel malts, grapefruit rind, and some dried grain. Flavor is sweet - rich milk caramel malts, puffed wheat cereal adding a bit of toasty/roasty appeal, more candied fruit.

 Then the strong-ish hops come in. First lemon candy with some lime bitterness, lots of pine, grapefruit, honey bitter hops, a very slight earthy backbone to tie all of the flavors together and make it seem really a hearty, wholesome brew. 

The puffed wheat cereal comes back for the finish and holds on with the only slightly bitter, mostly pine and citrus hops for the finish. 

The feel is slick, yet a little sticky, and substantial, like a good IIPA should be. 

Overall it is a fantastic beer that just oozes complexity. While it has hops and malt in spades it really suprised me how the rather strong hops aroma turned into the flavor actually being fairly balanced, and hops a little on the weak side in my opinion for the style. That oddity aside, I really can’t say anything bad about it.....great brew.

12 oz bottle. Pours honey in color with off-white dissolving head. Aroma has a quality of shellac; flavor has a huge frontal assault of hop bitterness with orange marmalade, and alcohol. It provides one cohesive aggressive flavor and finish: malty caramel sweetness balanced by this signature bold (but not coarse) hop presence that is not distinctly citrus peel or pine, just outrageous. (Reminds me of an improvement on Port Brewing Tide IPA, the coarse one. Would like to try 60-minute.) By the way, how can Esquire vote an IMPERIIAL IPA best IPA, since these are two different styles?
Anyway, I bet they didn’t try Moonlight Bombay by Boat IPA.

Hops are bursting forth with plenty of resinous oil and more pine than citrus.  The appearance is a medium copper off white head, with great initial head retention.  Great silk stockings down the glass.  It’s flavor is full of pine, some citrus, some alcohol, w/ a taste that reminds you of the way nail polish smells very sharp.  It’s smacks of alcohol, not at all a session, very potent, and to be honest I felt like it was less balanced than the 120 or the 60 minute brews.
Pours orange in color with a solid head . Hops dominate the aroma. Plenty of hops to share in this bad boy. The alcohol is barely noticeable until you finish a couple and stand up.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2009 I was a little disappointed in this. Pours a light golden color with a big fluffy, white head. Aroma is citrus, hops, and caramel. Body is actually not very bitter at all- very creamy, sweet, and smooth. The alcohol here really dominates over the hops. Very oily on the palate as well. I really prefer the 60 Min IPA to this. As for imperial IPAs, I would stick to Stone Ruination. This is too expensive and the extra gravity and alcohol really takes away from what I believe is a perfect beer in the 60 Min IPA. 120 Min....now that is just insane.

I’ve bought it in Amsterdam, Cracked Kettle. Nice amber-copper color with a lacing creamy head. Caramel, some roasted perfume and hop resin in the rich nose. Oily texture, smooth and balanced mouthfeel with a fantastic hop flavor, caramel malt and citrus tastes. The aftertaste is nice and hopfull and complex too. Delicious, fine, exciting! Please give me more beers like that!

Awesome light golden copper color, with a big fluffly off white head that seems to never go away. lots of lacing on glass. Nice earthy smell, bit of carmel and alot of hops. Nice bitter taste of hops and citrus with a raisiney finish.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2009 Lovely looking amber coloured imperial ipa with a small sticky head that leaves nice lazing on my snifter. Neat, bright caramell aroma with well integrated hops. Great oily, full bodied with a malty, fresh hoppy taste. Crisp, hoppy and perfumey finish and a sweet, lingering malt aftertaste on a soft, bitter base. Incredibley balanced, dangerously drinkable.

Bottle bought @ Knightly Spirits,Orlando in February. Drunk at home in UK. A beefy, full in the face IPA with the extreme hoppiness balanced by a strong maltiness and background sweetness. A lovely beer. Also had the 60min; would love to try the 120mins!
A lovely tasting IPA that feels warm and fuzzy in the mouth. A truly bitter beer mellowed by a raisiny, brandy flavor. A superb beer that I can’t say enough good things about.

12 oz bottle.  Clear, deep honey-colored, sparkling body topped with a small-but-persistent, bone-colored head that leaves behind nice rings of lace.  The nose is citrusy with grapefruit, pine astringence, sweet booze, metal, lots of roasted malt//caramel.  Mouth is medium with a good dose of creamy//foamy carbonation for a dry finish.  A nice mouth.  Flavor is big: lots of hops and lots of malts; a tremendous amount of both, kind of battling one another.  In the blue corner, fighting for hops, we have Grapefruit Rind being coached by Pinimus Maximus.  Fighting out of the red corner is Roasted Barley, being coached by Baked Raisin.  Refereeing the fight is a Sugared Brandy.  Other tasting notes include caramel, lots of floral, honey, heavily roasted finish from the malts, and some pine sap floating in the background.  A bit rough overall--maybe a few months of cellaring would help--but quenching, drinkable, unique, and very good.  Not your ordinary IPA.  Let it warm up.
Pours a nice amber color with citrus and pine aromas.  Nice caramel malt flavor with hints of raisin and brown sugar.  A truly great IPA.

I can see why everyone likes this one, sweet hops, excellent texture... the only one small drawback was the alchohol, but it is better blended and smoother than many other IIPA.  Incredible look in a tulip with a the clear amber body and lacy head, taste is as described, could not do better than DFH says... body is smooth, creamy and slippery... great beer.

From bottle.  Part of Dayton Beertastring event.
Pours orange in color with a solid head . Hops dominate the aroma.  Plenty of hops to share in this bad boy.  The alcohol is barely noticeable.  Classic IIPA.....

Come outta the bottle a nice dark orange with light carbonation and a very small head.  Aroma hits the nose as soon as the cap is opened up and consists of mostly a pine and citrus hop aroma.  Flavor is terrific!  Great sugary sweetness to the beer meshes well with the early citrus hops and which fades to a great pine bitterness to finish.  Alcohol is not overpowering but does seem to warm the beers flavor and meld everything together in your mouth.  Taste buds are a bit numb after this beer.  Great very well balanced and full beer.  Look forward to another one sometime soon.

Darker shade of brown, clear traces of gas rising; Very nutty, malted brown bread aroma; strong blast of deep, bitterness fills the mouth (almost overpowering), has that deep roasted nuttiness (not sure which type of nut) in the flavour; Rich bitterness in the aftertaste

Clear, oarnge / peach color with a small, white head which does not cover the surface of the beer.  Yeasty, candy, flowers and pine aroma.  The palate is warmed by a smooth, crisp bitterness with low carbonation.  Very well balanced,  very well balanced.  As a frequent Avery drinker, I find this brew refreshngly balanced.  This is a fine IPA, did I say it was balanced?

Enjoyed this last night out of a 12 oz snifter.  Had a wonderful citrus smell of oranges or lemons.  It was a warm amber color and poured nicely.  The 9% ABV is masked wonderfully in an array of citrus and fruit but not sweet.  Wonderful tasting hops, and a hint of caramel or brown sugar.  If IPAs are your thing this one is decadent.  Enjoy on tap at Flat Bread in Burlington.

Pours a dark orange with a white head. Aroma is of strong bitter hops, citrus fruit, alcohol, and caramel. Taste is heavy bitterness, balanced out by a strong alcohol bite and malts. Lingering taste of bitter alcohol. Finish is very biter.

An outstanding IPA. Purchased on draft at the Rehoboth brewpub. Poured a nice orange color, with a good head and a strong carbonation.  It had just an awesome hop aroma with some nice fruity piney notes and the hop flavor was just exploding in this beer but was in good balance with the malt.  It drinks so smooth you would not be able to tell this is a 9% beer until you’ve had too many.  Just an awesome, awesome IPA by DFH.
Had this at the brewery and the brewpub, delicious.  Very balanced while being very hoppy, if that makes any sense.  I can’t say much more that hasn’t been said, great beer.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber-brown with a thick fluffy white head. Aroma is hoppy, with a lot of pine, some fruit and malt. Taste is big and bitter, of hops and malt, with pine, citrus, caramel, and molasses notes. Lingering sweet malt and bitter hops flavors. Very tasty.
Sample at EBF Copenhagen. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich with hops and flowers.

Great malt flavor.  Just a bit too much bitterness for balance.  Could be dryer, even at 9% there is too much residual sugar left.  Citrus and surprisingly a grape sent present.  The hop flavor pops and then fades away.  All the components are great but together they do not fit perfectly.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2016 Averaging 2 ratings. Experience with BFH implies that they have pretty poor quality control, so not forgiving them for the bad one.
Bottle (EBF2008) (7:3:5:2:9=2.6)
Peachy aroma. Sticky zingy palate. Numbing. 1-dimensional hoppiness, and neither interesting nor exciting to me. Not a well balanced beer at all.
Rerate: 355ml bottle (Cambridge Winter Ale Festival 2011) (7:3:7:4:14=3.5)
Totally different beast from the mess we had before. Very sweet, but a pleasant balance of biscuity malts and very fruity hops. Very drinkable for its strength. definitely doesnt shout about its 9%, even if a bit gimicky. One of the better US hop-bombs, but a sloppy sugary mess compared to masterpieces like Alpos and Jaipur.
Rerate: 355ml bottle - thanks martjoobolut! (6:4:5:3:12=3.0)
Hmmm, between the two.Bitter, a bit harsh.
Bottle. Clear amber colour with a small white head. Powerful hoppy aroma and taste with rich notes of caramel and citrus.
Great IPA! Definitely one of the best I have had although for the price I do prefer the taste and cost of the 60 minute. I love the essence of the grapefruit hops. Definitely a great beer!

Clear amber with medium off white head. Sweet aroma with loads of caramel, toasted malt and hoppy notes. Sweet flavor with grapefruit, pine, caramel and loads of hops to finish it off bitter. Excellent!

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2013 Bottle. Pours clear orange with a small to medium sized off-white head. Nose of caramel, malt, citrus notes and alcohol. Sweet flavour with alcohol, port and overripe fruit. Syrup texture. Medium bodied. Pleasant bitter finish, again with alcohol. Complex and very enjoyable.

Bottled at EBF 2008. Clear amber, medium white head. Malty and earthy aroma with piney and citric hops, and with notes of tropical fruits. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Well balanced with a long bitterness.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2017 First ratingAt EBF 2008, Friday September 12Clear golden color, white head. Sweet scent also malty. Hoppy taste. Medium mouthfeel, high bitterness.7/3/7/3/13=3.3RerateA few bottles on a RC cruise from Ft Lauderdale to Haiti (70,000 Tons of Metal) in Feb 2017.Clear golden color, whtie head. Malty, sweet, hoppy scent and taste. Also an alcohol kick. Medium full mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.7/3/7/4/14=3.5
Draft at Hopleaf. Awesomely hoppy brew. Slightly thick with lots of warm caramel flavor. so good.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Summary: Deliciously sweet, syrupy malt bomb, and then the hops come out to play just when you thought it was safe to swallow.  Aroma: Intense hops, mostly pine, some grapefruit. Appearance: Clear caramel-colored medium amber, puts forth a thick, dense, off-white head that leaves abundant lace. Flavor: Big malt presence, honey, caramel, vanilla, somewhat boozy.  The hops are there, but dont become the dominant element until the finish, pine, a little citrus.  Bitterness lingers on the cheeks and lips.  Palate: Thick, syrupy while drinking, hops leave a cooling tingle in the mouth that trumps any alcohol warming.

WOW!!!  Now this is by far the smoothest IPA I’ve ever had.  It’s a little pricey but wow is it worth it!!  If you like true IPA’s then try this!  Even if it’s expensive; just remember you get what you pay for.  This is worth every penny.  SUPERB!!
Pours caramel colored. Aroma of pine, floral, and raisin, with a little citrus. Taste is very hoppy, very bitter, very delicious!  One of the best IPAs ever.

[Bottle] Pours a caramelly golden with a moderate off white head that sticks around. Aroma is pine resin, grapefruit, and a nice caramel-toffee malty backbone. Flavor is moderately sweet, plenty of citrus fruits, a touch of pine, and a little raisin. The mouthfeel is moderately slick with a great malt presence to increase the body. Bitterness isn’t overpowering but builds on the finish.

12oz bootle from a trade with NYbeer, thank you Steven. Very nice pour, orangy color to it. Big pine floral aroma if that makes any sense, very hoppy.  Sweet hop flavor, but not over the top, well balanced. Very good imp. IPA
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle. Hazy Orange color with a smaller tan head. Aroma is floral/hoppy and some citrus and fruity aroma. Hoppy taste, but not as powefull as expected. Very drinkable, nice crisp, hoppy finish.
Im a fan of IPAs, so I was really hyped for this one. I like the body, and palate, when warmer the high abv is fairly powerful. Citrus, flowers, bitter as you would think. I enjoy it.

Be careful with this one.  I have had two different bottles from the same four pack which were completely different beers.  If you get one that’s the way it’s supposed to be, it’s a hoppy IPA that’s simultaneously completely drinkable, more subtle than a Ruination even.  If you get a bad one, it’s a Dunkin’ Donuts regular with cream & no sugar.  Difficult beer to rate due to the inconsistency.  My personal opinion is that it’s Dogfish Head’s best when it’s on.  Citrus hops with a strong malt backbone almost every time.  I recommend, but recommend with the caveat that you’re purchasing an inconsistent product.

Capital Ale House Downtown 08/24/2008. Nice flora orange/citrus hop nose. Clear orange/amber with small fine white head. Rich malt background supports robust floral citrus American hop flavors. Medium body with full mouthfeel but residual bitterness leads to a dry finish. Fantastic beer.

Bottled(355ml). -Clear amber coloured, medium sized off-white head, flowery hoppy nose. Cytrusy hoppy, light grassy and fruity with mild notes of caramel and honey. Alcohol well hidden. Hoppy bitterness in the finish. Very good IPA.

Bottled 4/1/2008 from bottle neck. Pours a very nice copper color with a nice white head tapering off into some very nice lace work. Aroma is hoppy, citrus, caramel, malt, not quite as big an aroma as I had expected from this big brew? Flavor is caramel, malt, spicy, citrus, hops, the mouth feel is very nice. The 9% alcohol is hidding waiting for this one to warm up a touch. Long bitter hoppy finish. This is a really nice beer but I think this one does not live up to the hype! I always have this feeling going into these things that somehow it wont live up to the hype, very few do.

The only dogfish head worth drinking in my opinion.  Standard hop aroma. Somewhat one dimensional. Overly sweet in my opinion. Taste is good if you can get past the sweetness.  Palate is too heavy. One of these is almost too much unless you have a serious sweet tooth. Go for the Green Flash if you want an Imperial IPA.

@ tasting session by Joes. A clear amber colored beer, with a small beige head. The aroma was little hoppy some bitter, malty and caramel. The taste was malty, light bitter hop. Despite of the 90 IBU. Mabye given that the beer was a year out of date.. The aftertaste was little dry bitter and a bit burning.

A strong flavor with a crisp and definite aftertaste of bitter hops. The good sort of bitter hop flavor though. While not terribly subtle or complex in taste, it is an excellent example of its kind, though not very memorable for anything other than being a good beer.

On tap at Sergios in KY.  One of my favorite beers.  Just the right balance of hops and malt.  Sweetish flavor reminds you that the hops are prepared extra-long for the sugars to be released.  A slight alcohol flavor stands out, but just enough to add complexity and not ruin the experience.

back to back off the 60 minute brew.

noticeably darker.  still really clear.  same look as the 60 minute, just darker.

notably stronger aroma and taste, which is what you’ld expect.  

i’d say i like it more, but i would usually go for imperial over standard.  can’t hate on the 9%, but my friend noted you could kind of taste it.  still not bad.

i’d say it’s an understandable step up from the 60 minute, but keeping the 60 on hand would be good for when you wouldnt want to go the whole way to 90.

can’t wait to taste the 120.

Light copper color with nice carbonation and a nice big off white head.  Aroma smacks you in the nose.  Pine, citrus and a nice sweetness.  Big bitter in the mouth.  Tasted more alcohol than I thought I would (I know it is 9%) and it never really came together for me at the end.   A definite hophead’s dream but a little over the top for me.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2008 Sweet flavor for an IPA.  The bitterness is certainly there but finishes nice on the tongue.  Not overly bitter.  Very well balanced.  Smooth maltiness covers up the stog alcohol.  Very well balanced overall.  I really enjoyed this beer!!
On tap at Dogfish Alehouse in Falls Church, VA.  Wonderful aroma with fruits, herbs, and citrus.  Easy to drink with a long aftertaste.  Highly recommended.

Aroma is all citrus, weed and sweet fruits. Enticing. Nicely hopped, far from overpowering. Taste is dominated by sweetness, not as bitter as I would have liked. Excellent IPA to be sure, however, far from my favorite.

Bottle. Amber in color with a medium head. Lots of lacing. Hop and barley aroma. Thick palate. Flavor is a hop start followed by a heavy barley punch with a bitter finish. You wouldn’t know it has a 9% ABV by the taste  , the did a good job of hiding it.

A little sweet for me, which was suprising after all the expectations and the price.  I was looking for somethiing more hoppy, with a brilliant finish at the end.  Nothing too bad here, but for an IPA, and imperail, i was looking for something a little more uplifting.  Not a bad beer.
Amber, brilliant color, thin tan head, caramel nose - big flavor with heavy bitterness to come - very likable, but maybe more with slightly less bitterness in end.
Nice light copper pour. Weird hoppy aroma. I think I like it! Malty. Hoppy. Sweet and sticky. The crazy hoppy flavors are subdued by the malt. The carbonation seems just about right here. Very nice.
UPDATED: AUG 27, 2008 One of my favorites, for sure  my favorite IPA.  A hint fruity, with a great hop finish.  I can taste it just thinking of it.

Hop filtered at Dayton Alefest - Amber color with an off white head.  Very hoppy aroma.  Hoppy citrus flavor with a note or two of honey.  Sharp bitter start on the tongue with a bitter finish that does not hang around.
Really good IPA.  Poors a dark amber with a strong aroma full of many flavors.  Bitter finish left something missing, but a great bottled IPA.

A Mes rate: bottle from somewhere in Brooklyn.Gorgeous clean amber colour with a lovely white head that can be resurrected with a swill at any point. This is what I love about U.S. IPAs and it kicks the ass of the 120 any day. Amazing resinous and piney hoppage with notes of freshly harvested ganja. Slightly cheesey but in a really good way. Beautiful biscuity malt base supports it gloriously. Big bitter and almost stinging finish that is, dare I say it, almost restrained and just very well pitched. An absolute cracker.

Another I have been waiting to try, It did not dissapoint.  The aroma was complex, it seemed to go in several directions but the taste was what I expected.  It was an explosion of hoppiness that quickly balances out and makes you want more.  It is another super brew from dogfish Head.

Tasted while on vacation in CA.  Thanks Jeff and Jeremy!  Beautiful dark amber color.  Aroma of exotic fruits, honey and malty bread.  Citrus and pine with apricot and dark honey.  Understated bitter finish with a bit of sour as well.  A beer you taste over and over, getting something different each time.

Pours a thin but lasting head on a clear medium-amber body, good lacing.  Big hop aroma, amazing; like fresh-cut grass and dandelions.  Medium mouth-feel, very balanced.  The flavor sneaks up, smooth, innocent and mild, then smacks you in the face with a rush of flavors, a hint of fruit, and a bounty of wonderful hops.  Strong hoppy after-taste fades quickly into a pleasant mellow dryness.

overly-ripe banana peel yellow head thickly resting on top of nectarine color ale. no bubbles. aroma insinuates rivalry between hops and malts. overbearing mouthfeel. citrus hops rush forward, dressing my teeth and tongue in a malty-patterned sweater impossible to remove. malts eventually win out - even over the abundance of hops. lacing on the cup counts my sips - at the very least ten partakings - lining my glass in shadowy white air and froth. this beer showcases the usual complexity of dogfish head brews - often times too ambitious for enjoyable drinkability.

Bottle, 12 fl. oz. Pours a clear orange yellow beer with a white to off-white head. The arome associates to a wet dog and dry sweetness. The flavor is flowers, sweet and bitter. Great body and a nice bitter mouthfeel. Overall this IIPA is above average, might wanna try this again.
Very heavy, syrupy, IPA.  Trying for too much in my opinion.  Almost like the fermentation was incomplete - so much residual malt.  Over-rated.

YES! That’s the first thing that came to mind when i took my first sip of this beer. Pours a bright, translucent orange-amber colour with a medium sized frothy white top. Leave behind little evidence of a creamy head, however retention is fairly decent. Mouthfeel is incredibly peaceful. A tranquil step into hops heaven.

Flavors are initially piney, well balanced and fruity. ORange, apricot and grapefruit. Another great brew from Dogfish Head!

In the bottle from By the Bottle in Vancouver, WA.

Wow.  Truly a great beer!  Strong aroma of hop resin and malty goodness. Almost a brown ale aroma from the large amounts of 2-row used.  GREAT head retention and lacing.  If you’re not getting a great head on this someone isn’t pouring it right.  Beautiful dark orange, slightly cloudy color.  Hits you in the face with hops right off the bat.  Delicious hop profile.  Not overly bitter, especially for an"Imperial IPA."  VERY BALANCED!  This would be even better on tap.  Should be enjoyed just under room temp to accentuate the goodness.  All in all one of the top IPAs around!!
This is a good beer, but it’s not one that I’d revisit frequently.  I love IPA’s, but this isn’t what I’m looking for in the style.  Not enough hops, and the alcohol is too prevalent.
Very smooth IPA. Mild over tones of citrus. Not over the top: just right (balanced). Small head. Nice aroma. You can really smell the hops.

IPS tasting at Three Cellars Milwaukee.
I find this somewhat over rated. Still it is a good Mild IPA. Slightly fruity, raisin, citrus.
nice flavor- complex aftertaste.  I think this is the smoothest IPA that I have tried.  This brew hides the alchohol very well.  I will enjoy this again.

Poured amber/bronze, almost brown, with a one-finger head that lasted and left wonderful lacing. Strong piney hops aromas as expected, but offset by nearly as strong bread malts. Complex and intense flavor profile that featured the pine hops with a strong biscuity malt background. Ripe citrus fruits, caramel, brown sugar are included in a superbly balanced overall taste. The alcohol is subtle but is clearly evident in a warming way. Medium to full body, good carbonation, and an aftertaste that is consistent with the upfron taste and makes this a special beer.

So this is extremely good.  Aroma is very complex, hops, peach, floral, pine and hints of various other fruits.  Appearance is beautiful, golden red copper with a thin, slightly off white head (if head was thicker, would be 5).  Flavor is also amazing and complex.  Hops, citrus, peach, floral.  Extremely well balanced for an Imperial IPA, the hops are there but blended well with other flavors.  The palate is extremely smooth, great carbonation and some bitterness in the finish, but not quite enough.  Closest beer to Hopslam so far.
UPDATED: AUG 15, 2008 Apricot, grapefruit, pine and awesomeness. This beer is the definition of balance. Nice golden orange color with not much head. Not too sweet, not too bitter.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2008 Completely over the top guilty pleasure, rich, saturated, beautifully balanced goodness.  Awesome hoppy bite and aroma.  Piney sugary creamsicle in a glass.  These guys do a double IPA spot on.  Super tasty great beer experience.  This is the beer that made me realize that I like DIPA even though Im not the biggest fan of IPA.  Go get em theyre well worth the price.

Bottle. Golden amber colour with a long lasting white head. Aroma is quite spicy and not as hoppy as I would have expected for a DIPA. Add flowery malts to that. Flavour is nicely spiced and the malts and hops joins very balanced to this. A very nice experience and a different DIPA.
(Bottle).  Wonderful IPA.  Obviously, it packs more of a wallop than the 60 Minute, but is equally well balanced and complex.  Citrus, pine, bitterness.   A complete package.

Cask at GBBF 08. There’s not much to add on a beer with over 2000 ratings and which sits high in the rankings. Golden amber in colour, it sports a restrained hoppiness on the nose and superb balance for a 9% beer. Shows without a doubt that American brewers can do subtlety if they try!

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2009 Bottled.  Pours a clear copper color with a large, slightly off-white head that lasts and leaves a nice lacing.  Seemed dark and full bodied for an IPA.  Still has a great flavor - somewhat sweet but a strong hop flavor.  Slightly alcoholic finish.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2008 A quality blend of sweet malts and the full strength of this American hop combination make this one of my favorites. Calagione has a way of pushing the envelope without going overboard. Its hard not to like this one. Its all about balance here, though the 60 minute is a bit easer to drink.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2008 Bottled@ Martys. Amber color with a nice white head, creamy a lot. Aroma is sweety, hoppy and citrus. Flavor is quite hoppy with a smooth sweetness finish. Mouthfeel is well balanced bitterness and swetness. Amazing!!!

Semi hazy amber with a tan slowly dissipating small head. Aroma of heavy citrus and floral hops, sweet malt and mild alcohol.  Flavor of citrus, alcohol, sweet malts.  Decently balanced with a sweet dry hoppy finish.  Perhaps too sweet but overall it was decent even though Id probably give the nod to the 60 minute over this one.

Bottle.  Perfect color and head.  Some hops aroma, but very restrained in the bottle.  This beer is well balanced, not overly sweet like some IIPA’s.  I have had this on tap in the past and it is much hoppier when poured from the keg.

My first sip was something magical.
It was like kissing a girl for the first time. Sensations raced through my veins, and like Remy in Ratatouille describes it, "flavors exploded in my mouth".
A parade of tastes marching on my tongue.

Pairs very well with dishes with garlic and strong flavors. I’m going to attempt pairing this with Kalbi (Korean BBQ).
Charcuterie would also work well I think.
Very good imperial IPA. one of the best. very hoppy. you can definitely taste a hint of raisin with a crisp grapefruit esc finish
Bottle. Pours amber with thin head. Hop aroma, malt taste. Very, very well done IPA but overall doesn’t live up to the hype.
UPDATED: SEP 24, 2008 Hazy amber with minimal head. Very similar to the 120 minute, but noticeably smoother. Still big hoppy flavor yet smooth to drink.

Pours clear golden amber with thick off-white head which fades to a sudsy film.  Aroma is heavy on citrus and floral hops, honeysuckle.  Flavor is very complex with the hops up front balanced by a sweet malt and honey in the middle with heavy grapefruit bitterness at the finish. Somewhat spicy/zesty mouthfeel.  This was the one that got me hooked on imperial IPA’s.

I’ve had this beer both from a bottle and on tap over the last year.  Pours a clear amber color with a huge whitish head.  Aroma is citrus hops.  Taste is a rush of hops, followed by a sweet malt and something else I can’t place.  The flavor of the beer masks the 9% very well.  I could drink these all day.  I prefer Hopslam, but these are easier to get.

Pours clear amber with tall thick tan head that sticks around.  Aroma is fruity hops. The sweet malt is strong -- I taste molasses and raisins.  Has a bitter hop alcohol-evident finish.  Not the typical IIPA -- the hops are more subtle and the complex malts are more evident -- a bit too much for me, but I see what all the stink is about.  An IPA with complex malts that match the usual hop infusion.  Just one of these will knock you over.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2009 sooo good.  thus far the best ipa Ive had.  I enjoyed the 60 minute also but this is a more complex.  I was actually surprised by how sweet this beer was.  I was expecting to be bowled over by hops but it was surprisingly balanced.  Very fruity and very smooth considering the ibus.  nice finish.  My gold standard for an ipa thusfar  UPDATE did a blind tasting versus hop 15 and ruination and this was the winner.  Nose not quite as nice as hop 15 but edged it out on the flavour profile and palate

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2008 Fantastic IPA, although I had it served in a pint glass versus snifter, unfortunately.  Ruby appearance with limited.  Nice sweetness and light on bitterness overall.  Very fruity and good mouthfeel.  Big time winner.
Sweet beer tasty orgasm of hops. Though mine came in a non-classy pint glass.

Blew me away. Doesn’t taste a bit like a traditional IPA, as the hop profile is extremely subtle and allows the other flavors to breathe more. Honey, caramel, brown sugar and fruity hops are apparent on the nose along with a little yeast like a Belgian sweet ale. The drink tastes of maple, molasses, honey and malt, with some clear hop bitterness but no hop flavor. Meady and sweet, and despite some alcohol burn there are no out of place flavors.
Bottle.  Clear light amber pour with a slight head.  Aroma of malt and piney and citrusy hops.  Similar flavor with plenty of grapefruit.  One of the finest IIPA’s I’ve ever had.

Poured a orangish honey color from a 12 oz. bottle. Aroma is piney and also earthy. Flavor is malty and piney, high ABV. is hidden quite well. A very nice double IPA but not my favorite. Taste like it had been aged in wooden cask.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2008 Really Fresh: bottled under 1.5 weeks. Smell is a very nice thick malty sweetness, then piney with citrus and heavy hop and alcohol. Appearance is a redish copper and just looks thick with hop oil. Almost no head, but a medium bead continues to rise. Taste is bitter, tangy, heavy bodied with long bitter finish. This very welcome taste remains on tongue and roof of mouth for hours. Not excessive in alcohol taste due to the nice malt balance. I’ve had it a few times and have never been disappointed. A good double IPA.
An amazing IPA! A big hops beer; the finish a bit bitter. Lots of fruit and citrus on the noseperfect for a nightcap.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2008 Bottle at the Clark Street Ale House in Chicago. Pours a clear amber body with a medium white head. An awesome nose of citrus and grapefruit hops, also some sweet cake. The taste was full of tons of hops, not too bitter except in the finish, generally quite sweet actually. Some wood and sugary flavors too. Very good IPA. Enjoyable and not too hot.

12 oz bottle from Charleston’s (New Lenox, IL). Pours a beautiful hazed copper with nice head. Aromas are very pleasant, consisting heavily of citrus, hops, spice, and pine on the back. Initial is much the same, nicely balanced malt with a very strong hop presence, largely citrusy hops with pine notes (My favorite notes) and some other sweet but mellow fruits (Tropical?). Finishes clean, with a nice bitterness. I don’t personally think this brew overdoes malty sweetness. If anything, the other single IPA I had this evening did this much more noticeably. Very good DIPA.
Poured amber/orange in color, with a hoppy, fruity aroma. Small head with no lacing. Very Strong hoppy flavor. Hands Down my favorite double IPA!

Beautiful in-glass appearance, but this just doesn’t taste like an IPA--it’s almost like they’ve pushed the sweetness and hidden the hops to try to go for a mass-market appeal, except I know and respect Dogfish head well enough that I’m sure that isn’t the case.  

The overwhelming flavors coming through are a cloying malt and a bold (and not pleasant in this instance) alcohol taste, with a medicinal, almost prune-like aftertaste. It has non of the hoppy bitterness expected from an IPA.

Like everything from Dogfish, though, it’s certainly not a boring beer.  Worth trying once in case your tastes align better, just ignore the phrase IPA on the bottle and go in expecting a very sweet Strong Ale.

This was my go to IPA for years 
Bottle poured into a pint glass produces a finger worth of white head on top of a clear copper colored body the head leaves a good amount of lacing

Aromas of citrus hoppy goodness fill your nose.

A good amount of malt flavor for a DIPA but the hops bitter is still there for your hop fix. Medium mouthfeel good carbonation for your tongue

Highly drinkable but I would keep myself to two a sitting because of the alcohol will sneak up on you. Like I said my go to DIPA for a long time

12 oz bottle poured into tumbler. Tawny color, translucent. minimal, quickly dissapating white head. Low carbonation. Very little on the nose (probably because of my glass). Tastes of brown sugar, toast, spice, and pepper. Very long finish lingers on the palate with juniper flavors. Great flavor. Proof that a great IPA doesn’t have to be a puckered up hop bomb. Watch out!  This drinks easy at 9.1%! It’s a creeper.

ps- better than Hopslam

Probably one of the best beers in the world. Pours a nice bronze color with a thick head a a big piney aroma. Flavor is malts with a floral/pine hoppy middle a nice crisp finish. Definitely one to pick up.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2008 This beer made a big first impression on me.  The aroma is of sweet citrus and hops, with some coffee added in.  Color is clear amber.  Starts with a finger of white foam and leaves no lacing on the glass.  The flavor is big.  At first theres sweet maltiness followed by a very nice, balanced hop finish.  This one seems to start sweet then finish dry.  There is also the flavor of coffee and some citrus, making this a very distinct, versatile beer.  Very good.

Orange/amber in color with thin white head.  Floral/hoppy aroma that persists throughout.  Huge amounts of malt sweetness as it moves across the tongue.  Finish is long and bitter.  This is a beer for hop heads.  Hands down the best Double IPA I have ever tried.

One of the best I.P.A’s ever. Most high ABV IPA is one note with all hops that leaves a bitter taste in your mouth that you will regret for hours onward. Not the case here. Elements of orange and brandy round the flavor so well and event he alcohol taste seems measured for the taste. Not to mention this beer looks beautiful in the glass, it shined in the daylight with a firey orange. Just had to have another after my first even if that is ill advised with such a strong beer.

A lovely golden color with a slightly white head. Aroma is of fruity hops and a sweet malt. Taste is much sweeter than I expected. Different sweetnesses come out with time. Bitter, but not as much as I had expected. I definitely notice some darker, richer fruit like a peach or something. (Not exactly raisins.) Similar sweetness to Midas Touch but waaaaaay less. Overall I think it’s good; but not as bitter as I expected.
Wow just wow, at first I didn’t care for this beer that much, on my 2nd I fell in love with this beer, my 3rd I think I’m hooked on this beer, wow just amazing.. must try, highly recommend.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2008 ~Pours a light golden amber color with fluffy white head. Beautiful beer.
~Interesting hop scent. Im more used to westcoast hops. this scent reminds me of BBQ, which is a good thing. Earthy hop scent with some sweet maltiness. 
~Taste is nice. Again very different than what Im used to. Its the same thing that reminds me off BBQ. I cant figure out exactly what it is, but its in the flavor too. Flavor is sweet. Malt and hops balance out very well.
~Medium feel a bit sticky, bitter aftertaste, but not overpowering.
~Im not sure what to make of this beer. I like it, but its so different than other DIPA  and IPAs Ive had. Honestly I dont think i would buy this beer again. Mainly because of the price and there are other beers I enjoy better.  Im glad I got to experience it though and look forward to the remaining three bottles.
best I have ever tasted. everything just perfect. The only negative is I can’t drink more than a couple. At these times I open up some 60 IPA

Pint @ All Good in Athens, GA. Poured a murky, copper color. Delightfully floral bouquet. Deep taste of citrus & orange juice which is complimented by a fantastic citrus aroma. Well spiced and hopped. Mouthfeel is full and rich, medium bodied and lively. Masked alcoholic tartness. You definitely wouldnt think you were drinking 9%. This beer reminds me of Sierra Nevada on crack. Highly drinkable.

One of the best I’ve had.  Considering the alcohol content, it’s very mild.  Very smooth, though I was disappointed by the complete absence of a head.  It’s color is beautiful, and it is very rich, especially taking into account how easy it goes down.  The flavor is complex.  I would definitely reccomend it.
very smooth and appealing to the senses. not harsh at all, no alcohol flavor. will purchase again.

Despite the hype, I actually was not very impressed with this. I’m still not sure if I got a bad batch. Slightly citrusy nose that follows the flavor. There was a substantial alcohol taste, which should be easily fixed with proper brewing. Despite it’s flaw, it’s definitely not the worst IPA I’ve had, just not the best.
This was the first real craft beer I ever had. It’s still one of the most impressive beers i’ve ever had. Easily one of, if not the best, double ipas around.

12 oz bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar:  Golden-amber color with a medium, fading white head. Aroma is caramel, citrus and pine with a wiff of alcohol. Flavor is rich caramel, over ripe fruit (pineapple, apricot, mango) followed by some citrus and a lingering, dry orange rind finish. Medium-full body is creamy with moderate carbonation.

Deep copper, nice head with lots of lacings. Very syrup like consistency. Decent aroma. Taste is wine-like super malts with a less apparent amount of hops. Alcohol is fairly well hidden in the taste, but not in effect.  Only had a 12 ounce bottle but probably should have split it with a friend.

Apricot color with a quickly dissipating white head, leaving a decent lacing. Grassy, and some floral hops, seems like to much maltiness for a DIPA. Starts out with a lemon zest, followed by a caramel taste, quite malty for the style, with a grassy finish. Medium carbonation, syrupy and full bodied. Able to finish the bottle, but glad I only got the one. Probably won’t try this one again.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2008 On Tap at Stone Brewing World Bistro and Gardens. Pours amber/orange with small white head. Aroma of sweet hops and citrus. Cloudy. Flavor begins spicy and hoppy then finishes with flavors of nice citrus and roasted nuts.  Very impressive Imperial IPA!  Damn this is good!

Hazy Orange color with a smaller tan head. Instant notes  of a floral-hoppy bouquet. Citrus fruity aroma and a sweet grape, hoppy taste. Very drinkable, and the hops actually dont overpower the other flavors. But a nice crisp, hoppy finish.
this beer was extremely smooth for a double IPA i really enjoyed it a lot of good flavors going on you can taste the subtle flavors and the intense but not biteing hops. a great beer
This is simply a great beer. Even by Pacific NW standards. Pretty fruity, which I happen to like. But I would stop at two bottles. Taste becomes a tad too alcohol after two--IMHO.

Has the body the 60 minute doesnt - loved the aftertaste and body in particular. A little stridency in the alcohol takes it away from perfection. I like hops so the criticism of its hoppiness is foreign to me.
Definately a strong alcohol taste in this one. Poured out a copper color with a decent head.
Bottle.  Poured deep orange with a thick white head.  Lovely floral and citrus aroma.  Full   hoppy flavour with a big malt taste.  Lasting floral finish.  A lovely DIPA
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Pours amber with white head that dissipates. Hoppy aroma (duh) mostly pine and a bit sour (not in a good way). Smells and tastes a bit off to be honest. A bit of a vinegar aroma/taste to it. Says it was bottled 10April08 so its not that old. Alcohol comes through a bit. Pretty disappointing. I guess Ill have to try and find it on draught next time Im on the east coast, maybe it will taste better?!

Pale copper pour. Settles to a decent head with good lacing. Nose is of pine and citrus. Taste recapitulates the nose, and adds some grapefruit. Very nice, silken mouthfeel. Aftertaste brings back the grapefruit.
Wonderful beer, great aroma, for some reason, I prefer the 60 minute IPA. The flavor seems crisper, and the hops more aromatic.
Creamy head at the pour. copper hue. Complex Taste. Its like honey and grapefruit.  Hides the alcohol well.  Cant go wrong with this one.  One of my favorites now!!!!!

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2010 Amber color with a tanninh head.  Aroma was hoppy with a little bit of citrus.  Went down very smooth.  A favorite, for sure.

Rerate from 4.7 to a 4.  Rated this one when I was new to craft beer.  I still love this beer, but it is not what I origanally thought.  Very hoppy with a nice carmel malt backbone.  Notes of dark fruit, citrus, and pine stand out.

After having a couple more of these recently, Ive come to terms with what a unique, complex beer this is. The color is perfect. The aroma is a tropical fruit and sweet malt mix that I just adore. Those big tropical flavors show up on the first sip and never let up. The maltiness is the worker here: So much big malt to balance the hops. You get the best of both worlds instead of an overcarbonated hop-bomb that so many IIPAs turn out to be. Sticky, sweet, fruity, earthy and a lingering finish. Reminds me of Dreadnaught in that its so incredibly balanced. You get the best of both worlds, but to get the hops to smell and taste like that is truly art. Again, the drinkability and balance make this a really dangerous beer. A beauty.

12 oz bottle. Poured a nice amber color, great lacing.  Aroma was very fruity, hoppy, with some citrus and pine notes.  Flavor was a grapefruit and pine hops blend.  Palate was great: not too thick, not too thin.  Overall this is easily the best IPA Ive had so far.  Great hoppy flavor, great aroma, great everything.  Highly recommended.

Bottle. Amber in color with a small white head. Aroma is full of hops and sweet fruits. I was unsure what alcohol burn meant until I tried this brew. But that is not to say that it was because the beer was actually quite refreshing. The malt was the dominate flavor. Accompanying flavors were a long-lasting bitter hops and the fore-mentioned alcohol. The best thing about the beer was the last drop tasted just as the first.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2009 "serving type" I note on-tap, though Ive had this from bottle. You can take my review and notch it down 1 level for the bottle. This beer was head and shoulders better out of Keg. Rich aroma, rich mouthfeel, rich finish. Big hops but rounded and bold, slight bitter but balanced. Thats what made this beer great.
12 oz. bottle.  Light amber color.  Thin, white head.  Sweet citrus hops in the aroma.  Great balance between the sweet malts and the bittering hops.  Long, bitter finish.
UPDATED: DEC 18, 2011 Amber color, big head. Strong hops in nose. Mouth feel with a ton of hops and great malt to balance. Incredible beer.

Bottle from Total Wine in Roseville, CA (BTW, the managers fav).  I cant say enough good things about this brew.  It really found the perfect match between two previous brews I loved:  Stone IPA and Green Flash Imperial IPA.  From the Green Flash, the strong grapefruity flavors and smooth finish.  From the Stone, it had the full citrus flavor and smooth drinkability.  I cant imagine a more controlled palate on an I-IPA!  Unbelievable.

Bottle from Total Wine in Roseville, CA.  I heard the hype and this beer is one of the few that lived up to its reputation. Poured an amber color with a good sized head. This smell of hops was ever so present and when this sweet liquid touched my lips the flavor was amazing. A touch of bitter hops with a great malty backbone. WOW!!
UPDATED: APR 28, 2009 Piney with a lacing head thats similar to the 120 minute IPA but with alcohol burn.
Not my favorite IPA, but a dark, rich, easy to drink brew from a great company. I would love to try all of their beers, especially the 18%.
Absolutely loved this beer. IPA is my favorite style, and this one is easily my favorite thus far. If you like IPAs, youll love this one.
UPDATED: MAR 24, 2009 , POURS A  DARK COPPER COLOR WITH A LIGHT FOAMY HEAD. SMELLS OF FRUIT AND MALT,  AT 9% IT DOES HAVE A BITE, EVERYONE NEEDS TO TRY THIS ONE. EASY TO PICK UP AT MOST PLACES.

Average, frothy head, with a beautiful dark amber color.  Sweeter than the 60 minute, but not without a nice lingering of bitterness to finish.  Heavy on the hops and the malt, with a hint of citrus in there.  Complex, but not overwhelming, extremely well balanced, and the ABV is virtually hidden.  Full body, lively feel in the mouth.  Overall, a taste of heaven, and my preferred imperial IPA.
Well on a stand alone basis it stomps the 60 minute for its bang and buck.  9% a very drinkable ipa, great hop aroma and a solid choice on any summer day.  Cheers to DFH.

12oz. bottle. Pours a clear amber copper color with a .5 in slightly off white head that laced half way down. Aroma of fruit and malt. Flavor is rich and complex that bounces back and forth between the malt and hops, notes of pine, honey, citrus, caramel, and alcohol. Medium body with dry syrupy texture medium light carbonation and a sweet bitter warm finish that lasts and lingers. This is one of the best IIPAs Ive ever had.

The definitive Imperial IPA for me...Perfect refractive deep amber color, full, and slightly syrupy body, extremely complex aroma of apricot/kumquat, honey, annd grapefruit, with those aspects carrying over into the flavor, along with raisins, tobacco, a hint of jasmine, and leather. The finish has just the right of bitterness to balance the intricacies of the malt, and it compels you to take another sip, while languishing on your tastebuds. I used to pay more attention to the 120Minute IPA, but Ive seen the light at last!

Peaches, tobacco, caramel  in the front. Lingering effervescence and bitterness on the back....and the beautiful thing about that is it sticks around to 
the next draw. Beautiful dark amber color.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2008 12 oz bottle, pours a clear amber with small off-white head.  Beautiful, rich aroma of pine, citrus, caramel, and sweet malt.  Taste of hops, grapefruit, sweet fruitcake malt, and alcohol.  Mild carbonation, very smooth mouthfeel.  Great beer!
Draught: Delicious, sweet, carmel, and ripsnorting hops. Beautiful beer.  Wish i could afford the 120.

A centimeter of head dissipated into lacing throughout. Aroma of pine resin, florally, citrus hops. Delicious, creamy mouthfeel with really mind carbonation. Solid malt backbone balances the insane amount of hops incredibly well. Very good

Quite nice.  I could tell that this beer was approaching the obnoxious end of sweetness though.  Dances very nice on this edge of being too sweet.  I enjoyed the hop bill.  It certainly was not piney.  Very nicely done and unusual for an IPA.  I am glad I can get this now.

Aroma is pine & sweet bourbon with a faint grapefruit note
Mouthfeel is full and frothy with a balanced carbonation.  Malt is fruitcake without spice b/c there is a lot there. The hop bitter balances the complexity of the malt without too much hop bite.  Its formiddable flora hop bitter but the balance in the beer is amazing. Great!!

This beer is a rare pleasure.  The aroma hits you instantly as very hoppy,  grapefruity, with  slight pine notes.  It has a nice honey amber look to it with lively carbonation topped by a creamy head.  The dominating flavor is a tart grapefruity/floral that is present in a creamy, medium body.  It finishes with a nice, long, medium alcohol flavor. Well done!

Poured from a bottle, a perfect light copper color with a nice white head. Very good cling the whole way through. Smell is full of hops and citrus, a very nice medium body as well. The taste was very hoppy yet very balanced. You would never know it was a DIPA at 9%. It was very easy drinking and one of the best DIPAS I have ever had!! A very very good job by dogfish head ale. This is a must have in my books.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2008 Well my appreciation for IPAs is growing by the day.  And this one is pretty damn nice.  Amber pour wtih a disappearing head.  Aroma is hops with some malts in the background.  Flavor is hops for sure but a smooth malty beer peaks out in between the bursts of hops.  Nice.

Drinking it as I write.  A dark IPA with a nice amber color and a moderate but quickly dissapating head.  Very mild citrus aroma.  Very smooth and drinkable.  The hops are there but are balanced by the added malt.  Just try it, its semi-amazing.

One sexy beer.  Bought this one at a Binnys  on my way home from Honkeybras house.  We crushed this one together about a year ago before I knew what beer actually meant, aight, but this IPA rocks.  Maybe not the best in America, but that 99 is deserving.

Bottle, chilled, pours with a moderate head, a little of which remains after a minute or two- Nice rich, dark amber color- I dont know why, but i pick up some cappuccino aroma even though this is not a roasty beer. Nice mix of earthy hops- some iipas are very heavily grapefruity, which I dont like, but this one is (although aggressively hopped) very smooth and balanced. Nice sweet crystal malt body, somewhat creamy,  biscuity, alcohol is there but not punching you in the face. Verrry drinkable, I am getting through this one before it even warms up. Better slow down, I only bought one bottle. Solidly lands a 4 rating, which for me is reserved for exemplary beers.
This is a great Double IPA. Hints of Starfruit, table grapes, and fresh leather. Light citrus in the nose. Absolutely Yummy!
On tap at the gaithersburg brewpub.  Ill keep it simple here: one of the best.  Immense flavor.
Bottle. Aroma of grapfruit and peach. Taste of grapfruit, spice and malt. Dry finish. A really good double IPA.

Very good beer. From a bottle at TJ Finleys in Bayshore, NY.  Pours a deep golden color.  Aroma is hoppy and citrusy, as is the taste.  Somewhat bitter, like a grapefruit, but more delicious.  Definitely a really good beer, worth the money.

12oz bottle
9.0% ABV

I tried this beer on June 6, 2008 at "The Beer Bistro" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a translucent golden brown with a thin white head and a lot of effervescence.  The aroma was citrus, perfume, floral hops, some pine, and a little malt.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied, medium carboated, and a dry hoppy finish.  The flavour was a wallop of grapefruity hops, a little spice, and a little malt.  An excellent beer!

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2008 Best aroma Ive ever smelled in a beer, period. Strong grapefruit, pineapple aroma. Average IPA palate and appearance. Flavor is hoppy, obviously. If you love hops, youll love this beer, but theres more there. The beauty to this beer is the super complex taste under the hops. Lots and lots of different fruits, lots of good aftertastes. This beer is just a pleasure to drink. Update (06.28.08) - This beer is overpowering, in a good way. Having this after a token American light beer is a kick in the junk, to relate it to the average American male. It gets in your head, your stomach, and your taste buds. Few beers recreate the satisfying feeling you get while sipping on this IIPA. Hop-heads, rejoice. And if you dont like hops, well... Go drink wine.
Really great IPA, probably my favorite, easier to drink then the 120 minute and doesnt leave you completely smashed after 2 of them. If I was drinking an IPA this would be it.

Pours a medium dark amber with an off white head. Has an appealing aroma of juicy hops, bread, and citrus. The taste here is intense, with a very citrus/pinny/hoppy character upfront that is a little sweet with hints of bread then ending on a bitter note. Perhaps one of the best IPAs Ive had in a very long time. Very nice, very solid. Highly recommended.
Amber, slightly cloudy. Really great balanced beer. A fruity maltiness gives way to good hop character. Not super hopped though. This is a really excellent drinkable beer.

Sweet, hoppy aroma. Pours amber, small head. Very smooth, moderate carbonation. The fruit taste balances very nicely with the hop bitterness. Its actually not as hoppy as expected, which may disappoint some. A good compromise between the 60 and 120 Minute varieties. I prefer the 60 personally, but the 90 is a fine brew.

12 oz. bottle.  Copper pour, healthy white head leaves nice lacing.  One of the smoothest and easiest drinking DIPAs that Ive ever had, this ones damn good.
