Lots of hop bitterness, but unlike many DIPAs theres a healthy malt body balance that makes for a superbly drinkable brew.  One of my new favorites.

I actually was not a huge fan of this as an IPA, I was expecting a lot more hoppy bitterness. I know the hops are added for 90 minutes, but it feels like they left out the bitterness. As a beer its great, but I was expecting something else.

This IPA and the 60 minute are my favorites.  The bitterness is not obtuse, and the soft sweetness of the fruit is gloriously captured in lifelike obundance.  I would urge you to drink this after a morning swim on your day off.  You will be in heaven the rest of the day.

Now thats a IPA!!!

Much more balanced than its 120minute brother.  Just try it.  You will start to keep a 4 pack in the fridge, for those late night lupulin cravings.

What can I say? I love this beer! This really got me into IPAs. The aroma  is malty with hops to spice it up.  The taste is hoppy with some encouragement of the alcohol content.  This quickly mellows down to a smooth finish.  I could drink this all day...

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2009 My all time favorite IPA. Pours orange/amber. Nice light head with lacing. The aroma is amazing like over ripe fruit, and citrus. And the flavor... I am speechless, i cannot begin to describe its complexity to the magnitude it deserves.

I have been waiting so long for this beer.  After reading the comments from the many raters on this beer I come to realize a truth that I always suspected.  East coast, West coast are two totally different styles of IPA.  You must ask yourself...."Which do I prefer? & Where do I live?"  

This beer comes out of the glass quite nice.  Healthy carbonation and brilliant clarity.  Deep rich mahogany brown with medium head retention.  This beer smells of the Marris Otter malt and seemingly English hops.  Curious for an American Double IPA.  I agree with many of the members from the west coast here that this is hardly an American DIPA.  It really carries itself more like an English Strong Ale.  Which is fine, but "out west" here we are not looking for the "English" in our American IPAs.  Double or single for that matter.

I find a lack of balance actually in this beer.  It should be better attenuated.  These beers should be HOP focused, not  MALT focused.  This, however, is typical of east coast beers.  I find that they are quite afraid of the bitterness that the cohumulone in hops has to offer.  Maybe because in Delaware the climate is colder and requires a richer beer.  Here on the West coast we like it DRY.   

Because of the rich Marris Otter backbone the melanoidens from the extended kilning process has given this beer a pleasing breadiness, that gives way to the alcohol flavor and aroma.  This is sexy as a winter warmer, but for a warm California evening......Nope.  It just doesnt make it.

This is a malt forward beer.  Hoppiness is only subtly apparent in the background.  As it warms it covers the mouth with an almost "cream soda" like aftertaste.  Not what I was expecting.

Please understand, I find this beer to be a  fine beer with excellent qualities, but it is NOT what the label says it is.  West coasters beware!!!!!!!  It is not what you think.  If you like the English beers, this will be one of your favorites.  If you like hoppy beers, you will be disappointed.  Sorry.  Just look at where the individuals are from that love the beer.  The mid west to the east coast.  On the west coast the ratings are not so good.  We have Pliny the Elder, Pliny the Younger, Ruination, Racer 5, Racer X, Hopsickle, 21IPA, Anderson Valley Double IPA, Moonlight IPA, Blind Pig , Russian River IPA, Union Jack, IPA Nectar, Stone IPA & so on.  These are DRY, HOPPY & REFRESHING.   

The crux of the matter, once again, is....Do you like it Malty or Hoppy?  This beer is Malty, NOT hoppy.  Period.

I just hope with all this East Coast, West Coast stuff,  we do not end up with some brewers getting shot in a brewing "gang" warfare episode.  Relax.  It is all good.  We all have different opinions on what an American IPA should be.  Personally, I know it to be something entirely different.

Much love to all.  I know this beer carries with it much strife and partisanship, but I think it is ok.

The best IPA Ive ever had.... hands down. I love this great Imperial IPA. It has a perfect score in all catagories in my book. The aroma has strong flowery notes, the appearance is a nice red coppery color, with a beautiful off white head that leave a dilicate lace in its trails. The flavor is outstanding with its fruity, earthy, citrusy notes. The combination of hops used in the beer is perfect for every hop lover. You get a mouth full of hops and malted barley that is perfect for the palate. At 9% abv you can have just 1 or 2 and youll be fellin good.
UPDATED: FEB 22, 2009 Ive ruined many a friends palate with this one. Simply amazing in every way from the hoppy, floral aroma to the incredibly big, but balanced flavor. Delicious...

The best beer Ive ever drank!  This stuff is just an explosion of awesome floral tastes and smells.  Best if you can get it on tap in DE after its been run through "Randall the Enamel Animal," but bottles are cool too.  Its strong ABV, but you dont taste it at all.

hmm, picked this up in Seattle while on vacation and after waiting so long and hearing so much I guess I am just a bit dissapointed.  It has quite a bit more complex taste than your average IPA but as for the American IPA style it seems to actually lack some bitterness.  To me it tastes more like an IPA mixed with barley wine.

Verre de 4 oz, dune bouteille au Mondial 08. Arômes de houblon résineux et dalcool. Robe dorée, légère mousse. Très onctueuse en bouche, la malt caramel équilibre bien le houblon, puis laisse place à une belle amertume. Lalcool donne un léger côté sirupeux à la bière et réchauffe tendrement la gorge. Une IIPA bien équilibrée.
Thought it was tasty, but it didnt blow me away. It poured very nice, nice lasting head on it. I just found it lacking something.

So the vaunted Dogfish Head finally makes it out to California. The only ways Ive ever had the opportunity to try this brand of beer is either at tastings or via trades. Aside from the World Wide Stout, which I thought was damned tasty, the rest of the DFH beers Ive had have been really underwhelming. The 90 minute was no different. 

As far as DIPA/IIPA, this is just a mockery. Nothing about this beer says its a DIPA. Instead, what it tells me is its some kinda of American Strong Ale or a barleywine. But no way in hell is this an DIPA. Its just not. And the bottle I had was pretty damned fresh...bottled 3/24/2008. So its only about 2 months old. And to top it off, they are selling this stuff for $11.99 for a 4-pack?!?!? What a joke. 

The beer pours out a burnt orange color, almost copperish. It has a nice creamy two finger thick head, and thats about where the kindness ends. The aroma is doughy, a bit of cookie and light toasted grain, perfumey and thats it. I got no semblance of hops in the nose at all. No pine, no citrus, no herbs....just...zip. Flavor really sweet with nothing to balance it out. Syrupy comes to mind, like drinking some kind of beer infused with corn syrup. There is an imbalance of hops, but it goes the other way. Instead of being over-the-top in mouth numbing bitterness, its subtle to the point of being almost missed. I just dont get this beer. There are tons of other top-shelf DIPAs available for a fraction of the price (White Knuckle, Maximus, Hopslam, Ruination, Hercules, Hopsickle, etc) why would anyone waste their time, money and liver on this? I fail to see the fascination with Dogfish Head. I think a 2.3 for this beer is being VERY kind, and the only reason it receives this was because of the appearance. It should receive between a 1.5 and a 1.8 in all honesty.
extreme hoppy beer, bitter with a citrus taste, most likely grapefruit, very well balanced and full body beer. Amazing

I really really like this IPA..it might be my favorite. I recommend drinking 2-4 of them after an active day both before, during and after dinner...My favorite parts are the extremely better hoppy goodness knocked back with an extremely dry aftertaste...like a great champagne, only hoppy. I really like this beer.

Simply put, amazing. On others scales, the American Bud is "full-bodied," which alternatively lacks any direction or description. Moving on, Imperial IPAs dominate my taste buds, especially when DFH taps into some high quality hops! With these rising hops prices, its great to have such a distinct process as the constant 90 minute hop addition, as it makes beer delicious to smell, taste, savor, and when possible, share.
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Extreme hoppiness lends it an upper bitterness taste yet surprisingly remains balanced and flavorful; strong citrus aroma. Alcohol taste doesnât quite kick in until 2nd beer.
wonderful caramel and citrusy hop flavor. why there is a flavor reminiscent of coffee i do not know but it all sure is a beautiful thing. balanced more so than most IIPAs
Deep orange amber. More caramel and resinous hops in the aroma than the 60. Less fruit, more green sharp resinous hops and more sweet rich malt than the 60. Very long, very bitter finish.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: This is a lovely apricot-tan color with a thick fluffy off-white head. The aroma is lime, green mango and hops. Flavor is surprisingly creamy. It makes me think of tropical fruits that I had while I was in Cambodia, like custard apple, mangosteen, rambutan. Very nice clean fresh hops to round it all out. Medium bodied, velvety mouthfeel. Yum!

12 oz bottle.   This beer is finally available in the SF Bay Area.   Amber with nice head and lacing.   Aroma has a balance between malt and hop.   This is a big beer in every way ... lot of malt flavor and sweetness with plenty of hops.  Finish was even a tad sweet.

Amber, one finger head. Smells like malt, malt, malt. Flavor is sweet, spicy and slightly bitter. The palate is what wins it here; CO2 is at the perfect level, letting the roasted pine oil up the roof of the mouth.The rich, roasted malt character of the finish was my favorite part of the 90 minute.
UPDATED: JUL 10, 2011 A clear ruby body with a sweet cherry like aroma. This is a wonderful IPA that has a mix of sweet & bitter and there is no strong alcohol taste. Hints of cherry cough syrup.
Pours a translucent caramel color, with a foamy cream head. Aroma is hoppy, but not overwhelmingly so. Flavor is definitely hoppy, but not as bitter as one would expect. Very good IPA.
WOW!!   This beer is good.  I cant believe I got a buzz off of one bottle.  I must be losing my edge.

The beer poured a reddish amber color. The beer had very little head and it didnt stay long. The nose smelled of fresh hops with a hint of citrus maybe lime or lemon Flowery, citrusy nose. The beer was full bodied, it had a thick almost syrupy mouth feel. The taste was smooth with a sweet hopyness that got more bitter as the beer warmed but never became unpleasant.

Beautiful orange pour with creamy white head. Aroma is wonderfully deep malt sweetness with mango and peach notes blending well. Flavor is much the same as the nose. Perfect balance between the sweetness flavor and bitterness. One of the best.
This golden ale poured with a decent off-white head. There is a malty sweetness that is offset by a nice hoppy finish - well-balanced.
This is one of the greatest beers Ive ever had. It tastes much like happiness in a bottle. It pours copper beautifully and the long finish is excellent.

12/19/07 notes:  this beer is potent and intense: huge hops in aroma.  Flavor is malty-though-bitter, with honey, fruit, and raisins.  Great body, cant ask for much more from an IPA.  I will definitely have again.
UPDATED: OCT 9, 2009 I say the hype is all good.  This is what an IPA should be.  Every aspect of this beer is superior.  Talk about balance.  This one is in the rotation for sure.
Pours a light amber copper with brilliant clarity and slightly off-white head. Amazing sweet floral hop aroma.  ABV is extremely disguised.  Phenominally balanced. Medium almost medium-full body.

as soon as i popped the top off the bottle i got slapped in the face by the hop aroma! this pours a beautiful orange color, and has a thick off-white head at first, and then it goes away pretty quickly. The taste is exactly what you would expect, tons of hops with plenty of citrus notes and also some caramel malts, the amazing thing about this beer is how it is balanced so well with the two extremes. Great stuff all around!

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Wow. Huge hop aroma with a nice citrus smell. The taste is very similar but backed up by a wonderful malt backbone. The two go hand-in-hand and while the mouthfeel is nice and full, this beer never comes across as overbearing. I had no idea it was 9% until I got a buzz while preparing dinner. The alcohol is masked very well. Great beer, Ill be getting this one again......and again!

Pours beautiful burnt orange, with full light beige head. Fantastic citrus/pine hop aroma. The flavor is reminiscent of the aroma with more of a malt presence making a very well balanced beer. Great sticky sweet mouthfeel, that hides the high alcohol content well. One of the best IPAs Ive had.
Poured dark amber. Aroma of complex hoplexity. Flavor? Two words. Dark Chocolate. Amazing to bring that flavor out of hops and malt combined. A very well made brew.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2011 Poured into a snifter.

3.5 A: Dark orange color. Two fingers of creamy head with disappointing retention and plenty of lacing.

4.5 S: Lots of citrus hops, grapefruit stands out followed by some tangerine. Malts are overshadowed by the hops, which is fine with me.

4.0 T: Not all that hoppy, but very tasty. Herbal hops mesh well with the caramel malts. This isnt what I would reach for if I wanted a really hoppy IPA, but it would be something Id want if I wanted a good beer.

4.5 M: Medium heavy body. Good amount of carbonation. Quite creamy and smooth. Well done.

4.5 D: Super drinkable, probably more drinkable due to it not having an incredibly big hoppiness.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-02-2009 05:29:08

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2008 12 oz bottle into a shaker.  I was unaware when drinking this last night that it was an imperial.  Very nice floral and citrus hop dominated aroma.  Simple, dark golden pour with average carbonation and an impressive fluffy white head.  Extremely flavorful hops, yet still soft and not strongly bitting.  For a 9 abv, the alcohol is extremely well hidden (one of the reasons I was surprised to see this was an imperial).  Medium bodied and soft on the palate, not overly carbonated like some pales.  Overall: a great IIPA; delicious. 



(RERATE)  It has gone a bit downhill compared to what I remember.  A lot boozier than I remember, but still some great hops notes on the aroma and flavor as well as a good malt body.

Tasty beer, no doubt, but this is a powerful sipper where the sweetness and sticky hops make it tough to drink more than one. 12 oz pours reddish-orange with nice-looking, fairly persistent head. Nose is sweet, floral and fruity (grapefruit and oranges with fruit punch notes) with a backdrop of resinous hops. Tastes sweet, nearly cloying, and immediately carries with it a serious, sticky and lasting bitterness. Lots of flavor and virtually no subtlety. But forget that, did it taste good? Yes.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2008 Hops are superior in taste and smell. Nice bitter sweet balance. The sweet is like fruitcake, so not to sweet. Has a spicy hop that will linger yet make you thirst for more. The head is gold, continuous and steady, very refreshing. Would do well with aged swiss cheeses.

Poured into a pint glass. Goldenrod body sits under a one finger white head. Head reduces to a moderately large halo and leaves some sitcky resiny lacing on the glass. A quick swirl actually reconstitutes the one finger head. Piney citrusy hops on the nose, grapefruit, grainy malt Taste follows the nose, also maybe some apricot, brown sugar. Nice oily hop explosion here, but not overly bitter. Carbonation is perfect, finish is drying and entices the next sip, and alcohol is well hidden. Very easy to drink, just beware the 9% abv.
dogfish is alway impressive and this flagship ipa is loaded with spicy hops and lots of malty goodness.If you havent tried I suggest finding one or four at any cost today.
Great IPA.  I love the sweet balance to the the hoppy bitterness.  Dry finish from the heavy ABV and hoppiness is to be expected.  One of my all-time favorites.
Wonderful appearance and aroma! Ceder, pine and citrus. Big ceder and floral flavor. hides the 9% soooooo well. Very well my favorite along with HopSlam and Crooked Tree.

bottle. pours a beautiful copper with a small head that quickly turns into a thin film that laces the glass. aroma is light malt masked by grassy, citrusy hops lots of hops. The taste is much like the aroma; quick tickle of carbonation followed by a lot of sweet malt, but in no way cloying, that slowly turns to citrus hops with grassy hops lingering in the finish. one of the BEST double ipas ever

Pours a nice orange/yellow with a pine tree like aroma. Poured in a tulip glass. It tastes like citrus and grass. This is a great big IPA and I like. I cant say much more than has already been said. I wanted to say balance but it really isnt as it is so strong and hop like. But to me, you never taste the alcohol and it finishes so well.

Pours a lovely oragnge with a thin head and nice lacing. Aroma is fantastic - sweet and hoppy, marmalade and candied ginger. Tastes of Seville orange and present alcohol, fresh hops and a nice crisp, warm finish. Body is chewy but slightly undercarbonated. This is so much better than the 60-minute, and much more sessionable than the 120. Many thanks to SoLan for the trade!

Clear, darkish amber with a fluffy off-white head - not bad retention for this style. Sweet but seriously hoppy aroma. Very, hoppy, grassy and slightly malty taste with what is first a clean finish, but turns out to be a quite long hoppy finish. I expected to hate this beer since Im more of a Belgian-style beer fan, but this wasnt terribly bad. Bitter but refreshing and, I hate to admit it, tasty. If you like hoppy IPAs, then youll probably take a liking to this.
One of my favorite IPAs ever, along with Dales pale ale, the IPA I most often return to

This was my first Imperial/Double IPA.  I admit I was a bit skiddish at first because IPAs arent my favorite style.  This goes so far above and beyond any other kind of IPA Ive had.  Nice citrusy hop aroma.  Flavor is a near perfect balance between the malt sweetness and the hop bitterness.  No lingering aftertaste and finishes very smooth.  Absolutley loved this one.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2008 Copper body topped by an ephemeral, modest head.  Bit of a raisin kick, little low on carbonation, I thought.  

I have re-tried this ale a few times now and, in fairness, I am boosting my rating because each time I try it more complexity is revealed to me.  Take your time with this one and you’ll realize that it is one of the finest IPAs around.
Ours a hazy oragne with a white head. Aroma of citrus hops mainly. Flavor is citrusy hops, not much pine, very bitter. good stuff.
I think dogfish head has it right again. Great balance not over done as far as the hops, very smooth.  The hops are what make this brew but as I stated not over whelming.

Bottle.  Pours dark copper color.  Initial hop taste nicely balanced with malts which makes it very smooth and drinkable.  However, I prefer less balance in an IPA and more of a bitter aftertaste.  Also, towards the end I could smell alcohol and taste alcohol.  Good beer but not that impressed.
great ale. citrusy and grassy at the same time. pours clear mediam amber. light creamy crown. hops and alcohol are very evident. great all round beer but seems a little flat.

Wow, this one is very nice.  Has a really nice amber orange color with a white head. Taste is a wonderful combination of citrus, hops and malt.  This one is balanced very well, with a sweet malt finish that goes on and on.

Not normally a fan of IPAs, but this one was very drinkable. served cold from a 12 oz. bottle. good aroma, sweet hops. didnt see the color because it was consumed straight from the bottle. it was creamy and refreshing, somewhat pine-flavored but with a solid hop/malt combination. Just a really good and refreshing beer. Not much else I can say than that.

Shared with Pyrozoid.  Clear dark golden poor with a thicker foamy off-white head.  Aromas of Cirtus, pepper, grapefruit and orange zest... nicely hopped for sure.  Creamy, velvetty nicely balanced mouthfeel.  Carbonation is just right.  Alcohol is not as present as i originally thought...  Creamy caramel flavors with a blast of citrus zest.  Medium / full bodied mouthfeel.

(Dégusté avec french tickler) Biere qui resemble à la 60 minutes au niveau apparence. Odeur plus forte, par contre qui ressemble encore une fois à la 60 minutes. Saveur crémeuse, sucré , oranges, poivre et épices. Plus agréable en bouche que la 60 minutes.
Pours nice light bronze color with soft white head that disapates quickly.  Has a wonderful aroma of sweet hops.  Very nice taste with only slight bitter follow.  Packs a good size punch at 9%

Pours a clean amber, small white head
floral hoppy aroma. a little bit of grapefruit?
Delcious hoppy flavor with a malty base that ties everything together, well balanced, fantastic.
Standard grass and citrus in nose. Copper body, small white head. Really agressive palate but a little plain in taste. A little too bitter and expensive for me.

Bottle.  Pours a golden-amber color with a thin, off-white head.  Very citrusy hoppy aroma (yum) with a dose of caramel malts thrown.  Flavor is pretty much the same (yum).  Bitter, but not over-powerfully so.  I have had this beer many times and I never tire of it.  Prob my favorite from DFH.

This beer is quite tasty.  The aroma is a very very strong grapefruit, and the flavor has no choice but be exactly the same.  Im not a fan of grapefruit, but for whatever reason enjoy this beer.  The only problem I have with this beer is that it may be too much.  The flavor is borderline overpowering.  I will drink this again, but only when Im really in the mood for something with a very strong citrus flavor.

Poured a golden amber with a sturdy, two fingers of frothy, eggshell head. The nose was of grapefruit, pine and herbs with a sweet carmel/alcohol tingle. The taste started with an unapologetic grapefruit blast. A perfectly balanced carmel backbone brings you back from what could have been an astringic dissaster. Piney notes come in next to complete the finish. Alcohol was definatly present in the aftertaste. The mouthfeel was medium/full and its drinkabilty is huge, despite its high 9% ABV. This was a near perfect Double IPA. A hop-heads dream.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2009 12 oz. bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Florida) that was cellared at 40-45 degrees for one year. Pours a reddish orange with a thick white head. Aroma: Strong notes of grapefruit, orange, and spice with just a faint hint of chocolate. Flavor: earthy, fruity, strong grapefruit notes and a bitterness that smoothes at the finish. Mouthfeel was very silky and on subsequent tastes we experienced hints of chocolate and malt. The hoppy bitterness we have normally experienced in this beer seemed to mellow a little with the age.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear golden amber with a thin white head.  Aroma is sweet and floral, with a wonderful duo of syrupy hops and rich caramel complemented by roasted malt.  Body is full and surprisingly creamy for an IPA, with an initial taste of just malt and hops building to a finish thats pleasantly bitter but not overwhelming.  The aftertaste is lovely -- honey, floral notes, and some citrusy hops as well.  King among IPAs.

Light and crisp in aroma - a suitably bright orange hue. Notes range from citrus and walnut to licorice and thyme.

Flavor has a perky, piquant side that leaves the palate clean and refreshed. Sweet notes pleasantly linger for some time reminding one of a gin and tonic or crisp white wine.

Pair with a lighter cheese, perhaps even a chevre and a bowl of strawberries.

Im not even a huge IPA fan but this takes it all!  I might even agree with Esquire and say that this is the best IPA in America.  Extremely hoppy, hence the 90 IBU rating, but goes down smooth.  Nice pour, the aroma out of the bottle is great as soon as you pop the top.  I cant really say anything bad about this beer other than the fact that it came in a 4 pack and not 6!
user_location: originally from Michigan, New York, USA

text: UPDATED: AUG 8, 2008 On tap. Pours a nice deep amber-golden color with thick white two-finger head. Smell of hops with a stronger than average sweet malt backbone. Not surprisingly, the hops are the first thing to hit the palate, but its on the sweeter side of things...not an abrasive bitterness. Also got some fruity undertones (grapefruit?) with a solid malt background. Definitely a sweet hop aftertaste, very sticky, seems to linger.  This is certainly near the top of my list of IIPAs.

A- Pours a deep orangey red with a 2 finger head that fades to lacing and a small frothy topping.

S- Smells sweet and very piney, pretty characterstic of a DIPA, nothing too out of the ordinary but solid none the less.

T- tastes of black liquorice, subdued piney hoppy tones, hints of alcohol.

M- A bit thick for my liking but it complements the taste well. Medium carbonation.

D- This is a sipper to be sure. I am digging the taste because of how different it is from cookie cutter DIPAs but it is thick and definitely coats your mouth. Not the most drinkable DIPA in the world but very solid.
No complaints here. Hoppy aroma with the slight fruit flavor does a great job of masking the high abv. Hop balance is just right. It would take a lot of self-control to drink in 90 minutes, though.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2012 appearance of a nice strong clear dark amber with red tints. solid head, but not overly frothy, and dissipates quite slowly. aroma definitely of hops, raisins, and slight apricot. definitely hoppy but so smooth and with complexity that has delicious fruit tones.  gotta run, but a fantastic beer.

On tap...growler from consumers. Ive been eyeballing this brew for a while while it was on the on deck list and finally I get to try it today. Perfect way to celebrate the end of the semester. Poured a crisp, clear honey color with an eggshell head. The aroma was an intense floral bouquet with a hint of sweetnes to it. Very hoppy and well balanced. Citrusy and sweet, nice bitter, warm finish. Flavor would be a ten if it were a bit more hoppy. This brew is near the top of my list.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2008 Bottle. Pours a clear copper orange, with a moderate head that sticks around the entire glass and never stops with the lacing. Aroma is prominent, big time piney hops with a citrus crispness and caramel sweetness. Quite smooth for an IIPA, taste is balanced, sweet maltiness smoothly transitioning into a big piney hop body. Finishes with crisp citrus and resiny pine hops, but never fully loses the caramel sweetness. Moderately long bitter finish. Full bodied beer, syrupy, chewy, good carbonation. Excellent IIPA, superbly balanced.
On Tap.  Very strong flavour.  Citrus after taste.  very hoppy.  Golden color.  Not an IPA fan, but this was very good.

Poured from a bottle with a nice white head on top of a clearish golden hue. Very good smell of grapefruit, lemon, and honey. Very smooth and rich and slight syrup textures on your tongue. Excellent bitter hops and some balanced hops. Alcohol well hidden. Great finishing flavors that stay with you and gets you wanting another. Great DIPA!

Aroma: lovely, sweaty, mango nice hops, good sweet malt. 
Flavour: nice, bitter, slightly sweet, full-bodied, flowery, lightly smoky... plum sweetness. Aftertaste of citrusy & flowery hops. GREAT. 
Palate: powerful carbonation, but still nice. Slightly fluffy. 
Appearance: nice winegum orange, clear body w/ yellowish irregular foam leaving some laces.
Great beer!  I would probably have rated it higher, Im just not a huge IPA fan.  As far as they go, this is one of the best Ive had though.

A very big IIPA. Simply delicious. Pours a honey amber with a good head, though it dissipates fairly quickly. Pine and a bit of citrus hops (grapefruit) on the nose, but the remarkable thing about this IIPA is its balance. The flavor is packed with a near-perfect balance of hops and malts. Big, thick brew, but still maintains a fresh mouthfeel - it isnt quite as syrupy as other IIPAs. Dogfish Head has a tendency for the bizarre and over-the-top, but this is an instant classic - it goes down as one of my favorites.

if your compairing this to DFH 60 min,your really compairing apples,to oranges.this beer might come off alittle syrupy,or medicinal to a 60min,but bear with it.the hops,and malt have just upped there ante.all though i prefer 60 min.i thinks this is one of the best IIPAS out there

The first time I tried this beer, I didnt like it. Then I realized that I was comparing it to DFHs 60 Minute, which was already one of my favorites. But this beer is really in a different class. I have to give credit to the 90. It smells great, looks great in the glass, and the taste is phenomenal. This is the one to convince the IPA naysayers.

After about a thousand bottles of this amazing beer, I fully admit to being totally smitten by it. All the hyperbole applies from previous reviews. And after reading nearly all of them, I cant add much. The one thing I can add is that I embrace the  variation from batch to batch. I enjoy the randomness and the surrendering to the whim of the ingredients. Lotsa grapefruit in the nose one month, not so much the next. Sometimes I find myself saying, "A little sweeter in this batch."  But the most important quality for me is the fact that, I LOVE it each time. A classic.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2008 Rerate 09/28/2008.  12 oz bottle dated 09/05/2008.  Pours amber with a small white head.  Malty aroma with fairly strong citrus and spice.  Flavor is about an even balance of citrus and biscuity malts.  A very good IIPA to be sure, more malt-dominated than others, but still quite good.

12oz Bottle: Pours a clear amber/orange w/ a small white head. Heavenly citrus hop aroma. I dont know if there could possibly be an IPA w/ a nicer aroma then 90. Seriously, the aroma is perfect. Flavor is fruity sweet up front fading nicely into citrus hops. Leaves a sweet stickiness behind that tempts you to take another sip. Which of course you will, after all, who are you to argue? Now that I think about it this beer may be the devil. The alcohol is so well hidden that this one sneaks up on you in a hurry. I havent had one of these for so long I should be ashamed of myself...let me pour another...I dont think its wise to keep the devil bottled up in the fridge. Not wise at all...

Tasted 4/11/08.  12oz bottle.  Filtered with a bronze golden hue.  Layer of bone white head.  Earthy piney aromas with a touch of citrus.  All hops with a minor alcohol nose.  Sugary and earthy soggy aromas.  Full bodied and HUGE!  An explosion of alcohol and hops.  Solid effervescence.  The bitterness is like KAPOW!  Tingling and sticky.  Touch bready character.  Big zesty acidity.  Hits all parts of the tongue.  The malts take a backseat to the assaulting hops.  Caramel and grapefruity flavors.  Estery undertones.  Big complex and aggressive.  Lemon and toffee.  Nice warming sensation.  Fantastic!

BOTTLE: Beautiful clear golden colro with whitish foamy head and absolutely no lacing.  Aroma beckons DRINK ME with strong but not overpowering hop flavor.  Flavor is fabulous with nice malt and just a hint of citrus and other fruits.  Palate is perfectly balanced with nice liveliness, medium length, not very dry but leaves you wanting more.  Excellent!

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2010 Bottle at the GBBF 2009. Lovely, inviting pine aroma but theres a sharpness to it. It has a depth of flavour but its tipping to the unbalanced side. Earthy start, bitter throughout, but a peak of sweetness at the end. The booze really comes through and is a touch overpowering.
Bottled. This is a very good double IPA but not my favourite. The complex hop flavours and lingering bitter finish are very appealing; however, I prefer a double IPA with a sweeter malt body.

12 oz bottle.....
interesting but....sadly just not up to par with the whole cali IPA thing....nice english malts....sharp hops....balanced...but not great hop aroma......

12 ounce bottle-  never been much on the IPAs generally find them too bitter.  This one, though, proves to be an exception.  Pours out a golden orange with a moderate head,  Aroma was citrus and apple.  The taste virtually the same as the aroma.  A tart bite without the typical IPA wince.

Wonderful beer. I thought it would be terribly bitter but it surprised me with its drinkability. Better than the 60 minute IPA. A friend (who is not an IPA fan) and I drank a bottle each in Tucson and even he loved it. Im not sure what else to say, smells wonderful, tastes spectacular, biterness is perfect. This is probably my favorite beer. Now if only it was cheaper than $10 a 4 pack...
Very strong hoppy aroma.  Very flavorful, thick and hoppy.  Not really a session beer due to the high alcohol content and the high hoppiness.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle. Pours a cloudy mango color, with a big fluffy white head and nice lacing. Big piney hoppy aroma. Very floral and inviting. Flavors are packed with big hops, citrus, mango, grapefruit, and a healthy malt back-bone. Easy drinking despite the ABV, and thoroughly enjoyable.

It poured a thick, cloudy orange and smelled supepr hoppy with a mix of pine and citrus. It was full of body and flavorful. Although it was thick, hoppy, and high in alcohol, it was fairly drinkable. So watch out with these--theyll sneak up on you!
Bottle. A hazy amber beer with no head. The aroma is grassy and hoppy, while the flavor is sweet with primary notes of alcohol as well as lighter notes of hops leading to a very dry end.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2010 Re-rate 6/14/08. Nice copper color with a off-white head and some really nice lacing. The aroma is fruity with hops but not over powering. Sweet malts, a bit candy-like, with grapefruit hops. Some bitterness but the hops are relatively tame for the style. Easy drinking. This is a nice beer but could use stronger hops with more bitterness to make it a top Imperial IPA. Re-rate 1/8/09. I still find this beer pretty good but every time I have it now I am less enthused with it. I just cant put this in with the top tier of IIPAs. The pour generates a nice fluffy head, the beer laced well. The aroma is fruity, tropical-like, with some hops but the entire scent is mild. This tastes very sweet, too sweet, lots of fruity character, with the hops tilting towards a sour grapefruit but not nearly the sharp hop bite it should have. Hard to imagine me getting this again in the near future. Again, its good enough but if Im going for a big hoppy IIPA there are so many better choices. To be honest Im probably still rating this a tad high based on reputation.

Orange color.  Massive aroma of floral/citrus hops and some caramel malt.  The flavor is surprisingly balanced - not as bitter as I expected which.  There is a very smooth mouth feel with a dry finish.  The best IIPA Ive had.

Bottled. Pours an Amber coppery color but extremely clear with a medium head. Smell is......hoppy. As in Im sitting in a hops flower garden.   Taste is bitter, of course, but not as bad as it could possibly be.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Linus stick. This one pours a rich translucent copper color with a small white head. The aroma has a big citrus character with grapefruit and lemons. The flavor is hops forward with biter grapefruit in the forefront, filling in the sides are caramel and candied oranges. The mouthfeel is full and satisfying. The finish was just a bit short, or perhaps I was just expecting it to be longer. Overall: Ive been waiting a long time to try this one, thanks Linus. A great IPA

Pours a dark golden orange color with a small white head. Aroma of citrus, hops, malt. Flavor is malty, hoppy, citrusy, almost syrupy but well balanced and it all comes together very nicely. DFHs best regularly released beer.

Pours an attractive red amber with a thin white head. Aroma is floral and citrus hop goodness. Flavor begins with a fruity malt character and moves to citrus hops. A hint of alcohol as well. The hop flavor seems to stick to my tongue. Very tasty.

Pours a beautiful clear golden colorwith an inch of frothy off-white head. Wonderful aroma of apricots, citrus, light caramel, and over-riding hops. Fantastic creamy mouthfeel with a great fruity character at the start with the smoothest transition to a balanced yet healthy hop finish Ive ever seen in an IPA. Fantastic drink!

Draft @ Trappeze.  Nice hoppy floral aroma with citrus taste to it.  I remember having this beer years ago in 750 mL bottles and it was outstanding.  Now in 12 oz bottles or on draft it is just OK.  Has the recipe changed or are they not bottle conditioning anymore?  Different beer that is good but best IPA in US, I think not.

Im not a huge IPA fan (yet) but this was a great brew.....Poured a deep gold color and you can even see the body in this.  Aroma was sweet and full of citrus notes, very pleasing...Flavor was sweet malt with terrific fruity overtones with a very well balanced strong bitterness.....with a nice alcohole kick that is note too overpowering....Great mouthfeel! Kinda medium carbonation with a soft pallate then it kicks in when swallowed....Great beer...

If this is the best IPA in America, than I agree. Rich and full bodied, with extremely well balanced hops. Flavorful and drinkable for a 9% brew. I think it feels more put together than a lot of west coast IPAs that straight up punch you in the face

Pours with golden orange with a thin head.  Big aroma of hops but also a lot of malt.  Flavor is what I expected from an Imperial IPA, big hop flavor. However, this imperial has a huge malt backbone.  A very good IIPA.

One of the best IPAs Ive had. Excellent citrus nose. Body and mid-palate are very nice and deliver based on the nose. Finish is excellent if not perfectly appropriate. Impeccably crafted.

Wish they distributed to California. Much better than the 120 Minute which is too sweet for me.

Pours a beautiful, clear golden orange.  Very nice aroma with great citrus overtones.  Citrus comes through in the taste as well.  Beer has an oily, syrup feel in the mouth.  I havent been a huge fan of IPAs prior to having this tonight, but I can begin to see the attraction.  Aftertaste was more agreable than what I am used to with this style.
On tap at blindtiger- smells flowers, apple, soft biscuit nose and caramel. tastes honey, apple some sweet brandy notes and raisins. beautiful. an incredibly complex and well made beer.

My favorite IPA... but I havent had the 120 Minute yet.  Aroma is hoppy, but not overtly so, with mild citrus to it.  The flavor is very hoppy, citrusy, and grassy.  The citrus is very heavy in grapefruit flavor with some lemon in there as well.  Me liking this beer is big for me.  Im not a big hop guy.

12 oz. bottle.

Bought in Buffalo, God Bless America, wake up LCBO. This is my favourite IPA. Dark orange in colour with a small white head. Fruity and floral aroma. The blend of flavours is heaven, the bubbly, fruity, floral, hoppy malt taste dances in the mouth.

This embodies what an American IPA is.  Nice amber/reddish color, good nose, nice frothy white head.  First sip begins with the malt followed shortly by the hops.  This beer is so well-balanced that after 2 or 3 you still can determine what the brewewr was trying to do.  If you have the ability to try this at the Rehoboth beach brewpub make sure it is on a Monday or Friday when they are serving through the Animal, its the only way to drink it.  Truly, one of my favorites...
Hoppy, and bitter.  Not my type of beer at all.  Very bitter, astringent, in your face beer.

Had on tap at the DFH alehouse.  Wow, it smells like a garden of hops.  By far the greatest smelling beer Ive tried.  Extremely hoppy, but not unnecessarily bitter.  Predominantly floral flavor, but well blended with notes of citrus and pine.  Definitely a sipper, a superb drink.

This is the beer that got me hooked on micros.  Ive developed my palate of this brew.  The complexities in the flavor of this beer become more evident every time I drink it and I am pretty sure other beers dont taste the same to me anymore.  I always sniff the beer for a couple minutes before taking my first sip as the aroma can only be described as "freshy goodness".  I can often be found in a closet hiding with an empty bottle just sniffing away.  sniffing, and drooling.

Great beer.  Very little alcohol taste even though it has 9%  It  is moderatly hoppy and pours a nice yellow-orange.   Citrus flavors dominate, but in a good crisp way.  Drink 4 of these and you should be VERY happy!

This is a nice IPA, definitely one of the best Ive had in my few years as a beer drinker.  The aroma is very nice; hints of grapefruit and other citrus are very apparent.  The beer looks great poured into a mug, and the head is very frothy.  Upon tasting the beer, the taste of citrus becomes very dominant among subtler flavors in the beer.  Word to the wise: Dont drink too many of these because they definitely creep up on you!
Loved this beer.  Strongly hopped and strongly malted, more than a "standard double IPA."  The balance between the two was impressive, with nice depth of flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2009 Aroma was not what I was expecting.  I really didnt care for the aroma.  I got a citrus hops but also this strange copenhagen like aroma I was expecting a lot more hopy aroma since it was dry hopped.  I was scared to drink this beer because I thought it would be over the top.  When I finally to a swig it was excellent quite posibly the best IPA out there in flavor.  Citrus and other notes blend into a nice bitter finish thats not over the top.
Im not a huge IPA fan, but this was a drinkable beer along with the 60 minute. Will probably enjoy it more in the future. May rerate.

This is by far my favorite everyday drink. This ale pours nicely and immediately gets your attention. The aroma is strong and sends your nose on a search for all the complexity in the mix. It is one of the best IPAs out there, period. A full bodied ale that commands a little respect. It is  a bit pricey, ranging from around 9 to 12 bux for the 4 pack. I think its worth it, it finishes leaving you wanting another one.

Bottle pours an orange color with a white head that seems to last forever.  Medium body and aroma of pine, citrus, and some fruity smells.  Tastes like I just sipped on a drink with christmas tree soaking in the bottom.  Not much in the way of malt taste and is mostly complex flavors of hop goodness.

This beer is a bit pricey, but not as costly as Dogfishs 120 which will set you back about $10 a bottle. 120 is in a class by itself, and 90 is just one step behind. I can get this right in the Dogfish restaurant only minutes from home, it goes great with Dogfishe hamburgers and other menu fare. Has a great taste that will have you begging for more. Sold in package stores in 4 packs. A very silky smooth taste as you will want to savor the taste on your palate.

One of my favorite Imperial IPAs! I had been saving this beer for a while and it was everything I dreamed of! Golden color with a big head that dissapears to a creamy lacing. Tastes of a complex hop flavor with a blast of citrus. A beer that will leave you wanting another!

The bottle poured clear dark copper color with modest off-white head. Deep caramel aroma with resiny pine, blending as it warms into mellow florals. The flavor is intensely sweet and bitter at the same time, an exhibition of the harmony of opposites. Huge and absolutely dreamy.
Hop on the nose, hop on the tongue, hop in my mind. All this hop with a great malt complexity leads to a great beer, especially for my Winter holiday in the heat of the Valley of the Sun.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2008 A crystal clear amber-orange with a good sized fluffy head that leaves lace. The best part of this beer is the hoppy aroma. I get citrus, lychee fruit, and white grape. The taste is hop-dominated, on a solid base of caramel maltiness with some roasty notes, mostly citrus. Not quite as much bitterness and dryness as I would have liked in a DIPA, nor is the finish long enough. Finish is mostly roast malt, actually, with some bitterness.  The alcohol is amazingly well hidden. If you like the aroma and flavor of hops but are scared off by the alcohol flavor and bitterness of a true DIPA, you will enjoy this
On a Randall at the Blind Tiger.Poured a  dark amber color with a one inch head. Strong hop aroma, and a strong hop taste, with a nice bitter finish. Very good beer.
Represent Milton, DE. I feel its one of most exciting beers out their. Strong, bold, and beautiful, with a very fruity, mouth watering aroma. This beer drinks quite like a good woman.
Smooth almost bland hop aroma. Decent lacing. Smooth lightly sweet hop flavor. Caramel in color.  Smooth, clean finish with a delicious hop taste that lasts.
Great IPA, poured darker than most IPAs but with a simlar aroma.  Strong on the palate and initial flavor, long lasting with a good aftertaste.

12oz brown bottle with born on date, poured into a pint glass.  A nice, clear golden amber with consistent carbonation action, a perfect 2 finger head that sticks around.  On the nose, citrus and hops, lots of hops. You can smell it as soon as you crack open the bottle, and you can still smell it when you set the beer down. Amazing! A well balanced mix of citrus (grapefruit), grassy hops, and maybe a touch of alcohol. A nice clean smell.  The palate is erfectly balanced considering this hop explosion. Again, a nice dosage of citrus. You finally pick up the alcohol towards the end. An all around great brew. The hops are there but not overdone.  It has a nice medium to heavy body that is smooth and quenching.  I wish I could have my fridge stocked full of this. Great treat .

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2009 12oz poured into a snifter. pours darker than many IIPAs, almost a rosy amber with very little head. aroma is subtle, but delicious with pine, rose, gapefruit, maybe some peach. mouthfeel is solid, very drinkable at 9% and warms on the way down. flavor is unique to Dogfish with a hop bite balanced by a roasted, nutty (think pistachios) malt backbone. overall, an excellent brew from the east coast.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2008 Pale yellow-orange pour with a white long-lasting head.  Nice sweet piney aroma.  Sweet taste with lots of hops, slight creaminess on the finish.  I like this type of IPA with some sweetness to balance the bitterness of the hops.  This was just a little bit too sweet for my taste though.

Bottle pours a clear copper orange with a medium white head.  Powerful aroma of citrus, pine, hops, and cashews.  Great, rich, complex flavor with a splendid combination of malt and hops and a nice bitter finish.  I really love this beer!

Best imperial IPA made IMO. All the alcohol and hops notes as the other big IPAs out there. But unlike the other IPAs this one is balanced and just not over hopped for the sake of being bitter. This one is in my all time top 10. Thank god for the good people of Dogfish and great beer they provide.

12 oz. Bottle.  Pours a deep ruddy orange color with a medium white head.  Aroma is crisp, with some citrus character and that classic dogfish grapefruitish hop signature.  Hop flavor is upfront in this beer and has a heavy tongue buckling resinous character that I love.  Palate is incredibly well balanced with a strong malt profile that holds up to the hops and yet somehow refrains from exhibiting that syrupy quality that dooms many IIPAs.  Finish displays some bitterness and just the right touch of alcohol warmth.  From a brewery that makes some excellent beers, this is one of their best.

A very good IIPA by DFH. The malt to hop ratio is almost perfect in this brew. The nice juicy hop flavors are more present in the flavor then on the nose, but flavor is definitely most important. Pours a great looking slightly cloudy sunburst color with decent head. The palate is absolutely perfect, not to syrupy and thick, but not too puny and thin. Certainly one of the better IIPAs out there. I could definitely drink these all nght long.
Just an excellent beer.  Lovely hops that arch over the malty foundation quite smoothly.  I am having one and preparing to play cribbage.  Ill let you know how it turns out.
Pours golden-amber, little head, tasted far more true to the IPA style than the 120 min, initially astringent taste with slightly bitter finish, good beer

bottle. pours an attractive copper-orange color with one finger of off-white head. nose of pine and grapefruit. Im very surprised that the bitterness isnt overwhelming. it is very much present, but it doesnt push me away. has a nice malt backbone that holds it all up. notes of lemon and grapefruit are present in the flavor. has a prickly but oily feeling in the mouth. nice crisp bitter finish. well done Dogfish Head!

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2008 On a Randall at the Blind Tiger NYC: Aroma: Thick resinous hop character. Malt is juicy and lush.
Apppearance: Amber/orange almost no head retention.
Flavour: Big grassy hop character, like biting into a pine cone and a graprefruit rind. Big alcoholic zap which lingers in the mouth.
Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, thin carbonation, resinous and alcoholic.
Overall: Big thick and rich but very drinkable. A dangerous beer with lots of hop flavour and alcohol character to thin it out and keep it from being cloying.
this is an amazing beer.  very malty, but not syrupy sweet.  great orange/citrus hop arome and flavor.  hard to believe that this is 9%...going on taste alone, this could easily be a session beer
Excellent IPA.  Dogfish is brewed about 15 minutes from where I live, so that is awesome.  Represent.  As for the beer itself, it is definitely quite hoppy and the citrus comes through splendidly.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2009 Very nice, and quite smooth for a double IPA... one of the most mellow and best balanced.  Malt does come through and the hops arent overpowering. Citrus and pine, and a more malty sweetness than many. Good carbonation contributes to a complex palate and long finish.

have had it bottled and on tap @ dogfish head alehouse. amazing beer. hefty 9% alcohol. very refreshing. sweet floral spicy aroma. flavor - malty and floral sweetness, citrus. very hoppy, but the hops balance nicely with the malty, flowery sweetness. very hoppy finish w/ hints of herbs and flowers. color- beautiful golden orange. nice white head. love this beer. would drink every day if i could afford it.

Sweet fruity resin nose.  Golden amber with medium head.  Deep sweet malts with the multiple layers of the unique hopping process showing through.  Hard to describe, intensely hoppy, but the hops are not intense?  It has huge hop character without being overwhelming.  Body is full and rounded with great tight carbonation and a smooth long finish.  A very sophisticated and unique take on an Imperial IPA.  It very well could be one of the best available.
tap in Hop Devil, New York. my introduction to proper American IPAs, and possibly the most intense hop flavour I had encountered at the time.
If you like hops this one is for you. Certainly in my normal beer rotation.
EXCELLENT VERY HOPPY BITTER TATSE. MY FAVORITE IMPERIAL IPA. IF YOU ENJOY THIS STYLE BEER; THIS IS A MUST BUY.

(Bottle, Oliver Twist, Stockholm) Amber colour with frothy, off-white head. Fruity, hoppy nose with pine needles, resin and grapefruit. Fruity, hoppy taste initially with notes of pine needles, resin, black-currant and grape. After a while the solid malt base makes itself more and more evident, with toffee, chocolate, caramel and fudge, then leaving with a long, hoppy, piney finish. Oh dear, this is absolutely gorgeous ... and surprisingly well balanced. Brilliant beer!

Pours a beautiful amber color with a small white head that disappears shortly after hitting the glass.  The nose is all hops, powerful earthy, floral smells fill the air above the glass.  Not much carbonation on the tongue, smooth but not heavy drinking.  The great hop taste hides the alcohol well and a strong bitter finish is the epitamy of this style.  A ramped up version of Dogfish Head 60 Minute IPA and one of the best Imperial IPAs out there.
Toasted aromas, lychee nut and exotic fruit, a sweet toffee palate, with a touch of brine and grass.
Bought this beer at Beers of the World in Rochester.  Well worth the 11 bucks/4 pack.  A must in my opinion if you like IPAs.
Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA is a fantastic beer with citrus taste, extremely drinkable, with a nice aroma.
Hazy amber orange with white head. Citrus and piney nose. Hops hit you like a ton of bricks! Awesome beer from start to finish. A++
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA is a light amber color with a nice off-white head. The taste is full of hopps while not biting like Bells Hopslam. THis is a very drinkable Imperial IPA.

Bottle.  Pours true amber with a medium off-white head that dissipates quickly into very thin foam.  Aromas of spruce, juniper, and citrus.  A little sweet and malty when it hits the tongue, but this quickly morphs into a full-mouth, hoppy bitterfest.  The hops are strong, but they are actually pretty well-balanced.  Great carbonation with small bubbles.  In addition to hops, this beer actually finishes with notes of a lingering, mildly astringent herbal digestif

12 oz bottle from a trade with thecheeseman. pours orange with a small white head. aromas are a ton of piney hops. basically if you took a pine forest and shredded then multched youd get the same aroma. flavours are huge piney hops with noticable malt structure. the finish is not as bitter as the aroma would lead you to believe and i found this very palatable. the hoppiest brew ive had yet.
Pours copper with creamy off-white head.  Aroma of floral hops, caramel malt and light fruit.  Flavor to match with a bit of pine.

I found this in Springfield, VA Total Wine and Beverage in the keg cooler section.  Picked up the sixtel keg and it has been a favorite of everyone that visits the house.
Deep flavors with a nice hoppy bite in the beginning.
You truly dont want to stop drinking.

Wow!  A true work of art in a glass here.  An excellent beer to pair with several foods, like grilled fish and good steaks.  A must try, at whatever price you can get it at, if you like a malty and hoppy IPA.  Very extreme and very delicious.  I can only image what the 120 minute IPA is like!

Bottle. Transparent copper pour with a creamy off white head. Aroma of earthy and floral hops, toasted caramel malt, light tropical fruits, and light boozey fruits...citrus comes out a bit as well. Flavors of boozey fruits, toasted malt, caramel, citrus and light pine...a bit of pineapple as well. Medium-thick body, bitter/boozey toasty with a toasty/bitter finish. Overall a really balanced IIPA if there ever were such a thing .
This is my favorite IPA which makes it close to my favorite beer.  Creamy thick head with nice orange copper color.  Taste fruit citrus with some cream texture.  Beautiful hoppy finish I want more.

Pours dark orange with a white head. Aromas of pine, citrus, flowers. Very sweet that starts off very hoppy and finishes nice and malty. Very well balanced. Fullbodied with a creamy mouthfeel and average carbonation. An excellent IIPA.

Bottle. Outstanding IPA...best Ive had. Pours orange/copper with a very nice head and great lacing. The aroma is incredible, layers of floral, citrus, and herbal hops, you just want to keep smelling it. Flavor is the same, very full and complex hops but the bitterness is subdued by the sweet maltiness. Finishes with lingering remnants of the hops but again, the bitterness is not sharp or unpleasant at all. I was told that once you try the 90 minute, you can never go back to the 60. I think that may be true, although in some situations, the lighter and less malty 60 may be more fitting. Cheers on the great IPA, Dogfishhead!
Pours a beautiful full gold color with a red tinge.  Tastes strongly of hops with a very bitter finish.  A really great IPA.
UPDATED: DEC 4, 2008 amazing aroma, as if in a garden of herbs, the taste, OUT OF THIS WORLD! would pour this in my cereal and eat it for breakfast!

Had this beer at the brewpub in Reheboth Beach, DE and it was amazing.  My favorite beer bar none.  90 Min is everything I love in a beer.  A spicy, floral nose; a huge beer yet balanced but finishes with a piney hop exposion.  90 Min is smooth and well hopped.  It is a hop lovers dream as well as a beer lovers dream.  This would be my house beer if A. I was rich or B. I was a blazing, rip-roaring alcoholic or C. I was single.  Drinking this beer is like playing 18 holes at Pebble Beach or better yet strumming on Willie Nelsons guitar or even drinking Pinots with Miles.  A poetic brew...no?

Fantastic!  Heard lots of good things about this IPA...where to begin...loved the hop flavor and even though its very hoppy its not the skunky hops that i dont care for.  Has a citrus flavor combined with a slight malt ending.  This beer rocks...gonna have again

Perhaps the most sublimal example of an IPA, the 90 minute is definitely a great find.  Try it and be overwhelmed.

it has a medium, but substanial head.  the flavor is divine, for an ipa. there is never such a thing as too much hops!  enojy it for its phenomenal balance of alcohol, malt, and hops.
Pricey, but excellent hopiness, dont mind just drinking it out of the bottle. Very drinkable, tough to taste high alc content, from what I see here tho, SCARY amount of calories

Off tap...Pours a copper red w/ a slight white head. On the nose I got heavy citrus, some pine and caramel. The taste was a superb mix of the nose. The beer is very smooth for 9%. The alcohol is present, but never overpowers the beer. Very nice dry finish, and a nice bitterness that sticks around. My favorite DIPA!
Yum. this is a favorite IPA of mine. Its on the heavy side. Its super aromatic, super bitter. Silky. Just delicious and good.
UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 (USA) Red Amber color with Sm-White head. The Beer has a Citrus/Grapefruit taste!!!   bitter finish, pretty good stuff.

Bottled. Golden-amber pour, clear, with a tan, lacy head. Nose is resin, pine, grapefruit, and hops. Flavor is graprefruit, pine, honey, sweet caramel, toffee. Finish is hoppy and dry with alcohol notes.

Ah Dogfish Head, a magnificent achievement. I can not add anything that hasnt been said. Just a wonderful experience. Bitter, sweet, citrus, bread, pine all in the same glass. Take a sip, let it warm up, youll find different things to rave about.
UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 Pours a BEAUTIFUL red-amber color. Great smell, great taste, with lops of hops and malt, but never overpowering. Would definitely recommend.
great beer, great flavor, smell, appearance...yet the feel was a bit syrupy/sticky...would def drink again

Sampled through a 12 oz bottle, tap, and a Randall.  This is another one of those "what can I say that hasnt been said" beers.  Honestly, nothing probably.  This stuff is damn good, drink it when you feel like it!  (Finally got around to rating it after having one for the first time in a year or so...)

Tasted from Delirium Tremens snifter.  Pours a clear, amber-copper color with a sparse off-white head.  On the nose:  lemon peel, pine, caramel, even a hint of milk chocolate.  Big, broad palate provided by the pervasive malts is spotted with more caramel and citrus, toast, and spice/tobacco notes.  The hops are aggressive while the beer remains remarkably refreshing--delicious.

Pours a beautiful copper with a full, off white head. Nose is hoppy and sweet with a touch of resiny pine and a hint of caramel malt peaking through. Flavor is on the sweet side with pineapple and more malt than Im used to in a IIPA. Smooth flavor with a subtle bitterness in the finish. Very nice brew.

still in the top ten beers ive ever had, the 90 minute is one of the best imperial ipas out there.  rich in aroma and a clear golden reddish brown in appearance, it is incredible that the hops appear on the palate as much as they do with the amount of malt they use.  not a overly heavy mouthfeel, actually maintains a sort of cleanliness.  a must try for anyone!

Distinctive hoppy/floral aroma.  This one is heavily carbonated and will bruise the palate.  Good flavor, but a little too much bite on the backend takes away some from it.  Overall solid, but I much prefer Bells Two Hearted Ale for IPAs.
Phenomenal!!!!! thats all i can say nothing bad at all!  perfect beer!!!!!!!
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2008 Dogfish Heads 90 Minute Imperial IPA is excellent. For all the hops in it, it is very well-balanced.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2009 If I could only afford to buy this beer every day.  Smells great, tastes even better.  I need to go get another bottle right now.  For an IPA this is unusually creamy with that satisfying bitter bite in the finish that you hope for.

Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA
ABV: 9%

Purchased at: Circle
Consumed on: 02.04.08

first impression: Bubbly, frothy thick head, active, with great aroma that permeates.

Color, depth: A crisp amber with great depth and variation. Magnificent color with clarity. A beautiful beer. A definite change in color throughout the glass.
Belgian lace, legs: A head to be proud of, and the lace hangs nicely. Lots of foam.

Aroma: Smell is enticing and allows you to taste from a distance.

Hoppiness, bite: Knocks you over. Almost burns your palate. If I didnt love hops, I couldnt drink it. I love hops and it delivers in droves.
Maltiness, flavor: Lots of foamy flavor - malt undertones, but second to the hops without a choice.

Weight: Weight is good, but not overly heavy.
Mouthfeel: Airy, bubbles and air everywhere. A little bit chewy, somehow, despite its clarity.

second impression: A hefty buzz after one 12 oz beer. Its remarkable, in its hops, flavor, and color. Lace is the richest Ive tested so far.

I cant believe it took me so long to get around to rating this arsekickin beer. Simply put, one of the best widely available beers. Wonderful nose of piney resin and citrus-grapefruit hops. Big  malt backbone with lots of residual sweetness, and perfectly balance. Dogfish Head always does a fantastic job of balancing malt with hops, citrus with pine, you name it.

12 oz bottle  cloudy amber pour .decent white head, good lacing. aroma of pine and grapefruit. big hop flavor with some citrus and raisin notes.   pretty heavy and malty (sort of like bourbon )for being so hoppy . pretty good

I had this for the first time in a Chicago pub. Very delightful right from the first scent after popping off the cap. Pours ever so gracefully, its no wonder that Im putting this beer at the top of my list. Great hoppy flavor, something you would most definitely expect from the name. Dogfish does a fantastic job of brewing this, Im sorry, I just dont have anything bad to say about this IPA.

This beer pours a medium copper color with a nice active light tan head.  Busy carbonation is a constant here.  Aroma is as nice as I have ever experienced on any kind of Pale Ale and shows off the balance.  Hop taste is indeed extreme but is pleasantly balanced by the malt.  Delicious, and this is coming from someone who is not a fan of hoppy beers.  In the mouth it is silky smooth.  Very well done!!!
One of the best Imperial IPAs out there.  Also try Averys Maharaja!  But this is easily Dogfish heads best IPA -beats out the 120min in taste, but not in drunken-ness

bottle from 99 Bottles in federal way.  beautiful copper pour, with a nice lively head.  pine needle nose.  the flavor is wonderfully hoppy.  unlike the 120 minute, this beer is more drinkable and lighter on the palate, though the mouth feel is still nice.  a great beer.

Bottle. Orange gold, slightly cloudy, 2-inch loose head. Aroma of grapefruit and hint of pine. Taste: pink grapefruit with a bit of the rind, mild acidity, sweet with balancing bitterness. Ends in long, smooth finish with bourbon-like taste. Mouthfeel is full and pleasantly lively.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2008 This one is very good - Strong on the hops.  The taste and smell is very hoppy.  Beautiful!  Citrus notes in the taste.  Can taste the alcohol a little.  Get yourself one of these today!

Pours a hazy copper-golden color, with a thick white head and some enjoyable lacing.  Great aroma of hops and malt, with citrus and wood notes.  Flavor is amazing, lots of malt with dark fruits and citrus, followed by the alcohol warmth.  Great beer, and great IPA.

Not as good as the hype, but still a damn good beer! I feel that the 90 minute ipa is a bit too malty for my taste, but its brings me back to reality for other styles. I tend to forget how great other beers are. Ive become too much of a hophead. thank you dogfish

Draft. Poured amber in color with some haze/turbidity. Nice white head with some lacing and retention. Massive aroma of pine, grapefruit and caramel. The flavor is big and bold with hops coming at you from all directions. Primary flavor is piney with some citrus notes and raisin character. A really nice big IPA that is enjoyable in small portions.
Amber pour with thin white head. Hops are as expected, strong alcohol taste but very well blended in this IIPA. Another great beer from Dogfish

Bottled, consumed on 02/04/08.  Clear honey/burnished copper hue.   Good carbonation, thin skin of foam for head.  Aroma: maybe some Simcoe hops, grapefruit as well.  Flavor: very hoppy (duh!), but the pine and citrus are not as overwhelming as feared.  Some sweet malt character is apparent and fruit (apricot?).  Bitter, but in the right way.  This is much easier to drink than some "single" IPAs!  Exceptional.

Great amber pour with a very thick and hoppy head that takes a while to calm.  Hoppy, but very smooth taste and a noticeably strong alcohol content.  No undesired aftertaste on the palat.  This beer has been put together very well and is the best IPA (first Imperial) I have tried.  Hats off to Dogfish.

Bottle from Piccadilly in Champaign, IL. Brilliant amber body with a slight, off-white head. Fruity, obvious hop-y aroma. An explosion of hops, with hints of citrus. Excites the mouth with carbonation, and a slight alcohol nose. Excellent IIPA
pineapple citrus oily alpha aroma, clear light amber. oily hops everywhere up front, gives way to the caramely malt, more aromatic hops in the finish. you feel the 9% but never taste it.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2008 Poured reddish gold with smallish head.  Huge aroma of hops and sweet malts.  Initial sweet malts (citrus and caramel) is quickly dominated by hops.  Seriously bitter aftertaste which lasts for a long time.  Big taste.  Fretty full mouthfeel.  Fairly well balanced for such a hoppy beer.  Im not a hophead but I can appreciate this beer.

Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA is a crystal clear, very sparkling amber ale with a small off-white head that leaves nice, even lacing.  It has a very floral aroma.  Perfume, wood, resin and sugar are present in the nose.  It is medium bodied and reasonably smooth.  The flavor is very resiny with a round sweetness.  It tastes medicinal, minty... maybe a bit of oak?  The aftertaste is green.  Maybe a touch sweet, but well done.

Bottle. Golden orange with very good clarity. Slight off white-head with traces of lacing. Aroma is mainly resiny hops (citrus, pine) with some toast malt notes. Flavor of resiny hops blends very nicely into a strong alcohol flavor. Hop flavor is mainly pine and citrus. Some toast malt, sweetness, and fruity notes apparent as well. Firm bitterness kicks in after a couple of seconds, but does not overwhelm. Medium-bodied with moderate carbonation. Fairly long finish of hop biterness and alcohol warmth. Excellent beer. Big and hoppy, yet well balanced and complex.
On tap. Delicious aroma. The hops instantly hits the senses. pours a darker amber almost orange hue. Taste is extremely overpowering, but in a good way. Definitely a beer made for sipping.

Reddish copper hue with little white head.  Super hoppy scents consisting of citrus, mainly grapefruit.  Solid body a little high on the carbonation, but thats a negligible note.  Hops bitterness and thick raisiney malt flavors.  Slight candied finish thats clean and refreshing.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2008 Pours golden honey color, with a thick frothy off white head. Extraordinary sweet hops smell immediately. Taste of strong hops and a hint fruity sweetness, finishes with smooth hop flavor. Overall great IPA

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009  I really like what DFH did here, going with something slightly different. Malts and carmel are in every sip. Very, very awesome.  I would say this is just below Hopslam and Dreamnaught in the IPA, but its a very close 3 way race. In fact, Id like to try them all next to each other sometime. I have a feeling that this one might actually win when tasted at the same time.

Immediately noticeable strong smell of hops, thick and pungent. Pours a strong copper color in the glass, with a moderate head that lasts a little while. Creamy mouthfeel. Wonderful flavor of hops and bitterness. One can taste the sip just before the liquid touches the lips. Slight malt flavor balances out the strong hops without detracting from their wonderful flavor.

strong hops smell with some fruit as well.  taste is of strong hops and citrus.  just the right amount of carbination as well.  goes down very smooth with a nice bite at the end.  I would purchase again.
Near perfect IPA.  Wonderful kick great hoppy aroma and flavor.  Nice and smooth going down with just a little kick at the end to let you know its there.  Great beer.
Great IPA. Nice taste of hops and smells strong of hops as well. Excellent looking beer, little bite of an aftertaste.

A great IPA.  Quite possibly the best I have ever had.  Hops assault your nose as soon as the bottle is opened.  The hops seep out even more as the beer is poured into a glass.  The color is a nice light copper.  A good two finger head that is a slight tan is left on top.  The flavor explodes as it hits your mouth with huge amounts of florally and citrusy hops.  It ends on a light malt flavor that does not affect the hop characters that are left in your mouth when finished.  Quite smooth going down the throat albeit nicely carbonated.

This is the best IPA I have ever had. The first thing that you notice when the bottle is opened is a wonderful hop aroma witch gets better after it is poured. A perfect balance of hops malt and high alcohol.

12 oz bottle pours  a hazy copper color.  Aroma is  is lots of hops with some maltiness.  Flavor is much the same with some alcoholic spice showing up.  A nicely balanced beer from a brewer that likes to go over the top.  Not that that is a bad thing.
Very good beer, very balanced taste, good mix of citrus flavor. Also a great beer to mix or wash food down with. Loved it

Pours kind of copper with medium off white head.  Aroma of hops, fruit, and a nice balance with some malt.  Nice mouthfeel and body with a very balanced taste considering the amount of hops.  Very drinkable which can be unbelievably dangerous.
bottle. golden amber pour. Beautiful white head. very citrus. very bright. great bite on aftertaste. An incredible IPA.

An extreme IPA, the Dogfish Head 90 minute has one of the most amount of hops youll ever find in a beer (until you try the 120 minute IPA, of course). However, this hoppy flavor is largely hidden/balanced perfectly by the high alcohol level. As a result, its actually a hint of a sweet beer, with more of a hoppy aftertaste. If you really want to taste the hops, take a bite of a bread before drinking. This will hide the alcohol flavor and really allow the hops to come out.

The 90 minute IPA makes me think that it was an interesting experiment in brewing that turned out extremely well. Good beer, good price.

Pours a very nice copper color with a slight head (when poured slowly), strong hoppy aroma, with a hint of fruitiness. Great bitter taste with a fruity finish. This is by far my favorite IPA out of the 15 or so Ive tried.
UPDATED: MAY 10, 2010 One of the obvious best in the dogfish head category.  Good hoppy flavor and a strong leader in the IPA category.  Worth trying if you get the chance.
bottle. golden amber pour. Beautiful white head. very citrus. very bright. great bite on aftertaste. An incredible IPA.

A deep amber with a thin white head. Clean citrus hops in the nose. The taste hits hard with tons of hops a subtle hint of alcohol, overall the flavor is remarkably well balanced. Very smooth going down. Great brew.

A clear golden amber with very little head. Leaves just a lining of cream around the glass. Aroma is mainly of pine, citrus fruit. Flavor is of hops, sugar, pine and citrus (grapefruit). Carbonation is medium-high with a light body. A good IPA.

Poured into a pint glass. Goldenrod body sits under a one finger white head. Head reduces to a moderately large halo and leaves some sitcky resiny lacing on the glass. A quick swirl actually reconstitutes the one finger head. 

Piney citrusy hops on the nose, grapefruit, grainy malt 

Taste follows the nose, also maybe some apricot, brown sugar. Nice oily hop explosion here, but not overly bitter. 

Carbonation is perfect, finish is drying and entices the next sip, and alcohol is well hidden. 

Very easy to drink, just beware the 9% abv.
A golden pour with a very hoppy and citrusy aroma.  Hides it alcohol well.  An excellent IPA overall

Underrated is the 120 Minute IPA, overrated is this one...why waste a night drinking a beer that is average when their is something produced by the same brewer that is exceptional.  This is just a watered-down version of its Big Brotha!!!  This isnt a bad IPA, just nothing extraordinary...citrus, pine, etc., etc., etc....

Copper colored beer with thin head and light carbonation.  Has a strong aroma of pine, citrus and spice.  Similar taste along with some caramel and mint.  Some notes of sherry too.  Reasonably drinkable for 9% abv.
12 0z. , big lacy head with nutbrown color and with lots of caramel flavor, malt and very smooth, did not get as much hoppiness but very finished beer nice,

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2008 Pours a gold color with a medium frothy white head and plenty of lacing.  Decent hop aroma with some pineapple and peach.  Im directly comparing this to the Hopslam.  This is slightly bitter and grassier than Hopslam, but not as much citrus.  The bitterness is well-balanced, though, and the alcohol is hidden well.

This USED to be one of my favorite beers until Dogfish Head ruined it!  Shame on you!

It now tastes like a sugary, nutty, caramel malted piece of shit.  Where are the hops?
Thick head and plenty of carbonation. Good balance of hops and alcohol that allows a smooth overall experience.

My 100th rating! I was hoping to get my hands on a World Wide Stout for this one but I couldnt find one today, so I picked up a 4 pack of DHs next best offering and I am not disappointed.  It pours an amber color with a perfect head and oooohh the aroma.  If there is such a thing as hop coffee I am positive that this is what it smells like.  The flavor is more of the same.  Hops with a mild roasted taste and a slight citrus accent combine into perfection.  I love my stouts but this is hands down the best beer I have ever had.

Beautiful beer. Extremely harsh hop aromas. It made my eyes water; I have never had anything this hoppy before. There are also some toasted malts, cherry and apple in the background somewhere. The appearence consists of ungodly lacing from the head; absolutely amazing. Color is a clear fizzy copper. The head is a creamy off-white with good retention. The flavor is quite complex with a nice fruity bitter finish. There is an echo of a stronger type of alcohol in their, but I cannot place it. I REALLY want to try the 120 quite badly after this one. Great brew.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2009 This beer has a strong aroma of hops and other fruity characters. Red-ish in color, with medium size head. Flavor is what makes this beer. Strong in the hop catagory. This is one of my classic beers and has been a favorite since I first had it in 2004. In my opinion this is what beer should taste like! This beer introduced me to the craft beer world*****Update***** I recently had it in a bottle, way malty then I remembered, a little let down to be honest. Sometimes their batches taste alot different from the last batch.....But also just had it fresh on tap at the brewpub in Rehoboth...awesome!! So fresh and super smooth. It is worth the trip, especially if you can get it through the "Randell"!!! Its really hit or miss in a bottle..
Dark amber body with a small white head. Very citrusy hop scent. There are aromas of orange, lemon, and lime. There is a nice malty flavor balanced with citrus and a bit of spice a gum.
For a "big beer," it hides its alcohol content very well.  Nice hoppiness with malty undertones.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear golden amber with slight reddish tint and a thin white head.  Smell is of citrus and pine hops with sweet malt underneath.  Taste and mouthfeel are not subtle.  Citrus is strong and sweet malt is present.  Your mouth you are grabbed by the power of hops!  I dont think it is balanced with hops very strong.  Malt helps to counter giving a sweetness to prevent the bitterness from being too much, but hops rule here. Have to re-rate as Ive had quite a few better IIPAs since tasting this and have had it again and realize it doesnt stack up to where I had it listed before.  It is decent, but not on par with many west coast IIPAs.
Big floral hoppy nose. Citrusy hop bite coupled with an earthy hop presence. So, yeah, its very hoppy. Almost too hoppy, but well-balanced for all that. Enjoyable.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2009 Nice IPA.   Not overly hoppy.  Taste is fairly bold composing of citrus, orange, malt, fruity hops, lemongrass, and florals. Alcohol is hidden well.  I dont think it deserves all its praise.  *** After several repeated tasting of this brew, I realize this is actually awesome.... +.4
a reddish color.  plenty of hops, if that is what you like. nice bitterness.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2008 Bottle. Appearance: Clear amber red, beige head. Aroma: Grassy hops, some citrus. Palate: Medium, mouthfilling. Flavor: Floral hops, citrus. Overall: Great malt balance, very drinkable.

Pours a lightish amber with quite small head, eventually subsiding into nothing more than a veneer. Aroma was about as hoppy as one could possibly imagine. All other senses were shut down to accommodate for such a powerful blast. Flavor was like no other IPA Ive ever experienced.
