The massive quantities of hops were quite notable, but the malt content was exceptionally higher than I expected, and seemed to balance out the hops to create a smooth feeling. This in no way detracts from the hops, however, as they make themselves known throughout. Alcohol content is goes completely unnoticed despite its rather high 9%, as the mind is too focused on the hop assault. Mouth feel is typical of the average pale ale, but due to the higher than normal malt presence, it feels slightly richer than one would expect. This beer is just plain excellent, and undoubtedly lives up to its reputation as one of the best Imperial IPAs out there.
sparkling amber. Exciting aroma of pine/fruit/grapes/raisins. Complex taste with thicker mouth feel and much sweeter than most IPAs. Exceptional beer, but almost too sweet & rich...

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2009 [rerate] Ive had this beer a few times this year and it has been disappointing.  Either my tastes have changed or this beer has.  Or possibly a bad batch.  Its been over syrupy and sweeter than before, with noticeably less hops.  

[previous rating 7/5/8/4/18] 
12oz bottle.  A darker amber color with a nice white head.  Strong hoppy/malty aroma that lures you in.  Intense flavor of resin hops backed up by malt and some alcohol. A wonderful IIPA that always stands out. Excellent bitterness in the finish.

good brew, more fruity/sweeter than a typical IPA, with a very heavy mouthfeel that offsets the bitterness.  malt and citrus a bit overpowering.  i actually prefer the "alehouse 75" at the DFH alehouse - a mix of 60-minute and 90-minute.
Nice brew! Nice hop flavor and complex recipe of several ingredients. Very sweet finish (which I actually dont prefer) however, very solid ale and obviously masterly brewed!

On tap.   Pours a copper color with a nice dense tan colored head, lacing.   Aroma is grapefruit, pine, caramel.   Flavor is intense blast of grapefruit, sweet malt, floral hops, raisin.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finished with a blast of sweet sticky malty goodness.   Great.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2008 This is my favorite Imperial IPA. The beer finishes extremely clean and crisp. Poures a carmely kind of deep gold color and has a beautiful tannish head. Grapefruit/citrus and a smoothness that is amazing.

12 oz. bottle 
Pours a burnt orange color with very little head. Smells of grapefruit, hop flowers. Has a substantial body but without feeling syrupy. 
The taste surprized me with its super smooth malt sweetness which was on a par with its strong hop presence. The two contrasts meshed perfectly. The 9.0 abv masks itself well. Finishes with a bitter sweet hop taste. 
Excellent.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 2, 2008 Draught at the Pub in Ida Noyes in snifter.  Clear dark amber with thick, frothy white head.  Aroma is sweeter than most IPAs, with pine and grapefruit.  Its hard to believe this is 90 IBU, very fruity and sweet.  The alcohol also softens the bitterness, but in a very pleasant way.  Very long flavor profile, not sharp at all.  Heavy and slighly syrupy, I couldnt drink a whole lot at one sitting, but i dont think thats what they had in mind.  Very, very good.
full, rich and hoppy with strong citrus notes. copper color with a nice head that dissipated during consumption. a real beer drinkers beer

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2008 Amber color with nice off-white creamy head.  Beautiful lacing. Hoppy/grassy nose. Pretty thick smooth body. Piney/Grapefruit/citrus/sweet/raisin taste. Bitter finish that grows. Not as great as I had hop(p)ed.

Bottled on 11/29/2006.  Drank on 5/5/2007.  Golden copper in color the beer poured a 1/4" head that dissipated and left some island lacing.  The nose was filled with piney hops, grapefruit, caramel malt and some tropical fruits (orange, pineapple).  In the mouth the beer was weighty and had a wonderfully rich texture.  The huge hops were very well-balanced in the palate with sweet hops.  Overall, this was a wonderfully balanced beer that has a lot going for it.

I liked this beer a lot.  I could clearly taste grapefruit, but It wasnt as citrusy as some of the other highly hopped beers Ive had.  It was an easy drinker, and though I only had 2 bottles, I could have ketp going.  Great beer!

On tap.  Poured a deep amber color with a white head.  Aroma  of grapfruit, and citrusy hops.  Taste is kinda sweet.  The citrusy hops and the big malt backbone work together and make this beer very well balanced.  Had to buy a case of this after the first try.  Nice job DFH.

12 oz bottle and draft, this is always a good one to have as much as possible.  THis is my favorite IPA.  Smells and taste of grapefruit.  Very balanced beer.  Nothing has yet to better than this beer for me and I am a Hop Lover.  Thanks Kluba

Purchased at Bodega Brewpub in LaCrosse, Wisconsin.  I was very impressed by this beer.  Strong citrus and hop character in the aroma.  Medium golden pour with short lasting white head.  strong hop character that was well balanced with the alcohol.  Tons of grain also helped in the balancing.   Would absolutely buy again. Best IPA I have hade thus far.

Bottle and draft, whenever and wherever possible. This to me is the DIPA that all others are compared.  I cant believe that I have never rated 90min. A solid malt backing to a perfect balance of hop bitterness, flavor, and aroma. I flip-flop on my thought with this score, it may be a "5.0"!, but I have a hard time rating a perfect score. If there is a perfect IPA/DIPA, or just hoppy ale in general, this is it.

i drank alot that night.... then i found a bottle shop/ beer joint.... threw up outside after chugging a chimay 22 bomber... anyway.... i remember high fiving a bar full of people and chanting "90-90-90" so it was pretty good.

the thick fresh hop aroma this beer has is one of the very reasons i love to drink beer.
drinking it, it becomes more complex.  very lively on the palate, sweet and citrus, with the bitter of an imp ipa.  very drinkable.  
could be up amongst the best, not at the very top of my list though...

Draft at Ashleys in Ann Arbor.  Pours an amber color with a medium head.  The aroma and taste is of hops, hops, and then more hops.  There is slight citrus taste, with a little sweetness to balance.  There is no mistaking that this is a double IPA, and its a good one.

This beer looks great. There is a lovely brown/caramel/peach color to this beer. I believe that this is the first time I have even given a beer a 5 in appearance. The head just sits on top of my beer in a nice and compact manner. It looks delicious. I have had this numerous times before, but never actually gave it a rating. I never usually comment on the lacing because I dont consider it that big of a deal, but with this beer the lacing looks great. The aroma is also wonderful. Just a nice and fresh citrus/pine hop aroma. The taste is very nice. Very smooth hop taste. The beer is very creamy, and has an awesome palate. The hop aroma just is all over the place. There is a nice alochol burn at the back of my throat. It is a warming alcohol burn not a bad one. Considering it is freezing outside! The beer also has a noticeable sweetness to it. Very smooth and awesome I.P.A one of my favorite beers for the time being. Just has everything an I.P.A. should have.

Bottle. Bottled 11/28/07. Pours amber colored with off-white head. As far as aroma, it seems like I have my nose stuck into a glass of fresh hop flowers. Tastes a little more viscous that expected, very hoppy, but not harsh. Balanced nicely with malt. Very nice.

This one is much smoother than the 60 maybe because of the increased brew time? No bitterness usually associated with other IPAs.Hops and malt tend to jel together quite well on this one ..Highly recommend espically if you can get this on draft!

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2008 Aroma was plenty of hops and citrus and a nice touch of sweet malts.  It poured a nice amber red with a one-finger head that persisted through the drinking and left nice lacing.  The flavor was remarkably balanced.  In spite of 90 IBUs, it didnt leave any bitter aftertaste.  It was really great, though there was a slight kick of alcohol.  The mouthfeel was remarkably smooth and was my favorite part of this beer.  I will definitely be picking up more of these.  Re-rate:  I took the average of the two.  The biggest difference Im noting after having rated a lot more beer is that while theres a nice floral and citrus flavor, its just not very complex.  Its a lot of hops and lot of malts, but thats it.  No intricacy, but still quite tasty.
Pours clear amber. The aroma is hops for sure, a touch of citrus too. The taste is a very smooth malt and hops blend, with a nice lingering hop aftertaste. Beautiful execution.

bottle. poured a burgandy color. the initial smell was of hops, spied herbs and brown sugar. very strong clove taste really bitter aftertaste but yet its good. superb beer. dogfish head never disappoints.

Draught. Pours dark amber-brown with a moderate white head. Aroma is fairly complex malts (citrus, caramel, and maybe honey) along with citrus and floral hops. Flavor is citrus and earthy hops against the same malt backbone, with bittering hops in the finish. Pretty good on the whole; a very robust IIPA. I probably slightly prefer the 60-minute IPA (contrary to most people here), but this is an excellent beer as well.
Clear orange of color with a light, fast disappering head. An aroma of grain, hops, grapefruit and perfume. A flavor of sweet malt, hops and citrus.

Served to me a clean dark orange/amber with a creamy head that goes away slowly. Smells of exquisite floral hops, grapefruit, some malt and a hint of fig. Tastes like freshly cut piney hops, citrusy rind with no sign of the alcohol. Right before the punch of hops seems over the top the malt quickly balances it out in perfect fashion. Finishes deliciously, hoppy dry and bitter with excellent carbonation. Drinks as smooth as a babys bottom. An excellent choice and a must try.
Bottled.  90 IBUs and no harsh bitterness!  Nothing but sweet pink grapefruit and mild hops in the aroma and flavour.  Fantastic IIPA, especially for people adverse to a little bitterness.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2012 Bottled on 10/25/07, so Im drinking this nice and fresh. Gotta say that this beer seems to have gone a bit downhill of late, though its still quite enjoyable. The hops dont quite pop like they used to, and the beer is less than bright. So the admirable malt backing now makes this beer a bit more mealy than it used to be. Still high quality, as you can see by the score, but its slipped a notch or two in my estimation.
Pours dark amber color.  Immediate hoppy aroma with slight citrus blend.  Nice hop flavor with only hint of bitterness.  Highly recommended for those who like thier Imperial IPA

Deep orange and amber pour into a snifter.  Quickly diminishing head.  Nice stream of bubbles throughout the drink.  Green hop, citrus, pine, and resin aroma.  A bit of smoke as well.  Initial drink the  bitterness hits the front of the tongue.  A bit of syrup mouthfeel.  Molasses and brandy notes.  Does not overwhelm the palate too much.  Alcohol is felt in the throat after the swallow. Never was a fan of this beer but it is growing on me.
This beer has a rich flavor and the full hoppy finish.  The aroma is slightly citrus.  Overall, this beer is one of the best IPAs available in a bottle.

Pours a crystal clear amber with minimal white head, that quickly recedes. The floral aroma of the hops greets you as you first start sipping. The bitterness is curtailed by the malt and the sip ends on a bitter but pleasant note. Quite excellent!

I cant decide if I like this or Alpha King more.  This definetly hits a little stronger, so I guess that is why it falls in as a DIPA.  Would love to grab some on tap sometime.  Didnt really notice a whole lot of alcohol, and it isnt as syrupy as most beers this strong, which is a huge strong point imo.  Overall this would pass as a special release from most breweries, but DFH does it for a year round - shows how great they are.

Imperial IPA, 12 oz bottle from the Brew Crew Olivers Albany NY. Light orange in color, some head that lasts a while. Smells and tastes citrusy, some raisins. Great beer, if you like IPAs youll love Dogfish head 90.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2007 bottle. pours deep orange gold with a lasting two finger head.  fruity hop aroma. taste is exceptionally smooth.  sweet citrus (lemon) tones roll over the thick creamy malt base, nice bitter edge. some pine hop in there as well but it stays in the background.  subtle prickle from the carbonation is great.  nice warming from the alcohol as well - very little if any in the taste.  you can tell from first sip that this is an extremely well made beer.  if anything i might tone down the sweetness a touch but thats just my taste.  well worth dropping some cash to try it out.

12-23-07 bottle.    

Crisp amber color with a white fluffy head that lasts for days seemingly.  Great apricot hoppy smell - quite fruity and a little bit earthy too.  Nice hoppy fruity flavor too.  Great body and texture that is perfectly smooth and almost creamy.  Awesome finish!  One of my favorite Double IPAs so far!

Pours a deep amber color out of the 12oz. bottle. Has a little of that dogfish head tin smell to go with a bit of a different hop aroma. Tastes much better than the 60min. More like an actual IPA with the hop bitterness and a deep citrus finish. Palate is tingly. A much better beer than the 60min. I could drink a six pack of this. Need some water though to moisten the palate after a couple of these babies.

nice thick head and pretty color
sour smelling but a strong rich flavor, smooth yet not overwhelming.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2007 hmm...expected much more given all the hype about DFH.  really beautiful color, very thin and temporary head.  aroma has hops (obviously) and another smell i just cant quite put my finger on.  but its something decidedly not-beer-like.  im a BIG fan of hoppy beers and the pucker finish you get from them, but this just sort of feels like ive been sucking on a halls cough drop.  dont think ill buy it again any time soon.  got 3 more to try, though...
A little bit of a let down here.  Just a very good dry, highly hopped I.P.A. Not really special like Dreadnaught or even Two Hearted. Too expensive. It reminded me of Ruination by Stone.

12 oz bottle poured into tulip- poured transparent darken amber, thin lacing head.  Heavy aroma floral hops with a slight citrus note.  Hits the mouth with heavy hops from start to finish, a medium body, some sweet notes in the middle.  Delightful.

Pours an orange peach with a nice cream head.  Aroma is hops, malt, and apple.  Flavor is malty smooth with a hoppy bitterness that grows at the finish.  Subtle and understated sweetness that makes this a very drinkable brew.

Amber pour, slightly hazy.  Mostly grass and hops in the nose, flavor is fairly sweet with lots of alcohol and a fair bit of hops on the finish.  Mouthfeel is slightly viscous, fairly soft carbonation.  Fairly solid, but not as complex as I had hoped.  Possibly a bit overrated.
UPDATED: MAY 26, 2009 Im a big lover of hoppy beers, and this one always comes to mind when I think of hops.  Excellent when paired with a Don Pepin black label cigar.

Bottle. Pours golden orange with a slight off-white head that leaves light lacing on the glass. Aroma is hoppy, very pronounced and citrusy. The flavor is as big as the aroma. Very hoppy, citrusy (grapefruit) some resin with some malt underneath. The mouth feel is light and smooth. The hop flavor is HUGE and although the maltiness does somewhat support this explosive flavor, it misses greatness because of this imbalance. Still, very nice!

12 oz w/ Juart and Nate for 60, 90, 120 tasting.  Nice pour with rich golden color and a much better head than the 60.  Got the citrus hops in the nose.  Has a well-balanced flavor for the amount of bitterness present.  This is exactly what I was expecting and I wasnt disappointed.

12 fl ox bottle. Pours slight hazy and golden orange with a huge off-white head. Immediate aroma of grapefruite and pine. Solid caramel malt beneath. Flavour is perfectly sweetend with a nice set of fruite note on top, some mild spices appear here and there and there is a little edge og liqourice before the finish. The finish holds clear notes of alcohol, warming, a solid dry bitterness and a lingering fruityness.
Rich hoppy taste, with a hint of pine and some bitterness.  Has a rich texture with and pours a nice head, no IPAs will ever be the same!

The Dogfish brewery has several excellent beers.  This one may be my favorite.  I love the hoppiness, bite, and crisp aroma of the 90-Min IPA.  I have enjoyed this brew on-tap and in the bottle.  A true hop-heads dream, and good with a hearty meal of beef & potatos, or perhaps cajun cooking.

Pours a lighter amber color than I expected, w/ 2 finger head, some remaining. Aroma: Earthy, sprucy hops. Full sweetness and a tiny bit of alcohol. Taste is moderately bitter, quite sweet with a bit of alcohol. Finish is somewhat dry with a quite about of syrupy residuals. The alcohol is fairly warming, but not too hot. The hops have mellowed some, changing the character of the beer a fair amount, but the syrupy sweetness that comes out more is quite good as well.
My all around favorite beer.  If you like IPA, youve probably already tried it so I dont even need to explain.

12 oz bottle poured into tea cup.  A brilliant copper color with little head, very distinct aroma.  The best IPA I have ever had, leaves a clean, smooth aftertaste.  Not bitter like most IPAs.  This a truly enjoyable drinking experience.
12oz bottle from the fresh. Pours a hazy amber with a creamy white head. Aroma of pine and citrus as to be expected. Tasty brew.

12 oz. from Riverside, color of dull copper, good by not exceptional head, pine sap (in a good way) and orange blossom aroma, enough malt to keep this from being a one-dimensional all-hop beer but with unmistakably prominent hops which reflect the pine/citrus aroma with a nice balance of tart, bitter, and floral, appropriate level of conversation for the flavor/style. Overall an excellent beer worthy of its high rating

UPDATED: APR 23, 2010 12 0z bottle via trade with Acknud.  Shared with Naka and Nate.  Golden pour with amber hues.  Nice foamy white head.  Slight hop nose with a touch of malt sweetness.  Good malt back bone with a great dose of citrus and pine hops.  Mmmm.  

4/23/10 - Grassy nose with caramel notes.  Moderate bitter, dry and lingering.  Nice piny and citrus hop flavor.  A solid beer smack dab in the middle of aggressive and redundant.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2008 Deep apricot pour with one finger off-white head.  Aroma is very nice...citrusy and fruity (dark fruit) with some alcohol notes mixed in.  Something metallic-like in the aroma as well, but nothing too offensive.  Ill begin the flavor portion of my rating by saying Im not a hophead.  Mostly sweet, citrus hops up front...lemony and orangey, with some piney hop flavors later on the palate.  More sweet on the palate than most IIPAs, there is definitely a malt backbone to this drink, which is a very good thing in my book.  This beer is a great example of how you can use an abundance of hops but still make it palatable and not extraordinarily bitter.  There is the telltale bitterness on the end, but it is not too strong.  I found myself leaving with a slightly sweet flavor.  I came at this beer with a tentative approach and left very happy.  Palate is very pleasant as well...somewhat thick while not overpowering.  The emptier my glass gets, the more I enjoy this!  Ill try most IPAs/IIPAs once...this one Ill go back to! 

Quick addendum on 4/19/08 - Why did I give this a 3/5 on appearance...nice off-white head that settles with wonderful lacing...upping to a 4/5...also havent noted the metallic notes in future bottles, though dont see a big need to up the Aroma rating...

When I first found this beer, I was amazed that it was so inexpensive being this high on the RateBeer list.  It was a mere $9 for a 4-pack.  The color was a light amber, and the taste definitely had a hoppy taste.  Since they add a 90-minute hop addition, balanced by a "rediculous amount of English Two-row Barley."  This beer was so amazing its absurd!

UPDATED: APR 23, 2008 Hello hops!  Smells like a christmas tree.  Dark amber with medium white sudsy head.   Intense hop flavor, slightly salty, not as bitter as a 90 IBU would suggest.  This one does have the sweet malt underneath to give those hops a little base.  Some definite honey and grapefruit comes from this combo.  Very mouth puckering, not in a sour way.   Palate is good, lots of fluffy fizz action, not too sticky.     Unbelievably I have some excellent stilton in my fridge. , grabbing now!

[EDIT] yea some good stilton works very nicely =)
Always a favorite of mine....lots of pine/citrus flavors, very hoppy, medium-to-full palate. 9% alcohol is well-hidden, could mistake this for a 5% beer easily. Very drinkable.

Easily one of the best hops full beers ever designed. The aroma is excellent a showing citrus and wheat (?) suggestion. Appearance is normal for this particular type of beer. Although, the taste give a misrepresentation of the ABV; which is not apparent for this double IPA. However, be careful, because this one will get you with the four pack! Love it for baseball!

Beer was served from a 12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Appearance: The color was a slightly reddish amber with almost no head at all.

Aroma: There is a moderate hop aroma with a very slight citrus hint.

Taste: For a beer with 90 IBUs, it is surprisingly smooth. There is the initial bite from the hops, but that quickly fades do a more subdued flavor. It does leave an aftertaste from the hops, but it isnt heavy.

Mouthfeel: Light to moderate carbonation, but it tastes heavier than it looks. No doubt the "ridiculous amount of English Two-row Barley" has something to do with that.

Drinkibility: This is a great beer and Im not a fan of double IPAs in general. I have and would again drink multiples of these. It is 9% ABV though, so dont go overboard.

One of the truly great American beers; it should have an even higher rating. Ridiculous amounts of hops and yet tastes balanced at the same time. Amazing.

Whole Foods, Decatur GA

Nice head thats persistent, beautiful dark amber color, magnificent hoppy smell.  Flavor is good with a long-lasting aftertaste that coats the back of your tongue/mouth, and throat.  Not an everyday IPA b/c of its alcohol, but a must have if you like hoppy beers.
UPDATED: DEC 6, 2007 Very strong IPA. Pours a nice colored head. Not my favorite IPA but worth trying for fans of this style of beer.
UPDATED: FEB 4, 2008 Very good aroma I like IPAs and this one of my favorites. Sweet,with a delicious taste. Would buy again.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: 12 oz bottle from local store.  keep in mind Im not a fan of IPAs.  The beer will definitely not be pleasing to any just starting beer enthusiasts.  bitter, strong, hard to put down.

Great beer...  I didnt like it a few years ago when I had it, but Ive loved the 60 min, which due to bogus alcohol laws I can get the 90 min now, but not the 60 min.  I have to say, I love it now.  Amber color, poured a thick head, but it went away quickly.  Aroma is earthy to me, reminds me of damp woods.  Great hop flavor and malt.  With this much hops you usually dont get a lot of the malt.  The only average thing about it to me is that it feels a little thin.

Bottle. Bought this bottle about 10 months ago. Pours a hazy amber/copper color, thick white head that disappears quickly. Hops, citrus and grass notes in the aroma. Flavor is sweet, slightly syrupy, hops, citrus and caramel. Bitterness, but not in a bad way. A well  done beer.
12 ounce bottle purchased at ABC Liquors Pembroke Pines, FL at $3.05 Excellent

Just a beautiful beer.  No surprise that Dogfish Head turns out another amazing beer.  Ive had this before, but never reviewed it.

Porus a lovely copper with a thin off-white head.  Citrus/pine notes in the aroma - the hops aroma is just spectacular but not overdone.  The flavor is the same delicious blend of mild malty sweetness and amazing hop balance.  This is not like a lot of those asinine "hop bombs" out there that just shove hops into a brew.  This is a balanced brew that makes the most of the intensely floral hop characteristics that DF used.  Spectacular.   I dont usually care for IPAs, but this one is amazing.
12 oz. effing delicious.  You can get this beer anywhere and its always delicious.  same review as everyone else

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2008 12oz bottle: poured into glass had a good looking head and is a reddish amber with a very slight haze. aroma is of hops and even more hops but kind of a fruity smelling hop. flavor is the great part i have never had a beer like this before there 60min ipa lacked the hops i was looking for and the 90min made up for it all it has this kind of tangy hop taste unlike any beer i have ever had and i love it. highest rated beer i have a 120min bottle in the fridge and its going to be though to beat this. BEST BEER I HAVE EVER HAD!
Delicious.  Big hoppy mouthfeel, with a very nice malty body. Good flavors, and very well balanced, especially for this level of hoppiness.  Excellent beer, and excellent IPA.

12 oz. Bottle - Pours a surprisingly clear amberish yellow color with a little head.  Smells of bitter hops, citrus, pine, a bit malty and alcohol (a lot when it warms).  Taste is a nice balance between sweet and bitter hops with piney and citrusy undertones. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied, crisp, a little dry, but refreshing and quaffable - alcoholic bite if it gets warm.  Very nice - definitely will buy again.
Bottle.  Deep golden color with a citrus aroma.  Taste is first malt, than a hit of citrus hops.  A bit heavy mouthfeel on the maltyness.  Very good, just not my style.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2007 I was pleasantly surprised with this beer.  More of a fan of stouts and doppelbocks but I can get this everywhere so I thought it time to give it a try.  Poured much darker than I was expecting, a beautiful clear amber colof with a small head that faded into a 1/4 foamy ring.  Pretty hoppy smell which I thought might turn me off to it but I was wrong.  Very crisp, clean taste, moderately hoppy, with a nice malt base as well.  Very piney and fresh smelling.  I thoroughly enjoyed every drop of this beer and this is something that I will definitely be having again.  This was a very good beer. 


RE-RATE

This has become my favorite beer.  It is easily accessible to me, tastes unbelievable every time I have it, and is worthy of this rating, in my opinion.  Now, I have never had Dreadnaught and it may be better but as of now, it doesnt get any better than this.  I commend you, Dogfish Head, I commend you....

12 oz bottle. Nice deep amber color. Strong hop citrus aroma. Great Hulk Hogan bicep like malty backbone which balances the hop flavor. Again not aggressive hopiness here just a well balanced beer. Very tasty. Love the maltiness. IIPAs dont have to be over the  top hopiness...ita all about the malt!

on tap @ papago. pours orange amber with a thin long lasting white head. aromas of orange, caramel, malt, fresh rosemary and pine hops. flavor is on the sweet side but bearable...caramel, brown sugar, citrus (orange and grapefruit), carrots (skins with the dirt still on them), rosemary and bitter resinous pine hops. the bitterness borders being metallic/coppery and sometimes crosses over. medium in body, mouth feel and carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2008 I mean, yeah.  Its just fine.  Perhaps the best IPA in America is only true if you take into account how easy this is to find compared to other brews which are clearly better.  However, if this is the taste bastion at your local watering hole, jump in.  A very sweet IIPA, with very resiny hops and almost a note (and texture) of honey.
UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 My favorite beer - would drink it in mass quantities if not for the high ABV.  Very citrusy and clean tasting.  Very refreshing beer.  Love the stuff.
Pours a golden orange, fluffy white head, smealls of hops and citrus, taste is flower hops, citrus and pine. Thought is was to sweet and I did not like hop profile. A good beer just not for me.
Very tastey and very hoppy.  So hoppy in fact that it had a slight pine tinge.  Well made tothe point that the high alcohol was hidden.  Fresh tasting and very enjoyable

Had on tap at a local brewery. NOT a favorite style of mine so keep that in mind. Poured a hazy amber color. Smelled of sweet malts and lots of hops. Taste was mostly bitter hops maybe some pine, very light bread taste and MORE hops. Which I do not like. Therefor, I did not care for this
pours copper with off white head,hoppy malty aroma,very sweet with slight bitter finish...too sweet  I think the 60 has a better balance.
hazy amber body. heavy hop aroma, flavor. hoppy up front with smooth finish. excellent ipa, prefer hop whore.

A thin lasting beige head over a deep copper colored body. Strong and delicate hop nose; resin, pine-needles, grapefruit, grass and flowers. Taste is a nicely balanced mix of sweet malts and bittering hops. Feels fresh and dry in the mouth. Good body. Long hoppy finish. Very nice. (Bottle @ RBNAG07)

Bottled  pours a clear amber color with a small head. Aromas of pine, oranges, sweet malt and a little grapefruit. Flavor is a great balance of pine/citrus hops and sweet malts and long alcohol notes on the finish. Heavy mouth feel with good carbonation. Great IIPA!! I will have this one again.

Bottled.
Lots of sweet malt at the bottom of a load of hops. Grass, citrus and lots of dryness. A great Double IPA, not for casual drinking.
The best IPA Ive had.  Very flavorful, with a ton of hops.  Pours a very clear amber with a thin head.
I would say this is the best imperial IPA Ive had.  Nice aromas and flavors.  Not just a beer they tried to make as bitter and with as high an alcohol content as they could.  Excellent.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: 12 oz bottle- pours a golden amber color with a quickly disappearing head. Lacing sticks to the glass for some time. Strong aroma of hops and floral elements. Bitter on the palate but chewy. A bit of alcohol burn on the finish. Overall a great IIPA. One of my top 5 for the category.

Pours amber with a small head.  The aroma is powerful with notes of spiced raisins, citrus and pine.  Very hoppy with a solid malt finish.  It is bitter up front, but you can really taste the barley at the end.  The alcohol is well hidden on this dry finish.
Has to be one of the best IPAs ever brewed.  12oz bottle from BevMo Tempe AZ.  Amazing nose of sweet citrus and pine.  An almost sweet finish.

Hopsy aroma, great citrusy notes. Smells sweet. Head is small and quickly dissapates. Good hopsy taste but not as much as I expect... the 120 ought to be extreme. A very good IIPA. Almost a raisiny/grape finish in the aftertaste. very good.
The beer (from bottle) poured with a very little head and it doesnt have that overpowering of an aroma.  What is overpowering is the flavor and the massive amount of hops.  One of my favorite IPAs.
12 oz bottle, on tap around Philly. A Unique IPA that seems to taste different to everyone.  POWERFUL hops.  I still swear it tastes a little like tuna.

Unique and complicated flavor thats hard to describe exactly. Theres definitely hops in there, along with caramel, alcohol, citrus, and maybe licorice. Mouth feel was thick and chewy. The after taste was somewhat alcoholic and I didnt really like that. I found it difficult to finish this with my pork chop meal. The alcohol was really pronounced and gross for some reason. However, 90 minute is still very good and something Ill pick up, albeit occasionally.

Aroma is that of hops and flowers.  Has a nice white head and a lighter gold color.  Id say this is my 2nd favorite double IPA.  No alcohol taste present.  Like it, but dont really think it is worth the extra bucks.

A good IIPA, with wonderful fruity resin hops aroma that gushes out as the cap is popped.  Marred somewhat by a tiny note of coffee/roast flavor (not nearly as bad as the 60 min though).  Would definitely not know this was a 9% beer so big kudos for disguising the alcohol so well.

Well this is a great IPA.   Pours a clear light amber color with a flakey white head.  Great aroma of hops, barley and flowers.  Taste is full, rich and complex.  Hoppy, malty and with hints of citris butwhat citris I cant discern.  Finish is slightly bitter, full and hearty.  Alcohol well hidden - is this really 9% abv?  Wow.

I honestly bought this beer because I saw a rating that this was the best beer in the U.S. 2 years running.  I wont say it was my favorite,but it was very good.  Had a nice light amber color  and a very strong alcohol.  It was a little sweet  but had a very smooth drinkable quality to it.
Sampled bottle, RBNAG 2007 in Grimstad. Dark amber colour. Nice hoppy aroma, not as strong as expected. Very hoppy flavour throughout, bordering on "too much". Plenty of taste, you might say ...

4-pack bottles from HEB at Brodie Ln & Wm. Cannon in Austin. Meant to have only one, but just had to have another almost immediately! 2 down, 2 to go. Im slowly getting back into the game of big hop beers (after focusing on darks and experimental ales for a while) and this one was a perfect welcome back. Poured an amber-gold, soft... full head with a creamy, cloudy swirl. I picked up sour cherry on the nose and was captivated by the hoppity hops from start to finish. As it warms, the floral beatuy expands on the nose and the mouthfeel is very full. Seems to get more rich as it warm and near the bottom of the glass. Props!
Bottle. Dark golden color. Off-white head. Very hoppy, and I love it. (RBNAG07 in Grimstad Nov. 3th.)
UPDATED: MAR 24, 2008 A nice IPA with lots of aroma and hops to go around.  Good matching body.  Definitely will pick this one up when I can.

Hops dominate from the moment of uncapping. Pours a medium/deep amber with low greenish tan head.  full bodied malts are overshadowed by rounded leaf hops.  Sweet bodied malts are able to poke through and compliment the hops but are soon overtaken yet again by them.  9% is not evident, probably due tho the hops beating it into submission in the corner. Gentle steady carbonation yeilds thin ring of head.  I believ this is due to the fact that the bubbles are scared of the hops and only dare to travel in small numbers. Surpisingly mellow.  I can not believe they mentioned eating snails with this beer.  Anyone who eats snails has a serious lack for their self preservation...snails carry numerous nasty diseases that even this beer would not kill. those boys should have their heads examined...for brain wasting nematodes!   (often found on snails).  Anyway....my snail tirade aside...Thanks to the Slob for sending this one my way.

A FANTASTIC beer!!!!!!!  It pours a rich amber color with a thin foamy head. It has a great complex aroma of hops, fruit, sweetness and a subtle alcohol scent. After experiencing the aroma the taste is even better. It has a nice hop bite that is blended with a slight sweetness and a mild background alcohol taste. It ends on the slightly sweet side with a finish where all flavors stay on the palate for a long time. GREAT!!!!!!!
UPDATED: JUN 26, 2013 Old me sucks. This beer pretty much tastes like bitter caramel malt water. Scroll past.
Bottle. Pours crystal clear copper.Great citrus and hop flavor balanced very well. Notes of raisin.Not much alcohol character, very masked.

Thanks Drewbeerme... Very smooth and perfect blend of hops to malt ratio. A bit fruity with of good mix of bitter to sweet.  The hops are not overwhelming like regular imperials. Nice and warm, confort ale. It should go very well with pork, or cheese. Alcohol is barely noticebale in the taste, and the finish is a bit of mint, hay and lemon.  One of my new favorites.
Nice hoppy aroma with a hint of fruit.  Flavor balances the sweet malt and hops beautifully.  One of my favorite IPAs.

Smells very fruity with a hint of the alcohol in there. Pours a clear copper with a huge foamy white head. Taste is very strong raisiny taste, like fermented raisins or something. Hard to place. Not as much of a hop presence as I expected or hoped for. Very good, but I prefer the 60 minute.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 Yikes! Raisins, brandied fruitcake and citrus is right!! I have this beer every few months--especially after I have a mind blowing brew--and it always satisfies every bone in my mouth, both 26 of them! The hops in this beer are just a fistful that God handed down apparently to the brewer, and the balance between sweetness and hops is a sort of rare perfection. I recommend this beer to every person I meet. It gets a bit awkward at times...

I just had this for the first time.  A very tough beer for me to get in my area.  I had heard great things about this beer before i tasted it and it lived up to the expectations.  Very smooth and exactly what an imperial should be.  Cant wait to drink my next one
A nicely hopped IPA, well balanced with malt.  Great citrus finish, with just enough sweetness to make this a truly great one.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2009 Strong, hoppy aroma.  Rocky head with lacing.  The label is  the usual Dogfish Head shark silhouette and a description of the ale.  Now here is an IPA with substance - this is a pleasurable assault on the tastebuds!   I guess that is the purpose of an Imperial IPA.  It starts out smooth and malty sweet, with a hint of herbs, then shifts to a forceful, hopped up finish.  I am also revising this upward in 2009 (from 20007).  Here is a beer that started out great, and has gotten even better - it has become an American classic.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 The Dogfish 90 aroma contains massive malt and raisin notes closely followed by citrusy hops. It pours a clear medium amber with light carbonation, marked viscosity, and some hop lace.  The flavor is rather sweet with fruitcake notes.  The finish is much like pink grapefruit with a slight astringency and some residual sweetness.   This is an accomplished barleywine rather than a double IPA, quite possibly the best American barleywine currently made.  P. S. The draft version at the Falls Church, VA DFH Alehouse hews much closer to a double IPA, with its much fresher hop presence.

An excellent example of the style.  Pours a perfect copper.  Sweet and slightly hoppy aroma with some citrus.  Lovely balance of bitterness and sweetness - not overly sweet like some other double IPAs.  Alcohol not very noticeable.

This one pours a gorgeous copper color with a thin white head that quickly fades.  The massive intrusion of hops burst on the scene right out of the gates with a maltiness that matches.  This one is all hops with no excuse.  Grapefruit, pine it all good with the right balance of malt to go along with it.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2007 Pours a nice attractive orange/amber color with a decent head on it.  Aroma is a sweet, hoppy, fruity blend that is very inviting.  Flavor is very much of the same.  Nicely balanced IPA that hides its alcohol content very well.  Mouthfeel is great.  Drinkability is high for a beer of 9% abv.  Session this( 294 calories) and you will be a fat hunk of shit in no time.

Pours a clear orangish-amber with a nice thin head. The aroma is true to the style: lots of refreshing and spicy hops. HInts of something else, maybe apple, sweeten it up to make it a unique beer. The flavor is more of the same. Not nearly as bitter as other IPAs, this one is almost creamy, with just a touch of bitterness at the top of the mouth in the middle. A nice crisp finish, too. Really nice beer from a really great brewery.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Bright copper with lasting dense flat head and lotsa lace.  Aroma of fresh hops citrus and faint soy sauce.  Earthy, rustic honey sweetness with balanced bitterness and mild pine.  Medium-full body and medium carbo.  Damn good, but not as pleasing as 60 minute, just stronger.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2007 Way too rip your face off hoppy for this malt lover. You can keep your IPAS to yourself. I mean seriously, lets have a little ale with our hops. Real ale doesnt have any hops in it any way. Hops werent introduced into brewing until the 15th century making the ingredient an often unwelcome latecomer to brewing.

A fantastic medium body, slightly creamy, lively IPA.  It had a delicious, long finish and left me wanting more.  Had a somewhat fruity, apple taste and was much more drinkable IPA than I normally drink.  Highly reccomend.

Bottle. Pours a slightly darker amber than the 60 minute with a small white head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is VERY hoppy, bites you right on the nose. Decent lacing on this one. The taste is sweet of grapefruit and a hoppy finish but hides the alcohol well. An impressive double IPA from dogfish.
UPDATED: SEP 16, 2011 Love this beer.  Trying to clone it.  Hit me up if you have any tips or recipes..
I used to like this one a lot better, not hoppy enough anymore. It is almost too balanced, the more u drink the less hoppy it gets. Still an awesome beer. Dont serve too cold it makes it less hoppy.
Crazy crazy hops. Aroma melted my face and soon had me crying for my mom. I was confused after I drank it. I didnt know what do do or where to go with my life after this beer.

bottle.  Pours clear and gold with a thin, fading head and a bit of lacing.  aroma is of piney hops and a hint of alcohol. The flavor is of course hoppy, barley -- but is well balanced.  hoppy finish, long lasting, and the 9% alcohol is well masked.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2008 For some reason there is a shark on the front of the beer; perhaps it is a reminder that your teeth are going to be eaten up by the biterness. Jaws IPAs from the US - its impossible not to love em! This Imperial edition is very creamy with a full body. Sweet aroma with hints of old fruits, alcohol and hops. This also applies to the flavour with is raw bitter, but at the same time sweet with alcohol. I think its a bit too much and should have been more balanced without the primary presence of alcohol.

Bottle.
Amber colored appearance with a light brown head.  Strong hoppy aroma.  The malty flavor is up front and then comes the crazy hop bouquet.  But it is somehow still balanced.  With such a full flavor it actually has a clean finish.  
Everything I have this tried from these guys is fantastic!  They cant do any wrong.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2009 bottled 9/17/07, only a few weeks ago. pours golden with white head. nose has grassy hop notes with some citrus and pine, some sugary sweet notes as well. the hop aroma isnt very big nor that appealing. flavor is more sweet than bitter/hoppy, theres a good dose of PNW hops that leave a grassy and citrusy taste but it just isnt that bitter and the beer is just too sweet. what happened to this IIPA? different brewing techniques? filtration? probably both. 3.5. 

4/4/09, 06 vintage aged 2 years. still has some nice hop flavor with caramelized malt notes, aroma left a lot to be desired though. 3.4.

pours a golden amber orange with a slighly off-white head.  hop city!  very floral, hoppy, citrus aroma.  tastes even better than it smells, sweet with lots of grapefruit, apricot, hops, some malt, alcohol, a little pine, and raisins.  typical DFH sweet fruity taste.  complex!  medium body with a little carbonation. a little creamy, somewhat sticky.  lingering bitter fruit aftertaste.  excellent IPA.
Bottle Stockholm Beer Festival ...  Golden orange ... sharp american lime hop nose ... Juicy hoppy ... tart lime smooth rich bicg kick ... packed full of flavour ... lots of hop resins
12 oz bottle. Amber golden with an off-white head. Beautiful grassy flowery hop aroma. Very well balanced to start with a strong bitter finish.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.
pours a pretty amber/pink with light head/lacing.  smells amazing... orange, pineapple, & hops.  tingly & bittersweet on the tongue with a creaminess that Ive not experienced in an IPA.

I could drink a lot of this, what a great beer. So well balanced for a DIPA. Nose of spice and earth. Some piney and citrus hops. Taste is balance of sweet malts and a lot of hops. Some earthy hop flavor and some spicey notes. Some caramel and roasted flavor as well add to wonderful body of beer.

4-pack Bottle from Consumers Beverages in Cheektowaga NY.  This is the first IPA I have liked, and I like it a lot.  Poured beautifully, had a surprisingly creamy look to it but with a tight off-white head. Alcohol is noticeable, but well blended into the overall the taste. Much hoppier than beers I generally enjoy, the sweet maltiness tames the hops.  Very balanced.  Citrus aftertaste, smooth creamy mouthfeel.  Outstanding.

the nose on this beer is filled with hop spice just encouraging you to bring it to your lips. Take it slow though the color of this ale is a light hazy, orange gold with some suspension. A gritty hoppy spicey mouth feel. Full bodied and hints of citrus. This was a special tasting of this beer, I can not get it in the state of Texas.

12 oz. bottle. Wonderful, powerful, complex, sweet, dry-hops-dominated aroma of citrus, apples, pine, lemon tart, fresh-baked bread and cookies, pear, plum, apricot, and honey.  Pours a clear, light copper. Very little bubbling. Small to moderate amount of cream-colored head. Produces nice, long-lasting lacing. Both the liquid and the foam have an appealing gold hue. Surprisingly malty-sweet initial taste with a puckeringly dry finish. Alcohol clearly noticeable. Sugar candy, honey, and banana bread flavors from the copious malts. Also spicy and vegetal (especially cardamom and squash). Bitter coffee been flavors from the hops rather than the malts (unlike a dry stout). Somewhat reminiscent of a dry sherry. Tastes more like a hoppy barley wine than a strong IPA. Long, spicy, bitter, hoppy aftertaste. Full body. Syrupy, sticky, and frothy in the palate. 90 Minute IIPA is an aggressive, boozy treat.

nice off white head, with a nice peachy amber color.  very sweet, apricot aroma.  it was smooth coming in, but once it hit the middle of the mouth, it became rough, and got rougher going down. alcoholy, hoppy, and thick syrup in taste, with a bitter apricot aftertaste.  not really feeling this one.  i didnt think i liked IPAs, but the smell of this one made me think my opinion may change...

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2014 (bottle) Clear amber body with a medium, fluffy off-white head. The aroma is very floral, grassy, hoppy, sweet fruit. The flavor is surprisingly sweet, but still hoppy, strong alcohol, grape, a hint of peach. Soft and full bodied, oily.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2009 Poured from a bottle.  The most important aspect of this beer (in my opinion, that is) is the balance.  Nice balance for such a hoppy beer.  Just the right amount of malt to offset the big malt hit.  Its easy drinking too.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2008 Ive never fully enjoyed an IPA until this one. Fantastic complex aroma of raisin and some bread and caramel. Great sweetness balanced with the hoppiness. The first IPA Ive had that didnt hurt me with max bitterness. It is exceptionally malty though and not highly digestible compared to other fine IPAs like Pliny the Elder. But overall the blend is great. Excellent.
Amber color with a nice head.  Smell is intense and hoppy but not too much.  Taste is smooth, crisp, and highly hopped but goes down easy.
3/24/05 12oz. Amber with good sized beige head. Aroma full of resiny hop aroma. Lots of hop oils. Not very well balanced a little quick ending. Good hop flavor. Good not great.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2007 Snifter glass.  Orange red color decent head and lacings.  Perfume and alcohol aroma.  Alcohol is also immediately present upon taste.  Hops and malt galore but the malt has a dark dried fruit taste that doesnt mesh well with the floral/citrus hops.  Strong bitterness and more alsohol at the end.  I prefer the next generation of Double IPAs.

Pours a rich, clear golden color with a thick, eggshell colored head.  The head provides nice lacing and is somewhat creamy in texture.  The beer smells both hoppy and malty.  A little sweet smelling, but you can tell from the aroma that there is enough other flavor that it will not be overly sweet.  The beer has a bitter hoppy flavor.  It is powerful, but not as overhopped as some imperial IPAs.  This beer has a lot of good flavor, but is still drinkable so I can picture myself having more than one or two in a sitting without my mouth drying out.  The beer also has a nice creamy texture in the mouth, but remains crisp and refreshing.  This is a very solid beer.  It has a lot of great IPA flavor without being over the top.
Pours a clear, golden color with a quickly disappearing white head.  Sweet, floral aroma, sharp hop character.   Sticky, malty body gives way to a giant bitter hop finish.  One of my favorte IPAs.

Bottle - 12 oz. Limbid amber body with moderate carbonation and a lasting off-white foamy head. Very nice and complex hoppy aroma with oaky and grapefruit notes. Alcohol is perfectly hidden. Its sharp hoppy taste is simply awesome. Without carrying any alcohol hints, it displays a very enjoyable warming effect. It ends with a long and robust bitter finish. Superb beer!

excellent brew of a  brew. color is a rich amber brown like the soft skin of the punjabi woman I was once in love with. real metaphoric brew right here. slight hint of raisins and fruits, perfect amount of hops, my toungue is loving this brew. its begging me to let da liquid chill but I keep swallowing it teasing it. if i were to exalt vomit from my body later I could actually see it being a somewhat tasteful experience. slight hint of lace on da glass, sexy and sensual lace. wish I had a cigar to complete this experience.

The flavor sits with you for awhile after youre finished drinking it, however I cant possibly complain since its a great one to begin with. The fact that its 18 proof doesnt  hurt, either. Definitely worth a try.
Feel the burn?  Thats the sickness and the cure.  Simply beautiful.  Color is a deep mahogany, and the flavor is delightfully complex.  Also is 18 proof.  Ballin.

Pours an amber. Nice aroma. Fizzy feeling. When you take a chug from a glass the hops really musks your throat. Once again zest/orange peel finish, sharp. A hint of some roasted substance on the end. A lot of raters say it is a syrup. True when coming from other DIPAs. Many people cannot handle this beers thickness.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: On the pour, thick 1 inch head, dark ruby color.  Smells strong, fruit, carmel.  Very sweet tasting, and for me, not very pleasant.  This beer is ranked pretty high, maybe it was the bottle I got, but I didnt enjoy it one bit.  Tasted like cough surup to me.
Bottle: Amber with a huge head.  Very hoppy aroma and taste.  Very drinkable and good.

The color is amber with a thick beige head. The aroma and taste is of sweet barley hops, with justa bit of bitterness. There is also a taste of fruit of the citrus kind. The after taste is very pleasant.

Bottle. Orange color. Loads of grapefruit and red berries in the floral aroma. Sweetish, very malty flavor with flowery hops, lemon and red berries. Surprisingly malty beer, even a bit salty. Red berries in the hopbitter aftertaste. Extremely well balanced, very drinkable. This is indeed a world class beer!

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 I find myself going back and forth with this beer every year.  You can the fact that "density" in the mouthfeel is quite les than something of a English tradition, like Founders Centennial IPA, not much thick (again mouthfeel) malt body, but more American in its light super hop appeal.  A fantastic IPA by any definition.

Pours dark orange with a medium head.  Aroma is floral hops, riasin and sweet malt.  The flavor is extremely well balance with just enough sweetness to offset the hop bitterness.  Alcohol is well hidden and this is surprisingly easy to drink considering the amount of hops and alcohol present.  By far the best IPA Ive had to date.

Pours a clear deep-orange with a hint of red.  Head is off white to tan.  Aroma is strong hops, floral.  The taste is amazing, just the right amount of bitterness from hops but the nicest thing is the very strong malty presence.  It has a very heavy sweetness to it that nicely compliments the hops.  Very full bodied, with a sticky-creamy palate.  Very strong and warming, but wonderfully balanced.
UPDATED: APR 2, 2008 Bottle, poured out golden amber with lots of head. lots of hops  floral aroma, an a bitterness dry finish. Trully enjoyable.

Aroma of candied/caramel fruit, lots of hoppy floral aromas, and sweet malts.  Light stable head, pours dark birght amber.  Thick mouthfeel that has a sweet hoppy bitterness, and a fruity caramel maltiness.  Strong, warming dry finish.

Pours a brown/gold that is clear with a sizeable light tan head that doesnt stay around long. Nose is pungent with a perfume like quality that masks any heavy hops that are present. Flavor is sweet with a slight hop edge. Tangy mix to it. Feel is thick and almost syrupy. Slightly drinkable, but overall a bit too sweet and lacking in any unique character.

From bottle. Spice, herbs, generally a bitter sweet aroma. Decent crispy head, orange copper appearance. Strong flavour of hops, good body. Spicy ale with fruits. Tangy finish. I have mixed feelings about this one. One minute I love it the next not so keen. A bit like a hot and cold woman.

9/12/07 From the bottle.  Aroma is a very even malt/hop balance with roast balancing earth, sweet caramel balancing grass and altogether very well blended flavors.  Appearance is clear golden copper with an off-white head.  Flavor is resiny, earthy, malty sweetness forward followed by a medium bittering with a great citrus balance and finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a medium carb bite and light creaminess.  Overall, this is just so well balanced, and even more so when you realize its an imperial IPA.  I first had this when all my beer club buddies were raving about the 120 minute, and I just wasnt overly impressed.  I hadnt heard of the 90 minute when I first had it and just hoped it would be considered a classic.  Glad to try it again now that it is and find its as good as ever.

Bottle from Embassy Market, Roseville, MI.  Pours nice, with a single finger head which leaves incredible lacing throughout.  The head also sticks around throughout the entire brew.  The alcohol is hidden very well by the malts and intense hoppiness of the beer.  The aroma and taste of citrus is noticeable through the entire sitting, with an intense hop finish.  The mouth-feel is one of the nicest Ive had from an IPA.  Overall, my favorite IPA tried yet, just adding to why this is my favorite style of beer.
After trying a few other IPAs, i have to say that it was delicious.  Its thick, creamy, and very flavorful.  It has a citrusy hop flavor that kicks the hell out of your taste buds.

Drank from a glass that was poured from a 12oz bottle.  For having a higher alcohol percentage the taste of it was masked by the hoppiness.  Really good beer but thought it was rather heavy.  I wish I could of drank more of it but was full after a couple.

Hoppy, yet sweet and fruity as well.  makes my mouth water just smelling it.  agree with the raisiney sweet smell, and the effective masking of the alcohol.  Definately one I will be adding to the collection.

12 oz. bottle; in my possession over 3 years. Rich aroma of ripe light stone fruit. Hazy ripe apricot color with a creamy beige head that flattened, laced, and did interesting things. Medium bodied, with crisp carbonation. The flavor starts with pale raisin, citrus, and something floral. The malt approaches caramel, but it is quite balanced by the hop - bitter and floral. It really pleases the mouth, and the finish is primarily dry, a little fruit lingers, and surprisingly unbitter. Well, its bitter, but it is so nicely set off with fruit aspects, like apricot all of a sudden. This is one of those ales that just demands full attention for savoring. This one makes bitter non-bitter, but bitter. Try it.

This is my overall favorite beer.  I always keep some 90 minute in my private stock at all times.  The alcohol is hidden very nicely.  DFH is pretty good at masking the alcohol.  Starts out a bit hoppy and then finishes with a sweet aftertaste with a hint of apricot.  Just the right amount of hops and malts.  I highly reccomend this beer.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2007 From bottle : Pours a clear light amber color, with a medium head that fades to lots of lacing.  Fairly carbonated.  Has a very nice hoppy aroma, with a hint of flowers.  As soon as it gets to your lips you feel the bitter burn, but then as it moves to the tounge, it does have a very nice flavor..the malts fighting back.  Aftertaste is very stong as it goes down but then goes away.  My first real IPA, and i like.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2008 Best IPA so far!  Im not much on IPAs as I always feel theyre trying to be a bitter ale with no flavor.  Not Dogfish Head!  Youre getting a great flavorful beer hear that is complex almost like a Liberty Ale with rich flavors of malt and raisin.  Cheers!

Just had this on draft and what an experience.  Unbeleivably flavorful hops coming through the nose and caressing the palate.  Excellent!

on tap at brillobox.  pours a pretty golden orange with a substantial white head that gradually recedes, but leaves a lot of lacing.  smells like itll be sweet, with a sprucey hop scent dominating slight citrus and floral notes.  smell is not overwhelming.  tastes like it smells, with pine hops dominating citrus and floral notes.  finishes a touch sweet, but not cloying, with a nice bitter kick that lingers on the palate.  the malt really holds its own against the big bitterness of the hops.  moderate carbonation that befits a double ipa.
UPDATED: FEB 28, 2008 nice orange appearance with mild citrus aroma.  barely taste any alcohol either.  seems more like 5% than 9%.  kind of a light IIPA with the taste comparable to others.

Strong hoppy aroma, citrus and raisins.  Bright  golden orange,  foamy white head, good lacing.  Taste is almost immediately bitter with tons of hop flavor.  Very  pleasant though, and does not overwhelm the palate.  Mouthfeel is nice, crisp and not at all sticky.  Definetely buy again.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2010 12 oz bottle.  Orange-brown with a small head that recedes to a film.  Very little lacing.   Citrus and pine hops dominate the aroma.  The flavour is surprisingly well balanced, with the fresh, caramel malt almost (but not quite) holding its own against the citrusy, bitter hops.  Finish is bitter, but not disturbingly so.  Alcohol is there, but doesnt interfere. Medium to full body.  Very, very good beer.

Re-rate.  In my youthful ignorance, I was not generous enough.  This is a fantastic adult beverage.
Wow.  Very balanced and delicious.  Good hop bite with a fantastic finish.  I LOVE THIS BEER!
Beautiful color and head.  Smells of bountiful hops.  Taste with sharp hoppiness but with perfect malt to mellow.  Finishes great. As "perfect" and IPA that Ive found.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2008 Date: 04/28/2003
Mode: Bottle, 750ml
Source: Whole Foods Market, DC

Appearance: hazy orange, thin tan head, 
Aroma: sweet fruity malt and big hop aroma, 
Body: smooth creamy body, 
Flavor: well hopped rich malt flavor, lots of fruity character, only a hint of bitterness in the finish 
-------- />
Date: 10/12/2003
Mode: draft
Words: 5 seasons (gwcb)

much more citrus character hiding any of the fruity character
-------- />
Date: 01/12/2005

sweet winey malt aroma, lots of bitterness, 
-------- />
Date: 12/10/2005
Score: iii to ii+

Aroma: sweet winey aroma with good floral hops, 
Body: thin body, 
Flavor: rich sweet malt well balanced by hop bitterness but very little hop flavor at first but it finally comes through,
-------- />
Date: 09/10/2008
Mode: draft
Source: summits woodstock

Aroma: sweet fruity and spicy aroma, 
Body: decent body, 
Flavor: big sweet crystal malt flavor, nice spicyness from the hops, touch of pepper from the alcohol,  

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20
Rating: 3.1/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4
UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 the appearance and aroma are just standard ipa, but when you taste it it hits you.... dry hops are strong as any beer, great slightly sweet and salt finish
Bottle at OT, Sthlm. Huge and bold. Syrup, resin, somewhat lacking in aroma hops. Really nice, but at 12 euro a bottle.. Paired really, really good with stilton.
Great aroma, good pour, nice color and a bit hoppy for the palate, but still goes down smooth.  Very good!

Bottle.  Pours a clear copper with a receding creamy off-white head.  Aroma is very strong and complex floral hops with some malt.  Flavor is firm floral/citrus hoppiness, but not overwhelming.  Strong British malts back hop the hops, lending biscuity  and malty flavors.  Some raisin comes through as well with other sweet fruit; this actually has quite a bit of residual sweetness to it.  A very drinkable IIPA.

A beer this easy to find should not be this good. When tasting with 6 othe IPAs this was the favorite. It has a balance that none of the others possessed. The bottle pours amber with a small head. The hops are apparent in the aroma. The taste has the bitterness I like in an IPA without trying to hit you over the head as many of the strong IPA do. The aftertaste is long and wonderful. I could happily dringk this all day. At least until I was under the table.
Bottle from a 4-pack. A blend of malt-hoppy deliciousness. Mmm! Only complaint is the caloric content- WOW! Definitely delicous, but weird to think of a single beer as a "meal replacement"..!

Bottle. Amber in color with small off whtie head. Aroma is, of course, hoppy. It is hoppy in a light way, mostly floral then coming on with heavy malt, light fruit. Carbonation is light, body is oily. Flavor is moderately to highly bitter, with lingering sweetness. Very malty, very hoppy, full of flavor. Finish is a little cloying with sticky orange blossom honey. Im not getting the 90 IBUs in this one, if anything Id search for more bitterness. Its great though, makes me lick my lips. The best part about this beer is the taste in my mouth about 10 minutes after I finish it. All the good flavors hides the alcohol content well.

Like its 120 Minute brethren, the 90 Minute is among the best IPAs I have had. Cefallos in Coconut Grove (Miami) serves it by the bottle, actually offering a 2 for 1 M-F 4PM-8PM. Great way to try it for first timers, along with the 60 Minute.

12 oz. in what always seems an overpriced 4-pack (key word--seems) to kick off the Penn State Brew Fest with brother Jer and friend Ryan...deep orange body that supports a strong,firm inch-plus head--perfectly intimidating...yeasty aromas from Pavlovian hops work intermittently with peach hints to put runners at first and second..now, the meat of the order: the 9% is the slightest bit noticeable, as the tongue is attacked by a full-bodied, dry carbonation...was the beer even there? Sip one is crisp and pleasant, not quite measurable, an aggressive taste with a short aftertaste....fruity as much as it is hoppy--by the third sip, settles into a truly soft(!?!) IPA...this beer only leaves one with the question, is 90 IBUs possible? Unreal experience...bring on the Brew Fest!

This delicious copper-colored beer pours with a small, slightly tan head.  Lots of hops, not too bitter, but with a nice tartness.  Given the big malt finish and % Alc., Ill happily partake in one of these over two lesser beers on any given night.  Love it.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2010 Golden colour, small white head. Aroma of hops and fruits, not too outspoken. Taste is of hops, fruits and green olives. Has a lot of bitterness and finishes dry and fruity.
Rerate: hazy golden colour. Decent amount of pine hops in the flavour. + .4
Rerate II: nice bitterness, very drinkable. +.2

Aroma of raisins, caramel and a hint of hops.  Pours dark amber/mahogany with a fluffy creamy head that lasts.  The flavor is similar to the aroma with a bit more bite from the hops.  This brew is smooth on the tongue with the perfect amount of carbonation.  Overall one of the better Imperial IPAs that Ive had.
Aroma of fruity citric hops, caramel malt, some dust and some alcohol. Clear, copper coloured with a thin, off-white head. Taste is moderate sweet, moderate bitter and fruity malty. Nice.
Clear dark yellow coloured, white dying head. Hoppy and fruity aroma. Strong bitter flavour. Not very complex considered its gravity.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2007 Great floral aroma that you can get lost in.  Hoppy, some citrus, can taste the malt throughout.  Mildly sweet.  Not as powerfully hoppy as the 60 minute, but delicious and well balanced.

12 oz bottle clear golden color...thick white foamy head...pine, citrus and floral aroma...initial taste of bitter malts, hops...thick mouthfeel...bitter finish....very good but not as good as some of my favorite DIPAs
Bottle. Golden color with a white head. Fruity light malty body with good notes of hops. Nice and well balanced. Bitter and balanced palate with strong notes of hops. Very nice.

I am not a huge IPA fans, but when I come across one that I like I jump on it.  This is without a doubt the best IPA I have ever had.  Big time hoppy flavor, but not to the extent that it is overwhelming as in other IPAs.  Finishes with subtle fruity citrus taste.
What can I say I dont like the flavor or smell of IPAs. a lot of hops, hence the very bitterness. the alc% is nice.

Very hoppy, and quite piney as well.  Im sure other people like it, but I just couldnt stand the flavor.  Sadly, this is my second drain pour.  Thank God it was a friends beer and I didnt have to pay for it.
very malty, but then it is an IPA. Medium-light body, tastes like straight up hops. Nothing else. Just hops. The people that rate this beer high are IPA lovers. I am not. However, they are strong.

On draft at brewpub and bottled many times...poured deep orange color with little head and lacing. Strong floral and citrus hoppy taste, but seemingly less hoppy taste, sweeter and fuller taste than the 60 min...and quite a kick to boot. Nice DIPA.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2008 re-rated:
old ratings:
8/3/7/3/15 - 3.6
6/4/7/3/14 - 3.4
pours a clear orange-amber with a medium off-white head, very good lacing.
smell is citrus, light on the hops, touch of caramel, some malt, some leaves.
taste is oily at first and then as it warms becomes more watery, hops, roasted malt, some nuts, touch of sweet fruits, some citrus, just a wee bit of bitterness.
overall not bitter as i would like it too be, too be honest i dont see the reason for such a high rating.

This is probably my favorite IPA.  I have a case of it at home and never get sick of drinking it.  Its about time I finally rate it.  Pours a dark golden color with a foamy head, aroma is hoppy, the flavor is slightly citrusy and a bit hoppy, very balanced overall and a nice dry aftertaste.  Excellent stuff.
Absolutely exquisite and delicious. This is probably my all time favourite IPA.

Delicious. Ive been putting off buying a 4-pack for a while and a friend surprised me last night. Pours beutiful copper color with small slightly off white head. Smells of citrus and hops. Tastes of hoppppppps hopppps and more hopppps. Plus citrus and some other sweet fruity notes going on. Finish is an awesomely smooth bitterness that leaves you wishing this were cheaper!
I love drinking this beer. I never really cared for ipas (they were always too bitter, unbalanced.) but when I had this at Ashleys I was pretty stunned. This is a great beer.
bottle.  wow.  perfectly balanced.  wow.  definately smelled the raisins along with citrus hops.  glad i have 3 more.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2008 bottle.  This imperial IPA is like liquid gold.  Wonderful deep golden color with a 1/4" white head that gets cut in half throughout.  Aromas of citrus, spices and hops.  Incredible long finish full of flavor.  Sweet hops dominate.  This beer has been praised by many and it deserves every bit of it - this beer delivers and will permanently occupy a space in my favorites.

4-pack from DFH in Rehoboth Beach, DE...pours a beautiful transparent amber with thin off-white head...smell is very floral, hoppy, with citric essence...flavor rich of hops, and bitter with orange-grapefruit zest...these guys got it right, this IPA is awesome.
Thanks to Ramenen. Bottle: Dont know if the best in America, but best in list so far. Incredible hops, floral and herbal notes, aroma is great with a robust and strong body.
Bottle: What can be said about this beer that hasnt been said already?  This is big, balenced, and a well made beer.  If you like American hops, you need to drink this.

On draft at The Kinsale in Boston.    Came in a snifter as recommended  without much head, typical of a pub pour.  A swirl in the glass raised a little head and left nice lacing in glass.  Really great nose of citrus an floral hops.   Nice caramel malts balance it perfectly.  Very smooth and rich mouthfeel.  Favor is again of those citrus and floral hops, and it simply tastes fantastic.    Long. lingering, and wonderful bitter finish.  Without a doubt one of the very best DIPAs ever.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2011 Bottle. A clear pale to medium amber beer, with a large, frothy, lacing, mostly lasting white head. The aroma is lightly malty (caramel), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, pine), with notes of alcohol and a slight off note (perhaps butter).The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, syrupy/thick texture, lively carbonation, long finish with moderate to heavy bitterness, moderately to heavily alcoholic. In my opinion it looks very appealing, but the other aspects are average for the style. Quite pleasant but straightforward aroma with a buittery hint, overly sweet flavor and sticky palate with a boozy finish. Overall Ok, but I remembered it as one of the finest DIPAs available. I guess we all change.
I had to sneak this across the GA to AL border to try it; my friends loved it.  A great bitter IPA with such wonderful flavors...lemon, malt, big time hops.  One of the best Ive ever had.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2007 I am eager to find the beer that will take the 90 minute off of my top favorite spot. The intense front hop is amazingly balanced by the full malt backbone that comes up from underneath with a lasting finish. This beer does not have a strong hop finish, but rather leaves the palate with a residual raisiny sweetness. Big mouthfeel makes this brew a perfect winter complement.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2008 My favorite IPA and one of my favorite summer beers. Closed a few bars on this fine ale. Strong but sweet aroma of hops, flowers, apricots, and raisins. Wonderfully balanced between hops, fruits, and alcohol. Sits full and hoppy in the mouth. Citrusy flavors complement the full carbonation. Finishes surprisingly clean without the hoppy aftertaste that a lot of IPAs have.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2007 The fourth best IPA Ive ever tasted.  The aroma is amazing, the cascade  is prevalent but not overburdening.  A multitude of flavors that blend together beautifully and goes down smooth.

This is maybe the best IPA available; perhaps because its an Impy, perhaps because its better than almost any other IPA.  Strong aroma of flowers and hops, backed up with a crunchy hops taste and nutty dry palate.  From a bottle, let it warm up just a little.  Maltier than a lot of IPAs, but nearly sets the standard.  Frankly, Im not sure what IPA is better.

This can be quite the beer to enjoy after a good meal; it is very full bodided and and flavorful with a finish that seems almost too strong.

Do yourself a favor and drink this slowly; it is a beer that can remind you its about quality, not quantity.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2011 Re-rate 10/29/11: Bottle sample at a tasting at Porter & Sons. Thanks Lee. Clear amber with a white head. Aroma of resinous hops, flowers and some malt. Sweetish malty flavor with a bitter finish. Medium-bodied. Not so fresh - not calculating the score. 7/3/6/3/13=3.2

Bottle. Clear amber color with a small off-white head. Sweet aroma of floral hops, some cookies and some alcohol. Sweet flavor with lots of hops and citrus, malt and caramel. Has a very long, hoppy, bitter, and slightly alcoholic, finish. Full-bodied. Very nice double IPA. 8/4/7/4/15=3.8

Thanks to Dogfish Head 90 minute and the Avery Maharaja, the Imperial IPA is quickly becoming my new favorite style of beer. The 90 minute IIPA has found an outstanding balance between the hops, alcohol, and the citrusy/sugary flavors (something in there with a caramel edge too). The finish seemed relatively clean, not too bitter when compared to the Avery IIPA for instance.
I also didnt think that DFH90 was all that expensive; I got it at some bar (Hemingways El Paso, actually) for $4.
This beer has jumped to the top of my list of beers to keep in your fridge. Great taste and pretty strong too. Pricey but everyone should at least try it once!

Bottle acquired via trade with Hogtown Harry. Pours a perfect amber hue. Smell is more of malts than hops which surprised me. For an imperial IPA, the taste is way more balanced than expected. Hops/bitterness were quite subdued relatively speaking. Very creamy mouthfeel. Malt flavours Im picking up include tobacco, which dries out the finish. Drinkability is quite high for the style. A very well done brew.

Balance is what sets this such a great IPA. It is hoppy and citrusy on the nose and in the taste but one does not overwhelm the other. Botter comes on later but still does not shove the others aside. This is an IPA for everyone.

Oh.My.God.  I had some Dogfish Head years back in North Carolina (2002).  I thought it sucked, but perhaps the sixpack was just old.

Sampled this one with 4 others at the Flying Saucer in Houston.  Smelled it.  Fantastic!  This is what an IPA smells like!  Hoppy as all get-out.  Tasted great.  Very hoppy, but no nasty aftertaste; finishes smooth!  Looking to see if I can get some 120 IPA.  Thankfully, I can get this back in Indiana!
Excellent IPA.  Nice floral hop aroma with a thick malt taste.  Sort of swirls in your mouth coating all the tastebuds.
Thanks to Juancho.  Another beatiful Imperial IPA.  Nice balance between the hops and the sweet notes of citrus.  Definitely a beer worth drinking again.

A clear dark amber with light off-white head.  Aroma has a floral touch to it to balance with a strong citrus appeal.  Taste is an amazing malt flavor with hops to balance it out.  Wow, this is great.  Certainly the best IPA Ive ever tasted.

Hazy peach body is well carbonated with a small, but sturdy, eggshell head. Fruity syrupy malt aroma with plenty of hop backing of pine and citrus. Taste is well balanced with an avalanche of malts and hops struggling for supremacy. Very nicely done.

Bottle thanks to HogTownHarry. Poured brown and a bit murky. Nose was barley, apricots, alcohol, and perhaps the slightest touch of brandy. Taste was similar minus the barley, with a very dominating taste in caramel. Too strong and caramely (edging in Trafalgar territory). I prefer the smaller 60 min cousin.
350 mL bottle.  Deep orange/red amber with a fizzy white head.  Great grapefruit, pine, and herbal aroma.  Tastes of grape, raisin, lemon, and pine.  Very good.

Absolutely incredible!  This is a must have for any IPA enthusiast.  Enjoyed from the sample at the Gaithersburg establishment and also as a part of the Black & tan special there, too (Chicory stout & 90 IPA).  One can make an evening, or two, out of this one...must experience first hand to understand.  However, this still leaves the 120 minute IPA......

Looks quite and smells quite lovely. Aroma is dominated by flowering hops on a nice malty backdrop. Phenomenal balance btw. bitter and aromatic hops. Lingering aftertaste almost like brandied desserts. Lovely drop!

Pours a beautiful copper color.  Nice carbonation, smooth decent sized head that fades over time.  Very nice bitterness matched with a sweetness I have not encountered before in an IIPA.  Best bottled pale ale I have had.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2013 Pours a clear, golden amber, that thins out to a golden blond. Head is off white, and medium. Shows a bit of carbonation. Nose is of almond, floral notes, and sugary caramel.  Taste starts with sweet red fruits, and light citrus, before shifting into nutty, and caramel notes. Also a slight dark fruit note leading to the finish. Finish is nutty and lightly spicy, with slight earthy notes as well. Very complex. Mouth is pretty full and chewy, with a decent lingering bitterness.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2010 Pours clear liquid gold, wiht spiraling carbonation and a thick white head. Aroma of Citrus Hops, Malts, Brandy, Candy,  and Toffee.  Thick hoppy flavours with a strong malt base all the way to the end with a nice warm alcohol feel and toffee taste. The best IPA ive ever had, aswell as the best beer all around Ive ever had. Looking forward to there 120 minute IPA and there World Wide Stout. Wish I could get this back in Canada. I cant tell you how much I fn love this beer, cant get enough of it.

Bottle, from Ølkonsortiet, Aalborg. Pours a pretty clear redish copper with a small, slightly fizzy yellowish creamy head. Aroma is surprisingly mellow. A slightly tart caramelness dominates along with some citric tones. Very nice and full mouthfeel. Flavour is equally mellow - this isnt a hop-bomb, more balanced than most IIPAs. Not to say it isnt bitter, there are citric and ghrassy hops aplenty. A good finish on a sweeter caramel note as well as a lingering viniousness. A terribly well-balanced beer!
not a bad beer.  tried this one tonite with a friend and im pretty impressed.  went well with the filets we were eating.
Maybe this is sacrilege to suggest, but this beer is too hoppy.  The hops are just hopping out into your hop-hole.  I think Rogues Imperial double IPA is more interesting.

I bought this at my grocery store to conclusively determine whether or not Im a "hop head" and, just so you can gauge my input appropriately, Ill start by admitting that Im not. Poured clear amber with a satisfying, large, billowing head that leaves a fair amount of exquisite lace (but that couldve been my less-than-conservative pour). The strongest elements of the aroma were grapefruit and pine needles. The power of the two of those were overwhelming (in a good way) to me and made it difficult to detect anything else in the nose. The first thing to hit me in the taste was a syrupy sweetness with a spiciness to it that brought the flavor closer to a date (or "drupe") than to the maple syrup you put on pancakes. This slides down the tongue with a thick, syrupy consistency until it turns into a flavorful, hoppy warmth at the back of the mouth with mild-moderate bitterness.
