All of this is surrounded by a pine freshness with citrus notes (the citrus could be compared to grapefruit, if taken into account with the ending bitterness). Its a funny thing: Im drinking a second bottle/glass as I write this and can no longer remember what turned me off to it the first time. Maybe I am a "hop head" after all. Eh, well see, but Im truly impressed by this beer.
This beer had an extremely good hoppy flavor and complex taste. This is probably my favorite IPA.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2007 Strong orange peel, grapefruit, and thistle bouquet. Amber color with a thick creamy yellow head, wonderful lacing. Rather sweet taste and thick consistency. Tastes of caramel, grapefruit, orange, oak, and even a little smoke. Decidedly complex. Finish is orange peel and hops.
From a bottle at the Olympic.  An excellent IPA with great hoppiness and complex malty flavor.  needs to be appreciated from a nice pint glass

Wow! Thats what I said after drink this from my new 22 oz mug. This beer was not what I expected. It has a strong flavor that sticks with you well after. Strong mouth feel, great aroma and very hoppy! I needed to alternate between the beer. Everyone needs to try this atleast once.

pours a most delectable shade of orange, nice retained head, absolutely delicious hop scent, a melange of orange, grapefruit, and slight piney hops.  Perfect balance in the mouth between hoppy tang and smooth malt sweetness.  Delighted this is finally readily available in Georgia.  Got two in the cupboard aging for next year.

I had this  out of a tap in a Portland, ME pub earlier this month. I was surprised how complex it was.Evrybody was drinking it - mostly tourists. They had some other DogFish brands that I wished I had tried.   The hoppiness was a bit too citrus for me. But I can certainly understand its appeal. Great color,

Copper/amber pour with off-white head.  Sweet malt aroma with notes of hops.  Slight hop sting with bitterness on the initial taste that quickly yields to a sweet malt flavor that warms the palate with a little heat in the finish.  Not as hopped up and bitter as some in this category.  This beer is very balanced and easy drinking.  Very good.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 It pours copper color, with big offwhite head. The aroma was sweet, citrus, and malty. The taste was somewhat bitter with a sweet finish.  Its sweet, with some notes of caramel, candy, and fruit. The body is sticky. The alcohol was very subtle.
Bottle. Excellent beer, lives up to the hype. very smooth, easy to drink...thought it would be more bitter. Definite citrus aroma. Will drink again.

What can I say I agree!!

Esquire Magazine calls our 90 Minute I.I.PA., "perhaps the best I.P.A. in America." An Imperial I.P.A. brewed to be savored from a snifter. A big beer with a great malt backbone that stands up to the extreme hopping rate. This beer is an excellent candidate for use with Randall The Enamel Animal! 90 ibu
Tasting Notes: Brandied fruitcake, raisiney, citrusy.
Food Pairing recommendations: Pork chops, beef, grilled fish, frites, focaccia, split pea soup, Stilton cheese & escargot.
Glassware recommendation: Snifter
Wine comparable: Sauvignon Blanc
In case you care... the average 12 oz. serving has 294 calories.

Bottle poured into a sniffer.  Pours amber with a small white head, the lacing is fair with a mostly diminishing head.  The aroma is of citrusy hops.  The flavor is heavy on the citrus hops, grapefruit and orange.  here is a strong bitterness that sticks to the back of the tounge for quite a while.  There is also a very good malt balance to go along with the bitterness.  There is a slight nuttyness along with some caramel malts.  The body is medium to full with a body with a creamy texture and soft carbonation.
One of the best of style. Creamy and smooth! Very high in calories but worth the taste.

POurs a hazy copper with a small white head.  Smells hoppy, with a very profound malt character as well.  A little sweet caramel around the edges.  The taste is definitely hoppy, slightly bitter with some grapefruit, but I love the sweet maltiness that this beer produces as well.  Really balances it out, more than most double IPAs which are hop bombs.  A little bit of heat was detected in the finish and the aftertaste, but it was relatively smooth.  Awesome brew.
Bottle.  Nice copper color pour w/ nice lacing.  Very smooth, not exactly what was expected.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2010 Revisit of an old classic 06/08/2010.  Nice hoppy, fruity aroma, a little citrusy.  Beautiful copper color, decent head.  Nice flavor, not the hop explosion I was expecting.  It has a surprising amount of sweetness to it, caramel, chocolate (really!), fruit, citrus.  I cant pick up the alcohol, as it is so well hidden.  The body is medium to thick, oily, The finish is a long lasting burst of of citrus, pine and resin hops.  One of the nice examples of the style.

This beer was a surprise. As I poured it the color was much lighter than expected, with minimal off-white head. The aroma was also a shock, as I kept smelling and smelling but could only get subtle hints of hops and grapefruit, it wasnt that citrus/floral/hop kick in the nose I expect from my IPAs (imperial or not). Taste was excellent though! Amazingly smooth, loads of hops and a great finish. Also masks the 9%abv very well. This beer is excellent.

Dark copper hue, rocky & longlasting head, good lacing. Floral & sweet aroma; a nearly astringent hop-aroma. Very pungent, with a strong grainy malt backbone. Sweet & bitter taste, a huge hop-profile. Dark fruits (figs/plums/raisins) and molasses-sweetness from the malt. A long-lasting, assertive, citric hoppiness in the finish, along with liqourice and dark fruits. Surprisingly balanced. Full-bodied, low CO2. Huge.

One of my two favorite everyday IPAs (the other being Flying Dog Double Dog).  Pours a great orange-straw color, with a nice, sturdy head.  Great, luscious pineapple aroma.  The flavor is full of bittersweet pineapple hops and just enough malt to hold it together.  Like all DFH beers, it has a wonderfully smooth, creamy mouthfeel, despite some generous carbonation.  It does produce a little harshness at the back o the throat, but the finish is clean and hoppy.

Bottle purchased at Corral Liquors in Granite City, IL. Pours a sparkling orange with a rocky, off-white head that has some staying power. Not having read any reviews, I was expecting a hop bomb. I was pleasantly surprised at the nose: sweet caramel malts and fruity hops. Tangerine and melon notes...very nice and "light". Medium/full-bodied and creamy-soft it finishes only slightly bitter. This brew is very balanced for a beer weighing in at 90 IBU. They must use a boatload of malt to get such an amazing integration of flavors. The taste is a sweet toasted caramel malt front with a fruity hop finish, but I use that oversimplification primarily because its so difficult to pull out individual flavors.  It isnt really very bitter at all until a few seconds after the swallow. Then a nice bitterness sets in at the back sides of your tongue. Surprisingly malty, but very tasty; a light alcohol on exhale, but Im likin it. I see why this beer is so well regarded.

Bottle. Pours dark amber, even reddish with a very small head. (OK, I didnt have the appropriate glass, but still I expected a larger head) Aroma is soft and hoppy. Flavor is a bit disappointing: not so rich and very soft, but I give it a rating this high because of the wonderful and long-lasting finish of hops and bitterness.
Also I cant really sense the alcohol although its 9%. Overall a nice beer. The soft and pleasant aroma and flavor make it very drinkable.

Good amber color. Off white head with large bubbles, though not rocky or chunky. Moderate carbonation. Balanced nose with malt and citrus, grassy/earthy scents. Early flavors of malts gradually replaced with hop bitterness and citrusy taste.Slightly alcoholic finish (to be expected at 9%) that clears quickly due to carbonation. A thoroughly enjoyable drink that can be enjoyed by both beer-lovers and macro-drinkers alike.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear amber with a 1.5 cm off white head (mostly diminishing).  Moderately malty and slightly hoppy aroma with a tinge of citrus.  The initial flavor is mostly sweet with the citrus and hoppiness kicking in on the back end.  Creamy texture with light carbonation.  I just saw that this beer is 294 calories per bottle, wow, otherwise I wish I could drink this every day.

Bottle. A nice bonus in trade from pantanap. Pours a beautiful clear dark gold color with a light head with plenty of carbonation and lacing running the sides of the glass. Immediate aroma of malt, fruit tort, orange peel, and of course the generous dry-hopping is evident. Very sweet fruit and pastry flavor on the tongue at the beginning of each sip, fading into a complex blend of pine, grapefruit, and a huge hop nose with that steady "malt backbone" indeed. Finishes with some cognac-caramel flavors as well. Syrupy feel on the palate that fades quickly into a crisp, dry alcoholic finish, as a good Impy IPA should do in my book! Reminded me of Hopslam, but balanced much better. A great DIPA, and I would recommend it to any hophead.
pourse amber with hints of pine in the aroma i really cant describe the taste other than marvelous

A great IPA. A mild to heavy bodied IPA with a creamy off-white head, the IIBUs are ideal for this IPA enough so you know they are there and not too over top to kill the hop aromas. A great amount of hops, just what I was looking for. Best IPA I have had yet.

Not drinkable with a 90 BU level, the bitterness completely overpowers all other aspects of the beer.  Its unbalanced and is akin to drinking liquified hop pellets.  An extreme product that isnt something Id want to drink again.

Thanks to john_adam2002 for this 09/2006 12 oz bottle.  Drank in 07/2007, so maybe the hop aroma has been subdued, so my description is skewed, but thats OK, I prefer beers aged.  Pours with 1/2 finger tight head, probably from my pooouring skills.  Slight malt, medium alchohol aroma.  Pale orange color.  Guey, thick citrus hop bomb, balanced with tons of malty sweetness.  The beer clings to the side of the glass, trying to climbs its way out, as I swirl it in my glass.  Then slowly falls back leaving a trail of fine bubbles.  Gets better, more mellow as the beer warms up.

Appearance: Pours a clear copper body with a small, creamy white head.

Smell: Lavish, rich caramel maltiness with pronounced accents of pine, juicy citrus fruits, and dried pineapple. 

Taste: The malt and hops march side-by-side along the tongue with lush sugary caramel sweetness and pineapple juice garnished with pine needles. Sweet-bitter finish, with the bitterness enduring into the aftertaste. The purported 90 IBUs can hardly be felt what with all this rich, malty sweetness within. The ABV, though apparent, thankfully isnt glaring.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel. Quite warming.

Drinkability: Id recommend a 7-day 90 Minute Imperial IPA Diet. Go ahead, blow your mind once a day for the next week. That is, If you want all the squishy parts of your brain to leak out my ears.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2008 So far .... the best hop head beer  that has touched my lips.. I (so far ) have really enjoyed my (american) countries interest in a biter hops (fancy). The fact that you can taste the malt means there is plenty of that too. 2nd rate ..It tastes like a southern woman designed the recipe[Oh ..you like hops..well double the amount.(Wont that overwhelm the malt?) Oh.. well ..well double the malt too..] Too much medicine....Later gator ,

Pours a nice copper color and a lovely off-white, laced head.  Aroma is dominated by hops with a slight, slight alcohol aroma thrown in.  The aroma is very hoppy with a bitter aftertaste.  The alcohol is incredibly hidden within this wonderful, wonderful brew.  Great job, Dogfish Head.

Bottle.  Copper colored beauty,if thats what youre looking for.  Personally I like to "see" my hops.  The foggines alerts me to the pleasure my palate is soon to receive.  This shouldve served as a warning.  Brilliant considering the alcohol level, but severley lacking in the hoppy flavour that seperates the avereage brew from the mouth melting few.

Hmm maybe Im jaded.  I was expecting more since this is 10 dollars for a 4-pak.  This first thing I notice is that it is a clear coppy color and not hazy that I like.  The aroma isnt very strong but there is some floral and acohol notes.  The taste is of bitter hops and once again alcohol.  Bitter finish.  Ill re-rate once I finish the other 3 bottles and see if my opinion changes.

Found this one bottled at Binnys in St. Charles, Illinois.  Clear, dark orange pour with a thick, foamy off white head, a nose of orange and strong pineapple, soft bitterness of floral hoppy, some berries, slightly sweet.  Finishes mild.  Very unusual for an IIPA.  Pretty good!

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2007 This is the first time Ive tried this beer.  Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass.  Nice clear copper color with 2 fingers of foamy off-white head.  The armoa is floral, and the 9% alcohol makes itself known.  First thing I taste is the malt, and then a grapefruit like bitterness.  Again, the 9% alcohol is evident.  Honestly its a bit much for me.  Palate is nice, a bit sticky on my lips.  Overall, I think this is a good beer, but I was expected to be blown away from reading the ratings and seeing that this is one of the top ranked American beers.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2007 Amber with big, foamy head / Gorgeous nose of apricots, grapefruit, licorice, and pine / Medium, chewy, creamy body with lingering finish / Big fruit flavors of pine, apricots, grapefruit, licorice, lime, cinnamon, and black pepper / Perfection.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2007 6-30-07 - bottle
Looks amazing.  Aside from Guinness, the 1st 5 rating Ive given for appearance.  Rich golden, amber color with a thick frothy, creamy white head that held up a long time and left great lacing.  Smell is very hoppy obviously, juicy apricot, and light floral fruitiness.  Intense and great nose.  Taste is quite hoppy, juicy apricot like, bitter, drying, and floral.  Honestly, I was a bit afraid of this beer, not especially being a fan of regular IPAs even, but I was pleasantly surprised.  Still very hoppy, but not as bitter as I feared somehow.  Smelled, and looked delicious, and granted was bitter, but I actually liked it somehow, even not being a fan big bitterness.  Drinking it fairly cold, and not letting it mellow out all over my tongue controlled some of the intense hoppiness, while allowing to enjoy some of the big flavors and delicious smells.  Aftertaste was some residual bitterness, along with some pleasant honeysuckle sweetness.  I was quite pleasantly surprised and would actually get this again occasionally.  Not a session brew, but something Id look forward to when craving something of this style.  This will likely broaden the types of beers Ill try in the future.


RERATE 12-23-07
Pours a brilliant amber with medium lasting beige head in a snifter.  Smell is strong sweet and fruity hops.  Flavor is sweet, yet highly hopped and well bittered.  Fruity and piney hops in the taste with some hints of alcohol showing but not detracting much.  Much sweeter and less hopped than I remember my 1st time having this beer, but then again, that was one of my first experiences with a double IPA and it was quite a shock to my senses.  A touch warming in the chest.  Now I find this quite drinkable and nice, whereas before it was tasty but too hoppy.  A bit syrupy body.  Nice double IPA for sure.

Crystal clear copper color with a very thin white head.  Aroma of roasted hops and hints of pine and malt.  A very tangy hop presence in the flavor finishing with a fruity and intense hop outburst.  An excellent hoppy brew.  A very noticiable alcohil presence.  I would do this again.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2008 Flaske: Meget humlet i både duft og smag. Desværre var den ikke frisk, hvilket helt sikkert havde trukket op. En anelse lakrids i eftermagen.
Rerate: Betydelig friskere. Fantastisk afbalanceret IIPA, masser af blomstret humle i duften, stor maltsødme til at bakke den op. Rigtig rigtig lækker øl.

Copper colored with firm head.  Flowery bouquet on the nose, and this brew smells hoppy, with a tinge of spice and citrus notes.  A strong malty brew, you can definately sense the alcohol.  Figgy and raisiny malts are prevalent, with a pleasing pine/hoppy kick on the back of the throat.  Strong hops linger throughout the finish.  The beer also has a good mouthfeel for an ipa. Overall a good, strong ipa which certainly has alot of character!

Bottle. Roasted hops smell with sweet undertones. Pours a bright copper color with fairly large bubbles in the head for an IPA. Delicious, strong hops flavor with some fruit on the finish. Goes down amazingly smooth for the strength. A great IIPA that would be easy to drink multiples of.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2008 Bottle at Københavnske øldage 07. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is very hoppy, pine. Flavour is hop, alcohol, sweet, pine. Nice beer.   7-4-7-4-14.  Rerated with friends at home. A pleasent world class hoppy beer. Nice

A typical coppery color with a light white colored head. The aroma of hops is immediately detectable after pouring. A slight taste of lemon is noticed initially, and subtle pine flavors develop. Easily my favorite IPA. Dogfish Heads food pairing recommendations are right on the mark also.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2008 Bottle at Københavnske Øldage. Clear, golden beer with a small, white head. Very hoppy nose, with lots of pine, and beef-stock. Stinging bitterness in the mouth, with pine and beef-stock as well. Long piney finish and full body. Even though it is a nice beer, and I really like hoppy beers, it feels too unbalanced. Rating: 7-4-7-4-14-3.6. (070511)Rerated at home. Bottle. Clear, golden pour, with a dense, off-white head. Could wish for longer head retention. The initial aroma is very hoppy, with pine, resin, citrus, the usual stuff, then the malt comes forward, with meat-stock and sweetness, as well as a little alcohol touch. The flavor is quite intensely bitter, yet under heavy influence from the malt. Residual sugar, beef-stock, pine, resin, citrus and citrus peel, some caramel and a little alcohol giving it a warming mouthfeel. A full-bodied beer indeed, finishing mostly hoppy, but theres a well pronounced sugary touch as well. Definately not so unbalanced as it felt the last time I had it. The beer is so hoppy it feels a little astringent in the mouth, but combined with the warming sensation from the alcohol, and all the lovely flavors, it is really nice. Come on mr. Calagione, lets have this beer in Norway!  And big thanks to the_epeeist for sending me this bottle. (070906)

Bottle. Love the golden orange color!  Thin white head with good retention as a topper. Smell is initially moderate with a sweet fruit quality like raisins and oranges with a good hop combo. Flavor hits amazingly hard right from the first touch on the tongue. Sweet orange again noticeable along with the strong hops presence - It is strong but only initially then it resides so that you can enjoy the flavor. Works well to hide the alcohol flavor but its is still noticeable. Still my favorite IPA so far

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2013 Caramel, fruit, and lemon hops aroma. Copper with lasting head. Full bodied, syrupy, grapefruit, caramel, orange peel, alcohol notes and hops. Full body, smooth, medium bitterness.

355 ml bottle.  Pours a radiant golden orange with a copious off-white head.  Intense hoppy almost flowery nose with hints of pine in the background.  Full bodied with an initial malty sweetness that quickly turns to a full hop assault.  Lasting sharp finish that pulls you in for another round.

I loved this kick ass ipa when i tried it in Arizona for the first time, because they dont ship to NM. One of the smoothest most enjoyable Imperial IPAs ive ever had. Right up there with Averys Maharaja. I appreciate the fact that it comes in 12 ounce bottles. Truly one for the IPA lovers who want a bit more out of the India Pale Ale style.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2009 now we are talking good beer. pours a nice dark coppery color with nice fruit aroma. have had this on tap as well and you can taste the apricot and fruits much better. my favorite dogfish so far

Bottle and on draft.  Tasted individually, as well as a part of a tasting flight of the 60, 90, and 120.  Copper colored pour, slightly more reddish than the 60.  Sweet hoppy aroma.  Much smoother and sweeter than the 60 minute, with more of a flow of flavors from beginning to end.  Remarkable balance.  One of the top Imperial IPAs in my book.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2009 This is my favorite IPA.  It has a very citrusy, tangy aroma followed by a mouthful of grapefruit-like bitterness.  The hops swarm and make it a great mouthfeel for this beer that is not too watery, nor too thick.

So, this was the last of the "Minute" series on my list, and I would say the worst (or least awesome), in that its neither a wicked IPA or a ridiculously overwrought double. Nevertheless, very complex and distinct: nose of pear, alcohol, spicy hops and something else -- watermelon? A bit of metal in there. Otherwise, a smoother, sweeter 60 Minute, but not as intense as the 120, giving it an over-sugared malt liquor vibe. I need to try this on tap.

WOW. Amazing flavors coming forth in this one. Warms you right up with the alcohol content, but you wouldnt guess it was that high while drinking it. The bitterness of the hops is intense, but not overpowering. Its perfect. The lacing is fun to look at. The aroma is piney hops. This beer is so drinkable I get upset with the fact that you have to take your time with it because of the alcohol content. I WANT ANOTHER ONE!
definately one of the best IIPAs if not the best, what a kick in the face, tons of hop flavor but very drinkable

I loved it because the bitterness that IPA freaks seem to get off on was balanced by the raisin flavor that reminded me of Dogfish Heads Raison Detre.  So imagine that with some extra complexity and kick.
A great beer with a long last head and excellent lacing staying power. It was a bit bitter for my taste, but obviously a great amount of people like it that way.

This is monster beer! Pours deep amber with a humungous foamy cream colored head that leaves so much lacing its simply insane. The aroma is powerful, evoking thoughts of pine trees and citrus fields growing inside a humidor filled with the choicest cigars and most decadent fruit pastries. Everything youd expect from an Imperial IPA is here in abundance. This is pretty impressive stuff. Cant wait to try the 120.

Simply, the best Double IPA that has ever hit my taste buds. It is daring with its stylistic punch of spicey yet fruity flavor. Holds a unique punch of hoppiness. Goes great with good cheese like a smoked gouda or even a good blue cheese.

Pours a dirty brown with thick lacing and a quick to dissipate 
                  head.

                  Nose was actually not as hoppy smelling as I had hoped for. 
                  Still a very bold piney, hoppy aroma.

                  Well the taste of this brew is truly spectacular. Hop heads 
                  rejoice there may be a god. The Randall system does seem to 
                  add mucho hop and more character to the brew but I wonder how 
                  often they have to add new hops and take out the old? Oh yeah 
                  back to the taste. Slight grapefruit with other citrusy notes 
                  shining through, pine needle, a significant amount of tannin 
                  but thats due to the spectacular hop texture. 

                  Extremely long finish of pure hop, pine, and tannin. This beer 
                  is extremely drinkable. Almost too much so. Hopefully my local 
                  bar (Bostons Bistro) will have a go at Randall The Enamel 
                  Animal.

                  Would have loved to try a draught 120 minute with this. Would 
                  have also been interesting to do a side by side of a regular 
                  Draught 90 min and the Randall 90 min. 

                  Conclusion, if you know of a place thats not over a 2 hour 
                  drive from your homestead (unless you get a hotel) stop and 
                  try this unique concept in beer history. Well worth it.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2010 Poured a deep golden amber color with a nice white head that left good lacing in the glass.  The aroma is all hops at first.  Big fruity hops with some pine and flowery hops as well.  You get a hint of the malts as well.  The taste follows the same with a lot of citrus hops like grapefruit, pine, and orange and lemon zest in there as well.  The sweetness follows next with the nice malt profile that this beer has.  It has the sweet citrus taste with some raisins as well.  The malts blend together with the monster hops almost perfectly.  Full bodied with ample carbonation that leads to a lengthy, bitter finish. The alcohol leaves a warming feeling as it goes down. This is a good beer with its only detractor being just a touch on the boozy side.

12 oz bottle:  A big fruity hop aroma for starters, pine, somewhat of a malt aroma, but for the most part this is all hops.  Very nice.  Appearance is a clear golden color with a rocky white head that lingers for a whiule then deminshes into a soapy white flim.  Taste consists of nice bitter and fruity hops that consists of grapefruit notes, pine, and other citrus like lemon and orange peel are intermingled.  Some subtle malt characteristics also in there.  Overall, This is a pretty damn good Impy IPA not super, but really great.
Hands down one of, if not the best IPA in America, Sam got it right on this one
What a great IIPA!  easy to find nice "high gravity" and tasty hoppy beer

Simply one of the best beers made. Full frontal hops explosion, supported by dense, but not syrupy, body and hops carry you through to the end. Every sip tickles your taste buds. Pineapple, grapefruit there at the end. Flowers at the beginning. On tap, less hoppy, more malty, even a little sweet, but still excellent.

Quite light amber with a big solid head. Surprisingly malty aroma, with caramel, grain and some dried fruit - the hop notes are grassy and citrus. Dry and bitter but with a giant malty mouthfeel. The bitterness has a tobacco-like astringent touch which isnt bad at all. Some alcohol.
After being underwhelmed by the bitterness I checked the date to see if the journey across the Atlantic could have killed it. But it was bottled in April, and I was disappointed in May and in June. Im just not a fan of really malty and sweet IIPAs. But store it three years and Ill probably love it as a barleywine.

Bought a few bottles after trying and enjoying the 60 minute but thinking it was a little mild on the hops.  This one gets it perfect.  The deep golden color and thick head hint at something special.  The smell is pure citrus hops.  A hint of caramel and spices perhaps as well.  The thing that separates this for me from others like this is that the taste delivers on the promise of the aroma.  Hints of tangerine, herbs, and some sweet candy linger on the tongue for a long time.  It is just a remarkably well balanced beer that goes well with a nice grilled meal, cheese, or by itself.  Ive got some Dreadnaught stored up, but until I try that, this is the best IPA/DIPDA around.
(bottle) Nice amber color with a nice, frothy head. Citrus aroma. Sweet, caramel flavor initially but quickly turns bitter. Makes for a nice balance.
Bottle. Pours a clear amber color with a small white head. Malty hoppy citrus aroma. Sweet malty hoppy and bitter citrus flavor. Sweet malty finish with a long bitter and slightly harsh aftertaste.

[bottle] Amber colour, dense head. Aroma is biscuits, vanilla and orange peels. Thick, oily and sweet mouth feel. Really bitter, but in a balanced way, theres also some notes of tobacco. Finish has a slight alcohol burn. Maybe a bit too sweet but still a great beer.

After seeing the high remarks I had to try this beer and was on the same page as everyone else. By far my favorite IPA to date. Just turning 21 I havent had the chance to experience a lot but this tasted great!

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2007 Bottle.  A damn good beer.  Definitely set aside some time for this one as the depth and maltyness can be overwhelming if you drink it too fast (or too cold).  It is at its best in the 50 - 60 degree temp range.  Worth seeking out.  Bravo.  
rr.. raised from the initial rating of 4.3.  This is just one of my favorites.  I feel like the malt almost steals the show.  Great aroma (brandied fruitcake indeed)on this one.  Color translucent.  What a fantastic beer!  I could drink this anyday with a big smile on my face.  One of the handful of Unique Double ipas

Pours a perfect dark gold with a nice white head. Lots of hops in the nose with some citrus and pine. Spicy, hoppy taste that is soooooooo smooth. Wonderfully complex and very easy to drink.. Absolutely wonderful.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2009 Boittle thanks to enjoyit, gareths party shack ipa tasting. Aroma is biscuity, grassy with muted citrus hop, vague hints of roasted barley. Taste has hints of coffee, molasses, big toffee base, balanced with hops but where are the 90 ibus? Wheres the american citrus hops!!!!!!! RERATE:down from 3.6. Perhaps i expect too much from this beer. Its got alot of biscuity and caramnel malt, the hop character is muted somewhat however the alc is very well hidden. It does pair well with stilton but its more on an english strong ale than any IPA iv ever had.

Pale orangey/peach clour with a thick foamy head.  Aromas of strong coffee,  hops  and yeast with some brandy finishing notes.  This is quite a sweet beer and had minimal carbonation which made the malt flavour on par with the hop character.  The brandy tones also linger in the finish.  I had high expectations of this beer. Not bad but not as good as its meant to be

Thanks to sk8viking for this wonderful beer. The aroma is full of hops the typical american hops - wonderful, you can sence the alcohol and there is also a bit of aroma could be comming from the yeast. The body is very similar to a pilsner - which is the only negative thing about this beer. The flavor is first sweet from the hops, but then it gets very bitter. You can also taste the alcohol. The appearance is very nice - its copper, but with a red tone.

Orange, amber colour with an off white head. Hoppy fruity and pine bitter aroma with a light caramel sweet note. Sweet malty and hoppy bitter flavor with fruity notes. Light dry and pine bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2007 Definitely one of my favorite IPAs.  Poured into a snifter a rich amber with a small, quickly diminishing off-white head.  Good lacing on the glass.  At first smell I detected hints of apricot and grapefruit, as the beer warmed it smelled more of hops and alcohol.  The taste is excellent with more hints of apricot, sugar and hops.  It feels extremely smooth in the mouth and going down the throat with almost perfect carbonation and a mild bitter aftertaste.  This is a great beer!

Bottle. Pale amber with small off white head, long lasting. Nice hoppy aroma with citrus notes and also some caramel in the background. Taste hoppy but not so dominating as in other IIPAs I have tasted also some prominent notes of malt. Very complex flavor and nice mouth feel. 

The end is a little bitter and some alcohol burn. A very good IIPA the high rating is deserved. Nice to see that a very hoppy beer doesn´t have to be onedimensional. You don´t sit back with the feeling of eating hop pellets, that is extreme in Mikkellers Green gold, and I think that is positive.
Bottle at KØ07. Clear copper colour, very small head. The flavour is very malty with a good pepperiness. Fat and sweet and nice.

bottle pours a rich golden color. with nice frothy head.  Aroma is of sweet caramel with a hint of bitterness but very malty.Taste is smooth and sweet with some lovely fruit notes.  finish is both sweet and bitterness with a bit of alcohol kick.  Good but I expecet more bitterness.

Perfect for hardcore hop-heads!
very typical of dogfish head!
deep orange body with a white head. 
Grapefruit, pinapple and a touch of sweetness in the aroma.
Great hoppy flavours on a huge malt base.
Matches really well with fish!
love it.
Deliciously hopped ale with little evidence of alcohol. Strong pine smell with citrus accents. Looking forward to having this again.

Good Lord, what a beer. From the bottle, pours dark amber with one-finger white head. Aroma is grapefruits, some pine, slight apricots, and sharp hops. Taste has a surprising malt backbone, with grapefruits and some citrus in there as well; hops are surprisingly mild for a brew this powerful. HIGHLY recommended.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2007 Pours amber with a small off-white head. Citrus hop aroma. Taste is very hoppy (citrus and pine) with a hint of grapefruit and maltiness. A bit thick but not too much so. Could be more bitter; secondary hop flavors are prominent.

One of the best DIPAs out there.  Has more than enough hop flavor, and the alcohol is well hidden.  Hints of grapefruit-- that bitter flavor of a grapefruit rind.  Very comparable to Three Floyds Dreadnaught, but I give Dreadnaught the edge.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2009 I always loved this beer at Ashleys in Ann Arbor, as it was hand-pulled, cellar temp, left sticky, sappy lacing all over the pint glass, but the dark-lit, smokey atmosphere took away from the experience.  Out of the bottle, into a snifter: it was a mostly-transparent dark orange with a lasting spongy white head.  Aroma, strangely enough, was exactly like a big red sucker (syrupy sweet with artificial cherry), and with some pine and grapefruit in the background.  Sticky mouthfeel with sweet flavors that reflect the aroma, and a heavy malt character to balance out the amount of hops.

12oz bottle: Pours a copper/amber with a small head that quickly disappears. Some lacing left. Aroma sweet butterscotch with some citrus. The mouth is malt driven with some bitterness but not a clean, fresh hop profile. Over numerous tasting this bear is one of the more variable brews Ive come across. Ive had better examples, on tap, and worse examples, in old bottles. This is a good DIPA but not great.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2008 Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA - Draught through "Randall The Enamel Animal" (Cascade hops)
Date: 4/26/2007
Event: Dogfish Head at Dilly Deli. 
Location: Dilly Deli - Wines & Gourmet.
Serving: 16 oz draught.
Tasting Notes
Aroma: Fresh hops and grapefruit with some light orange and citrus as well.
Appearance: Clear golden color with a mild level of carbonation.  Lasting puffy/whipped foamy off-white head.
Flavor: Toasted and sugary malt with lots of grapefruit and citrus hops.  The bitterness level is moderate and seems less hoppy and bitter than the bottled version.
Palate: Medium body; smooth and mellow.
Overall: The hop-back is definitely a fun and interesting gimmick, but I actually think that the 90 Minute from a bottle or better yet, just straight, un-adulterated 90 Minute on draught is better...
Rating:  7  4  8  4  17 = 4.
______________________________
2008 Vintage
9/29/2008:  Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA is the color of an apricot with a coppery tone.  It has a frothy to foamy beige head and low level of carbonation.  A sugary cornucopia of fruit/tropical fruit (orange, grapefruit, apricot, pineapple, mango, peach, etc.) fill the nose.  The flavor is a wonderfully balanced combination of sweet, toasty caramel malt and mixed fruit in heavy syrup.  Its strong, yet delicate and sweet, yet bitter (moderately so and then some).  This beer has a medium to medium-full body that just slightly syrupy and goes down so damn easily!  This is an awesome Imperial IPA that is so easily sessionable that its completely dangerous, but yet I just cant stop!!!
Comparison to DFH 60 Minute IPA...  Sweeter and stronger with more citrus, more caramel than toffee, more bitterness.  IT is slightly darker in color and a thicker, more syrupy body.  Slightly sticky and completely addictive!
12 fl. oz. bottle (9% Alc. by Vol.; Bottled on 05/15/08 F).  Rating:  8  4  8  4  18 = 4.2.

12oz Deep Amber color with a good long lasting head.  Lots of tarty hoppiness in the nose with strong orange peels and grapefruit.  Flavor lives up to the nose, good blend of hop/malt balance.  The alcohol content is well hidden.  Mouthfeel is smooth, and has a thicker body to it.  This is right up with hercules.

pours nice golden copper color with large head.  nice fresh hoppy aroma.  good malt backbone with alcohol being evident.  bitter.  i like bitter.  this may be overdone a bit.  maybe i need to rerate this after another one.  however, maybe one of these at a time is enough.  i usually have stayed away from this because of he high cost, but i was able to pick a few up in a mixed 6er for under 9 bucks.

Hazy copper coloring. Hoppier, stronger flavoring than the 60 minute IPA and leaves you with a heavier, higher alcohol delivery to the tongue and back of the throat. Solid, impressive IPA but a little short of too high expectations.

The best beer Ive had, and I dont know how much better it can get.  Definitely a different beast than the 60 minute offering from Dogfish Head.  Initially, the aroma and first taste of the brew is definitely that of an IPA, but the finish and the effect on the palate is incredibly smooth.  I cant think of an occasion not to have this beer.

Lovely amber color, head appears thin but lacing is thick and healthy. Beautiful collumn of carbonation. Nose is of rasberries, hops, alcohol, barley, and almond. Tastes sweet, sharp and wonderful. Alcohol is present, but not overpowering. Full bodied and dry. Basically, I love this beer. Thank you again Dogfish Head.

What a way to kick off my Memorial day weekend with my first Imperial IPA.  All I can think of when I drink this is grapefuit juice.  The balance between sweet and bitter with a note of fruitiness.  Very viscous, the bubbles have a hard time rising to the top.  I wonder what the specific gravity is on this one.

Bottle. 12 fl. oz. A pure, clear amber color with a thin, off-white head. Sweet, fresh aroma of hops and citrus.  Palate is very smooth and drinkable. Flavor is much sweeter than expected with a dry finish.   Maybe a little too sweet, but still very good.

I could watch tv thru this beer. It is just pure magic. The tiniest head and most pleasing copper colouring. Sweet sweet sweet. As much as they claim the IBU to be 90, you really cant feel it for all of the wonderful sugars. This beer is a legend in its own world. Easily one of my favourite beers.
great beer espicially when they run it through the randall right at the brew pub
Bottle. Amber colour. Malty, hoppy, fruitish and alcoholic aroma. Flavour is quite sweet and hoppy with a good fruitiness and some spices, alcohol and with a pretty bitter finish.
A nice caramel hop aroma. Not much head. On tap in Flagstaff. Tase is thick and strong, reminds me of an Arrogant Bastard but without all the astringency. A bit too strong in the finish.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2007 #200 Clear amber look with a very small white head. Aroma is fresh hobby with a minor caramel sweetness. Flavor is burning bitter but yet pretty balanced. Has a soft oily mouthfeel and a very dry finish. Not really a signature brew, but very solid and tasty.
clear reddish amber with fruity aromas. sweet malt , fruity hops and spicy undertones very good

Bottle. White creamy medium high and lasting head. Clear Amber good looking body. Hoppy barley malt aroma with fruity notes. Dry nutty grassy herbal flavor with a suitable dry hoppiness, long dry bitter aftertaste and low carbonation.

On tap at the Landmark Inn.  Red amber color with a small but creamy head.  Sweet malt aroma with peaches and pears bolstering the malt.  Flavor is sweet and spicy malt with a sweetness of fruit and brown sugar.  Nice herbal bitterness in the finish as well.  This is a really good, satisfying beer if you have the money for it.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2007 Re-evaluation 12-30-2007: Same tasting notes as before but I enjoyed it much more this time around.

 Nice creamy IPAish ale. Really sweet malt dominates - hops really are more like backup singers in a malt ensamble drink. A little apricot and pear characterize the slightly spicey malt body, which is nicely complex. Its a really nice drink overall - again, I would call it well balanced, but not what I expect out of an IIPA - nonetheless pretty damn good.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2007 This is the Flagship beer of Dogfish Head!  This 90 minute Imperial is heads above their 60 minute IPA.  I think it is worth every penny, $9.99 for a 4-pack, if you have the pennies to spend!  A great deep golden color, great intense body full of hop and fresh aromas, and leaves a great, crisp-dry finish...Has a superb balance of flavor.  This beer is one of the best out there...period!

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2009 Pours mostly clear, dark brassy amber in color.  A persistent head of light khaki colored foam leaves sticky splotches of lacing all over the glass.  The nose, when fresh, displays good balance between darkly toasted caramel-toffee malts and a bouquet of potent, citrusy, floral hops.  Though the biscuity, malty side tends to win out, grapefruit and orange are still prominent.  The flavor follows suit, again well balanced, with notes of caramel and toffee deepend by hints of dark fruit, while citrus and pine resin lend substantial bitterness.  The palate is big, balanced, and falling on the sticky side.  Overall, this is a classic, well-done, East Coast style IIPA.

Københavnske Øldage 07. Golden with a nice, creamy head. The aroma is nicely hopped, but not as much as I hoped for. The flavour is sweetish with notes of caramel, pine, grass and citrus, but again, a lot less than expected. Its nice, but compared with a lot of other nice DIPAs, I think it could have a lot more personality. 2131

Bottle @ Københavnske Øldage 2007 in Copenhagen. Clear light amber color with a average fizzy good lacing mostly diminshing off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, moderate hoppy, citrus / orange, alcohol. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long duration, very nice balance. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.  Very nice malt and hop balance ;o))
By far my favorite in this style, easy to find, and easy to enjoy.  We have found it to be very consistant from case to case.  Great hops/malt balance, Head/carbination are fine.  Finish is pleasant.

Bottle @ Copenhagen Øl Festival. Small fizzy white head that mostly diminished. Spar lacing. Clear flat amber color. Pine grapefruit, elderflower, citrus, liquorish, caramel. Medium to full bodied with an average carbonation and dry texture. Well balanced between the moderated bitter hoppy notes and sweet malt flavor. Dry and bitter finish.

Pours red/ sparkling copper with a creamy white head. Aroma is moderately malty; cookies, cereal, toasted malts and caramel, Hoppy: moderately so of grapefruit and lemons. Yeasty; lightly, of bubblegum, prunes, apples a hint of vanilla. Flavor is well balanced. Nice malty body, and great hop balance, clean and refreshing, medium bodied creamy. Drinkable!
 
-couldnt have stated it better!
Fantastic. 12 oz. bottle from a local wine shop. pours dark tan, almost red, light tan head.  very balanced taste. delicious.
Excellent!  I wish that all beers could be this good.  I also enjoy the less volatile 10 minute IPA.  jja

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2007 Bottle.  Pours a clear golden/amber with a medium sized light tan head that lasts.  Aromas of hops, grapefruit and pine.  Flavor is of light citrus and hops with a slight undertone of alcohol.  Very smooth and lightly sweet with a quick bitter finish.  If not for the higher ABV, the underwhelming hoppiness of this beer could pass it off as a regular IPA.  That is not a complaint.  Just that most IIPAs tend to be a bit more of an onslaught on the senses.  Overall, very nice balance.  High quality and definately worth trying.

12 oz bottle. Pours a crisp clean reddish/amber with a nice size white head and just the right amount of visible carbonation. Aroma is a hoppy piney resin and slight earthy notes. Palate starts off oily but turns creamy as you swallow. Flavor is a little weaker then the smell and I would of liked a little more hop bitterness especially on the aftertaste. Very smooth especially for a double IPA. Very nice beer that wont disappoint the hopheads.

Pours sparkling medium amber with a creamy white head.  Aroma is moderatly malty; cookies, cereal, toasted malts and carmel, Hoppy: moderatly so of grapefruit and lemons.  Yeasty; lightly, of bubblegum, prunes, apples a hint of vinilla and dust.  Flavor is well balanced. Nice malty body, and great hop balance, clean and refreshing, medium bodied creamy.  Great!

This starts with a hop nose, with some sugary sweetness lurking behind it.  It pours  a clear amber with almost no head, but good lacing.  Slightly sweet flavor to start with, that then changes to bitterness, with just a hint of citrus in it.  Not the best DIPA, but far from the worst.
Bottle. This is a hop heads dream. Light and cloudy in color. Cascade nose as soon as you open the bottle. Taste is all hops, nothing else.
Light cobber. The well-known Cascade hops to the nose. Very Cascady with lots of citrus and pine to the nose with a bit of spice. Medium body with a malty backbone to support all the hoppes.
Bottle at CPH festival. Clear gold with off white head. Moderate hoppy and malty. Very well balanced. Bitter sticky. Surprised how moderate/well balanced this is!
UPDATED: AUG 20, 2007 Bottle, Olfestival. Obvious hop aroma, caramel malt, quite soft, bit sweet, some grapefruit. Smooth flavor, alcohol hardly noticeable, quite bitter, bit malty, some caramel.
An exceptional; brew.  A smooth hoppy taste from beginning to end.  This beer is consistent in its flavor.  Beautiful color and an intoxicating aroma.

Rated 2/3/06:  WOW, this is one amazing brew! Sampled a 12 ounce bottle which I poured into a merlot glass. The aroma was an intense mixture of hops, sweet malts, and more hops. The bitterness of the aroma lead me to believe that this beer may be too much for me. In the glass this beer is a wonderful amber color with ample head and very nice lacing. Once I took my first taste I was immediately blown away by the flavor of this beer. The hops were not overpowering like I had expected, in fact they hit you at first but mellow out to give way to some nice malt flavors. This beer is extremely high in alcohol content but you wouldnt know by the flavor which hides it well. I could definately see myself enjoying a few of these and then sliding back into my comfy chair with a very nice mellow buzz.

Orange and copper with a pillowy head. Smells sweet, citrusy, and piney. Tastes of candied oranges, sweet sugars from the malt with lemon and grapefruit that give way to a pleasant bitterness, very nice balance between the two. Medium to heavy body, the alcohol is hardly noticeable. High quality dipa.

An above average beer ...one of my regular favorites... Everything about this beer speaks hops...from the moment of opening the bottle to the goldern copper pour to rich hoppy taste that fills your mouth...
UPDATED: MAY 14, 2007 Probably one of the best IPAs out there.  Strong hop presence.  Poured a copper color with an off-white head.  There isnt an IPA from Dogfish I havent liked.

draft. golden amber with a decent head. sweet alcohol and hoppy aroma. flavor is sweet and velvety with a big alcohol presences cmplimented by a great big hop presence. was expecting a bit more bite but what is there is just great. medium coating mouthfeel that lingers. nice bitterness in the finish with a warming alcohol feel. great beer. one of my favorites.

Pours a slightly cloudy light copper, off-white head, still. Aromas are nice and big; fragrant perfumed floral & herbal hops, orange, honey, altogether smelling harmoniously sweet and quite inviting. Flavor big again, maybe too big? well see... Bitter and sweet are waging war on the tongue throughout, oily mouthfeel, lingering finish with a gritty ending. Definitely intense and engaging throughout. Perhaps a bit too sweet, but still excellent.

(bottle)  I cant believe I havent reviewed this one before!  Very sweet caramel like aroma and pours a light see thru amber.  Nice strong, but not too strong bitter.  Hops linger in aftertaste.  Refreshing and bold after more sips.  90 minute lives up to the hype, and is certainly better than the ridiculous 120 minute.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2007 12oz. Nice overall sweet malt aroma. Lots of different flavors going on, a tad to sweet for my blood. gives you a lot to think about while its in your mouth, lots of flavors going on. its just darling.

Pours a dark yellow/amber color with a white head. Huge hop and malt aromas with some alcohol hidden in there. Wonderful hop flavor that is back perfectly by a great malt flavor. Wonderful bitter finish. This brew is a light enough drink all night compaired to some of the "Bigger" imperials Iv had.

12oz Bottle: My first purchase at Consumers in Buffalo, Id heard good things and desired trying it myself.  Cracked it open to find a very appealing aroma of grapefruit, malts, heavy floral hops, just amazing.  Poured deep orange/brown in colour, a thick white foamy head.  So far so good.  Then I tasted it.  This was truly one of those "OMG" moments when it comes to beer, its just exceptional.  All the promises offered in the aroma come through, somehow treading the line of heavy hopping without shocking the palate.  This is by far the best balanced beer Ive had to date, and Im cursing myself for having bought four and promising two of them away in the car ride home.  %$#@!!

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2007 On tap at the Flying Saucer in San Antonio.  Poured a medium amber color with a creamy white head.  The smell was fantastic.  Surprisingly fruity nose with a heavy scent of hops.  Took me two tries to really fall in love with the brew.  But if you are a hop head like myself i know you will love itl.

On tap at Gooskis, i smell (thourght he cigarettes) grapefruit, carmel, toast & orange. deep amber color with medium head. a llittle thick but frictionless in the mouth. Among hte flavors of hop, citrus & caramel malt I sense strawberry. the hops always win the bottle but the malt/sweet keeps coming back. Nice thats its a 5 minute walk away.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2007 Love this brew.  Pours a deep copper color with thick, white head and excellent lacing.  Nice, balanced hoppy taste that isnt overpowering just for the sake of abusing the tastebuds.  Nice kick on the finish.  One of my favs.
On draft at Zenos, Penn State.  Poured amber with a white head and splotches of lace.  Thick malty body with a blast of hoppy bitterness.  Excellent IIPA.

Excellent, Wonderful, Exceptional, Awesome, Freakin great.  You have to be a fan of hops to enjoy this brew.  This is a serious IPA.  Crisp clear light reddish yellow in color. Thick frothy head.  Taste started super hoppy but then faded into a nice smooth malt.  Intense, but not overbearing or distracting from the overall taste.

An excellent beer -- well balanced, sweet and clear, with a smell that will seduce you from across the room. Nice head finish. ...And leaps and bounds the best thing available by the keg in Dallas -- at a friends birthday party, this ended up being the only thing available and at some point, we were using this for beer pong -- best tasting game Ive ever played.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2007 Poured into a pint glass with a medium white head and honey-gold colour. Medium Carbonation. Aroma of caramel apple blended citrus hops. Initial taste is sweet, malts present with finishing silky hop bitterness. Alchol presence is minimum and palate is long lasting.
A very good IPA. Im always impressed by what Dogfish Head comes out with. Bought a single, the finish was a bit dull and tasted very odd. Mightve been an older batch. Cant wait to rerate.
One of my favorite beers of all time. The hops are fantastic and it is quite strong. I can drink these beers all night long......well most of the night

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2013 Mild floral aroma with some citrus as well.  Very pale with fairly thick white head.  Alcohol bite up front with even bitterness throughout.  Slight bit of pine with a slightly sweet malty finish before tailing into an alcohol aftertaste.

Great Beer!  I am not a huge fan of the Extra hoppy IPAs but decided to give this one a try just because it is rated so high.  I like it alot.  Wonderful Beer just a little too expensive. $8.99 for a 4 pack.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2007 Color is uniform dark gold. Clear, not cloudy. Wonderful strong smell. Smooth taste, not quite enough bite for me, but they have a bunch of different variations in terms of how much they hop it so I could probably find one more to my liking (Oh, by the way, strong! 9%)

Bottle. Poured a a beautiful red amber color with a small white head. Small amount of lacing on glass. Strong hop nose with undercurrents of peach/apricot. Smooth mouth feel. At first the hoppy bitterness is overpowering, but the nice peachy citrus taste comes through eventually. The alcohol is well hidden. This seems to be one of those beers that can sneak up on you and kick you in the ass if youre not careful. Hey, its friday, who wants to be careful. Good brew. Not quite sure if its worth the price I paid, $10.99 4 pk. Will buy again if I can find it a little less expensive.
Lace of head.  Dry citrus flavor.  Great aroma.  Full-bodied and sweet.  Hoppy, yet well-balanced.  Overall, a really good brew.

Vast improvement in my opnion over the 60 min. expect intense hops that slighly fruity. The texture is smooth and very pleasent on the tongue. The alcohol is well hidden and worth the price of the 4 pack.
One of my favorite beers. Tastes awsome I havnt had it in a snifter yet. I can drink a few of them and I like that. It doesnt fill me up which is very nice to. Get it. Love it. Drink it. Yum.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2009 This beer has a nice orange color to it but there is no head at all. The aroma is of pine and hints of hops. As you drink it you get strong pine and hops but still refreshing enough that you can enjoy it any time. You can really taste the caramel malt and that pepper finish on the sides of your mouth. Each sip is just as good as the first.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Oak Tree Discount (South Plainfield, NJ). Arôme: Odeur dagrumes et de pins. Apparence: La couleur est cuivrée avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dhoublons fruités. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence damertume en arrière goût. (Rating #990)

Bottle. Pours a clear amber with a two finger light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of sweet malt and tons of floral and citrus hops. Taste is the same with a very strong but well balanced bitterness. Full mouthfeel that is slightly sticky and resiny. One of my favorite IIPAs.

Pours dark golden brown with plenty of foam
Plenty of hops with hints of fruits in the aroma, tastes fruity and smooth and has a nice bitter taste at the finish.. overall an excellent IPA

pours a deep gold, with a touch of red. thick two finger head with some serious staying power. Aroma is more subdued then I expected. very smooth, silky mouthfeel, with a sweet malt up front with a very nice lingering, citrusy bitterness. alcohol is evident, but not overly so.
good beer in the bottle, very good beer on tap. nice balance of sweet and bitter
I just love the taste of this one, a lot of alcohol for what it is, but somehow that doesnt dampen the flavor

This is a great tasting beer considering the fact that it has such a high alcohol content. The price is about $10.00 for a four pack but is well worth it, because after drinking two of these you feel like you have drank a six pack. The alcohol is well hidden with the great complex of ingredients and processes they use to make this beer. 

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

After the pour the taste is somewhat hoppy but after the beer is very smooth in taste and the sweetness is evident in this great beer. Alcohol is strong and unnoticeable until beer 2.   One of my favorites.  Kudos to Dogfissh Head.
Golden in colour. Small white head. Was more sweet than bitter, and lightly carbonated.Overall a good/decent beer.

Pours with a nice gold color and decent white head.  Good Hop nose but not overpowering.  Excellent hop flavor and sweet which combined well for drinkability.  Good hop finish but not overpowering.  High alcohol content not noticeable until you had 2 or more.  Not a hop biter IPA, but overall smooth and enjoyable.
Golden in color. Hops with hints of a sweetness in aroma. Taste was hops and sweet malt

Probably shouldnt have started with this brew as my first IPA.  Beautiful golden color with white head.  Light carbonation.  Smells like candy and tastes great. Sweet, hoppy flavor that makes you want more.   Wow....much better than I expected.

Bottled 9/22/2006. Pours rich amber with a minimal bright white head. Not overly expressive on the nose. Notes of sweet malt. Some hints of citrus developing. Nice creamy, malty body. quite a bit of hops on the palate with a sweet malt backbone. Hints of pine, mango and tangerine. Finishes quite dry and hoppy.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2007 Clear amber, small off white head with some lacing.  Slightly citrusy aroma.  A very complex flavor with some sweetness. Not overly bitter. Highly drinkable.
A great beer but I would  prefer it to have a lower alcohol content.  Nice amount of hops but I found it to be a little too sweet, but im just being picky.

i like the hops (hop head) but prefer an alcohol level of about 6 to 7%. it has all of the great attributes associated with this great brewer. so complex and full of monster hop qualities. malt base which is truly fine. perfect carbonation and a real beer guy wash which is my idea of drinkability.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2010 Delicious beer. This starts out very sweet for a double IPA. The hops provide a lightly bitter sweet finish. Not much alcohol presence. It has a complex flavor that does not get boring as you drink it. A good bit of roasted malt as well.

This one, wow, you drink 2 or 3 and you are good.  I should know b/c I drank 4 and was gone.  The taste is awesome, well balanced, the smell, well smells like heaven.  The appearance is great, nice head, well balanced beer for an IPA fan.

I dont know about this one...I was expecting it to blow my current favorite IIPA away (Terrapin Big Hoppy Monster)...but it didnt. Great beer, but not THAT great. Drinkability is an issue here...I didnt want to drink more than 2 at a sitting...

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear copper, small head, huge lacing.  Very pleasing aroma of citrus and flowers, however, missing that big hop presence that I expect in a 2IPA.  Flavor has a nice balance of sweet malt and grapefruit.  I can also taste some pine notes.  Alcohol presence is almost non-detectable.  Smooth and oily mouthfeel and lasting bitter finish.  There are better 2IPAs out there, but still a contender.

Pouring this beer was an experience. The aoma traveled stongly from arms length to my nose. I dont really know what makes an IPA into an imperial IPA, but somehow I was expecting lots more hops. The flavor is really just like any IPA, the hops definately do not overpower the malt in this brew. Soild and well ballanced.
UPDATED: OCT 29, 2008 Had numerous times...and this might be the most overrated IPA i’ve ever had.  Where are the hops?  Malty, boozy, and VERY unenjoyable.  This is average at best.
This is one of the top beers and I agree.  It is cokmplex and shows nice amounts of dense hops.  Just watch it as it bites you at 9%.

Amazing beer.  A very full hops presence, verging on overwhelming, but not quite.  Looks great, tastes great, the only problem I have with the beer is that for 9% the alcohol is a lot more pronounced than I would expect.  Other than that it is a great beer.

Appearance light copper to a honey. Aroma is slightly floral to a light pine."Sweet grass in the spring." It has an instant sweet to bitter flavor, without an overwhelming hops bite. Quick change from front to back and right back to the front of the taste buds.

This was an okay beer.  Ive had several offerings from Dogfish Head and this is probably my least favorite.  Its still good, but not my cup of tea.  It has a strong fruity flavor.  If youre into that, this beer is for you.  I am not.  The finish is a bit sour and leaves you feeling like you need another beer.

Pours a deep, golden color. Inch high white head. Fruity, citrus nose. Well balanced flavor with moderate malt, fruit highs and well hopped. Mouth-feel is good as well, very smooth. One of the best IIPAs Ive ever had.
Darkish golden color. Very hoppy with hardly any alcohol flavor. Fruity tasting. Certainly the most drinkable IIPA Ive found.

The perfect beer for a lover of hops! Flavor is full and balanced, with all the ingredients complementing one another well. Bitter/sweet taste that grabs you as it warms you. Despite the higher alcohol content, the alcohol does not overwhelm the taste as it does in some other hop beers. Lots of distinct, rich fruit flavor mixed in with the best of hops. One of the top selections I keep in stock at home.
Bottle.Medium amber.Floral aroma.Hops are pronounced,but not overpowering.Well balanced,smooth and delicious.This is one of my favorites.

Bottle in Chicago, citrus aromas and pours a nice golden amber.  Sweet at first sip, then follows through with the citrus from the aroma.  Refreshing and complex, a rare find.  Almost unrecognizeable next to the 120 minute IPA, but equally as interesting and much more "drinkable".
Pours with a dark orange-honey coloring. The flavor is a brisk, hoppy tangerine with a hint of grapefuit. Tart and bitter, but pleasantly palatable.

Bottle at Jbru´s, march 07. Hoppy, flowery and fruity/ citric aroma.  Full, malty, bitter, flowery, bittersweet and spicy finnish. Full MF a punch of flavors, though extreme, it´s very balanced and full of hop presence. You can notice the 9% but it´s highly drinkable for such a big beer. Betifull, shinny, clear golden appareance with a fine medium white head. An excellent sipping, not over the top, supercharged IPA.

Bottle.  Pours a lighter amber color with a small head  Nose is sweet, with malt muted pine.  This was delicious.  VERY balanced. Caramel sweetness with hops that are held under control by the maly guards.  Somewhat viscous and sticky but alcohol is totally hidden.  Lovely 2IPA.

Pours a brilliant,  golden orange with a medium-sized, light tan head. The aroma is mesmerizing - it is extremely malty, but not in a one-dimensional way: caramel, toffee, fruit, karos syrup, all combined. There are also some grassy hops in the aroma, too - though not as much as Id expect from continuous hop-infusion. The taste is bliss: the tingly carbonation prefaces a deep, bitter-sweet, strong malt and hop duo. The tip of the tongue detects some bitterness. The middle of the tongue picks up more hop flavor that playfully balances the  heavy malt backbone. On the back of the tongue, the hop flavor and bitterness gain considerable ground against the sweet malt. There is some fruit flavors in the middle and end of the beer, but overall the taste is very clean. The finish is somewhat dry from hops, though feels full-bodied in texture. The after-taste is hoppy and sweet. The mouthfeel is a bit too bubbly - but swirling the glass to release more carbon dioxide fixes that right up. After that, it feels creamy, sudsy, and medium in body. Overall - what an awesome beer!
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2007 Great example of what a double IPA is supposed to taste like. Great hop flavor throughout. Very well balanced. Aroma was citrus and hops.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2008 Blows 60 minute IPA out of the water.  This beers aroma makes you feel like youve already drank the beer.  Some very piney notes and sweet sugary flavors.  Its a very crisp IPA with some fruity undertones.  An excellent beer for sure.  I gotta save up for a 4 pk.  This beer has since become one of my greatest pleasures.  Sitting down with a glass of this is just about as good as it gets!
wow....great hop flavor. orangish color, medium amount of head, easy to taste fruits and hops, great great ipa.

Bottle... Poured a slightly hazy orange with a fluffy white head, nice lacing.  Has actually a strong presence of malt in the aroma for an IPA. Great palate which helps with the enjoyment of the hops, tart fruit flavors, and a nice crisp, bitter finish. I love it, this is what I expect for an imperial.
Bottle. fresh strong hop aroma.very bitter, medium sweetness, long nice bitter aftertaste.
90 is clear and amber-orange.  It has a great, strong aroma...flowery, hoppy, citrusy.  A very hoppy flavor, with a creamy, full-bodied palate.  A great example of a DIPA.
perfectly balanced, variety of hops and finishes with a citrus aftertaste. simply a superior brew
Totally delicious.  Nearly perfect.  Strong, but not overbearing.  Flavorful, but not overwhelming.  Perfect.

[227-20060310] 12floz. Sweet grassy alcohol aroma. Clear, amber orange body with some medium-sized bubbles and a medium-lasting white creamy head. Same sweet earthy grass in flavour with a boost of alcohol. Very boozy medium body. Was anticipating a hoppier time with this one.  (Should probably re-rate with a fresher source.)
12 oz bottle thanks to dmac621. Good hop presence balanced out by sweet malt flavor. Hoppy smooth finish. Some citrus detected in the after taste.

Brown bottle, 12 ounces, purchased on November 19 2005, savoured on March 29 2007; eye: burnt orange, lightly hazy, creamy white-beige head, a bit of lacing, light effervescence; nose: hops, dry hops, lots of grapefruit, lightly syrupy (alcohol), caramel, grain; mouth: in that order: smooth, lliquor-like, not as hoppy as I was expecting but still lots of hops, nice malt skeleton to support the flavours, thin layer of caramel, alcohol become more apparent as the beer warms up, a bit of scotch, dry finale with a hint of alcohol and grapefruit, mildly bitter and sweet, full body, oily, slightly grainy and alcoholic texture, good carbonatation; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 12 onces, achetée le 19 novembre 2005, savourée le 29 mars 2007; oeil : orange brûlé, légèrement voilée, mousse crémeuse blanc-beige, un peu de dentelle, légère effervescence; nez : houblon tranchant, houblon sec, beaucoup de pamplemousse, légèrement sirupeux (alcool), caramel, grain; bouche : dans cet ordre, « smooth », liquoreuse, beaucoup moins houblonnée que je ne mimaginais, quand même beaucoup de houblon, beau squelette de malt qui supporte le tout, petite couche de caramel, lalcool devient plus présent au fur et à mesure que la bière se réchauffe, un peu scotch, finale sèche avec une pointe dalcool et de pamplemousse, moyennement amère et sucrée, corsée, texture huileuse, légèrement granuleuse et alcoolique, bonne carbonatation; en résumé : bien

My 1st PERFECT rating.If i won the lottery this how I would brew a IPA.
Not a shot of super hops but a mellow
barley dampner to simmer.Highly
recommended.9% drinks like 4.6%.

Poured into a tulip glass and noticed plump bubbles gush to the creamy head that retained itself rather tidily.  Caramel sugary nose reminiscent of wee heavy English ale. Bright copper body and a taste of candy sugar, burnt fruit with some alcohol heat.  The finish isnt too hoppy, more malty. Probably the most down to earth DFH beer, and one of my favorites.
What can I say that hasnt been said? You already know this is a MUST TRY brew. The best-bodied Imperial IPA. Period.

12oz bottle served in a Trappist glass. Pours a golden amber with a big, sudsy white head. Bubbles come up from the bottom of the glass to help form the head. Aroma of hops, citrus (mainly lemon and grapefruit), pine, some barley, malt. Low to mid carbonation, creamy mouthfee. Not astringent at all on the tongue as some others are. Finishes clean with just enough bitter kick to remind you this is a big beer. Alcohol is well hidden. Very nicely done.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2007 Not what I expected but still a treat. From the bottle. First time I had one of Dogfishes IPAs. Very smooth and sweet with many hints of citrus and herbs. I like my IPAs to kick my ass a little more than this, but it is definitely something I will have again when I’m in the mood. It’s unique and a definitely something to try.

As soon as the cap came off, I knew it was going to be good. Basically, this is a freaking excellent beer. Serious hops are set off by just enough syrupy sweet and citrus. A nice dry finish to each gulp. Nearly perfect, IMO.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 Bottled on 06/19/06, poured in Ball quart jar. Incredibly clear, shiny new-penny colored beer with 4 finger off-white head that leaves nice lacing. Aroma is excellent balance of dark-fruit malt and zesty hop. Flavor is dirty, earthy molasses, honey, tea leaf, alcohol, oak and peppery citrus. Medium body is mostly smooth, a little tingly but not nearly as bitter as I expected. Slightly sweet entry is extremely well-balanced at the end.

Bottled. Nice aroma, fruity, herbal, fresh twigs, grassy. Golden color, off-white head, good lace. Sweet, honey, herbs, grass, fruity, nice malts. Sticky, soft but light dry finish. Quite complex yet very well balanced.

Bottle. Golden hue, white foamy head and little bubbles escaping up the glass, lace runs throughout.  Grassy pine smell evident of the painstaking hopping process of this brew.  Suprisingly light and nuetral on the palate considering the strong aroma.  Clean taste with a dry finish, not bitter as I feared with all the hops.  I guess the rich amount of malt and barley causes such a great balance.  Excellent and hard to beat!
Good amber head.  Nice retention all the way to the bottom of the glass.  Very well balanced hop monster.  Wonderful floral hop aroma and great full mouth feel.  One of my top 5 all time favorites.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2009 Not exactly what I expected, but quite enjoyable nonetheless.  Pour was an average pale copper color with a one-finger foamy white head that receded quickly.  Some nice lacing hung around for most of the glass.  The aroma was sweet malt, mild citrus and nice floral hops.  The flavor was an incredibly well balanced blend of sweet roasted malt, grapefruit, floral and piney hops.  Velvety mouthfeel with soft carbonation.  Not a hophead beer like I expected.  More refined.  Like a grownups DIPA.  All kinds of beers can punch you in the face with a blast of hops.  Few beers find the delicate balance this one did.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2007 Pours a deep amber color with a foamy carbonated head. Tons of hops and the alcohol content is hidden. Great bite to this beer. Really good but somewhat overwhelming. I threw this up on St. Patricks Day.

Light amber, slightly cloudy.  Moderate-sized head with a slight amber tint.  Aroma of raw eggs and hops.  Moderate, fine carbonation.  Nice, smoky malt flavor with more body than Id expect from an IPA, but it needs more hops.  Probably the best IPA Ive had so far, but I think perhaps people are rating it a bit high.

Bottled 10/24/06, poors amber/copper , normal clarity, with Off-white frothy head.  Good Lacing with a mostly diminishing head.  Aroma is moderate with notes of hay, flowers, dough, pine.  Medium to full on palate with an Oily texture, soft/flat carbonation, and moderate alcoholic finish.  Flavor is initially moderately sweet and lightly acidic and finishes with heavy bitter, acetic, lightly acidic and sweet flavor.  Very hoppy beer with short finish that didnt linger as some have noted.  It places in my top 5 IPAs and only loses points on flavor and the aroma is good, but not intense enough, its too one dimensional for me but it is one of the best IPAs in the world.  Would recommend.
This is one great smelling beer - floral hop aroma abounds. Wonderful palate, hops very evident - lots of em too! Hints of fruit, sweet taste progressing to warm alcholic goodness.
Hazy golden orange body, clingy tan head.  Superlative palate, excellent hop profile, nicely balanced with malt.  I approve.

Surprisingly enjoyable, as I usually dont like IPAs too much. Not nearly as hoppy as I expected, although the hops are still quite present. Just a great tasting, crisp brew. Maybe I should try more of the style.

Pours an amber color with a small, fluffy, off white head. Aromas of citrus and hops. Sweet malts at first that are complimented by pine, citrus, and a nice alcohol warming at the end. Very smooth and  full mouth feel. Excellent Double IPA.

Pours a dark amber that has a reddish hue to it. There is a real nice half inch head that sticks around for a while. This beer looks very nice.
Smell is very floral hops. Its not smack you in the face hops smell, but its hops and all hops.
Taste is very well balanced. The hops are very well complimented by a good amount of malt. They all blend and work well together. Theres no bitter, astringent hops here.
Mouthfeel is very smooth and non-cloying. The label states that this beer is 9% but its nowhere to be found. This is a highly sessionable beer that I would not get tired of drinking. I could see myself buying this regularly.
a nice amber color...a little bitter at the end...smells as well as tastes sweet with some hops...was expecting a little more kick out of it, but overall a very good tasting beer

Where are the hops in this?? WHen i have a DIPA, i want it to kick me in the face with hops, but all i taste is sweet. Here is how i know this wasnt all that....my wife could drink this!  Pretty let down by this one. This makes two diff. DIPA in a row, along with the Goose Island that were dissapointing with very little hop kick.  Lots of grapefruit/orage sweet taste, with a little hop bite. Drinkable for sure, but after reading all the good reviews, i was very let down. Ill stick to Furious.
Clear amber color with a thick head. Aroma is hoppy and very inviting. Taste is strongly hoppy with a nice bitterish bite. Texture is zingy and smooth, and it goes down nicely.
Very well rounded IIPA.  Lightly malted with a very strong bitter finish.  Dogfish Head certainly knows how to do IPAs.
12 oz bottle. Pours clear orangish amber color with small white head. Hoppy aroma and taste with hoppy bitter after taste. One of my favorite IIPA.

Pours a clearish orange with a white head. Smells of hops (toothpasty). Very sweet - slightly sickening. Fresh flavors of hops. Malty back bone - bit too sweet, though. Full bodied. Medium to low carbonation. Bitter finish.
The Best IPA Ive ever come across.  Absolutely smooth taste.  Well worth the price.

bottle: fruity, pnw hop aroma, substantial off white head, ornage amber in color. not as bitter as one would think, and alcahol hidden extremely well behind malty sweetness and hop bitterness balance. Only evidence of high abv is warmth going down. Great beer.

A seriously good imperial IPA. Bottle. Pours amber gold. Medium rocky head, which lasts through the entire pint. Nice carbonation. Fruity aroma, with a nose of caramel and citrus. Flavor contains a taste of apricot. Medium finish. Full balanced. Goes without saying, but truly excellent.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 DFH 90 minute pours a deep hazy orange color with a decent head.  I smelled malts, hops, citrus, when I first poured it.  As it warms up a bit, there are hints of brown sugar.  The taste is an excellent blend of malts and hops with a good mouthfeel that is is warm and makes you crave another sip.  This beer has it all.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2008 Rated this before, and it was a touch different. Might have been a little older. Anyways, big dry hop aroma. Grapefruit, flowers, softer citrus like orange. A little sweetness of toasted caramel malts. Pours a nice golden orange with fantastic lace and a thin lasting head.Hoppy up front with a nice citrus floral bitterness, balanced by a good amount of toasted malt. Not too sweet by any means, but incredibly balanced work of malt and hops. A herbal hop/toasted malt profile is left lingering on the palate. Pretty freaking good.

very hoppy aroma
light gold appearance
hoppy flavor, very good
medium body

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2011 Bottle. Bold aromas of roasted nutty malt, light bread, orange, perfume, and soap dominated. Hints of dates, toffee and brown sugar appeared after it warmed. Its orange/brown in color with an off white head that has good lacing. Taste is just about perfect, sweet, tart, and bitter, and balance is its best quality. The palate is exactly what it should be. Light to medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation and a dry finish. This is one of the maltier and sweetest of the top DIPAs.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2008 I really respect what Dogfish has done here. This is my favorite DIPA. Very different from the "west coast" style, the 90 minute has a very complex malt character to it that does a good job of balancing out the abundant hop presence. This beer does not disappoint! If you can make your way to the DFH brewpub in Rehoboth Beach, Deleware I highly recommend trying a "Randalized" pint of this stuff.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2007 Bottle. Pours clear orange, very little off-white head. Head dissipates quickly leaving only small amounts of lacing around the edges of the glass. Smell is very hoppy, floral notes, as well as citrus, overall very crisp and refreshing. Flavor is very bitter, the alcohol is nicely balanced and is only strongly evident in the finish. The hops hit right from the beginning but there is also a malty sweetness. The hops soon win out and you are left with strong hops bitterness assualting the palate.  Moutfeel is creamy and very warm from alcohol. This is an excellent beer.

12oz bottle. Poured into a 22oz glass lead to a 2 inch+ head. Great orange color and fluffy fluffy white head. Floral hops came out to blow up all over this beer. The smell filled the room with a sweet hoppy smell. Taste is really sweet with a gentle bitterness that cleans the mouth after the awesome sweet bombardment. 

Freaking fantastic beer. Im really pleased with it and Im not a hop head, more of a malt monger and I think this brew finds a happy place that will please both sides of the equation.
Strong and tasty. Its a nice fit right between the 60 ans 120 minute varieties.

12oz. Bottle

90 Minute poured a beautiful dark orange. An aggressive pour produced a 1+ finger head. The head was creamy white along the edges of the glass with moderate bubbles throughout the the center. Decent lacing. Big carbonation bubbles rising from the center of my snifter.

Smell is mostly hops but there is a solid malt backbone. A ton of floral hops along with tropical fruit. Pineapple, mango. I also pick up bubblegum every now and then. Strong hop scent. Makes my mouth water.

Now on to the most important aspect of it all. The taste is up there with some of the best IIPAs Ive had. The flavors are exactly like the smell.
