A solid caramel backbone but the main point is the juicy fruity hops. I was expecting more bitterness but the end is a good balance with only a slight bitterness. As it warms I can feel a warming alcohol in my nose and throat.

Medium bodied. Coats my mouth nicely as I drink. Moderate carbonation tingle on my tongue. 

Drinkability is good. It would be a little higher but the alcohol comes out more as it warms. 

Sampled 10/22/06
This IPA has an amazing blend of hoppiness and sweetness. It is currently my favorite IPA out there.

Enjoyed this beer quite a bit.  Nice color, smooth head.  Great flavors from start to finish, a very well put together ipa.  A little too syrupy sweet to get on my drink often list, but I definitely appreciated it.
Herbal, grassy nose.  Body is somewhat syrupy and sticky, with a big malt build up to a very bitter finish.  Hops come in late, making for a very interesting and balanced IPA.

Really enjoy this beer.  Clear orange with a big head.  I smell the hops while I pour it....a good sign.  The flavor is amazing.  Very dry malt backbone, yet it still fills my mouth.  Not thin......carbonated.  Very spicey.  Lots of pine and citrus.  Yum.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2007 pours an orange/ copper color with a large foamy off-white head.  apricot hop aroma.  hints of alcohol with tons of hops and a ginger bread malty finish.  bigger malts than the 60 min. but the alcohol shows itself more too. creamy mouthfeel, not stingy.  i liked like 60 minute better.
Great beer,copper with soft white head.Gets better as it warms .Very drinkable.I would drink it any time.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2011 ++++ Re Rate 2 February 2011 ++++
12 oz bottle, Brew Urban Cafe in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Bottled on 12/20/2010. Pour is hazed golden orange with a 1/2 inch white head that falls quick. Aroma is honey and floral hop sweetness, along with some resin and caramel malt. Mostly about the honey sweet. Taste is sweet honey and caramel malt, along with a bright citrus resin. Decent balance, some booze showing through in the back. Sweetness cloys ever so slithly as it warms, though this serves to minimize the alcohol some. Palate is medium to heavy bodied, coats the mouth a bit and lingers with honey floral sweetness. (7,4,8,3,15 - 3.7).
++++ Original Rating 1 March 2007 ++++
Bottle.  Pour is copper amber with quite a bit of initial carbonation, which settles quickly.  Head is smallish white.  Aroma is hop, earthiness as it warms.  Taste is extremely smooth, extremely full, with a ton of balance for a DIPA.  Tastes of citrus, flower, dried apricot, just a ton going on with this one, but still tied together well.  Finish is dry.  (8,4,8,5,16 - 4.1)
Sampled a 4-pack in Maine. A very nice beer. Flavor is tremendous. It pours very nice into a glass giving a nice head and aroma. Very smooth and tasty when you consume. A very well crafted beer.

Bottle from Wilburs poured into tulip - Pours a beautiful amber with a 1 1/2 finger white head; Big malt note, with lots of floral and piney hops that I could smell straight from the pour to the nose; BIG floral notes with some fruity esters, a piney bitterness and alcohol on the initial taste; A sweet maltiness and balanced hoppiness on a warming aftertaste; Smooth full body; Present carbonation that didnt get in the way; Damn good beer. It was like a solid IPA with a little bit of a belgian trappist twist added to it. I definitely enjoyed! Couldve done with a bit more hops (I know...I shouldnt be saying that).

Clear copper penny with a pillowy off-white head.  It has an intoxicatingl nose of stewed apricot and orange, ginger, and clove.  Soft and full on the palate with very light carbonation.  The flavors his deep on the palate with candied orange peel dominating with spice overtones.  THe finish is very hoppy and surprisingly woody.
very good. reminds me of sam adams, but with much more flavor (more hoppy).  Recommend, but BEWARE....very strong.

Nice hop/malt aroma.  Good balance. . .   	Lt Orange w/ white head. Fair amount of bubbles. ..	Malty start with hoppy notes thru the finish.  Not too hoppy overall though. ..	Medium body, medium carbonation. ..	More malty than the color would imply.  Less hoppy/bitter than the label implies.  Good stuff though. ..
Good amber color, good head. great hoppy and citrus smell and taste. Liked it a lot just not as much as HopSlam.
NIce color, a lot of flavor, medium to full body, very hoppy, the best from a great brewery.
90 minute is a lot more hop than the 60 minute. Great balace though. Pous a nice amber.
Pours amber with thick off white head. Has aroma of hops, fruits and citrus. Flavor of grapefruit, hops, floral, and citrus. Execellent IPA not too strong and well balanced.  WoW

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2007 LIght copper, dark orange in color. Almost exact match to the coat of my golden retriever. Nice crisp hoppy aroma with citrus and pine undertones. Wide array of changing flavors throughout the beer. Starts off hoppy, but opens up to all kinds of citrus, pine, and malty flavors. A very nice, clean, refreshing drink.

Bottle.  A very nice balance of orange/grapefruit hops and caramel malt aroma.   Medium amber with a nice big head for a I2PA.  Caramel malt hits the tongue initially with a strong pine/grapefruit hops finish - however found the hops much more restrained than I would have expected.  Much more malt flavor and much less hops than most I2PAs.
I liked this beer, but I didnt find it AS exceptional as others have.  Good IPA, but i wouldnt drive 50 miles just to find some.  Hopslam > DFH 90min.

Im not much of a fan of IPAs in general, but I actually like this beer.  I think the alcohol really balances it out, and gives it a good backbone.  Where other, lower gravity IPAs are far too bitter, this manages to have a smooth, yet decidedly hoppy finish.
Pours a deep golden orange, copper with a thin head.Aroma of citris. Tastes sweet, malty, hoppy. Not bitter or over carbinated. Slight alcohol finish.
Light aroma of hops and coffee. Dark golden color. Starts off with a short sweet flavor then turns in to all hop flavor.

35,5 cl bottle. Dark golden clear colour with a nice fine head. Aroma of caramel, hops, sweetness and strong alpha hops. Very bitter but with a fine balance between the caramel and sweetness. Ends up very nice endeed.

Im not a professional beer taster, just a guy who likes a good beer, so my comments should be taken with a grain of salt. First off, I found the high alcohol content to be a bit distracting...it adds a certain roughness to the beer and may be one of the primary reasons I didnt like this beer. The aroma reminds me of paint thinner and so does the taste. Sorry, but that is the best comparison I can make. Perhaps this is the nature of all IPAs...hopefully not. I honestly believe that the excessive alcohol content is partly at fault here, so I am going to try a lower alcohol IPA to find out.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange-gold with a small off-white head.  The aroma is of hops, grapefruit and smoke.  Very sweet with the taste of hops, smoke and grapefruit. Smooth with an carbonated slight alcohol finish.  Nice.
12 oz. bottle.  Clear orange hue with a small white head.  Citrus aroma.  Taste a little bit on the bitter side.

Pours a hazy light amber/golden brown with a huge off white head.  Aroma is malty and citrusy, with a little alcohol in the background.  Taste is malty for the style with a bitter hop aftertaste and alcohol is present as well.  Overall a pretty good brew.
UPDATED: MAR 11, 2015 Great IPA..well balanced.. Copper pour with medium cream head.  Nearly perfect IPA that masks alcohol well.  One of the best.

A little more malt than most IPAs. It helps flesh out the flavor to keep it from being too bitter. THe hopping technique gets you the full range of hop flavors without getting as bitter as a lot of the extreme IPAs. Manages to be huge and full flavored but not overpowering.  Possibly the most rounded and best IPA.

This is by far the best IPA ive ever tasted.  It pours a golden color with a medium white head.  The aroma is of citrus and malts.  It tastes of hops and malt at first, but isnt overly bitter like many other IPAs.  It finishes with a strong citrus aftertaste, and then a bitter taste which is not overpowering at all.

[Bottle, February 2007] Pours golden with medium head. Aroma is grapefruit. Mouthfeel is wet. Flavor is grapefruit and hops with a bit of grass. Finish is bitter, but without the offensive bite of some DIPAs. Very well balanced beer. Not  being an IPA fan, im impressed.

12oz Bottle. Orange amber, with an ample white head that fills the pint glass. Floral hop aroma. Hop flavor starts out strong and seems to build, eventually coating the palate. Hop presence is huge, but well balanced by malt.
Nice orange color with a small white head fading to a ring around the glass.  Aroma is hoppy.  Taste is hops balanced by a nice caramel sweetness.  Very balanced IPA I could drink all the time.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2007 Reddish orange amber color with medium sized head. When fresh, its quite tasty with sweet caramel notes, fruits, appropriately balanced hop bitterness, and creamy mouthfeel. A little on the oily/resiny side. One of the more unique IPAs available. Warning: ages really poorly. Do yourself a favor and drink this fresh only.

The aroma threw me off a little bit because I couldnt pinpoint from citrus or hops, both were present. Pours a great color orange. The flavor is very well balanced by citrus hints and a floral hops note. Goes down very smooth and finishes clean leaving a dry non bitter not sweet taste. For me this an outstanding beer that has left a good impression.

Pours orange, clear with a light, bubbly head. Strong aroma of hops, light citrus fruit like lemons and orange. Very solid mouth feel with a sweet addition of malt. Warm, alcoholic, sweet, with a strong hop bitterness to balance it all out. Very excellent beer!

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2008 Take some grapefruit and pineapple juice, add a bit of vodka tonic, and youve got DFH 90 IPA.  This 9% outdoes every IPA Ive had.  Perfect balance, starts sweet, but then drying with a touch of acidity.  Even though I favor porters and dark lagers, I always find myself buying a case of this beer because it is such a crowd pleaser.

Update: 2004, aged 4 years.  Hazier, lettting less light through.  A lot less hop aroma and flavor.  Pineapple and citrus flavors are heavily muted.  Dark rum, raisin and burnt sugar are dominant flavors.  I notice mroe alcohol, especially on the finish.  Overall, reminds me of a tripel - 4.1

12 ounce.  Pours the color of a newly minted penny.  The head is a light cream color, frothy, an inch thick, and leaves sheets of lacing behind.  Lively carbonation fuels smells of sweet, summer grass; citrus; other fruits; lightly buttered, toasted grain; and a hint of alcohol.  The flavor is complex and balanced.  Orange is primary, with a grapefruit edge.  Just slightly acidic.  The flavor mellows as it progresses, but lasts.  For a high "alcohol by volume" beer (9%), there is surprisingly little alcohol flavor on the finish.

This Imperial India Pale Ale is not quite as "harsh" on the initial draught like some IPAs.  It is acidic, but not overly so.  Excellent.  I could just keep drinking this.

12oz Bottle Pours out a goldish orange. Topped with nice off white head. A Great aroma of hops and I could pick up some of the alcohol in the aroma. But in the tast I didnt pick up on the 9%. A nice combo of hops and sweet. Vrey good. thanks to Schutzenliesel 
for this one.
Bottle.  Good hop aroma, and flavor of bittering hops and lots of malt.  Very enjoyable.

Good stuff. One of the better imperal IPAs.  Good body.  i smell a lot of grapefruit on this one, but also some apricot and banana.  Very balanced aroma.  The balance continues in the flavor.  The beer is centered around the hops, as any Imperial IPA should be, and they dominate, but there is an underlying malty flavor that is firm and provides much of the body, but is less assertive than the hops.  Finish is all clean hops.  An excellent brew.

poured a dark orange with thin layer of head that dissippated fairly quick, hoppy aroma, bittery hop taste is apparent at first but then disappears and develops into more of a sweet-malty character. felt a little bit of the alcohol as it went down.  a very balanced beer nonetheless.

What an awsome beer.  Poured a orangesh hue with a nice white head.  Taste is of apricot, hops , and malt.  I realt liked the smoothness of this beer.   I cant remeber a beer that had such a complexity to it.  Cant wait to try the 120 in a few  minutes

Brilliant copper hue, sparkling body fueled by active carbonation, frothy head leaves thick, uniform lacing. Seductive aroma- citrusy hops slightly-overpower grain and hay malts. The taste is bitter along with toasted grain and alcohol. Palate starts off syrupy then transistions to watery. Finish is bitter and alcoholic. The alcohol is a bit too apparent for my taste. The best American IPA?! Not in my book.
a very tasty brew. dark amber color. nice aroma.considering the ABV, I was expecting the alcohol taste to be strong but it wasnt ... definitely a dangerous beer ;)

Bottle poured a clear copper with a small lingering off white head. Aromas of carmel, pine and a hint of citrus. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, pine, light orange and a hint of grapefruit with a lingering moderatly bitter finish.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2008 12 oz bottle...Nice filtered coppery color with nice big fluffy head. Aroma is grapefruity. Hop flavor leans heavily on the grapefruit side, with a nice caramel-like malt backbone. Alcohol is just slightly present as it warms. Carbonation is moderate and about perfect for the style. Very filling IPA, and definitely one of the better ones Ive had.
I really love this beer. The smell, taste, everything about it. This has to be one of the best beers that ive tried so far. I apparently need to trade a little more to keep some in stock..

pours fairly thick dark gold with a nice white head. good lacing. aroma honey malt and floral hops nicely balanced. sweet honey dominates the flavor with a nice touch of bittersweet toffee and spicy hops. finish medium dry spicy bittersweet floral honey hops. full bodied. thick syrupy mouth feel but with lively carbonation. hardcore heavy IIPA. good.....a bit too sweet.....but good.

Poured gold-tinted auburn.  Small to medium white head.  Aroma of grapefruit, hops, and flowers.  A little sweet.  Good balance of malt and hops.  Multiple hops create a unique overall flavor.  Some throat warming.

(bottle)into a tulip.  pours a cloudy golden amber with low fizzy head that sticks and does not dissipate.  has a light sweet hoppy smell and you definitly notice the barley.  taste is heavy in the front, light in the middle and the finish, with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  you taste the barley and the hops in this one.  a very good IPA, and you do not notice the alchohol so be careful, it will sneak up on you...

12 oz Bottle. Pours a hazy amber. Huge hop nose, but the taste is surprisingly sweet. Alcohol is noticeable. Nice bitter finish. A very good brew, but I was hoping for more. Certainly not my favorite IIPA. I would rather drink Dreadnaught any day of the week.
One of my new favorites.  Tons of hop flavor and aroma, yet well-balanced malty character.  The only problem I have with this beer is that its $10 a four pack.  Would love to find this in a keg.
my favorite beer of all time.  so damn tasty. nice and creamy, bursting with hops.  a hopheads dream beer.  there is no trace of the 9% here.  makes it a little dangerous.  thank god its year round

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2008 Golden color on pour with a whitish head that disappeared in a hurry.  Light aroma of hops, malt, and grassland flowers.  The mixture of hops creates a very unique and interesting flavor.  In fact, the flavor is mostly malt and the different hops with a touch of grass.  Smooth on the palate, the finish is mildly bitter (for an IPA).

(Boittle brought back from the East Coast by a friend) Very heavy body, but then again what to expect from something at 9% alc?? Its supposed to be dry-hopped, but not a very heavy nose of hops in my glass. Color is cross between dark golden and orange, leaning more to the former. Nice hop charactor. Yes, there are hops there like there should be with an IPA, but its NOT an overly bitter hop charactor. (Note to self, start experimenting with Warrior, Simcoe and Amarillo hops!!!!). Quick pouring head, which disappated pretty quickly. Nice palate. Hops stay in aftertaste, albeit VERY light. Just enough to remember what you drank, but not enough to make you wait to take another sip. Make sure this beer is not too overly chilled. When I first poured it it was a bit on the cold side, but after letting it warm up in my glass the hops open up a bit. Id buy it again, assuming it ever gets out here in the West Coast (the neck lable DOES have CA CASH VALUE on it so they must be planning to some day!).

12oz pour(wish I could find it on tap). Nice white fluffy head, crystal clear golden color. head disipates fast, laces nicely. Huge aroma of hops + malt. Hops + malt balance in the first sip are awesome considering the eclectic blend of hops used.A balance like this is no easy task! Only at the very end do you have any sensation of warmth from the 9%abv. This could be a session beer, but it would be a short session! Everyone wants Imperial IPAs now, this is the gold standard.

Rustic, very hoppy.  Very good for the IPA genre.  Nice head, a bit dark for an IPA.  Holy Hops batman.  Cant quite give it a perfect score, not quite complex enough for me (belgium fan) and touch too hoppy.  Did I mention the hops?
UPDATED: MAR 21, 2007 Dark golden with a foamy white head.  Sweet and hoppy nose.  Very strong flavor.  Incredibly hoppy, full and complex.  This is really well balanced as well.  A favorite.

This is one  of my favorite brews and it sets an example to all other IPAs out there...from the bottle or straight from the tap...the distinct and perfect blend of hops malt and the delicate sweetness that pulls it all together makes it an irresistible brew...not to forget the feeling of euphoria that dogfish consistently delivers..Gatorade bottle or any other large plastic bottle is a wonderful way to enjoy the ultimate IPA...my first plastic was a wawa bottle
UPDATED: JUN 14, 2007 My favorite IIPA. Nice clear amber orange in color with small head. Sharp aroma. Very citric flavor with much grapefruit and hops. I enjoyed this much more than Dreadnaught.

This IPA is a hoppy, full bodied brew that is a great IPA. Actually, hoppy does not even come close to describe how hopped us this complex necter really is. This is overly Hoppy for some but if you are an IPA fan like my self, then this brew will hit the spot.
simply my favorite IPA ive had so far. everything you could ask for...big floral and citrusy hops, a nice malt balance, and an almost creamy mouthfeel.

pours with a nice head and a clear copper hue.  its fruity, and not quite as woody as its little brother.  its nice that the head retention is there till the end.  had the 60 minute and i was impressed.  luckily, theres a stronger hops presence here.  overall, well go with sufficiently above average.  i should go get more.
My favorite from the Dogfish series. Great flavor, balanced between hops & barley, with a little citrus flavor and definite sweetness.

bottle. pours copper amber. nose is tons of hops and sweetness. palate is spicy but generally smooth. flavor is the delicious west coast hoppyness dfh is so good at capturing and accentuating. sweet as hell and overall just a damn good beer. not the most drinkable thing in the world, but a great one-beer night.

On Tap-Pours out a slightly off orange color w/a moderate off white foamy head. Definate hopped/roasted aroma, but not overpowering-pleasent. Initial flavor of deep, crisp hops, but not so much to be offensive-youre not chewing on them. Has a sweet, grassy, somewhat nutty barley flavor on the back end to balance it out. Long sweet finish. I am not usually an IPA fan, but Dogfish knows how to make them right, this is one you can easily enjoy as a sesson brew. Cant wait to try their 120M-and I never thought Id say that @ an IPA!!

Pours cloudy amber with a thick, off-white head. Great retention. Super hop aromas but no ttoo overpowering. Very intense sweetness of grapefruit aroma with grassy undertones. DELICIOUS!!! Fantastic balance of hops and malt. Goes down easy for such a big beer. I tried not to compare this with the 60 minute which I also tasted this night and evaluate it on its own. The extra half-hour does wonders for this beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Wow hops!  Pours a golden copper with white foam which diminishes to a very thin lacing.  Aroma is deep amounts of citrus and fruity hops.  Initial taste is citrusy with something like apricot seed and mouthfeel is incredibly smooth with alcohol not noticable until the end, which has a arming effect.  The hops are what really stand out obviously, but after a few sips the sweet malt emerges and lingers along with the hops which is now diminishing but balances out very well.  I dont know if Id call this the best beer in America, but its certainly the best IPA Ive ever had.

This sets a standard that has yet to be matched by any other double IPA. You would never notice the alcohol content without it displayed prominently on the front. Its more refreshing than any other double IPA i have ever tried.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2007 This is probably my favorite dogfish head. On tap at various NYC and DC pubs. it has a substantial mouthfeel, weighty but balanced, in hte glass its a beutiful copper that just emanates hops. Nice citrus tones/flavors, but pine dominates. Wonderful Perfect !

Bottle.  Amber with white head.  Wonderfully floral aroma.  Rich, complex--fruit, floral, bittersweet--taste.  A really distinctive DIPA:  cant think of any Ive had that taste quite like it.  Ive had many bottles over the past year and my only complaint is that taste its a bit *too* floral for it to rank with my very favorite DIPAs (Russian River, Great Divide), but I think this is a more interesting beer than, say, Stone ruination.  And, to me, this is probably the best thats easily available all over my New England state in a 12 oz. bottle.

Bottle at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Clear amber, thick and dense offwhite head. Delicious hops fills the nose- promising fruit, citrus and toffee. The taste does not let you down- this is medicine for the hopaholics! Yet it is also well-supported by a solid toffee base. Consistency is almost sirupy, but very appropriate. Lovely, but dangerous!

Pours a clear, deep, amber - the color of apple juice - with less than an inch of tightly packed white head. The foam quickly recedes to a ring around the glass. Spotty lace. Strong spicy and floral hop aroma from the moment the cap is popped. Lovely aroma in the glass.

Hops, sure, but what gets me is the malt. Prominent malt with a lot of sweetness. OK the hops are fantastice. More spicy hops with a lot of tangy bitterness. Rounded out by a good deal of alcohol. Full body, full flavor, wonderfully hoppy - yet smooth. Nice carbonation combines with the hops to bite the tongue. Hops stays in the aftertaste (for a long long time) along with the alcohol.

Great IPA.  One of my favorites thus far.  Although, I am a n00b, so might find myself re-rating some of these first ones in a couple months.  Either way........ Poured nice amber color, w/ small, lasting head, and a little spotted lacing.  

Smell is malty. Taste is moderately acidic/sweet, with a nice malty overtone.  Do also taste a slight citrus/floral flavor.  

Initally hits the palate with the strong malt/pungent alcohol combo.  Finish is very light and leaves almost no lingering aftertaste.  Almost seems as if the high alcohol content washes any aftertaste away.  

Overall, very enjoyable.  I like, very much!
I really didnt like this one too much. The high alcohol content really came through in the taste and lingered. It also had a small head which lasted. To me the flavor was just too complex.
Very smooth, "different" tasting IPA.  Less bitter, with a great hop aroma. Very good.

very strong on the malt flavors. this is not quite what i was expecting from this. I expected more assertiveness from the hops. I could really taste the alcohol in this one. poured a nice clear amber color with very minimal head retention. not quite what I was expecting.
very nice citrus aroma, indicative of an IPA. Color was a cloudy caramel. Palate was a little thick, more than i expected. Not as bitter as i was expecting, but still one of te best IPAs ive had.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2007 Time for a re-rate. Picked this bad boy up because I havent rated it since the beginning of my beer career and wanted to see what I thought of it now. Poured a deep soft amber with a creamy thick light orange head, well retaining and stained the glass with lace. The aroma was sweet, dry alcohol, vinous, fruity, caramel. The flavor had a very vinous quality to it, sweet, dry alcohol, citrus, spice, grape, mild bitter/waxy hops, caramel. Smooth vinous body, felt like a wine. Warms as it goes down. Held up nicely.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2007 The color was crisp amber orange.  The head was thin, creamy, light biege, and laced some.  The aroma was very citrisy, lemon, hoppy, and alcohol.  The flavor was very hoppy, citrusy, fruity, bitter/waxy at the back of the mouth, and alcohol.  The palate was meium/thick bodied.  The finish was bitter/waxy and warm.

Bottle:  Orange amber pour with lots of head.  Nose is mostly citrus hops with hints of grass and some malts.  The taste is just a marvelous blend of hops to malt, balanced, and smooth.  Not a pure hops assault like I had expected, but a nice blend with the malt that created a rich and succulent taste.  Goes down almost syruplike and very smooth.  Thanks DocLock.

light amber appearance that looks a little thin with a strong white head.  a nice texture with a nice complex finish featuring both the hops and malt intertwined with some alcoholic warmth.  pretty well balanced, the hops arent overwelming and the alcohol is definitely noticeable
Citrus and malt aroma, hoppy!  Deelish imperial IPA, good balance between strong malt and hops flavors.  Pours a nice golden/orange.  Killer!

Bottle.  Strong pineapple aroma with citrus and malt notes.  Golden rose color with frothy white head.  Very well balanced and smooth.  Bitter and sweet balance between malt and hops.  Creamy smooth mouthfeel. Excellent IPA.

Ill start off by saying, wow. The only other dogfish ive had before this was the Raisin brew, and im not a fan of that one, so I was skeptical about this one, despite its reputation. Man was I wrong, its intense maltiness satisfied by an abundance of hops makes it a very strong while very drinkable beer.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2014 First slow and deliberate swig out of the bottle was spectacular, definitely an explosive scream of "quality" in comparison to the Summit IPAs that Ive had a number of times, although I do detect a fairly sharp taste of alcohol (which went away the more I drank, probably because of the buzz). Halfway through and Im buzzin well and a second might be out of the question on account of high ABV and I have to work in the early morn. Less appealing the more I drink but Ill definitely get another 4-pack in the future. Price: $10.99 plus tax for a four-pack. (Dare I take poetic license and deem four-packs "four-bangers"? Sure, Im buzzin a good one from this IPA so why not?)

Bottle. Poured an amber color with an off-white head that left light lacing. Big hoppy citrus aroma with some caramel in the background. The flavor is well balanced with citrus and malts. Medium to full body with a creamy texture that leaves you with some sticky lips. Sweet up front, then bitter in the end and after. Very Nice!

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2007 Bottle; pours a clear golden with nice white head; great lacing.  Aroma is surprisingly muted, but some malty hints of caramel and toffee come through.  Hops is undetectable in the aroma.  More light caramel, toffee, and a bit of raisin in the flavor, with a very smooth palate and just a slight hops bite in the finish.  Intensity is not a word that comes to mind when drinking this beer; you can tell theres a good dose of each, but the malts seems to balance the hops very well, if not a touch too well...  Recommended.
Bottle. Quite strong, rich and good. Both malty and hoppy. Very well balanced.

Pours a quite cloudy orange color with a big thick white head with great lacing. Aroma is a strong citrusy hoppy smell with a touch of spice. Big malt up fron that is beaten down by a considerable hop bite. Medium body and a nice aftertaste lingers for a while.
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2007 Golden. Very hoppy, sweet, tastes golden. Rich and slightly syrupy. A great IPA. Christmas present.

12 oz bottle - pours clear orange with a white head that leaves chunky lacing inside the glass.  Big west coast hop aroma, but quite a bit of malt in there as well, to balance.  Alcohol is there too, lurking.  Results in a sort of candied aroma, which continues in the flavour.  Grassy, sticky hops, and a far sweeter mouthfeel than I was expecting.  The alcohol remains hidden in the mid-palate and then right near the end of the finish you kind of get "burned".  Near the end of the glass, the alcohol becomes veeeeeerrrry apparent.  Much maltier than other dIPAs Ive had, but it works. A nice, nice beer, but Ill take (much to the chagrin of many, Im sure) the 60 minute over this, if I have the choice.  Great nonetheless.
Nice lace, good hop balance not very bitter just very flavorful.  This beer works well for rookies looking to sample a hoppy beer and for hop heads who love to taste well made hop beer.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2011 How unfortunate that I should try an IPA for my first taste of dog. I know they are a well respected brewery but the IPA is not one of my favorite styles. Had this on tap at the Bocktown BAr in Robinson Township Mall.  HAs a sweet fruity aroma, very nice.  This has a slightly different hue than your typical pale yellow american beer - a bit more brown in there.  However, this is not dark by any means.  Very hoppy initial bite, an excellent example of IPA.  The taste has an intense bitter grapefruit peel. Syrupy sweet, like medicine. Hardly any carbonation. You IPA lovers are smiling at my yuks.  Finish is long lingering astringent bitterness that will simply not go away.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: JUL 13, 2007 Delicious.  Awesome.  Surprisingly not that hoppy compared to what you would think.  But just a quality brewskiii.
smooth mouthfill. with a nice citrusy aroma. alcohol lingers on tongue along with a little bitterness.
Rich golden color. From bottle in tulip glass. Nice hop flavor, but not too hoppy. Long finish. One of best IPAs.
Bottle. Golden copper with frothy head. Storng citrus hop aroma that gives way to a surprising malty palate with a fuller body.

The initial taste is not what you would expect from the fresh citrus aroma coming from tiny bubbles of carbonation; it is a strong, spicy, hoppy explosion. This is my favorite beer of all time, but one will do it for me (unfortunately!)

Ample, persistant frothy white head on a clear amber sea.  Overwhelming citrus/pine aroma.  Lively mouth feel and a pleasing sweet aftertaste to contrast with the substantial hop bitterness.  Had this fine brew with an aisian marinated thin sliced ribeye and sesame noodle soup - with which it went excellently.  The high alcohol content became more noticeable in both taste and aroma as I proceeded through the glass which distracted a bit from this otherwise outstanding brew.

Pours a beautiful glowing copper/amber, well carbonated. Beautiful aroma, I can smell the hops from arms length! Amazing American beer, best beer Ive had to date. Hands down. Paid $8.50 for a 4 pack

UPDATED: APR 16, 2007 Bright copper color with a two finger head.  Hoppy aroma of floral and citrus.  Very balanced flavor between the malts, hops and alcohol that is most detectable in the finish.  Palate is slightly syrupy.
Very decent ipa, excellent hops , with a good sourness and touch of sweetness to round it out - well balanced..
Bottle. Very good beer had alot of hopps. Has a citrus undertone with the taste of hopps. Loved it.
Bottle. Very nice.  My 1st Imperial/Double IPA and I must say it wont be my last.

(Bottle) Pours a nice copper color with a small white head. Hoppy aroma, with citrus undertones. The beer is very well balanced, and the alcohol is disguised pretty well. Not quite as bitter as other DIPAs that I have had. Overall, a solid brew, and something I would buy again.
On tap & bottle @ Coles Buffalo, NY. My first DIPA & quite possibly my favorite DIPA. Amber color with huge hop aroma. Very well balanced with the high alcohol. Fantastic
Bottle Amber pour with small head. Very hoppy aroma and flavor. Great flavor that starts hoppy and transforms to a malty flavor with a malty aftertaste. Alcohol is decetnly hidden.  Great balance.

Aroma is slightly hoppy, mixed with sweet and a slight twinge of alcohol.  Pours gorgeous golden with a nice head.  Flavor is instantly warming from the alcohol.  Also sweet and hoppy dry.  Palate is a little sticky from the sweetness, but overall a fantastic beer.
Pours golden amber with a good frothy white head. Smells strongly of hops. Extremely smooth taste of hops, slight bitterness, with a crisp clean finish. Absolutly amazing beer.

12 fl. oz. bottle share with a buddy.  App.: med. orangey-amber colour, slightly off-white head.  Aroma: grapefruity hops, a bit of toffee, sweet malts and other fruits.  Palate: med. body, a bit syrupy, med.-full carbonation.  Flav.: malts, raisins and dried fruits, peaches and dried apricots, moderate bitterness, somewhat alcoholic finish and a bit of corn syrup.  Decent, but not really for me...

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2006 Bottle, from mug. A hazy, golden-amber with a fluffy, pale-yellow head leaving stratified lace. Aroma of apricot, citrus and spruce, with caramel emerging as it sits. Full bodied, with an oily yet creamy texture and soft, smooth carbonation. The flavor is dominated by potent hops, which are carried to the sinuses and vaporized with the alcohol. A strong foundation of malt breaks through the intensity of the hops and cannot be denied. The finish is big and bitter, but not overly dry. Clearly, this is a world-class beer: every aspect has a compelling counter argument. Sensational. I feel small in the presence of this beer.

Pour a rather amber colour with a white head that isnt really all that thick or that big... maybe it was the pour though. It had very much a fruity smell to it and twas swell. Nice bitter taste with a definate taste of alcohol. The taste was almost sweet at time with a sort of dried fruit undertone to it or something.. not sure exactly what taste it was, but it was definately sweet in more than one way. Nice thick bodied beer... good for the first double IPA that I tried... hope for some more soon.

Pours pale orange and clear for the most part.  Aroma is spicy...Im surprised to detect more yeast than hops (candies) but there is a bit of floral presence as well, and just a touch of pineapple.  Thick malts on the tongue, honey, green apple and orange.  Syrupy rich mouthfeel, but there isnt the searing bitter finish that I sort of anticipated.  Rather theres a hint of something sour that is vaguely unpleasant.  I liked it quite a bit but its nothing too enlightening.

12 oz bottle, via Secret Santa 2006.  Pours a clear bright copper colored body under a fizzy and foamy one finger white head.  Some very light lacing remained.  Aroma is actually fairly light on the hops, just a light floral note with a touch of grapefruit.  The malt really takes center stage.  Thick and almost candy like with touches of marshmellow, caramel, and toffee.  Pretty well balanced flavor for an IIPA, moderately bitter with some bright citrusy notes.  Alot of sweetness remains though, mostly toffee-like, and a little too candy like again.  Mouthfeel is pretty full bodied, lightly syrupy in texture with pleasant soft carbonation.  Finishes a little sticky and cloying.  Overall, this was pretty decent, but way down on my list of IIPAs.  I want something with a little more brash and in your face flavors.

I will be damned for this review, any credibility gained as a beer jester lost forever as hordes of angry beerophiles charge screaming at my doorstep to demand my head. It was my fault for drinking the beer before it reached ideal temperature (drink this warm or youll be sorry,) but even so, this beer didnt really interest me even at its best. The head is minimal, but thick. The color is crystal clear apple juice. The nose on this one is the dealbreaker - the 90 minute IPA smells distinctly of tuna fish. As one who dislikes tuna fish, I could not abide this. While this odious flavor does not carry over strongly in the flavor of the beer, it lingers JUST enough to sour my appetite. This beer doesnt have much overall identifiable flavor, but whats there is sour and unpleasant. It does improve greatly with warmth and time, but I think the 60 minute is much better than this fishy brew.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours an orangeish color with a small white head.  Lots of citrus in the aroma.  Thick mouthfeel, flavor is bitter, with a hint of citrus.  Alcohol very noticeable.  Very good, but perhaps a bit too much alcohol presence.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2006 12oz. bottle - pours a deep golden/orange with a medium white head on top. Lots of very earthy and lightly citrusy hops in the aroma. Some grapefruit. Also, suprisingly, some sweet malt in the background. The mouthfeel on this is amazing, very creamy and thick. Lots of bitter hops in the front of the flavour, earthy & grassy tasting. Sweet, citrusy notes take a backseat. Quite a bit of alcohol shows through in the middle and especially the finish. Again, the malts make themselves known throughout, tempering the intense hoppiness and keeping them from being overwhelming. This is a big beer, and very good. The only thing that keeps it just below 4 or higher is that, for my tastes, the alcohol is a bit too hot.

Clean tasting beer. The best mouthfeel in the business. Great balance. Lacks the punch in the face hoppiness of most yank iipas but in this case definitely a good thing. Only thing that puts me off is the price. Butterscotch flavors, with some smoke,  and grannys house or beefy aroma. Great beer.

Hop taste in the front with a clear hop finish.  Did I mention the hop taste in the middle?

Thick mouthfeel rife with hop oil yet smooth.

Bright citrus notes and shows a glowing copper color.  Long alcohol notes on the finish may turn off some timid souls but if youre searching for a very strong IPA, this is the one
Lots of citrus hops in the aroma.Pours a light copper color with a big long lasting white head.Flavors are a great balance of malts and hops.Pretty thick mouthfeel with a bitter hop finish.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy orange gold with a long lasting moderate head. Very pleasant aroma of grapefruit, sweetgrass, and malt.  Initial taste is not quite as flavorful as the aroma.  Then the hops kick in big time. Long, and I do mean very long, bitter finish.  Long after the beer has been swallowed the finish is is still making the mouth tingle.  Some heat from the alcohol also in the finish.

Fantastic microbrew.  Full body, longevity, flavor, everything.  It is what they say it is, and its good.  Great double IPA.
Some notes:
Red Amber and clear, lively carbonated, aromatic Full White Head, hints of the seashore amungst the complexity for hops and brew ingredients.  Twards the bitter side, but the aftertaste and mouthfeel make the equalizer.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2017 This was the first IPA Ive ever tried. Sweet and malty with some hops. SECOND/THIRD TRY::: Just split a 4 pack with Pat. This beer pours a clear reddish amber body with a nice head, even nicer lacing. Thick, syrupy consistency. The aroma is very subdued, slight sweet hops. The flavor is extremely smooth, sweet candy hops that take center stage. A bit too syrupy sweet.

Bottled - 1st of all GREAT BEER.. It took me a while to develop the taste of an IPA.. but damn its good..Pours an orange/amber.. Nose is a grassy hop aroma with some sweet floral tones.. Flavor is flowery with a sweet bitterness due to alcohol... awsome beer

12oz bottle.  Slightly cloudy straw cloured pour.  Balanced nose, sweet and malty.  Little or no hops in the aroma.  Slick, smooth mouthfeel.  Slighty bitter but not much hop flavor.  I have had this before but did not rate it then.  I thought I remembered it being better than this, guess my taste have changed.

Had a 60 minute yesterday and wow what a difference! The hops have a stronger bite (naturally) than the 60 and the bitterness fills your soul. The citrus isnt as noticeable in the 90 minute which is good for me. This is one tough cookie and one of the tops in the Imprial category
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Ive found this beer more and more around Charlotte, NC.  Its a nice flavorful beer but, is quite strong.  I dont recommend more than one or two at a time unless you want to get sloppy.  Well worth the money, if you can find it.
good ipa.  very hoppy taste and feel.  a little sweet for my taste.  its meh
Another outstanding IPA from Dogfish.  Great hops, sweet taste with hints of citrus and sugar.  Dark yellow/orange color, slightly cloudy.

Bottle. Poured a cloudy orange gold color with a thin white head. Citrus (grapefruit) hop aroma with just a little sweet malt. Sweet malty taste that was nearly perfectly balanced with the citrus hop  flavors. Somewhat sticky but not overly thick. Also some candy and maybe a little brown sugar smell and taste came out with warmth. Had a small amount of lacing and light, pleasant carbonation.

[Bottle from Beermouth tasted with the hop-bros at Jess cosy inn.]

Sweet barleywine-like-style. Could indeed have judged it as a barley with all this sweet hoppy notes, but the commercial description indicates that there has been used "ridiculous amounts" of barley. Maybe therefore!!!. But a nice barley/Imp. IPA indeed with this special mixed taste.

on tap at several bars in Washington, D.C. again, I wish I had written down which ones. (say hello to thanksgiving break!) but my commenhts suggest that it has... pours a deep amber body with a thick bubbly white head.  smells strong and hoppy and sweet. florals and citrus hops.  feels creamy on the palate. has a strong taste of alcohol and hops. citrus, orange peel. complex and interesing and well balanced and definetely worth drinking another and rating it all over for a better understanding of what the brewer was going for. try it!

This is the first beer ive rated, so i figured id start with a good one ive never had. Orange in color with a thin white head(mmmmm....heeaaaddd) very flavorful and aromatic. tied with golden monkey as my favorite IPA!

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2009 12oz bottle.  Beautiful, clear honey-orange appearance; bright white head with nice large-bubble formation at the edges.  Full aroma, showing plenty of honey, citrus, and pine notes; smells more sweet than bitter.  Medium-to-full, chewy mouthfeel: a nice upfront citrus hop presence, plenty of Simcoe piney notes surrounding it; with generous amounts of sweet maple syrup and honey to keep things well-balanced.  It doesnt show the dank, over-hopped qualities of a lot of the West Coast IIPAs, but I personally prefer this style. 8.4.9.4.17=4.2  Rerate. Oh, sweet mother of god, what happened to us, 90 Minute? I go away for nine months and I come back to what? Cardboard? Stale malts? Singular sweetness attempting to pass of as hop character? Shame on you. You look great, as always, but like many things after nine months abroad, I will not be picking you up and putting you in my mouth again anytime soon. There really is a huge sweetness here, nothing close to a dry, crisp, intense IIPA character; just sticky and stale cardboard malts, and this isnt an old bottle... Sigh. 7.5.6.3.11=3.2.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2007 Overall, one of the best IPAs Ive tried.  Perfect balance of flavors that let the alcohol come through, but not overpower.  Earthy (citrus, pine & wheat) mix with the semi-sweet caramelly malt and flavorful blend of hops to create a smooth and refreshing full tasting IPA.  Excellent!
(2004) Orange/yellow with reddish notes and a fine offwhite head. Hops, fruit, grass, herbal and malt. Very balanced and nice bitter finish.

Orange pour, bit of white bubbles.  Aroma of fruity and floral and a lot of hops.  A bit of malt and some sweetness also.  Flavor is similar, though sweeter, with, surprisingly, a very complex array of hoppiness.  Extremely well balanced, a bit of everything with a nice clean bitter finish.

One of the best brews on the planet as everyone attests to....Dogfish Head Brewery AND Restaurant in Rehoboth have gotten a little too big for their britches - $10 for a 4 pack of this is excessive - will drink Stone brews before ths.  Yes its a greaat tasing beer as is their whole family of brews, but their attitude, from the founder on down, sucks

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2009 Re-rate of a 2 month old bottle. Pours slightly hazy orange, with a medium head. Aroma of floral hops,  yeast and caramel. Taste of citrusy (orange) hops, fruit hard candy and raisins (yes). Velvety, syrupy finish. Very balanced flavor and a fine tasting brew overall. Not hop-forward enough for me, but its still good.

Sampled from bottle, as well as on tap at my home. 90 min is a hopheads dream come true.  Not quite as balanced as some IPAs out there but I tend to like the over the top bitterness more. Golden amber in color, the aroma is out of this world. Finishes with very little citrus which I like. And after having a few 90s you experience a euphoria that no other beer has quite touched for me.
Perfect Beer
user_location: Egg Harbor Township, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle from Beermouth. One piece of art, a beer to sit back and let it fill youre world.

light honey color. huge frothy head. typical sweet smelling imp ipa. honey and caramel malt. soem citrus. with hints of deeper pine.  dweetcaramel breadiness. soem pine and resin. bitter finish. the alcohol is decently hidden. pretty good but a bit too sweet too much resin aftertaste

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 A surprisingly good beer, that masterfully incorporates its high alcohol content.  The aroma was well comprised featuring caramel malts and citrus hops; it was strong but controlled.  The flavor had a rich mixture of sweetness and bitterness, and was well balanced.  Carbonation was mild to average and it was light and easy on the palate.  The beer was a dark amber color with a thin white head.  All in all, a wonderful India Pale Ale!
Amber color, thin white head. Little to no carbonation. Aroma of hops wine. Very rich flavor that lingers for a while. A truly amazing beer. Actually sessionable.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2007 I really enjoy this one.  Good hoppy nose and hoppy taste. Strong, but not overpowering.  I think this is probably the best of the DFH -minute IPAs, because its solidly hoppy, moreso than the 60 minute, but not as heavily alcoholic as the 120, which I find is so rich its lost its hops.

This double ipa has a mild aroma of citrus styled hop as well as malt adding into the mix. Strong and right in your face flavor of bitterness, tartness, and little reminder of sweetness. Plenty of citrus, grained malt, buttered biscuit, floral flower and pine all being put into effect so that this beer comes off as a standard imperial ipa by all standards.

Bottle dated 7/24/06.  Pours a reddish-copper hue, minimal head, some lacing , and miniature little bubbles rising to the top.  The aroma of this beer is amazing, not overpowering, but attention will be drawn from a small distance away.   Hoppy, citrusy, bitter finish.  Not too surprised, many friends have been raving about this for a long while, just got around to trying, and will make some room for this excellent beer.
12oz dated 06/27/06 - Beige head over tan liquid with bananas and hops on the nose.  Tiny, tiny bubbles and nice lace.  Flowers and malt on the front fading to hoppy bitterness.  Good times.
Bottle. Clear amber - white head. Weird thick feeling, high malty, sweetness, a lot of hop, resin, high bitterness. burning feeling on the tongue.

redish orange in my snifter. Wow is just about all i can say. This is the best imperial ipa ive ever had. 

Ive had the 120 and that was just a little to extreme for me, ths 90 min is just fabulous. 


caramelly in scent decently high alch. rating which is perfectly hidden beneith the beauty of this one. 

the finish is nice also, a tad bit bitter but not bad at all!!!

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2008 If there ever was a perfect beer, this may be it.  Seductive in its copper orange color and resilient head.  The quintessential aroma of fruity hoppiness.  Big burning hop character; toasted malt undertow.  Warming.  Resiny.  Nice sticky lacing.  Whereas the 120-minute is over the top, and 60-minute borders on the "ordinary", the 90-minute is the perfect balance between good and BIG ... even at $9 a 4-pack, I keep going back.  Sign me up for more.

[Sampled at SBF, 2006]
Golden.
Extreme fruitiness and maltiness.
Full-bodied.

Amber/copper body with almost no head.  Smells hoppy and caramel-malty.  Hops and alcohol stand out in the flavor, though there is a strong caramel malt presence.  Medium in body.  Very tasty and surprisingly drinkable considering the abv and ibus.  If theres a better IPA than the 60 minute, this is it (I know this ones imperial, but still.)

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2011 Bottled. Thanks to Stegosaurus and Beerded_one for this gem. Pours a red/gold looks beautiful. Hop aroma punches you right in the face. Good sharp hop taste blended perfect. A real GEM !!

Nice color and a very strong citrus nose on this one.  The mouth feel on the first drink always gets me.  A real sticky beer but the hops mellow out into a slight hint of alcohol flavor that hides itself well in the malt and hops.  The 90 minute IPA is probably the most enjoyable of the three (60, 90, 120) and it is not a seasonal.
Very nice golden/orange color. malts of toasted grain. Hoppy citrus orange.Sweet light flavor with light bitter finish.Medium to full on the palate. Wonderful.
Bottled. Clear golden coloured with a small head. Malty and a bit sweet and round. Heavy notes of hops and pines. Hints of caramel, spices and citrus. Well balanced.

This is the best of the double IPAs from Dogfish.  Dogfish loves their hops and this one is no exception.  With 90 IBUs it is best enjoyed out of a sniffer.  The hoppy aroma draws you in and is matched by the smooth hoppy flavor.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2007 Pours an almost clear copper with a decent, off-white, creamy head with some longevity and nice sticky lacing.  Nose is nice, but not extraordinary for an IIPA; piney resins meets citrus (grapefruit and lemon peel) and some grassy undertones.  A touch of sweet caramel with some lighly spicy alcohol.  Flavor is intense!  Starts with a nice rich, malty caramel, raisins, and some citrus hops, but soon gives way to the spicy, piney, resinous hops which make a bold takeover.  Bitterness is high, but the malt backbone is supportive.  Palate is medium, quite lively, sticky and smooth, and with some alcohol being noted into the finish, quite bold.  Finishes mostly bitter and dry with alcohol warming and spice with underlying citrus.  Wow, such an intense and bold Imp, much better than the 120 minute.  Plenty of bitterness and hop character with some nice malt qualities.
bottle. golden color. hoppy aroma. great hops in taste. strong aroma nd taste. bit bitter finnish. great beer.
Hops! not much more to say. the high alcohol gives a bit of an alcohol tatse, but it actually enhances the beer. Finally got my hands on some 120 Minute, so I cant wait to compare

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2006 The beer pours orangey-brown. Some might well call it copper, but its not as lustrous. Were presented with a solid off-white head showing good size and retention and even leaving some lacing, which is always nice.

The first aromas are purely hop resins. I love this piney stuff, and its a pleasant surprise, since I know whats coming next. When the resins recede, the citrus hops take over. Oranges and lemons fall from the sky. Alcoholic pepperiness is there, too, but no malt aromas at this point.

The beer is full-bodied with a bright acidity. It is not dry - there are some non-fruit sugars here. Dont get me wrong. The beer is not sweet. There is a sturdy malt balance to all the hop power, but frankly its a little boring. Cereal and grain and, to be generous, cookies. Alcohol is overt and ever-present. The finish carries its slight burn and a pleasant bitterness.

As the experience goes on, I receive impressions of tobacco and raisins, There are glimpses of toasted grain, but by now the lemony citrus has completely taken over and is driving us home.

The hopheads will be quite happy with this one, but I would be a lot happier with some additional malt character.

The basis upon which all other IIPAs were built.  Better ones have since been brewed, but this is one of the inspirations for many that have since passed it by.  Wonderfully balanced malt and hop character.  Smooth hop profile with no sharpness produced by their own patented style of adding hops.  Missing the malt complexity of other IIPAs, but still a good standby.

Bottle. Transparent copper hue with an attractive white coating. Inviting (but not overbearing) floral grapefruit aroma. Grapefruit and other citrus tones dominate the initial mouthful. This wasnt nearly as hoppy as I expected it to be, and the finish is almost sugary. However, perhaps because of this this, DFH IIPA is an exceptionally smooth, unobtrusive IIPA - dangerously drinkable despite its ABV.
very hoppy and bitter, but I say that as a positive...amazing ale with nice citrus notes and a very very clean, crisp mouthfeel.  Great IPA.

On tap @ Barleys Smokehouse: Clear copper color with a white head. Aroma, citrus floral and piney hops. Some light malts, caramel. Flavor, citrus, a nice malt backbone and some floral notes. Ive had this so many times, and while it used to be one of my favorites, it just doesnt stack up to some of the other IIPAs out there. Still a good beer though.

An hazy golden ale with a thin lacing white head. A doughy malt with nice floral hops, not as strong as expected. In mouth, a refreshing mentolated hops with dry malt, earthy notes, piney, but not as resinous as I expected. Medium bodied, a bit underwhelmed. A sharp alcohol attack is noted in final. Bottle is one year old, from BOTW.
Golden with a white head.  Fruity aroma.  Flavor is stightly citrus and a little hoppy.  Goes down smooth for 9%.  Very good, I had to drive 300 miles to find it.

Poured out of 12 oz bottle a medium Amber, smell of light hops and malt.  Had a medium sized beige head that sparkled with delight.  The first sip was of PURE heaven!  Caramel, honey and citrus!  Of extreme smoothness at the end that could make this a beermans essential brew.  This is the absolutley finest pale ale I have ever experienced.  This product puts the mega brewers of America to shame!  The smoothness hides the alocohol which can sneak up on you, but is so pleasurable.  This is a must stay in ones fridge.  For those that have not had the priveledge to experience this beer, God bless you and may someone have mercy upon you to share in this wonderful liquid of Gods delight!
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Thanks Dennis!  Pours amber with a thick beige frothy head, can smell the citrus as im sitting nearly 2 feet from the glass. NIce!! Floral, tangerine, toffee notes.  First taste, delish, just the right amount of hops, and is nice and crisp.  Good citrus flavors.  Very well balanced DIPA, wish it was more widely available.
We had a couple of them this weekend very good.  A lot of great mouth feel hoppy all around good.

This is an exquisite IPA, its powerful hops almost overpower you, but they are quickly smoothed out by the beers amazing mix of gentle flavors and graceful body.  By far one of the best IPAs Ive had.
Excellent Brew.  I would not rate this beer higher than Dogfishs 60 Min. IPA due to the thicker palate.  Still excellent beer flavorwise, but not as drinkable as the 60 min. IPA.
Excelent beer. My only complaint is that the beer felt a bit syrupy if that is even a word. It was a little to thick for an IPA. I would still reccomend this beer to anyone.
UPDATED: MAR 13, 2007 Moderate citrus and floral aroma.  Medium amber color with little head.  Smooth crisp hop flavor, slightly sweet with nice complexity and finish.

Had this a number of times, but I finally had the "randalized" version. Draft, of course, pours a nice burnt orange color.  Clear.  I thought at first that this beer smelled like a plant store, but my girlfriend pinpointed it and said it smelled like snapdragons.  Tastes sweet upfront still, sugary and earthy, well balanced with hops and snapdragon taste.  Texture is smooth while the beer is pretty thick.  Medium carbonation.  Finishes unexpetedly nutty/brown, and in this version very planty.  Excessively herby, and wonderful.  A bit cloying though after a while.  I like the sweetness, and the finish blends into the flavors incredibly well.  With the added plantstore-like flavors, this beer had a whole 4-dimension of flavor.  Wonderful stuff.

Deep amber creamy head
Pervasive hop profile ranging from earthy, to piney - resiny and citrus notes.
Oily solid mouthfeel.
Wild honey retronasal.
Nose is full of citrus delights-- great body, full of hops, smooth finish.  Couldnt ask for much more from an Imperial IPA
Tastes Imperial-y.  A very great DIPA.  Very well balanced for being a DIPA.  By imperial-y I mean sweet, of course.  Just a very good, solid beer.
this is a glorious ipa, maybe not the best but damn good. i like d.f.h. for whatever they do though. it is on tap at the bar/liquor store i work in and customers call it happiness in a barrel
Pours a beautiful clear copper red, with a short lived frothy head. Smells of grapefruit pine and raisins.  Sweet malt and bitter hops mix together well. Long lived malt and hops finish.
read rave reviews so i had to try this. honestly dont see what the big deal is. the aroma is great. flavor was ok. decent beer. nothing special nice head when poured, which disappeared quickly.

Aroma is floral, caramel, some pine.  Beautiful appearence, amber with some pink hues, small white head, nice lacing.  Beautiful flavor, complex hops, with nice malt backbone.  Nice full body.  When Im on the east coast, I always like having a 4 pack of this in the fridge.  Never dissappoints.  Mmmmmmm.  Great brew.

Coppery pour, with a light head.  For the billing of a double/imperial IPA it was lacking in the brute force category, but nevertheless it was balanced very well.  I cant imagine the weight of hops they used, because youd think for a 90 min hopping, itd be a lot stronger.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007 i think this one of the great ipas of america one of the great beers period especially price wise! nice hoppy flavor little bitter at first but goes down smooth.nice head and dark orange red tint. i love this beer a definite must try enjoy.
Amber orange colour, nice amount of head, slightly sweet, was expecting more hop kick . enjoyable though

Yum.  Orange-gold pour with a nice little head.  More citrusy in the aroma with some pine.  Medium mouthfeel, not sticky.  Bitter and sweet hop flavors ranging from grapefruit to resin.  A little woody towards the back.  One of the better IIPAs, but not the best.

A superbly balanced brew.  Hefty hop bitterness covers a very sweet strong malt flavor.  Taste covers the entire mouth and finishes very smoothy without an alcohol aftertaste.
My favorite in the Imperial IPA category
Light amber/gold color.  With citrus hoppy aroma.  Flavors of sweet malt, fruit, citrus, orange, and caramel.  Finishes with hops and a little alcohol.  Good but not as intense as some other IIPAs.

Bottle. Traffic light amber beer topped by a short, but wickedly creamy and longlasting beige merengue. Smothering aroma of sweet buttery malt with diesel aftertones; surprisingly subdued lemon and peach hop presence. First sip reveals the unexpected taste of vanilla poundcake. Subsequent sensations of anise, maple syrup, and resiny hop. This barley behemoth torques through with the finesse of an avalanche. Seriously sweet and merely mildly bitter. Sticky palate, as thick as paint. An utter failure as a hop-forward concotion; definitely a dessert beer. Pecan pie in a glass.

Pours golden orange from 12oz. bottle.  The aroma is odd, I had to get used to this.  Reeks of apricot, caramel, and cannabis.  The flavor is over-the-top for sure.  Its really malty sweet with caramel, orange, apricot overtones...then BANG! it hits me with a bitter, bittery, bitterness.   The only thing bothering me from the bitterness is the cloying sweetness.  It almost tastes like a concoction of barely wine and a IPA.  This is the strangest IIPA I have tried.  I suppose this has balance, but Im sure I dont want my IIPAs to be balanced.
Clear reddish amber colour with medium beige head. Fruity malt and citric hop nose (well balanced). Carmel malt taste with bitter hop through the taste and warming alcohol finish.

holy hop heaven.  great DIPA, spicy, piney and citrusy hop aroma all throughout the beer, from aroma to finish.  very thick, resiny, mouthfeel, a little two thick.  overall, a great sipping DIPA that opens up as it warms.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: After having heard about this beer for a while, was finally able to chase it down. Poured from a bottle. A very good taste of hops along with a citrus flavor makes this a very drinkable beer.

Poured at GABF 06  Through a hop grant comming off the tap.  Huge fresh hop aroma that lacks in the bottled versions iv had.  Big citrus, pine and sugar flavors swril to a lingering hop finish.  Went back for more in a long line of people waiting.  Superb!
(Stockholm Beer Festival 2006) Yellow, white head. Dry hoppy aroma, citrus, floral but also with some smotth malty notes. Really hoppy flavor, oily, fruity, citrus, grassy. Hoppy, metallic finish.

This is a great IPA, and I would put it in  the DIPA category. Pours a dark amber with a small off-white head and minimal lacing. Very nice floral, citrusy sweet aroma. Honey is definitely present in the aroma. Palate is extremely full and smooth and the flavor is well balanced. Flavors of sweet hops and citrusy fruit, and slight alcohol as the beer warms up. Definitely one of the better DIPAs out there.

Copper coloured beer with gold highlights, it has a generous white head when it pours.  A solid IPA, it has the tell-tale hoppy aroma with florals and peach; unmistakable IPA hoppy taste, it is very good, though the 9% alcohol comes through a bit.  Overall very good, but I personally prefer the 60 minute version.

The hops in this puppy are truly overwhelming on first sniff, but surprisingly the first splash on the tastebuds and then the finish are much smoother than any other IPA Ive tackled. Really worth the extra shekels--when I can find it (at Discount Liquor in Milwaukee, of course).

Bottled. Pours a clear golden amber with a massively lacy, creamy head. Creamy medium body mild carbonation. This beer seems like it has DIPA-level malt, but only IPA-level hops which have a tough time making their way through all that malt. The net result is a tasty beer, but one that seems to be more on the barleywine end of the spectrum than on the Imperial IPA end. The aroma is dominated by pineapple with oranges, nuts and toffee behind it. Theres a big shot of toffee and pineapple in the taste, which stays sweet almost to the end, which has just enough grapefruit to clean things up. Vaguely reminiscent of orange juice with alcohol added, but not like drinking a screwdriver - if that makes any sense at all.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2011 Bottled. Wow, this is a fanny kicker for certain. I tried the 60 minute a few weeks back, this 90minute is thicker with a chewyness about it. It is slightly sweeter than other DIPAs I have had, there is a bit of a bananna bubble gum mix with malted hop and maybe some other fruit like flavors. The alcohol is high in this puppy, I can feel it half way through my glass. I wish this Dogfish head was easier to find....I paid big bucks for a 4 pk. 
Rerated: Originally at 4.1, lowering to 3.5 after 4 years of other great IPAs, when I drink this now, it tastes like liquid SweetNLow. Recently had a bottle and on tap the other day, just horribly sweet.

Bottle. Poured a pretty good viscous golden brown with a small head that dissipated to just a white ring and some lacing. Good, thick, heavy malt mouthfeel with some good but slightly subdued hop character. I was expecting this one to be extremely hoppy but its actually quite light. However, very filling.

Bottle.  Hazy copper coloring.  Hoppier, stronger flavoring than the 60 minute IPA and leaves you with a heavier, higher alcohol delivery to the tongue and back of the throat.  Solid, impressive IPA but a little short of too high expectations.

This is one 4 pack I always replace.  Very easy on the nose and palate, yet has a nice alcohol kick.  I am a newbie, but this brew is me favorite yet...Nice blend of flavors.  I recommend this for every fridge!
An absolutely amazing brew.  Very smooth to drink, great palate, very well balanced.  My favorite IPA
UPDATED: MAY 19, 2007 If you like hops you will love this beer.  The dogfish people love there beer and this is one of there best.  Excellent hoppy flavor!!!

Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA
12 oz bottle
Bottled 05/26/06, gratified 09/06
Medium pour in a snifter

Poured a clear copper with a tiny, barely off-white head.

Smelt of light grassiness, sweet clover honey, and cinnamon banana.

Taste was upfront heavily sweet with a light bitter crisp hoppy bite followed by a peak in bitter hops and a slow gradual descent in sweetness, finishing in a spicy flowery lingering hop finish.  Mouthfeel was medium to full bodied, syrupy and velvety, soft nuanced carbonation with very light cozy alcoholic warmth and light to moderate astringincy.

Overall, an Imperial IPA that is beatiifully balanced for taste and drinkability, but the sweet malt backbone hides the hop showcase a bit.

CONTAINER VOLUME: 355mlCONTAINER TYPE: BottleFRESH: Packaged 4-4-06 consumed 9-15-06 (5 months old, but the high ABV and high hop rate probably keeps this brew pretty fresh)PURCHASED @: Binnys McHenryCOST: $2.49 for 12 Oz chilled bottleHEAD: large frothy; light-yellow; mostly lasting(used styro-foam cup; dont ask...)LACE: goodCOLOR: clear rich amberAROMA: Ligltly malty (grain/caramel); heavy pine/grass/flower; moderate sweetness; slight orange?MOUTHFEEL: medium to fullPALATE: leaves oily coatingTASTE: START- lightly sweetMIDDLE- slight brandy/raisenFINISH- heavy acidic dry bitternessCOMMENTS: Seriously buzzed from 1 beer.  this has 300 cal/serving!  slightly more bite than the 60.  Wonderful tasting beer; drinking Bud, I would never guess that there could be a beer that would actually taste good.  this is more than a good beer tasting, its a beer experience.CONDITIONS: MOWING/WORKING ON CAR- No (Im tempted to put yes because this would be good at ANY time)WITH FRIENDS-YSIPPING-YGET MY BUZZ ON-y

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2007 Pours a nice amber color with a light head.  Deep hoppy flavor complimented by caramel undertones, particularly if sitting for a few minutes.  Very enjoyable beer.  Easy on the palate and goes down smoothly.  Finishes perfectly.  Definitely worth trying!

Pours a hazy light golden color with a small white head that dissipated quickly with moderate lacing. Aroma was of apricot, fruit, hops, and some alcohol. The flavor was of hops, but it was well balanced with malt, with a nice bitterness. The alcohol became more pronounced as the beer got warmer. Overall very enjoyable brew.
Veyr nice, not of the style but it was pleasant to drink, very good taste and good foam. It was a little sweet.

had it before a few times, first time actually pouring and rating critically...  a bit too clear for my tastes, i like my dIPAs unfiltered..  smells like i expect all IIPas to, except, amazingly, the obvious hops and obvious malts are stunningly well-balanced.  giving it a 9 since i have had a couple other beers i could spend an hour smelling.  in flavor, the malts balancing but not strong.  whereas the tendency is to overmalt to hide the alcohol, this has a malt backbone but doesnt have a large sweetness accompanying it.  great stuff.  good hop finish.  i think i like this more than yulesmith, i2pa, and most ive had.  its actually a reminder that you can make a great dIPA without the tremendous hops/malts characteristic of the style.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2006 A phenomenal brew.  Beautiful light golden color with a white head and great lacing.  By far the best IPA I have ever tried.  Extremely bitter flavor is wonderfully complimented by the maltiness of the barley.  Has a great sweet fruity hop flavor.  I really cant say enough about the quality of this brew.

a beautiful cloured beer with a whitish head that diminishes. the clour is a nice golden copper. the aroma is sweet with a nice hop aroma. the taste is a nice bitterness not to much of the alcohol comes through the hop finish. a great everyday IIpa to drink

Clear copper color and an off-white head wih decent lacing.  Aroma is slightly one dimensional... sweet caramel and molasses malts.  Taste matches aroma but with an intensely bitter, but tasteful, hop finish.  Definitely one of my favorite IIPAs.

Clear amber pour with a small, creamy, off-white head that quickly diminished. Moderate lacing. Aromas of carmel malt, grapefruit, molasses and alcohol...strange. Taste is fruity, syrupy-sweet malts, hops and alcohol. Finishes bitter-sweet with a nice hop bite. Alcohol is not hidden very well and theres a metallic aftertaste that I find unpleasant. This is like boozy, over-hopped barleywine.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2007 Wow.  Not what I expected.  This beer is medium gold with a modest hop aroma.  The body is full and heavy, with much less hop bite than the name would indicate.  The sweetness is also unexpected.  

6-9-07 Tried again at Alefest Columbus, using the Enamel Animal.  It imparts a woody, leafy raw flavor that, while more bitter, I feel destroys some of the character of the beer.  Interesting for a try. But, Ill stick with the original in the future.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle. Pours hazy gold, white head. Aroma is fruity, hoppy, and malty. Flavor is fruity, malty, hoppy. Nice apricot finish.

i cant lie this is one of my favorites.  nice amber color, clear in the glass.  smells of grapefruit and heaven.  great hoppiness with a malt backbone to rest upon.  i am always angry when i finish my glass of this, there just never seems to be enough.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2008 Pours a nice amber with off-white head. Scent is predominantly grapefuit hops with a thick malt background. The flavor is full, with a sweet candy like/almost bakery cookie malt aspect, followed by a huge grapefruit hoppyness, a touch of caramel and a nice dry finish.

Pours bright amber with a thin foamy tan head. Aroma of sweet orange, candied fruits, and mango hoppiness. Taste is exploding hop resins, piney, with sweet fruity caramel. Notes of mellow whiskey, almonds, and oak barrels. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and resinous with lively carbonation. Interesting and tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2014 Bottle.  Orange pour, medium-strong carbonation, short white head.  Strong citrus and grapefruit nose from all the hopping, hint at medium-strong maltiness.  Taste is a smooth wave of strong bitterness blended with lightly crisp hop notes and thick, syrupy dark maltiness, which slightly edges out the hoppiness.  Very full-bodied, even obese!  Vinous and coating.  Molasses, grape, light toasted caramel.  Id rather label this a malt bomb than a hop monster, and it takes the IPA close to Barley Wine territory.  Very dry end and aftertaste with a vivid memory of the malty experience - a decadent sipper, but really nice! [5 Sept 2006: 4.0]Re-rate bottled on 10/10/13, so not extremely fresh.  Nose is strong caramel malt and extremely oily hops, pours very clear orange with an off-white head and moderate carbonation.  Nose has this sugar dust thing going on.  Very rich in the mouth, sweet without cloy, yet powerful and somewhat alcoholic, firm bitterness, clouded with hops (positives and negative there).  I didnt realize this in past sampling, but this is clearly the attempt to imperialize the 60 min, which I originally liked less but now come to favor; this one is so much less repeatable, much more brute force in its solution than elegant.  Still, stands up to the pressures of time, and thick enough to stand up to food.  [7 Feb 2014: 3.8]

This beer is top of the line, just as I expected. Poured to the expected hazy orange-red color, with thick off-white head that lingered throughout entire glass, and left excellent lacing.  Strong aroma of citrusy hops early on, but as beer warmed, the 9% alcohol became mopre evident, and was nicely blended with the bitte hops. A hint of malty sweetness also contributed to leave a great finish. A most excellent beer.

12 oz bottle purchased from Bauer Wines in Boston.  Bottled 05/08/06, which I think means May 8 in US logic.  (Explain to me again why it goes month/day/year??  Thats not in order!  But I digress...)  Pours a light copper with little head and little carbonation.  Aroma of sweet sugars and hops.  Taste is quite sweet, and the alcohol is noticeable.  This reminds me of a barleywine - a style that I generally have not taken well to as they tend to be too sweet for my tastes.  The DFH 90 does not have the fullness of flavour and aroma and hops that I enjoyed in the DFH 60.  I had such very high hopes for this beer considering its wonderful reviews, but alas, different strokes for different folks (and so and and so on and scooby-dooby-doo...)

Clear Copper with light frothy head.  Potent hop aroma, citrus and floral.  Malty sweetness and delicate hop flavor.  Kind of spicy.  Bitter and fruity.  Chewy hop bitterness that lingers.  Fantastic.

Great study in hops.  Packs of powerful punch of 9% and rediculous hops, but still very drinkable with a nice sweet malt.  Had it with a slice of artichoke pizza, and might have enjoyed more on its own.  I liked it slightly better than the 60, but dont know if its worth the extra price.

Bottled.  I had to be patient with the aroma on this one because I opened it too cold.  Patience paid off, however, with a wonderful boquet of hops (mostly floral, but some others thrown in too).  I tasted a lot more of the citrusy hops in the flavor than I got in the aroma.  I liked that this tasted generously bittered, but was not uber-aggressive.  It was well balanced.  You can tell that this is a "big" beer, but it isnt throat- scorching like some other 9% beers.  This is one of the few DIPAs that I will get again.
Absolutely one of my favorite beers. At Zenos in State College, we get it on tap. Super nice hops. Rich taste. Brilliant.

Ive wanted to try this brew for a long time, but every time I went to find it, the store(s) were out!  I finally snagged a 4-pack, and I have to say right away that I was not disappointed!  It pours a distinctive copper color, with a huge foamy, offwhite head!  The aroma is immediately sweet, malty, but not as hoppy as I expected.  The taste is the same, but with an emphasis on bitterness and malt, with a lingering, sugary, candy-like finish!  As I said, there is a lot of malt in this one, and obviously a lot of hops, but not the "grapefruit" taste that I expected.  Its sweeter, with some notes of caramel, candy, and fruit.  The body is a little oily and sticky, and very fitting for this brew.  I dont notice the alcohol much in this one, not like some others have said.  Overall, this is definitely one of the best Imperial IPAs Ive tried, and a great introduction to Dogfish Head!

Bottle from my baby boy Chris (Enniskillen); Really nice hoppy nose, not as good as Hopsicle, but better than Dreadnaught; Copper-gold with a small, longlasting yellow head; hops mixed with citrusy-caramel flavor, along with some alcohol showing up.
I totally lovef this beer, one of my favorites form Dogfish, I wish a I had more than one bottle to share with Matthew. It has become one of my favorites!

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2010 Shared with Seb. Complex and full. Massive flavor and impressive malt backbone. Nice blend.
Malt: caramel, toast
Hops: citrus, grapefruit
Other: alcohol
Color: amber
Liquid: clear
Head: minimal
Initial: medium bitterness
Finish: light sourness, heavy bitterness
Finish Duration: average
Body: full
Carbonation: soft
Finish: bitter

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2008 I love this ale it is one of my favorite imperial IPA, Ive had it in bottle and draft many times, both at the brew house in Gaithersburg Maryland.  This beer is fantastically complex sweet and potent.  I cannot find a flaw in this robust beautifully produced and always fun to consume brew.  If you have the opportunity to try this beer, do it.  It is refreshing and drinkable and goes down smooth.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2007 Pours a medium amber copperish color with a nice sized head. Aroma is Pine, hops, grapefruit.  Big hop, pine and malt flavor. Alcohol is barely noticable. Very full mouthfeel. Rich and sticky to the palate. A great overall IMPY IPA.
I preferred the 60 minutes. There are more alcohol taste in the 90 minutes that hide a little bit the taste of fruits.

12 oz bottle pours light copper with a nice offwhite long lasting head (given alcohol content.)  Bittering hops perfect with just enough malt sweetness to balance.  Hop flavor and aroma is extreme, but not too bitter.  Usually after an imperial ipa, i want something a little lighter to follow, but not this.  I could drink this all night!   One of my favorites!!

12 oz. bottle.  Poured a medium amber iwth a large, rocky, off-white head, mostly remaining.  Aroma is medium-heavy hops, pine and citrus, some caramel maltiness.  Flavor is dominated by heavy alcohol.  Very bitter, medium sweet of sugar candy, pronounced malt character comes through even with the hopped up hops.  Barley strong in the finish.  Some toffee.  Lively carbonation, slightly syrupy, full body.  I imagine this is what barley wine mixed with an IPA tastes like.

De HogTownHarry, bouteille de 12 oz (#600). Couleur orange claire avec un collet moyen qui dure. Arome dhoublon assé fort et sucré. Un petit goût dhoublon sucré avec un arrière goût légèrement amère et alcoolisé. Très bon!

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2006 Bottle, obtained in Ashland, OR.  Pours clear, almost too clear for the large amount of hops in thie beer (filtered?).  Nice head retention, considering the alcohol content.
