Theres not a lot going on (as far as breadth goes), but what it lacks in breadth, it more than makes up for in depth.  All present aspects are heavy.  Lots of hops, but its balanced by lots of malt, and thats balanced by the combination of brandy and woodiness.  It finishes dry and bitter, but not too much to make you cringe.  This is much better than I was expecting
Rerate.  I had to bump this up a notch.  After repeated samples, this is by far one of my favorites.  It sits somewhere between IPA and barleywine.
Pours a nice amber with a great white head that is very strong. smells of stron acidic, citrusy fruits ( lemons and oranges) the taste is very dry and bitter, with some astringency to it.

This is like the 60-minute IPAs bigger, badder older brother...Extremely hoppy and citrusy, with a strong strong alcohol taste.  This beer has one of the finest hop tastes that I can recall.

(Had in bottle at Bilbo Baggins in Alexandria Va)

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2009 Starts off with a dense, creamy head, dark copper color, and a vibrant hops aroma.  Very bright and crisp with fantastic bitterness and a sweet edge.  Light mouth feel with a quick finish, very clean and refreshing.  Has a high but very well balanced, practically hidden, alcohol character.
Its good, but a little to bitter to be an IPA. Seems more like an ESB. I would drink it again.
Dark copper color with thin head. Lots of flavor, but bitterness is well balanced. I like this a lot.

A literal "bouquet" of floral hops rise from this terrific beer. Has a murky, rusty-amber body with lively carbonation and a dense, rocky, cream-colored head. Wonderful lacing held on like whipped egg whites. Heavy, perfumed, flowery aromas along with pine and citrus notes. Similar flavor that started with a moderate maltiness and a hop presence that burned my lips. Much more flavorful and aromatic at room temperature than chilled.
<font size=-4><a href=
http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.as DiCarlos Armanetti<font size=-1>

This is, quite simply, the best IPA which I have ever had. Unlike the 60 minute, there is not a huge head and also has a great taste. It is very drinkable and does not give that bloated feeling which so many IPAs do.

Wow, this is definitely the strongest IPA Ive tasted.  Aroma is a friendly sort of malt, but the taste kicks in quickly with strong citrus notes and a woody undertone, followed by a strong bitter finish.  I dont know if Id do more than one per night, but this is a powerful and complex IPA.  I want to splurge soon on the 120.

Bottle, about 9 months old.  
This beer is murrr-ky.  Very cloudy, nice burnt orange color, with a head full of crowded tiny bubbles that last all the way down.  
Aroma is surprisingly malty for a beer that bills itself as a hop monster.  It IS hoppy - but also maltier than Id have suspected.  Id say its a little less sweet than some of the other DIPAs Ive had (think Stoudts), but it strikes me as a little on the astringent and harsh side.  
The alcohol is well hidden in this; probably wouldnt guess it was 9%.  
This is good - very good - but I think the 60 Minute is even better, especially on cask.  In fact, it really makes me want to try the 90 on tap/cask, and see if its a little more balanced.  I should say that this bottle, which was aged somewhat, was, in fact, more balanced and subtler than the fresh stuff I had last July.
nice aroma, smooth malty fihish, mellow head with long lasting finish. an outstanding imperial ipa. one of a kind.
Nice amount of hops.  Full body strong foundation.  Dont let the taste make you consume more than a couple.  Treat like a fine wine or a great cigar.  Enjoy every moment as long as you can.

Possibly the best IPA on the market.  Pours a nice reddish gold with frothy head.  Floral aroma with hops and alcohol both sublty notable.  Taste is unique.  Citrus and fruit mix nicely with light evergreen undertones and heavy hops.  I might not survive if I ever find this one on tap!
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Fantastic beer. Pours great. Smooth fuity taste that keeps on giving.  Citrus-like aroma.  Well worth my wife yelling at me for speng 10 bucks on a four pack.
Well hopped smell with sweet undertone... Lots of bright white bubbles set against a light golden color. Muscatty taste to the finish when the hops kick in and gradually fade. Very nice! ($2.5/12oz)

One of the best IPAs out there, but still not as good as Dreadnaught =) This is a nice and hefty DIPA with plenty of alcohol (9%) and plenty of hops. This brew has a nice citrus flavor with a very slightly earthy note that is less noticeable as you drink a few more >>hiccup<< Is this beer worth $11.00 a four pack (in CO) what the hell... sure. Oh, by the way, on tap this brew is heavenly!

An instant classic. bottled: a hazed orange gold ale with  a miraculous frothy cap that stays...great lacing..... the nose fills with grapefruit and pine over a sweet cooky dough aroma. Marvelous mouth feel...oily with the malts so dense they are syrupy/viscous...all the time balanced by the marvelous citrus-pine hops which turn only slightly bitter in the long finish...a masterful effort...an ale full of malt body and taste in balance with luscious citrus hopping.

This is one for the ages. The orange tint to the pour is nothing special, nor is the head that diminishes rather quickly. The taste is a blend of caramel and fruit and  the hops are definitely there but not overwhelming. There arent too many IPAs that I must have, but this is definitely one of them!

bottle. clear light orange color. small white head short lived. great hop flavors with complex flavors. great full texture, coats the mouth, full bodied. little notice of high ABV. very impressive IPA. a must to have in stock.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2007 From a bottle and into a glass. Clear orangish-brown color, with a nice thick white head with good lacing. Citrusy and hoppy aroma that also hints at a strong malt backing. Amazing rich flavor. I think grapefruit immediately and maybe melon at the as well? Incredibly complex with the huge amount of hops with enough malt to keep this beer from being overly bitter or one dimensional. Challenging to the palate while still being extremely drinkable. Alcohol is masked well and it can make this beer dangerous.This is damn good beer.

Im a bit of a hop head AND I LOVED THIS STUFF!  Looks-wise it was nothing special, dark yellow with small white head.  Fantastic fresh American hops aroma.  Same hops in the palate and very dry finish.

Opened because I was so disillusioned with their "flagship" beer Shelter Pale Ale and because I need a big, hoppy beer to have with my Indian food. Straight fom the cellar @ 51.3° and served in my NB worthy glass. It poured light orange with a smallish off white head. When swirled, the beer coats the glass. Aroma is hops, nice and spicy and beautiful. There is also a honeyish background. The taste is hop flavored with all kinds of crazy flavors, the first the comes to mind is a honeydew melon (thats a first in a beer for me!). The hops are also spicy and piney, but that melon flavor really steals the show.  Pretty tasty. The bitterness not overwelhming, but it can be felt.  Despite its huge hop aroma, this is a somewhat balanced beer. The finish is piney and melon flavored, with a bit of tongue tingle from the underlying bitterness. Mouthfeel is nice and full. Overall a really nice beer.
Very good beer.  Fairly large off white head.  Body is clear and light amber. Slight citrus aroma.  Full well balanced palate, sweet, bitter and alchohol flavors are present.

Poured into a pint glass, a very rich, clear copper colour with moderate head,
Intense and inviting piney aroma. Taste is deliciously bitter in hoppiness with some nice malts too..alcohol is well hidden. This beer is very refreshing, cant wait to have it again.
Very very good IPA. The best I have had, actually. I look for this brand wherever I go and am dissapointed when I dont find it. Higly recommend.
Light amber coloured with a thin white head. Clear hoppy flavour. Sweet and fruity with an acid aftertaste. Fresh with a slight alcoholic segment.

Bottled. 
Light clear amber colour. White head. Alcohol nose, citrusy, nutty, fresh feel to it. Very malty, piney hops in flavour, then the abv takes over. Still very well balanced, but maybe with too much alco to it. Also, not as bitter in the finish as expected.

This is by far the best IPA Ive ever had.  ABV very strong, but the flavor is just delicious.  Gotta go, I am getting thirsty just thinking abou thaving one!  beer is not cheap, but is is not that expensive either.
UPDATED: JUN 30, 2006 Well, Its the best IPA Ive had. It is sweet and hoppy and smells flowery and alcoholic. Expensive, but worth it. I will buy it again.
This was the beer that got me hooked on IPAs.  It is a great beer although not for the faint of heart.  It has a great hoppy aroma and flavour.  Get giddy just thinking about having one!
Smells great just pouring it.  Nice clear amber color with nice corbonation that settles to a small but healthy head.  Malt and hop team up in a complex yet balanced flavor.  Well worth the price.
UPDATED: JAN 17, 2006 "Brother gave me this as a birthday gift. Not a huge IPA fan, but this beer has a great taste if you like hops. Also has a hint of a fruity taste to it."

Cloudy, medium oragne color with a huge off while head.  Hoppy aroma, pine/citrus with some earthy pear.  Flavor is initially acidic with a bitter finish that still has an acidic feel to it.  I taste major spurce-pine like hops, some citrus and some earthy fruit (apple).  Medium palate with a dry texture,...lightly metallic finish.   It took me a while to finish this one.

Botttle. I had been sitting on this, and well for 400. Poured amber with a white, fizzy head.  Spruce and grapefruit hops smack you right from the pour. The taste was not as hoppy as I feared.I liked this IPA. It maybe the use of hops other then casscade. Excellent.
Had this one on tap at Ashleys in Ann arbor, MI. Light amber, alchohol comes through later, fruity with strong hop presence. An excellent IPA, worth the price. Thick mouthfeel but very drinkable.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2006 i mean wow.  pours a clear light amber.  aroma is a bang of resin-y hops .  flavor: wow.  malty fun in front, hoppy finish in back.  it ends with some sweetness, but the dry-hopping character is there.  enough of the malt gets through to make this an absolutely stellar beer.  no evidence of the 9% alc.  i think im in love.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2006 Pours amber with thick off white head.
Has aroma of hops, fruits and citrus.
Flavor of grapefruit, hops, floral, and citrus. Execellent I2PA not too strong and well balanced.
UPDATED: MAR 27, 2005 hands down the best I.P.A ever strong hop flavor, even stronger hop finish and nine percent alc. WOW this is heaven

Boy,I love the looks and the nose of this brew.Clear amber brew with a dash of big bubble head and a blast of piney resiny hops that leapt outta the glass and landed one on my nose.Hoppy and malty,I found there to be a very good balance between the two.
UPDATED: APR 17, 2005  Nice but not great Imperial. too much malt sweetness for me not hoppy enough. a good beer fron a much overrated brewery.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2009 Im not a big hop head or at least I didnt used to be. The flowery hop aroma in this one is actually very enticing. Nice 1 finger head that holds its form. Very smooth and hardly any of that hop bite that I used to hate. Extremely drinkable. The 9% is not noticeable at all. I could drink this regularily and thats saying a lot for this malt lover.
Wow! Like jumping into a hops pool. Dark red pour with a small lasting head. Must be sipped to get the full citrus tang with the sharp hoppiness. I guess there is malt as well, but who cares?

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2007 a wonderful deep, mahogany red appearance with thin, white head; aroma of full of hops (more on the floral side) and sugars, while the flavor is full of grapefruit, malts, and sugars; good palate

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2005 a wonderful beer.  with much anticipation i poured my first glass and was certainly not disappointed.  the grapefruit flavor is very unique and the alcohol punch is just right.  beautiful deep golden color and nice sweet/spicy aroma.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2006 I wasted two glasses of this stuff just trying to find one thing wrong with it.  Never did, but I enjoyed trying.  Pours a lighter golden color which is a little weak but the balance of hops and malt in the flavor along with the crisp finish is just perfect to me.  Alcohol is masked nicely and it is deceptively strong.   Wow, just highly enjoyable and I wish it came in 6 packs and not the 4s.

One of my favorite IPAs that I can find regularly. Taste is very hoppy and floral, but surprisingly drinkable considering its strength. Almost dangerous, because I could drink it as a session beer if I didnt realize the alcohol was as high as it is.

Fridge temp bottle pours clear golden amber.  Frothy head receeded to thiun but never disappeared.  My favorite "widely available" IPA.  The hops come through like freshly crushed indica buds.  Full of resin and tart and piney woods.  Crisp, short lingering aftertaste that begs for another.  $9 a four pack.  Tthey should charge more for this.

pours a nice clear dark amber, with a frothy white lacing head.  aroma is piney hops.  nice citrus hoppy flavor,  almost balanced by malt.  you can detect the alcohol  a little, but its very well hidden.  good full mouthfeel.  a great iipa.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear golden orange with a fine creamy white head that lasts through the entire glass and leaves some lacing.

Its aroma is some spicy floral piney hops at first.  It kind of devolves into a peppery leather smell though that isnt very appealing.

The flavor is sweet melon and some pepper up front.  I dont get much hop flavor, but it does have a good lingering bitter aftertaste.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied, but very smooth.

Overall, I found this to be underwhelming.  Its a pretty average IPA and didnt live up to the high expectations (or price).

A hop lovers dream.  Golden amber body with creamy white head. The aroma is huge on hops.  Flavor is also all about the hops and just a little maltiness to balance it out. Some citrus comes through as it moves in the mouth.  Suprisingly creamy for such a hoppy beer.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2007 Fridge temp. Pronounced resinous, somewhat herbal aroma with overtones of ethanol. Dark amber in the glass. Fizzy head, recedes to a thin layer. Heavy bitterness throughout with heavy alcohol on the finish. Dry and medium body with a slightly chalky, very long penetratingly resinous wood aftertaste.  Second rate: Heavy mouthfeel almost oily. Both sweet and alcoholic. Big bourbon soaked cherry flavor. A bit of a burn in the finish. Packs a major wallop. Comes off far more as a liquor than a session beer.

[on tap at Sunset Grill and Tap] Bright golden colour with a fine bubbly ring.  Wonderful citrus, grapefruit, and peach aroma with some faint, sweet malt.  Not grassy in aroma or flavour.  A bit "salty" from all the hops with dominating grapefruit in balance with a pleasant bitterness and obvious alcohol.  Warming and full bodied.  Excellent.  I want to learn to have such good hops control--it must have to do with freshness.
Very good.  Strong at first but mellows.  I thought it was fairly well balanced but seemed to be missing something.  Still very good beer.  Like the Burton Baton blend a little better.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2005 First rating: 4.5  Unbalanced and hoppy as hell, but amazing.  Citrussy aroma.  Round, full mouthfeel.  Bubbly.  Id drink this beer everyday.

Second rating 4.0  Syrupy sweet, with a good citrussy/piney hop profile, but the constant addition process they use at DFH doesnt get quite enough hops in at the start of the boil to bitter them up as much as Id like.  A great beer, nonetheless.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2016 Ive had this numerous times over the years. Its never been a 4+/5 IIPA - except on this site lol. If youre looking for an American hop bomb, this is the furthest thing from it. Clear amber color, moderate head, good lace/retention.  Its malt forward with toffee and wood, some caramel. The hops are citrus and grapefruit. Really easy to drink, lightly chewy, atypical for the style.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2005 rerate 4/17/05 VIA RANDALL on tap at the Blind Tiger.   hoppy smoked meat aroma, lightly hazy amber orangey gold.  short quick light tan head.  flavor is bitter but only at the front of the palate.  hops are flavor soaked like tobacco.  clean finish and mild smoky hop aftertaste. 


2/6/05:   golden amber color, fluffy and rocky white head.  nose is strong hops, pine, resin.  powerful hop bitternes, resiny  flavor too.  not cloying like the 120min.  dry citrus for measure but not too much.  not sticky sweet like a lot of other IIPAs.  an imperial IPA on the brink but keeps it together.
Orangy gold in colour with a lasting white head. Malty toffee start with a hoppy citrus finish. Big grapefruit and lychee flavours and aromas. Medium-full bodied. Nice beer.

Bottle.  Pours a clear gold/orange with a thick fluffy off-white head.  Aroma is of hops and grapefruit.  Smells like breakfast.  Taste is hoppy and of grapefruit juice with a finish of alcohol.  On the dry side.  Very enjoyable.  This is the beer that could put me in the hospital.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2005 Pours medium amber/tan  in color, thin whispy almost non existent lacing to go with the very thin offwhite head.  Smells of hops, citrus,  and some slight pine.  Definite hoppy kick to it but in a very nice way, bitter buit not too much so, at least not for my tastes.  Delicious after taste made me want to take my time drinking it.  Slight warming sensation in the belly.  Taste very even for an IIPA, I like this beer a lot, Im glad Ive got another one stored away.  Goes outstandingly well with grilled hamburgers, which brought out some subtler tastes in the beer as opposed to covering them up.
This beer should come with some kind of warning.  Drink with caution, hops will jump out of the bottle, kick the hell out of your tongue, and leave you in a gutter crying for your momma.  Seriously.

Pours copper/amber with nice bubbly head that fades to just a film. Strong earthy aroma of floral and pine. Initial taste is all pine hops that afdes to a very malty sweetness. Aftertaste is very unique not as hoppy as you would expect but nice. Nice lacing in the glass. Very well done.

Had to see what the big deal on this stuff was, so I picked up a 4 pack.  Coppery color with a tan coating for the head, ends up ringing down the side of the glass.  Aroma is pungent hops, with hints of the malt.  The taste has a great balance, but not until the 2nd or 3rd sip. After you get past the original bitterness, you realize the complexity and evenness of the flavor.  Aftertaste is very palatable, not too bitter, but holds the taste from the mouthfull.  Feels a little bit fizzy in your mouth, maybe a newer bottle, I think I will have to cellar some of this and see how it is in about a year.  Overall, I am impressed, with both this beer, and the IIPA class.  I need some more samples of the doubles.
A thick, almost milky pour, as expected from this Imperial IPA. The taste is dominated by hops and citrus--delicious. Savor this beer!

Thought Id enjoy this as we close up the store.  Poured a nice golden copper color...clear(filtered), smooth head that fades leaving thin lace clinging to the side of the glass.  Nice aroma of fresh hops, not as pronounced or green as the 60 min....This beer tastes fantastic.  Almost perfect balance between malty sweetness and hop[ bitterness.  You would think this would bite more by the description, but it doesnt. Big mouthfeel rounds out the package.  Flavor, flavor, and more flavor....Outstanding

huge hop aroma. nice gold color, few bubbles. bottle conditioned? i doubt it, but ive been wrong before. i like better than 60 minute but thats not saying alot. this ipa is sweet and finishes with a cloying sweetness. i like an ipa that shows dry malt. 90 minute is not solid, only strong in hop flavor and aroma and alcohol strength. once again im glad i bought only a single. dogfish head is a cool name though.

Deep, brilliant golden-orange colour. Big hop aroma - slightly medicinal, but very appetizing. Flavour is as bracingly bitter as I expected, but is also surprisingly well balanced, with some caramel and fruit notes coming up the rear. Got even better as it warmed up. Fantastic.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2010 Pours a dark gold in color with a healthy head that lingers for some time allowing for some excellent lacing.  Very nice hoppy taste with caramel undertones.  By far my favorite IPA and one of my favorite beers. Update 8/7/08:  Ive sampled this beer so many times over the years and it is still my go to even after all this time.  This is the quintessential IIPA for me.
liquid Dutch hydro THC.  sticky cream head, brilliant honey colored body, full range of hop bitterness/flavor/aroma.  stellar.  best at 60F.

Absolutely terrible aroma.  I could not drink the beer due to the smell.  Taste was nice and crisp with a ton of flavor.  Good balance and nice hopiness.

No my cup of tea.

Deep amber/bronze with a rocky off white head and good lacing.  Hops out front of the aroma (as expected).  Nice malty and apple sweet aroma as well.  For an aggressively hoppy IPA, this one is also extremely well balanced.  Some very hoppy IPAs are so far out of balance that they become unappealing - not the case here.  Bracingly bitter but still clean finish to round out a great IPA!
Certainly one of the top three IPAs Ive ever had.  Strong delicious Hops presence in the aroma, texture, flavor and finish.  Absolutely one of the best.

Im not usually a big fan of IPAs.  This was my first DFH and it makes me rethink my position on IPAs. I found the beautiful copper color and the piney citrusy aroma gave away the wonderful taste to follow.  I have three more in the cellar to look forward to!
First beer had at a beer festival. Good head and gold in color. Noticed a fruity aroma and beer went down fast because by smell I knew I would like this one right from the start.

Good to see Dogfish in Arizona. A nice floral aroma very citrusy. Nice heather like appearance. Hops are ever present. Could use a little more balance, still this beer is very thirst quenching. Clean and refreshing on the palate. Very similar to Hopfather here at Papago brewing.

Great looking bronze pour with a good sized white head that stayed around for a few minutes.  Left good lace as it subsided.  Aroma is intense...fresh cut pine, sappy, and hops, hops, hops with a little cutting from the malt.  Flavor has the same intensity...strong piney, floral, citrus flavor.  The barley does its job here.  The tongue assault is held in check.  The balance is remarkable and the flavor is on from beginning to end.  Finishes bitter.  Very appetizing and leaves me wanting more.

Bottle. Classic IPA color...thin white head ok lacing. Smells wonderful...sweet pine aroma...initial sweet malt flavor that quickly subsides to a wonderfully harmonious orchestra of hops!!! So amazing! hop heaven....crisp delecious, very well done. not a ridiculous amount of hops but just perfection. I would love to shake the master brewers hand! I loved this beer.

On tap at the scottsdale big beer fest.
Gold yellow in color with decent head.
Great clean hoppy aroma with a little citrus thrown in.
Good hops flavor just strong enough and not bitter at all with just a taste of alcohol at the finish.
VERY GOOD!

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2005 Rate adjustment 1/20/04: Okay, Im warming up to this a bit more.  Not as off-putting as the first bottle I tried.  Maybe it happened to do with it being taken directly from the cool, cool basement rather than fridged first.  Still highly sweet and syrupy and sticky, and pretty alcoholic in the flavor/palate.  And Im still too afraid to take another shot at the 120-minute monstrosity concocted by this brewery.  Only so much A-oiliness I can take.

This needs more balance.  It isnt too highly hopped; its too highly alcoholic in the flavor and palate!  Oily character comes through too much.  Stones Ruination IPA managed to do this style to perfection; this has too much A.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2005 Achtung!! Zis bier kerls mein leiderhosen. In der fadderlant such as zis bier haz nebber bin brewt. Zees Americaner micros are ashamet ov Budmiloors, so zey "kranken up" der bier styles. Eben der Englander vould zay, "I say, Old chap, havent you beefed this one up a tad?"Earlier Rating: 12/31/2004 Total Score: 3.9Massive hop aroma of american hops thats not true to an English IIPA, Luscious mouthfeel but dominant hop flavor to the finish. I havent looked, but is there seperate catagories for American and English IIPAs? I think  Golding hops blend better with this style of beer.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2007 Yes.... very nice.... Pours orange into the glass with decent head and nice lacing.  Aroma contains citrus fruits & floral notes.  Has a bit of a citrus upfront, nice bold malts with grapefruit in the mid-palate, backed with a nice array of bittering hops.  This has a bit of retentive alcohol burn, mixed with an abundance of toffee and caramel.  Feels very full-flavored in the mouth, and has a rich embodiment.  The finish contains a nice warming complexity.  An awesome IIPA, one of the best brews available!

Intense pine hop aroma that is like sticking your head in a bag of hops.  Crystal clear light amber body, lacey head. The flavor is forcefully bitter, obviously generously hopped, sticky malt background pulls it all together.  Very good stuff

Bright orange beer with cream head, quite thin. Smells of hops. Citrus. The taste is quite strong, thick, bitter. The finish is dry. It feels like it coats the back of your throat. You can really taste the alcohol here. It warms you right up.

Pours a clear light orange with amberous tones to it. Aroma of stale tobacco, grass, and lemon and pine. Flavor is dominated by what I can only describe as "stale hops". Not sure exactly, but the flavor remains pleasent. Palate is pleasent. Very dry finish.
Wicked Brew!  Cant wait to try the 120 if I can get it.   Great hops and a bit of citrus in there.  Love to drink it nice and slow!

i poured the 90 min. into my snifter glass.i was very impresed by the color of this brew.it was a nice translucent orange.i didnt get anything as far as head.just a ring around the snifter glass.the aroma gave me blends of banana,and vanilla.i was very surprised by the tatse.it did have a hop character,but not like any other ipa i have had. i got flavors of honey,caramel,and then some hops.even though this is nothing like any other ipa i have had,its still really good.

Awesome beer that started off my eve before New Years Eve.  Moderate head, about 1/3".  Smells sweet, smooth and crisp.  Color is calming; an easy amber brown.  "Holy crap" was what went through my mind as I took the first sip.  Tastes of honey, alcohol and lemons.  Mouth watering and semi-citrusy; very sharp.  Grassy and bitter afterbite, making me pucker up.  You could feel the alcohol resonate with the finish.

Nice hoppy aroma, but could use a little more dry hopping.  Golden to Amber and slightly hazy in appearance.  Very heavy malty flavor.  Balances more toward the malt than the hops.  I get a slightly strange aftertaste.  Another rating said metallic, and that is what it feels like.  Warmth from the alcohol content.  Overall, not bad but I would rather go with a hoppier regular IPA or an Imperial IPA.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2005 Pours amber with a bubbly countenance.  Forthright aroma, punches you in the face, but not overly sweet.  Very silky and rounded palate, decent enoguh flavor, but seems to have been brewed with a quixotic detachment better relegated to lesser imperial IPAs.
A good IPA but not my favorite.  I got a little metal taste after every drink.  Not a nasty metal but a lingering taste on the sides of my taste buds.

This is easily one of the best IPAs available. This is a more accomplished IPA than the 120 minute, which probably suffered from overkill. The hops are strong, but remain balanced. The finish is strong, but clean, with a slightly lingering caramel flavour.

While trying to smell this I got some up my nose.  Sometimes I feel like a total moron.  Hoppy New Year!  Dogfish seem to know what they are doing.   They could slap their  label on a bottle of floor cleaner and I would probably taste it (and rate it a 4.1)  Im waiting for the 150 minute IPA (next logical progression).

Poures a very inviting amber/orange with a quickly thinning off white head. Sappy pine, hard candy sweet, thickish aroma. Very rich and chewy mouthfeel. Sticky sweet maltiness, fruity, toffee, almost rum-cake like. Although the alcohol is evident, it is still very smooth and easy drinking. This is easily one of my new favorite beers. Try it.

Pours a beautiful deep gold.  Thick white head thats practically 1/4 the body.  The aroma is suprisingly subdue - caramel being the main scent.  This beer starts with a sweet chocolate/candy base.  Then the hops literally jump off the tongue and tingle the roof of my mouth.  Is this an IIPA or a stout?  Good balance for ALOT of hop/malt activity.  Is it too much though?  The finish shows a bit of the 9% abv, but definitely not overbearing.

In the bottle. This was dark gold in color- not really amber at all. Aroma of tootsie roll candy. In fact, the dominant flavor was candy sweetness. So sweet in fact that you could not tell that there was any alcohol at all. Hops were a disappointment as I had expected some ultra-super-dooper-high hop bitterness. This was very underhopped in my opinion for a top-notch IPA. Could it be that Dogfish head gets my newest "Overrated" vote?

bottle. copper body with a medium sized white head. hoppy aroma is just phenomenal, also notes of citrus and caramel. WOW, this beer has great balance and is very easy drinking. A little bit of alcohol shows up but I wouldnt be able to tell that its 9%. The guys at Dogfish have certainly done it with this one.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a beautiful hazy golden color with decent off-white head.  Minimal lacing.  Aroma contains citrus notes....and sort of smells like rubbing alcohol.  Not a very pleasant smell, in my opinion, but you can definitely smell the hops.  Nice rich mouthfeel.  Bitter, hoppy flavor; slight floral and citrusy notes.  Overall, kind of overrated, in my opinion, but definitely not bad.
This is the best beer I can get where I live in NJ. It moves fast so its alwasy fresh.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2006 Rerate: Orange-golden colour topped by a thick off-white head.  Gorgeous grapefruit, orange, and pine hoppiness.  Sweet maltiness, with a touch of brown sugar and toffee.  More sweet apricot/papaya fruitiness as well.  Flavour is also very hoppy tasting.  Sweet caramel balancing the sweet fruity hops.  Light resin and a beautiful citrus flavour.  Some hints of alcohol toward the back that help thin the body a bit.  Great beer.  I underestimated it the first time around.

Deep amber-orange colour with a very thin white lacing. Slightly cloudy.   Rich caramel toffee malts balance off a huge load of pine, spice, and grapefruity hops.  There is also a bright citrus hop aroma and some cookie dough in the malt profile.  Flavour is quite well-balanced with just enough malty sweetness to balance the prominent hopping.  Resiny and citrusy hop flavour with a nicely bitter finish.  A good beer, but I think its highly over-rated.
8/3/7/3/15
Good lord dat-alada-hop...Silly name excellent brewery.  Havent had anything bad from them yet!

Dark golden/orange color with a lingering whitish head.  Smell-super hopped!  Sugary/hoppy taste and  full of flavor to the end.
This is one great beer that has just arrived in Houston-lucky us.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Dark orange with a cream colored, soapy head. Strong citrus and piney hop aromas. Flavor is mostly bitter hops, with grapefruit and lemon dominating, overlaid on a caramel malt base. Mouthfeel is smooth and somewhat oily, and the finish is lingering and bitter. The 9% ABV provides a pleasant alcohol burn. Not my favorite style, but I did enjoy this beer.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2009 . Distinct malt tinged hop aroma, thick almost syrupy mouthfeel, ( the glass is always sticky if you get this on tap) the citrus hop blended perfectly with over the top malt, I see no room for improvement, its the standard that everyone else will have to match. My only hope is that DFH never softens or weakens it

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2005 Draught.  Flying Saucer in Fort Worth, Texas while attending the Breeders Cup, October 30, 2004.  Great look of dark orange and amber and nose is strong malt and hops.  Huge thick and chewy head that stays for the entire pint.  I have been told about this one for a while, but I believe it has a bit too much sweetness.  I did drink this one outside on a sunny day (not the perfect environment for a heavily malted IPA) but I still found it a bit too malty and barleywine-ish.  Not that that is terrible by any means, it just masked these great and uncommon hops, and I wanted to taste some more of those.  I cant wait to try the 60 minute....
I sampled this one again on 1-29-2005 with homebrewerguy from the bottle.  Not nearly as sweet as the draught and also a bit more smoky.  Actually a little more interesting if sampled from the bottle.  Good stuff

Wow, this is a huge beer.  The only imperial IPA Ive had before is Victory Hop Devil, and honestly, I was a bit drunk at the time so I never rated it (Mondiale de la biere 2004).  That being said, I dont remember that one being as malty or complex as this.  This tastes much like some of the better barley wines Ive had.  Huge nose of malt and hops, sweet and chewy mouthfeel, with a LONG finish of 3 hops Ive never knowingly had before.  Incredible beer.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Botte dated 11/03. Open the bottle for a big malty smell. Malty, malty, malty! I poured it into a narrow pilsener glass for some odd reason, but that let me see its copper body with golden highlights, under a bubbly head. The taste is sticky; any sweeter and itd be beer candy. Then I noticed the nice American IPA hop bill sliding in nice and gently, until it demonstrates its every bit the match of the oversized malt profile. Total impression is of a hoppy young barley wine. I hadnt realized this was an Imperial IPA. Ill have to see if I can cellar my remaining bottles. Still, glad to have had a relatively fresh one, so I could catch the hops before they fade out.
Maybe the most drinkable of this brewerys IPAs.  Not as swiggable as the 60, or as incredible as the 120, but a killer beer.  Well-balanced, perfect choice of hops, and just the right kick...

After the 60 minute I was expecting something crazy.  Well, its not crazy, just really bitter.  I was amazed to find that I could barely even smell this beer.  I dont really care for the hops DFH used.  Are they the same as in the 60?

Lite citrus hop upfront on the aroma.  Poured a hazy orange/amber color.  The taste had immediate sweat malts with buried hoppy grapfruit that start to move foward (as citrus and wood) then retreat, letting the malty sweatness back in.  Finishes with a bitter pine and wood flavor. A very enjoyable drink!

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2005  Great red pour with great hops.  The taste starts great.  You can taste the malts.  The taste is like graitfruit and malts put together.  The mouthfeel was kind of like hard liquor at times, but good.  The finish was a little bitter.  Really terrific though.

Nice orange color with a lasting white head...good lacing.  Excellent aroma of hops, fruit, and cotton candy.  Great hop profile, hints of citrus and cloves.  Hops were much more mild than expected...great tasting IIPA.

IPAs are not one of my favorite styles of beer but this is the best of the bunch. DFH overdoes the hops without overdoing it. Dark orange hoppy color with a crazy head poured from the bottle. Nice balance of malt and hops.

Relatively clear amber body with vibrant oranges and syrupy brown and honey colors. Head is loose, white and does not last long at all. Smell is hoppy with pine fragrances, as well as fruity melons and bananas.  Mouth feel is cool and syrupy. Flavor comes with a wallop of dry vegetable/pine cone hops then gets sweeter with fruity papaya, pineapple and sweet melon. Aftertaste is that excellent, dry, biting hop flavor that you want from a good IPA coupled with some nice roasty nut flavors. Alcohol is definitely there too and is brutish for the otherwise refined high alcohol beverages by DFH. But still, its completely normal for a big IPA. You know, if I had been blindfolded in a room of 100 IPAs (heaven for most of you), I guarantee I could have found this beer and classified it as DFH, it just has that distinctiveness.  Cheers, for drinking back to back 99-100 percentile beers by a fine brewer from my region.

330 ml bottle at Smokeless Joes. Orange amber colour with a frothy and bubbly white head. Fresh, leafy, piny, grapefruit, and caramel aroma. Bready, caramel, and lightly fruity malts leading to a fantastic fresh pine, grapefruit, and fruity bitter finish. Full bodied and smooth mouthfeel. The relative "balance" of this compared to Dreadnaught just leaves this head and shoulders above that for me.

This is my fav. of the dogfish head IPAs - hoptastic!  

Moderate head and lacing, the beer pours deep copper.  Finish is very hoppy with a linger of slight citrus. I love amirillo hops, their flavor is very apparent.  The malts are balanced with the hops for a well rouned taste.  I dig it.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2007 Orange with and off white head. The aroma suprised me. I was expecting more hops, but instead I got a sweet yeasty aroma complimented by spices. The flavor suprised even more as the hops werent dominant. It had ridiculous maltiness for an IPA. The dominant taste was  sweet fig, and the hops were not very strong. This beer ends more bitter than it starts. Just a sweet superbly balanced beer.

An instant classic in my books.  Im all about the hops and this has it in spades!  Pours a big creamy smooth beige head and a hazy orange. Nose is floral, spicy, citrus and sweet. Malt start with hops tickling the tip of my tongue. Dry finish with a tad of carbonation and more hops aftertaste. Alcohol is a silent and wonderful delight... fabulous and complex.
almost a copper/bronze color..head stayed the entire drink, which was at least 20 minutes.  sweter than i like.  one or two a night is enough.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2005 My original rating for this beer was terrible. I will allow the numbers to speak for themselves as this is one of the few beers that I crave on a regular basis. Although I do have a couple of bottles at home, I prefer to sample at bars and save the ones in my care. This one really grows on you, and although it isnt balanced, she is quite delicious and fun.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2005 Bottle:  Aroma is sweet grapefruit.   Real malty and hoppy.  Light transparent orangish-amber.  Decent white head with great lacing.  Very malty IPA.  Maybe a little too sweet as far as my preference for balance.  Hop finish isnt as big due to the maltiness of this beer.  Alcohol is slightly noticeable in the finish.  I like the 60 better.

This is a very interesting IPA.  The smell reminds me of an oak cask with hints of charcoal.  Pours nice.  The flavor for an IPA is simply unique.  First off, theres no overwhelming hop aftertaste, instead its more a continuation of flavors throughout.  The initial taste is hoppy citrus with a preeminent alcohol flavoring (usually the inability to mask alcohol is bad, but in this case it is welcome).  The flavoring of the hops is very unique.  The complexity is superb, with no individual dominance, but instead a pleasing harmony of flavors throughout.  A little dark and dreary for an IPA, needs more life, but still extremely deep and satisfying.  If there was a uniqueness rating ... it would receive a 10.  Excellent overall, refinements would make this an unbelievable offering.

Very cloudy dark orange body with a small but persistent white head. Once it was in the glass, I could smell this one from a distance of a few feet (literally). Upon closer inspection, I was hit with a huge hoppy aroma. The tastes consists, predominately, of lemon and other citrus with a long, slow dry finish. I look forward to comparing this with DFHs other IPAs (or at very least the 60 min).

Bottle.  Nice orange-amber color.  Small white head.  Aroma is a pleasant mix of malt and hops.  Better yet if you allow it warm for about 30 minutes after you take it out of the fridge.  The only complaint I have is that there is so much malt to balance the hops that its a bit on the sweet side.  None-the-less, its a great beer from a great brewery.
Wow pretty much describes it.You can smell and taste evry hop.High frutiness taste with a very clean finish.

Bottle. Pours orangish-amber with a small-medium sized head. Wonderful citrus hop aroma--a barely detectable alcohol burn in the nose. Flavor is very good, not over the top as I expected. Well-balanced with a dry finish. Excellent.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 Bottle from 23rd Street,
Aroma of sweet hops ,citrius grapefruit.
Medium body kinda syrupy.pine hoppy flava not malt in there  somewhere.BEAST

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2005 Eye-watering hop nose includes pine, orange/tangerine citrus and suede. Clear copper coloured body with white head that recedes to thin cover with some patchy lacing. Pine, orange, woody notes to the aggressive hop flavour that is cut by a sugary sweetness with finishing bitterness that seems comparatively light. Medium-full body and tingling mouthfeel. An interesting offering but altogether far too sweet for my taste. Must say I prefer either the 60 or 120 minute versions. Sampled on draft at The Moan and Dove (Amherst, Mass) with MartinT and Rastacouere.  Resampled a few times since both from the bottle and on tap and with each time I try this one, I find I like it less.  The sweetness becomes cloying and overpowering.
Good IPA. Definetly not a Three Floyds, but this beer has a good flavor. Citrus with a hint of alchohol. Hoppy, with a lingering fruity finish.

Classic. A delicious IPA with a well-rounded, non-intrusive hops. A bit overly-citrusy, but over all, its a great balance between smooth and bitter. Its a step above the 60min in smoothness - not as grapefruity.

Maybe its me, but these Dogfish Head beers dont do it for me. I find them wildly overrated.  Overly citrusy, very hoppy, and not a great aftertaste at all.  Im disappointed...no comparison to Stone IPA.

Clear IPA with beautiful honey color and a creamy (smallish) head.  Smells of maple and tastes like caramel malts.  Malts head off the aftertaste of this hoppy concoction.  Thanks to my brother for sending it via USPS!!!

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2017 Wow. I know this has a great rep, but I guess I didnt appreciate before how superbly this fits into the whole superabundant hop trend. Seems really smooth to me, for a beer with such a hop presence, and, for the record, I generally think of myself as a hophead. Im glad to have some on hand, whenever possible, and its certainly a tasty beer--theres enough malt to keep it drinkable, and the ensuing 9%ABV beer buzz from my 12 oz bottle was pleasant. I enjoy getting the roof of my mouth ripped to shreds by hop soldiers, but I also enjoy the smoother, more strategic attacks by the likes of this.

A good quality strong beer, as is most of Dogfish Heads products.  However, I just cant enjoy too much of this style anymore:  strong, citrusy hops that are presented in an almost thick and sweet cloying fashion.   Drink only 1 bottle per session.
Pours a nice ruby, with a decent head.  Pronounced flavour is mostly hoppy, but well-balanced with some fruity cherry and pear notes.  Aroma is also mostly hoppy, but has some fruity notes as well.

Pours a hazy amber with a medium, long lasting head. Aromas is huge floral hops with some citrus. I thought that the hops would really dominate the flavour but the malt really comes through, obviously with a big hop too but more balanced than I expected. Silky smooth mouthfeel.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2005 Hazy orange with a good sized white head.  Aroma is citrus with some sweet pineaaple undertones.  Smooth, creamy  feel.  Flavor is very well balanced and relatively complex.  Hops definitely take center stage, but unlike some IPAs, the hoppiness does not completely overpower the malt.  There is a lot going on in this beer.

My second review, this time from a 12 oz. bottle, the previous from a 750ml, ah, but I was so much older, then, Im younger than that now...
Gorgeous peachy color, big, fresh, full head of bone-white foam.
Aroma: BAM! Whoppity-snappityBAM!BOOM!BAM!, thats the full force of the pine up in there, the intense grapefruit, all the citric flavor that embarks on the senses and nevers flags for a second, grassy, herbal, potent, totally hoppy, sprucey, piney, pineappley, so much going on in this nose!
But, to taste...Ah! A wonderful mess here, a big, mix of hops and citric fruity flavor, the punchy pine on the palate, yum, yum, yum. If youre not sufficiently infatuated with humulous lupus, sit this one out, by all means. A big, sticky, fruity, citric mouthfeel, and, yeah, theres grapefruit, but so much more. Like licking a forest floor, at times, this one, if I may be so bold. Yeah, but if its hops you want, lean back and enjoy this onslaught, its astonishingly tasty!
Love it, love it, love it!

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2005 Pours a light peach. The head is well developed and thick and leaves a nice coat of lace around my la chouffe tulip. 

Nose is spicy. Pine, oily hops and flowers all around in the nose. Not bad.

Many juicy hop tones. The malt is very subdued, providing some body and a backbone but not much flavor. The hops bring tons of grapefruit accompanied by orange and lemon. The alcohol is warming but doesnt produce any flavor at all. Very bitter and quite dry but still very smooth. Delicious DIPA.
UPDATED: SEP 30, 2004 (tap) WHOA now... HOPTASTIC flavor, warm and smooth... im feeling this one... and it feels like a long, sexy massage.

Poured a dark amber with small head.  Aroma is big and hoppy floral, citrus, and some sweetness.  Flavor gets balanced by the malt sweetness but still is very big in the hops in both the bitterness as well as the hop citrus and fruitiness.  Medium and smooth body.

Poured a nice amber with a white compact head and nice lacing. Huge hop aroma with floral and citrus and alfalfa notes. The flavor was accentuated by a perfect palate, almost creamy in texture. Hops are most prevailant in the flavor, but the maltiness complimented it well. Outstanding!!

I love the flavor of this beer just as i love the flavor of most Dogfish Heads brews.  It has a woody and hoppy flavor with an amber color.  The tast of alcohol is present as well.  This as well as a large majority of Dogfish Head beers are hard to find in Indiana.  Too bad.

Deep amber, dense offwhite head. Aroma of citrusy hops, dried fruit, alcohol. Very woody flavor; toasty, fruity, bitter. None of the ganja notes that I get from the 60 Minute. Medium to full body. Very tasty indeed, but then Ive been known to chew hop pellets. Sometime soon I need to get my hands on a bottle of the 120 Minute...

Bottle. Rich amber color with a decent off-white head. Big fruity hop aroma. But the taste is malt - a rich caramel flavor with sweet malt, some pine tar bitterness, raisin and prune. Well balanced - not what I typically want in a double IPA. Its just not as bitter as I thought itd be. Slight alcohol warming. A double IPA for the non-hop-heads.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2005 Good carbonation and head, leaves a good lace. Pours a clear yellow/orange. Fruity hop aroma. Starts as slightly sweet then the hops kick in but it is a really good balance of malt and hops. Clearly an above average IPA nearly as good as a McEwans IPA.  $2.25 for a 12oz bottle from Northend Superette Manchester, NH.

Copper color with a thin white head. Very good aroma of floral hops and caramel. Amazing flavor of floral, spicy hops and carame, the ABV is pretty well hidden. Strong bitter finish. Light to medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. This beer is simply amazing.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2005 Im normally not a big fan of IPA, but this one is pretty good-- not spectacular, but it will do.  A little steep  in the pricing department (over $9 for 4 bottles) and I cant say it was worth the cost, but Id rather buy four for that price at a store than spend that much on 1.5 bottles at a bar.  I am curious to find out what this one tastes like on tap.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Amber colored liquid.  Has a strong aroma with a very sweet taste.  I did not care for this beer at all.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2005 Pours gold mahogany with a creamy ivory head that settles fairly quickly. Aroma is wonderfully fragrant, complex and strong. Floral, apricot, leather, pine and lots of other things going on I cant quite put a name to. Taste is huge and mouth-filling, but still a well-balanced play between malt and hops. Though as the glass progresses, the hops win out. The 9% ABV hides pretty well, but provides a nice warming sensation.
This is a hop-lovers beer!  Heavy hops aftertaste is amazing.  Kept looking for the sediment as I poured it but it never came.  Only down side to this beer but flavor is incredible.

Deep golden hue with a decent creamy off white head.  Strong citrus nose with a twist of orange.  Brutal hoppy taste.  This beer is crammed full of hoppy flavour with citrus, flora and hints of caramel.  The after taste is long and intensleybitter.  This is the full on hop experience for IPA lovers.  Fantastic!  It is hard to describe the great flavours that this beer holds due to its glorious complexity.
Poured a cloudy orange with a small white head. Strong hop aroma.  Strong spicy hop flavor.  Alcohol taste is also present. A great double IPA that i will have more of.
Delicious and hoppy as hell.  To me, this is the standard of Imperial IPAs and all I dream about when I think of serious IPAs.  Another good call from Dogfish Head.

Extra strong pineapple, floral, citrus, spice, sweet peach, very complex aroma. Gorgeous orange color with obvious strength by how the light is refracted by the thick syrupy body and the numerous bubbles move slowly to the dense perfect white head. Slight chill haze that clears as it warms. Straight ahead hop bomb flavor with a rich malt liquor palate. Finishes sweet and spicy with low percieved bitterness. Very good but a bit sweet for my tastes.
Lovely amber color with thin white head.   I smell hops and banana fosters (banana/caramel/molasses). A little bit spicy, and definitely interesting wthout overwhleming.  Emjoyable finish.

Deep golden orange with fine head. Peach, syrup, malt, orange, candy, and more in the nose. Medium mouthfeel with bitter lingering finish. Roasted flavors, carmel, pine, citrus, vanilla, nice flavors. Not enough malt it seems to support the hops, though this could show more when warm. Not bad
Very sweet initial taste that turns into hints of the high alcohol percent.  Not as hoppy as I thought it would be, but still very drinkable.

Its certainly very hoppy, but not too extreme for me. However, like many US hop monsters, I found the overall impression rather too sweet. Big alcohol afterburn. As SilkTork says, Randall wasnt working when we were there, although they did manage to get it set up the following day.  Unfortunately the hops, which were supposed to be coming over from the US with the brewer, never turned up, so they had to cadge some from Fullers.  Cask, GBBF 2004.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2007 Very hoppy, very dark for an ipa. I love the bitterness. This is the best ipa I have ever had.

ON TAP at DFH Brewhouse in Falls Church, VA. More pronounced hops and a stronger floral quality is present.

Poured deep amber with bright white dense head...smelled quite piney and citrusy, also a little alcohol...tasted very smooth with the bittr hoppiness coming on slowly at the end...very drinkable, but definate alcohol in the finish...overall a great beer, but I think a little over-rated...

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2006 Great golden color that holds wonderful hoppy sweetness.  Not very bitter at all considering. Easy to drink for this hoppy of an IPA....leave a lingering orange/citrus flavor. Just an exceptional IPA!
Very hopped brew without the extreme bitter taste.  Its an exceptionally hopped beer with a balanced flavor that wont scare tha average beer drinker away.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2006 Rerate:  On tap at The Spot in Bethel, CT.  Served in a Dogfish Head Snifter.  Poured a beautiful clear orange with a large creamy white head.  Looks like a picture.  Rich aroma of grapefruit, orange, a bit of pine, and some sweet candy and brown sugar.  Taste is orange, grapefruit, pine... somewhat bitter but hugely supported by sweet malt.  Creamy body thats full but feels perhaps a bit undercarbonated.  Overall a stellar brew, and a deliciously easy-drinking double IPA.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2006 Bottle. Almost perfectly made. Floral nose with some grapefruit. Great bitter taste. Sweet without being too sweet. Marvelous.

Re-rate-slightly burnt caramel nose, mildly dry, lots of caramel.

bottle. deep dark almost orange. thick white head. citrus aroma. very strong thick hoppy taste. leaves a creamy orange sweet lingering flavor.  even though this is strong there remains a balance that does not kill me. i guess it is from the ridiculous amount of barley.

I love Dogfish Head.  This again, has a blend of hops and maltiness.  Hops dont overpower like Sierra or other Pales.  They are there, but theres more going on here than just hops.  Feel it burning as you swallow.  Smile and enjoy.

12 oz. bottle.  Copper/orange color with medium-sized head that is cream colored.  Nice and clear.  Malty, hoppy, citrus aroma.  Great flavor combination with bittering hops balancing the malt.  It has some tea-like flavors and the alcohol starts coming through as it warms.  Great beer!

12 oz. Bottle.  Pours a clear light copper hue with good head and some lacing.   Great pine, citrus,  and sweet malt nose.   Piney bitterness with some citrus and a good malt profile.  Does not seem to be 9%abv!  Great beer!

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2005 A hop-heads delight.  The aroma stuck my head into a sack of citric hops.  The taste... wonderously bitter with a floral/citric aftertaste.  Bless those Dogfish Head folk for taking chances like few other American breweries do.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

Thick aroma of milk chocolate with citrus notes.  Ambery orange color with a trace of a white head.  Flaovrs of milk chocolate with a very bitter peachy aftertaste.  Would like to see more aroma and flavor hops to balance intense bitterness
[Cask conditioned] Amber coloured. Extremely hoppy, rather citrusy and fruity. Very bitter. Long bitter finish.

Pour is a burnt orange amber without much head.  The aroma is all hop bitterness.  The first hit of flavor is all hops but it quickly finishes on a lighter note.  I dont know if this is worth the really high ratings it has recieved.  It wasnt nasty like the 120, but I wouldnt call it a top 50 beer.
I get really excited about IPAs and this one did not let me down.  Nice maltiness to balance the crazy hops!  Thank you dogfish head.

I must admit that I love a good IPA.  In this case this one qualifies on all fronts.  The beer poors a nice orange color with a big frothy off white head.  The araoma is full, foral hops with citrus nose and enticing.  flavor is hugw with the incredible hops but nicely balanced by a stong and enjoyable malt backbone.  Check this one out it is worth the hunt.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2008 Bought a bottle at Hyde Park Express. Poured great. Smelled like chronic bud. No lie, this stuff smells like pot. Tastes like northern lights chronic. Maybe with some northern brewer hops thrown in. Bitter as a beer gets. It gives new meaning to the word bitter. Definitely intense, but highly offensive to my palate.

Sitting in Avalon, NJ, doing the vacation thing, and no better double IPA than DFH 90min.  I have had the 60 and a pint of the 120, and I would say that the 90 is the perfect hoppiness for me.
Smells great, as good as Exponential, which rates high with me!
Between this, Oggis hopjuice and Alpine Exponential, I would have a hard time picking my favorite.
I look forward to a blind taste test.

didnt realize this was bottle conditioned until after the pour. a deep golden hazy pour. aroma was citrus and hops and something i just cant place. was surprized at the smoothness of this beer, i assummed it would be hop overkill at 90 IBU but perhaps the smoothest big beer ive had in this style to date! A very nice beer.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2004 Bottle pours a deep hazy golden with a very nice just off-white head that is reluctant to leave just yet.  There is enough effervessing to maintain it and to support rich sticky lacing.  Aroma is quite hopy (of course) but also somewhat fruity citrusy and floral. Like pumpkin bread or shortbread cookies.  Tastes of strong hops but ballances well with the other, yeast, grain, butter and strangely... carbboard.
Mouthfeel, this I think is its strong point.  It feels full,, heavy, substantial and smooth.  Before you swallow, as you draw it in you can tell that it is going to feel good going down.  And it does.
The bitter hops stays with you and is the calling card it leaves on your palate.
Possibly my favorite of my non-favorite.
As a Imperial IPA fan, I would have to rate this one in my top five.  It really shows great signs of sweetness, citrus and bitterness throughout the palate.  Impressive.

Gravity cask at GBBF.  Dogfish Head seem to like the GBBF - theyve been here at least two years now with cask ales. This year the intention was  to have this 90 Minute served through Randell and then it would be called 91 Minute - but the guys were unable to assemble Randell correctly, so we just had it served straight from the cask. Huge hop bitterness, like chewing hop pellets. Though more fragrance than pellets. And backed with malt sweetness. A hop monster for sure. Surprising soft aroma considering the big flavour. I thought this was good.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2008 What an interesting beer.... First, it poured a radioactive orange color that seemed to glow. Beautifully colored pale orange/yellow head. My first whiff caught me totally off guard. This thing smelled more of chocolate than any beer Ive ever smelled, including the Youngs. Also backed up with some nice aromatic hops.  The taste was equally interesting. First, I tasted a huge amount of malt, then the hops shined through. It struck me as similar to the 120 in that it was very oily and sweet, though not as sweet. THere was a definite hop presence, though. Not until it warmed did the hop juice I expected show through.

Amber gold body with a medium thick white sustaining head with great lace. Sweet and citrusy hop aroma. Superb aroma. Sweet and citrusy hop flavor well balanced with maltiness. The finish is strongly bitter and hoppy. Best IPA Ive had to date. No overly strong alcohol presence. Great stuff.
UPDATED: FEB 19, 2005 Cask-conditioned (Gravity) at the Great British Beer Festival, Kensington Olympia, London. (Thursday Session). Massively herbally hoppy beer.

Pours a clear orange golden body with a foamy off-white head. Heavy bittersweet hoppy aroma with undertones of toffee and caramel.
Flavor is very hoppy (!) with a good bitterness specially in the finish. Dry, heavy and flavorfull. Hides the alcohol well but gives
you a warm feeling inside.

Not what I was expecting based on the other comments.  I didnt care for the aroma or appearance.  A little heavy in my mouth, not as much bitter aftertaste as I was expecting with as much hopping that they do.  I know its bottle conditioned, but maybe my bottle was a little flat?  Recommended and I would drink it again, but not on the top of my list.

Way over rated. I was expecting hop nirvana in a glass and was met with very little anything. No aroma, some hop bitterness and a very slight grapefruit flavor. No balance between malt and hops. Very disappointing, maybe I got a bad bottle but I was not impressed.
Great stuff.  Amber with an off-white head.  Aroma was grapefruit/hops.  Full-bodied, thick, creamy.  Flavor was awesome.  Citrus/grapefruit.  Refreshing and satisfying.  Excellent!

This is one fine ale....one of the best Ive ever enjoyed.  It pours a nice deep amber color.  The aroma is a sweet, floral, citrusy one.  The mouthfeel is thicker than I imagined, not as syrupy as the DFH 120, and darn good.  The taste is superb.  Id be hard pressed to think of a better example of the style.  Hop Wallop and Ruination are excellent, but this bad boy kicks it all up a notch.  Ill always have some of this on hand...period.

Dark golden pour with a good head that held for a fair amount of time.  Nice hop smell not overpowering.  The suprise to me on the beer was the balance.  I expected more hop bitterness and was met with that but almost just as much sweetness as well
Probably the best IPA that I have had to date.  Nice pour with a amber color.  Excellent maltiness to compliment the hoppiness.  Outstanding flavor.  It brought me lots of happiness!

on tap at blind tiger and i reckon it might have been a bit more subdued than in the bottle. woody, sherry aroma. pretty sticky in the mouth but with some vanilla and plum and then a big hit of grapefruit

Bottle(s).  Ive had so much of this and Im shocked Ive never rated it here.  Pretty copperish amber pour; medium brainy head that fades to a lingering trace.  Aromas are a surprisingly solid mix of malt and hop.  Flavors are not even close to blaanced.  This beer is an assault of hops.  The difference between this and many hop overboard beers is that this one presents a substantial, sweet, chewy malt backbone on which to stand its hop component.  Its good beer.  No, its great.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2008 Bottle into tulip glass.  If there were a Platonic form of IPA floating in the supersensible ether, DFH 90 min. is the reflection of it in the mortal, human world.  Drinking this is tantamount to fighting off the shadowy, unreal imitations of beer shackling us in our cave of ignorace to emerge (as if from the womb) to see the sunlight for the first time.  The perfection of this beer actually scares me; Im tempted to look into the sun, to try and actually see that glowing orb, but I know I will be blinded by its brilliance.  

Now, to practical matters.  The smell: smoky hops and alcohol.  The vision: orange amber, clear, with a peachish white head, creamy and average sized, mostly lasting, small-bubble lacing.  The taste: cream and fruit at first and some unexpected maltiness; hops bitter comes on slow like a train from far away, and intensifies; basil dryness and a bit of black pepper accent the hops; all flavors last through the long finish.  The touch, the feel: medium to full bodied; creamy; soft carbonation.  Overall: DOPE.

With IPAs being my favorite style, I must say I havent enjoyed one as much as this in quite awhile. Balanced and luscious in every way. The floral / citrus hops just fill the air. Gotta enjoy this one on the warmer side (55-60 degrees) to really appreciate the aroma. Lots of sweet crystal malts balance out the orange-grapefruit hop flavor and snappy bitterness. Mouthfeel is smooth and silky with a long bitter-sweet finish. Makes me want to go out and drop the $7.50 on a bottle of the 120 to compaare. This babys gotta be tough to beat!

Amber/orange with a medium white head. Aroma of  rosemary and hops.
Somewhat malty/sweet at first then finishing with a nice hop kick. Alcohol
is well hidden.
UPDATED: AUG 10, 2004 poured clear amber. the alcohol% was hidden better then other high percentage beers. the consistency was oily and it seemed to slide around in your mouth. NIce fruity taste.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2010 Had a very nice balance for such a strongly hoppy beer. The finish is pretty bitter as well. Definitely a beer you need to sip, as the flavors are very intense. The high alcohol content is hidden very well. Had a nice sweet aroma and above average mouth feel. If youre in the mood for a very strong, but well-balanced IPA, this is one of the best!

Bottle.  Poured a thin head, orange in color.  Aroma is malty with a little hop.  Taste is initially malty and then a nice juicy, piney flavor.  Good, and I would not hesitate to drink this again,  but I am going with Dreadnaught
Didnt really like all that much.  It was okay, I just feel its terribly overrated!  Very hopsy.  Tasted like bongwater!
a great ipa.  well balanced, and more complex than the 120 minute.   hops continue to kick your butt even as it warms up a little

I never thought I would try any IPA (or variety thereof) that would have Two-Hearted against the ropes.  Truly brilliant first-class beer.  Some piney earthiness in the nose.  Sour metallic flavors hit early on, but they are soon settled with a nice malt syrup mouthfeel.  I am suprised to hear others call this unbalanced.  This is a well-crafted beer with dynamic personality.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2006 Cant believe I never rated the 90 Min.  Its still one of my favorites to date.  Deep orange, creamy white head.  Nose is rich pine, spruce, spiced grapefruit, caramel, and a hint of earth.  Bitter citric hops and sweet malt chime in with big flavors that provide great balance.  Full bodied, syrupy, soft carbonation, bitter-sweet finish. Soooo freakin good.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2005 I guess I miss the boat on this IPA.  I liked it out of the 750ml bottle, but out of the 12 oz it is overwhelmingly sweet to hide the 9%, I assume.  Love the idea of the IIPA, but I prefer the Ruination. (7/4/4/3/14: 3.2)

ReRate (Last Day of June 2005): Beautiful on tap -- and will enjoy this frequently at this new "dive" bar -- for $3.50 a pint!!  For whatever reason now since, I even enjoy this baby in the bottle moreso -- it seems less sweet and less "sticky."  I love the more understated hoppiness to this.  Its amazing what a year can do.
Gold Goloring.  Good Head.  Hoppy I would say Henry!  Dees ees Gude yah? Would keep this in stock...excited to try the 120

I dont know what it was, but something about this aroma was weird. Very metallic, hoppy. I dont think it really mattered once you got a good taste. Light amber, golden color with a good size head. Great hoppy flavor. I need to try again. Ill be back for this.

Intoxicating aroma...the appearance did not call out "dirnk me" but the aroma drew me like a tantilizing mistress. It seems best to drink it very slowly because the taste is intense and becomes a little syrupy  if your dont take your time. It is like drinking a perfectly balanced flower. Not as good as the Hercules for me but one of the best imperial IPAs Ive had.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2006 Re-rate from a bottle I got in a trade with Hogtown Harry.  Lovely hop aroma, small tan head.  Great hop taste, tons of malt, I really enjoyed this a lot more than a couple of years ago. I found it really nicely balanced with no hint of the alcohol.  Ill take the 60 as a session, but if I want a perfectly balanced double IPA, this is the one.  Thanks Harry! Original 8/4/5/3/14

Bottle.  Fantastic orange colour, small head that dissipates quickly.  Lots of citrus hops right off the bat in the aroma.  First taste is surprising  there is a lot more body to this than I was expecting.  But I found it very syrupy  it certainly balanced off the hops, which I really enjoyed in the taste  yes, they were aggressive, especially in the finish, but I thought they totally made the beer.  What I didnt like was the overpowering alcohollike syrupy taste I got.  So overall, certainly a good beer, one of the best Ive tasted for taming a tremendous amount of hops, but the balance isnt quite there.
This is a brutal one. A bit too alcoholic and aggressive. However i like the extreme amount of hops in this beer. Interesting and worth dribking again.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2004 Comparing the Stone IPA I just had with this Dogfish 90 Double IPA. Stone was Excellent, Dogfish is even better!!! Wanted to save some of these for Milestones but posting made me rethink cellaring this one for too long a time period. Dark Amber out of bottle Hoppy, Sweet, Potent, Intense. Believe it or not I like this better than Dreadnaught!!! Very nice beer. Im glad I bought all these from Vintage Cellar and they were available. This is truly a great Beer.  Dogfish just a wee bit better than Stone Ruination.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2004 Its all there but for some reason it doesnt come together for me.  Ive tried this now a few times and hesitated to rate considering the legendary props.  But I cant hold out any longer.  The booziness is distracting and the hops are too astringent. However, lets zoom out and consider all the crap thats out there- this is still quite a fine effort.

Re-Rate on Tap at the Maproom 8-11-04:
Here is what everyone is talking about!  The ingredients come together in a seamless and creamy double IPA that is wonderful.  Still not as nuanced as dreadnaught and a bit too much alcohol in the end.  New rating combines bottle and tap results.
Pours orangish, blonde. Crisp, strong, hoppy nose. Heavy bitterness, and powerful hops.Dry finish. The first taste was the best, after several drinks my tongue was saturated w/ bitterness.

If youre a hophead, then this beer is fantastic.  It pours with a tall head that eventually diminishes and leaves a nice lace behind all the way to the last drop.  Aroma is of fresh hop flowers and citrus.  This is what turned me on to Imperial IPAs.  Im new to rating, so its tough to describe this beer.  It has a decent mouthfeel -- sort of snappy.  Sharp bitterness with some citrusy flavors.  When I first tried it, I thought it had such an interesting flavor.  I wasnt sure if I liked it, but I couldnt stop taking sip after sip.  I guess thats a good sign?  :)
Light gold color with thick bubbly white head.  Pleasant hops aroma.  Very nice feel in the mouth. Strong hops feeling upfront.  Tastes very good for the amount of alcohol.
A truly awe-inspiring IPA. Powerful, slightly fruity aroma.  Deliciously intense hoppy flavor with an interesting herbal aftertaste.  This beer has taken up a permanent residence in my top 10.

Ruthless. Simply ruthless.  This has a great mouthfeel.  Lots of piney orange fruitiness with some diacetyls.  Intense burnt orange coloring, but the bottle and label ought to take a deduction, however Ill give it a pass.

You can smell the hops as you our the dark amber/brownish ale into the glass, finsihing it with a full lasting head.  Hops are most prevalent flavor, with a little bitterness and a good amount of dryness.  An exceptional beer!

Im not the biggest hops fan as I prefer to lean toward the sweeter side of     malt.  Still, The aroma was unreal.  A beautiful frothy head that had a very pleasing hoppy aroma.  Extreme cloves comes to mind.  The initial flavor was a bit overwheling for me (too hoppy) but doesnt linger for too long.  The finish is soft and sweet.  You certainly can feel the 9% ABV half way through.  The strong hops flavor reminds me of the same hoppy flavor s at American micro breweries.  As the beer warmed up to 60F, hops flavor mellowed and I really enjoyed this beer.

The color is a very dark copper with a medium white head on top. The aroma is pungent with orange peels and caramel. There is a very sharp hops bite of pine and orange peels. Not much malt balances this out. This is very good but, I personally would prefer the 60 min.
UPDATED: SEP 8, 2006 this is a better IPA, even though i really dont care for IPAs. A reddish brown color.  not as bitter as i would have expected.

definently not your typical IPA, pours a brownish red color, good smooth head that does desappear and thick lacing around glass.  Very aromatic smell, belgiany spice, and fruity essence. Very smooth in mouth with little bitterness, hoppy and sweet. I am very impressed.

What a great brew, pours a cloudy reddish brown color with a small off-white head. Aroma is very sweet and malty with a nice hop presence. Taste is very sweet and masks the higher alcohol very well, very good balance of malt and hops, ends only slightly bitter. Oh hell of a great brew.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2013 Poured a dark orange with a small head. Nice hoppy aroma with smells of citris (especially grapefruit). Nice hoppy flavors - citris and some pine (not overpowering hops) with a nice malty balance. This is now one of my favorite IPAs.
Filled with tastes of citrus and hops,  very well balanced IPA.  Enjoyed this one til the last drop, excited to one day try the 120 min.
Crazy out of control hops, but thats a good thing.  Hints of citrus besides the hops.  A new favorite
It starts with great coloring, a nice head, and full aroma.  It finishes with a spice / clove taste and aftertaste on the back of the tongue.  Very nice...

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2008 Original Rating, May 21, 2004.  Holy buckets of hops, Batman!  Very nice, golden color with a thick head.  Aroma was a killer blend of hops and flowers (other than hops).  The taste explodes with hops.  Malt is definitely present.  Some trace spice also.  It feels a little thick in the mouth and hides its alcohol well.  Very splendid brew; Ill be looking for another one to discover even more about it!  9/5/9/4/18  Re-rating, October 31, 2008.  Copper color with a medium head.  Aroma of dried flowers and citrus hops.  A strong vegetal bitterness, not really piney or citrusy.  Strong caramel malt and a little chocolate.
This is my favorite beer, so its the only one Im giving a 20 rating.  So hoppy and has a great fruity finish, and its so creamy in your mouth.  Best beer eva.

Thanks IPFreely for getting me a bottle of this. And thank you dogfish head for making such an amazing beer. Body is copper colour with just a touch of white foam resting on top. Aroma is hoppy with some fine candy notes that balance things out quite nicely. Taste is hoppy bitterness to a great extent. Also noticeable is a caramel type sweetness. Again nice balance. Smooth mouthfeel with only a slight alcohol aftertaste. Id love to have more of these.

Ale Fest Fort Wayne 2004.  This bottled brew poured a small head of fine clear colored mostly diminishing bubbles that left behind a fair lacing.  The body was a softly carbonated transparent orange color.  The aroma was mildly hopped with some caramel notes to it.  The mouth feel was medium strength hoppy with a bit at the start and then smoothened in the finish.  The flavor contained notes of caramel malt and piney hops.
Nice beer with a bitter after taste. Nice hoppy flavor. Not much head. A nice IPA. Needs to tone the after taste down.
Citrus aroma. Dark orange color. Bit of lace for attractiveness. Hop attack on tongue and bitterness on palate. Unique mellower finish, after all those bubbles.

Poured orange/yellow with minor head.  Had a medium grapefruit aroma.  The taste was defintely grapefruit with a good amount of hops and a slight alcohol burn, much less so than the 120.  Aftertaste had some spice in it as well.

On tap at "Big City" in Allston, MA.  Heavy and bold.  A mix of cream and a dash of spice.  Feels heavy in the glass, and has minimal froth.  Dont expect the beer to jump at you extrovertedly; this is one that seeps down into your corpus.
Great beer!  Hops, hops, and more hops.  Has an amber like color, with a little head.  There is a hint citrus and a lot of hops.  One of the best IPAs I have ever tasted.

poured a cloudy amber with a small head that didnt hang around long. aroma hops, citrus and a little yeast. flavor hops and  hints of oranges with some bitterness.mouth feel was smooth and and just the  right amount of bitterness. this one I will drink again
A great Ipa. Very hoppy and bitter.  I love the color of this beer.  Didnt really notice the alcohol.  One of my fav Ipas up there with stone and bells
Damn. What a beer. Hoppy, bitter and smooth. I love you 90 Minute IPA. Pours amber with a tan head and goes down fantastic. Best IPA Ive had.

Art of Beer Festival 2004:  Has a nice amber color and a tan head.  Smell is of hops all the way.  Taste is syrupy/sweet and finishes with a strong hop bitterness.  Overall another fine uber-IPA from Dogfish.

Great pour right out of the bottle - fast fizzing bubbles and a thick head. Delicious hop aroma is readily apparent. The high alcohol content is surprisingly helpful because of the complex flavors that reach the back of the mouth near the end.

This is certainly the best IPA I have ever had, and I have had some pretty damn good ones. It just barely squeezes by stones IPA. This may sound wierd and sorry for using the reference, but the aroma very much reminded me of really dank pot. This beer has a great hoppy flavor that doesnt come out as overly bitter. Also, nice citrus sweetness that is common with IPAs. Everything blends together very well. If you can get this beer, definitly give it a shot!

Very nice looking brew, golden amber body with creamy white head. The aroma is explosive hops.. the hops flies right up your nose...
Flavor is just hops, hops, hops, hops and a little maltiness to balance it out, i was actually expecting a little more excessive hoppiness. It is very balanced though its so extreme and creamy.
I was a little dissapointed with this brew, I was just expecting something more palate wise. Well, this a plain hop beer. Nice for those who dig something like that.

Pours into the glass with an amber gold body topped by a medium thick white sustaining head with great lace left behind. Sweet and citrusy hop aroma with some tropical fruit notes. Incredible aroma. Sweet and citrusy  hop flavor well balanced with maltiness. The finish is strongly bitter and hoppy. Best IPA Ive had to date. I expected a strong alcohol presence, but it wasnt there. Medium bodied, remarkably smooth and slightly dry.

Very nice reddish orange color.  Sticky stuff, leaving lots of lace on the glass on the way down.  Robust, enticing nose with lots of hops that made my nose tingle a bit and the saliva start flowing.  Explosion of vibrant hops on the tounge.  Malty flavors take the back seat here, but do make a bit of an impression.  I enjoyed the dominant floral charicteristics of this brew, as opposed to the huge citrus/ grapefruit found in most big IPAs.  Long semi sweet finish.  Never overly bitter or out of balance, because of the hop selection, in my opinion.  Very well done.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2004 Huge hops!  Not as over the top as some of the Imperial IPAs, but one of the best for sure.

Certainly packs more hop aroma and taste than the 120 min.  I like that its more balanced than other Imperial IPAs.
This is a perfect beer if you enjoy hops.  
More floral than grapefruit rind like some IIPAs.  
The alcohol is well hidden, dont know how they keep doing it!
DFH has a big winner here.

Semi-transparent amber with a white head that almost vanishes.
