Aroma is basically hops, and the flavour made me think "hopwater" with a bit of malt to add a semblance of balance.

Now, I like big hops, but these were not working for me. Not much of interest in there besides the hops and these didnt have any uplifting qualities for me.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2013 [re-rate pending] .....   Initial Rating Date: 5/1/2004             3.4

08102013:
Opinion has not changed, still think it is one of the most overrated beers in america, apricots dominate the aroma which is the only good think about this, faint fruits but overly malty. Nice bitterness but nothing really to back it up.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2005 bottle 12 oz. Purchased @ Total Wine in Claymont, DE. Beautifull clear amber/copper w nice beige head that fell fairly quickly, moderate lace. Aroma is fresh malt w clean, potent, fresh hops with a very resinous, slightly bubblegum characteristic. Full bodied, big malty flavor with kick ass hop flavors described above. Spicey, complex, quite good. The palate explodes with flavors and they linger with a slow fade to an ever pleasant bitterness. Wonderfull hop "burn" all the way through. I do notice some alcohol taste but basically well hidden. Somewhat sweet. Mighty fine stuff. The hop flavors and bitterness can last on the lips and palate for quite some time afterward. Youre still gonna enjoy even for hours after its drunk every time you belch. 4/$7.99.... Add on: 10/2/04 its as good from the bottle as it is on tap. 10/9/04 Hey, you guys were right...it does smell like bubblegum.
I must give DFH credit when it comes to IPAs they are standard on the East Coast. This one hides the 9% very nicely until your realize what your are feeling. A winner for any IPA lover

Light copper appearance, looks like a fine single malt scotch. Little to no head, Fresh, strong sprucey, hoppy aroma. Good grapefruity essence with a heavy, malty undertone - one of the best balanced "intense" IPAs I have had. Heavy hop presence very evident without being tongue numbing. this one just sits right.
Citrusy hop aroma.  Color and taste is like Yulesmith, but finishes more mellow.  Has a nice creamy texture to it.  On of the smoothest double IPAs I've had.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2004 This bottle has been aged for probably about a year and I think it has mellowed out too much. The aroma is that of a slightly hoppy scottish ale. The flavor tastes the same, lots of soft caramel with hops only in the background. I will try to rerate a fresh sample

Well, this is a good quality strong IPA.  It's very, very bitter, but it's lacking the brighter hoppiness of some beers I prefer.  Stone Ruination IPA is much nicer, with even more outrageous hoppiness that includes the higher, citrusy hop notes, vs. the black sludge of pine tar taste in the dogfish head 90 minute.  I'm not sad that I have three more to drink, but I don't know if I'll buy another four-pack.

As typical with dogfish, this beer has a long lasting creamy white head. The hop aroma smacks you in the face the minute you pop off the bottle cap. It pours a golden hue of amber. The taste is very hoppy as the name would suggest with a dry/alcohol finish. At first sip you don't realize the 9%, after that it hits you. Great Imerial IPA to sit back and enjoy

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2006 Re-Rate July 2006 Cask @ Ashleys in Ann Arbor. I was excited to the point of annoying my fellow beer travelers at seeing this available. Teehee! Orange body with a massively creamy head is glorious, and long lingering lace down the glass. Green leafy hop aroma is suprisingly sweet. Sweet yet hoppy flavour with lots of green resiny hops, bitterness is dangerously well balanced by malt. Smooth creamy palate. Worth the trip to Michigan! 9/5/8/4/17 - 4.3

Re-Rate Oct 2004 Orange amber body with a fluffy white head. Big hoppy aroma with a resiny sweetness in the flavour. Full smooth body, sweeter than I remembered it being. 7/4/7/4/17 - 3.9

Original Rating Crowned by a beautiful pillow of an off white head. Orange body with lots of slightly floral hops in the aroma, lead you to a very hoppy but surprisingly well balanced flavour profile. The bitterness is not as powerful as I anticipated. Velvety soft palate that cannot quite be described as thick. Thanks to IPfreely for sending this one my way. 8/4/8/4/17 - 4.1

Pretty good stuff. Very hoppy. Pours a nice golden/amber color with a frothy off white long lasting head head. Lots of hop aroma and flavor with a slightly sweet/alcohol finish. Enjoyable, but I have to say I like the 120 minute better. I think if I had tried this first I wouldve liked it more. Still, tasty stuff.
user_location: New York, east village, New York, USA

text: Another killer brew with big hops in a 90-minute boil   I haven't been able to get my hands on the 120-minute IPA yet, so this one will have to do.  You will have to love the basic IPA to get along with this offering.

This poured a dark amber hue with a lasting head, with an herbal-citric smell. The flavor was sharp and complex, but I have to go against the masses here and say that
I prefer the 120 Minute... the 90 just didn't have the certain quality I was looking for in an IPA. Yes, it's a very good beer, but just not what I was expecting.

"Deep orange color, medium head. Aroma is floral and herbal, touch of grapefruit. A big bold malty and hoppy IPA. Very smooth taste. The over malting is balanced by the extreme over hopping. At 9% alcohol and 90 IBU, you would expect this beer to be much harsher and stronger tasting. It is surprising in it mellowness and subtly. Malts have a touch of fruitiness and sweetness to them. Hops are dominant and are floral and slightly spicy. Complex flavors. Thick taste, thick I will be picking hops otta my teeth for a couple of days. Grapefruit flavor intensifies as it warms. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter."

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2004 Beautiful hoppy citrusy aroma.  Makes my mouth water.  Dark gold/light amber appearance...a little murkey, with a small amount of manilla head.  The flavor is a massive onslaught of hops and absolutely no malt taste.  Bitter and dry aftertaste.  Sits nicely on the palate and you really don't get the full balance until swallowing.  Very good IPA.
i wish that i had opened this 750ml bottle earlier. open'em up if you've got 'em...there is no need to wait...hop heads unite and enjoy before all we have are 12oz'ers.
Beer pours a nice thick dark amber. The smell is dominated by piney hops.  The taste is dominated by hops as well.  Minimal malt balance -- that's fine with me.

750ml bottle:  Mine was bottled 12/02 and opened 4/11/04.  This one poured a cloudy, dark golden color.  There was a big frothy head on it, which settled down rather quickly.  Some lacing down the glass.  Don't know if the aroma mellowed as it aged, but it is a bit weaker than expected.  Still, it has a strong hop aroma, with some lemony notes.  Suprisingly sweeter taste with only a little bitterness.  maybe even a little bready and lemony taste.  This was really nice!

Bottle pours translucent golden, small milky white head, good lacing, and minor carbonation. &nbsp Strong hop aroma, as well as spruce/pine. &nbsp Initial taste is of biscuits, slowly fading into the hoppiness that is the IIPA. &nbsp That transition is quite smooth, and the hoppiness is quite delicious, not overly bitter, well balanced. &nbsp Finishes with a soft sweet maltiness with a hop tinge. &nbsp Very enjoyable for a IIPA. &nbsp The 9% ABV is well hidden.

cloudy amber color, small carbonation bubbles and a nice rising creamy head, highly hoppy aroma with a bouquet of hops mixed with a fruity touch; flavor is hoppy and bitter with a very faint fruity flavor  citrusy, acidic, a bit of bready malty as well
This is a real treat. It has a long and bitter finish.  The aroma is very floral with hints of orange, pine and complex sweet/bitter flavours, awesome IPA

Had this as part of a 60/90/120 Min vertical tasting and loved it. Gorgeous copper kettles colour with thin off-white, lasting head and lots of nice lacing. Noticable alcohol but smooth and mild. Lots of great outdoors aromas - pine forest, meadows, floral. Very creamy and complex bitter/sweet flavours lead to a dry finish with great bitterness. Really good.

clear amber-orange colour, almost no foam, strong floral hoppiness with notes of cream, butter, litchies and lemon, very dry and very bitter, long floral and bitter finish - good stuff but hard to drink: one more us-extravagance ... - thanks to Clarkvv for this bottle

Beautiful copper in colour.  Aroma was floral, piney, citrus.  Flavour of pine, oranges, creamy mouthfeel, some malt and alcohol.  Full bodied and nicely balanced.  Finishes with a very nice bitterness and dry.  The alcohol is only noticable in the finish.  Thanks for the bottle Jeff.
UPDATED: MAR 18, 2009 One of the best IPAs out there.  A hop lovers delight.  Nice copper color, and the aroma hits the nose warmly.  This is a beer to sip on slowly to enjoy the delicious flavors.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2014 2014-09-18, bottled 2 months ago, 7-5-7-4-14=37Parallel with 60 Minutes and Sixty-OneAmber color, bright, hazy. Fruity and sweet, almost a special Barley Wine, not the expected IIPA.2004-03-26, 9-5-9-5-17=45Beautiful copper-amber color, creamy head. Wonderful hop aroma. Explosive; I like it because the maltiness can somehow support the huge hopping. And the fruity character in the nose and palate. Excellent IIPA. Thanks Philippe (Bov) for sharing this bottle.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2005 Great imperial IPA. Pours a beautiful amber with an off white head. Has an INTENSELY strong, floral hoppy aroma. Actually the aroma has a bit of hop stink to it. Taste is citrusy and obviously ridiculously hoppy and sweet but not overly bitter. Although the alcohol content is high, it is hidden pretty well. Aftertaste is spicy and very dry. Actually, I was thirsty as hell after drinking this. Mouthfeel is full and round. Excellent!! Recommended.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2005 absolutely amazing aroma showcasing citrus, pine, even some tannin-like hoppiness.  super-tangy with a superb malt backbone, and a finish that doesnt go away.  it just stays there and lingers.  the hops profile is excellent, and the malt profile is excellent--but there isnt any interplay.  theyre both just kinda THERE, doin their own thing.  cant we all just get along????

UPDATED: APR 26, 2012 I tried this beer for the first time last summer, and was blown away.  This beer started its own style, the Imperial India Pale Ale.  This beer is very rich, unbelievably hoppy, and extremely malty.  It is so complex that your taste buds will need a moment to realize what has just hit them.  It may be too strong or hoppy for some, but all hop heads must try this!
This was another Christmas present Brew from 'Beers of the World'.  It poured a large head that would not fade.  Plenty of hop bite.  It was the best IPA I ever had(I usually don't like IPA's)

strong smell of hops- i can already tell this is going to be a great IPA.  pours out of the bottle tan to brownish color.  head disappears almost instantly.  very strong flavor of hops. hops hops more hops. this is fucking GREAT.  this is a wonderful IPA.  i could drink this all damn day if i didnt have to drive to VA to buy it.  the aftertaste lingers and is somewhat dry.  An EXCELLENT ipa.

Bottled.  Turbid orange colour. Strong aged bitter hop aroma. Nice but a very strong and intense experience. The strength of the hops really only comes through when you taste it, the aroma is more subtle. So the flavour is strongly bitter with extreme length on the palate. Cloying, silky texture as well. This beer has to be the last of the night as the flavour wipes your palate out.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2007 the alcohol content is hidden. and i mean HIDDEN. it tasted like a regular ipa, not a double. huge hop nose, weet, bitter, lucious hops. the taste was bitter of course, hoppy. it also had a bit of coffee and malts in it. as always an interesting taste from DFH. the finish was not of hop resin, grainy and course, but of a smoothe wonderful hop ending that didnt taste like chewing the pellets.

Pours a copper color with a white head. Strong hop flavor which I could see to be over powering for those non hop-heads.  I also taste grapefruit and a bit of malt that give it a little bite at the end. To top it all off 9% alcohol which is well hidden. Bravo!

bottle. enjoyed the 60 minute and could not wait to give ot a shot. good color. great floral aroma, morso than the 60. nice bite. I dont know yet which one i like better. Might have to sample the 2 closer together.

On tap at Spuyten Duyvil in Brooklyn.   I was kicked for not liking this brew, but it isn't all that and a bag of chips to me, anyway.  Kind of copper colored, decent head.   Smells nice and flowery.  The viscosity is a problem for me, and the hops were way too over strong for my taste. Can't enjoy more than a couple of sips.

Starts with a bold nose and bite and leads to smooth long finish.  This is almost the 60 Minute in reverse order (which starts smoother and ends more harshly).  Not over the top sweetness, just right.
Nice dark gold color with off-white head.  Smooth mouth feel with a wonderful balance of malt for the extreme hop finish.  Very nice, easy to drink and enjoy!

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2004 Excellent IPA all around. Dead on mouthfeel with medium orange amber cloudy body, lively carbonation, and strong hoppy aroma. The hops do not overpower the malty goodness. Very juicy citric hop bitterness (grapefruit and orange rinds). The yeast acts as a softening influence to round out the taste. The 9 percent alcohol so well hidden, this would be a dangerous brew for me if it was available locally. This is now my second favorite beer behind Sweetwater IPA from my hometown, Atlanta.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2004 Orangish, dark amber color with thin white head.  Piney, floral aroma.  Deliciously hopped and very well balanced with malt.  Lasting citrus and pine flavors with lingering sweetness from the malt.

orange with a hint of gold in color, white head, that dissapated rather quickly.  Beautiful floral hop aroma coupled with malt.  Incredible full malt body that is complemented by the hops.  More in the way of flavoring hops as opposed to bitterness.  The malt flavor just hangs in your mouth and fades out with some lingering bitterness.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2006 This has to be the most extreme IPA I have ever tasted, which was to be expected. But my overall expectations were way off. There was very little head, and what did exsist lasted only a few seconds then ran for the sides of my glass and hide there the rest of the session. A deep, hazy amber. The nose was strong of hops and hops alone. The taste is brutally hopped, but right when you are about to curse the heavy hand of the hop tosser... the malts come around and save the day.  You are still left with the pine-citrus linger, which is plesent, but not extra-ordinary. I suspect much time went into balancing such a big beer. I like IPAs this one was just a little over the top for me.
~--~ Re- Rate!  3/12/06 bottle ~--~
 Well apparently more carbonated this time.  Aroma is good but really just like smelling a hop bag.   This is thick and  surupy?... Thick. Oh, and  strong by the way.  Two  glasses and a fine buzz, check!, Yes Sir!  Good and pure.  Would I change my previous rating? No... & thats saying something since this was one of my first IIPA... SOLID.
Hoppy.  Very Hoppy.  A real treat for fans of beers with flavor.  Crisp and clean, with great bite.

Probably one of my favorite IPA's, although im not a huge IPA fan in the first place. Most notable about this beer is how the taste demands to be recognized. I'm sure I'll find myself picking up some more sometime down the road, I've gotta get back to this one at hand.

There is an interesting clash with this beer that I can see. I am in the middle of my second of a four pack and the aromas are very subdued. There is hoppy presance and you can tell that there is strength there but everything is strangly muted. Then the color is orange/red but clear with a beautiful head. But really clear, not what I was expecting to see of a so-called bottle conditioned beer. The flavor on the other hand is explosive with powerful malty body that beats up your mout and then come the hops like a pack of wolves hitting every hidden spot with their beautiful bitterness. All-in-all this is an incredible beer, and I haven't had a DFH brew that I didn't like.

I have had it on tap and the orginal in the 750ml bottle - this is my first tasting of the 12oz bottle in the 4-packs. Deep gold color, with lots of hops and malt in the aroma. After pouring into a glass I notice that the beer is filtered. Still has a wonderful, intense malt and hop flavor, leaving me with a pleasantly bitter aftertaste. Its also nice that I only have to drink 12oz so I don't have to be shnockered like after having the BIG bottle.

surprisingly wonderful from the inconsistent dogfish brewery.  great one to try for those wanting to make the jump to the 'double' ipa's.  well balanced, though i suppose it isn't THAT well balanced because the style dictates huge hopping rates.  very drinkable, give it a try!

I've had this in bottles, on cask and today got the first pint out of a brand new keg (Map Room-Chicago).  What always strikes me about this beer is how well balanced it is. Before I tried it the first time I thought it would be way too bitter, but its a big enough beer to hold its own.  Reminds me of a 290 lb linebacker that moves like a ballerina-bulky, yet graceful.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2008 [bottle] Pours a hazy amber with a thick and fluffy white head. Hoppy aroma mixed with the scent of pine. Initial sweet taste that gives way to a caramel finish with a nice creamy mouthfeel and a super smooth finish. Leaves a nice bitter flavor afterwards.

Oh beautiful, for spacious beer...for amber waves of greatness!!! I sampled this at the San Diego Strong Ale Festival and Im glad i did. It pours an ambery orange hue with a pretty white fairly long lasting head. The aroma is naturally supra hoppy with a life of its own. Weeds, grass, trees, twigs and woody smells dominate your nose. The 90 minute goes down VERY smooth with one hell of a caramelly sweet finish. There is definitely some souring acidity right in mid sip, but man that is one hell of a great finish. Dry, with hints of vanilla, clean, fresh hops, a tingle of carbonation, and a caramelly sweetness. You could almost feel the stickyness or syrupiness of this great IPA throughout the tasting...a great beer!
My favorite beer at the 2004 SE gathering. Very hoppy aroma. Crisp, clean hop flavor throughout with a lingering bitterness on the tongue. Wonderful!

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2014 This is a classic and a staple of my beer fridge. It has changed some over the years but remains a favorite and a hard draft for me to resist when I am out and about. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer pours a golden bronze color with very little head. There is an intense bursting grapefruity hop scent. This brew drinks thick and strong with a mealy texture. There is a heavy grapefruit explosion that paints the tongue and dares you to try and remove it. The grapefruity taste lingers forever. Absolutely wonderful. A hopheads delight.

Sample glass, RateBeer Southeastern Gathering.  Great IPA aroma; cookie, piney, citric.  Sweet and hoppy.  Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: thanks Scoobyluv, this was a delicious IPA.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2009 Wow! Hops, hops, and more hops! Dark orange appearance with a fair head and good lacing. Flavor was hoppy and slightly sweet with some sour citrus fruit lurking in the shadows. Full bodied and very complex. I think Double IPA has just taken over regular IPAs as my favorite style! Update......Amazing how this beer has gone to shit the original score 9/5/9/5/19.
Great IPA..nicely done good dose of hops but not overdone...Great amber color with decent head retention.  Flavor was extremely complex lots of fruits mainly citrus.  Huge finish.
Now this is a beer. Pours an inviting gold with a nice white head. Malty aromas, which also predominate in the flavor as well. Definately one of the best IPA's i've had.
Wonderful malty aroma, crystal clear Märzen syle color, a wonderful fresh malty flavor balanced with the perfect amount of hops. Alcohol shows through a bit too much however.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2004 (Draft: Double IPA tasting, O'Brien's in SD) Pretty light and gentle flavor overall for a double IPA, and less bitter than even a standard IPA; Gentle, smooth maltiness is reminiscent of English ales; Moderately sweet with maybe a fruity, slight orange-citrus flavor, but it would be masked by a stronger hops signature; Very well balanced until the finish, which is moderately hoppy; Smooth, velvety mouthfeel; Mildly hoppy nose, but overall, the nose is gentle; Dark, golden color and slightly cloudy; Plentiful carbonation bubbles; Off white head is creamy with excellent retention; Remarkably dense, thick lacing coats the glass

Kind of a glowing copper color going on with little bit of head. Has a nice floral aroma, fresh floral aroma. I get pine and grapefruit, pink grapefruit mostly in this one. Ya, alot more citrus bitterness than pine, but its pretty damn good.

I was expecting a hoppy aroma but found a neutral blend with malt. Appearance was pleasing to the eye of orange koolaid. I was expecting hops but found slight hops and a hint of sweet citrus. Palate was empty besides the alcohol. Overall, I didn't know what to expect from this 90 minute IPA but I found myself slightly disappointed with the IPA characterization.

Draft.  Orange/amber color and a small head.  A great beer with a nice hop bite as well as some complex fruity/spicy flavors.  Balanced nicely and surprisingly different flavor than the Alpine Exponential Hoppiness I had right after it.  On this day I prefer the 90 minute.

750 ml bottle. Hazy orange colour with huge fluffy white head. Piney hop aroma with notes of peaches, pine-apples and tobacco. Taste of caramel, apricot, peaches and grapefruit. Finish is hoppy! I can find notes of grapefruit, leather and green hops. Good stuff! Ciderguy - Thanks!

Fruity grapefruit peach aroma.Dark blond appearance with a full head.Fruity apricot peach grapefruit flavors with medium bitterness with a smooth bitter fruity aftertaste.Not as aggressively hopped as I thought it would be.
Nutty, malty, grassy and lemony aroma.  Reddish gold with an off white head.  Honey, malt, amazing hop bitterness in the flavor.  Scotch/alcohol burn at the back of the throat.  Citrus aftertaste.

Paid $9.99 for a 4-pack (12-oz bottles)

MMMM, nice looking brew. Golden orange, kinda hazy, with a small soft head. Nice lacing.

Great smell... love IPAs... Soothing pink grapefruit scent, that's not overwhelming like some IPAs can be.

MMM tastes like it smells... just a bit stronger. Grapefruits all over... the alcohol is well masked by the sourness of this brew... Drinking this reminds me of drinking carbonated grapefruit juice...

A bit too sour to be a session beer (and a bit too high in abv too), but this is one to try and enjoy!

A cloudy golden orange color, it looks great when held up to the light.  There are some citrucy hop tones and faint floral aroma.  It has a strong hop character present in the aroma and the taste. An initial sweetness is present at the front of the mouth that rolls to a full figured citric bitterness at the back.  Good Beer.

Brilliant orange/amber body, dense white head.  citrucy and resinous hop tones, fruity and floral as well.  Dry pale malts.  The great thing about this beer is its balance.  with a 9 percent and outrageous hop quantity it still presents a beautiful blend of all that is IPA.  Clean, bready malt tones mingle among the undescribeable (at least to me anyway) hop notes.  Just sticky enough to hold the flavors on the palate to enjoy far after the initial sip.  GREAT balance

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2004 This beer fares better in all alone tastings than is side by side comparisons.
I thought the aroma was overly fruity with citrus and bubblegum dominating. The flavor was to the sweet side and the palate was light, dry and softly carbonated. More hops in the aroma and finish would provide a better balance and would greatly improve the score for this beer. All around I think the 60 minute is a better balanced brew. 6/3/6/3/16
6/20/04 re rate: Randall at the Blind Tiger NYC, Brewtopia. This was so much better than bottle!! The hops I thought it needed int eh atoma and finish were right on. With the Randall... 7/4/7/4/17.
An amazing balanced beer considering the 90 moinut hop. Lots of tasty malt with a rich amber color. Alcohol remains hidden in the flavor.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2004 A strongly hopped yet well balanced IPA. Flavor is citrus with a bitter finish.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2006 Okay, this stuff is some good stuff. Golden with a thin white head. Excellent balance of malts and hops good bitter presence. The taste starts sweet and then followed by a bitter sharp hop. The mouth is full and fun.

Addition 2-26-06

Had on tap the other day at the Bread Coompany in Urbana Illinois. Served in a snifter, wow this is great on tap. Clean all around, round and full. very good. The hops are so crisp. Wow.
Light hop aroma with an amber body. Palate shows smooth hops and malt balance with light alcohol kick in finish. Great brew!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2006 Citrusy aroma. This beer seems a little too out of balance for me, too much bitterness without enough residual sweetness to counteract. Alcohol is also present. A little disappointed but overall a decent Imperial IPA. 3.6.

Re-rate 6/9/6 - The out of balance I described in the first rate is not accurate. Pours bright orange with a very stinky hop aroma. Flavor is sticky sweet upfront with some balancing hop bitterness to balance. I think I may have found a new favorite.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2009 This was enjoyed at a local Bar in Richmond.  The beer came with a thin head. The IPA had the full hop flavor of an IPA.  The 9 % ABV was very evident.  Very smooth IPA that is an excellent drink.
Very Nice. A very hoppy taste and finish with added complexity. I didn't like the bitter drawn out finish but I say that about most ales. All in all, i give it a thumbs up.

Cloudy amber, beige head.Nose is floral, citrus & slightly malty.Big citrus hop flavor with lots of body and lasting med strength finish. I don't agree with most of you; the finish isn't all that strong for an Imperial. Most are stronger and longer. Also I find the balance quite good, plenty of malt here.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2008 Wow...possibily a new favorite all around.  This is the first Imperial IPA Ive gone down on and I really feel that Im closer to reaching enlightenment from this experience.  This extremely smooth IPA has a strong citrus hop smell and flavor With the perfect ammount of barley to keep the beer balanced and not overly bitter.  Thanks again D.F.

Orange amber with decent head. Wonderful sweet floral hop aroma. Minor contribution of slightly roasted malt. But the dominant strong flavour is resiny long lasting bitterness. Also quite thick. Excelent, thanks Ciderguy.

This beer pours thicker than imagined, with a light amber color and thin, white head.  Aroma is defintely hop heavy, but not overpowering.  Flavor - Very balanced, this IPA is extremely strong flavored with a nice kick, but no flavor dominates.  Very smooth, very long lasting.  Great beer!

UPDATED: APR 26, 2004 4/25/04.  Poured out of 12 oz. bottle, obtained in the mail from Dogfish Head Brewery 2/30/04. RERATE.  Pours a clear, dark golden color with fantastic, dense creamy off-white head and viscous, thick appearance.  Just amazing head on this beast, lasts all night long.  Aroma is divine-- bubblegum hops, nice sweetness and floral quality with just enough bite.  Flavor is a bit of a letdown, much milder than I'd expected; piney hops and subtle sweetness return, but it doesn't do a whole lot.  Pretty nice, but not mind-blowing like I'd hoped.  Body is just exquisite, a full, creamy mouthfeel with a nice, smooth finish.  A very drinkable, elegant double IPA.  Just delectable.  I actually gave the exact same ratings on my re-rate as I had on my original rating.

12/5/03.  On tap at Pizza Port Strong Ale Festival in Carlsbad, CA 12/5/03.  Incredibly dense, frothy and rocky head, off-white, with good size.  Lasts forever.  Dark, golden clear body.  Mellow, sweet bubblegum hops, very strong in flavor concentration but mellow, if that makes sense.  Perfectly clean taste of hop and pale malt.  Very fresh and clean taste and feel.  Very nice, cooling mouthfeel and wonderfully smooth finish.  Not too bitter, but very long and elegant finish.  Finish is extremely balanced, as is the beer in general.  I went on a Double IPA binge at the Strong Ale Festival, and this and the Pizza Port Frank were my two favorites that I tried.

Thanks to jcalabre for this taste. This is a wonderful example of the style, very close to being my favorite (if I could easily get more that would help). I have it placed just south of Stone Ruination and Three Floyds Dreadnaught.
(Bottle Dec 13 2003) Orangy hue, light beige head. Cloudy. Fruity flower aroma slight spice present in aroma Smooth bitter dry. Citrusy Hoppy as hell. Delectable.

Bottle - thanks to The_Beer_God for the trade!  Pours rich amber and slightly hazy with a fluffy, white head that diminished leisurely.  Aroma is immediately hoppy, lots of citrus and piney scents, with a rich sweet malt character also evident.  Flavor is sweet maltiness, bit of orange, and a hop bite that chomps down and lingers on the back of the tongue.  Thick body and creamy carbonation make this one a pleasure to drink.  Not my favorite Imperial IPA, but definitely a good one.

Slightly hazy orange color with a small head and a bit of sediment at the bottom of the bottle. Delicious and big citrusy aroma of grapefruit, lemon/lime and mint. Good medium body and quite drinkable, with loads of hoppy flavors surprisingly well balanced by the malt. Lingering bitter hoppy finish with a hint of alcohol. Maybe I'm just getting more used to these hop bombs because this one seemed fairly civilized. I'm not complaining though-good stuff!

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2006 This courtesy of hopsrus (thanks!) poured a clear orange body covered by an initially large off-white head that diminishes quickly in a fin du monde glass. Nevertheless, an honest film for a beer of this caliber maintains the position. The smell is floral hops up front with definite orange character. Innocent malt is not absent from that sniff in the form of baked cookies. As it enters the mouth, its rather "coating", thick and velvety as seems usual with dogfish head. First sip is excellent with a sausage+sauerkraut dinner, great combination. I appreciate the difference from all-cascade IPA, but still, the last sips seemed far more boring, one-dimensional, rather tart in mouth and all about agressive (unbalanced) bitterness in the aftertaste. Mouthfeel is top notch clean though and 9% is nowhere to be found.  On recent samples, either I got over sensible to sweetness or this one got sweeter, because this is agressively sweet for an IPA though not so much as the 120, but still not very pleasant to me, syrupy and very hard to drink.

Poured a bright, nearly glowing amber with a big white diminishing head.  Smells like petunias and grapefruit.  Tastes like sucking on a grapefruit.  Sucking on a grapefruit sucks.  I don't care how much malt was trundled into this; it doesn't make me change my mind about the grapefruit.  Ew.

This beer POURS big! Long lasting head that sheets the glass all the way to the finish. Body is creamy, full,  sweet citrus and a slight taste of wood. Finishes slightly acidic with a real nice hop bite. One of my favorite IPA's!
Cloudy orange color.  The flavor is piney more so than citrusy like the 60 minute.  A decent amount of malt presence to balance it off and the alcohol is very nicely hidden.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2004 12oz Bottle
Large rocky head which fades into almost nothing. Body is a very nice medium amber color. Hops of course are present in the aroma... very heavy with some herb and grapefruit. Texture is creamy, but a little too carbonated on the tongue. Not too thick. Bitter grapefruit like hops all around in the flavor, which I absolutely love. Hops are balanced by the barley, which sweetens it just right.

Old 750ml Bottle - 5/21/04
Nice creamy white head, dark amber body that gets cloudy towards the end of the bottle. Full aroma that isn't your normal IIPA... brown sugar, butterscotch/toffee, cherry, strawberry, cookie. Flavor: Cinnamon applesauce, brown sugar, butterscotch, corriander. I think its like stale hops to, but that could just be in my head. Really complex in both aroma and taste. Very enjoyable. 
Aroma: 7  Appearance: 5  Flavor: 8  Palate: 4  Overall: 18

Finally found this in a 12oz bottle! According to the bottle, it was packaged in 6. No clue as to 6 of what, but if it meant June, this was a mighty fresh bottle.

Pours a dark orange color. It wasn't easy getting a head on it, but once it was there it stayed around for a while and left a nice lace.

Smells florally malty with some strong hops in there.

Tastes a bit citrusy. Well balanced between the hops and malt. I was expecting more, to be honest. I mean, it's good, but just not *that* good. The high alcohol content is barely perceivable, but it's there.

Mouthfeel is good and full; anything *but* watery. Nice crisp finish.

Drinkability is good as well. I think I was expecting something a little more "extreme" than this. I wouldn't have a problem having several of these, but from all the hype I was thinking one would set me back a few days.

What a great IPA. Reminds me of the arrogant bastard from stone. Great hop aroma, flavor and bitterness balanced with malt at the end. The finish is a liitle more on the hop bitterness and flavor than the bastard. It still has that nice spicey hop flavor that lingers on your lips after you drink it. What a great beer that I will enjoy again.

I have had this in both 26 oz bottle and in 12 oz.  Deep orange in color, with slight head which sticks to the glass.  Citrus and grapefruit hop aroma, with the flavor being somewhat piney.  Some malt background but overall, it is dominated by high alpha hops.  Alcohol is hidden well.  Surprisingly quaffable for such a strong beer..

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2004 Bright brassy orange, decent carbonation, snow white velvety head, and thick lace. Great aroma of honeysuckle flowers and sweet apricots. Initially the thick malts are striking, however the palate gradually surrenders unconditionally to the hop onslaught. Flavor also has some dustiness. Very full palate. This is a serious hop fix.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2004 Every day this brewer starts becoming my favorite. I love the diverse product line and cannot wait until more product is readily available in So. Cal. Well, since I'm not in So. Cal I don't give a rats ass if it makes it out there. This stuff is perfect on Randall. Glad Blind Tiger has it on most of the time.
This is one of my favorite IPA's. Very hoppy and a lovely ABV. Don't take many to make you feel good.

Pours a quite cloudy orange color with a big thick white head with great lacing.  Aroma is a strong citrusy hoppy smell with a touch of spice.  Big malt up fron that is beaten down by a considerable hop bite.  Medium body and a nice aftertaste lingers for a while.
Noticeable alcohol aroma and flavor, but plenty of hops to balance out the strength.  A delicious beer, one of the best I've had.  Good citrusy, hoppy flavor.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2004 Very impressive brew. Huge hop nose, unlike anything I have ever experienced. Hops Galore! Nice lasting head and light copper color. Malty, yet very hoppy flavor. Not too bitter and backed up with malt. Lingering hop flavor that is rather pleasant. Not unpleasantly citrussy like some breweries would make. And very drinkable. Did I metion the hops?
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Light copper coloring with a thin offwhite head.  Rich spicy aroma - floral and pine hoppiness on a mellow malt backdrop.  The spicy flavor is an excellent, smooth blend of malt and pine hops; neither are overpowering but both easily noticed.  Leaves a pleasing aftertaste with moderate, understated bitterness, yet it is not dry.  This beer is truly worthy of its high ratings.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2004 My first double/imperial IPA.  Must have more. Is it just this one or are they all so damn good!?  Dark murky amber brown color with a thin tan head that left as soon as it got there.  Beautiful evergreen, floral hop aroma.  Taste is amazing big burst of hops quickly blended with a huge malt. Near perfection in balance but yet the flavors are so separate.  Wonderful rich medium body with just enough carbination to play the flavors back and forth.  I love this brew could be my favorite. (untill my next favorite, of course)

Bottle pours a hazy orange amber with an off white head an good lace.  The aroma is piney.  The flavor starts malty and builds to a powerful hop finish, more like explosion.  The palate is nice and rich as it should be for the flavor burst.  Overall, real nice I2PA!

Redish brown pour with a very large head that coats the glass with lace. The aroma is bold, dominated by pine and a slight hint of citrus...drooling...  now, the moment of truth... Wow, this is a hop powerhouse. How the malts manage to keep up is beyond me. No trace of the 9% at all. I could read War and Peace before this finish subsides. Ladies and gentlemen, I have found a new favorite beer. If only it were avaliable in this area. Many thanks to Putnam at Cloverleaf for pulling this out of the backroom for me!

Hazy copper pour with a lingering head. Not many bubbles. Not as strong an aroma as I had hoped, but still full of floral and hops. The alcohol lingers around in the taste, yet very drinkable. Hops flood the flavor of this lovely Dogfish Head brew!

UPDATED: APR 30, 2004 Ohhhhh.... How I love the dogfish head.  This brew is so tasty... I can't even describe it.  Floral and hoppy with the perfect amount of hops. Drinkable and easily getting drunkable.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2004 Whoa, this is the malt-hop heavy.  Big in your face beer, with straight up hops and malt, no freaky yeast stuff going on and no fruit/herb additives.  This is the smoked peat DIPA. Heavy.  No head.  Some lace. What a way to end a night.

Perfumy, floral, dry and hoppy aroma. Dark gold in color with an off-white, large bubble head that mostly diminishes. Cloudy with good lace. Alcohol is pervasive, as are the hops. Piney with some pepper. Very good but a little too peppery and not sweet enough. Nevertheless, excellent! Very well made, fine. long finish. Thanks Kinz for sending another one on my Beerlist!

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2004 On tap. Nice fruit/pine aroma. Orange/yellow coloring with a small head. This beer is excellently hoppy and malty at the same time. Not a big alcohol taste, but the hops will knock you out near the end of the glass.  Great beer.    RERATE 5.10.2004:  Art of Beer '04 - For this festival Dogfish Head brought with them a crazy divice they were calling "Randle the Enamel Mammal".  It was a cylindar that they ran the keg though which was packed tight with hops.  They said that it would strip the hop oils off as it ran through.  It made the beer a bit more flowery and bitterly dry.  I liked it even more so I had to bump it up from my original rating of 4.4
UPDATED: AUG 25, 2006 Ah, thou fallen angel!  Shalt we ever see thy return to glory?  Why must thou be so filtered?  To where has thine vivacious flavors and substantial mouthfeel gone?

Wow, so good.   Roasty malt, incredibly hoppy nose thats beautifully balanced with some mild alcohol peaking through and a bit of malt bitterness also.   Bronze color, no head as seems to be the usual with DFH.   Sweet start, so hoppy throughout each sip.  Long lasting hop taste, beautifully put together, so much more sophisticated and enjoyable than the Moylans Double IPA, its got the malt and body to enjoy even if it wasn't hopped through the roof.

Pouring into the recommended snifter yielded a sparse, cream-colored head, which quickly dispersed to the edge of the glass. The 90 minute hop treatment must be used to rein in the heavy-sweet maltiness--a Good Thing.  After-sip hop bitterness safely guides the malt sweets away.  An excellent, but not outstanding, IPA.
UPDATED: OCT 2, 2007 (Bottle)  Hands down the best IPA that I have tried.  Pours a dark amber color with a small head.  Great flavor that makes your taste buds crave for more.
dark amber color.  pours a thick, frothy head that leaves relatively quickly.  not as hoppy as i expected.  tastes more sweet to me than anything.  honestly, it tastes like a barley wine

Golden color with some haziness.  Head lingered for a while.  Lacing reminded me the head had been abundant.  Hoppy aroma that almost masked the malt.  Some bite from the alcohol and nice bitterness from the hops.  Malts come in and try to balance it, but the hops won't let them.  That's a good thing.  Goes down smooth but didn't last long enough.  I'll need to get two bottles next time.

Wow!  This is a nice IPA!  It first goes down smooth, but the maltiness is quickly replaced by the strong hops which stick around for a long-lasting aftertaste.  I haven't yet had the 120 minute, but this is the hoppiest beer I've ever had that has remained balanced and natural-tasting.  Most highly recommended.

Pours to a nice frothy head, which disappears quickly. Some nice lacing. Dark brown color. First taste is malty, with lots of hops. Smooth with a nice aftertaste, a bit on the dry side. While a high ABV, not a high alcoholic taste. A  great flavorful beer, although the high ABV will keep me from enjoying too much of it.

Refreshingly unique hop character.  Citric, spruce, cedar, herbs, etc.  Satisfyingly full bodied.  Woody, bitter flavor, finishes bitter (duh). Gets away with being a bit tongue-coatingly sweet.  Bitterness is balanced by huge maltiness.  Toward the end of the glass, the malty sweetness fails under the bitter assault of hop.  Hides its alcohol well.

Hops galore.  Wow!  This one is powerful from the start.  Strong hop aroma with grapefruit.  Big white head that slowly diminishes to a dark golden colored body.  Nicely laces the glass.  Smooth and somewhat creamy. Flavors are nicely balanced with hops, malt, and a hint of grapefruit again.  The finish is mildly bitter.  And, long lasting.  It leaves a feeling of hops dancing on the tongue long after the beer is gone.

Light hazy golden color. Aroma is musky hoppy, not citrusy or grapefruity like I like. Flavor is lightly sweet but the hops are pretty straight up in this. This was after my homebrew IPA (which has lots more hops) so it was subdued. Very nicely balanced IPA though. Thanks hopsrus & Indra

Pours a nice and hazy gold with a thin layer of head and some spotty lacing.  A very nice blend of hops in the aroma, some malt.  Oh, citrus hops are abundant in the flavor, nice sweet malts compliment the hops! A nice and smooth body with some more hops to finish it all off.  This is a fine example of an Imperial IPA.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2005 Draft:  big beer!  Nice spruce hop aroma.  Even a bit of alcohol burn in the nose.  Ditry gold to amber with a small white head.  Big malt balance.  Very good, but I still prefer Hercules.  Even with that said - keep em coming!

Wow, this stuff will knock your socks off.  Incredible hop aroma and taste.  The pour is a very light golden color with a rich creamy head.  The taste is so big and hoppy that everything else is kind of pushed aside.  Sweet and extremely well balanced for such a hoppy beer.  The aftertaste is stinging and reminds me slightly of a fruity carob candy.  You must try this stuff!
Orangeish and hazy. Good lacing with head that quickly dissipates. Sweet and fruity aroma. Very hoppy flavor with an aftertaste that I can't place a finger on...maybe it's the "Simcoe" hops.

12 oz. bottle.  fresh, hop aroma, beautiful.  slightly opaque orange-gold color.   clean, hoppy front end. slight malt middle. great body, hides the alcohol unbelievably. slight bitter finish. smooth.    really enjoyable.  great job DFH.

This was the 90-minute Imperial IPA.  Man, is this good stuff.  I've heard it described as oily and that's an accurate description.  Thick and bitter.  EXCELLENT stuff.  A couple of these in the evening and I fall asleep!

This is one of the 5 best IPA's in the world. It is excellent in every respect. As with other top Imperial IPA's, don't plan on operating any heavy machinery after slammin' down a couple of magnums.
Note: I have tried this in the 12 oz. bottles recently and the quality doesn't seem to be quite as good as with the big bottles.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2010 Bottle:
Golden light orange hue.  Just barely enough to be called murky.  Not much of an aroma.  Mild earthy, leathery feeling and flavor, like wheat on steroids.  Doesnt fit the "US IPA" category well, but that seems to be DFHs style.  Nice and mild, pleasent, most importantly.  6/4/7/4/14


Draft (Aug 2006):
Had this at Zenos in State College, PA.  Extremely nice fruity and floral hop nose, creamy mandarin oranges and pineapple all over the nose in this thing.  Very well hopped.  Smooth, thick, a bit sticky and syrupy... very fresh all around, really orders of magnitude above the bottled version. 8/4/9/4/17

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2005 Strong but smooth hops initially with a balancing malt follow; not as much hops as I had expected. Alcohol is noticeable but not disconcertingly so. An excellent IPA but somewhat pricey.

Good amber orange colorsmall white creamy head that lasted for a nice long time.Malty fruity aroma with a nice hop presence,fairly sweet caramel as well.The taste is malty and light caramel then it switches to a nice semi-sweet hop taste,the alcohol does make a brief appearance in the taste but not to harshly.There is also a mild fruity taste that pops up in the beginning citrusy.The after taste is gentil and smooth with a nice hop bitterness and mild malt.This is a very nice brew and was a very nice trade to get it.Thanks Pabobcat.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2003 UPDATE:  I swear I tasted pineapple and grapefruit (much like the juice) this time.  It was prominent in the flavor and the aftertaste.  What's even weirder is that I liked it.  
9/18 - Has the fresh, clean aroma of a brewery.  The hop flavor is hearty and delicious.  I could actually feel the hop flavor dancing on my tongue well after swallowing - kinda like Indian food.  Alcohol only noticable in aftertaste and is not dominant.  A real treat for hop lovers.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: SEP 16, 2006 Way too sweet.  Not very hoppy, lots of malty sweetness.  Its got good color.  Doesnt really reveal its ABV.  But, the flavor is not very good, the mouthfeel isnt very good, its rather cloying.  They need to cut back on the malts or get a yeast that can attenuate it or do something with this.  Too sweet like all of their beers.

An excellent choice for my 100 rating.  Hazy orange color with small carbination bubbles constantly on the move.  Aroma was hoppy, but not everly so, floral and spices.  The taste was hoppy and bitter as expected, but I think I was expecting more, but thats ok with me.  Finishes with an alcohoic kick, just to let you know its there.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2005 small white fizzy head that remains only as a ring. grapefruit citrus with pretty flower/perfume taste and smell. slightly sparkling body thats a yellow/orange haze. tastes sweet, bitter, and all with alcohol. should i go on? not today. i just want to drink another. UPDATE 8/3/04: so damn smooth. the best IIPA to drink at a party. lots of alcohol to make up for the full body. UPDATE 4/29/05: snifter / tight and complex little (er, big) brew... alcohol, wood, caramel, and light citrus, floral/perfume. actually, i still like it a lot! UPDATE: mix this with Averys Maharaja!

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2004 This one was sampled from the 12 oz. bottle 10-03 batch.Smells like sweet (malt hops blend)w/ a pineapple edge.I sense the alcohol.Nice hazy looking autumn gold/decent quick fade head/some lace.Very kind and smooth strong ale(though this is the revised recipe? Still some fine sweet balanced hop nectar.More realistic than the 120(still a stellar creation!)Has some dreadnaught characteristics.(I recently aquired quite a few 750's(12-02 batch)Much different than the 12oz. version which I enjoy alot more.The yeast adds an undesirable character IMO,still very good but not nearly as good as a nice fresh bottle.I must say the head out of the 750 is awesome(belgian like)Creamy mouth,awesome mellowing effect(still bitter yet smooth)

Bottle. Rich amber color with a small head. Aroma is of powerful hoppieness with some light fruity/floral tones. Taste starts off stongly hopped but not overpowering. Some lighter citrus comes through and just a touch of balancing malt. Finish is bitter, slighly dry, and warmingly alcoholic.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2005 Bottle, basement temp: Ive had this beer many times, since it came out, but apparently Ive never rated it before. Im sure I have, but I guess I just never entered it. Anyway, the beer has a lovely amber hue and a frothy, lasting head. It just sparkles in the light. What a great-looking beer. Malts are thick with flavor: toast, some roast and some baked. Cakey and good. Hops really spice up the nose, providing a sense of "warmth." Alcohol is wholesome and friendly, like a stone fireplace in a snow-covered cabin. Wonderfully flavored, rich and balanced. One of my favs. Rerate, year-old-plus bottle: Vibrant nose. Rather vinous. Seems thicker and creamier, texture-wise. Much more complex malts, with notes of toffee, dates and caramel. Still a big bitterness, but wafty pine notes have faded. Malt lovers will like the aged version better, but hop lovers need to seek out fresh bottles. At any rate, its still REALLY good! New recipe: Seems to be much maltier, with tamer hops.

Pours a nice golden amberish color...Nice fluffy head with the cascades of hops flooding to the top of the glass.  Enticing sweet aroma, you can smell the hops calling you.  Nice floral and citrusy flavors, with almost a grapefruit aftertaste.  This is a perfect blend of bitter and sweet.  So far I haven't had anything I didn't love from Dogfish Head.
UPDATED: DEC 5, 2003 Strong Ale. Much like a barleywine. Very good, and and hoppy. If you like hops, then this is a good beer to try. Nice body and aroma.

Pours a nice vibrant orange-hued copper color
with a decent head. Good lacing as head diminshed slowly. BIG hop aroma. Very nice body. Flavor is great. Gentle but big up front hop sensation balanced by a subtle maltiness that hides in the background. Not to much lingering bitterness at the backend. Very good IPA. I highly recomend it.

I have a glass of pale golden brew, with nearly no head.  I smell flower fields smoldering.  It drinks smooth initially, but the hops sit on the back of my tongue.  Not unpleasant by any stretch, but I may have been expecting more...

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2011 Pours a slightly hazy honey color with a moderate 1-2cm white head.  Aroma is of a smoky, must odor with maybe a hint of fruits.  Start is hoppy like like an IPA should be with a smoky flavor.  This really smooths out and leaves a mild hoppy after taste.  Palate is appropriate and the 9% is spledidly hidden.  Although this has gotten a lot of rants and raves, I must admit that I was expecting more.(6/4/9/4/15)----- ounce sample on tap at Davis Beer Shoppe.  Soy sauce aroma with hints of Panda Express Orange Chicken.  This is just sweet, and annoyingly cloying.  Transparent orange body with a medium white head and decent lacing.  Starts with a ton of orangey hop character.  Becomes fruity and medicinal.  Malt character is roasted and a bit burnt.  Finishes with sweet, sugary, and sticky flavors.  A bit boozy, and unimpressive.
Awesome character full of hops. Similar to the 60 minute but seems to be a bit sweeter actually. The malts really do a fine job of balancing out this beer. Bring on the 120 minute...

Bottled 05-03. Where can I begin? This ale don got no stinkin' hops! A fresh '97 Sierra Nevada Celebration or Bigfoot (ever see a golden retriever shake its head to dry off? Same thing with me, first sip of either 2!); or a  (yeah this ain't no forum) a '97 Brooklyn East India Pale Ale now those ales had hops (What was it about '97??)! This one wasn't even as hoppy as fresh Anchor Liberty, but there was a bit of Cascade presence, followed by lovely malts (don't know malts... yet). Did I mention that the alcohol was completley hidden?

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2003 Tasted in DC from Cairo. Oh sweet mother of Jesus.  I am tasting this after trying the World Wide stout.  And the bottle is a 750ml.   Woooooo.   Absolutely beautiful massive hopped taste.  Magnificant. Nasty, dirty, lovely.  This is what I am looking for.  My search has come to an end.  I am a hop head.  Orange brown colour.  Big beautiful white head.  Scent is one thing only - hops.  Massive.  Great.  Hops forever.

Bottled: Clear dark golden coloured. Off white frothy medium lasting head. Very hoppy aroma. Fruit accents. Flavour is dominated by the hops. Wellbalanced. Starts mellowed but explodes in a acrid bitterness on the palate. This bitteness grows as the beer warms up, and sit on your palate for quite a long time. Nice. Have tried several of these imperial IPA's and kind of like them, but find it hard to find distinct differences in the samples. Thanks to Raindog for this.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2013 This is the beer that led me to this site.  I found the bottle with the guy nailing himself, it looked interesting, I took it home and drank it.  I was impressed, so I went to the website, found a link to here, all downhill ever since.  This is a rating of the 12 oz. bottle.  Nice aroma, hoppy, faintly of violets.  Appropriate deep gold color, nice head, good lacing, clear.  Taste is hoppy, with just enough malt to balance it out.  The alcohol is totally masked, well done.  A highly commendable beer.  RERATE  Almost 10 years later, actually hard to believe it has been that long.  Draft at Aw Shucks, kicked the keg when they filled my growler.  A touch more toward orange than gold in my opinion now.  Aroma tends towards earthy and pine hops.  Flavor matches.  Good toasty, slight caramel malt backbone.  The malt backbone probably impresses me more these days than the hops, which now strike me as a touch on the rough side.  Probably old school high co-humulone hops as opposed to the smoother varieties you get these days.  Alcohol is just a touch apparent now.  Wont change the rating, just too much nostalgia here, but if I were totally honest, it would probably drop to around a 4.
Nice copper/amber color with a thin off-white head. Tons of hops, but kept in balance, not too overpowering. Nice masking of the 9% abv. A great IPA.
Clear amber color with thin head.Hoppy aroma with some floral notes.Very smooth for the ABV.The best well balanced IPA I have ever had.Finishes with a solid warming feel.

Much more enjoyable than the 60!  Light gold.  Medium head with a nice lacing.  Strong hop aroma.  Perfect hop blend with an interesting malt finish.  Alcohol notes are not overly strong.  Clean and dry.

Lemon, citrus hoppy aroma. Soft and pleasing. Pours golden brown, thin white head. Very smooth. Pleasant sweet aftertaste. Hop bite but not as hoppy as expected. A smooth and tasty beer, much better than the 60 min.

This is my first rating, I think I picked a good one to be my first. 

Bottle.  This is a hophead's wet dream. Intense floral hop start, then a nice bitterness that stays constant during the the sweet maltiness afterwards and a warmness at the end. Thick and sticky. Just keeps getting better and better as it warms and as you have more of them.
I have just started the rating process. To date the Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA is the best beer I have tasted.
Very clear golden orange color. Smells of floral and fruity hops. Hides the 9% abv, very well. Has much more malt balance than I expected. Very good.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2010 Really dropped over the years, or perhaps I have, for some reason I can no longer find this beer as I once remembered it.
Sampled July 2004
A nice strong citrus & pine aroma wafts to my nose as I pour this beer.  It pours a deep copper color and is quite clear.  The head is quite large and it a tan color.  As I take a couple of sniffs I get a strong note of candied orange peel, lychee, grapefruit, apricot, and some pine needles.  The taste tells me that thankfully this is a fresh bottle.  The taste is sweet up front, and is pretty much all hops.  The beer is much less hoppy than your typical west coast hop monster.  Never-the-less this is quite hoppy, with a candied fruitiness in the mouth.  The finish has a hint of harshness from the mixture of alcohol and hops, a sort of raw hop type astringency that clings to my mouth in the finish.  I really like the front half of this beer, it is like sucking on a candied hop lollipop.  This is quite tasty, yet is still missing that certain something to really make this great.

Sampled August 2003
Pours brilliantly clear.  This beer is an amber color with a pale tan head.  The aroma is of American hops; floral and grapefruity.  It smells a bit sweet as well.  It tastes citrusy with a  sweet maltiness to it.  Finished by a solid bitterness.  This beer tastes strong with a bit of alcohol in the finish. There seems to be something missing to make this a great beer, nothing wrong with it, just seems to be missing something that could push it over the edge.

Big hop aroma.  Fairly dark amber color for a pale ale, with a nice head.  It took me a few sips to get into this, but it's very good.  A big hop finish which is balanced by the malts.  9% abv, you would never guess.  Still, this is a big beer that takes some getting used to.  But when you get used to it, boy, is it good.

Aroma...aroma...aroma...aroma.....
Bitter....bitt  but, after the initial assault, the flavor settles down on your tongue like a chatty rapist...asking you if you liked the ordeal....strangely...I did...a lot!

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2003 [Updates 10/10/2003] Hazy orange color. Moderate malt aromas, bready with hop citrusy/fruity notes. Frothy off-white head with good lacing. Looks very appealing. Very bitter but malt-presence is substantial. Big creamy/syrupy body. Alcohol bite at the end.  Lies just about 1/2 between the 60 and the 120 minute IPAs.

(bottle conditioned about a year old).  Beautiful orange color, almost brilliantly bright.  Pronounced malty nose with great citrus (Amarillo adds a hint of tangerine?) & woody hop aromas.  Mouthfeel is big with great malty smoothness and fantastic lingering bitterness.  Complex, big malty beer with a lingering citrus finish and a little spicy alcohol to boot.  Very nice!

Nice hazy gold, with floral hop aroma. Head presented well, and lasted. Incredible mouthfeel! Very smooth. Initial hop bitterness complemented by citrus sweetish finish. The underlying maltiness makes this IPA really unique. Overall, an outstanding India Pale Ale.

Very faintly hazy pale amber under a huge size medium lasting faint yellow white  head. Awesome perfumed floral hops with faint hints of citrus and bready yeast. Medium thin body. Strong to fierce hoppy bitter start. Flavours are mainly bitter hops but includes those hints of something floral and malty sweetness.  Superbly masked alcohol by very high but not unpleasant hop bitterness except perhaps the extreme biting bitter finish and aftertaste maybe detracts from what is otherwise a lovely IPA
Citrusy hop aroma on a nice amber beer.  A nice sharp hop flavor, with an almost candy like sweetness.  This is a freakin' good IPA.
pours a golden amber, with a nice white head. hop flavor in the nose. flavor is hoppy, citrusy and a little spicy. gets bigger and better as it warms. an excellent ipa

Sharp initial shot of hop citrus in the aroma followed by a touch of caramel. Surprising initial toffee/caramel sweetness on the palate, moderately carbonated, infact pretty smooth. Hops are certainly bitter in the finish but are kept in check by the initial sweetness and light toffee aftertaste. What's more overwhelming is the rush of hops up the nose with every sip.

A hazy golden color with little head.  The best part of this beer is the aroma, different then any beer and more complex then any american beer.  This is the best aroma of any american beer.  Bitter kick at the end of the sip with a light-medium body.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: A hophead's delight!Pours with a short-lived white head, copper body.  The hop presence was great, but what really set this one apart from other IPAs was the great malt background.

This is so much better than the 60 minute, oh and by the way, I am so bummed that I didn't get the bottle with the dude tapping himself the nose with a hammer.  As for the rating, the aroma is excellent, hops, hops, and more hops.  This is the kinda of IPA we hopheads look for, it has layer upon glorius layer of hops.  It is magnificant to behold when you hold in your hand a beer that presents layer after layer of what really gets you going, the hop flower.

incrediable smooth for an ipa.  the hops are flavorful without being oppressive. i didn't really get much of an aroma, but that's probably because i inhaled some of the head trying to find it... dogfish continues to be the ipa king (for ipa haters)

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2007 What got me when I was drinking this one was how well integrated the malt, hops and alcohol were.  It was hard to tell it had 9% abv.  Nice resiny hop taste, refreshing bitterness, a big, big IPA.  The carbonation on mine was much less than in the 60, a bit flat for my taste.  Some of the estery aroma from high gravity brewing lets you this one will pack a punch, but the balance is superb.  The 60 is a more refreshing choice ... sacrilege but I mix the two.

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a red-orange golden with little, slightly off-white head quickly disapating to nothing.  Aroma of cherry-alcohol-citrus-pear.  Flavor of... strong hops, dry.  Hops are an undesireable characteristic IMO.  Hops are best described as drinking concentrated soapy water - not good.  This is a drainpour.  But if you are into hops, this is probably your beer.  No good for hop-haters.  Sampled at 73 degrees Fahrenheit.
A Unique IPA (like most of Dogfish Head's beers)  Floral, citrusy nose with a Piney deeply bitter  finish. Good IPA, A bit unbalanced (actually a lot)

12 oz. bottle, packaged in "5", which I assume to be may 2003....Damn, this is round and danerous stuff, I've had the corked (bottle conditioned?) 750 of this as well, but I think this particular bottle is the best I've had of this beer. Great full mouth-feel, combined with a smooth and rich tropical fruit flavor with very prominent(yet fully integrated) bitterness I'm not going to get any more "flowery" than that, I'll just own up to this being an ass-kicking apertif that you really should nail at some point if you consider yourself a SERIOUS beer rater.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2005 Rerate:   Have you ever Had this beer on Draft... WOW!!!  - Talk about a beer style that has grown on me, Imperial IPA! Large notes of caramel and apple, but mainly a citric grapefruit / cumquat portrait. Also, long notes of pinesap and a touch of smoky molasses. A Very tasty I-IPA, I will certainly be drinking more of this being that we just got distribution here in Florida.     7/13/2003For my 100th rating I chose a beer that I am unable to find in Florida, if it were not for a beer trade with a first rate beer enthusiast from Philadelphia, Dberger624. ** The Dogfish Head 90 min is a unique IPA. I am drinking a 12oz bottle, which must not be bottle conditioned like I thought it would be. However, I must say that its still an almost flawless representation of my ideal IPA; Complex, but not over the top in any particular manner. == Yet with the number of ratings that this beer already has, I will not get into great description of this beers characteristics.=  I will say that this 90 min in particular had a very small head but a majestic rusty amber color. The aroma is citric and sweet, but the flavor is mysteriously smoky, malty, and spicy with a dry bitter finish. This is an excellent beer by anyones standards, but it was not as interesting an experience as I had anticipated it being. This 90 min would be a wonderful beer to have on a regular basis, but for me it was no endorphin rush.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2004 Copper hue with a small solid white head and some lacing. Very piney, woody, earthy, smoky aroma. Hint of vanilla and fruit. Aggressive bitter hop taste initially, smoothed out after a bit with the presence of alcohol and grain. Lingering pine aftertaste. Mouthfeel was surprisingly smooth and syrupy. Medium to full-bodied.

Compared this side-by-side with the 60 Minute IPA.  The 90 was a little darker and clearer than the 60.  The nose is less malty and more hoppy and citrusy.  While the hops dominate, the malts and barley are quite evident, especially as it warms.  The sweetness seems to increase as well.  More complex than the 60, with a better finish and aftertaste.  Both are head and shoulders above many other IPA's.

Excessively thick head with a bronze body with a wonderful, refreshing hop aroma that had a touch or saly sea air. The flavor was similarly hoppy and the seaside touch remained. Decent fruity profile. A nice IPA that is neither boring, nor mind blowing.

a smokey, piney aroma, a beautiful copper color with no head at all, the hops are very potent - but they seem to balance each other out, my mouth almost feels like it is in a forest when i am drinking this, besides the hops doing a balancing act - there is no one else working there - no malt flavor or yeast - just hops, leaves a coating of hop flavor madness on the tongue, but there is one thing this beer has and it is a perfectly hidden alcohol content

Beautiful orangy color with a somewhat smoky aroma.  Earthy tones in the flavor which masks the strong alcholic content.  Great stuff!  heh a good weekend for IPAs for me, with the Three Floyds Dreadnaught and this.

I have found my new favorite beer.  Orange with a white foamy head.  Very well balanced between malt and hops.  Nothing is overbearing, but it's still a large beer.  Also, there's none of the harshness that I found in 60-minute.  Smooth and good.  This is how IPA should be.
I didn't like this.  No sir.  Way too much hops.  I couldn't even clear my palette afterwards and it ruined my next beer.

Color is a solid cloud of orangy amber with a big fluffy ivory colored head that grew to be just over two fingers high of impressive strength, but was fast to crumble and pop down to a hazy mist over the top. Leaves incredible stringy lace in drippy rings. Smell is all peachy, a bit citrusy and a piney/woodish backing, somewhat earthy, soft but nice and rich of hops galore. Taste is wildly smooth and soothing of peachy/citrus hops, one hell of a nice bittering effect thats very calm and easy. Some light earthy tones dotted in the mix with a blend of well balanced malts, gotta keep those hops in check, I suppose. Feel is full and quite bittering in a mild sense, in which it doesn't linger to much to be over the top in any way. This is quite excellent stuff, I don't care that its 9%, which is masked beautifully by the way, its way to damn easy to drink, which makes for a short evening.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2009 Poured a dark orange color with not much head.  Aroma was very sweet, almost like bubblegum.  Had this on tap this weekend and in the nose I also noticed a rose petal and very skunky herb aroma.  Its taste was initial hops followed by a very sweet finish.  Also tastes like eating marijuana nuggets while drinking this.
Great Beer, the best American IPA I have had. A big beer, but the high alohol content did not overwhelm the beer.

nice slightly hazy amber colour.  citrusy hop nose with a piney herbal hint.  good coating slightly syrupy mouthfeel.  big citrus hop flavours with wood, malt and a hint of alcohol.  a nice big beer to be sure, but it didn't impress me as much as the 60.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2003 deprogram and i picked up a 1/6 barrel for a moving party we had last night. not too sure if this is a great drunken backyard beer, as a number got spilled, and it was such a waste! however, i enjoyed it, nonetheless. thanks bob (and john) for your help
very foamy head due to pouring from the keg with a pump tap, this was convenient because the bugs would just walk across the beer, making them very easy to remove :]
otherwise, i stand behind everything i said before [read on]

nice frothy, cream-colored head when poured from the 12 ounce bottle i had the good fortune to obtain (after much prompting from my favorite salesman at the local beer store). the 90 minute ipa is a medium bodied, crisp beer with a bitter, hoppy overwhelmingly great taste, that has the good sense to leave you with litte to no aftertaste. the head, while frothy to begin with, widdled its way down to very little in no time at all. however, the tiny foam bubbles cling to the side of the glass, leaving a small sticky mess for those unfortunate enough not to have a dishwasher.
side note: i really need to learn more about beer, so i can sound snobby in my reviews and talk more about the actual taste and nose of the beer, rather than just the way it looks...
favorate beer in favorate category,  for such a hopped up special the malt balance at the start holds it's own.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2005 750ml Corked Bottle and Re-Rate 11/30/03
Nice pour, hazy orange hued with a nice thick head. Head dies down some but retains well and completely laces glass. Nice big hop aroma with notes of citrus, especially grapefruit. Has a smooth body and overall pleasant mouthfeel. Flavor is classic IPA, good hop flavor, citrusy and bitter. Alcohol is well hidden and maybe better than most others in the style. This is a fantastic Imperial IPA, not as bold as Dreadnaught and some others, but a really nice one overall. Thanks CaptainCougar for the bottle.
 Rerate: a 12oz bottle on 3/17/04Poured a crystal clear copper/gold color with a huge frothy head that lasts. Nice retention. Big hoppy nose that is sweet and fruity with some graininess from the malt. Body is really smooth and full with a nice carbonation level. Flavor is super hoppy with tropical fruit all over the place. Bitter finish but nothing that will knock you down. Hard to say wich was better, the 750 or this fresh 12oz. Both very good. I may give the edge to the 12oz.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Tan head. Hazy orange color. Good american hop nose. Full bodied brew. Foam clinging to the sides of my glass sticking around as i consume it. Good mouthfeel, pleasent carbonation. Mellow, piney, citrusy hop flavors. Alc. shows its self gently also.The alcohol seems to add to the just right hop flavors. A maltiness is also perceived in the finish. Personally, it blows the 60 and 120 minute IPAs away.
UPDATED: JUL 9, 2008 A beautiful beer. One of the finest I have ever had. An orange color with fluffy off white head. Big bold hop flavor with citrus and a little sweetness. I love it. Awesome!!
Hazy orange with ample white head. Citrusy, and floral hop scents abound. Very hoppy flavor, but had some nice malt characteristics to back it up.
Dark Golden color.  Small head.  Nice Cascade head.  I was very impressed with how balanced this beer is.  This very well may be the finest beer I've tasted!

Pours a beautiful golden deep amber, a steady stream of bubbles rise up the center forever. The head lands thick, creamy lacey, and creates a thin layer that keeps going and going. Man, I wish I had a picture of this, it's making me drool just looking at it. Big hop aroma, of course, but not as strong as I expected. There is a big, nutty, almond malt type color in the nose too. Starts off a bit on the citrus side, more like sweet oranges with the peels thrown in, rather than a tart grapefruit. A little on the roasty edge going out, there is so much sweetness in here that the bitter finish takes quite a while to come through. This is a very unique Imperial IPA. I think the sweetness may be a little be to much of an overcompensation for my own tastes, but wow, what a beer.
UPDATED: MAY 30, 2003 Great label on the bottle.  A big hoppy aroma.  Big, big head.  Deep dark flaxen color.  Very bitter and malty flavor.

This is my favorite IPA. A bit pricey, but worth the bux. I really enjoy a hoppy beer, and this one strikes just the right balance for me between hop & sweet. My second favorite DFH behind World Wide Stout.

Orangy body with little in the way of head. Srong spicy fruity notes in nose. Good lacing but little head retention. Initial taste is slightly sweet then hop bitterness takes over with a vengeance. Bittnerness lasts long into aftertaste. A hoppy bonanza!

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2003 Re-rated: The rating given previously was really good.  I'm not sure whether my taste buds have changed or the ingrediants in the beer, but it seems to have an strange flavor or should I say off-flavor.  My previous rating was from a big bottle while the most recent tasting was in the 12 ouncers.  It still has a good malt backround and nice mouthfeel with a nicing warming from the alcohol.  Anymore when I drink it I notice a cardboard/oxidation flavor to it.  Its even in the aroma.  I'm not sure whether it's the hops used but I find a similar thing in the 60 minute.  It shys me away now.

The west coast IPAs have a serious IPA competitor on there hands!  After trying just about all the great IPA's out there, Dogfish Head Brewery may very well have the best.  This beer has ridicules amounts of hops, but very tasty.  If you like this one, try the 60 minute and 120 minute IPA's.
Holy hop overdose. Gimme more. If you like hops (lots and lots of 'em) you've come to the right place. Perhaps a little too much alcohol, but oh, those hops!

This beer pours a cloudy and pale orange color.  It has a moderate head and the aroma is very earthy and hoppy.  The taste was very odd.  If you've had the 60 minute IPA, this is very similar, just stronger tasting.  The taste was very much like the aroma - very hoppy and earthy.  I'm not sure what exactly it tastes like, but I'm not a fan of it.  It says that this was voted one of the best American beers recently, but I did not enjoy it much.

Deep clear amber w/ a just off white head that didn't stick around long.  Very, very, citrusy and piney hops aromas w/a hint of Catawba grape fruitiness.  Also has a little caramel maltiness.  Hops dominate the flavor with pine and citrus but overall well balanced with malt and a restrained caramel flavor and very little fruitiness.  Finishes decidedly bitter, but not harsh.  Moderate carbonation and warming full mouthfeel is very smooth.  I'm not a hop head but this is very refreshing for a bigger beer.

This beer was sensational, the Dogfish Head beers are my first introduction to real beer from the US. This had a great malty nose and a palate that has a huge punch of flavour with a sweet liqourness to it. I dig this beer!

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2003 Hoppy, hoppy, hop to the hoppy!  I was actually surprised at how nicely this brew was balanced...what could have been a hopfest was actually a malt/hop consilience of sorts.  Strong, crisp hops define the palate, and leave a nice aftertaste.  I agree with previous reviewers that the alcohol is well-hidden.  A quality brew.  Hopefully I will get a chance to try the 120-minute IPA.  Update 6/29/03: after sipping several 12-ounce bottles, I have to bump up the flavor and overall ratings.  I love this IPA.

Wow, floral bouquet slams you in the nose as you pop the cork.  Huge white frothy head which lasts for quite a while.  Hoppy aroma but not overpoweringly strong with some citrus.  I actually expected more in the aroma.  Color of clear, golden orange.  Flavor is slightly sour (don't know if this is expected) with more citrus presence.  Very smooth drinking.  Finish is bitter with a hops kick and very smooth.  Hides its alcohol very well.  A very good beer that is loaded with hops but not to overpowering.  A brew for anyone who likes bitter and hoppy style ales.

very good, deep golden color with a white head.  Had a strong hoppy taste with a nice malty balance.  Not a strong alcohol taste. For an IPA i found it to be heavy on the stomach.  I also noted the aftertaste lingered for sometime after i took a sip.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2006 Light orange/amber color with big fluffy off white head that leaves lots of lacing. Aroma has lots of sharp, catty american hops (chinook?), with hints of apricot, caramel, and lemon. Flavor is rather malty upfront, with caramel and vanilla, followed by citrusy american hops and a hint of wood. Finish is acidic and mildly bitter, with just the faintest metallic note at the conclusion.

Hmmm, where to start? Serving size : 25 oz. cork capped bottle. No best before date that I can see. Pours out a deep golden
color, with over-flowing head. I had to actually use a spoon and take some of the head out, because I couldn't smell the beer
itself. Sweet aromas of fresh cut hay, malts, and hops. Nice smooth caramel taste up front, with a smooth maltiness in the
middle, followed by a subdued hops bite at the end. Very floral in it's aromas as it warms up. Hints of citrus and spices in the
nose. Well balanced mix of malts and hops on the tongue. It has a pleasant aftertaste, and hides it's 9% ABV very well. You
don't even notice it, until your stomach starts getting rather warm. My first Dogfish beer, and not a let down, either. Let's all go
fishing, gang.
Amber, nice long lasting head. Aroma has floral notes.  Mildly sweet; hop profile is strong but not harsh at all. In some ways a simple beer but a big one at the same time.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2003 Wonderful shade of bronze with a light tan head. The scent reveals a full bouquet of hops! Surprisingly sweet tasting considering the amount of hops in the beer. Like a lighter version of Stone's Ruination IPA. Finishes well with a slight lingering hop bitterness on the palate. Recommended. Can't wait for the 120 Minute IPA.

Intense hops bitterness in the aroma...nice sweet character to it, but really it was just all hops. The flavor was much of the same...sweet, citrusy, floral hops character that drowned out anything else that could have been going on. The bottle shows a man hammering a nail into his nose. That's exactly what this beer feels like...hammering in the hops.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2005 .Beautiful amber body, white lacy head.  Nice hoppy aroma, but not overpowering.  Big hoppy flavor balanced by some malt.  Smooth, dry mouthfeel and a bitter, lasting finish.  This is an amazing beer for a hop junkie like myself.  My first perfect score after 85 beers.  Re-rate: Unfurtunately, the switch to 12oz bottles and an apparent recipe change has left this beer a shadow of its former self.  Much of the hop profile that made it so unique is gone, and left it simply an average IIPA.
