UPDATED: APR 22, 2003 Strong citrus/grapefruit aroma, even through sizeable thick frothy off-white head. Flavor includes strong fruit aspect. Extremely strong flavor. Surprisingly rich from the maltiness, with lingering pleasant bitter aftertaste.
Outstanding. Nice pale gold color with a white head. Very hopped with as you'd expect, but very nicely balanced by malt. Nice citrus notes. A big beer.

Kind of an IPA/Barleywine.  Aroma is IPA all the way - fresh citrusy American hops.  The flavor was barleywine-esque - rich malt intermingled with spicy hops, the way a well-aged barleywine has that smooth blended flavor.  There were also notes of fruit and citrus in the flavor.  Appearance was dead-on, and the mouthfeel was full with a littel warming from the alcohol.  I'm kind of a puriost when it comes to IPAs, but this was pretty darn good.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2004 If you are a fan of IPA's, then this is the beer for you. Very citrus aroma, and taste. Reminded me of grapefruit. Alcohol is well hidden. Nice golden color. This drinks very easily, almost too easy for the 9% alcohol!!
Update, 4/16/04: I just tried a 750ml bottle that had aged a year. Although it's still good, it doesn't pack a punch anymore. Drink this beer fresh!!
on tap. beautiful aroma, flowery, pine and citrus. quite a bit of hops here. well balanced, somewhat bitter and dry finish. easy to forget how much alcohol is in this stuff. great beer.

Concur with bro on the ABV....I liked this because it was very west coast with the hops, but it came with a nice, smooth malty sweetness that made it worthy of top 50 status on this site.  This is not your father's west coast IPA!  Chaz was suggesting that they come out with a 24 hour IPA...classic!
Bottle.  Pale but N-I-C-E=H-E-A-D.  Tastes like hops in a blender!  Like a west coast IPA but cleaner and more alcoholic; I don't know how they snuck in 9%.  Excellent.

(1 pint 9.6 ounces bottle) Another exciting beer sent from my new friend CiderGuy! Pours a thin, white head and an orange, cloudy body. Mild golding hops, mellow malt and ever so slight cloves. Great flavour - Enough hops to knock you on your ass! Thick fluidity filled with a caramel, malt, raisin and citrus. Calming bitterness finish. Absolutely mesmerizing IPA.

Holy moley!!! This is a great beer. Yeah Dogfish. What a great hoppy flavor. Nice tartness and an aroma to match. Great smooth flavorful aftertaste. If this beer was dry hopped for 90 minutes I can't wait to try the 120 min IPA.
Cheers Delaware

Glowing orange/copper w/ big, creamy light beige head. Fresh, floral & citrusy nose w/ malt (caramel) & spice in the background. Thick, resiny feel. Sweet malt (honey, caramel) at first giving way to a big, very long, very bitter, citrusy/grapefruity finish. Alcohol comes through late in the finish as well.

Nose is caramelly, subtle hoppiness, slight fruitiness---nice...Color is a glowing hazy bronze/copper---head is a bit thin with light speckled lace, but color wins out here...Flavors are a successful marriage of sweet malts that meld seamlessly with hops that are at once floral and well-bittered---this fine balance carries over to the dry finish...This has substantial mouthfeel, aided by the light carbonation that allows the flavors to stand on their own---smoothness belies this brew's potency...Overall, this has excellent balance and is both rich and mouth-puckeringly dry--a delight for the palate!  The 750ml bottle also produces a most satisfactory buzz...
UPDATED: MAR 22, 2003 Copper colored with a  creamy beige head. Mild hop aroma. Malt and hop flavor. Long bitter finish. I think this is not hoppy enough.
Facinatingly strong, wonderfully balanced IPA beer.  Good color, nice hop aroma.  Strong beer, but not terribly alcoholic tasting.  Just a good strong beer.

Pours a cloudy amber with a thin white head. Aroma is fruity, citrusy, and hoppy. When it hits your tounge it is pure bliss. Malty, fruity, citrusy mouthfeel, with a sour and bitter finish. This beer makes me proud to live so close to Lewes.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2003 Okay, now it's hoppy as shit but amazingly enough it's not bitter. God I love that hop flavor when it's not masked by overly high IBUs. Well done.  3/12/03 - 3.6: Yeah so my roomates tell me that this bottle I am drinking is a bit off the beaten path from the bottles they have had so far. Considering this is the result of intense hopping I expected something a bit more, well...hoppy. Now, the rediculous amounts of barley malt are most definitely coming through - like a big thick malt bomb amidst a light disapating vapor of floral hops. Damn I'm poetic. Very well rounded, lots of flavor and the label is awesome (is that a real picture!?!). I plan on buying another bottle of this real soon (only $6.50 for the liter at Red Apple) so I'll bump up the rating if needed...so I don't want any nasty messages from people who baptize their children in the shit.

Pours into the glass with an amber gold body topped by a medium thick white sustaining head with great lace left behind.  Sweet and citrusy (grapefruit) hop aroma with some tropical fruit notes.  Incredible aroma.  Sweet and citrusy (grapefruit) hop flavor well balanced with maltiness.  The finish is strongly bitter and hoppy.  Best IPA I've had to date.  I expected a strong alcohol presence, but it wasn't there.  Medium bodied, remarkably smooth and slightly dry.
Beautiful ice cream soda like head, smell the cascade hops overwelms as it reaches your lips! The bitterness stays until it burns out down the back of your throat! I like it!!
This was a real treat! This is my first IPA and it really caught my attention. Nice hoppy/fruity smell with bittery taste but not overwhelming. Alcohol not very noticeable. Excellent brew.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2003 From the bottle. Honey piney nose. Nice amber color. Rich mix of hops and malt, kinda creamy. Thick and bitter with a slight drop off during the finish. I call it a Hopwine.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 5, 2003 The first thing I thought of when I drank this was Double bastard.  Beautiful amber color with a small amount of white head.  Smell jumps out with citrus from the massive amount of hops.  This nice crisp blend realy gives this beer a nice sharp texture.  With the large amount of malt the hops don't just jump out at you, they settle into your palate and stay there long after you've had a drink.  Very good beer for a strong mouth, something not to be taken lightly.

This hop-a-licious brew delivers a smart blend of malt and bitterness that curtains the 9% ABV.  This beer is craved often as its flavor represents a fusion of what I enjoy in American Ales.  A must try for those who haven't.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2005 ReRate 2-nov 2004 12oz bottle-pours a light orange hue with no floaties or anything like that.  decent white head.  aroma of apricots, peach, pineapple sweetness, green apples and lots of residual malt sweetness.  sweet malty flavors with some twangy citric hops.  lots of apricot and pineapple in the flavors along with some cantelope notes.  The malt sugars are just to detracting for me to really get into this beer.  Im sorry, this beer is over-rated!  i will say that the palate is very good-no trace of alcohol anyplace!
ReRate-12oz bottle-bottled in september 2003-sampled 1/27/04. pours a deep orange color with long lasting big bubble head.  Aroma of sweet/sour apples/cherries thats very different from most IMP IPAs.  Must have something to do with the english malts and the high alpha acid hops.  Strange palate-full of cherries and somewhat like a belgian beer IMO.  Very sweet, almost detracting.  Apricots?  Did i get a bottle of Aprihop?  Well balanced, but definately a twist on the IMP IPA style.
Cask at RAF 2/28/03
hmm, somethimg may have been off on this cask because this beer definately didnt have the hop kick i was planning on.  No malt to speak of in the palate either-very one dimensional.  Did anybody else sample this and think that the cask was off?

solid bitterness - but actually much mellower than I expected - you won't pucker.  perfectly balanced body - malt, hops and alchohol all present and welcome.  more copper in color than pale.  nice floral nose - but again the hops are more mellow than I would've thunk considering the label.  ipa meets barley wine - excellent.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2006 A hazy orange color with a creamy white lasting head.  A crisp hop/ orange aroma.  Pleasant hop taste and bitterness without being overpowering.  A very tasty, mouthwatering beer.  Not a hint of the 9% in aroma or taste.  Excellent beer.
note: rating of 750 ml bottle.

This beer is awesome.  The malt is wonderful as it's full flavored, rich, and sweet.  The beer is warm, very pleasantly hopped, finishes very smoothly, with a nice lingering hop flavor.  Outstanding brew.

Copper with some cloudeness. Sweet malty taste with strong bitter undertones. The taste is just outstanding. One of the best IPA's to date. If you get a chance, please try this. Dogfish head continues to suceeed.

Very hoppy.  It's a pretty good beer.  Very bitter, with some sweet pale maltiness, but I found it unbalanced.  Instead of wowing us with tons of hops, toning it down with extra malty esters and sweetness would help.
YUM.  Very close to the Three Floyd's Dreadnaught.  A very serious, BIG IPA.  Awesome.

Poured a mostly clear light amber/golden orange color with a huge, thick white head. Powerful fruity floral hop aroma. Quite expressive. Lots of hop flavor up front with a nice balance of malts. The hops came through with a strong bitterness in the aftertaste. Smooth taste with a medium mouthfull and resiny creaminess. Quite enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2006 This beer begins with a big, citrus aroma and nice color. The head is creamy and rich and the flavor is full, bold, and delicious. This is, in every way, a BIG beer. Its not hiding anything, and doesnt need to. Superb!

RETASTE: Tried it on tap, which really added a nice mellowness to this brew.  Almost a creamy IPA, and delicious.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2010 Cloudy golden. Thick wonderful head. Tons of lace that sticks in sheets to the side of the glass. Perfectly bitter. Hoppy grapefruit aroma. Smooth mouthfeel punctuated by carbonation. Strong malt backbone supports floral, pine, and citrus flavors from the hops. A beautiful, beautiful beer.
UPDATED: OCT 31, 2004 This is a really good IPA.  90 min. IPA is spicy, hoppy, and bitter flavor.  Also the 9% ABV. is well hidden.  It finishes clean smooth and slightly bitter.

The label grabbed me and the beer hooked me.  The hops are huge and forward but in no way overbearing.  Finish is clean and not too sharp as some pales can be.  I love this one but the price is going crazy in our area!?!?!

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2003 750 ml bottle-conditioned (8 months old): Amber with a full creamy off white head.  Wonderfully frothy sweet orange juice. . . Beautiful flowers and soft citrus fruits, I was expecting this one to be way over the top (overhopped and too much bitter), but I was surprised at the softness, sweetness and complexity of this rare gem.  AMAZING.
12 oz. non-conditioned: Bright yellow orange with the same full, creamy, rocky off white head. . . aroma has more grapefruit and citrus rind characteristics and not as much pulpiness.  Palate is a bit more bitter, but has the same great complexities in the sweet, soft malt and fruit.  Note:  Numbers are for the 750 ml bottle, though I would only lower the flavour and overall one point each for the 12 oz bottle.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2003  Poured a deep straw color.  Thin to medium head, medium body.  Smells great, kinda citrusy, definitely hoppy.  Tastes very good, sweet and tangy, with a dry, bitter finish.  Alcohol not too apparent.  Very good.  Thanks to dberger624 on this one.

This beer poured a dark gold color and formed a nice foamy off white head that held and left some nice circular lace as it slowly subsided. A good deal of carbonation is present. An aroma of hops and a touch of citrus. A flavor of hops with some sweetness present. Also some of the alcohol is present. A touch astrigent in the finish with some bitterness. The sweetness of this one is offset by the presence of the alcohol. While not one of the hoppier IPAs, it is good and doesn't get offset to much with the sweetness. A good IPA.

This one pours a clear, deep copper color with a medium sized white head. The aroma is very attractive, floral hops and a nice fruity sweetness. Full bodied and very smooth, the hops dominate at first, but the malty sweetness comes through in the end. It is really not very bitter, the finish is long, starts out with a slight bitterness, but ends with a strong sweetness and a slight hint of alcohol.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2006 Classic. This beer is so near perfection it"s amazing. A drinkable and approachable IPA, unlike other ruinous IPA"s that take some nuts to drink. Sweeter that any other IPA I"ve had. Why is this called a strong ale when the bottle says IPA? GREAT beer!
ReRate: Doesnt quite have the subtlety I used to enjoy. A little agressive on the alcohol, not as balanced.
This is a great beer. Has an enormous hoppy aroma, with a certain sweetness to it.  Golden copper color, with a small head. Carbonation is a little high, but it fits the hoppy flavor.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2003 1/15/03 (750ml corked bottle) (8,4,8,4,16) Big hop aroma with some malt and butterscotch.  Caramel color with little head.  Moderately complex with a woody, bitter finish.  Hides its alcohol very well, but doesn't quite match the Dreadnaught in complexity and smoothness.
Re-rate 7/12/03 & 11/2/03 (12 oz bottle) (8,4,9,4,17)  The smaller bottle is not only easier to open, but tastes better IMO.  Lots of fresh hops abound and plenty of sweet caramely malt to back them up.  Very smooth and crisp.  Lightly syrupy mouthfeel holds a good amount of complexity.  A great imperial IPA.
Being a hophead this was a truely a wonderful IPA. Pours an orangish color with a good amount of head. Can smell hops from 3 feet away. This brew is all about the hops. Recommend.

#200, Popped the cork and was overcome by a huge citrus and grapefruit aroma, poured a copperish-orang with a huge slowly disappearing head, that left lacing all over the glass.  Initial taste was a blast of grapefruit, with other citrus and pine flavors jumping in, then it becomes nicely balanced with a nice touch of caramel malt, alcohol is well hidden. An excellent beer

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2003 Capped 12 ounce bottle:
Copper colour with orange highlights and a dense tan head. Aroma (very potent) of hazlenuts, hops, oak, strong malt and alcohol. Heavy-bodied; Sweet initial flavour then melds to a hoppy kick with oak and tannins. Aftertaste bittering from the hops-but well balanced. Overall, decent-but I  really prefered this in the 75 cL bottle. I didn't really care for this one too much-just another Imperial IPA. Score for this rating: 6,5,6,3,12. 

Cork Finished 75 cL bottle:
Great overall IPA, good hops, but an overpowering oaky taste. Cork was almost impossible to open on the first bottle--a lot easier the second time around, but insanely difficult on the third bottle! Score for this rating: 8,4,7,3,15.

Floral earthy hops and a smal oily head and a weak tea color.  Grapefruit citrus, and resinous earthy hops.  Almost perfumey and floral.  Biscuty malts come through to give support.  Not as bitter as expected, medium hops in the finish with sweet malts.

Had this in a BIG bottle.  A grapefruit orchard bursts out of the bottle right behind the cork.  As the brew breathes it settles down and perfume, flowers, toasted malt, alcohol and the slightest hint of spiced dried fruit replaces the citrus.  The brew pours a cloudy medium honey amber.  The large bone colored creamy/rocky head is fully lasting with stellar lacing.  I could substitute this head for my edge gel next time I shave.  The flavor is colossal.  Everyone showed up for class today: sweetness, warmth, bitter, and spicy.  Very complex with a long bitter finish.  My only knock is that the alcohol was not as well hidden as I prefer.  The medium to full body is creamy and lively.  The finish feels alcoholic.  Labeled as “Imperial India Pale Ale” this is as near to it’s own style as no other brew I have sampled; definitely in a class all by itself.  I am anxious to try more from the fine brewers at Dogfish Head.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2003 Rerate:  Still the King of IPAs.  Dispite the rediculous hop-load that this beer posesses, it's so perfectly balanced that it doesn't give you bitter-beer face.  This is definately my favorite IPA.
excellent as is all of dogfish head products.
excellent hoppy ale! a big fun time in a bottle!
Cask. Smooth, creamy, and very hopppy. good, yet not as impressive as other IPAs and strong ales i have had.
The best american IPA Ive tried. A beautful showcase for west-coast hops. A good malt balance not found in most American IPAs. Well done. I think the English would really like this stuff.
Bottle.  Amber color with a big foamy tan head.  Powerful floral sweet hop aroma with a foreshadowing of fruits.  Very bitter.  Wonderful aroma throughout.  Malty flavors and dry.

Amber copper, retaining a thin head.  Very nice floral aroma; quite like an English strong ale--interesting to see where the IPA style ultimately leads.  Soft alcohol and very dry flavor.  Smooth, a bit creamy, and gentle bitterness.  But in the end, Im not a hophead, and as much as I drink in these genres, I have yet to rave.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2008 the label of course depicts a hugely unsavory lizard-necked gentleman apparently hammer-pounding a 20 penny nail straight into his sinuses.  why the brewer would choose to regale/repel us with this image in connection with their beer is not explained.  self-torture? a freak show?  the beer however is beautiful, a flowing yeast-studded flaxen pour with a tub of linen white suds, dot-spangled with tattered lace.  nose is buttered hop pollen, both the sap and dry woodiness of pine cones.  quite magnificent, truly.  ’perfume of the gods’ may be hyperbole, but ’armpit of aphrodite’ works for me as a fanciful allusion.  i began to recieve my 9% buzz almost at once: sense of calm and relaxation upfront with mingled notes of moderate euphoria; light cheek-numbing and ruddy blush coupled with heightened wit and cerebral animacy, leading to a lingering glee and richly colored tones of vim conducive to holiday merry-making. (actual results may vary). slo- poke caramel with electrified hops. and whataya know?  it actually took me 90 minutes to drink it!  a great entertainment value, priced today at only $5.99.

Re-rate:  I had this again last night, and I had to up its rating some.  The 3.8 I had previously given it was not justified.  Its just one hell of a satisifying beer.  Plenty of hops, nice malt balance, and a happy amount of alcohol to boot.   9/8/2002  This was a deceiving beer.  At first, it smelled very nice, citrus, flowers, perfume.  The taste, however, was very sweet and malty, I was surprised, thinking of the name.  However, as time elapsed, the beer became much more hoppy and bitter.  I became more and more happy as I drank.  This may have been the 9%, but I know the added hoppiness and bitterness contributed.  I was surprized, but certainly happy with this one.  Enjoy.

Wow, Wow, Wow.  What a great IPA, and the best lable of any brew I have had yet!  Yes the cork is a bastard, but then all that fighting makes you thirsty!  Now, about the beer, this has one of the thickest heads that I have ever had, the liquid is orange brown in color, smell of strong hops, taste of hops and strong malt.  There isnt a over the top hop burn, which in my mind in a good thing.  My only complaint is that it tastes slightly metallic.  This is probably the best IPA I have had. Re-Rate 8/17:  I must have had a dirty glass, no more metallic taste with the next 2 bottles, this is the best American made beer I have ever had. Update 12/21:  No longer my favorite American beer but still my favorite IPA

Dogfish Head, do I need to say more?  After trying this wonderful, flavorful and floral brew I needed more.  The round trip of three hundred miles was worth it to stock up.  A truly great beer.  Think Ill chew another.

Clear rusty tan in color, slim foam. A small hint of hops in the smell but not to much at all. The taste is hoppy but is unfortunatley covered by the terrible alcohol taste , like wise it leaves an after taste of alcohol. IMHO not a great brew, not at all.
This is THE beer for Hopheads. Nice hoppy aroma and flavor

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2003 The bottle is 1 pint 9.6oz. of big beery goodness. I was expecting it to be more bitter than it was. The barley adds a sweet and playful note that brings balance to the beer. The color is a rich light amber, the head is pale and fluffy. The aroma is likewise sweet, though not in such a way as to overpower the body of the beverage.

I would recommend this highly as a first or second beer of the night. More than two of these and you will lose the complexity and play, though it is certainly palatable enough to drink all evening. If you enjoy a big, hoppy beer, this is an excellent choice.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2004 Aroma features some big malt, with caramel and toast, and even bigger hop, with juicy citrus and spicy pine sap, along with some yeastiness upon warming.  Brilliant golden amber color, hazy, partially opaque with a fading off-white head.  Flavor has some honeyish, caramel malt sweetness just before the hops come crashing in and and bitter everything up.  Cascade grapefruit is prominent but I'm glad they chose Chinook too, it has such a nice, deep, earthy, spicy, piney herbal character, it's really becoming one of my favorite hop flavors.  Finish sees a bit of yeastiness and spice before the weighty but graceful hop and malt flavors are inextricably mingled and a bit of lightly warming alcohol starts to show.  Definitely full-bodied yet very drinkable; the balance is simply superb.  Note: this rating is for 2002 750ml version of this beer, bottle-conditioned and made with Cascade, Columbus and Chinook hops.  My score for the 12oz. version would probably be closer to a 3.9.
An alarm clock for the tounge! Pretty orange/gold color with a nice creamy head.  Overpowering hops with  a citrus overlay, an excellent mixture.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2003 Hazy dark golden in color, with a variety-size of bubbles comprising the head. Orange aroma with a backing of grapefruit and some nice malts. Behind all the hops I found some lightly toasted marshmallows, apple blossoms, vinousness, and a hint of bubblegum. Surprising body (medium-full) for such a light colored beer. Bitterness is not overpowering at first, however it quickly becomes overdone as it lingers on the back of your tongue like bad medicine.

This beer is right up there with Ruination as far as beers with hops that snap your head around go. It only took me 5 minutes to get the damn cork off (I was very close to getting pliers). Throughly orange with a medium thick off-white head and thin but sticky lacing. Aroma is a nice blend of hops and a bouquet of flowers. Flavor is hoppy, buttery, malty and citrusy all at once. Nicely complex and a very good IPA.
I got pretty much what I expected from this one. Figured it to be a hoppy beast and it was. Think if it leaned more to a malt balance that I would enjoy it far more.

This beer wants to grap your tastebuds by the scruff of the neck, shake em up, then take em out back and fight them. This one will get your attention. Very rich mouthfeel that stand up to all those hops. I cant quite put my finger on it, but some about this beer seems like the work of a skilled homebrewer as opposed to a commercial brewer.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2007 12/7/02: good amount of head when initially poured.  hopy smelling.  very light amber in colour.  some lacing.  very hopy to the taste.  good stuff.  6/9/07: The Enamel Animal (draught) at Columbus Ale Fest 07.  ...adding to rating... nice lace - light orange-brown body.  hoppy and de-lish.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2003 750 ml bottle
What a beer to try to put into a category!
A copper body with a thin, tan head.
You can smell the malt with hops, lots of hops. Reminds me of the nose of a good barleywine.
I knew what I was getting into when I poured this beer...90 IBU's. Wish more of the malt stood out in the flavor.
Very smooth on the palate.
No way you can detect the alcohol here with all the hops going on in your mouth.
I've now enjoyed 100% (2) beers that I've tasted from Dogfish. Midas is next from these guys.

Deep orange color, medium head. Aroma is floral and herbal, touch of grapefruit. A big bold malty and hoppy IPA. Very smooth taste. The over malting is balanced by the extreme over hopping. At 9% alcohol and 90 IBU, you would expect this beer to be much harsher and stronger tasting. It is surprising in it mellowness and subtly. Malts have a touch of fruitiness and sweetness to them. Hops are dominant and are floral and slightly spicy. Complex flavors. Thick taste, thick I will be picking hops otta my teeth for a couple of days. Grapefruit flavor intensifies as it warms. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. It took forever, several tools and a corkscrew to get the cork out, but it was worth it.
This is a great IPA!  It is smoother than Victory Hop Devil, even though I love that one too.  The aroma is bright and flowery, as is the flavor.  I will buy it often.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2007 [yea...she aint so good anymore] Wow!  This has the most well-masked 9% ABV Ive ever tasted.  Pours with a nice white head that shrinks to a pretty lacing.  Fruit and hop aroma, with a buttery sweetness in the flavor, along with hints of caramel, and a decent helping of maltiness.  This ranks up there with Victory Hop Devil as the best IPAs Ive ever had.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2003 My first US Double IPA/Imperial IPA/American Strong Ale, or whatever you want to call it. Very nice, very bitter and hoppy, really gently sticky, but not unpleasantly so at all. Citric grapfruity bitterness. I really dug this stuff.

Bottle conditioned. Copper orange with an excellent rocky head and plenty of lace. Good level of condition from a seemingly tiny amount of yeast in the bottle. Enticing aromas of malt, chocolate and big blast of hops. Complex blend of grapefruit, malt and orange balanced perfectly with immense hop flavour that becomes bitter in the finish without ever becoming obtrusive. Supremely well balanced and drinkable despite the strength, which is only apparent when you decide to stand up and you head starts spinning a little. The embodiment of Umami.

750 ml bottle, about a year old I believe. Great golden color, almost no head; no "pop" on opening either which surprised me.  Aroma is initially just super hoppy/fruity, with orange being dominant to my senses, but as you dig deeper you get some nice caramel and pine also.  Flavor is initially closer to a barley wine than an IPA, very sweet and malty, thick and smooth, with apricots and grapefruit and oranges swirling in your mouth; gradually a piney hoppiness sets in and burns up the back end, but on leaving the tongue for the throat a pleasant warming sensation replaces the burn.  I for one loved it, not as hoppy as I might have thought, or maybe its just the supreme balance.  Id put it just a notch below 3Fs Dreadnaught, but its in the same league.  Bravo for the American Strong Ales!
Dogfish does another fine job on this IPA.  The taste reminded me of grapefruits tanginess.  Even the aftertaste has it also.  Still an excellent brew with a great color and nice head. ;)

Fragrance not as over powering as I had hoped. Weak fading head. However super tangy and hoppy. Fuzzy floraly taste going down and I can still taste it when I lick my lips. Magnificent IPA! I will definitely get again. Id buy often if it werent so expensive!

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2006 RERATE: Dark orange color, small layer of a hed. Wonderful nose - woody, rosemary. Lively carbonation. Roasemary and sage in the taste. Some cardboard in the finish. Wonderful long lasting bitter grass aftertaste.


Raisons and strong alcohol nose. Orange body. Very bitter / makes you pucker. Nice, enjoyed it a lot. 8/4/8/4/16 -4.0

UPDATED: APR 6, 2003 Tremendous hops in nose and taste.  Enough hops to make it almost thick in the mouth ... wonderful palate.  I love the taste; sweet malt, citrus, but almost entirely hidden under bitter   west coast hoppiness.  Sort of like a wonderfully fresh chicken curry, where at first all you taste is the pain. Removing the cork is more of a barrier to drinking this beer than the price! // rerated 6 April from a different batch.  Still delightful, but a smaller beer in every way.  Less nose, less full in the mouth, less hoppy, less malty.  Still hoppy, still malty, sill yeasty, but no longer dances head and shoulders above all other IPAs.
Tremendous hops...almost biting on the palate; wonderful!

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 overripe cherry in color with a head bigger than george W. bush..aroma was carmel malt accompanied by older, more mature hops...By the time I was ready to take a sip, the head had settled sharp, spiked and dangerous...Malty alcoholness is your maitre"d who tells you that the hops will be with you in a minute (or maybe 90)..as you wait, the carmel maltiness crawls around your tongue and creeps into every crevice... suddenly a walking & talking flowery hop bud walks up to you and backhands you in the face...such a smack stings you for an eternity...This resembles a barleywine more than IPA...IMO of course...but that is by no means a bad thing..Re-Rate 1/12/02:  aged a bit..this monster is the equivalent to a hoppy barley wine with its deep carmel cream and hoppy backing leaving you lifeless..upin sometin fierce..

A massive IPA.  Pours hazy orange, with a decent head that quickly fades.  Aroma is malty, cirtus, and pine.  Initial taste is slightly sweet, then the hops kick in - lots of citrus and pine flavor in there.  The joyous flavor lingers on for a while, too.

This is a great IPA, tastes like an Imperial IPA.  The hops are thick and flavorful all the way through.  The flavor lingers in your mouth with the hopped maltiness sticking to your tongue.  Slight alcohol flavor mixed in underneath the bitterness.  This beer is pure IPA and it does not let you forget it for one second!

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2003 Started off with a nice big head and fruity aroma.  At first, each sip is thick and sweet and ......whoah, here comes the hops, strong, piney, warming, lightly burning, sticky....the sweetness fades, but the thickness remains... A more "traditional" styled IPA, similar, but brighter than, Stoudts.  This is some good hop juice!
no head, amber color, lots of citrus/pine hops up front clean finish.

My own personal "quest" for finding 90 Minute IPA was just as great as the beer.  For some time, I was not able to find this beer, and then when a case became available, it was scoffed up before I could buy it.  Ok, now finally to the beer.  I picked up the crazy labeled beer yesterday at my favorite restaurant, Coopers and popped the cork.  Immediately, I was hit with a huge hop aroma.  The beer poured a very deep gold color and was somewhat hazy.  The half inch egg white head lasted and laced the whole way down the glass.  The tasted was hoppy, of course, but as it warmed, a nice maltiness became apparent to balance the taste.  It also finished very creamy as my mouth became accustomed to the hops.  This is a amazing beer and well deserving of a perfect score.  I know that many of you hate to give perfect score, but I think that can be justified for a beer that is just as great to drink as it was hard to find.
Kick-ass IPA. Clears out your mouth, nasal paassages, etc. A good beer for after dinner. Super assertive but well-balanced for the ABV.

I shared a bottle of this with my buddy a few months back to sort of celebrate the end of work for the summer.  So when I came across a bottle out here in CO I picked it up to save it for a worthwhile event.  Unfortunately, it wasnt as happy as the last one, but I figure the best way to start a night of drinking after a break-up is with a good bottle of brew.  Hoppy aroma, not surprisingly.  Lasting creamy head.  Golden amber in color.  A hoppy blast from start to finish.  Not nearly as bitter as Id expect given the amount of hops.  This is one my very favorites.  Oh, and its not very apparent that this beer is 9%, well concealed.
I love this brew!  Wonderful balance between the malt and hops.  Every time Im at the store I grab two of these, I just have to!
Nice rich frothy head atop a great copper colored ale.  Huge hops up front, good citrus in the middle and more hops on the finish.  Well worth the $!

Golden orange copper color, lasting creamy white head.   Fresh spring-like aroma.   Hops hit you right from the start and stay till the finish and beyond.   Alcohol is well hidden in the taste.   Good stuff!

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2003 It's got a nice aroma, I can really smell the hops.  It has great  balanced between hops and malt.  It has a sweet taste, with not much finish.  Very good IPA overall, but being a hops head a little more hops would have been fine with me.

So weve had a tradition since Ive been at Notre Dame (and its been around before me) called 40s at 4.  Its pretty self explanatory...everyone gets together and drinks a 40 oz at 4 oclock on Friday afternoon.  Its a nice way to relax from a hectic week, and start your buzz for the weekend.  Well Ive had my share of Colt 45s and Mickeys, but a few weeks ago, while my friends were pounding OE 400, I had a bottle of this instead.  This has recently become available locally, so I think Im gonna make it 90 minutes at 4, though it definitely wont take me that long to finish it.  Very much like a barley wine in mouthfeel and alcohol, I love the burning, resinous hoppyness, and the faint, fruity malt.

Light orangey amber with a light, full, stiff almost meringue like head - long last with heavy lacing.  Surprisingly weak aroma!  Some hints at grapefruit only, with a little caramel malt - yes I could actually smell malt!  Flavor is very well balanced.  Hops dominate of course, but theres a full creamy malty body.  The hop flavors are citrusy, the malt is caramelly with a little hint a light fruitiness, esp as the beer warms up to 60 deg F.  Firm, bitter finish.  Very creamy.
Hoppyness is less sharp than in some IPAs.  Very smooth drinking for 9% abv.

I am going to disagree with Josh here. I love this stuff. Again I have gone up the ladder with this brewery. I loved the bitterness in the finish. Excellant IPA, loaded with well balanced over hopping. A bit more viscous than most of the IPAs about. I am going to put this up for at least 18 months and see!!

Another excellent Dogfish concoction.  Consists of somewhat sweet & malty tones that are nicely balanced.  The brew is accentuated by a wonderful hopped finish.  The impressive hoppy character makes your mouth tingle & wanting more.

Rated 7/12/02 (4.1): Wow, this is one hoppy brew. The taste is suggestive of a Bitter with a strong IPA presence. The sweet undertones compliment the hopped body excellently. The finish is strong, dry and accented with malt. This being my first experience with Dogfish, I definitely look forward to trying more from this brewer.

PS: The cork on this beer kicked my arse. Took me 5 minutes just to get the damned thing off.

**Re-Rate: Okay, I had to come back and re-rate this stuff. Honestly, the more I drink 90min IPA the more I like it. Im to the point now that every time I go to the store to try some new beverages, I end up buying a couple bottles of this sweet nectar of life. Its seriously starting to cut into my RateBeer time. Curse the demons at Dogfish for tempting me with their witchs brew. If this keeps up, I may need to seek rehabilitation.**

deep golden/copper color, thin head, mostly lasting. aroma is slightly citrusy with floral notes dominant. flavor is initially sweet fading into a wonderful hoppy bitter finish. slightly astringent and dry. more malt presence than Ruination, but somewhat less than Stone IPA and Hop Devil...outstanding IPA...excellent choice for #400!
an IPA that drinks like a barleywine, my only complaint is that the cork got soaked in my cooler and snapped off at the top, luckily maria brought a corkscrew

Ruby-orange hue.  Caramel fruity nose; apricots, lemon, pine needles.  Clean white gracious head.  Starts sweet, medium to full bodied, finishes long and deep, tons of bitter.  Giant hops, supported by a caramel malt backbone.  Alcohol is completely hidden, Dogfish is the shiz.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2003 Another update:  Fine.  But I keep buying this.  I like it, obviously, and must increase the overall rating.  
Update:  Sampled recently in the 12 oz bottle, I found this even more complex--the hop flavor is really incredible.  Lots of herbal and woody notes (not unlike the 60 minute) but a bit more citrus than the 60.  Terribly good.  But I cannot justify rating this higher than Bell's Two Hearted Ale.  Nevertheless, I can certainly understand that many would prefer this one to Bells (or 3 Floyds or Rogue, for that matter).  I'm not one of them.
Old:  Remarkable.  Tremendous hop content somehow actually balanced with fantastic malt.  So damned complex.  Very nice.

great IPA. 
huge  floral hops yet retains a easy drinking malt:hop balance
A nice smooth beer.  Average appearance, lightly pleasing aroma that was kind of flowery.  Its taste was clear, clean, and wonderful.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2006 (First few batches): Emperor RazorHop and his troops of grassy caramel blades happily invade forlorn and welcoming palates with their glittering flowery canons of glory...Biscuity malt shields shine brightly under the growling hoppiness and honeyed oranges...A triumphant citrusy smoke heads the one-sided war as the hop-starved do not need to worry anymore...Bizarrely enough, the malty sweetness gets tiring after a pint and recalls the sugary proficiency of the 120 Minute...

A more recent version (about 1-year old keg) produced more cereal sweetness than any sort of hoppiness...Luxurious maltiness yes, but barely any sign of its Double IPA heritage...Honeyed fruitiness was rampant, and citrusy hops a mere afterthought in the background...Still a great sipper, but nowhere as talkative as the first versions were...

Wonderful aroma  reminiscent of tropical fruit(pineapple?). Big mouthfeel, very lively. This is a nicely balanced beer. Was a little worried this would be another over the top hop monster but they did an excellent job on this one.Almost forgot to thank jayme_9874 for this one.

Wonderful aroma, nice finish with a grassy aftertaste.  Just
what an IPA is supposed to taste like.
Yep, lots of hops but not overly done.  Nice aroma, good flavor.  Only had on draft at the pub in DE.  Need to try again and re-rate to be fair.
I am not man enough for this beer.  Tastes like hopahol to me.

Hops, sugar and citrus aroma. Orange/red colour, a big creamy vanilla head. With a never ending stream of bubbles. Hoppy to the max, citrus is so strong, its like eating orange peel! Malts are present as well. Strong like orange brandy. Bitterness with some sweetness. Fabulous bitter aftertaste. Very dry finish. Sensational! Thanks Volgon.

No problems with the cork here - just pulled it straight out.  Bitterness is even perceivable in aroma.  Copper colored, pours with a loose head with a creamy top.  Head lasts for at least 5 minutes.  Well carbonated.  Hints of grapefruit in the nose.  Very clean tasting.
Mmm.  Hoppy.  Yet with an interesting aftertaste/tongue feel.  The bitterness was quickly overtaken by a milder soothing taste.  Bravo.

True amber color, catches the light and seems to glow. Nice foamy off-white head builds easily  and has good renention. Actually never got below a centimeter in thickness.. Surprising lack of hop aroma for such a high IBU.  Seems to be lacking in hop flavor as well. Have I really gotten this used to hop bitterness or has this bottle been aged long enough that the hops arent as much a part of the mix anymore? Ill find out tomorrow when I revisit the Arrogant Bastard. Has a flavor (from the yeast perhaps?) that I picked up in World Wide Stout and Raison Detre. Its similar (vaguely) to some of the flavors I associate with Belgian yeast. As it warmed, I picked up more hops, mostly pine-like but some citric qualities, but never as much as I would expect from a beer that advertised its IBU.
Thick creamy head, nice lacing. Super hoppy. Very good IPA.

Like drinking scotch or some other highly flavorful, powerful, strong liqueur.  Its pure hops, of course, but complex in its hoppiness.  It has bite, bark, bite, then bitter.  Its wonderful and unusual and pretty near indescribable.

This beer had a head that lasted as long as it took me to remove the cork!  Nice lace too.  Even though it took so long to remove the cork, it was worth it!  Unbelievable is all I can say.  This beer poured a beautiful copper orange color and had a strong smell of citrusy hops.  The taste was out of this world...by far the BEST IPA I have ever had.  This is one of the hoppiest beers I have tasted.  It makes Sierra Nevadas Celebration Ale and Victorys Hop Devil look like pale ales in comparison.  I love this beer and thus it gets a top rating.  (Disclaimer: I am partial to hops.)

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 Nose is very citrusy Pour is a creamy brown frothy head.  Color is amber/brown.  Wonderfully heavy hopped flavor that is balanced with a very generous amount of malt.  This is a hop heads dream.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2007 (Re-rate, 750 ml version) )Clear orange/amber. Persistent but impotent sticky head. Nose is all piney, citrusy and floral hops along with a very well defined malt. Wow..this is damn good. Is it hoppy? Does a bear shit in the woods? Of course. The hops are insane but i think it maintains a good balance with the malt. The amount of malt seems to give it am almost sweet bubblegum flavor, i also get a touch of honey as well. You can actually feel the hop oils within the body of the beer which is on the thick side. The alcohol in this just adds another dimension, the yeast adds character and the hops in the finish numb your lips...oustanding IPA.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2004 Huge creamy head on a hazy orange, super hoppy smelling beer.  I'm not sure if the amount of hops or the fact the malt keeps up is more amazing.  The 9% ABV is unnoticeable except in the stomach and may be its biggest flaw.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2004 Very excellent IPA, cloudy dark copper color, kept a very nice head out of the bottle that I had with a cork, tasted as close to out of the tap as humanly possible, very much full bodied, very hoppy taste, just a hint of orangy & citrus flavor, very very spicy aftertaste, you could drink eight glasses of water & still not gotten the taste out of your mouth, just a wonderful IPA, very very excellent, rates right up there (in my mind) with Stoudt's IPA, very much worth the expense and/or the trip, awesome beer

I have never met a such a hoppy beer with such little hoppy aroma.  I kept trying to smell and take in a nice hoppy aroma, but it just never happened, not even when warm.  I agree there is a very nice underlying maltiness to this beer.  Hops are nice, but it really lacks that synergystic quality that would take it to the upper echelon of IPAs in my book.  An entertaining beer and much respect for the Joel-Peter Witkin photograph, good beer but not deserving of a 4+ rating.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2007 Hops hops hops, yes, but User_Ex has it right to my mind: The malt is also huge! Honey and fruit, as he says, but also way way down is that doughiness. This thing is really incredible. Not my favorite IPA, but one of the most packed beers in recent memory...since my last Bear Republic beverage, I believe.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Very well done.  I was not expecting such a smooth beer.  A great amber color and a nice head.  Alcohol is warming, and there is an appropriate balance between malt and hops.
Too much alcohol and hops, tastes like hop vomit.

I had this beer at a  Beer festival in the Poconos this past year.  This was a step up from their 60-minute IPA Dogfish Head head the year before. The hoppier the better.  Thanks for producing a great beer and I cant wait to see these guys in Boston.

Cloudy orange, with minimal head.  Smooth hoppy hoppy aroma -- rich potential.  Much stronger flavor -- big bang, so one-dimensional its not funny.  Almost pulls it off but suffers for that imbalance.  Still a good beer but misses greatness.
I believe that here they went over with amount of hops. Aroma was actually quiet nice (peachy alcohol etc).

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2004 7-19-02 Damn, I thought I would have to call the Crocodile hunter to wrestle this cork from the bottle, get a cork screw, nothing else will do.Very hoppy, nice and bitter and very complex.Loads of flavors here I'd recommend this one, reminds me of my buddy Tim Totty's famous Tennessee homebrew. Good value! Re-Rate IPA's are the One. 12 Oz. bottles out now, I will call this Dreadnaught's little brother, citrus, complex, sweet , so much better than corked bottles,Ok someone trade me for the 120, Highly Recommended !
Deep oragne color with a subtle cascade hoppy nose.  Predominantly bitter flavors with a hint of citrus, well balanced by the malts.

I could smell this one two houses over.  Great long lasting thick head.  Smells of fresh citrus fruits.  An amazing blend of hops, complex and subtle.  Theres a good balance here.  Thick, sweet feel.  An IPA to travel aroud the world.

Redbrown. Cascade, toffee, merengue and butter in the nose.
Bittersweet flavor with lots of hops.
Hey, not bad! Good hop flavor with good malt balance. Wont make anyone change their religion, but this is a good IPA.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2003 750 ml bottle, no problem removing the cork, pours cloudy light copper color, aroma of pine and citrus hops and hops and more hops, very malty to balance the loads of hops, not bad, you have to be a real hophead for this one, left my mouth and lips numb.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2008 12oz bottle. Head is initially small, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is clear medium amber. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie, toasted grain), moderately hoppy (resin, grapefruit), lightly yeasty (dough), with notes of perfume, gum, and alcohol. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter. Medium to full body, syrupy texture, lively/soft carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Its pretty ordinary now, though it was admittedly pretty nice 5 years ago when they still bottle-conditioned it.  All the nuances are gone, so its just another resin-grapefruit bomb now. Sad.  Very syrupy/sticky mouthfeel without much carbo to help, so its difficult to drink much.  The kitchen sink is here, but "all that" is missing.

Burnt orange color; Head was huge and dense and fluffy; Pine and floral in the nose. Interesting sweetness right at the start. Amazingly unabrasive. Great dryness on the sides- sweetness still prevades at 1/2 mark. A fun beer to drink.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2009 Cork impossible to remove. Every scent possible from a hop emerging from the bottle. It pours a delicate looking hazy orange color which has a pretty inch thick head foating on it. Aromas of of pine,an entire fruit platter,and some bubblegum aromas.HUGE,CHEWY,taste filled with hops but pretty well balanced by a huge malt profile.I couldnt see this losing much flavor any time soon.For 5 dollars a bottle, it doesnt get any better. 

12oz:Much more raw than the big bottle. More potent hop aroma,and overall,hop,taste. The malt arent as pronounced as the big bottles,but I might just like them even more.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2006 Mega-IPA. Super fresh hop nose. I feel like I am walking in a pine forest. Beautiful tan head that is leaving a great deal of lace behind. The palate is very fruity, malty, and hoppy. The malt is very extracted. Dry finish with a load of hops. Cascade burps. Very nice. What makes this different from a barley wine is the beers dryness. Fermented as far as possible.

Although IPA is not my favorite style, this is a good beer.  The 9% ABV is so well hidden that no alcohol is present in the taste or nose.  Great looking beer in my Ravenhead mug. Damn cork was stuck and broke in half, leaving me with a mess to get out of the bottle. Oh yeah, its hoppy...
The energizer bunny tore through this IPA and delivered a ton of hops.  Go get some.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2007 Bottle... This beer rocks!... Lovely amber/orange ale. Creamy, white head.
The aroma is of caramel, pineapple, evergreen and citrus fruit. The flavor is well-balanced by a very big malt profile. Bitter and piney with notes of grapefruit and pineapple. Full-bodied, fatty and chewy with a syrupy mouthfeel. Fizzy carbonation. Long, bitter, grassy finish.
Great Beer!

Just came across this at the local store. I am an English Bitter fan, and this beer bowled me over with quality. Lots of hops, but not the kind that constricts the back of the throat, but the kind that refreshes your soul. Lots of body and remarkably smooth for 9%. Drink it in a hot attic while writing poetry! Its good to see that I am not the only one who had a $*!@ of a time getting the cork out. I will pursue other Dogfish brews!

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2013 I dont know if this beer has changed or I have. This is no 4.3? Pillowy head of foam. Not the last couple of times. Very sweet, in aroma and taste. Melon and light caramels, with citrus and floral companions. Honey and biscuit. Bitterness and sweet balance falls squarely into the sweet. Sugar affecting mouthfeel. Fine foam. Medium effervescence.
a hop fiends delight.  This beer is high octane and hopped to the max.  A new classic.
I must be a hophead.
Man what an IPA. Suprizingly smooth for 9% alcohol. The hops hit nicely with a littl malt finish.Definately an Imperial IPA.
I was fortunate to try this beer on draft.   The wall of hops bitterness prop up the heavy alcohol flavor of this beer.   Sam is the Man

Dogfish does it again. Big hops nose. Big head atop gold amber beer. Lightly carbed, oily. Hoppy, very hoppy but well balanced with malt. Bitter after but crisp and refreshing. I think Im becoming a hop head.
UPDATED: NOV 3, 2007 This is a great IIPA -Very hoppy both in aroma and taste, but also very clean tasting.

My favorite IPA had to date.  Very fresh, piney, spicy flavor.  Some citrus qualities, but very subtle. Heavy and thick mouth feel.  Copper color and quite cloudy (reminds me my my own brews).  Smallish head, maybe I didnt do a good job pouring, and I did have a little trouble uncorking.

About 10 months ago a friend asked me if I could brew him a Imperial IPA(his love for high gravity and hops is legendary). I hadnt really ever heard of the style,but since researching it and now finding this monster of an IPA I now ahve to say this a whole category onto its own.I love stout,but when I think back, I relaize I hadnt had stout until I had a Russian Imperial, now I know, I hadnt had I.P.A. until I had 90 Minute!!

Unusual hop-fest from Dogfish.  Feeling threatened by Stones Russian Imperial, the Dogfish folks in Rehoboth, DE, squeezed the juice of 1,000 hops directly into a bottle.  The whole room smelled like hops for awhile.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2014 Big frothy white head, very interesting aroma, and oh-my-g-d that is fricken hoppy! This is the most hoppy beer I have ever had! Crisp, hoppy, and not to malty, fruity, or thick like some other IPAs ive been disapointed in. This is probably the best IPA ive ever had, and 9%abv....wow? Fantastic beer, one of my favorites! Orig rate 5/11/02..4.8. Very clear amber. Caramel, piney, resiny hop aroma. Hop bitterness is highly assertive,  but balance evenly with malt caramel. Body is medium full, with an almost creamy mouthfeel. Carbonation is high. Leads into spicy herbal quality, caramel, and hop flavor. Excellent balanced hop flavored yet malty brew.
If you are a hophead, you will love this beer.  First they made an IPA, then they added a few more hundred pounds of hops.

Wow - this really floored me...almost literally!  Hops are prominent, but with the deep malt character, dont knock you over like a standard IPA.  Bitterness hits at the end. Nice rounded mouthfeel.  These Dogfish guys really know how to brew!

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2009 re rate:  cask sample- hop rind and piney taste with wonderful malt structure, compared to the bottled forum; complex.  Heavy mouthfeel in the beginning takes away from the balance, hops, overpowered with little balance.  Just a beautiful glowing amber color with large bubbled head that has little staying power or stick.  Yeasty, bubble gum, citric, floral nose.  Hits the mouth heavily initially, then finishes bitter and hop tingy.  I must say, it is much better at around 60-65 degrees F.  I will age the others for a few years as this beers flavors need to marry a bit more.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Liquid hops.  If you like IPAs, youve gotta at least try this one.  Pricey beer, but I doubt too many people can finish it by themselves.  Aroma leaves a little to be desired but WOW, your taste buds will sing!  Dont try to drink anything for a while after this because you wont  be able to taste it.

A bit out of balance but there is plenty of malt.  So an IPA with a attitude- thats saying something.  Hops hit you from the time you open the bottle.  Malt sweetness and the lingering alcohol join in during the tasting.

Reddish amber. Flowery, citrusy nose. Full bodied, seet, slightly syrupy mouthfeel, and a late bitterness that just keeps growing. Despite its bizarre hop rate it somehow manages to remind somewhat balanced. As usual a very interesting brew from Dogfish Head.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2004 Mad, mad hops. The hops is evident in the nose from arms length. The taste is out of this world. I actually expected it to be too hoppy (if possible) but it was almost balanced out (but not quite.) I had a big corked bottle all to myself and wont ever do such a thing again. I will, however, get another bottle, put it away for a while (as suggested) and share it with a friend in a few months. Go try this with a friend!  Whoa! This recipe changed! While it is still an amazing IPA, this isnt the knock-me-down monster that it was when it had the label with the circus freak hammering the nail into his nose. This is disheartening, but still damn better than most!

Big beer but not really an IPA.  The high alcohol content brings this into the range of a barley wine (although it is not a barley wine).  Nice rocky head that lasts over ten minutes.  Very high IBU (90 per label) but balanced nicely by the malt.  Believe it or not, I think it could use more hops.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2003 ORIGINAL (12-4-01): This is a love it or hate it beer and I understand why.  This beer is THE absolute hop monster!  The floral, sour apple and grapefruit aromas are overwhelmingly strong and pleasant.  They translate well into the flavor profile.  There is orange peel, grapefruit and a certain fruity sweetness I couldn't quite put my finger on.  These are complimented with some oak and an intensely dry middle and finish.  The only detraction in the flavor is the presence of alcohol, which is clearly evident.  You know it's bitter at 90 IBUs.  The head on this beer is large, off-white and creamy with moderate staying power. The color is cloudy copper to bronze and is beautiful combined with the head.  This beer also has tremendous body and sits heavily on the tongue.  Very viscous.  This is a tremendously hoppy brew throughout, and I love it.  DFH has done it again and I'm going back to the store to buy 2 more bottles to age!  UPDATE (4-8-02):  After aging in my 'cellar' (beer closet) for 4 months, this is a significantly different beer.  The hops, as expected, have mellowed considerably.  Don't get me wrong - they're still bold, but they're no longer completely overpowering and mouth puckering.  The bready and toffeeish malts have shown their presence and the alcohol flavor has run away and hidden.  Reminiscent of a West Coast IPA after 4 months of aging.  Still full bodied and heavy, but it's a more balanced product now.  For those of you who criticized this as overly hoppy, I'd suggest laying it down for several months.  You'll be happy with the results.  UPDATE: (7-25-03)  From the handpump.  Good lord this is amazing stuff.  Hops are softened by the handpump and the beer seems more mellow and creamy.  Still has a nice hop bite and is fairly dry, but it almost seems tame.  Not a hint of alcohol in the aroma or flavor.  Just fantastic.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2004 I have found my favorite IPA. What a work of art by this extremely creative brewery, one of the finest in the land. This beer pours thick while the powerful smell of the hops overpowers the room. A monumental amount of hops, 90 IBU, and a huge portion of malt balnce to form a beer that defies all presumptions. When is somebody going to interview the brewmaster? 
re-rate: Yeah it's still really good but lacking in some serious bitterness.
High Class stuff. Not my style, cause Im not into bitter ales, but its a very smooth bitter high class ale that got me feeling real good in short order.
Ho-Lay Cow!  Hoppy.  Smells like hoppy cider, tastes like hoppy hoppy.
Extremely hoppy. Intial malt sweetness quickly gives way to to the hops. Nice.

First of all, the label on this beer is wicked - a photo of a
guy driving a nail in his nose. Fresh hops all around here:
in the nose and in the taste. Big bitter taste, as well it 
should with 90 IBUs. A strong alcohol intensifies an already
powerful flavor. Over the top but delicious. Wow.
An IIPA. Very smooth. Some hops and alcohol flavor but not much else. A sold effort but not outstanding. NOTE most of my ratings today are from Real Ale Fest so the appearance was from cask.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2015  Amazing on the nose, floral and citrusy, very aromatic. Complex body of banana and citrus, fruitcake and understated caramel notes. Lots of alcohol here, but it is well balanced by a huge hop backbone through the long finish. Creamy texture for such a hoppy brew, and perhaps the best balance of toffee malt and citrus of any DIPA out there.

Not something youd want to drink everyday.  This is a very interesting beer, and a must-try for those who like their beers big and hoppy.  I picked up three bottles when DFH first released it.  Tried one right off the bat and it was quite a wallop.  Opened a second one about 6 months later and the marriage of flavors had just started to take hold.  Ill crack the third after a year or so just to see how it goes.  As with most beers, this one tastes better on-tap.

Pours a big creamy smooth beige head, sheets of lace, and a cloudy orange color. Nose is floral, spicy, citrus and maybe a tad of yeast showing through. Malt sweet start, full top, the finish dry, slightly acidic, moderate carbonation and a nice hop bite. A bazillion tiny bottles, creeping up the glass with the second pour, interesting beer, and I feel quite complex, but quite quaffable. Thanks JCA
Good beer. I tasted a little too much alcohol for beer.

A truly hoppy concoction: strong, floral, citrusy hops, and a ton of bitterness. Some sweet taste once you get past the hops, even a hint of something like strawberries, but its hard to find under all those hops.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2007 Big and impressive!   The visual presentation was a light amber topped by a soft, whispy white head.   The aroma was a blended concoction of sour grapefruit and big floral, grassy hop notes.  I found the mouthfeel to be rather smooth, full, and round.    The hops dominated the flavor profile, in addition to malt sweetness and strong alcohol tastes.  90 Minute IPA finished with a strong, sustained bitter and some alcohol warmth with a hint of mint.   It was worth a try but I cant see myself shelling out for it again.

Pale Ale color, foamy.  Very nice Pale Ale nose.  Extremely dry hoppy/bitter taste, too dry, really.  I guess Im learning about the contribution of American hops as an element towards imbalance in a quest for galumptuous taste.  Its similar to drinking an overoaked wine lacking basic fruit.  Too bad, though, it sure beats Coors light!

Amber, brilliant colour; florals, herbs, caramelly nose; body is full of woody bitterness; big flavour with citrus, cascade.  The bitterness really comes on strong late in this beer, detracting from the overall balance and coating the mouth.  I wanted to see a more expressive nose and less bitterness in the finish.

Cloudy, light golden color.  Floral, supermarket aroma.  Huge hops, woody. I couldnt decide if I liked this or not.  Might be good with something really spicy, but really over hopped, but I think that is what they are aiming for.

Massive, massive hops in this one.  Just MASSIVE.  Definitely some maltiness to back it up, but its so hoppy the bitters dry your mouth right after swallowing.  Forms a thick, luscious head.  Very tasty, though (I never thought Id say this) it may be too hoppy.  Still, a hopheads dream brew in many ways.
